title: "Of every tribe a thousand" - serving G-d being of one heart
content:
# "Of every tribe a thousand" - serving G-d being of one heart ## Frage

In parshas Matos (Bamidbar 31:3-4), we read:

"And Moshe spoke to the people, saying, Arm from yourselves men for the army, and let them go against Midyan and avenge the L-rd on Midyan. Of every tribe a thousand, throughout all the tribes of Yisroel, shall you send to the war".

The Baal HaTurim (ad loc.) observes that this posuk begins with an "alef" and ends with an "alef".

אֶ֚לֶף לַמַּטֶּ֔ה אֶ֖לֶף לַמַּטֶּ֑ה - תִּשְׁלְח֖וּ לַצָּבָֽא

The Baal HaTurim explains that this means that B'nei Yisroel were all of one heart to their Father in Heaven.

One thousand from each tribe. The verse begins with an aleph and ends with an aleph, which teaches that they were all of one heart to their Father in Heaven.

What exactly does this mean? Are there explanations on what this Baal HaTurim means and how this is important when fighting Hashem's wars?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The verse is talking about new generation who did not stand at mt. Sinai. One could think that Baal haTurim hints that the new generation achieved unity for the war comparable to the one their fathers had when receiving the Torah, as Rashi to Exodus 19:2 quotes Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 19:2:10, כאיש אחד בלב אחד - as one man with one heart. However, the Rashi's comment states, that only at Sinai the encampment of Bnei Yisrael had such kind of unity. In other words the Jewish people were united in their desire to serve Hashem, be a holly nation, which brought their hearts and minds in unison. A similar expression is used when describing the approaching of the pharaoh's army towards bnei Yisrael, see Rashi to Exodus 14:10 quoting Mekhilta d'Rabbi Yishmael 14:10:3: בלב אחד כאיש אחד - with one heart like one man - in reverse order vs. Exodus 19:2. In other words the unity of a heart was built by the thought of revenge against the enemy. Egyptians were seeking revenge against Israelies, and Israelies were seeking revenge against Midianites and in both cases the idea united the people.

The reason why unity when waging war is important is discussed in mishna Sota 8:5 among other places. Any breach of the front line due to any lack of unity can lead to exceedingly large losses. In fact all mishnayot in perek 8 of Sota add good points on the issue of unity.

title: Source for 613 Gates to Emunah
content:
# Source for 613 Gates to Emunah ## Frage

I heard in a shiur that the Zohar says each one of the 613 mitzvos is a gate to Emunah. I would like to find the Zohar to see it myself.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The introduction to the Zohar covers this. It discusses how the first commandment of the Torah is בראשית ברא אלהים, i.e. the commandment of יראת י'י, and the Zohar then states

ודא איהי תרעא לאעלא גו מהימנותא

and this is the gate that leads to Emunah

The Sulam explains

וכפי שיעור היראה כן שיעור השראת האמונה

One's fear of Hashem is the measure of one's Emunah

He then arrives at the conclusion that all of the Mitzvot are gates to Emunah in that every Mitzva is included in this first Mitzva, which he defines as reshit. Fear is the beginning of every Mitzva, and without fear it will not produce Emunah:

היראה היא ראשית ושער לכל מצוה להיותה השער לאמונה

Fear is called reshit, and is the gate to every Mitzva, being the gate to Emunah.

See here also.

The subtle point being made here, I believe (based on what my Rav taught me) is that Hashem is totally beyond us, so it seems impossible that we should be able to have any connection to Him. Hence, He gave us His Mitzvot to connect to Him. Every level of connection we have with Him from performing these Mitzvot is predominantly a connection of Emunah because, as we said, He is totally beyond us, so we cannot grasp Him with our Chochma or Da'at (directly).

title: Commentaries relevant to doubled phrases in Aleinu
content:
# Commentaries relevant to doubled phrases in Aleinu ## Frage

The Aleinu prayer contains many instances of doubled phrases - where the same idea is expressed twice (or two very similar ideas are expressed) with different language. Here are three in the first sentence:

  • לְשַׁבֵּֽחַ לַאֲדוֹן הַכֹּל / לָתֵת גְּדֻלָּה לְיוֹצֵר בְּרֵאשִׁית - to praise the Master of all / to ascribe greatness to the Creator of the [world in the] beginning

  • שֶׁלֺּא עָשָֽׂנוּ כְּגוֹיֵי הָאֲרָצוֹת / וְלֺא שָׂמָֽנוּ כְּמִשְׁפְּחוֹת הָאֲדָמָה - has not made us like the nations of the lands / and has not positioned us like the families of the earth

  • חֶלְקֵֽנוּ כָּהֶם / וְגוֹרָלֵֽנוּ כְּכָל הֲמוֹנָם - our portion like theirs / nor our lot like that of all their multitudes

I am aware that this pattern exists in Tanach as well. I think I've seen it in Tehillim and Mishlei, at least. I realize that it could be interpreted as merely a mechanism for poetic emphasis.

  1. Do any commentaries on Aleinu discuss the use of this pattern there, in particular?

  2. Are there any articles about this pattern in general that could shed light on its use in Aleinu?

  3. Is there a standard term for this pattern in Parshanut literature?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Rav Chaim Kanievsky zatzal authored a commentary on Aleinu, which can be downloaded from this site . I have checked the first of your questions therein.

He maintains that “Master of all” refers to Hashem in His attribute of giving the Torah. (page 21, in Biurim 1) whereas “Creator of the [world in the] beginning” refers to Hashem in His attribute of Creator in the fist 6 days of creation (page 25, in Biurim 6).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

The phenomenon that you describe is a part of a much larger group of patterns called Biblical parallelism. A book by Adele Berlin "The dynamics of Biblical parallelism" is considered a good study.

title: How can the Kabbalistic significance of the 42 masaos (desert stops) be known to other Kabbalists in light of it having been unknown to Ramban?
content:
# How can the Kabbalistic significance of the 42 masaos (desert stops) be known to other Kabbalists in light of it having been unknown to Ramban? ## Frage

Malbim writes (Bamidbar 33:5) that the Kabbalists say that the 42 stops of Bamidbar 33 correspond to the 42 letter name of HaShem (והמקובלים כתבו שמ״ב מסעות אלה היו מכוונים נגד שם של מ״ב.), see there at length.

Otoh, Ramban (ibid:1), after citing Rashi and Rambam's reasons for spelling out these stops, writes as follows:

והנה מכתב המסעים מצות השם היא מן הטעמים הנזכרים או מזולתם ענין לא נתגלה לנו סודו

Thus the writing down [the stages of] the journeyings was a commandment of G-d, either for the reasons mentioned above or for some other reasons, [for] a purpose the secret of which has not been revealed to us.

Ramban was one of the foremost Kabbalists of his day if not the most eminent of them all.

Kabbalah connotes received knowledge that is passed down from generation to generation.

How is it possible that something that Ramban was unaware of should be known to other (and presumably later) Kabbalists (cf אפשר אם משה לא ידע אלעזר יודע)?

(Are there multiple schools of this esoteric oral tradition one of which bypassed Ramban? Are there "kabbalistic" chiddushim [innovative explanations] that don't require being passed down?)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Many later Kabbalists learned directly from אליהו הנביא including the אריזל

So presumably אליהו didnt teach it yet

title: What commandments did Reuben and Gad break?
content:
# What commandments did Reuben and Gad break? ## Frage

The Sources criticize the tribes of Reuben and Gad for two things: Not settling in the Land of Israel and placing their cattle above their children. [Midrash Tanhuma, Matot, Siman 7; Numbers Rabbah 22:9; Proverbs 20:21] They were punished by being the first of the Ten Tribes to be exiled.

1-They did not settle in the Land of Israel because the land east of the Jordan was better for their cattle. They got permission from Moses, in exchange for fighting with the other tribes in the frontline, which they did for seven years. Whether or not a Jew is commanded to live in the Land of Israel is still a matter of dispute. Naḥmanides says yes and Maimonides says no, according to the lists of 613 they left us. Both sages acted on their beliefs. When Maimonides was forced out of Muslim Spain, he lived only very briefly in Israel, then moved to Egypt, did all his work there and died there. When Naḥmanides was forced out of Catalonia, he went directly to Israel, and worked and died there.

2-They said: "We will build here enclosures for our flocks and towns for our children." [Numbers 32:16], and Moses gently rebuked them by reversing the order: "Build towns for your children and enclosures for your flocks". [Numbers 32:20,24] But there is no commandment to build dwellings for your children before you build enclosures for your cattle. And they never said they were going to start with the cattle pens, they only mentioned them first to emphasize that they were settling there because of their cattle.

So what commandments did Reuben and Gad break?

One could argue that the Torah says: "Be sure to keep the commandments… Do what is right and good in the sight of God." [Deut. 6:17-18] The Talmud says the repetition means that you must sometimes go beyond what is strictly commanded. Perhaps Reuben and Gad did not do that. But it's a very subjective matter.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The way the question is stated - is somewhat misleading. Bnei Reuven and bnei Gad were not exiled after they chose to live east of Jordan. However, their choice to be separate from other tribes created a number of problems, which resulted in sins, caused the decline of their society, and perhaps resulted in early exile many years later since they were also the first frontier of defense against Ammon, Moav, Edom, and Aram.

There is a comment of Tur, haAroch on Bereshit 30:11,

ותאמר לאה בגד. י"מ על שם שבני גד היו ראשונים שבגדו לקחת נחלה בארץ ישראל כדכתיב ויגשו בני גד ובני ראובן. Blockquote The meaning of the root בגד - betray. There are comments that bnei Reuven and bnei Gad were first to betray (joint tribal acquisition of Eretz Israel)

Sefer Yehoshua 22 describes a bigger problem, which resulted from settlement of Bnei Gad and Bnei Reuven east of Jordan. They realized that their descendants may not want to go to Shilo for festivals and have connection with other tribes. They started building an altar as a reminder of tribal connection west of Jordan. The building almost sparked the tribal war averted by Pinchas.

Finally, the mussar seforim state that absence of fathers east of Jordan river during the time of conquest negatively affected the children, so that they grew up being more cruel to others. The accidental killings east of Jordan were more frequent than in Eretz Israel, which had a higher population density. Rashi on Bamidbar 35:14.

In other words, one may make a halakhically acceptable decision which may, neverthelss, yield bad and difficult consequences. Bnei Reuven and Bnei Gad did not violate halakha, but their decision had bad consequences.

title: Widow of a Cohen allowed to eat truma?
content:
# Widow of a Cohen allowed to eat truma? ## Frage

Does the widow of a Cohen keep the right to eat terumah if they had a child (Cohen) together?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

The answer is yes, but complicated, as Mishnyos Yebamos 7:5-6 explain if a child survives or has surviving offspring (her grandson or granddaughter until she remarries), and also the widow did not remarry a non-cohen or did not become pregnant from a non-cohen. Gemara Yebamos 69b also brings baraisa, that only if the Cohen gives a woman a bill of divorce 1 hour before death she is prohibited to partake of teruma immediately.

To give a definite answer, one should study either perek 7 of Mishna, perek 7 of Gemara Yebamos, or as suggested in the comments Rambam Terumot (Heave Offerings) perek 8

title: Names of cities given by Onkelos east of Jordan
content:
# Names of cities given by Onkelos east of Jordan ## Frage

There seem to be several changes that Targum Onkelos makes when giving names of the 9 cities east of Jordan.

  1. The city Atarot. Bamidbar 32:3: מכללתא; Bamidbar 32:35: עטרות

  2. The city Dibon. Bamidbar 32:3: מלבשתא; Bamidbar 32:34: דיבון

  3. The city Jazer. Bamidbar 32:3: כומרין; Bamidbar 32:35: יעזר.

  4. The city Nimra. Bamidbar 32:3: בית נימרין; Bamidbar 32:36 בית נימרה

  5. The city of Heshbon. Bamidbar 32:3: בית חשבנא; Bamidbar 32:37 חשבון

  6. The city Elealeh. Bamidbar 32:3: בעלי דבבא; Bamidbar 32:37 אלעלא

  7. The city Sibmah / S'bam. Bamidbar 32:3 סימא (סיעת); Bamidbar 32:38: שבמה

  8. The city Nevo. Bamidbar 32:3: בית קבורתא דמושה; Bamidbar 32:38: נבו

  9. The city Beon. Bamidbar 32:3: בען; Bamidbar 32:38: בעל מעון.

In most cases earlier name in the Torah matches the later one, however Onkelos does not always copy names. Why?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

According to Rabbi Refael Binyamin Posen in his book Parshegen (פרשגן) on Onkelos (Bamidbar, pp. 665-667 and nn.), the best manuscripts of Onkelos don't have the Aramaic of verse 3. It seems that this Aramaic list of names originated in one manuscript tradition of Targum Yerushalmi, and at one point some scribes mixed in this translation into some manuscript copies of Onkelos, and from there it made its way to the Onkelos of the editio princeps (first printed edition) of Mikraot Gedolot. In other words, Onkelos was consistent, but later scribes botched up some branches of the textual tradition and unfortunately these were used for Mikraot Gedolot, which is how this version of Onkelos was popularized and why this translation is thought to be original. It should also be noted that there are several variants to this list in other manuscripts of Targum Yerushalmi, including some significant changes.1

Per Rabbi Posen, I'll also correct my comment on the question: It's not entirely certain that these Aramaic names are Roman-era identifications of these Tanachic sites, because some of the names are literal translations of the Hebrew. For example, another version of the Targum Yerushalmi translates יעזר as סיען (Si'an); in Hebrew the word סיוע means עזרה (Ezra: help, assist). Nevo actually appears as-is in later sources, so the name בית קבורתא דמושה (the burial of Moshe) simply comes to explain the significance of the site and was likely not the actual name of the Roman period town at the site. Rabbi Yehoshua Falk (or Valk) in his commentary Beit Yisrael (AKA Perisha and Derisha) on the Tur, Hilchot Shabbat, § 285 also explained the name מכללתא as a literal translation of עטרות, because עטרה (Atarah) means crown, and מכללתא in his opinion comes from כליל (Kelil), which also means crown. On the other hand, בית נימרה/נימרין is known from contemporary sources (including being Yerushalmi Shevi'it 9:2's proposed identification of Nimrah). And כומרין in particular caught my eye because of its phonetic similarity to Qumran, and it has been suggested in the past that Qumran is derived from כומריא (Kumria, which means "priests" in Syriac (also related to כומר [komer] in Hebrew). While the general area of Ya'azer is far from Qumran, in light of the phonetic and possible etymological similarity, it's possible that there is a preservation of a real site name here.2

1 For a full list of variants, see Alexander Sperber, Kitvei Ha'kodesh Be'aramit (כתבי הקדש בארמית), vol. 1, p. 279, verse 32. Can be found on Otzar Hachochmah.

2 Interestingly, Yisrael Ben-Shem, Kibbush Ever Ha'Yarden (כיבוש עבר הירדן), pp. 68-69 argued that there is evidence that there were two Ya'azers. However, Yoel Elitzur, Shemot Mekomot Kedumim Be'Eretz Yisrael (שמות מקומות קדומים בארץ ישראל), p. 310, n. 3 (cont.) noted that he found the theory to be original but ultimately unconvincing.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Ramban to Bamidbar 32:38 explains that the cities changed their names twice after they got the names from the Moabites who settled them before (1). After the Amorites' conquest, the new rulers named them after their idols. When bnei Reuven and Bnei Gad aquired the cities from Amorites they returned the original Moabite names (because they wanted to shame the Amorites and because they did not want to call the names of their idols). Chizkuni (citing Bechor Shor), Rashi and R. Saadia Gaon offer other reasons, but the Ramban's seems to be the most compelling.

(1) The Torah states that Moabites took over the territory of giant Refaim (Eimim) Devarim 2:10-11. Most likely, it happened because Refaim were smitten by the army of 4 kings Bereshis 14:5. It is not clear if Moabites established the cities or they resettled them.

title: If מי יימר דדמך סומק טפי is true, and the same logic applies to property, then what about a property case where דמך סומק טפי?
content:
# If מי יימר דדמך סומק טפי is true, and the same logic applies to property, then what about a property case where דמך סומק טפי? ## Frage

The Talmud in Sanhedrin 74a states that if a Jew is forced to either forfeit his or her life or murder another, he or she must give up his or her life. The Talmud continues:

רוצח גופיה מנא לן סברא הוא דההוא דאתא לקמיה דרבה ואמר ליה אמר לי מרי דוראי זיל קטליה לפלניא ואי לא קטלינא לך אמר ליה לקטלוך ולא תיקטול מי יימר דדמא דידך סומק טפי דילמא דמא דהוא גברא סומק טפי

The Gemara asks: From where do we derive this halakha with regard to a murderer himself, that one must allow himself to be killed rather than commit murder? The Gemara answers: It is based on logical reasoning that one life is not preferable to another, and therefore there is no need for a verse to teach this halakha. The Gemara relates an incident to demonstrate this:

As when a certain person came before Rabba and said to him: The lord of my place, a local official, said to me: Go kill so-and-so, and if not I will kill you, what shall I do? Rabba said to him: It is preferable that he should kill you and you should not kill. Who is to say that your blood is redder than his, that your life is worth more than the one he wants you to kill? Perhaps that man’s blood is redder. This logical reasoning is the basis for the halakha that one may not save his own life by killing another.

By the same logic if one is forced to destroy his friend's property or forfeit his own property of equal value, he should forfeit his own - who says your property is more valuable than your friends? And if one is forced to either beat his friend or receive a similar beating, he should opt to receive the beating. Do we find these parallel rules in Halacha?

Let's add a twist. Someone threatens you - destroy your friend's bottle of soda or I will destroy your house. What now?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The way I understood it, is really by all mitzvos you dont give up your life, since vichai bahem ( you should live by them). The gemara said that logic to explain why this din doesn't apply to murder. When it comes to any aveira a person is obligated to give up all his money not to do so. So if someone tells you to destroy someones property you would have to give up all your stuff not to do so. That logic cant permit you to do an aveira. There might be other reasons why you would be allowed to distroy your friends stuff, maybe he would allow it to save your house etc.. But just because your property is more valuable wouldn't allow you to destroy your friends stuff. We dont see from the gemara that using that logic would allow a person to do an aveira.

content:
# Rabbi who made a deal with the devil ## Frage

I've heard over several years a legend of a certain (medieval) Rabbi who made a deal with the devil to save his community.

I somewhat recall that there was a plague in his community. The Rabbi's name may have been "Baal Shem of Chelm". I also dubiously recall a link to the recitation of Psalm 27 between 1st Elul and Hoshana Raba.

Does anyone have more details? To be clear, I don't care if this is considered a total myth and was fully debunked; I'm just looking for a source.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

From the lecture by Dr Shnayer Leiman (linked by @Efraym): The Sefer Nezer Hakodesh of Ropshitz mentions a tradition not to say Psalm 27 in Elul or the kabalistic paragraph "kegavna" on Friday night.

These customs were attributed to the Ba'al Shem of Chelm, and as a punishment for making a deal with Satan himself, it was decided that the customs he created should be cancelled.

The story goes that the local ruler threatened to banish all Jews from his land unless they prayed for him to have a child, and the Ba'al Shem could not receive approval from Heaven so he turned to Hell instead.

The story considers this as an act of heroism, that he was willing to forfeit his eternity for the sake of his fellow Jews, rather than a betrayal of Judaism.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Rabbi Dr. Shnayer Leiman in a lecture on why we say L'Dovid Hashem Ori discusses this story. I don't remember off hand all the details.

title: Is it considered lashon harah if it is said in a manner that the person will hear about it?
content:
# Is it considered lashon harah if it is said in a manner that the person will hear about it? ## Frage

Tosafos (b bb 39b second from top: פירוש לאותו שאומר לפני ג׳ דבפרק יש בערכין מייתי עלה הא דא״ר יוסי מעולם לא אמרתי דבר וחזרתי לאחורי פי׳ שלא היה חושש אם ישמעו בעלים) explains a gemara (ibid 39a-b) "אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא כֹּל מִילְּתָא דְּמִתְאַמְרָא בְּאַפֵּי תְּלָתָא לֵית בָּהּ מִשּׁוּם לִישָּׁנָא בִּישָׁא—Rabba bar Rav Huna says: Any matter that is said in the presence of three people is not subject to the prohibition of malicious speech, as it is already public knowledge" as meaning that if one says over negative information in a way that would naturally reach the ears of the person being spoken of (in front of 3 people, and certainly if the person is present) then it isn't considered lashon harah (which per this is only negative speech that one is chicken to have the person hear about).

R Yaakov Emden seems to hold of this lhalacha as his autobiography (megilas sefer) is chockful of attacks on various folks that he had issues with.

Is this the accepted halacha nowadays?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Please see the Chafetz Chaim, 2nd chapter, who has a whole perek for this halacha explaining all the conditions necessary to be met in order to rely on this concept. He writes, for example, that only avak lashon hara can be said with heter. The explanation being, that avak lashon hara is a case in which the words can be understood to mean something negative or positive based on the tone. When a person knows that what he says will reach the person he speaks about he will make sure to use a positive tone.

The chafetz chaim very much advises against using this heter as it would be very hard to find a case in which all conditions are met.

וְאַחֲרֵי כָּל הַדְּבָרִים וְהָאֱמֶת הָאֵלֶּה שֶׁבֵּאַרְנוּ, רְאֵה אָחִי, כַּמָה יֵשׁ לְהִתְרַחֵק מִקֵּלָּא זוֹ, שֶׁכִּמְעַט אֵין לָהּ מָקוֹם בַּמְּצִּיאוּת, וּבִפְרָט שֶׁאַךְ אִם יִצְּטָרְפוּ כָּל הַפְּרָטִים, גַּם כֵּן צָּרִיךְ עִיּוּן אִם הֲלָכָה כְּדֵעָה זוֹ, אַחֲרֵי שֶׁלְּדַעַת הַרְבֵּה פּוֹסְקִּים אֵין שׁוּם מָקוֹר לְקֻלָּא זוֹ מֵהַשַּׁ"ס {וכמו שכתבנו בסוף סעיף קטן ד' בבאר מים חיים}, לָכֵן הַשּׁוֹמֵר נַפְשׁוֹ יִרְחַקּ מִזֶּה.

And after all these things and this truth that we have explained, see, my brother, how much one must distance himself from this leniency [of apei telata], which has practically no place in reality; and, especially, even if all the conditions [for leniency] obtain, it is still to be determined whether the halachah is consistent with this opinion [of leniency], since, according to many poskim there is no source for this leniency in the Talmud (as we have written in section 4 in the Be'er Mayim Chayim). Therefore, one who guards his soul will distance himself from this.

Re, Rabbi Emdin's autobiography

  1. The authenticity is not really confirmed, you would have to rely on the original publisher who found a handwritten copy in England
  2. If rabbi yaakov emdin believed that those people were not righteous, there could be other heterim of speaking about them.

title: Defensiveness when accused of Lashon Hara
content:
# Defensiveness when accused of Lashon Hara ## Frage

I have personally noticed that if a person is accused of speaking Lashon Hara, they have a strong tendency to get very defensive.

This seems to me to be something that is above and beyond the standard defensiveness that people respond when when generally accused of wrong doing.

Have I spotted something real? Are there any sources that also point this out and perhaps offer a reason, as well as advice on how to get people to stop talking Lashon Hara in a way that will have more success?

The reason why I suspect there might be an answer is because a Rosh Yeshiva once told me that the reason we speak Lashon Hara is actually not so much to do with the yeitzer hara, although this was a long time ago, I don't remember his full explanation or if he gave any sources, but I do believe there is something unique about this one particular aveira.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I believe they react strongly because they think what they said (that others may call lashon hara) serves a useful purpose. Remember that you are allowed to speak ill of others under these conditions:

-Saving a life;

-Testifying in court;

-Writing a letter of recommendation on request;

-Warning someone against dealing with people who have been crooked in dealing with you (and only with you);

-Referring to the misdeeds of people currently serving a legal sentence for those misdeeds;

-Teaching about cruel and crooked historical figures to avoid history repeating itself;

-Speaking to someone, in private, to advise him on how to correct the faults you perceive in him.

Etc.

content:
# Earliest time for Maariv on Tisha b'Av ## Frage

This year (2024) Tisha b'Av begins on the evening of August 12. In my locale, Plag on August 12 will be at 7:11 pm, and Shkia will be at 8:39 pm. The fast, of course, begins at sundown (8:39 pm).

If it is the usual custom of a community to daven Maariv right after plag, is that permissible on Tisha b'Av? Or is it necessary to wait until the 8th of Av is "fully complete" before davening Maariv? In particular, can the reading of Eicha start before Shkia?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

This is my understanding

There is no need to wait until night any differently than on any other night of the year. Reading of eicha is a custom without stipulation to have to be read at night.

If it were necessary to wait until night the commentaries would have pointed that out similar to shavuot, first night of pesach, megilah on purim etc.

title: What is considered a "makom" in "Minhag Hamakom"?
content:
# What is considered a "makom" in "Minhag Hamakom"? ## Frage

When we talk about Minhag Hamakom (place), what locality are we talking about: a country, a city, a neighborhood, or a family home?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

It's not entirely clear from the question which type on minhag hamakom he is referring to. This answer discusses the minhag hamakom of makom shenahagu of Pesachim 50 - the obligation to adopt the customs of the place one lives. I don't think minhag hamakom often mentioned as a deciding factor in Choshen Mishpat is the same.

The implications of the responsa of R' Moshe Feinstein zt"l (Igros Moshe OC 1:158, EH 1:59) is that 'minhag hamakom' applies even within one home.

R' Moshe discusses the concept of a married woman adopting the customs of her husband, and he categorizes this within the framework of minhag hamakom. [See the teshuva for a very original insight by R' Moshe zt"l that even according to the Rambam (Yom Tov 8:20) that one is obligated by the customs of the his original place, a wife entering the domain of her husband is different.]

A similar analogy is mentioned by Minchas Yitzchok (4:83), (albeit with a slightly different application).

title: What is the translation of the word "ibn" that some Rabbis have in their name?
content:
# What is the translation of the word "ibn" that some Rabbis have in their name? ## Frage

For example R. Chisdai ibn Shaprut, his full name is R Chisdai ben Yitzchak ibn Shaprut. So that "ibn" cant be translated as "son of".

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 17)

It means son in Arabic but doesn't typically denote a father-son relationship but rather the patriarch by which the family is known

(Eg Ramban Bamidbar 26:13:

אבל הענין כי היה המנהג בישראל לעשות להם ראשי בתי אבות, יתיחסו כל יוצאי יריכו לעולם אל האיש ההוא, ויקראו על שמו לכבודו, כאשר יעשו גם היום כל הישמעאלים וכל ישראל הדרים בארצותם להקרא כולם למשפחות אבן עזרא, אבן שושן. וזה טעם: אלה ראשי בית אבותם (שמות ו':י"ד), כי מעת אשר פרו ורבו במצרים העמידו להם ראשי משפחות להתיחס אליהם. ואולי התחילו בענין הזה במצרים, שלא יתערבו בגוים ויהיו ניכרים וידועים לשבטיהם, ששם עלו שבטים שבטי יה עדות לישראל,⁠ ותהי לחק בישראל.

But [we must say that] this matter was [as follows]. It was the custom in Israel [for people] to appoint over themselves "heads of fathers' houses," and all the descendants of that man would always trace their lineage back to him, and be called by his name in his honor; just as all the Arabs do to this very day, and as do all the Jews who live in their [the Arabs'] countries, calling themselves by family [names, such as] "Ibn Ezra," or "Ibn Shushan." This is the meaning of the verse which says, These are the heads of their fathers' houses,⁠ for from the time that they were fruitful and multiplied in Egypt, they established heads of families over themselves, to whom they would trace their lineage. Perhaps they initiated this practice in Egypt in order not to mingle themselves with the nations and so that they would be recognized and distinguishable among their tribes, [for it is there in Egypt] whither the tribes went up, even the tribes of the Eternal, as a testimony unto Israel,⁠ and it became a custom in Israel.⁠

(HT @b a & TY @RabbiKaii for the suggestion)

# Lashon Hara in the modern day, when it can be immediately proven by public information ## Frage

If someone has done something that makes them look bad, and there is proof - something very easy in the modern day, such as a video, or a message they wrote on social media - what is the halacha of showing people this proof? I'll give a couple of examples:

I buy a new car. One of my friends shows me that one of my other acquaintances has sent jealousy-driven messages to him and a few others, along the lines of "can you believe how irresponsible this guy is with money, we shouldn't let him near the shul bank account".

Was my friend allowed to show me that message? Am I allowed to show others? Does it make a different if I was, at the time, trying to get elected to the shul board or not? (note, this is not a personal question or looking for psak, just a hypothetical)

A bochur goes on holiday, and lets himself indulge a bit, and on his social media there are videos where he is speaking nivul peh.

title: Responsibility before commandments?
content:
# Responsibility before commandments? ## Frage

The Midrash has Moses make the argument that God should not punish the Israelites for the Golden Calf, because He never told them not to engage in idolatry:

[Moses] said in front of [God]: Master of the Universe, from where does Israel know that what they did [was wrong]? Did they not grow up in Egypt? And all people in Egypt are idolaters. And when You gave the Torah, You did not give it to them, and they were also not standing there, as it is stated: "And the people remained at a distance." [Exodus 20:18] You only gave it to me, as it is stated: "And [God] said to Moses: “Ascend to the Lord.”" [Exodus 24:1] And when You gave the [Ten Commandments], You did not give [them] to them. You did not say, אֲנִי ה' אֱלֹהֵיכֶם “I am the Lord, your God” [in the plural]; but rather אָנֹכִי ה' אֱלֹהֶיךָ “I am the Lord, your God” [in the singular]”. [Hence] You said it to me. Did I sin? The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, “By your life, you have spoken well. לִמַּדְתַּנִי – Limadtani! You have taught Me! From now on, I will say אֲנִי ה' אֱלֹהֵיכֶם “I am the Lord, your God [in the plural]”. [Numbers Rabbah 19:33]

Earlier, at the time of the flood, we read:

The earth was filled with violent crime... God saw the earth and beheld that it was corrupt... God said to Noach: "The end of all flesh has come before Me. For the earth is filled with violent crime because of them, and so, I will destroy them with the earth." [Gen. 6:11-13]

In the spirit of Moses' argument, how should the people have known that they should not have engaged in violent crime?

title: Is the Book Shaar HaYichud a continuation of Shaar HaEmunah By the Mittler Rebbe?
content:
# Is the Book Shaar HaYichud a continuation of Shaar HaEmunah By the Mittler Rebbe? ## Frage

BH

Hi in the Mittler Rebbes book translation on Sefaria translated by Rabbi Amiram Markel [1] it says that "it is through the delving of the concentration that one can come to the depth of the concept, until its very source in the depths of Chochmah and Binah. ([Through the above he is capable of] reaching the aspect of the upper Da’at which unites Chochmah and Binah, as was explained previously regarding the matter of the depth of the comprehension (Omek HaMoosag) of Binah."

Although where does it in Shaar HaYichud say before this that through deep consentration when one reaches the omek hamusag(depth of the concept) he is able to reach the aspect of the upper Daat which unites chochma and bina?

Does this mean it is mentioned before in Shaar HaEmunah as Shaar HaYichud comes right after Shaar Emunah in the Traditional Ner Mitzvah VeTorah [2] and the two are connected Shaar Yichud being a hemshech of Shaar HaEmunah?

Also if yes where does it mention this in Shaar HaEmunah?

[1] https://www.sefaria.org/The_Gate_of_Unity.1.46?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en

[2] https://hebrewbooks.org/16054

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Mitteler Rebbe did intend for Sha'ar HaEmunah and Sha'ar HaYichud to be published together, as can be seen at the end of his introduction to Ner Mitzvah veTorah Or. I don't know if that means that one should be viewed as a "continuation" of the other, but that's also not really relevant here.

In the piece you cite, he's referring to what he wrote earlier in chapter 1 of Sha'ar HaEmunah, that the "depth of comprehension" represents the source of binah in chochmah i.e. the point of connection of the two.

title: Rebbeim wearing wedding rings
content:
# Rebbeim wearing wedding rings ## Frage

Is there any reason why Rebbeim typically don't wear wedding rings? I have never seen any Rav wearing one and was wondering if there are any specific reasons for that. Are there any examples of famous or well respected Rabbis that do/did?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I would assume that sources on this will be rare to non-existent since there is no reason in Judaism for a man to wear a wedding ring.

It is true that Jewish men can wear rings, and might even have done so (see mishna in Masechta Shabbat discussing Men wearing a ring and many other sources in the Talmud) but that has nothing to do with this question.

The purpose of the wedding ring given to to the women in a Jewish marriage is in order to create a Kinyan Kiddushin - a transaction that makes the marriage valid. Only the man has the ability to be mekadesh the women and as such he gives the ring (btw, he could technically give anything else of monetary value more than a Peruta). So there is no point for the man to receive a ring.

I welcome you to also read the Wikipedia page, which brings some reasons for wedding rings in the gentile world , which do not apply in judaism.

title: Kamatz read as kholam!
content:
# Kamatz read as kholam! ## Frage

Sometimes kamatz is read as kholam. Example: written as וַיָּשׇׁב read as vayyashov Bereshit 37,29:

וַיָּ֤שׇׁב רְאוּבֵן֙ אֶל־הַבּ֔וֹר וְהִנֵּ֥ה אֵין־יוֹסֵ֖ף בַּבּ֑וֹר וַיִּקְרַ֖ע אֶת־בְּגָדָֽיו׃

Can anyone explain for me what's the grammatical law behind this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

In Bereshis 37:29-30, there is the following word:

וַיָּ֤שׇׁב

The word has a kamatz under the ש. The kamatz does not have stress, and is known as kamatz katan, or a short version of kholam in the Palestinian pronunciation adopted by Sephardim. It's "o" as dog/fog for British and or/oil/own for American speakers.

title: What does it mean col Minei gehinom sholtim bo
content:
# What does it mean col Minei gehinom sholtim bo ## Frage

BH

Hi, in Igerret HaRamban the Ramban quotes Razal (Nedarim 22a) and says:

כל הכועס כל מיני גיהנם שולטין בו

Anyone who gets angry, all kinds of Gehenna rule over him

What does this mean? Isn’t Gehinom a punishment in the next life? How could someone have punishment here in this world control him if he gets angry?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

The Rosh on Nedarim 22a offers two explanations:

  1. Anger is as harmful to the body as all the punishments of Gehinnom.
  2. Anger leads to sin, which ultimately condemns the person to Gehinnom.

See the commentaries there for other explanations.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

If you rely on the explicit explanation from Ramban in the Chumash, he says that גיהנם is gematria חמס.

That means in context of your text from his letter to his son, to always speak gently toward others. That in so doing, one is freed from anger. That all who indulge in anger, allow all types of violence to rule over them.

title: Source for Secret Signs that Yaakov gave Rachel
content:
# Source for Secret Signs that Yaakov gave Rachel ## Frage

I heard some time ago that Kaf haChaim or some other author suggests that the secret signs that Yaakov gave Rachel were the places of the body, where later the kohanim had oil and blood applied during their inauguration: right ear, right thumb, and right big toe. Is it possible to identify the source for this midrash and explain the connection?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Thanks to אילפא for linking to the correct section of Kaf HaChaim on Shulchan Aruch, Orach Chaim 240:64:1-2 from Sefaria.

The Kaf HaChaim indicates precisely where he took it from. The tradition is passed down by Rabbi Avraham Azulai in Sefer Chesed l'Avraham, Even Shetiyah, Maayan 2, Nahar 61:1-2.

The full explanation is about proper marital relations between husband and wife and how it should always be at the initiation of the wife and not be initiated at the discretion of the husband nor because of the desire of the husband.

Interestingly enough, it also connects this to the proper practice of Kapparot by a man on erev Yom Kippur when using a rooster. The full text is:

נהר סא - בסוד תנוך אוזן ובהן יד ורגל, ובסוד סימנים שמסר יעקב לרחל:

דע כי יש ג' שרים גדולים מסטרא דשמאלא והם המתעוררים את האדם לרדוף אחר תאות גופניות, אחד משכנו על תנוך אוזן הימנית והוא הגדול, והבינוני על בוהן יד הימנית, והקטן על בוהן רגל הימנית, ועל ידי נתינת הכהן מדם האשם על ג' מקומות האלו מסתלקים מעליו השרים הנזכרים, כמו שעל ידי הזאת מי חטאת על טמא מת מסתלק מעליו טומאת המת שהוא רוח טומאה מסטרא דשמאלא, וכך צריך ליתן מדם התרנגול הנשחט לכפרה בערבי יום הכפורים על תנוך האוזן המכפר הימנית ועל בהן ידו הימנית ועל בהן רגלו הימנית, ובזה מסתלקים מעליו השרים המעוררים אותו לרדוף אחר תאות גופניות, והם הם המעוררים הם ההמקטרגים, ובהסתלקם מעליו ניצול מתובע וממקטרג, ואין שום ב"ד יכול לידון מבלי תובע. וכן הענין בסוד התשמיש כשהתעוררות בא מהזכר אותו התשמיש אינו לשם שמים כי אם לשם תענוג, ואע"פ שאי אפשר להיות התחלת התשמיש שלא יהיה לשם תענוג מצד זה נולדה הערלה כנזכר לעיל, אבל הזוכה לאשה כשרה שכל תשמיש ותשמיש בא על ידי התעורותה, ועל ידי שאוחזת בידה בתנוך אזן בעלה הימני ובוהן ידו הימני ובוהן רגלו הימני בזמן שכוונתה לעורר אותו, צריכה שתתכוון לבה בשעה שמחזקת באלו הג' סימנים שיסתלקו מעליו הג' שרים המעוררים התאוה שלא לשם שמים, וכאשר יתכוון הוא לקיים מצות עונה לבד ולא לשום תענוג כלל, אז אפשר לאותו עובר לצאת מהול ממעי אמו, ואלו הסימנים שמסר יעקב לרחל, ואמנם האשה צריכה להתחיל מהבהן הרגל שהוא הסימן התחתון, ואח"כ מבהן היד שהוא האמצעי, ואח"כ בתנוך אזן בעלה שהוא העליון, ובדרך זה מסרן יעקב לרחל, מסכ"י, וזמש"ל:

That in context, this is a tradition which follows after the two covenants established by G-d with Avraham, namely the upper covenant over proper thoughts and speech. The brain being between the two ears, and the mouth, which is in between the two hands.

And the lower covenant of circumcision which is between the two feet.

title: Learning during the Leader's Repetition of the Amidah - sources that permit it?
content:
# Learning during the Leader's Repetition of the Amidah - sources that permit it? ## Frage

The sources are clear that one should not learn Torah during the Leader's Repetition of the Amidah. See Halichipedia

It is improper to learn Torah or say other parts of davening during Chazarat Hashatz.[17]

The Mishnah Berurah O CH 124 MB 17 expresses it so:

(יז) ולכוין - ע"כ יש ליזהר מלומר תחנונים או ללמוד בעת חזרת הש"ץ ואפילו אם מכוונים לסוף הברכה לענות אמן כראוי שלא תהיה אמן יתומה כמו שיתבאר ג"כ לא יפה הם עושים שאם הלומדים יפנו ללימודם עמי הארץ ילמדו מהן שלא להאזין לש"ץ ויעסקו בשיחה בטילה ח"ו נמצאו מחטיאין את הרבים:

"(17) And to focus - Therefore, one must be careful not to say supplications or study during the repetition of the Amidah by the prayer leader, even if they intend to respond 'Amen' at the end of the blessing properly so that it will not be an 'orphaned Amen,' as will be explained. It is also not appropriate because if those who are studying turn to their studies, the unlearned will learn from them not to listen to the prayer leader and will engage in idle chatter, God forbid. Thus, they cause many to sin."

This is the answer to the question Can you learn during chazarat hashatz?.

My question is that I observe that many people ignore this teaching. I wonder do they have any sources on whom to rely?

title: Vilna Gaon's commentary on מחצית השקל

# Vilna Gaon's commentary on מחצית השקל ## Frage

I read somewhere the following:

The verse says, "Each Jew was commanded to give מחצית השקל, half-shekel, for the Mishkan to achieve atonement (Exodus 30:15).

צ stands in the center of the word מחצית, denoting צדקה. It is surrounded on either side by the letters חי, life, and at the ends of the word by the letters מת, death. This is an indication that by giving charity one gets closer to life and keeps away from death” - Vilna Gaon

שמעתי בשם הגר״א בזה דבר נחמד דהנה בתיבת מחצית השקל האות האמצעי ממחצית הוא צדיק והוא ר״ת צדקה ואותיות ח״י סמוכים לו אות ח׳ לפני הצדיק ואות י׳ לאחר הצ׳ ואותיות מ״ת רחוקי׳ מאות הצ׳ מ״ם בתחלת התיבה ותי״ו בסוף התיבה לומר לך דע״י צדקה יהיה קרוב לחיים ורחוק ממות וכמאמר הכתוב וצדקה חציל ממות

title: Jew threatening another Jew with violence
content:
# Jew threatening another Jew with violence ## Frage

If a Jew threatens a fellow Jew with physical violence, does that make him a bona fide rasha (wicked person)? (e.g. Moshe and Dasan and Aviram, see Rashi Ex. 2:13 and Sanh. 58b) Even in today's day and age? If they are religious rather than secular?

What is the halacha of dealing such a person?

E.g. is one obligated to love them still? Is one obligated to continue talking to them because otherwise one would be guilty of Sinat Chinam (Sanhedrin 27b)? Should one report them to the police? Should one strike them first before they strike you? Is one obligated to hate them? Are they allowed for aliya? Valid witnesses? Can one inform others and believe if warned i.e. Laws of Lashon Hara regarding such an individual etc.

Basically, I am not trying to ask too many questions, I just want a full understanding of what the Torah says about such a person and how we should deal with such a person.

[I have separated out the latter half of this question into its own question]

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Perhaps, one could look in the book "The Right and the Good" by R. Daniel Z. Feldman, Section 11 titled "One Strike and You Are Out: Hitting and Raising a Hand in Violence", p 159-168. Since you are asking only about threats, I am providing the relevant middle subsection.

The basic implication of the gemara about this is that a person who threatens another with violence is a Rasha, as we learn from Moshe Rabbeinu and Dasan and Aviram (see OP for source).

Some hold that this is not to be taken literally in halacha, but is rather meant to provide a stigma against people who do this, as a deterrent to actual violence (e.g. R Aharon Grossman, VDarashta VChakarta pp 120-122).

There is discussion about the reasons for the prohibition. R Chaim Kanevsky (cited in L'Reacha Kamocha vol 3 #43) holds that the prohibition is actually intending harm, and R David Ariav (ibid) questions if maybe it is due to the fear instilled by the threat i.e. ona'at devarim. The nafka mina is if the person threatened didn't know about it, then there's no sin.

There are some who declare that the issue is the degredation of civil relationships; it is animalistic to introduce physical violence to a conversation, and this is an independant prohibition (see Parach Mateh Aharon, Mada, p.6).

If we hold that such a person is a Rasha, then they will be disqualified for testimony, especially if it is the latter reasoning that we adopt. The Rama rules that someone who does this is allowed to be a witness d'oraisa, it is nonetheless a rabbinic prohibition (some disagree, e.g. R Shlomo of Lublin, quoting R Moshe Mintz, Responsa Maharah MiLublin 89).

R Yehoshua Falk, in Sefer Me'irat Einayim cites the Mordechai that although it is a biblical prohibition, there are no lashes. R Shmuel Rozovsky (Chiddushei R Shmuel on Sanhedrin 12) holds that it is not d'oraisa, and the status of Rasha is not literal (the pasuk is just an asmachta).

R Yoel Sirkes on the Tur (Bayit Chadash, Choshen Mishpat 34) cites the Rambam and holds that it is indeed d'oraisa, and R Yehoshua DiTrani also holds this way (Responsa Maharit Even HaEzer 43 - note the objection of R Yosef Shaul Nathanson, Responsa Shoel Umeishiv, Mahadura Tinyana 2:70), and R Yaacov Veil takes this further and says there is indeed lashes (Responsa Mahari Veil 28).

R Menachem Mendel uses the later to question if a shochet should be removed from his position if he does this (Responsa Tzemach Tzedek CM Shaar Hamiluim 15). R Yehudah HaChasid states that the ban of excommunication that applies to actually hitting someone also applies to someone who raises his hand to do so (See SA CM 420:2, and Sefer MeIrat Einayim 4).

title: Midrash about yetzer hara
content:
# Midrash about yetzer hara ## Frage

I heard a midrash which describes yetzer hara, the evil inclination, as acting through his 3 generals: one pulls the person's right ear, one pulls the person's right thumb, and one pulls the person's right toe. Is it possible to find a source and explain the midrash connection to the procedure of inauguration of cohanim and purification of metzorah. דע כי יש ג' שרים גדולים מסטרא דשמאלא והם המתעוררים את האדם לרדוף אחר תאות גופניות, אחד משכנו על תנוך אוזן הימנית והוא הגדול, והבינוני על בוהן יד הימנית, והקטן על בוהן רגל הימנית, ועל ידי נתינת הכהן מדם האשם על ג' מקומות האלו מסתלקים מעליו השרים הנזכרים, כמו שעל ידי הזאת מי חטאת על טמא מת מסתלק מעליו טומאת המת שהוא רוח טומאה מסטרא דשמאלא

title: Sources for Adam being the father of mankind
content:
# Sources for Adam being the father of mankind ## Frage

Adam is the father of all humanity. He was literally the first father, and the measure of how good a father he was has repurcussions for literally every human on earth.

Looking for any sources that discuss anything related to Adam specifically as a father (Chava is explicitly called the mother of all life, so I am not asking about her yet).

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Ohr HaChaim Hakadosh makes reference to this, albeit just as an aside, when speaking about how Chava was formed from Adam's side.

On his commentary on Bamidbar 21:7 he writes:

והכוונה היא על זה הדרך הגיא אשר בא מפאת האשה שהיא חוה שבאה מאב כל הנבראים שלקחה ה' מצלעותיו ואין אשה בעולם שבאה כדרך זה מצלעות האדם כי אם זאת

The meaning of the verse then would be as follows: "the valley (grave) which was a state reached due to woman, who had been formed out of the "father" of all mankind, Adam, is the only one who had been created in this fashion, part of the rib of Adam, her husband." (Sefaria transaltion).

This choice of expression is also adopted by Rabbeinu Bachya. The verse in Bereishis 19:32 when discussing Lot and his daughters says:

לְכָ֨ה נַשְׁקֶ֧ה אֶת־אָבִ֛ינוּ יַ֖יִן וְנִשְׁכְּבָ֣ה עִמּ֑וֹ וּנְחַיֶּ֥ה מֵאָבִ֖ינוּ זָֽרַע׃

Come, let us make our father drink wine, and let us lie with him, that we may maintain life through our father.”

Rabbeinu Bachya there notes:

והנה חטא האם וחטא הבנות במעשה הזה שוה ע"י היין שהוא הגורם רעות העולם, ואולי רבוי את אבינו, את אבינו הראשון, שגם הוא שתה ע"י אשה

In this instance the sin committed by the mother (Chavah) and the daughters (Lot’s) was identical in that it was committed by means of wine which has brought much tragedy on mankind. Perhaps, the additional word אבינו, “our father,” in this verse is even an allusion to our original/first father (i.e. the father of mankind, Adam). It reminds us that he too had been given wine to drink by his wife.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Probably, it would be wrong to think of Adam (or Noah) as a Jewish father, because only regarding Abraham (Bereshis 18:19) it is stated that he was instructing members of his household. Possibly, prior to Abraham's times it was not necessary, because people in earlier generations could easier achieve their perfection. However, one could look at Adam as a the original source of inspiration and education based on who he was and mistakes he made, just like we look at generation of Midbar. They do not have portion in Olam haBa but we learn from their experience, from their achievements and failures. For example, Adam was the first parent who learned something important from his son (the power of teshuva), Bereshis Rabba 22:13.

title: How to reconcile the verse in Yeshaya 49:14 to the beginning of Shaar HaEmunah
content:
# How to reconcile the verse in Yeshaya 49:14 to the beginning of Shaar HaEmunah ## Frage

BH

It says in Yishaya 49:14:

‎ וַתֹּ֥אמֶר צִיּ֖וֹן עֲזָבַ֣נִי יְהֹוָ֑ה וַאדֹנָ֖י שְׁכֵחָֽנִי

whereas in Ner Mitzvah V'Torah Or (Shaar HaEmunah) it says:

וה' שכחני

Why does R. Dov-Ber Schneuri say ה'‏ (meaning י-ה-ו-ה) instead and explain the verse as if it's the name הוי'‏ when the name used in the verse is actually א-ד-נ-י?

In the actual verse, the word שכחני is said about the name אדנ'‏ and עזבני is said about הוי'‏.

However here, in Shaar HaEmunah, he asks how can שכחה be said about the name הוי'‏ when in the verse it's only said of the name אדנ'‏?

This is the part from Shaar HaEmunah:

כתיב ותאמר ציון עזבני ה' וה' שכחני וזה פלא גדול לכאורה דאיך יתכן לומר בחי' שכחה למעלה באלקים חיים שהוא ית' למעלה מן הזמן כהוראת שם הויה היה הוה ויהיה כא'‏

title: Punishment for hiring false witnesses
content:
# Punishment for hiring false witnesses ## Frage

We read in Bava Kamma 55b:

It is taught that Rabbi Yehoshua said: [One] is exempt from liability according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven [if he] hires false witnesses to testify.

Halacha says that if you testify falsely and are caught, you get the same penalty as the defendant would have gotten, and by human hands. But does this baraita add that if you just hire someone to testify falsely, you can't be punished by human hands? Are there commentaries that elaborate on this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Yes, the Baraita does teach this.

The Maharam mentions in his responsa (300 in the Prague edition) that the reason why the one who hired the false witnesses is exempt is because he has only caused a grama, an indirect action:

כל אלו דיני [דגרמא] הם בנזקין ופטור

All these cases of damage are ones of indirect action and are exempt

The Sefer HaTashbetz (II 114) concurs, and clarifies that the reason why the person is chayav bidei shamayim is because damage did come about through his hands, despite it not being direct.

Interestingly:

The Rosh notes a case brought by the son of Rabbi Yechiel, where people deliberately hired false witnesses:

A woman hired false witnesses preemptively against someone else, who had stated he would produce witnesses against her (which she knew must be false because she knew he was lying about his claim - it was regarding his claim that he had betrothed her).

In that case, the false witnesses did not end up testifying, but it did become known that they planned on doing so, and the Rosh states that in this case the she wasn't even punished bidei shamayim, but was placed under a 30 day excommunication as a warning to others.

title: Does plant life have value?
content:
# Does plant life have value? ## Frage

Is there anything wrong with destroying plant life for no reason? Does plant life hold any value according to Judaism?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

You may not destroy even a grain of mustard for no reason. The Sefer HaChinuch, a systematic discussion of all 613 commandments from 13th-century Spain, writes:

This the way of the pious and righteous people: They love peace, they are happy for the good of the creatures, they bring them close to Torah, and they do not destroy even a grain of mustard in the world. And they are distressed by all the loss and destruction that they see. And if they can prevent any destruction, they will do so with all their strength. But not so the wicked… They rejoice in the destruction of the world, and they destroy themselves — [since] in the way that a person measures, so is he measured. [Sefer HaChinuch, Mitzvah 529]

title: Would someone who is a Hebrew but not from the Tribe of Judah be considered a Jew?
content:
# Would someone who is a Hebrew but not from the Tribe of Judah be considered a Jew? ## Frage

For example, Dan the patriarch is not related to Judah. Is he still a Jew? Technically he would be like a Hebrew but was born in Egypt before the giving of the Torah. Can he still be considered a Jew or would he have to reincarnate with a Jewish mother to be considered a Jew even though he was a patriarch?

To continue. Currently, the status of the Northern Tribes is "lost". Will they be Jews when "we" "find" "them".

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

What is Jewishness? Don't get stuck in semantics. It's not

'someone who is connected to the tribe of Judah, because the etymology of "jew" is "yehuda".'

Jews are those who Hashem chose for the special mission of receiving the Torah and being a light to the nations. This started with Avraham, and passed to one of his children, Yitzchak, and then passed to one of Yitzchak's children, Yaacov. See here for Scriptural reference to this process.

This was then passed to ALL of his children, meaning that every child of Yaacov received this mission. Indeed, all of the people camped around Sinai were the children of Yaacov, representantives from all of his own children (the 12 tribes - also there were converts and eruv rav but that is beyond scope).

Once the Torah was given, we were obligated in all of its commandments, as well as the tradition given along with the Torah which contains the explanation and methodology to the commandments. It is from this that we understood that "choseness for 'Judaism'" passes through the mother.

So, tl'dr, don't get stuck on the etymology - "Jewishness" is more connected to the original Jews, Avraham, Yitzchak and Israel (Yaacov). All the descendants of Israel, through matrilineal heritage, are "Jewish", i.e. of the House of Israel who were chosen to receive the Torah and be a light unto the nations.

title: What happened to the keilim after the destruction of First Beis Hamikdash?
content:
# What happened to the keilim after the destruction of First Beis Hamikdash? ## Frage

Inspired by this question (about the vessels of the Second Temple): I am looking for sources that discuss what happened to the vessels of the Tabernacle/First Temple.

We know from the Talmud (Horiyus 12a) that the Aron Hakodesh was buried (although, see Yerushalmi Shekalim 6:1). Do we have any information about the other vessels?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

In addition to the sources brought by the OP in his question and answer, there are a few other sources that describe variant traditions regarding what happened to the vessels from the First Temple:

A couple of traditions are known from apocryphal sources:

2 Maccabees 1:23 mentions that the kohanim hid the fire of the altar before being exiled to Persia (likely a mistake for Babylon). In 2:1 it is revealed that they did so upon the command of the prophet Yirmiyahu. According to 2:4-7, Yirmiyahu further commanded that the Tent of Meeting (Ohel Moed), the Menorah and the Altar of Incense (Mizbeach ha'Ketoret) be hidden away in a cave in Mt. Nevo. A similar tradition is mentioned also in Vitae Prophetarum (Lives of the Prophets) in the section on Jeremiah, where Yirmiyahu hides the Ark and everything in it in an unknown location between Mt. Nevo and Hor Hahar (where Aharon was buried). Something similar may be echoed in Fragment no. 4 of the early Hellenistic Jewish historian Eupolemus's writings, where he states that Nevuchadnetzar took all of the gold, silver and brass from the Temple to Babylon, but left the Ark and the Tablets with Yirmiyahu.

According to 1 Baruch 6:7-10, the various vessels were swallowed up by the earth.

A similar tradition was brought in 4 Baruch 2:27-30, where Hashem commands Yirmiyahu to hide the vessels beneath the earth.

In Chazalic sources there is a dispute regarding the location of the Ark:

In Tosefta Shekalim 2:18 and Tosefta Sotah 13:1 Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon state that the Ark was taken to Babylon, while Rabbi Yehuda b. Lakish states that the Ark was hidden away by the place where it was kept in the Temple, i.e., below Kodesh ha'Kodashim. This dispute is brought again in Yerushalmi Shekalim 6:1, along with a third view, that of Rabbanan, who state that the Ark was hidden in the Chamber of Wood (Lishkat ha'Etzim). As evidence, they bring a legend about a kohen who accidentally came upon it and was killed. The dispute and description of the legend are likewise brought in Bavli Yoma 53b-54a.

In Mishna Shekalim 6:1-2 it is stated that Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Chaninah Segan ha'Kohahim had a tradition that the Ark was buried in the Chamber of Wood, and then a variant of the legend regarding the kohen finding the Ark is mentioned.

And there are also sources regarding the vessels in general:

In Tanchuma (Buber) Beha'alotcha 14:1 (= Tanchuma Beha'alotcha 9:1) it says that that all of the vessels were brought to Babylon, save for the gates of the Temple, which were hidden where they stood. This is based on the verse in Daniel 1:2:

"The Lord delivered King Jehoiakim of Judah into his power, together with some of the vessels of the House of God, and he brought them to the land of Shinar to the house of his god; he deposited the vessels in the treasury of his god."

Likely following this or a similar tradition, Targum Sheni on Esther 1:7 stated that the vessels eventually passed into the hands of Achashverosh, who used them during his feast. See likewise Bavli Megillah 12a, Esther Rabbah 2:11, Pirkei d'Rabbi Eliezer 49:9 and Yalkut Shimoni on Nach 1048:6.

A significantly more expanded and detailed tradition regarding the locations of the vessels from the First Temple appears in an anonymous midrash called Massechet Kelim (not to be confused with the Shas tractate by the same name), first published in Rabbi Naftali Hertz Bachrach's Emek ha'Melech in the 17th century (Introduction, ch. 11). The midrash describes five men - Shimor the Levite, Chizkiyah, Tzidkiyah, Chaggai the Prophet and Zecharyah b. Ido the Prophet - gathering together and burying the vessels in various locations: a few in Eretz Yisrael but most in Babylon. Interestingly, after discovering the Copper Scroll among the Dead Sea Scrolls, it was noted that there are a few similar details between the two texts. One suggested interpretation of this connection is that the anonymous author of Massechet Kelim built upon the foundations of a tradition regarding the location of the Temple vessels that was also shared (or some variant of it) by the author who composed the Copper Scroll.

It should be noted that a variant of Massechet Kelim was found inscribed on a marble slab from Lebanon sometime during the first half of the 20th century. The most notable addition to the text was the mention of four copies of the text, one on a deerskin, and the location of some of the vessels at Mt. Carmel. As much as I've managed to discover, the inscription has not been dated. The inscription was published here, pp. 567-575.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Rashi (Melachim 2, 16:14) writes that the Copper Mizbeach that Moshe made was buried:

ואת מזבח הנחשת ויקרב וגו' - אי אפשר לומר מזבח הנחשת שעשה משה שהרי נגנז

Midrash (Bamidbar Rabba, 15:10) seems to say that the Menorah was also buried:

אמר לו הקב"ה: לך אצל בצלאל והוא יעשה אותה, ואמר לבצלאל מיד עשאה. התחיל תמה ואמר: אני כמה פעמים הראה לי הקב"ה ונתקשיתי לעשותה, ואת שלא ראית עשית מדעתך? בצלאל, בצל א-ל היית עומד כשהראה לי הקב"ה עשייתה. ולפיכך כשחרב ביהמ"ק נגנזה המנורה, וזה אחד מחמשה דברים שנגנז: הארון, והמנורה, והאש, ורוח הקדש, והכרובים. וכשישוב הקב"ה ברחמיו ויבנה ביתו והיכלו הוא מחזירן למקומן לשמח את ירושלים

However, Avos d'Reb Nassan (41:12) provides an alternative list of the 5 things that were buried, and the implication is that the Menorah was not one of them, and lists the Menorah among the spoils that was taken to Rome.

חמשה דברים העשויין וגנוזין אלו הן: אהל מועד וכלים שבו, ארון ושברי לוחות, צנצנת המן, וצלוחית של שמן המשחה, והמטה, ומקלו של אהרן שקדיה ופרחיה. ובגדי כהונה ובגדי כהן משיח. אבל מכתשת של בית אבטינס שלחן ומנורה ופרוכת וציץ עדיין מונחין ברומי.

I am not entirely certain that the Menorah referred to here is the one from the First Beis Hamikdash (which was made by Moshe and Betzalel for the Mishkan), or the one that we know was taken by the Romans upon the destruction of the Second Beis Hamikdash (see Gittin 57 and Bereishis Raba 65:22). The context implies that this is the Menorah of the First Beis Hamikdash.
