title: How can Chazal identify chukim as mitzvos that aren't readily understandable if the nations will be positively impressed by them?
content:
# How can Chazal identify chukim as mitzvos that aren't readily understandable if the nations will be positively impressed by them? ## Frage

Devarim 4:6 reads as follows:

וּשְׁמַרְתֶּם וַעֲשִׂיתֶם כִּי הִוא חׇכְמַתְכֶם וּבִינַתְכֶם לְעֵינֵי הָעַמִּים אֲשֶׁר יִשְׁמְעוּן אֵת כׇּל הַחֻקִּים הָאֵלֶּה וְאָמְרוּ רַק עַם חָכָם וְנָבוֹן הַגּוֹי הַגָּדוֹל הַזֶּה.

Keep therefore and do them; for this is your wisdom and your understanding in the sight of the peoples, who shall hear all these statutes, and say, "Surely this great nation is a wise and understanding people."

Chazal identify חוקים as statutes that transcend reason and that if anything leave non-jews scratching their heads (e.g., ספרא ויקרא י"ח "וְאֶת חֻקֹּתַי תִּשְׁמְרוּ" – אֵלּוּ דְּבָרִים הַחֲקוּקִין בַּתּוֹרָה, שֶׁיֵּצֶר הָרָע מֵשִׁיב עֲלֵיהֶם, וְאֻמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם מְשִׁיבִין עֲלֵיהֶן.)

How does that identification jive with this pasuk?

(I am looking for something other than that they will praise them in light of the effect they have on Israel [as Malbim quotes from Ran] or as how Chazal seem to themselves be bothered by this and identify them as astronomical calculations [in B Shab 75a])

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)
  1. Moshe is using this word broadly to mean any law.
  2. If the Jews are meticulous in keeping the reasonable mitzvah, and gain a reputation for going out of the way to do righteousness, the goyim will assume that the Chukot also have some esoteric righteous reason behind them.
### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Very often, I see a comment from a non-Jew (and sometimes, from an estranged Jew), responding to a certain halacha with the following sarcastic comment:

Where in the Torah of Moses does it say you have to do that?

This comment will apply both to super rational mitzvot as much as rational mitzvot that they simply never saw a source for. Those who study Talmud and Halacha deeply know the answer, as they've witness the intellectual process of our Sages in deriving the Will of God (including Chukim) from the Torah - a truly remarkable process, if only someone would take the time to look at it honestly and non-cynically.

So I presume that at least part of the answer is that one day, when God Himself confirms that He is proud and approving of the work of the "Pharisees" and "Rabbinic Judaism", people will finally be impressed at the intellectual acumen. At that time, we know there will be a thirst for knowledge of God, and we also know that knowledge of God is primarily through His Laws (including Chukim), and therefore they will be so so impressed at the amount of knowledge of God the Jewish people have generated through their study, and under the conditions that they were subjected to!

On top of that, they will see how it is those very laws themselves (including Chukim) that have caused the Jews to be so successful at becoming Godly, holy, and produce healthy, homes that kept our nation everlasting in said conditions.

All in all, I don't see a problem here.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

Take a look at the kli yakar. He interprets the verse to mean that G-d is promising the Jewish people that despite the seemingly nonsensical nature of chukim, the esteem the nations of the world have for the Jews will not be diminished.

For further reading, here is an excerpt from a piece I wrote for a local weekly:

“ושמרתם ועשיתם כי היא חכמתכם ובינתכם לעיני העמים אשר ישמעון את כל החוקים האלה” (דברים ד:ו) You shall safeguard [them] and perform them, for it is your wisdom and understanding in the eyes of the peoples who shall hear all these statutes… רש''י:בזאת תחשבו חכמים ונבונים לעיני העמים Through this you will be considered wise and understanding in the eyes of the peoples. (Artscroll Translation) In other words, solely through keeping Hashem’s Mitzvos will we achieve prestige among non-Jews.

Up until today there exists a fallacy that has persisted among many Jews throughout History. That is, that in order to be held in high esteem among the Gentiles, we must endeavour to impress them with our worldliness, our sophistication, our Nobel prize record. But the Torah (and History) reveal to us that the opposite is true. The more we attempt to prove ourselves to them, the less they respect us. (In the words of Rabbi Lord Jonathan Sacks, “Non-Jews respect Jews who respect their Judaism, and they are embarrassed by Jews who are embarrassed by their Judaism.”) What does seem a bit odd, however, is the Torah telling us this as a motive for us to keep the Torah. Surely the opinion of a bunch of Goyim shouldn’t be our primary motivation. Is there no better reason out there for us to do Mitzvos other than a bit of ego-stroking? The Kli Yakar provides the answer to this, with a basic yet profound psychological insight: For better or for worse, people are influenced by the opinions of others. Simply put, the Torah doesn’t mean to imply that the above is a reason to keep the Torah. Rather, it is addressing a part of our psyche that may be restricting our Avoidas Hashem - intimidated by fear of public opinion. It is this aspect of us that the Torah wishes to reassure that on the contrary – being a Torah-True Jew (TTJ) will earn us the respect of the world. (Hence the wording of the Posuk. כל החוקים – all of the Mitzvos. The intention is to include our performance of the Mitzvos Chuki’im, such as Shatnez or Parah Aduma, which lacking a human rationale, would seem to invite ridicule.)

The Lubavitcher Rebbe Zt”l in Likutei Sichos makes it clear that the Geula hinges on Jews feeling and acting as Jews in an increasingly secular world. It goes without saying that we should never allow the opinions of others to dictate the way we should live our lives. Secular ideals and cultures have no place in our homes and our communities. R’ Moshe Shternbuch Shlit”a interprets the Posuk (Al Pi a Gemara in Taanis) “Eretz…” – “a land whose stones are iron” – that our leaders need to be strong like iron, to prevent our communities falling to the winds of change.

R’ Sacks adds that “Ambivalence spells the end of identity, because it cannot be passed on to our children.” Only a strong sense of mission will enable the continuity of Klal Yisroel.

title: Did G-d foresee the sin of knowledge?
content:
# Did G-d foresee the sin of knowledge? ## Frage

BH

I heard that if a person sinned, then all of his sins were Hashgacha pratit, after the fact, although before the fact, if there is something bad that a person knows, he shouldn't do it.

So did Hashem know that Adam and Eve would sin? If yes how come he made that happen in the first place? Is it considered hashgacha pratit and was it suppose to happen? If yes how come? Also how was life before in Gan Eden? Was it only spiritual and not physical, e.g. the whole world was all like a fire that is in a potential way, i.e. hidden inside a coal?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Hashem wanted Adam and Chava to eat the fruit, but He wanted them to volunteer. He therefore set things up that they should figure it out and do so. The reason is because it is better to be a Baal Teshuva than a Tzaddik, and as a result we would be able to not only reach a higher potential ourselves, but also have the opportunity to bring Hashem Himself in His full Essence into the world, completing the ultimate purpose of creation which is Dira Betachtonim.

You can find a source for your first paragraph here. As for Gan Eden before the sin, please ask that as a separate question.

Sources: Basi Legani 1972, Midrash Tanchuma Vayeshev 4 (thanks @shmosel!!), Rabbi Manis Friedman Shlita.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

So did Hashem know that Adam and Eve would sin? If yes how come he made that happen in the first place? Is it considered hashgacha pratit and was it suppose to happen? If yes how come?

There is a slightly different spin from Rabbi Kaii's answer that I saw in the book "Where's My Miracle" by R. Morey Schwartz, p. 119-125, which is really close in spirit to Midrash Tanchuma Vayeshev 4.

G-d created humankind in His image by giving Adam and Eve the freedom to make their own personal choices. I.e. they were not compelled to make an action (eat, drink, procreate, etc.) based on instinct, but through a freedom of their personal sophisticated choices, unlike all other creatures. Humankind, however from the outset was not satisfied with their blessing of choice. As they sought to choose between better over good, G-d wanted that they obtain capacity to reason, to weigh pros and cons of a situation, and then expand their choices to include capacity of choosing bad over good, and willing to suffer potential consequences of such a decision.

The snake nachash, which excited Eve, represented the capacity to use one's own intelligence to discern right from wrong, good from evil. (Similarly to how Yosef stated regarding the goblet nachesh yenachesh (Bereshis 44:15) and Rashi there explains used my own intelligence and logical deduction.) Thus, the Tree of Knowledge was not necessarily a test, but rather means through which G-d enabled the first humans beings explore their capacity for judgement. It taught them that when they use their G-d like priviledge of reason and discernment, they by nature of their humanity will sometimes choose erroneously, and will at times perforce suffer the consequences.

Also how was life before in Gan Eden? Was it only spiritual and not physical, e.g. the whole world was all like a fire that is in a potential way, i.e. hidden inside a coal?

I agree that this is a separate question, one of the possible references is Sanhedrin 59b.

title: How to live in the times of Mashiach right now
content:
# How to live in the times of Mashiach right now ## Frage

BH

I heard that the Baal Shem Tov says that you are where your thoughts are. I also heard that certain big tzadikim, like Rabbi Shimon Bar Yochai, lived in a level of Torah in which the Temple was never destroyed. I also heard one of the big students of the Magid of Mezritch was living in a level of the times of Mashiach. I also heard—correct me if I’m wrong—that even all the students of the Mittler Rebbe were living in the times of Mashiach, like he was already there

What does this mean? I heard that Rambam says—correct me if I’m wrong—that a person shouldn’t think so much about the future redemption, like what will happen after mashiach comes and such (even though I know he also says that a person should await his coming every day, and that if he doesn’t, he doesn’t believe in Torat Moshe at all).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Learning halachos of korbanos is equivalent to bringing korbanos. The same can be said regarding laws of ritual purity that we do not observe. With laws of zeraim there is a difference in opinions, but there are opinions stating that learning is like practicing and practicing is also like learning. When the Temple is going to be rebuilt we will practice all the mitzvos.

However, there is more than just learning. There is a clear responsibility for situations when one did an aveira, even b'shogeg, - one has to do teshuvah and attone bringing a korban. There is no police, but only a personal response regardless of what other people will see one bringing many such korbanos. One has to address missing opportunities for positive commandments, etc. Sha'arei Teshuvah by Rabbeinu Yonah speaks a lot about how to develop such a sensitivity to doing mitzvos.

title: Is Baal teshuvah really greater than a tzadik according to the Mittler rebbe
content:
# Is Baal teshuvah really greater than a tzadik according to the Mittler rebbe ## Frage

BH

I heard in the name of the Mittler Rebbe that although a Baal Teshuvah can reach greater heights through his repentance than a tzaddik ordinarily would, the tzaddik can reach even higher levels by overcoming the challenges of the world. If this is true, what is the source of this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I'm no Lubavitcher but I heard from Rabbi Shapiro of Miami who used to write the Likkutey Sichos for and in collaboration with the seventh Lubavitcher Rebbe that he once said on Makom she’baalei teshuva omdim ein tzadikim gemurim yecholim la’amod bo - In the place where a baal teshuva, stands, even complete Tzadikim cannot stand mean what it says- they can not get there even if they try. Afterwards his brother in law, Rabbi Shemaryahu Gururi, challenged him on the truth of his understanding and asked what is based on. The seventh Lubavitcher Rebbe acknowledged that he has no source for his understanding but claimed that his understanding is the simple and correct meaning of what the Gemora is saying.

Being that neither of them made any reference to the Mittler Rebbe having said what he is quoted as saying in the OP it is unlikely that he said it.

(This isn't meant to say it isn't true. Only to question if the Mittler Rebbe is the source)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The original source is Brachos 34b:

Rabbi Abbahu said: In the place where penitents stand, even the full-fledged righteous do not stand

In the gemara it's brought as a dispute, but the Rambam rules according to the latter view:

A Baal-Teshuvah should not consider himself distant from the level of the righteous because of the sins and transgressions that he committed. This is not true. He is beloved and desirable before the Creator as if he never sinned. Furthermore, he has a great reward for he has tasted sin and yet, separated himself from it, conquering his [evil] inclination. Our Sages declared: "In the place where Baalei Teshuvah stand, even the completely righteous are not able to stand." The level of Baalei Teshuvah transcends the level of those who never sinned at all, for they overcome their [evil] inclination more.

Zohar expresses a similar idea:

Happy are the penitent, who in one hour, one day, one moment, get as close to the Holy One, blessed be He, as most righteous come to the Holy One, blessed be He, over several years. Abraham did not come into the supernal days until he was old, as has been explained. Neither did David, as it is written, "Now King David was old, advanced in years (lit. 'coming with the days')" (I Kings 1:1). But a penitent comes right in and cleaves to the Holy One, blessed be He.

Rabbi Yosi said, We learned that the wholly righteous have no permission to be in that place where the contrite stand. They are closer to the King than everyone else and draw plenty from above with a more intent heart and greater force in order to come closer to the King.

The concept is ubiquitous in chassidus, from Tanya through the Rebbe, to the extent that a common expression (paraphrased from Zohar) is משיח אתא לאתבא צדיקיא בתיובתא, "Moshiach will bring the righteous to repentance." That is, he will impart in them the quality of Teshuvah they normally lack. Since you asked, here's one excerpt (among many) from the Mitteler Rebbe expressing this idea:

כענין צדיקים גמורים שיכולים לעמוד ולהגיע במקום בעלי תשובה כאשר עושים תשובה דוקא, ואם לאו אינם יכולים לעמוד כלל במקום שבעלי תשובה עומדים, שהוא בחינת החשך העליון שקדם לאור דתיקון

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

It's understandable that a baal teshuva could go higher than a tzaddik. After all, the Mishnah says: "The reward is proportional to the effort" [Avot 5:23]. For example, a baal teshuva who grew up eating bacon-cheeseburgers may miss them terribly and has to work hard to stay away from them, but for one who grew up observant the very thought of them makes him throw up.

title: How would the Hebrews have light on Shabbat?
content:
# How would the Hebrews have light on Shabbat? ## Frage

How did the Hebrews have light on Shabbat when it’s against Torah to light a fire.

Or say if it went out and it was pitch black, or very cold?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

As already pointed out in the comments, the prohibition of lighting fire on Shabbat is only if one light it on that day. One can light fire before shabbat and have it burn throughout.

If the fire went out in certain instances one can ask a non jew to create a fire, for example if children are afraid in the dark, or if people are cold.

In circumstances where a Jewish life might be endangered without a lit fire, a Jew himself is obligated to light the fire.

Important - the above scenarios are nuanced and have more details which i left out.

title: Why can't wrong-owner intention refer to a communal bull?
content:
# Why can't wrong-owner intention refer to a communal bull? ## Frage

If someone slaughters a designated-as-pesach animal in the month of (for example) Adar, and has in mind that it should be a pesach, it's invalid, since that's the wrong time to pring a pesach. However, if one slaughters a pesach animal in Adar and has in mind that it should be a sh'lamim, it's valid as a sh'lamim.

The Bavli, P'sachim 60–61, asks whether this wrong-intention logic applies also to wrong intention for who's bringing it. Specifically, suppose someone slaughters Person A's pesach in Adar, intending it as Person B's pesach. Normally, if someone slaughters an animal (actually, sprinkles its blood on the altar, but let's not get into those details now) with the wrong supplicant in mind, the korban is invalid. But Rav Papa in the g'mara proposes that this one should be valid as a sh'lamim, just like the other wrong-intention case.

Rava refutes this comparison by citing four ways that wrong-supplicant intention is a weaker wrong than wrong-type-of-offering intention is. One of those ways is that wrong-supplicant intention ruins only an individual's offering, not a communal one, whereas wrong-type-of-offering intention ruins also a communal offering.

On the idea that wrong-supplicant intention does not ruin a communal offering, Rashi explains:

Because for whom would his wrong intention be, that would not be its actual owners?

If the central sanhedrin rules something is permitted, and most of the people follow that ruling, but really it would normally require bringing a chatas if done unintentionally, then not most of the people bring a chatas. Rather, as Rambam (Sh'gagos 12.1) rules,

each and every tribe brings a bull as a chatas.

So why can't wrong-supplicant intention apply to a communal offering, namely the communal bull? The one bringing it can have the wrong tribe in mind.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Rabbi Yaakov Yitzchak Ruderman answers:

… according to my explanation [see context there –ed.] that "each tribe is called a community" means each tribe is like all of Israel and its offering is like an offering from all of Israel (for indeed we see that even if one tribe sins all twelve bring a bull apiece), so [the twelve bulls] constitute one big offering from all of Israel, and thus one can't speak of "slaughtering A's offering for B" since A's offering is also B's.

title: What is the Halacha if I pronounced הוליכך with a patach under the כ instead of a shva?
content:
# What is the Halacha if I pronounced הוליכך with a patach under the כ instead of a shva? ## Frage

I realize that this question may be quite specific but this is something that I am genuinely concerned about and I am beating myself up for it.

I leined this Mincha on Shabbat. In the leining, I think I pronounced it as אשר הוליכַךָ instead of אשר הוליכְךָ (with a patach under the כ instead of a shva).

It may sound ridiculous but I feel like I may have invalidated the kriyah altogether because of that and I feel very sad about it and it's affecting my self-esteem.

What's the Halacha? Does it count as a kosher leining?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Yeah, you’re completely fine. In the pronunciation of the Tiberian Masorites—who invented the niqqud symbols to reflect their own system of pronunciation—Shva was pronounced as a chataf-Patach. (There are exceptions, but this isn’t one of them). In fact, some Masoretic manuscripts mark this vowel with a chataf-Patach, a custom followed by some modern Chumashim.

If you prolonged or stressed the Patach, the above would not apply, since in the Tiberian tradition, Shva and the chataf vowels were pronounced quickly and unemphasized.

However, there would still be no issue, for the simple reason that putting a Patach (or Kamatz, or Segol) in this location would not affect the meaning of the word. Originally, before the Masoretic era, the vowel before the ךָ suffix was always what we would call a Patach, regardless of pausal form. This vowel is also where the emphasis would fall (see row 4 in linked source, under PH and EBHP).

And remember: Even if you had made a real mistake, it’s fine. That’s how humans are. It’s wonderful that you care about doing this correctly, but please, don’t beat yourself up over it.

### Antwort 2 (Score: -2)

you didn't change a meaning to something else, so it is fine, but chataf patach under non גרוניות is just sheva with horizontal line indicating that sheva is נע and not נח at least according to תורת הקורא.

title: Do we believe in objective morality?
content:
# Do we believe in objective morality? ## Frage

title: Do we believe there’s 100% proof Hashem exists
content:
# Do we believe there’s 100% proof Hashem exists ## Frage

Do we believe that (nowadays at least) there’s 100% proof that Hashem exists and it’s a mitzvah to go and discover that proof and “know” that there’s a G-d, or do we believe that, although many signs might point to it, there’s no actual 100% proof Hashem exists but rather we have faith that He does.

During let’s say the midbar times, when the people actually saw G-d, there you’d say that they had 100% proof. But nowadays, do we believe there’s 100% solid proof out there and that we must seek it out, or is our faith simply “blind faith”

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Rambam held that the 13 Articles of Faith needed to be accepted because of proofs. Not "believed", not accepted because you were taught them by an authority figure or read them in a book. But each person should be able to prove them for themselves. (Igeres Taiman)

R Chaim Heller noted in his translation of Sefer haMitzvos (1914) that the Rambam uses the Judeo-Arabic word "itakad", which means "knowledge". R Yosef el-Qafih, commonly known as Rav Kapach (of the Yemenite community) has a similar footnote in his translation (1994).

One could ascribe to the element of the Rambam's position that emunah is knowledge without agreeing to the facet of his position that you asked about -- that knowledge is most centrally something you can prove. At least, not in the sense of a philosophical proof.

Perhaps the most famous line in Epistemology is Plato's definition of "knowledge" as "a justified true belief." (That definition is flawed, most famously by the Gettier Problem, but it's still the basis of all such discussion.) There are other ways to justify belief than Philosophical Proof.

Before the Rambam, Rav Yehudah haLevi (Kuzari sec. 1) even belittles the entire concept of philosophically proving this kind of thing. In his dialog, he has the Rabbi say (1:13):

That which you describe is religion based on speculation and system, the research of thought, but open to many doubts. Now ask the philosophers, and thou will find that they do not agree on one set of actions or one principle, since some doctrines can be established by arguments, which are only partially satisfactory, and still much less capable of being proved.

And later in that section (1:63), he pardons the Greek philosophers for their errors in that they lacked a tradition and had to rely on a second-best -- philosophical deduction:

There is an excuse for the Philosophers. Being Grecians, science and religion did not come to them as inheritances. They belong to the descendants of Japheth, who inhabited the north, whilst that knowledge coming from Adam, and supported by the divine influence, is only to be found among the progeny of Shem, who represented the successors of Noah and constituted, as it were, his essence. This knowledge has always been connected with this essence, and will always remain so...

Skipping out of our tradition and ahead to Modern Philosophy...

This skepticism about the perfection of proof becomes fundamental to the Empiricists, who believed that only experience of the outside world can produce reliable knowledge. And then it really came to the fore with Immanuel Kant, who denied our ability to experience what's really "out there" altogether. That because everything we experience and think are shaped by pre-existing human categories, the way people work, none of it is real and objective. We only know the world of phenomena, how things look to humans, and only can reason with those more limited givens.

And this progresses through the Existentialists and the Post-Moderns. So that today, in most College Liberal Arts departments, there is no concept of objective truth altogether. Never mind being able to prove things.

I think the Kuzari's argument would be classified today as a kind of Reliabilism. We trust our Tradition because it comes from sources that have proved themselves reliable in the past. Which is a way to justify belief, so -- contrary to the Rambam -- today's philosophers would consider trusting a fact because you were taught it bey someone you trust would be considered knowledge.

Another possible justification could be first-hand experience. And I think this happens far more often today. Someone experiences their first Shabbos. It agrees with them, provides meaning to their lives. I don't just mean the aesthetics, that they enjoyed themselves, but the experience itself -- the thing they enjoyed. Like the way mathematicians are likely to agree on what makes a proof "beautiful" or "elegant", there is an objective feature they are identifying and giving an aethetic judgement about. That math proof, or living that Shabbos, has the features one expects of truth.

Or, when you learn something about the laws of property that somehow has implications in the laws of Shabbos and resolve what seemed to have been an unrelated question. Truth works like that, not invented systems. If this happens to someone when learning Torah often enough, they stop wondering whether or not they can prove the Torah is from Hashem. Or whether halakhah as we now practice it, which is largely a product of a system, is a product of the system Hashem gave us at Sinai. It seems obviously so.

The experience of living Judaism as justification for the givens assumed by the Judaism lived.

Speaking for myself. I do believe a philosophical proof does exist. But, just to frustrate the Rambam, I don't think we could identify it. We have too many of what Mussarists call "negi'os", personal ulterior motives, that color our vision. Our ideas of what is a self-evident given that could be used as a postulate for an argument start getting subjective as soon as we go much beyond "x = x". Similarly, our sense of which questions refute the whole argument or are interesting little side challenges that could be shelved for later. They all are so colored by what we want the answer to be that a person couldn't identify a solid argument for or against their position.

Not when dealing with something we are so emotionally invested in as a question that changes how we live our lives.

Or, to rephrase as a Truism:
The mind is a wonderful organ
for proving conclusions
the heart already reached.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The Rambam in Hilchot Yesodei Hatora Chapter 1, Halacha 1 says "יְסוֹד הַיְסוֹדוֹת וְעַמּוּד הַחָכְמוֹת לֵידַע שֶׁיֵּשׁ שָׁם מָצוּי רִאשׁוֹן" "The foundation of all foundations and the pillar of wisdom is to know that there is a Prime Cause"

Apparently the Rambam holds it is a Mitzvah to prove the existence of God.

The Rambam himself provides a demonstration from the science of his times to prove God. Apparently he holds that in each time we would need to look to the physical world to reach a point in our understanding that would demonstrate the existence of God.

Here is a link to modern approach to "prove" God. https://www.physicstogod.com/

They do an excellent job of demonstrating a "proof" for the existence of God.

### Antwort 3 (Score: -1)

There is no proof that God exists, and there cannot be one. It's 100% a matter of faith. You can never be sure that what you see and experience is not the work of a powerful alien with super-advanced technology, who has no more answers to ultimate questions than we do.

Think how easy it would be to convince a primitive islander of 500 years ago that you are God. You land in a helicopter, cure his sick with antibiotics, use a machine gun or a grenade to show him who is boss, magnify your voice with a loudspeaker, etc.

title: 1 amen for 2 berachot?
content:
# 1 amen for 2 berachot? ## Frage

If I say בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה ה', שׁוֹמֵר אֶת־עַמּוֹ יִשְׂרָאֵל לָעַד אָמֵן, does the אמן at the end count towards a response to a Beracha I heard at the same time? E.g. if the Chazzan says Kaddish, and that Amen times perfectly to be one of the Amens for it?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 10)

The Mishneh Berurah O.C 124 Seif Katan 25 says:

מי שנזדמן לו לענות אמן על ב' דברים עונה שני אמנים זה אחר זה ויכוין בכל אמן את הענין על מה הוא עונה וטפי עדיף לומר אמן ואמן:

"One who happens to answer Amen to two (different) things should recite two Amens, one after the other, and should intend with each 'Amen' the specific matter to which he is responding; and it is more preferable to say 'Amen VeAmen'."

Mishneh Berurah in O.C 61 Seif Katan 28 says:

ואם נזדמן לו לענות על ב' דברים אפשר דאמן אחד יעלה לכאן ולכאן ואם יאמר אמן ואמן עדיף טפי

"And if it happens that one needs to answer Amen for two (different) things, it is possible that one Amen can count for both. However, if he says 'Amen VeAmen, it is preferable."

So in Siman 61, it seems that he raises the possibility that one amen would be good for both brachot.

title: Can one repair an "Amen Chatufa"?
content:
# Can one repair an "Amen Chatufa"? ## Frage

Going by the second definiton of an Amen Chatufa in Shulchan Aruch OC 124:8, i.e. saying Amen before the Beracha one is responding to is finished - is it possible to repair this or has the opportunity been lost? I.e. if one realises one did it, and then says Amen again (still in time to not be an Amen Yetoma - an Amen said too late), has one said Amen?

Does it make a difference if the utterance of the Amen Yetoma began before the Beracha finished but ended after it finished?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

In the Sefer נוטרי אמן חלק ב פרק ז footnote ג he states that if someone responds with an Amen Chatufa (or Yetoma), it’s as though they haven’t answered amen to the bracha, and it doesn’t count.

Although I haven't seen him address if it's possible to repair an amen katufa, logically we can ask the same question by brachot (which is more stringent in the fact that Hashem's name is involved). Where if one says a bracha too early, i.e. saying brachot kriat shema before Alot Hashachar, etc (where the bracha is not good), can one say the bracha again at the correct time later? The answer would seem (and haven't seen anyone disagree) that one is able to do so, since he still has the ability to say the bracha at the correct time (we don't punish the person, and he should say baruch shem etc).

The same in regards to answering amen, one can answer amen even if he won't hear the end of the bracha, as long as you know which bracha is being said and heard certain important words which would be מעכב, as stated by Rav Ovadia in Halichot Olam 1:195, and also brought down in Shulchan Aruch O.C 215:2 with commentaries there.

Therefore if one says amen and there is still time for it not to be an Amen Yetoma, one can still answer amen.

title: Is there a source for there being a Psalm inscribed on King David's shield?
content:
# Is there a source for there being a Psalm inscribed on King David's shield? ## Frage

I've been told that the Magen David was found on King David's shield (although sources for that seem scarce).

I recently heard that King David had Psalm 67 inscribed on the back of his shield in the shape of a Menorah.

Has anybody else heard that and is there any source that confirms this tradition?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Chidah in מדבר קדמות מערכת ד אות כב says:

דוד הע"ה הראהו הקב"ה ברוח הקדש מזמור למנצח בנגינות מזמור שיר אלהים יחננו וכו' כתוב על טס של זהב מופז עשוי בצורת מנורה וכן הראה אותו למשה רבינו ע"ה. והיה דוד הע"ה נושא זה המזמור כתוב ומצוייר וחקוק במגינו בטס של זהב כצורת מנורה כשהיה יוצא למלחמה והיה מכוין סודו והיה נוצח אותם ואויביו נופלים לפניו. קונטרס מנורת זהב כ"י מועתק מכ"י הרב מהר"ר חיים באכנר זלה"ה בעל אור חדש על דיני ברכות והעיד הרב מהר"ח הנז' שהוא העתיקו מכתיבת יד הקדש של הגאון מהרש"ל ז"ל ושם כתוב סודות ונפלאות הרמוזות במזמור הנזכר

"David Hamelech was shown by Hashem through Ruach Hakodesh, psalm 67 which was written on a plate of refined gold, crafted in the shape of a menorah. This was also shown to Moshe Rabbeinu. David Hamelech would carry this Psalm, inscribed and engraved in the shape of a menorah on a golden plate, in his shield when he went out to battle. He would focus on its secret meaning and would defeat his enemies, who would fall before him. This is from מנורת זהב copied from the manuscript of Rabbi Chaim Bachrach author of אור חדש on the laws of blessings. Rabbi Chaim Bachrach testified that he copied it from the Maharshal where secrets and wonders related to the mentioned Psalm are written."

title: Did the English Koren-Steinsaltz Utilize an Erroneous Translation for Meilah 7b?
content:
# Did the English Koren-Steinsaltz Utilize an Erroneous Translation for Meilah 7b? ## Frage

The Talmud in Meilah 7b records a back and forth between R Yochanan and Reish Lakish regarding a position of R Akiva. R Yochanan finally gets the best of Reish Lakish and states (per Sefaria Meilah 7b The William Davidson Talmud (Koren - Steinsaltz):

אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: קַצֵּצְתִּינּוּן לְרַגְלוֹהִי דְיָנוֹקָא.

Rabbi Yoḥanan said in this regard: We have cut off the legs of the child, i.e., I have refuted Reish Lakish’s opinion by raising a difficulty that eliminates the basis for his opinion.

Why did he say, 'we have cut off'? He refuted R Lakish on his own! I have checked other translations which use "I."

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 11)

In fact he does say "I" in the singular. קַצֵּצְתִּ-ינּוּן means I cut them off (as opposed to קצצנא or קצצינן which would mean "we cut off"). The more familiar suffix for "them" in the Babylonian Talmud would be קצצתינהו, but Rabbi Yochanan is speaking in his own (Israeli) dialect which is more common in the Targumim (וְשִׁנַּנְתָּם לְבָנֶיךָ = וּתְתַנֵּינוּן לִבְנָךְ).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

The English Koren - Steinsaltz has messed up R' Steinsaltz's Hebrew translation many times. Here, R' Steinsaltz translates it as I, and Koren changed it to we. They do something similar in Niddah 19a.

I forgot the exact location but somewhere in Eruvin, R' Steinsaltz explains a Gemara like Rashi does and Koren completely deviates from his translation and makes up their own explanation (which I didn't find anywhere else when I quickly looked around).

title: Making a bracha mentally in case of doubt
content:
# Making a bracha mentally in case of doubt ## Frage

Normally, in cases where the necessity of a bracha is in doubt, we say safek brachos lehakel—skip the bracha rather than risk making one in vain. But there are opinions that you can make a bracha mentally in cases where you're unable to make one verbally. Does anyone recommend doing so in case of a safek? Or could it still be considered a bracha levatala?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

In two places (Yabia Omer 9 O.C 98:10, Yabia Omer 4 O.C 2:12) Rav Ovadia quotes many Achronim who say that there is no bracha levatala if one makes a bracha mentally.

As to if this is recommended, Rav Ovadia cites the Kaf Hachaim (O.C 174 Seif Katan 49, O.C 184 Seif Katan 22, O.C 185 Seif Katan 5) that one should mentally say the bracha in a case of a safek. He also quotes the Ben Ish Chai (Vayeshev 6 and 12, Achrei Mot/Kedoshim 13, etc) who says the same. And it's only because of Midat Chasidut.

Nusach sefard, sefardim and maybe others have the following nusach for Kaddish:

יתגדל ויתקדש שמה רבא (אמן) בעלמא די ברא כרעותה וימליך מלכותה ויצמח פורקנה ויקרב משיחה (אמן) בחייכון וביומיכון ובחיי דכל בית ישראל בעגלא ובזמן קריב ואמרו אמן (אמן)...

(Translation by sefaria)

title: Why is there a custom to say "Kiddush Levana" (Moon Blessing) on Motsaei Tisha Be'av?
content:
# Why is there a custom to say "Kiddush Levana" (Moon Blessing) on Motsaei Tisha Be'av? ## Frage

Why do some have the custom to say Kiddush (Birkat) Levana on Motsaei Tisha Ba'Av and not on the Shabbat after it (or before it)? After all, it is customary to say Kiddush Levana on Motsaei Shabbat is said out of joy and in nice clothes. And we don't wear nice clothes on Tisha Be'Av? And if the temple is not built, then there is no joy either? And besides, the people are hungry after the fast. If so, why did they use to say precisely on Motsaei Tisha Be'Av?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

Why not say kiddush levanah on the motzaei shabbat before tish'ah be-av?

Rema Orach Chaim 426:2 (quoting Maharil) writes that one does not recite kiddush levanah before tishah be-av. Mishnah Berurah 8 explains that this is because before tish'ah be-av one is in the midst of mourning.

(However, it is worth noting the custom recorded in Aruch HaShulchan 551:22 to ignore this Maharil and rather to recite kiddush levanah before tish'ah be-av -- as we don't want to delay a mitzvah, and out of concern for subsequent cloudy nights. That was also the practice of the Vilna Gaon (Maaseh Rav 159).)

OK. So why not say it on the motzaei shabbat after tish'ah be-av?

Kiddush levanah can only be said until the moon becomes full (approximately on the fifteenth of the month; see Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim 426:3.) Thus when the ninth of Av falls on shabbat or Sunday, one cannot wait until the following motzaei shabbat (the night of 16th or 17th of Av) as it is very likely to be too late.

Even when tish'ah be'av falls on Tuesday, one would not want to wait until motzaei shabbat (the night of the 14th of Av) in case there are a few cloudy nights and he ends up missing the opportunity. (See Rema Orach Chaim 426:2, quoting the Terumat HaDeshen, that in any month one does not wait to say kiddush levanah on motzaei shabbat past the tenth of the month.)

When tish'ah be-av falls on Thursday, Rema in Darchei Moshe (quoted in Mishnah Berurah 10) indeed rules that one waits to say kiddush levanah on the following motzaei shabbat (the night of the twelfth of Av), notwithstanding the general rule of not waiting past the tenth quoted in the previous paragraph.

So kiddush levanah in Av is generally not going to be done on motzaei shabbat. But why do it on motzaei tish'ah be-av?

This is a great question. Rema Orach Chaim 426:2 specifically says not to recite kiddush levanah on motzaei tish'ah be'av, and instead do it on a subsequent night, although not (in general) waiting for motzaei shabbat. Levush ibid. :4 writes such as well. Mishnah Berurah 10 explains (as you note in your question) that motzaei tish'ah be'av is not a time of joy. (Presumably, Rema would also instruct you to put on nice clothes when you recite kiddush levanah on a weeknight following motzaei tish'ah be-av, as he rules in general regarding reciting kiddush levanah on a weeknight (462:2).)

However, as you observe, many people do not follow this ruling of Rema, and do recite kiddush levanah on motzaei tish'ah be'av.

Mishnah Berurah 11 quotes "the acharonim" as permitting this practice, but notes the incongruity of reciting kiddush levanah while still fasting and not wearing shoes. He therefore writes that one should eat something and put on one's shoes before reciting kiddush levanah on motzaei tish'ah be'av. (In Sha'ar HaTziyun 9, he points out that if waiting to eat will cause one to miss reciting kiddush levanah with the community, it is better to recite it with them before eating, due to the principle of berov am hadrat melech.)

If we rule against the Rema, then kiddush levanah in Av can be done on motzaei tish'ah be-av. Is there a specific reason to do so, rather than waiting until a later night?

Baer Heitev to Orach Chaim 551:8 notes the Arizal's directive to specifically recite kiddush levanah on motzaei tisha'ah be-av, as it is the time of Mashiach's birth, which ties in thematically with the rebirth of the moon.

On a more practical level, we pointed out that one is not supposed to wait past the tenth of the month to recite kiddush levanah, out of concern for cloudy nights. That being the case, once we rule that it is permitted to recite kiddush levanah on motzaei tisha'ah be-av (the tenth of Av), my assumption is that one should specifically do so, to minimize the chances of missing it (as well as the general principle of doing mitzvot as speedily as possible). See Kenesset HaGedolah, Orach Chaim 426 who invokes the worry about cloudy nights as a reason to not push off reciting kiddush levanah from motzaei tish'ah be-av.

Further, in many communities, I imagine that arvit on motzaei tish'ah be-av attracts larger crowds than a regular weeknight arvit. Therefore, it makes sense to me for those communities to specifically recite kiddush levanah then, to increase the chances of more members of the community reciting it that month.

title: When is a convert's birthday?
content:
# When is a convert's birthday? ## Frage

Birthdays are relevant in various halachic contexts.

  • The Ben Ish Chai says one should have a seuda and do learning on one's birthday (Re'eh 17).
  • One's age is determined by one's birthday, so calculating when one is 25 (Chazal say one should marry before 25 - Beit Shmuel 1:5; full footnote to Peninei Halacha Simchat Habayit U'Virchato 5:9:5), or calculating when one is 20 (the age when one can get the punishment of Karet) etc is relevant.
  • It can come up in a case of an oath, if someone swears to do something by the time they are 30, for example.

So, it seems that halacha does care about when someone's birthday is, even if "birthdays" are not a big deal in Judaism as a whole.

So my question is, when is a converts birthday?

title: Why thank HaShem for skirting (larger) tragedy when He orchestrated the situation in the first place?
content:
# Why thank HaShem for skirting (larger) tragedy when He orchestrated the situation in the first place? ## Frage

If one subscribes to a theory of hashgacha that ascribes everything to HaShem (which altho not taken by most rishonim seems to be the prevailing opinion nowadays), then why, when say someone gets sick or injured, but avoids greater sickness/injury or better yet is ultimately fully healed, or for instance is involved in an mva but comes out with minor injuries only, etc, do people thank God for it?

After all, He is the one that orchestrated this tragic circumstance in the first place, and while it is nice that one wasn't hurt even worse, gratitude seems to be misplaced, as if it wasn't for HaShem orchestrating this hardship then there wouldn't have been any hardship at all.

By analogy, if someone breaks someone else's arm should he thank him for only breaking one arm or setting the broken arm in a cast to heal?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

I once heard a Mashal by the slavery in Mitzrayim.

A King sends his soldiers to battle. When the war is over, the King returns the armies, and then there is celebration, even though it was the King who sent the soldiers to battle. This is because sending them to battle was not the pleasure of the King; it was necessary, and unfortunate. However, it greatly delights the King to bring the soldiers home.

I think we can learn from this about what you ask about as well. When Hashem brings difficulties upon a person, He is only doing it because it is necessary, and ultimately for the good (which, when Moshiach comes, we will thank Him and bless Him for too). He does not take "pleasure" in it, so to speak - the opposite. Hashem suffers along with the person. However, when the "job is done", Hashem then heals the person with great love and delight, so to speak, and of course we thank Him for that.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The Creator wants us to acknowledge him in all our ways. The rabbis stated in tractate Bruchas "Would that people could pray all day long continually." This is one more opportunity to praise God. So, not only have we been saved- but we have been given a great opportunity.

title: Difference between Birkas haMazon and Amidah with the Sequence of Blessings
content:
# Difference between Birkas haMazon and Amidah with the Sequence of Blessings ## Frage

When we say Birkas haMazon (blessing after meals), the second blessing contains thanksgiving Node L'kha with the addition for Chanukah and Purim and the third blessing of Yerushalaim contains request for Avodah/Service in the Temple with addition of Ya'aleh v'Yavo on Rosh Chodesh and Moadim.

In the last 3 blessings of Amidah the order is reversed. We first request for Avodah in the Temple with addition of Ya'aleh v'Yavo on Rosh Chodesh and Moadim. Afterwards we say thanksgiving Modim with the addition for Chanukah and Purim.

What is the reason for such a reversed order?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

"When you have eaten your fill, you shall bless Hashem your God for the good land that He has given you." ((Deut.) Devarim 8:10)

The Talmud (Brachos 48b), explains that this mitzvah of blessing G-d after a meal (based on bread), is made of 4 blessings according to Jewish Law, and evolution. The first three blessings are directly relevant to the OP.

The first blessing of "Zan", was authored by Moshe Rabeinu in his times thanking G-d for the sustenance (as Moshe merited to receive the "Manna" from heaven which we ate for forty years).

The second blessing for "the Land of Israel", is attributed to Yehoshua bin Nun. He lead us in conquering Cana'an. By the time this blessing was enacted it marked the fact that Jews could finally fulfill the mitzvah of blessing after a meal for the first time in history as commanded. (The verse commanding blessing conditions the act of blessing on thanks for the Land.)

So once we miraculously received the land the second blessing is made for thanks and praise. Other things are then listed like Bris Milah, and Torah, and going out of Egyptian bondage. (without which nothing else was possible)

(The first blessing thanking for the miracle of Manna, would not have been appropriate to use to include references to thanks for the other items as we didn't have a land then; and Sichon and Og's lands didn't count as long as other Jews didn't have their land. Meanwhile since the Land is so significant, it rated its own seperate blessing. Once that happened, it became the blessing to list other items of thanks.)

So naturally, "Al HaNissim" for Channukah and Purim attaches to the second blessing for thanksgiving on the land and other miracles.

The third blessing is attributed to King David and King Solomon. In their time it was a pettition to build and establish Jerusalem and the Temple (and was so worded).

Nowadays we say it as a pettition to rebuild Jerusalem and the temple. Therefore mentioning things which are connected with the missing Temple service are attached to this blessing.

This includes "R'tzey" and "Yaaleh v'Yavo" for the Sabbath, Rosh Chodesh, and the Festivals which have Biblically mandated "Korbanos" (temple offerings), while Purim and Channukah have no such mandate in the Torah.

Finally, the fourth blessing was instituted by The Sages of Yavneh during Roman occupation, for thanking G-d that the slain Jews of the city of Beytar miraculously did not decompose and were finally allowed burial by the Romans.

This thanks deserved its own special Rabbinical blessing which would not have normally been listed in the second blessing of thanks since that blessing focuses on miracles like the land which are Biblical pre-requisites for living people to fully take part in mitzvos. (Bris, Land, freedom, Torah)

Therefore kindness to the dead was viewed as a special seperate blessing.

On the other hand.....

The Amidah prayer was compiled/formulated/standardized by The Men of the Great Assembly.(except for blessing 19 against heretics authored later in Roman times)

The blessing for the temple service follows immediately after a series of supplication requests ending in a request to ask G-d to return to Jerusalem and to return the Davidic dynasty. (followed by a general blessing for all possible requests)

The next blessing declares the return of the Temple Service which is the Biblical basis for pristine and organized prayers in the first place. So this follows in the previous order.

Since it addresses the Temple service itself, it is now appropriate to attach "Yaaleh v'Yavo" for Rosh Chodesh, and the Festivals which have Biblically mandated "Korbanos" (temple offerings), while Purim and Channukah (Al HaNissim), have no such mandate in the Torah.

The next blessing of thanksgiving (even if it might not be a "request") now includes thanks for everything from G-d, and for miracles such as those surrounding the holidays of Channukah and Purim; so "Al HaNissim" belongs here.

(Finally we beseech for Peace at the end of the Amidah because the Talmud explains Peace is the proper vessel by which all other blessing can be established properly so it must go at the end.)

So once you compare the way the blessing after a meal conforms with the verse commanding it and the evolution of Jewish history, and then realize how and why the Amidah prayer was formulated, the apparent contradictions or differences simply disappear.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The OP makes the observation that while the Blessing after Meals has thanks first and mention of the Temple Service second, the Amidah prayer mentions the Temple Service first and thanks second. The OP then demands to know the significance behind this difference.

The answer is that there is no significance as the two prayers are not comparative at all.

(If the mere initial observation of such a "difference in order" has deeper meaning, then the burden of proof is on the OP to show why.)

Blessing after the Meal is based on a requirement found in the verse:

"When you have eaten your fill, you shall bless Hashem your God for the good land that He has given you." ((Deut.) Devarim 8:10)

The Talmud (Brachos 48b), explains that the choice of order of the prayers in the Blessing after Meals evolved with Jewish history. Its order was therefore forced by history.

Moshe Rabeinu authored the first paragraph of blessing for sustenance (because he had the Manna). When Yehoshua conquered most of Eretz Yisroel, he authored the next paragraph of blessing for thanksgiving having received the Land of Israel. In fact the Land is central to the Biblical obligation to Bless after a meal. So such "thanks" belongs in the Blessing after Meals (and we customarily add other thanks here like Al Hanissim).

When The Jewish people were further established, G-d spoke to King David and King Solomon commanding the building of the permanent Temple in Jerusalem as mandated by Deut. Devarim 12:13-14 etc.

They in turn saw fit to add a petition in the Blessing after Meals for every Jew to ask G-d to build and establish Jerusalem and the Temple with its service (avodah).

Nowadays, we do so as a petition to ask G-d to rebuild and restore Jerusalem and the Temple service (after the destruction). Likewise we customarily add Yaaleh V'yavo here because Biblical holidays require Biblical Korbanos (sacrifices at the Temple).

Therefore the order of the paragraphs is forced by the chronology of Jewish history as appropriate.

On the other hand, the Amidah was standardized all at once by the men of the Great Assembly hundreds of years later (See Talmud, Megillah 17b). So the Sages were free to put thanks and avodah however and wherever they liked. But their reasons are beyond the scope of the OP.

In any case the choice of order of thanks and avodah in the Blessing after Meals and the order in the Amidah have no connection.

title: Fasting with a medical condition
content:
# Fasting with a medical condition ## Frage

My wife suffers from debilitating migraine headaches that cause vomiting and require medications and hours of bed rest in a dark room to recover. She has reached middle age and her condition is aggravated by fasting. She is very stubborn and insists on some sort of Rabbinical authorization in order not to fast when required by a particular holiday. Whom could I contact for such a thing or is there another way to prove to her that her health comes first?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

For cases of practical ruling, ask a competent rabbinic authority.

The Mishneh Berurah (551:4) rules unequivocally that a choleh/sick person - even a choleh she'ein lo sakanah/ non life-threatening condition - is exempt from fasting [the four fasts, not including Yom Kippur], and indeed forbidden to fast.

וכל שכן אם הוא חולה שאין בו סכנה, בוודאי פטור מלהתענות, ואסור לו להחמיר על עצמו

However, the rules for Yom Kippur are different. Nothing less than pikuach nefesh [or safek pikuach nefesh] would allow eating or drinking on Yom Kippur. Speak to a competent medical practitioner and then a competent halachic authority to ascertain whether a specific medical condition constitutes a safek pikuach nefesh.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

As was pointed out, the fast of Yom Kippur is Biblical in its requirement, and very strict, while he fast of 9th of Av is Rabbinical in nature but still strict, while other fasts are even more lenient et.

The truth is that it is correct for you and your wife to have a Rabbi who is knowlegable in Torah Law to guide you.

If you have no one that personally connects with you and your needs in your community, you might ask your doctor about it, and also call this resource to speak with a Rabbi and talk it over:

https://kavhalacha.org/medical-halacha/

May your wife become well from any trace of migraines and be able to enjoy life.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

From an article by Rabbi Eliezer Melamed, Rosh Yeshiva of Yeshivat Har Brachah and author of Peninei Halacha

> The Ill Are Exempt of Fasting

When the Prophets and sages instituted these fasts they did so with healthy people in mind. They did not legislate these fasts for sick people. In this sense, Yom Kippur is different than other fasts. On Yom Kippur, even the sick are obligated to fast because it is of biblical origin, and therefore only if the illness is so serious that fasting will be life endangering is he exempt from fasting - for preserving life takes precedence over Torah commandments. But when the sickness is not dangerous, on Yom Kippur one must fast and on other fasts instituted by the sages one is exempt.

As a rule, one whose suffering and weakness prevent him from going about his life as usual and force him to lie in bed is considered sick from the point of view of Jewish law. For example, a person who has the flu, angina (choking inflammation), or a high temperature, is exempt from fasting.

While fasting, almost everybody experiences a head-ache and weakness, and it is easier for one to lie down in bed than to carry on as usual. Sometimes the suffering experienced during a fast is greater than that felt by one who is sick with the flu. All the same, these feelings are not considered "sickness" in a halakhic sense; they are the natural results of fasting which are bound to disappear a number of hours after the fast. Therefore, one who is sick to the point that he must lie in bed as a result of his sickness is exempt from fasting, but one who suffers as a result of the fast itself is not. One who suffers from fasting to the point where he is no longer merely "afflicted" in the normal sense of one who fasts but has entered the realm of one who is seriously ill, is exempt from fasting.

A weak or very old person who knows that he will be discomforted by the fast and fears that the fast will cause him to lose his strength and become sick is exempt from fasting. The same goes for a person who recovered from sickness and fears that fasting will cause his sickness to return (Kaf HaChaim 550:6; 554:31).

Any person who knows that if he fasts he is bound to become sick is exempt from fasting. For example, a person who suffers from an active ulcer or severe migraine is exempt because the fast will quite likely awaken the malady. ...

...Any time a question arises, one must ask a Rabbi or a Torah-observant doctor.

Torah authorities teach that one who is permitted to eat on a fast day should at any rate refrain from partaking in delicacies and eat only that which is necessary. Such a person, however, is permitted to eat a full meal and drink as much as he desires, and there is no need for him to eat small portions at set intervals as is the rule on Yom Kippur. Only on Yom Kippur, because it is biblically mandated and even the sick are obligated in its fulfillment, must one who is permitted to eat consume small portions of food at intervals in order to (technically) avoid breaking the fast. On rabbinically-ordained fasts, the ill are not obligated to fast, and therefore there is no need for them to eat in the manner indicated.

It is also important to point out that one who is chronically ill or must take medicine on a regular basis, viz., one who is on antibiotics, must continue taking medicine on fast days. If possible, such a person should take the medicine without drinking water. One who needs to drink water in order to swallow the medicine should mix something with the water in order to cause it to become bitter, thus making the water "unfit for drinking." This is the kind of water that should be used when taking medicine on a fast day.

title: What mitzvos did Moshe Rabbeinu want to fulfill in Eretz Yisrael?
content:
# What mitzvos did Moshe Rabbeinu want to fulfill in Eretz Yisrael? ## Frage

The Gemara Sotah (14a) writes:

דָּרַשׁ רַבִּי שִׂמְלַאי: מִפְּנֵי מָה נִתְאַוָּה מֹשֶׁה רַבֵּינוּ לִיכָּנֵס לְאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל? וְכִי לֶאֱכוֹל מִפִּרְיָהּ הוּא צָרִיךְ?! אוֹ לִשְׂבּוֹעַ מִטּוּבָהּ הוּא צָרִיךְ?! אֶלָּא כָּךְ אָמַר מֹשֶׁה: הַרְבֵּה מִצְוֹת נִצְטַוּוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל, וְאֵין מִתְקַיְּימִין אֶלָּא בְּאֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל. אֶכָּנֵס אֲנִי לָאָרֶץ כְּדֵי שֶׁיִּתְקַיְּימוּ כּוּלָּן עַל יָדִי - Rabbi Simlai taught: Why did Moshe Rabbeinu desire to enter Eretz Yisrael? Did he need to eat its fruit or satisfy himself from its goodness? Rather, Moshe Rabbeinu said: many mitzvos were commanded to Klal Yisrael, and some of them can be fulfilled only in Eretz Yisrael, so I will enter the land to fulfill all of them myself.

What were the specific mitzvos that Moshe Rabbeinu wanted to fulfill himself? Since he was a levi who does not have a portion of the land, many of the agricultural mitzvos would not apply to him.

title: Early morning appointment vs. Shachris
content:
# Early morning appointment vs. Shachris ## Frage

Is it preferable to daven at home on my own before netz hachama in order to make it to an early doctor's appointment, or to go to the doctor's appointment and daven after נץ and with a minyan?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -2)

I would daven נץ on my own, based on Gemore below.

Talmud Bavli Berachot 5b

That my prayer should be before my bed, the Gemara asks, what does before my bed mean? If you say that it literally means that he would stand before his bed and pray, it is difficult, as Rav Yehuda said that Rav said, and some say that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: From where is it derived that one who prays should have nothing separating between him and the wall? As it is stated: “And Hezekiah turned to face the wall and prayed” (Isaiah 38:2), in order to facilitate his concentration during prayer. That being said, why would Abba Binyamin pray before his bed? Rather, do not say that before my bed refers to where he stood during prayer, but rather, say that he prayed adjacent to the time that he would retire to bed; he was careful to recite Shema and recite the evening prayer just before going to sleep (Rabbeinu Ḥananel).

Rashi סמוך למטתי – כל ימי נזהרתי שלא לעשות מלאכה ושלא לעסוק בתורה כשעמדתי ממטתי עד שאקרא ק"ש ואתפלל:

All days I was careful not to do any labor and to to be engaged in Torah when I stood up from my bad until I read Shema and I prayed.

title: World record for longest time of being Fleishig
content:
# World record for longest time of being Fleishig ## Frage

Based on the discussions here: Where do the different traditions for hours of waiting between meat and milk come from?, what would be the world record for the longest time one can maintain their state of being Fleishig?

In other words, what is the theoretical maximum amount of days one can be Fleishig non-stop if they consistently consume meat every 6 hours, or based on the opinion they follow?

The furthest I can posit is 384 days before hitting Yom Kippur (see Jewish leap year). How I reached it:

  1. There can be up to 385 days in a Jewish leap year, minus Yom Kippur bringing it down to 384. They would have to achieve this during a leap year.
  2. It could be achieved by someone living during a time when Tisha B'av isn't observed (such as before the Beis HaMikdash was destroyed)
  3. And ideally if this person lived before the Taanis of Esther was formed (such as before the story of Purim happened).
  4. And before the 10th of Teves became a fast day.
  5. And before Gedaliah was murdered so that there wouldn't be Tzom Gedaliah.
  6. And either not be a Bechor, or else attend a Siyum Erev Pesach.
  7. It would be ideal if this person would hold that they cannot eat dairy for 24 hours, like Mar Ukva's father did. Otherwise they would have to eat meat consistently sooner.

Based on these assumptions, the maximum time someone can maintain their state of Fleishig should be 384 days. Is there any way it can be longer than this? Such as if this person is weak and needs to eat meat on Yom Kippur?
