title: Does Judaism care if Jesus performed the miracles as reported in the Christian testament?
content:
# Does Judaism care if Jesus performed the miracles as reported in the Christian testament? ## Frage

Devarim 13 teaches about a navi sheker that can predict the future accurately (אות) and/or perform miracles (מופת), and yet, as he contravenes the Torah, that we ourselves heard, we're to disregard him, and even have him eliminated. As for the miracles, HaShem is testing our faith, see there.

That being said, does Judaism care if the Christian miracles occurred or is it agnostic to them as JC was no more than a navi sheker (ditto for other religions and their miracle claims)?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 13)

I don't think Judaism cares. Let's give Joshua son of Joseph (aka Jesus) the benefit of the doubt and say he did perform miracles of healing and even raising of the dead. Okay great, so he's a prophet. We've got dozens of those, men and women, Israelite and Gentile who have performed miracles of healing or raising the dead. The Messiah is supposed to at some point usher in a time of great peace, where nations will beat their swords into plowshares and spears into pruning hooks (Isaiah 2:2-4). Until that happens it doesn't matter how many miracles a single prophet performs. They could have a regular act at The Magic Castle with a hundred miracles a night, doesn't make them the Messiah.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 5)

Whether or not Jesus performed miracles has no bearing on whether Jesus qualified as messiah. The reasons Jesus is rejected are straightforward and I can break them down for you.

To start. The Torah has a long list of honored figures and even enemies who performed miracles. Miracles are not unique to messiah.

  • Moses and all the miracles he performed
  • Pharoah's sorcerers being able to mirror miracles performed by Moses
  • Elijah raising a widow's son from the dead or raining fire from the sky
  • Joshua freezing the sun and moon in the sky
  • And many others

These people are obviously not Mashiach. Some of them were directly in contrast to the goals of God and the mission of the Jewish people. (referring to Pharaoh's sorcerers)

Miracles in and of themselves do not indicate a person is mashiach.

This leads me to the explanation for why Judaism rejects the claim of Jesus being the Messiah.

  1. The mashiach is not to be worshipped as God. The new testament makes many claims about Jesus and his nature. One of these claims is that he is the embodiment of God in flesh (which is a violation of Jewish belief about God's nature) - The Torah states outright that God is not a man (Numbers 23:19)

  2. The rejection of human sacrifice is at the core of what separates Hashem from the various idols of that time period. Jesus is claimed to be a sacrifice which forgives the sins of all of mankind. Besides the fact human sacrifices cannot forgive sin (and are in themselves a sin), the Torah is clear that no man cannot die for the sins of another man. (Deuteronomy 24:16)

  3. Jesus endorsed ritual cannibalism as a form of worship. He told his followers that they should treat bread as his body and wine as his blood. I shouldn't have to explain to you why that's a problem from the Jewish perspective. Jews can't even eat the blood of an animal. The shechita slaughter process is done in part to remove as much blood as humanly possible. The idea that God would create a new form of practice which includes violating his original covenant doesn't work.

  4. Mashiach is to be from the line of King David. Specifically, he is a male descendent passed down through a male line. The core issue with the entire Jesus narrative is that Jesus has no earthly father. While Christians hold this as evidence for his divinity, it's actually the biggest issue against Jesus. If he has no father, he has no direct line back to King David. His mother could not pass that title to him as women do not grant that status and Joseph (his adoptive father) his not his blood. You can't be adopted into the Davidic line.

  5. Similarly to the previous point, the Mashiach is said to come from the tribe of Judah. The problem Jesus has is tribal affiliation is passed from father to son in the Jewish faith. Where a mother grants a child their status as a Jew, the father grants the child their tribal affiliation. Jesus has no tribe. The fact he is claimed a virgin birth means he has no father to grant him tribal affiliation.

  6. The Mashiach is described as a god-fearing Jew who will honor the laws that we have been given. Jesus didn't just violate various Jewish laws, he did so on purpose in order to make a point about the morals of the Jewish leadership at the time. He did not honor the laws as though he was fearful of disappointing God, he purposely violated them and then lectured back at the people who called him out on it. That character trait violates a core value of Mashiach.

  7. The Mashiach will ingather the Jewish people back to Israel. Not only did Jesus not bring the Jews back to Israel, the Jews were exiled 70 years after Jesus lived. This is the opposite of what should have happened.

  8. The Mashiach will reign at a time of global peace. Not only did Jesus not usher in world peace, wars have been fought in his name for thousands of years. The colonial expansion of Christianity and even the infighting between Catholics and Protestants in their civil war are examples of that lack of peace.

  9. The Mashiach will reign at a time when the knowledge of God is universal. Think about this from a historical perspective. Christianity and the Jewish exile are both equal parts of how the knowledge of God spread throughout the world. Even if Christianity makes claims we reject, their version of the Hebrew bible tells our stories in their own way. There are more people alive today who know about the Jewish people and the story of Hashem than at any other point prior. The fact is Jews were restricted to Haaretz Yisrael. No one outside of this region of the world had any clue what a Jew was, let alone who they worshipped.

  10. Jesus changed the nature of sin in multiple ways. Firstly, he stated that the only way to God was through him. That's objectively untrue and God does not need a doorman to have a relationship with his people. Secondly, Christianity endorses the need of believing in Jesus to be forgiven of sin and granted salvation/eternal life. God does not require belief in a third party to free you from sin. If you ask God for forgiveness and change your ways from that point forward, the Torah tells us our sins will not be held against us. Jesus is not part of that equation.

  11. And one of the most important issues with Jesus. He did not accomplish anything the mashiach was meant to accomplish. The mashiach is not a payment plan. He doesn't come and do some things and then leave and come back to do others. The mashiach comes one time and he does everything he was meant to do. Jesus failed at this and his followers were aware of that enough that he promised to eventually come back and finish the job. It gets even more complicated when you realize Jesus promised he'd come back before the death of the last apostle. Meaning he was expected to return in maybe 30 or 40 years time from after he is claimed to have ascended to heaven. Christianity wrote that off and simply says "He will one day return and fulfill the prophecy" which isn't a claim found anywhere in Jewish scripture. Mashiach comes once and does everything in a single human lifetime.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 3)

The discussion in the Talmud does not deal with the actual Jesus and his actual acts, as has been established even by christian scholars like Johann Maier. The Talmud, written many years after the supposed events, does not deny that the miracles described by Christians could take place. However, the Talmud associates such miracles with deception, sorcery, and idolatry, which are forbidden in Judaism (Bavli Sanhedrin 107b and Sotah 47a). For example, Bavli Shabbos 104b R. Eliezer asks: But did not ben Stada bring forth witchcraft from Egypt by means of scratches/tatoos (biseritah) upon his flesh? (a similar point in Yerushalmi Shabbos 12:4/3).

The message is, paraphrasing Peter Schaefer's words in "Jesus in Talmud" when he discussed cases of healing: the fact, that Heaven accepted some acts described by followers of Jesus, did not mean that it approved of them, because they were based on unauthorized and misused power. The fact, that something miraculous but not approved can happen, we learn in the Torah in parashas Chukas, when Moshe strikes the rock twice and water flows; however, the action is not approved by Hashem. The Talmud uses the subject to teach importance not to resort to such behavior. Judaism is a religion based on law and miracles are not viewed as a reason to abandon the law as the words about Navi Sheker tell us.

title: Archeological, geological and astronomical correlations to the flood of Noah
content:
# Archeological, geological and astronomical correlations to the flood of Noah ## Frage

In reviewing tractate Rosh HaShanah 12a in connection with the rules regarding determining halacha between Rabbi Yehosuah and Rabbi Eliezer, I stumbled across an interesting detail concerning them.

It states that concerning the age of the world and the flood, the Sages follow the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.

And this caused me to look more carefully at what Rabbi Eliezer actually is quoted as saying there.

דְּתַנְיָא: ״בִּשְׁנַת שֵׁשׁ מֵאוֹת שָׁנָה לְחַיֵּי נֹחַ בַּחֹדֶשׁ הַשֵּׁנִי בְּשִׁבְעָה עָשָׂר יוֹם לַחֹדֶשׁ״, רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: אוֹתוֹ הַיּוֹם שִׁבְעָה עָשָׂר בְּאִיָּיר הָיָה, יוֹם שֶׁמַּזַּל כִּימָה שׁוֹקֵעַ בַּיּוֹם וּמַעְיָנוֹת מִתְמַעֲטִין. וּמִתּוֹךְ שֶׁשִּׁינּוּ מַעֲשֵׂיהֶן, שִׁינָּה הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא עֲלֵיהֶם מַעֲשֵׂה בְרֵאשִׁית, וְהֶעֱלָה מַזַּל כִּימָה בַּיּוֹם, וְנָטַל שְׁנֵי כּוֹכָבִים מִכִּימָה וְהֵבִיא מַבּוּל לָעוֹלָם. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אוֹתוֹ הַיּוֹם שִׁבְעָה עָשָׂר בְּמַרְחֶשְׁוָן הָיָה, יוֹם שֶׁמַּזַּל כִּימָה עוֹלֶה בַּיּוֹם וּמַעְיָנוֹת מִתְגַּבְּרִים. י״ב א וּמִתּוֹךְ שֶׁשִּׁינּוּ מַעֲשֵׂיהֶם, שִׁינָּה הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא עֲלֵיהֶם מַעֲשֵׂה בְרֵאשִׁית, וְהֶעֱלָה מַזַּל כִּימָה בַּיּוֹם, וְנָטַל שְׁנֵי כּוֹכָבִים וְהֵבִיא מַבּוּל לָעוֹלָם. בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ, הַיְינוּ דִּכְתִיב: ״שֵׁנִי״. אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, מַאי ״שֵׁנִי״? שֵׁנִי לְדִין. בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ, הַיְינוּ דְּשִׁינָּה. אֶלָּא לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, מַאי שִׁינָּה? כִּדְרַב חִסְדָּא. דְּאָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: בְּרוֹתְחִין קִלְקְלוּ וּבְרוֹתְחִין נִידּוֹנוּ. בְּרוֹתְחִין קִלְקְלוּ — בַּעֲבֵירָה, וּבְרוֹתְחִין נִידּוֹנוּ

It mentions that G-d altered the works of Creation and caused the constellation, Kima (This is the constellation called Draco today.) to ascend and G-d grasped two stars (from that constellation) and brought a flood to the world. Rabbi Eliezer explains that this was actually in the month of MarCheshvan after Tishrei (when G-d judges the entire world) and Rav Chisda, explaining the view of Rabbi Eliezer says that initially the waters from the flood were scalding hot. This suggests volcanic involvement, at least initially, like pyroclastic flows.

Classic dating for this event attempts to count onward from the exile of Adam and Chava from Gan Eden and places the flood in the year 1656, 4,128 years ago like is found in Seder HaDorot.

But archeologically and geologically, there is no obvious evidence for such a cataclysmic event in that time frame where all life (or even a vast majority of life) was wiped from the earth.

But the details from Rabbi Eliezer point to something else entirely. Rabbi Eliezer is describing a very large celestial cycle connected to the shifting of Earth's pole star.

He is saying that when the binary star in the constellation of Draco (Kima) was ascending (meaning becoming Earth's pole star), in the month of MarCheshvan, the flood began. The Draco constellation actually has about 8 different binary stars contained within it's pattern and not all of them align with the pole star pathway for Earth's view.

That because the polar axis of the Earth wobbles slightly, the pole star changes over time to align with various stars in the sky, in different constellations. This pattern of alignment can be charted out and anticipated with precision. One of the pole stars in that alignment is a binary star, called Thuban, in the constellation of Draco. This binary star becomes the pole star for Earth every 26,000 years.

The last time Thuban was the pole star for Earth was from about 3942 BCE to 1793 BCE which was when the pyramids were being built in Egypt. That does not agree with the traditional time of the flood details like found in Seder HaDorot.

But in the cycle prior to the last one, which was approximately 30,000 BCE, it coincides with a very significant geological event. It overlaps a period called The Last Glacial Maximum.

In the Last Glacial Maximum, much of the earth was covered with ice sheets,temperatures dropped significantly, desertification spread over large parts of the world creating dust bowls making agriculture extremely difficult and sea levels dropped by almost 400 feet! Many of the details described in the Torah about the Earth not yielding up its produce willingly match these conditions like is mentioned in Bereshit 3:17-19. With sea levels dropping so precipitously, human settlements followed the waterlines to lowlands.

There is archeological evidence of such things like significant human settlement and even cities under the ocean off the coast of India and elsewhere. Similarly, the remains from places like Gobekli Tepe and Karahan Tepe in Turkey extend back to these time frames.

Following the Last Glacial Maximum, this process reversed itself, sometimes rapidly. Areas of human settlement could have been inundated and, in fact there is evidence of such things around the Black Sea in the vicinity of Mount Ararat.

Are there any traditional Torah sources which suggest, the flood story of Noach is actually an older human memory from this time period indicated by Rabbi Eliezer?

title: Textual evidence against Torah being composed as a "Foundation myth"
content:
# Textual evidence against Torah being composed as a "Foundation myth" ## Frage

Some Biblical scholars suggest, that the Five Books of Torah were compiled between the fall of the Israelite Kingdom and the end of the Babylonian exile as a "founding myth" for the newly formed Judaite/Israelite nation.

I'm looking for evidence that might object to this view, in a form "if the Torah was written as a foundational myth, it would be improbable to include such and such passages/words/topics/events"

For example, if the Torah was composed by the Judeans, it would be improbable to make Reuben Jacob's firstborn.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

This has been addressed long ago. Among other reasons (is this from Rabbi Herrz? I forget now) -- it would be a profoundly inconvenient foundation myth.

  • Why not say that we've always been in Israel, rather than acknowledge that Father Abraham was in fact from Mesopotamia and we were not the initial inhabitants of the land?

  • At the times of King Josiah, the Edomites were no longer allies with Judah, put mildly. Yet Deuteronomy stresses that the Israelites of the desert opted to avoid war with the Edomites, and in fact were commanded to welcome an Edomite convert. Why make up that story if it would be a lot more convenient to whip your people into a religious frenzy against today's boogieman?

### Antwort 2 (Score: 5)

To add on to what Shalom said, I remember hearing something along these lines in the name of the kuzari (though I'm not sure I've ever seen it inside):

If the Torah was false/ written hundred of years after it claims to have been written, why and how could we make a claim that 3 million people heard God at Har Sinai? Claiming something like that, if it's not true, make it very easy to deny: "Where are these 3 million people? What happened to them? Why don't we have any knowledge of such a large event, a mere few hundred years later?"

Claiming that one person heard God is a lot easier, because there's no way to refute it. If the Torah was made up, that should've been the go-to story. (Christianity and Islam both utilize this type of 'prophecy' for this exact reason).

### Antwort 3 (Score: 2)

The Jews treasured a history of being slaves in Egypt as their national origins.

This would be seen as very demeaning by the world around them. Therefore the Jews must have been doing so out of religious truth and acceptance of facts.

I believe William F. Albright (famous Biblical Archeologist) is quoted as expressing this idea.

title: What is the Chaya?
content:
# What is the Chaya? ## Frage

The medresh (Bereshit Rabba 14:9 - see full passage, as well as related Midrash Devarim Rabba 2:37; see also Zohar I 206a-207b, for example) records that the soul is composed of 5 levels:

ואהבת את ה' אלהיך בכל לבבך ובכל נפשך (דברים ו, ה), מהו בכל לבבך ובכל נפשך, בכל נפש ונפש שברא בך. אמר רבי מאיר על כל נשימה ונשימה שאדם מעלה חיב לקלס את יוצרו, מנין, שנאמר (תהלים קנ, ו): כל הנשמה תהלל יה. אמר רבי סימון, חמשה שמות נקראו לנפש, ואלו הן: רוח, נפש, נשמה, חיה, יחידה

"And you shall love Hashem your God with all your heart and with all your soul" (Devarim 6:5). What does it mean 'with all your heart and with all your soul'? It means with every soul that He has created within you. Rabbi Meir said, 'For every breath a person takes, he is obligated to praise his Creator.' From where is this derived? As it is stated (Tehillim 150:6), 'Let every soul praise Hashem.' Rabbi Simon said, 'Five names are given to the soul, and they are: Ruach, Nefesh, Neshama, Chaya, and Yechida.' [Devarim Rabba 2:37]

One of those levels is Chaya.

חַיָּה, שֶׁכָּל הָאֵבָרִים מֵתִים וְהִיא חַיָּה בַּגּוּף.

Chaya: As all the bodily organs die, while it lives on ("chaya") in the body. [Bereshit Rabba 14:9]

What is the Chaya?

Any and all information to help me build a grounded and intuitive understanding of the Chaya is welcome, but generally hoping to find a much better explanation than I have found so far, so hoping to find some new high quality sources if possible.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to Moshe Miller:

The soul merges into a state of complete nullification of the ego… The aspect of the soul called Chaya gazes upon the Divine energy of the world of Atzilut. Whereas the primary activity of the level of Neshama is to use intellectual comprehension in order to come to communion with G‑d as the Creator of the worlds, the level of Chaya communes with G‑d as He transcends the worlds. Here the soul's knowledge is not in the immanence of Divine attributes which identify the nature of the Divine energy manifested in Creation, but rather with knowing what G‑d is not — i.e. how He is not limited or defined by the finite universe. Thus the soul merges into a state of complete nullification of the ego. There is no self-seeking and no self-identity outside of G‑d. Chaya is called loving G‑d "with all one's being" (Deut. 6:5). This is knowledge of the absolute truth of things.

Makor:

Chaya

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

This is an interesting question dealing with how to conceptualize these abstract Torah concepts found particularly in kabbalistic and chassidic teachings.

To have a better comprehension of this subject, it first requires prefacing the idea that existence, meaning creation is broken into three general divisions, namely World (עולם), Year or Change (שנה), and Spirit (נפש). This is discussed in Sefer Midbar Kedmot by Rabbi Chaim Yoseph David Azulai and other places.

These divisions are alluded to in the Written Torah in Shemot 19:18 and 20:14 which say:

וְהַ֤ר סִינַי֙ עָשַׁ֣ן כֻּלּ֔וֹ מִ֠פְּנֵ֠י אֲשֶׁ֨ר יָרַ֥ד עָלָ֛יו יְהֹוָ֖ה בָּאֵ֑שׁ וַיַּ֤עַל עֲשָׁנוֹ֙ כְּעֶ֣שֶׁן הַכִּבְשָׁ֔ן וַיֶּחֱרַ֥ד כׇּל־הָהָ֖ר מְאֹֽד׃

and

וְכׇל־הָעָם֩ רֹאִ֨ים אֶת־הַקּוֹלֹ֜ת וְאֶת־הַלַּפִּידִ֗ם וְאֵת֙ ק֣וֹל הַשֹּׁפָ֔ר וְאֶת־הָהָ֖ר עָשֵׁ֑ן וַיַּ֤רְא הָעָם֙ וַיָּנֻ֔עוּ וַיַּֽעַמְד֖וּ מֵֽרָחֹֽק׃

That one of the earliest paradigms of existence is the division into thirds, of right (ימין), left (שמאל) and center (אמצע), also called the three Kavin (קוין) or dimensions (מאימדות). That these 3 Kavin are comprised of: the aspect of World which is conceived of as the idea of Space in the nomenclature of the natural sciences, or Place (מקום) like is used in Yalkut Shimoni to Bereshit 28:11.

The aspect of Year relates to the concept of Time in the nomenclature of the natural sciences, both non-linear time (זמן בלתי המשוער) and linear time (זמן משוער). Linear time is associated specifically to the principle of Change (משנה).

The third aspect of Existence is the aspect of Soul which in this usage is better translated as Spirit or Spiritual. This third aspect of existence, like Space and Time, is distinct and yet all three aspects are interwoven to make up our tapestry of existence.

This paradigm of three dimensional existence is also expressed in our bodies with right hand, left hand and torso.

With this introduction, we can now consider the five aspects or dimensions of soul mentioned in your question.

Like with our body and the five organs of the mouth (throat, pallet, tongue, teeth and lips See Sefer Yetzirah 2:3), the five fingers of each hand, and the five toes of each foot (גודל, אצבע, אמה, קמיצה, זרת), these five dimensions of Nefesh (נפש), Ruach (רוח), Neshamah (נשמה), Chayah (חיה), and Yechidah (יחידה) are consequences (תולדות) or offspring (בנים), so to speak, of their higher, general, categorical root, the Spirit (הנפש, נפש).

They are mentioned in ascending order and from the more specific and individual to the more general and inclusive.

The first three terms associated to the Spirit are restricted in proper usage to the individual. They are associated with the animating aspect (נפש,נפש הבהמית) of the soul, meaning what interacts with material, physical existence, the emotive aspect of the soul (רוח) and the intellectual aspect of soul (נשמה). These latter two categories are not capable of interacting with material existence directly, but rather influence the animating soul, which is the bridge or link between material and spiritual existence.

That the physical body (גוף) without a soul dressed within it, is considered a dead body, a corpse (פגר). So too, when the constituent parts of the individual soul are not woven together, that is death (מות). But when the individual, constituent parts of the soul remain woven together, even outside the material body, they retain the status of being alive.

And just like with the 5 parts of the mouth and the 5 fingers and toes, the remaining two aspects of the Spirit, the Chayah and Yechidah are not about the individual (יחיד), but to the collective (צבור). This is in keeping with the concept in Halacha that the Congregation doesn't die (צבור לא מת).

In this context, the distinction between the aspect of Spirit (הנפש) referred to as Chayah (חיה) and the aspect referred to as Yechidah (יחידה) are understood. That Chayah pertains to the vitality of all animate, living creations, while Yechidah is that aspect of Spirit pertaining to the vitality of all inanimate creations.

That is all the time I have currently to write. There are many textual sources that still need to be listed and linked to this answer. But this should be sufficient to understand.

title: A Ben Ger who converted before his mother did - can he become a Dayan?
content:
# A Ben Ger who converted before his mother did - can he become a Dayan? ## Frage

Shalom, On this topic (Can a convert serve as a dayan?), I saw this answer:

" [A convert can ] Force a judgment even on a Yisrael if the converts mother or father was born of a Yisrael"

This answer was based on Shulchan Aruch, Choshen Misphat 7:1

However, it seems in that case it is only a Jew whose father is Israel and mother is a convert or whose mother is Israel and father is a convert.

So we are not talking about a convert with a jewish father but a Ben Guer. (If his father is Israel and her mother a convert)

So what applies in this case (does this apply to a son of an Israel and a non-jewish mother, who converts before his mother?)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

If this fellow himself converted, he is a convert and can't execute the full functions of a "blue-blooded" Jewish judge.

Say in 2004 a non-Jewish woman gives birth. Then in August 2024, the 20-year-old son converts. It doesn't matter if his mother converted in July 2024 or September 2024 -- this fellow is still halachically a convert.

Let's look at the original Hebrew again from Choshen Mishpat 7:1:

ב"ד של ג' שהיה אחד מהם גר ה"ז פסול לדון לישראל אא"כ היתה אמו (או אביו) (מרדכי בשם תוס' פ"ב מ"ח) מישראל

A Beit Din in which one is a convert may not judge a Yisrael; rather it must be that his mother (or father) was from Yisrael.

I.e. Jewish stock in there someplace. That doesn't mean "as of today", it means "as of the day he was born."

title: Shevet Sofer's commentary on the "one above and seven below"
content:
# Shevet Sofer's commentary on the "one above and seven below" ## Frage

The Shvilei Pinches (Parshas Shoftim, 5772) quotes a famous teaching of the Rama that says that the sprinklings of the Kohen Gadol on Yom Kippur (one up, and seven down) refers to the Yetzer Hara and the Yetzer Tov. He writes (Toras HaOlah, Part 2, 26:11):

אמנם מניין ההזאות שהיו שמונה על בין הבדים ועל הפרוכת, וארבע על קרנות המזבח, ושבעה באמצעו, הוא מבואר בדרך זה. כבר נודע הזאות יום הכפורים (חלק ג פרק נח) שהוא אחת למעלה ושבעה למטה, כמו שיתבאר בהלכות יום הכפורים אם ירצה השם יתעלה. והטעם שהיו רומזים על עניין יצר הרע המחטיא האדם, והוא נקרא בשבעה שמות, ולכן היה זורק שבעה הזאות למטה ואחד מלמעלה שהוא נגד יצר טוב, והיה מונה עם כל הזאות שלמטה שלמעלה כמו שאמרו (יומא נג, ב) וכך היה מונה כו', להורות כי מן הראוי לשתף יצר הרע עם יצר הטוב, ואז שניהם כאחד טובים, והיה זורק כמו שנאמר (יחזקאל לו, כה) וזרקתי עליכם מים טהורים. כמו שיתבאר כל זה אם ירצה השם יתעלה בסדר יום הכפורים (חלק ג פרק נט). ולכן היה זורק אלו הזאות על בין הבדים והפרוכת. וכבר נודע חלק ראשון פרק חמשה ועשרים על מה היו רומזים, ובדרך שכתבתי בסמוך.

The number of sprinklings, which were eight between the poles, eight on the curtain, four on the horns of the altar, and seven in the middle, is explained in this manner: It is already known regarding the sprinklings of Yom Kippur (Part 3, Chapter 58) that there was one above and seven below, as will be explained in the laws of Yom Kippur, G-d willing. The reason is that they alluded to the evil inclination that leads a person to sin, which is referred to by seven names. Therefore, the High Priest would sprinkle seven times below and one time above, corresponding to the good inclination. He would count each of the lower sprinklings along with the upper one, as it is stated (Yoma 53b), "and thus he would count, etc.," to teach that it is appropriate to combine the evil inclination with the good inclination, and then both together are good. He would sprinkle, as it is written (Yechezkel 36:25), "I will sprinkle clean water upon you." All of this will be explained, God willing, in the order of Yom Kippur (Part 3, Chapter 59). Therefore, these sprinklings were done between the poles and on the curtain. It is already known from Part 1, Chapter 25, what they symbolized, and in the manner I have written previously. (emphasis mine)

The Shvilei Pinches then goes on to quote from a sefer called "Shevet Sofer", written by Rabbi Simchah Bunem Sofer, the grandson of the Chasam Sofer. The Shvilei Pinches says:

In his view, when the Kohen Godol sprinkled “one above and seven below,” he had in mind to make a case proving Yisroel’s merit before HKB”H in the Kodesh HaKodoshim on Yom HaKippurim. The Gemoreh (Beroches 17a) presents a prayer recited by Rabbi Alexandri: ”רבון העולמים גלוי וידוע לפניך שרצוננו לעשות רצונך ומי מעכב ”שבעיסה שאור—Master of the Worlds, it is revealed and known before You that our will is to perform Your will. And who prevents us from doing so? The yeast in the dough—the yetzer hora. This, too, is the message inherent in the Kohen Godol’s sprinkling and counting protocol in the Kodesh HaKodoshim on Yom HaKippurim.

Thus, the Kohen Godol presented his case before HKB”H: ”למעלה אחת —”he sprinkled one above, indicating that there is but one way to connect with HKB”H above--by means of the yetzer tov. Conversely, ”למטה שבע—”the seven below indicated that there are seven ways by which one can fall into the spiritual abyss as a result of the yetzer hora’s forces of evil. Therefore, it is appropriate for HKB”H to forgive Yisroel for all of their transgressions. The Shevet Sofer concludes: והוא” incredible an is this—רמז נפלא ודבר גדול גילה לנו הרמ“א בזה“ message revealed to us by the Ramoh.

I have trouble understanding what the Shevet Sofer is explaining to us here.

We have a wonderful teaching in the Gemara that "we should always incite our good inclination against our evil inclination" (Berachos 5a), can the words of the Shevet Sofer mean that the one time the Kohen Gadol sprinkles upwards, referring to the yetzer tov, symbolises that we should incite the yetzer tov to overcome the yetzer hara?

Anyone able to expound this teaching? I am also looking for his original words (of the Shevet Sofer). Does anyone have access to his sefer on this?

title: Why the Har Sinai experience had to be so negative?
content:
# Why the Har Sinai experience had to be so negative? ## Frage

I had a conversation about the Haredi world, and I was pointed out that the Receiving of the Torah on Mt. Sinai, the founding event in the history of the Jewish people, was also a dreadful and frightening experience just like the rest of the Haredi conduct (Haredi meaning "being frightened" in Hebrew).

I've reread the chapter, and indeed, it starts with God threatening to kill anyone who derails from his strict rules, and continues to describe the Jewish people as being in a constant state of anxiety and fear (ויחרד) during the whole show, up to the point when they can't stand it anymore and retreat.

The Rabbinic interpretation in Shabbos 88a also depicts a bleaky picture:

"Rabbi Avdimi bar Ḥama bar Ḥasa said: the Jewish people actually stood beneath the mountain, and the verse teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, overturned the mountain above the Jews like a tub, and said to them: If you accept the Torah, excellent, and if not, there will be your burial.
Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: From here there is a substantial caveat to the obligation to fulfill the Torah. The Jewish people can claim that they were coerced into accepting the Torah, and it is therefore not binding. "

Was this negative experience a necessity? Could Har Sinai revelation be fun and a happy and positive experience for all participants? Couldn't the air be filled with flowers and serpentine instead of bolts of lightning, and couldn't they hear the voice of violins instead of war-summoning Shofar?

Why couldn't this epiphany be the best experience of their (short) lives?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The definition of negative depends on perspective. For a former powerless slave who just ran from an excruciating bondage it was very important and encouraging to align oneself with the power greater than one could imagine. Indeed, the Arab tribes even today make alignments with stronger powers at all costs, even religious costs, in a fight for survival. On the other hand, for a person of grown in the West the description of Matan Torah in the Talmud may appear coercive. There is a discussion in the Gemara and the comments (brought in Artscroll) for why coercion took place.

The experience at Mt. Sinai is described in gemara Shabbos 88a:

the Holy One, Blessed be He, overturned the mountain above the Jews like a tub, and said to them: If you accept...the Torah, excellent, and if not, there will be your burial....Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: From here there is a substantial caveat to the obligation to fulfill the Torah....The Jewish people can claim that they were coerced into accepting the Torah, and it is therefore not binding.

Tosafos:

And even though they had already first said, "We will do," before, "and we will hear" (a valid commitment) - perhaps they would retract when they would see the great fire [on the mountain], such that their souls departed as in Gemara on Shabbos 88b. (I.e. their commitment could have been rescinded on the basis that it was made without knowledge of awesome consequences - Artscroll).

The proof is given from other nations: And [regarding] that which it said [that the other nations said in their defense for not accepting the Torah] in the first chapter of Avodah Zarah (2b), "Did you overturn the mountain above us like a tub?" - which implies that if He had overturned [it] above them, they would not have had an answer/excuse (for refusing to accept the Torah). Whereas here it said that it [itself] is a substantial caveat to the Torah: That means [that it is not an excuse, but rather a reason that would have made them guilty] for their not accepting it (the Torah). But regarding their not keeping it, it would have been an [excuse].

Maharal, Tiferes Israel ch. 32, asks, why did G-d not first wait to see if the people would renege, and then force their acceptance if necessary? He answers that G-d wanted that the Jewish answer "We will do and we will hear", which was made out of love, to be binding forever. Hence, He did not want to risk drawing a new coercion.

Midrash Tanchuma, Noach 3, states that the words "We will do and we will hear" signaled acceptance only of the Written law. The people were reluctant to accept the Oral Law which requires effort and discipline in its study and observance. I.e. coercion was in regard to Oral law.

The next comment of Tosafos shows that eventually Jewish people accepted both Written and Oral Torah willingly.

A substantial caveat to the Torah*: And [regarding] that which it said in Nedarim (25a), that Moshe made a covenant with Israel about the Torah and the commandments and had them take an oath about this; and in the chapter [entitled] Elu Ne'emanim (Sotah 37b), that they accepted all of the Torah at Mount Gerizim and at Mount Eival - Rabbenu Tam says that it was by way of a command [from God]; so behold it is like [it was] against their will. But at the time of Achashverosh, they accepted [it] with their consent from love of the miracle. And [regarding] that which Yehoshua made a covenant with them to serve God - there they only accepted not to worship idolatry. As it is written (Yehoshua 24:), "God forbid for us to forsake the Lord"; and all of the matter [there] implies this.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

The Midrash says:

The whole world was created only for the sake of the Torah… God saw a single rose-colored flower, to wit, Israel. He took it and smelled it, when He gave [the Israelites] the Ten Commandments; His spirits were calmed when they said: We will do, and we will listen. [Exodus 24:7] [At that time], the Holy One said, “The orchard shall be saved on account of this flower. For the sake of the Torah and of Israel the world shall be saved.” [Vayikra Rabbah 23:3]

From this, the tradition emerged that Mount Sinai blossomed with flowers right before the giving of the Torah.

One of the five traditions of Shavuot, when we celebrate the giving of the Torah, is to decorate homes and synagogues with plants, flowers and tree branches. The earliest mention of this custom is by the Maharil, from 15th-century Germany.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 3)

This is an excellent observation - Har Sinai is described in the Chumash as a physically terrible experience for klal yisrael. This is consistent throughout Tanach that encountering G-d or angels is often disturbing or even terrifying for the human involved - e.g., Moshe at the burning bush, Yakov upon waking up from his dream, Gideon and Manoach both thinking they would die after meeting an angel, Yeshayahu saying woe is me during one of his prophecies, Daniel and his companions being terrified and losing their strength during one of his prophecies.

This is a signicant topic - here are three high level approaches to this: the simplest is literary - during the time period of the Tanach, this was the way all ancient cultures described their respective deities and religions. Thus, the Tanach was written in the style of the times that made sense to the audience of the time - terror at Mt. Sinai is consistent with how all early religions described encountering heavenly beings.

Second, the terror experienced at Mt. Sinai speaks to Theodicy/Tzadik vra lo - why bad things sometimes happen to good people. Rav Nachman in Likutei Maharan discusses the episode at Mt. Sinai at length and explains it is a metaphor for the challenges that G-d must impose upon jews in order for us to have free will / grow as individuals.

Third, the terror that humans encounter throughout Tanach experiencing G-d and angels is part of a broader pattern to encourage Jews to focus on living in this world (while following the Mitzvot) and less so on anything outside this world/supernatural - there is almost no mention of any afterlife in Tanach, magic is not allowed, the Mishkan is described as deadly and only safe for a select few, encountering G-d is described as terrifying and only fitting for a select few. The broad idea is presumably that a Jew must focus on this world and succeed here (especially in his relationships with others here) before being ready to meet and greet his maker. (Rav Kook discusses the concept of human relationships being "practice" for an eventual relationship with G-d in many places)

title: Why did the Har Sinai revelation only include commandments?
content:
# Why did the Har Sinai revelation only include commandments? ## Frage

During the Har Sinai revelation, God spoke to the nation only the Ten Commandments. He could, for example, give a very different speech, for example, include theology, as He did with Job (38.1):

"Where were you when I laid the earth’s foundations?
Speak if you have understanding.
Do you know who fixed its dimensions
Or who measured it with a line?
Onto what were its bases sunk? ... Have you ever commanded the day to break,
Assigned the dawn its place,
So that it seizes the corners of the earth And shakes the wicked out of it? ... Have you surveyed the expanses of the earth? If you know of these—tell Me."

maybe discuss cosmology, or repeat the words He said to Moses (Ex 19.3):

"You have seen what I did to the Egyptians, how I bore you on eagles’ wings and brought you to Me.
Now then, if you will obey Me faithfully and keep My covenant, you shall be My treasured possession among all the peoples. Indeed, all the earth is Mine, but you shall be to Me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation.”

Another option that comes to mind is the blessings, as in Lev 26.3, I bet Israel would love to hear those promises from God's mouth:

"If you follow My laws and faithfully observe My commandments, I will grant your rains in their season, so that the earth shall yield its produce and the trees of the field their fruit. Your threshing shall overtake the vintage, and your vintage shall overtake the sowing; you shall eat your fill of bread and dwell securely in your land. I will grant peace in the land, and you shall lie down untroubled by anyone; I will give the land respite from vicious beasts, and no sword shall cross your land. [Your army] shall give chase to your enemies, and they shall fall before you by the sword."

But God chose to dedicate this once-in-history event to relaying the Ten Commandments that, weirdly enough, have no particular importance in Judaism.

Hence my question: why did God's revelation on Har Sinai only include commandments (given that "I'm YHWH thy God" is the first one)?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The Torah is a contract which Jewish people made with Hashem. We have 2 verses in Vayikra: 25:42 and 25:55: For it is to Me that the Israelites are servants: they are My servants, whom I freed from the land of Egypt — I, your God Hashem. According to the p'shat: Hashem took us out of the Egyptian bondage and made us His servants. (Rashi says that His acquisition contract is older, i.e. has priority over anything else). A master or a king open the contract with the list of rules. We are not really "partners".

(Of course one can sweeten it with meaning of true freedom as service of G-d). Sefer Iyov is not a contract, it is a long answer to a question. In fact Hashem did not speak in commandments with anybody in sefer Bereshis.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Think about how Hashem rescued us from Egypt, with this whole build up to this great meeting and worship on a mountain. One can imagine how exciting that must have been for Benei Yisrael, and what was going through their mind - the awesome creator of the whole universe, who performs all these wonders on our behalf, and revealed Himself at the splitting of the sea, and has shown His great love for us and desire to be our God and us His people, has done all this for this great meeting! What is He going to say? Was He going to teach them the secrets of Torah and life? Show them the heavens? Take them to Gan Eden?

Turns out, He wanted tell us to be nice to our mother, as well as a list of other dos and don'ts, and that's it? On the face of it, this needs an answer.

The Torah's Mitzvot are not simply a list of dos and don'ts. The revelation at Sinai wasn't a revelation of law. It was a revelation of Hashem. Hashem was telling us that not murdering, being nice to our mother etc. are not just good rules for a society, and Shabbat is not just Hashem's wise idea for us to help us keep families together.

No, the Torah and Mitzvot are Hashem's revelation to us. The whole Torah is informing us about Him - things we wouldn't know unless He told us. He hates murder, absolutely. He needs us to be nice to our mothers - that's an absolute value for Him. It's His Shabbat that He is sharing with us, and inviting us to.

This is why Har Sinai is likened to a wedding between us and Him - He is telling us about Him; what is essential to Him, which we need to know if we are to be wed to Him, to worship Him and to be in this relationship with Him. Just like a marriage, we need to get to know each other. He knows us, but we didn't know Him. The Torah, therefore, is His love note to us, His revelation to us, and the Mitzvot He gives us will enable us to connect to Him and be truly wed, because the Mitzvot are His essential will.

This is based on many Chassidic concepts, including that the Mitzvot are "nogeah b'Atzmus"; Na'aseh v'Nishma and connecting to Hashem as the Baal HaRatzon; and is explained exquisitly by Rabbi Manis Friedman in several shiurim, which I will link here soon.

title: Order of Washing Hands
content:
# Order of Washing Hands ## Frage

When washing hands, which hand needs to be washed first, when waking up, before bread, and after toilet respectively?

Are there different opinions in it?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Mishnah Berurah 4:9 for Netilat Yadayim in the morning

One should wash one's right hand first, then one's left hand, and repeat this process two more times so that one washes each hand three times, while alternating hands in the process. Some say one should wash each hand four times.

OC 162:2

To wash netilat yadayim for a bread meal one should pour water on one's right hand three times and then pour water on one's left hand three times.

Upon leaving the bathroom, “Many poskim hold no kli is necessary and neither is washing three times.” Mekoros:

https://www.ou.org/torah/machshava/tzarich-iyun/tzarich_iyun_washing_after_leaving_the_washroom/ quoting Yalkut Yosef v. 3 p. 96. He points out that there is a stringency to wash with a kli outside the bathroom but washing with a kli in the bathroom is pointless. Rav Ben Tzion Abba Shaul (Ohr LeTzion 2:1:15) held that a keli is nice lechatechilah but not necessary MeIkar HaDin; however, three times is always necessary. Rav Ovadia (Yabia Omer 9 OC 108 fn 4) lightens some of his arguments by noting how one cannot compare this to washing in the morning. Rav Mordechai Lebhar (Magen Avot Orach Chaim 4:18) quotes Rav Shalom Meshash (Shemesh uMagen vol. 3 Siman 37) as reporting that the custom in Morocco was always to wash once at the sink without a kli according to the simple reading of Shulchan Aruch that a kli is only necessary for the morning washing

title: Personal Bakashot in Shema Koleinu or Elokai
content:
# Personal Bakashot in Shema Koleinu or Elokai ## Frage

When we speak to Hashem in our own words and make our personal bakashot, is it more proper to say this in Shema Koleinu (right before כי אתה שומע) or do we say it in Elokai Nezur (after the paragraph but before the second Yihiyu Lerazon)?

Does it matter what type of bakasha you’re making? For instance, some siddurim have set texts in Shema Koleinu for Parnassah and forgiveness, while the text of Elokai seems to be about thoughts and enemies.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The rules about adding to the normal text are found in OC 119. In short, personal requests that fit thematically with a particular blessing (eg. forgiveness, health, livelihood, in blessings 6,8,9 respectively) are added to their particular blessing, and any requests that don't fit elsewhere go in blessing 16 (שמע קולינו). After prayer-proper comes "Tachanun" which has no fixed form and you can add whatever supplications you want (such as for a fast day).

There is a minority opinion of Rabbenu Yonah that the Shulchan Aruch recommends following if you can as a nice stringency (cf. Beit Yosef and Aruch Hashulchan ibid.) that additional personal requests must be phrased in the singular and additional communal requests must be phrased in the plural, and some say (MA ibid.) that this applies to שמע קולינו as well. Some also say (ibid. :2) that additional personal requests can't be "too long". Additionally, while prayer can in principle be in any language (OC 101:4) there is some dispute about the language requirements of individual additions, especially if mixing languages with the regular text being in Hebrew.

Accordingly, if you want to not deal with any of that then just stick all your additions after prayer in whatever wording/language you want. However, please acknowledge the religious cost that comes with that, whereby your "prayer" isn't where you actually pray to God.

title: How to pronounce שׁוֹמְרִים?
content:
# How to pronounce שׁוֹמְרִים? ## Frage

Shalom to all.

I am not sure how to pronounce the following word, which comes up in prayer (e.g. in Tehillim 130): שׁוֹמְרִים.

On one hand, I learned that Sheva after big vowels (Patach, Ṣere…) is independent. Based on this the pronunciation would be “shoMErim”.

On another hand, I’ve heard some people read this word as “shoMrim,” with a silent Sheva.

Which is correct? Please explain. Are there exceptions to the rule? Thank you.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

It’s a Shva na`.

Many people, especially in certain Ashkenazic communities, ignore the rules of Shva. Shva isn’t such an important vowel, so this (usually) isn’t problematic, but it’s not accurate either.

(Note: There is a scholarly opinion that this kind of Shva was silent in the Tiberian Masoretic tradition. Even if that was case, we don’t follow that rule today, so it’s irrelevant; and if it were relevant, we'd have to be extra careful with vowel length distinctions; far more careful than those who believe that this Shva is Nach, and who likely don’t know what vowel length is).

### Antwort 2 (Score: -2)

It's a bit complicated because sometimes rules conflict, for example שַׁרְבִיט, there's one rule that shva followed by a בּ is silent and followed by a ב is vocal, but usually a shva that closed patach is silent so this case is complicated, or in a case like מַלְכֵי vs מַלְכִּי, or similarly in וַתְּכַבֵּד what is type of dagesh is the תּ? It cannot be תּ because the patach makes it a closed syllable and a closed syllable it has to be rapha, It cannot be ת because because it has to open the syllable to be a vocal shva, and the כ rapha demands a vocal shva before it. In your case probably is vocal because it's after a long vowel. In a shva after the qamets in שָׁ֫מְרוּ there seems to be an argument if silent or pronounced, if this qamets is considered long

title: What is so special about "ve'sechezena" that it is the one word in bold in the whole Amida?
content:
# What is so special about "ve'sechezena" that it is the one word in bold in the whole Amida? ## Frage

Practically every Siddur I've seen puts it in bold along with the first words of every blessing.

Is there any reason for this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Nothing is special about it. Many Siddurim bold or otherwise emphasize the first word in a printed paragraph and many insert paragraph breaks unnecessarily at places where there is sometimes a traditional insertion or a seasonal variant text. Some examples of other common misleading pseudo-paragraph headings where the text is intended to just be continuous when a particular insertion/variant isn't used:

  • הוד והדר לפניו (notice to pause (the real break is 4 verses earlier after תָּרֵעוּ))
  • וכרות עמו הברית (variant Mohel-song at a circumcision)
  • המאיר לארץ (insertion of Yotzer poems)
  • תתברך צורינו (end of Yotzer poems)
  • את שם (insertion of a tiny pause)
  • על הראשונים (variant for Zulat poems)
  • עזרת אבותינו (insertion of Zulat poems)
  • וֹתתן לנו (insertion of Havdala on Yom Tov)
  • ומפני חטאינו (variant text for Musaf)
  • ותחזינה/ובנה ירושלים (insertion of Yaaleh veYavo)
  • ועל כולם/ועל הכל (insertion of Al haNissim)
  • לא לנו/ה' זכרנו/מה אשיב (beginning and end of omitted parts)
  • מן המצר/אנא ה'/ברוך הבא (beginning and end of responsive part)
### Antwort 2 (Score: -4)

The root of the word v’sechezena (ותחזינה עינינו בשובך לציון ברחמים) is chazone (חזון), one of the 10 expressions of prophecy.

The bolding is to emphasize the intent of that specific posuk, that the return of the Shechina to Tzion will be in a way of mercy (רחמים).

That Tzion (ציון) is referring to Moshiach ben Yosef (יוסף is gematria ציון).

In this context see Rashi and Metzudat David to Isaiah 59:20 who emphasize that Melech HaMoshiach, meaning Moshiach ben David, will be the Redeemer of Tzion.

Prophecies of the חזון (chazone) variety are prophecies pertaining to Judgement and Severity (דין וגבורה) like is expressed in Bereshit Rabbah 44:6.

הָיָה דְּבַר ה' אֶל אַבְרָם בַּמַּחֲזֶה לֵאמֹר (בראשית טו, א), עֲשָׂרָה לְשׁוֹנוֹת נִקְרֵאת, נְבוּאָה, חָזוֹן, הֲטָפָה, דִּבּוּר, אֲמִירָה, צִוּוּי, מַשָּׂא, מָשָׁל, מְלִיצָה, חִידָה. וְאֵיזוֹ הִיא קָשָׁה שֶׁבְּכֻלָּן רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אָמַר חָזוֹן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (ישעיה כא, ב): חָזוּת קָשָׁה הֻגַּד לִי. רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר דִּבּוּר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (בראשית מב, ל): דִּבֶּר הָאִישׁ אֲדוֹנֵי הָאָרֶץ אִתָּנוּ קָשׁוֹת. רַבָּנָן אָמְרֵי מַשָּׂא, כְּמַשְׁמָעוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (תהלים לח, ה): כְּמַשָּׂא כָבֵד יִכְבְּדוּ מִמֶּנִּי. גָּדוֹל כֹּחוֹ שֶׁל אַבְרָם שֶׁנִּדְבַּר עִמּוֹ בְּדִבּוּר וּבֶחָזוֹן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: הָיָה דְבַר ה' אֶל אַבְרָם בַּמַּחֲזֶה.

This relates to the possibility that Moshiach ben Yosef could have been murdered prior to completing his life's mission.

Jews in every generation have prayed that this will be overturned and that Moshiach ben Yosef would be permitted to live until his mission was accomplished.

According to the teaching of the Vilna Gaon as expressed in the beginning of Sefer Kol HaTor (קול התור, פרק א, ד״ה [א] ״עוד יוסף חי״ וכו׳), already by his generation, those collective prayers by all the Jewish people in all the generations had been accepted by G-d and Moshiach ben Yosef would not be murdered by Armilus, the evil one. That this decree was nullified because of the great length of the final exile, and the afflictions and illnesses which Moshiach ben Yosef will bear together with his total dedication to his lifelong task to complete the Ingathering of the Exiles.

In context of the statement from the Vilna Gaon, it would seem that even though the petition had been accepted by his time so many years ago, it was relying even on the future prayers of Jews that as of his time, had not yet been said. Meaning, that from G-d's perspective, past, present and future are all seen as one.

title: Are soldiers sinning when they kill enemy in a war?
content:
# Are soldiers sinning when they kill enemy in a war? ## Frage

Soldiers are like slaves to their commanders and have to do whatever they are told to do. If not, in war war-like situation, they can be punished by their commanders. So will the soldiers be accountable for the killing they do?

The question came to mind because of the recent war in Gaza. The Israelis who are fighting Palestinians are doing so because they have to do compulsory military service, so even if they dislike killing people, they are compelled to do so.

Note: I have asked the same question in the Islam section also. Actually, Muslims and Jews are brothers who are descended from our patriarch Abraham (Peace be upon him), It is sad to see them fighting each other, I feel like they are forced to fight each other by some who have a vested interest in this conflict.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Maharal of Prague, 16th-century commentator, writes:

The Torah allows war when we are attacked, and in responding, we are allowed to not distinguish between the guilty and the innocent. [Gur Aryeh to Gen. 34:13]

However, warning may be given. The Torah says:

When you approach a town to attack it, you shall offer it terms of peace. [Deuteronomy 20:10]

In commenting, the Midrash tells us:

Rav Shmuel bar Naḥman said: What did Joshua do [when he was about to enter the Promised Land]? He would publish an edict in every place [of the Land of Canaan] he went to conquer, on which he wrote: “Whoever wants to go, let him go; whoever wants to make peace with us, let him make peace; and whoever wants to make war shall make war.”

-The Girgashites vacated and departed from there, and the Holy One, blessed be He, gave them a land as beautiful as their native land, namely Africa.

-The Gibeonites desired to make peace with Israel, and Joshua made peace with them.

-However, the 31 Canaanite kings came to battle with Joshua, and the Holy One blessed be He caused them to fall.

[Deut. Rabbah 5:14]

title: What is the source of Rambam's cosmology?
content:
# What is the source of Rambam's cosmology? ## Frage

In the Mishneh Torah third section of Yesodei a geocentric world is described with a number of spheres containing stars that revolve around the Earth due to the motion of the spheres that contain them. Are there any sources in Chazal where we see a similar world described or is Rambam basing this on Greek astronomy?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to the paper "Divine Science: Reevaluating Rambam’s View of Ma’aseh Merkavah," Maimonides's cosmology is based on the philosophers Aristotle, Ptolemy, and Al-Farabi, as well as various Torah sources emphasizing the number ten, such as Sefer Yetzirah and Tractate Chagigah. While Rambam was not a kabbalist, and to say such revisionist history would be an insult to him, the kabbalistic cosmology was not sourceless, and he happened to agree in the Guide with the kabbalists on a ten sphere cosmology.

title: Why didn't Bne Israel say Shirah (song) upon Matan Torah?
content:
# Why didn't Bne Israel say Shirah (song) upon Matan Torah? ## Frage

I understand that Shirah is usually associated with the miraculous defeat of enemies, but I don't see any reason it should be limited to it.

  • Undoubtedly, the Matan Torah was a crucial event in the history of the whole world - God finally gave the Jews a precious present that would change the history of humankind.
  • Alternatively, one might see it as the miracle of the mass Divine revelation to the Israelite nation, and some say, all generations of Jewish souls.
  • Some may even see it as the day of divine marriage between God and the Jews — the more the merrier - more reasons to sing Shira.

It appears, however, that neither the scripture nor the majority of commentators see Matan Torah as Shira-worthy - in the end, the Israelites get genuinely scared, return to their tents, and keep complaining about wandering in the wilderness.

So, was Matan-Torah worthy of singing Shira, and if yes, why didn't Moses, Miriam, and the rest sing?

Special thanks to @shmosel.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

There are 10 songs of Israel, each one comes after a certain completion or victory has been acomplished. The Experience of Matan Torah has not been complete.

As we know, after the first two commandments Jewish people delegated Moshe to receive the rest of the Torah, which delayed receiving of the Torah from the the 6th of Sivan to the 17th of Tammuz. When Moshe Rabbeinu brought the Tablets on the 17th of Tammuz, he had to smash them because of the Golden Calf, which delayed receiving of the Torah. After that Moshe prayed for 40 days and nights and then went up to Mt. Sinai to receive the second Tablets, which he brought after Yom Kippur on the 10th of Tishrei. The bringing of the second Tablets set in motion the process of learning the Torah and doing many mitzvos connected with the building of the Mishkan.

When there was Temple, there was much singing after Yom Kippur, as described in Mishnah Taanis 4.8. Now, we sing a lot on Yom Kippur. Although our singing is not connected so much with receiving of the Torah, it reflects our belief that if we do proper repentance - G-d will forgive us. G-d gave us the Torah on Yom Kippur because He forgave us.

There are many views on how creation of the Golden Calf affected the Jewish people. Some say that originally Jewish people could learn all of the Torah from the text of the written Torah without a need for the books of prophets and writings. One way or another, the story of receiving the Torah is not complete. It is also one of the reasons why the blessings on the Torah are formulated in the present, i.e. that G-d is teaching Jewish people the Torah and giving us the Torah now, every moment.

title: Distinctive form of "לאהוב ל-" instead of "לאהוב את"
content:
# Distinctive form of "לאהוב ל-" instead of "לאהוב את" ## Frage

AFAIK, out of more than 200 transitive uses of the word לאהב in the Tanakh, only two close to each other in Lev 19 .18: "לֹא־תִקֹּם וְלֹא־תִטֹּר אֶת־בְּנֵי עַמֶּךָ וְאָהַבְתָּ לְרֵעֲךָ כָּמוֹךָ אֲנִי יְהוָה׃" and 34: "כְּאֶזְרָח מִכֶּם יִהְיֶה לָכֶם הַגֵּר הַגָּר אִתְּכֶם וְאָהַבְתָּ לוֹ כָּמוֹךָ כִּי־גֵרִים הֱיִיתֶם בְּאֶרֶץ מִצְרָיִם אֲנִי יְהוָה אֱלֹהֵיכֶם׃" use the form "להאוב ל" (somewhat probably similar to "to love to").

What is this special form, why is it used in those two cases, does it have any connection with loving "as yourself", and why isn't it used with nearby prohibitions, like "לֹא־תִשְׂנָא אֶת־אָחִיךָ בִּלְבָבֶךָ הוֹכֵחַ תּוֹכִיחַ אֶת־עֲמִיתֶךָ"?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Bechor Shor explains that ואהבת את רעך כמוך would imply you're obligated to value others as entirely equal to yourself, when in fact the Torah obligates you in self-preservation before saving another. Rather, the passage is teaching the Golden Rule, that you should treat others as you would want to be treated by them. The phrasing לרעך indicates that it's about interpersonal behavior: You should [act with] love towards your fellow.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

Haamek Davar (to Deut. 6:5) explains that "to feel and act with love" is with את whereas "to act with love" alone is with ל־‎.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 3)

Several commentators suggest that the distinction is between loving the person (את) and loving things or attributes relevant to the person (—ל).

E.g., Ibn Ezra: ״כמשמעו שיאהב הטוב לחברו כמו לנפשו״. "Just as it implies: that one should love that which is good for his colleague as one would that for oneself."

My reading is that Lev. 19:18 is part of a section dealing with interpersonal behaviour and with the rights of others. For instance, 19:9-10 command farmers to leave harvest gleanings and the corners of their fields for the poor; 11-12 forbid theft, fraud, and oppressive conduct; and so forth. In this context 19:18 addreses itself to people who might "take revenge" and breach someone's rights, or "begrudge" by failing to vindicate them: don't be like that; love their rights as your own.

title: Why "do not avenge" applies to "[all] members of your people" but "love" only to "thy neighbor"?
content:
# Why "do not avenge" applies to "[all] members of your people" but "love" only to "thy neighbor"? ## Frage

In Lev 19:18:

לֹא־תִקֹּם וְלֹא־תִטֹּר אֶת־בְּנֵי עַמֶּךָ וְאָהַבְתָּ לְרֵעֲךָ כָּמוֹךָ אֲנִי יְהוָה׃
You shall not take vengeance or bear a grudge against members of your people.
Love your fellow as yourself.

Why does "do not avenge or bear a grudge" apply to "[all] members of your people" but "love" (and many others) only to "thy neighbor/fellow"? Are there any Halachic implications, compared, for example, to the prohibition of "hating your brother"?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The word רֵעֲךָ/neighbor is not exclusive to the mitzvah of loving one's neighbor. It is also used in many different mitzvos including 10 commandments: Shemos 20:13, Shemos 20:14, Devarim 5:17, Devarim 5:18. Also commandments Vayikra 19:13, Vayikra 19:16, and many other places. In particular, when Dathan and Aviram were fighting Shemos 2:13:

וַיֵּצֵא֙ בַּיֹּ֣ום הַשֵּׁנִ֔י וְהִנֵּ֛ה שְׁנֵֽי־אֲנָשִׁ֥ים עִבְרִ֖ים נִצִּ֑ים וַיֹּ֨אמֶר֙ לָֽרָשָׁ֔ע לָ֥מָּה תַכֶּ֖ה רֵעֶֽךָ׃

Moshe is using the word רֵעֲךָ when rebuking one of them. The reason is that the word רֵעַ means one who has something in common with another, often a bond of friendship (Artscroll Rashi commentary). Hence, Rashi comments: "THY FELLOW" (the word denotes one who is the equal of another) — who is as wicked as yourself (Exodus Rabbah 1:29). Because the word is used in 10 commandments, it means that all Jews became רֵעִים.

Additionally, I think, loving the ones who are closest, like neighbors, parents, siblings, spouses, is harder, because that is where the relationship can get tested for real. When dealing with people who stay far, issues that are mentioned in the above negative mitzvos are much less likely to arise due to distance.

The positive mitzvah to love one's neigbor, Sefer haChinuch 243 is also formulated in the negative: (Shabbat 31a), “What is hateful to you, do not do to your fellow.” And they said in Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 4:12, “Rabbi Akiva said, ‘This is a great principle in the Torah’” — meaning to say that many commandments are dependent upon it. As one that loves his fellow like himself will not steal from him, will not have adultery with his wife, will not cheat him of goods or oppress him with words, will not move his boundary, and will not harm him in any way. So are many other religious duties bound up with it; the matter is evident to every understanding person. (translation of R. Elchanan (Charles) Wengrow). It means that at the bare minimum one has to fulfil all negative precepts bein adam l'chaveiro, which necessarily include רֵעֶֽךָ as the most likely chaveiro. Without רֵעֶֽךָ one could make a case that loving permits violating the above negative mitzvos.

The point is even strenthened with the fact that taking vengeance and grudge is formulated in plural, while loving the neighbor in the sigular. Revenging or bearing grudges or any other negative action is usually decided based on a limited number of bad character traits and can easily be extended to several people lacking such good qualities. At the same time, loving at the minimum is abstaining from all prohibitions bein adam l'chaveiro. Since some of the negative commandments are also formulated in the singular רֵעֲךָ, even at the minimum, we must have such personal conditioning when loving another Jewish person.

title: Does a Jew have to be the one doing libun hagalah
content:
# Does a Jew have to be the one doing libun hagalah ## Frage

According to Halacha, does a Jew have to be the person who does hagalah or Libun, or can a gentile do it with proper instruction?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I asked your question to R Binyamin Tabady who rules it is permitted if the non-Jew is properly instructed and supervised. title: Tefillin and upset stomach
content:
# Tefillin and upset stomach ## Frage

A person suffering from diarrhea is exempt from tefilin (SA OC 38, KSA Tefillin 10:23). According to the lashon of the halacha, it is ok, or even obligatory, to wear them if one feels they can keep themselves clean for Shema and Amidah. See the KSA:

חוֹלֶה מֵעַיִם אֲפִלּוּ אֵין לוֹ צַעַר, פָּטוּר מִן הַתְּפִלִּין, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁאֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לִשְׁמֹר אֶת עַצְמוֹ בִּנְקִיּוּת כָּרָאוּי. וְאִם נִרְאֶה לוֹ שֶׁיָּכוֹל לִהְיוֹת בְּגוּף נָקִי בִּשְׁעַת קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּתְפִלַּת שְׁמוֹנֶה עֶשְׂרֵה, יָנִיחֵם אָז

A person suffering from diarrhea, although he has no actual pain, is exempt from the mitzvah of tefillin, because he is incapable of keeping himself properly clean. If he feels that he will be able to keep his body clean when reading the Shema and during the Shemoneh Esrei, he should put them on then.

My question is, if someone has taken a medication that prevents them from opening their bowels (and doesn't cause pain), are they still "exempt" for the rest of the tefillot, or are they now "permitted" or even "obligated" to wear the tefillin? On the one hand, they practically don't have diarrhea anymore, however it is just a temporary protection (even if it works for 24 hours), and technically they still do have the ailment.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Piskei teshuvos brings in 38:1 footnote 1, that even if one is unable to clean his bowels because of constipation , he is considered to have a גוף נקי and allowed to put on tefillin. He brings this from Orchos Rebbeinu 1 page 46 in the name of R' Chaim Kaniyevski ZL.

There shouldn't be a difference between someone who is naturally constipated or someone who took medication to get himself artificially constipated.

title: Why there's no yearly Biblical commemoration for Matan Torah?
content:
# Why there's no yearly Biblical commemoration for Matan Torah? ## Frage

In the Torah, Exodus is a serious event that must be remembered and celebrated the same week every year. Multiple Biblical Mitzvos aim at remembering and enacting the event, such as retelling the story to future generations, preparing and eating the sacrifice, consuming Matza, and more. Even Succos is mentioned as the remembrance and enacting of living in Succos in the wilderness (albeit we see no textual mention of the Israelites dwelling in Succos during Exodus).

Matan Torah was, undoubtedly, a pivotal event in the history of Jewish people, however, there's no Mitzvah of remembering that day or event and replicating it yearly. IIRC, the night Torah study (Tikun Leyl Shavuos) was established only in the 16th century.

Why?

Edit: this question is specifically about the Torah view, not Rabbinic commentary.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Kli Yakar in parshas Emor addresses why there is no mention in the Torah that Shevous is commemorating Matan Torah. He says since the Torah is a constant, and is always supposed to be viewed anew, Hashem didn't make any particular day the explicit commemoration, as that would limit it to one day. Rather every day should be view as a new day of receiving the Torah.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

This specific question has actually bothered R. Nathan Laufer to write an entire book about it. "Rendezvous with God. Revealing the Meaning of the Jewish Holidays and Their Mysterious Rituals". He said in the podcast on Judaism Demystified that it is inconceivable that the celebration of the experience of receiving of the Torah has not found its way into Judaic holiday experience. Specifically, he makes the point that the holiday of Rosh haShanah, which we call Yom haZikaron, is about rememberance. Rememberance of what? Which day do we need to remember when facing Hashem's Judgement? He points out, based on what we do on Rosh haShanah is that we are remembering the day when we stood at har Sinai when receiving the Torah. Facing the Judgement of G-d is the awesome experience, which can certainly compare with what happened at Mt. Sinai, when people were dying and getting revived. (Recall Unesaneh Tokef).

During musaf of Rosh Hashanah we recite 10 verses for each of the malkiyoth, zichronoth, and shofaroth blessings. This corresponds to 10 dibroth. Many congregations opt to blow shofar 10 times right after each one of the blessings, both in the silent tefilah and in the repetition. One blow for each saying. That's also exactly a reference to the Sinai experience.

I think R. Laufer's point that Matan Torah and standing at Har Sinai is hinted on Rosh Hashanah, the celebrated Day of Creation, can be found in the second Rashi comment on the Torah in parashat Bereshis: Bereshis Bara (In the beginning of G-d's Creating): This verse says nothing but "Explain me!" It is to be understood as as the Rabbis of the blessed memory expounded it: For the Torah, which is called "The beginning of His way", and for Israel, who are called "the first of His crop". Here's where Rosh Hashanah (act of creation) got connected to Matan Torah with gzeira shava.

### Antwort 3 (Score: -8)

The Torah isn't shy about telling the future. The Torah recounts how God promised Abraham he will be a great people in the future, he will inherit the land of Israel and that his descendants will sojourn for hundreds of years and be enslaved. But where's the prophecy of the giving of the Torah? I haven't found such a prophecy, have you?

The closest hint I've seen is that when God is about to destroy Sodom and Amorah God mentions that Abraham will teach his descendants righteousness and justice... But we also don't see that happen. Can anyone point to a story in which Isaac's Torah knowledge and righteousness is on display? Jacob and Esau don't seem like they're being raised in righteousness and justice, but rather strife and jealousy. Which makes their redemption into righteous loving brothers so much more powerful in my opinion, but regardless. Why isn't the Torah talking about the wonderful Torah these people should have been learning/living?

My answer is that God might not have perceived as handing the Torah over as one of His original plans. Afterall, God seems to believe that we humans can intuit some things as right vs wrong naturally, otherwise how could God be angry at Adam for disobeying? Or warning Kain to try and dissuade him from letting his anger/jealousy consume him into murdering his brother. I don't believe God always planned to give Kain a mark, but instead chose to be in relation with Kain and humans and therefore gave Kain a mark. I believe the same is true with the Torah.

God wants to be in relation with us. And so I don't think it's fruitful to talk about whether God is perfect or not, whether God changes Their mind or not. Because regardless of God's attributes/actions, the relationship will only survive if God is in relation to our attributes/actions. Our relationship with God is described as parent child and husband wife, both of these relationships require both parties to change and adapt to each other.

And therefore it seems to me that God saw the golden calf, saw Moses as a worthy figure of teaching the people, and then for the good of us, His now chosen people, He gave us the Torah through Moses who merited being the one to teach it. God didn't change His mind, God was in relation to Moses and the Israelites. But it seems to me that God didn't give the Torah to the whole nation, He gave it to Moses, which would explain why we lack a national celebration.

title: Origins of the diagrams in Rashi, Rashbam or Tosefos
content:
# Origins of the diagrams in Rashi, Rashbam or Tosefos ## Frage

In Bava Basra 62 there are some diagrams/illustrations in the commentaries Rashbam and Tosefos, related to the topic of borders of fields, as well as in many other places in the Talmud. My question is, were these diagrams in the original manuscripts written by the authors or were they added later?

I did some research and found these manuscripts on Sefaria.

  1. Bomberg (Venice) Pressing (1523 CE) - this one seems to have space for the diagrams, but they were either erased or never added, the one that is there seems to be hand drawn
  2. Munich Manuscript 95 (1342 CE) - I don't see any diagrams, but I am not sure if the commentary is Rashbam and if the diagrams may be on a different page.
  3. The Vilna page linked at the start of the question does have the diagrams in a less graphically pleasing format then the modern Oz Vehadar I saw them in, so there is definitely upgrades done by each publisher

Also, if the commentator wrote "כזה", is that an indication that he drew a diagram in the original manuscript?

If anyone can point to any research or more info on this subject I would appreciate it.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 9)

Tosafot to Menachot 75a ד"ה כמין כי refers to a picture in Rashi, writing "צייר בקונט' כמין טי"ת". So it 'appears' that Rashi included at least some pictures in his commentary. However, as you note in your question, these diagrams were redrawn many times throughout history. Therefore, our versions may not always match Rashi's original.

For more about this, see here.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

No, but

Yad HaChazaka Teshuva 3:5

בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁשּׁוֹקְלִין עֲוֹנוֹת אָדָם עִם זְכֻיּוֹתָיו אֵין מְחַשְּׁבִין עָלָיו עָוֹן שֶׁחָטָא בּוֹ תְּחִלָּה וְלֹא שֵׁנִי אֶלָּא מִשְּׁלִישִׁי וְאֵילָךְ. אִם נִמְצְאוּ עֲוֹנוֹתָיו מִשְּׁלִישִׁי וְאֵילָךְ מְרֻבִּין עַל זְכֻיּוֹתָיו אוֹתָם שְׁתֵּי עֲוֹנוֹת מִצְטָרְפִים וְדָנִין אוֹתוֹ עַל הַכּל. וְאִם נִמְצְאוּ זְכֻיּוֹתָיו כְּנֶגֶד עֲוֹנוֹתָיו אֲשֶׁר מֵעָוֹן שְׁלִישִׁי וְאֵילָךְ מַעֲבִירִים כָּל עֲוֹנוֹתָיו רִאשׁוֹן רִאשׁוֹן. לְפִי שֶׁהַשְּׁלִישִׁי נֶחְשָׁב רִאשׁוֹן שֶׁכְּבָר נִמְחֲלוּ הַשְּׁנַיִם. וְכֵן הָרְבִיעִי הֲרֵי הוּא רִאשׁוֹן שֶׁכְּבָר נִמְחַל הַשְּׁלִישִׁי וְכֵן עַד סוֹפָן. בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים בְּיָחִיד שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (איוב לג כט) "הֶן כָּל אֵלֶּה יִפְעַל אֵל פַּעֲמַיִם שָׁלוֹשׁ עִם גָּבֶר". אֲבָל הַצִּבּוּר תּוֹלִין לָהֶן עָוֹן רִאשׁוֹן שֵׁנִי וּשְׁלִישִׁי שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (עמוס ב ו) "עַל שְׁלֹשָׁה פִּשְׁעֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וְעַל אַרְבָּעָה לֹא אֲשִׁיבֶנּוּ". וּכְשֶׁמְּחַשְּׁבִין לָהֶן עַל דֶּרֶךְ זֶה מְחַשְּׁבִין לָהֶן מֵרְבִיעִי וְאֵילָךְ. הַבֵּינוֹנִים אִם הָיָה בִּכְלַל מֶחֱצָה עֲוֹנוֹת שֶׁלָּהֶן שֶׁלֹּא הֵנִיחַ תְּפִלִּין מֵעוֹלָם דָּנִין אוֹתוֹ כְּפִי חֶטְאוֹ וְיֵשׁ לוֹ חֵלֶק לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא. וְכֵן כָּל הָרְשָׁעִים שֶׁעֲוֹנוֹתֵיהֶן מְרֻבִּים דָּנִין אוֹתָן כְּפִי חֲטָאֵיהֶם וְיֵשׁ לָהֶן חֵלֶק לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא שֶׁכָּל יִשְׂרָאֵל יֵשׁ לָהֶם חֵלֶק לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁחָטְאוּ שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (ישעיה ס כא) "וְעַמֵּךְ כֻּלָּם צַדִּיקִים לְעוֹלָם יִירְשׁוּ אָרֶץ". אֶרֶץ זוֹ מָשָׁל כְּלוֹמַר אֶרֶץ הַחַיִּים וְהוּא הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא. וְכֵן חֲסִידֵי אֻמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם יֵשׁ לָהֶם חֵלֶק לָעוֹלָם הַבָּא:

When evaluating a person's actions, sins that occur only once or twice are not considered significant. A sin is counted only if it happens three times or more. If these repeated sins outweigh a person's good deeds, then any lesser sins are also included in the judgment. If a person's good deeds are equal to or greater than the sins committed more than three times, they receive forgiveness for their sins one by one. The third sin is forgiven as it is treated like a first sin because the earlier two were already pardoned. This pattern continues: after forgiving the third sin, the fourth is seen as a first sin and is also forgiven, following the same principle. This approach applies to an individual, as referenced in Job 33:29, which states that God will act multiple times with a person. In contrast, for a community, punishment for the first three sins is put on hold, as indicated by Amos 2:6, which says retribution is withheld for the first three sins but not for the fourth. When assessing a community's sins, the evaluation begins with the fourth sin. A Beinoni, someone whose good deeds and sins are balanced, is treated according to this method. However, if this person has never performed the mitzvah of tefillin, they will be judged based on their sins but will still receive a place in the world to come. Likewise, even those who are deemed wicked and have more sins than merits are judged on their wrongdoings but will also be granted a portion in the world to come, as every Israelite has a share, shown in Isaiah 60:21, which notes that all of God’s people are righteous and will inherit everlasting life. The same applies to the righteous among the nations, who also have a place in the world to come.
