title: Job suffering for the misdeeds of his ancestors
content:
# Job suffering for the misdeeds of his ancestors ## Frage

The Torah introduces the idea of intergenerational punishment (Ex 20.5): "For I, your God YHWH, am an impassioned God, visiting the guilt of the parents upon the children, upon the third and upon the fourth generations of those who reject Me."

Moreover, it is unanimously accepted (in Judaism) that suffering as an inherent condition of the human race, stems from Adam's original sin. So, presumably, all generations must have known to attribute their sorrows to their ancestors' misdeeds.

The Book of Job contrasts different explanations for Job's suffering (surprisingly nobody reveals to him the true cause which was merely a bet between God and Satan): Divine Testing, Retributive Justice, Mystery of Suffering, and God's Sovereignty.

We observe that Job attempts to atone for the possible sins of his children by bringing sacrifices, implying that he's aware of some intergenerational influence.

However, nobody in the book suggests that he may simply pay for his forebears being idolaters which is more than reasonable.

Why is this option not on the table?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

There is a Rabbeinu Bachaya that explains how the "visiting the punishment on the children to the third and fourth generation" is actually known as a "midda rachamim" - one of Hashem's 13 attributes of mercy. Therefore, we need to understand what is merciful about it, because it comes across as justice (and at first glance, might even seem unjust, chas veshalom)

So, the explanation is this. A person who sins and deserves to be cut off is not cut off. Instead, Hashem exercises patience and mercy, and allows his children to atone for him. If his children continue to sin, Hashem still doesn't cut off the family line, but waits another generation, perhaps up to four. This can only go on so long, and eventually if there is no sign of teshuva from this branch, it will be cut off.

So, we can see, this act of mercy isn't about getting transferred punishments from our ancestors. Rather, it is that we are influenced by their ways, and we get a chance to do teshuva for the whole branch by overcoming these ways (and perhaps even tested by Hashem as part of the rectification process - true teshuva, as Rambam teaches, is achieved when we are tested again and pass, and perhaps this is part of what is being "visited" upon the children).

Job was a Tzaddik, and therefore, he had already "started fresh". Any sins of his ancestors will have been atoned for by him, and therefore he doesn't need to be tested for their sake. This story is actually about the righteous suffering, rather than sinners suffering.

title: Why is Stam Mishna attributed to R' Meir, a fourth-generation Tannah?
content:
# Why is Stam Mishna attributed to R' Meir, a fourth-generation Tannah? ## Frage

It is widely accepted that "Stam (unattributed) Mishna" is Rabbi Meir's (c. 150 CE, Sanhedrin 86a) who was one of five students of Rabbi Akiva (c. 135 CE).

I struggle to understand the implications of this statement:

  • Why is it stated by R' Yohanan who lived some 70-100 years later and not R' Meir's contemporaries?
  • Was it a hypothesis and the basis for the resolution of Mishnaic contradictions ("Let's assume that all Stam Mishna is aligned with R' Meir's views"), or a historical statement?
  • Why the bulk of the Mishnah is attributed to the fourth-generation Tannah, and not the first-generation, like Hillel, Shammay, and more, or even earlier, like Zugos, when there were no disagreements?
  • Why then, no Mishna is attributed to Moses and Jewish never-broken tradition?
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

R. Sherira Gaon explains in his Iggeres, Ch. 3 "Mishna" (translation R. Nosson Dovid Rabinovich):

"Every anonymous Mishna is [the teaching of] R. Meir. But he did not create them from his own heart. Rather, R. Meir had a certain way of teaching the mishnayos (1) to his disciples; and Rebbe (R. Yehudah ha Nassi) chose and established this way (2) to teach [the mishnayos] to everyone. R. Meir had received his way of learning [the Mishna] from his teacher, R. Akiva; and R. Akiva had received it from his teachers, the earlier sages. This we say (Sanhedrin 86a):

R. Yochanan said: " An anonymous Mishna is R. Meir. An anonymous Tosefta is R. Nechemiah. An anonymous Sifra is R. Yehuda (bar Ila'i) An anonymous Sifrei is R. Shimon (b. Yochai). And all of them taught in the way of R. Akiva.

These baraissos of Tosefta, Sifra, and Sifrei were taught by the earlier sages. Then R. Yehuda, R. Nechemiah, and R. Shimon came, and each made his own compilation of [the baraissos]. Sifra [was compiled by R. Yehuda]; Tosefta - by R. Nechemiah; and Sifrei - by R. Shimon; and the Mishna by R. Meir. And all of them follow the method of R. Akiva, for all of them were disciples of R. Akiva."

Rebbe, Rabbeinu haKadosh, R. Yehuda haNassi - he was well versed in all existing halachic presentations, Rebbi mastered 13 approaches to the laws (Nedarim 41a) as discussed here; he also can be considered a student of many rabbis. It was his choice to use approach of Rabbi Meir, because he found it the most suitable for a kind of a code that Mishna is supposed to be: fairly generic, yet detailed enough. Says gemara Eruvin 13b in praise of R. Meir:

On the topic of Rabbi Meir and his Torah study, the Gemara cites an additional statement. Rabbi Aḥa bar Ḥanina said: It is revealed and known before the One Who spoke and the world came into being that in the generation of Rabbi Meir there was no one of the Sages who is his equal. Why then didn’t the Sages establish the halakha in accordance with his opinion? It is because his colleagues were unable to ascertain the profundity of his opinion. He was so brilliant that he could present a cogent argument for any position, even if it was not consistent with the prevalent halakha. As he would state with regard to a ritually impure item that it is pure, and display justification for that ruling, and likewise he would state with regard to a ritually pure item that it is impure, and display justification for that ruling. The Sages were unable to distinguish between the statements that were halakha and those that were not.

It was taught in a baraita: Rabbi Meir was not his name; rather, Rabbi Nehorai was his name. And why was he called by the name Rabbi Meir? It was because he illuminates [meir] the eyes of the Sages in matters of the halakha. And Rabbi Nehorai was not the name of the tanna known by that name; rather, Rabbi Neḥemya was his name, and some say: Rabbi Elazar ben Arakh was his name. And why was he called by the name Rabbi Nehorai? It is because he enlightens [manhir] the eyes of the Sages in matters of the halakha.

The Gemara relates that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said: The fact that I am more incisive than my colleagues is due to the fact that I saw Rabbi Meir from behind, i.e., I sat behind him when I was his student. Had I seen him from the front, I would be even more incisive, as it is written: “And your eyes shall see your teacher” (Isaiah 30:20). Seeing the face of one’s teacher increases one’s understanding and sharpens one’s mind.

And the Gemara stated that Rabbi Abbahu said that Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Rabbi Meir had a disciple, and his name was Sumakhus, who would state with regard to each and every matter of ritual impurity forty-eight reasons in support of the ruling of impurity, and with regard to each and every matter of ritual purity forty-eight reasons in support of the ruling of purity.

(1) Each Tanna had his own style and order of teaching the mishnayos.

(2) R. Meir was his teacher (Eruvin 13b, Yebamos 93a). This point was discussed here in the comments that R. Yehuda ha Nassi did not study with Rabbi Meir, but that he studied his work.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 6)

Re:

no Mishna is attributed to Moses

The Bet Yosef (O"H 50) writes from the Ra'ah (Brachot 31a) that the chapter Eizehu Mekoman (Z'vachim 5) was said by Moshe. It is attributed to the GRA (P'ninei m'Shulhan haGRA) that this can be deduced from the language "לפנים מן הקלעים" (within the curtains) that shows up in these Mishnayot a couple times. Only the Mishkan had curtains and not the Bet Hamikdash which the Mishna generally discusses.

IMHO, there are parts of other individual Mishnayot which are clearly from Moshe. For example Negaim 7:1 which discusses if one had Tzara'at from before Matan Torah. Similarly, in Bava Kama 5:7 regarding animals going on Har Sinai which only applied while they were there.

title: Advice how to prevent sin
content:
# Advice how to prevent sin ## Frage

I would like to ask for advice when in the following situation:

  • Being in a cycle of having a habit to certain things that are forbidden, without the motivation to work on getting better. Basically, knowing that it is forbidden, having the animal soul repeatedly and naturally win. And not being motivated to do anything about it.

How can one get out of this pattern according to Mussar/chasidut?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

According to the Mesilat Yesharim:

אֲבָל כְּשֶׁיִּתְבָּרֵר אֶל הָאָדָם הֱיוֹת הַטּוֹב הַהוּא כּוֹזֵב לְגַמְרֵי מְדֻמֶּה וּבְלִי שׁוּם הַתְמָדָה נְכוֹנָה, וְהָרָע בּוֹ אֲמִתִּי אוֹ קָרוֹב לְהִוָּלֵד מִמֶּנּוּ בֶּאֱמֶת, וַדַּאי שֶׁיִּמְאַס בּוֹ וְלֹא יִרְצֵהוּ כְּלָל, עַל כֵּן זֶהוּ כָּל הַלִּמּוּד שֶׁצָּרִיךְ שֶׁיְּלַמֵּד הָאָדָם אֶת שִׂכְלוֹ לְהַכִּיר בְּחֻלְשַׁת הַתַּעֲנוּגִים הָאֵלֶּה וְשִׁקְרָם עַד שֶׁמֵּאֵלָיו יִמְאַס בָּם וְלֹא יִקְשֶׁה בְּעֵינָיו לְשַׁלְּחָם מֵאִתּוֹ.

But when it becomes clear to a person that this [apparent] good [of sinful indulgence] is completely false, imaginary and ephemeral, while its evil is truly real or truly near to result from, certainly he will become repulsed by it and not desire it in the least. Therefore, this is all of what a person needs to teach his intellect - to recognize the weakness (insignificance) of these pleasures and their falsehood, until on his own, he will be disgusted by them and have no difficulty casting them away.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The general rule is to study Torah.

אם פגע בך מנוול זה משכהו לבית המדרש. אם אבן הוא נימוח, ואם ברזל הוא מתפוצץ

If this despicable one (the yetzer hara) attacks you, drag him to the Beit Midrash. If he is like stone, he will melt; if he is like iron, he will shatter. (Kiddushin 30b)

If someone is sinning, knowing it is forbidden, it could be because they don't care enough that it is wrong. The person isn't impressed by right or wrong enough. Sometimes its because they have pleasures and desires they don't want to deny, or because they've rationalised it, or are cognitively dissonant. This includes not caring enough about the reward or punishment. Things can be worse too - not caring about Hashem or others, chas veshalom.

All are made worse by repetition and addiction. All are made worse by the numbing of the person's soul overall that happens through sin.

As Rabbi Manis Friedman says in this shiur, we weren't born yesterday. Is it right? Is it wrong? Does it matter? We know that it's forbidden, and we know that that's the truth, whether we are motivated or not. And yes, we know it's wrong too.

So, to work on that, study some Torah, a little or a lot but as much as one can:

אפילו לא שנה אדם אלא פרק אחד שחרית ופרק אחד ערבית קיים לא ימוש.

Even if a person studies only one chapter in the morning and one chapter in the evening, he fulfills the commandment of 'this Torah shall not depart from your mouth.' (Menachot 99b)

Along with prayer for success: it's got all the information we need to help us connect back reality, and Hashem will help us, even if all we can open is the eye of a needle.

תּוֹרַת ה' תְּמִימָה, מְשִׁיבַת נָפֶשׁ.

The Torah of Hashem is perfect, and restores the soul (Tehillim 19:8)

I would just add from personal experience: even if someone does already learn Torah, and has never been particularly affected by it, don't give up. It can years, or even decades. Sometimes a person learns for decades, and then one day stumbles upon just the right thing that speaks to his soul, shines a new light on all the learning that came before, connecting dots, and ends up affecting real, permanent change. It's guaranteed, but the timeframe is up to Hashem. Don't ever give up or lose hope!

For example:

Moshe answers the big, eternal question of life: "what does Hashem want", in the pasuk:

"And now, Israel, what does Hashem your God ask of you, but to fear Hashem your God, to walk in all His ways, to love Him, and to serve Hashem your God with all your heart and with all your soul." (Devarim 10:12).

The Tanya explains the first step: fearing Him. Chapter 41 paraphrased (heard this paraphrase from Rabbi Roni Fine):

If someone is in the room with us, we usually are ashamed to sin or be improper. This means we fear them.

and thus fearing Hashem is staying in touch with reality. It's a starting point, and the beginning of the ladder for the rest - following in His ways, doing it for Him (and our fellow Jews) with love will also come from this study.

These things that Moshe asks of us are explained in the chapters of Perishut, Tahara, Chassidut and Yirat Chet of Mesilat Yisharim, rather than the first 3 chapters. Tanya teaches that everyone can apply these lessons, and do all this for some and eventually all the Mitzvot - every Jew. It's "not across the ocean" but "very close to our heart and mouth to do it" (Devarim 30:13-14).

Learning this doesn't change one over night, but it does change one eventually, the Torah guarantees anyone can do proper Teshuva:

And you will return to Hashem your God and obey His voice... And Hashem your God will restore your fortunes and have compassion on you. (Devarim 30:2-3)

and

תנינן, לית מלה בעלמא דקיימא קמי תשובה

It is taught: nothing in the world stands in the way of Teshuva (Zohar, Saba d’Mishpatim, 106a)

title: Issur Matzav & Issur Ma’aseh
content:
# Issur Matzav & Issur Ma’aseh ## Frage

Around 45 minutes into a shiur on Shehiyah, Rabbi Eliezer Krohn said in the name of the Chazon Ish that if you put on a food item in a forbidden manner, not accounting for the kulas of Chazal to permit it, before the item reaches ma’achal ben Drusai, before Shabbat, and it cooks into Shabbat, it is assur to eat it b’di’eved and you can’t simply do teshuvah later on.

The phrase he used was that it is an “איסור מצב” rather than an “איסור מעשה,” in the sense that the איסור applies to the condition itself rather than only to the action.

Are there any klalim in terms of differentiating between these two types of issurim?

L’choira, for example, for a healthy adult Yisroel to be uncircumcised would be an איסור מצב, but are there general principles governing which issurim fall into either category?

title: The Chofetz Chaim's Shocking View of Baalei Teshuva
content:
# The Chofetz Chaim's Shocking View of Baalei Teshuva ## Frage

The Chofetz Chaim in Sefer Nidchei Yisroel makes some shocking statements about those born to parents who did not keep the halachos of Nidda.

See beginning of chapter 41, where he assumes that these children will be evil and rebel against God.

At the end of the chapter see here (middle of the first column), he states that these children will certainly be "Reshaim Gemurim". This contradicts what is said in the name of the Steipler that by learning Torah and performing Mitzvos these children are just like everyone else.

Additionally, see here (second column in brackets), where he also seems to disagree with Rabbi Moshe Feinsteins' view which states that if the mother bathed in other bodies of water, we can assume it was a proper Tevilah.

Does anyone know if his opinion is discussed by other commentators?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

The context here is that the Chafetz Chaim is exhorting people to observe the laws of nidda by warning them of risks associated with failure to observe these laws, and the purpose of his writing isn't directed as a polemic against children of nidda.

The Chafetz Chaim is basing himself on the statement of Rabbi Levi in N'darim 20b:

וברותי מכם המורדים והפושעים בי אמר רבי לוי אלו בני תשע מדות בני אסנ"ת משגע"ח בני אימה בני אנוסה בני שנואה בני נידוי בני תמורה בני מריבה בני שכרות בני גרושת הלב בני ערבוביא בני חצופה

Translation (Sefaria):

The verse states: “And I will purge out from among you the rebels, and those that transgress against Me” (Ezekiel 20:38). Rabbi Levi said: These are children of those who have nine traits, who are defective from their conception and from whom rebels and transgressors emerge. The mnemonic for these nine traits is children of the acronym aleph, samekh, nun, tav, mem, shin, gimmel, ayin, ḥet.

The children of nine traits are as follows... children of ostracism [niddui], i.e., one of the parents was ostracized by the court...

This translation of "בני נידוי" (as referring to children who were conceived when a parent was under niddui excommunication) follows the view of a number of rishonim (Rashi ad loc., s.v "בני נידוי"; Rambam, Mishneh Torah, Hil. Isurei Bi'ah 21:12)

The Tur (EH 25), however, states as his primary interpretation that this refers to children who were conceived when their mother was a nidda:

בני נידוי בני נדה אע"פ שאינו ממזר מן התורה וי"מ שהוא או היא בנידוי שאסורים בתשמיש המטה וה"ה נמי אם אחד מהם אבל

Translation:

Children of niddui: This refers to children of a nidda mother, even though they are not biblically mamzerim. And there are those who explain that it refers to when either he or she is in niddui excommunication when they are forbidden to engage in marital relations, and the same law applies when one of them is in mourning.

In Beiur Halacha (240, s.v. "בני נידוי") the Chafetz Chaim cites both opinions, and actually presents the interpretation of excommunication first:

בני נידוי: היינו כשהוא או היא היו אז בנידויים וה"ה כשהוא או היא היו באבלם... ויש גורסין בני נדה דאף דאין הולד ממזר מזה פגום מיהא הוי ועליהם אמר הכתוב וברותי מכם וגו' [פמ"ג]

Other authorities, as mentioned, have grappled with how to approach this issue from the standpoint of couples who wish to get married, when one of them was born from parents who were not particular to observe the laws of nidda. R' Moshe Feinstein (Igros Moshe EH IV, 14), for instance, says we can infer from someone's good character that the mother likely immersed herself in a body of water that constitutes a valid mikva (like the ocean) before her child was conceived, even if the mother's intention wasn't to observe the laws of nidda.

The Chafetz Chaim, when referring to "all the waters in the world", merely meant that showering is insufficient and that immersion in a valid body of water would be required (see Shulchan 'Aruch YD 201:1). As such, he would not necessarily object to R' Moshe Feinstein's reasoning.

title: How much does a ma'ah cost in £/$ in today's world?
content:
# How much does a ma'ah cost in £/$ in today's world? ## Frage

To work out the exchange rate between the mishnayos/gemoroh money and nowadays to make the numbers more realistic.

EDIT 13.9.2024 to answer a few questions: I meant in terms of purchasing power but i guess you could use silver value to get to there.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 11)

According to the table of coins in the "Practical Talmudic Dictionary" by R. Yitzchak Frank, מעה/Ma'ah is a silver coin weighing about 0.7 gram / 0.02251 oz (early opinion per Double AA), and more precisely 0.58 gram / 0.02046 oz (16 medium barley seeds). I will use the US dollar value of silver for comparison. Obviously market prices can vary from country to country.

Silver is a very soft metal. Due to high purity of the presently minted silver coins, they are sold in plastic casing for protection. Old silver coins were harder and obviously they did not have the same purity. The present cost of 0.999% pure silver bar is $31.31 USD per 1 oz. Therefore, the 0.90 pure silver should be about $28.75 USD per 1 oz (one needs to add the cost of additional weight) so that 1 ma'ah comes down to about $0.65 USD (old opinion) or $0.60 (more precisely).

As far as purchasing power, evidently, market prices changed all the time even in the times of Gemara. In masekhes Gittin 57a there is an example that 1 (silver) dinar could purchase 40 modios of grain, or 1 seah. The currently accepted volume of 1 seah is either 8.29 liter (R. Chaim Noeh) or 14.4 liter (Chazon Ish). It follows, that 1 ma'ah, which is 1/6 of a dinar, could be used to purchase 1.38 liter - 2.4 liter of wheat.

The comparison to current prices may not be meaningful because the agricultural commodities became cheaper due to advances in technology. The current price of wheat is about $6.1074 per bushel which is 36.368 liter or $0.167933 per 1 liter. Thus, we see that the wheat equivalent of 1 ma'ah would cost $0.23 - $0.403 today.

Production of silver also became much cheeper. R. Baruch Epstein in Torah Temimah (published in 1902) on Shemos 22:6 (comment עט) notes: that in his days the silver for two ma'ah was equivalent to 10 kopecks = 0.1 of the Russian Ruble. He says that in the time of gemara silver was much more expensive, and already in his time it was so cheap that one could not use it for oaths or marriage. Torah Temimah points to Tosafos in Menachos 107b, who notes this specific issue with the value of silver.

One can take over-all value of money from comparing minimal savings which prevented a person from getting gifts to the poor at the time of Mishna and now. Mishna Peah 8:8 states that a person in posession of 200 dinar cannot get gifts to poor. There does not seem to be a similar statistics on personal savings that prevent receiving government support. However, at present, to get by in most states to meet basic needs one needs between $30,000 and $45,000 annually depending on a state. Taking average of $37,000 as equivalent of 200 dinar, one gets about $31 per ma'ah. This value encapsulates all price reductions due to advances in technology.

There is another example in Mishna Hagiga 1:2 (suggested by ProfJames - thank you) which gives the minimal value of a lamb for the 'Olah (R'iyah) and Shlamim (Chagiga) offerings as 1 ma'ah or 2 ma'ah. The feeder lamb current prices (older than 9 days) are around $200-220 USD. In this case, advances in technology increased the value of domesticated animals by making them bigger. Based on the size of bones, as the video by Simcha Jacobovici attests, at the time of Mishna animals were smaller.

The market for old coins despite their lower silver purity is very different. Certainly, the antique value and the good condition of the rare coin could fetch a lot. Even not so antique, pre 1921 year 1oz Morgan silver dollar is sold for $49.95 USD compared to $28.20 value of its silver content.

title: Where Does Rashi Mention the Streets of Venice?
content:
# Where Does Rashi Mention the Streets of Venice? ## Frage

After some discussion with some chavrusot, someone mentioned that there is a Rashi somewhere in Shas that discusses either the streets of Venice, or at least a city with "dry streets" surrounded by water. I cannot seem to locate a source for this using other methods. Has anyone heard of a mekor for this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 15)

Perhaps this, in Rashi on Yeshayah 42:10:

ומלואו. הקבועים בים ולא באיים אלא בתוך המים שופכים עפר כל אחד ואחד כדי בית והולכים מבית לבית בספינה כגון עיר ווניציי"א:‏

"[Those who go down into the sea] and its fullness": who live permanently in the sea - not on islands, but within the water. Each person pours out enough dirt for [the foundation of] his house, and they travel from one house to another by boat, as in the city of Venice.

title: Is there any explanation on whether Terach knew that Nimrod would kill the slave baby that he substituted for Avrohom
content:
# Is there any explanation on whether Terach knew that Nimrod would kill the slave baby that he substituted for Avrohom ## Frage

It seems that Nimrod changed drastically over time to become so narcissitic and murderous. I am not clear where Terach sits in the middle of that politically - Is there any explanation or discussions on the close relationship between Terach and Nimrod?Historical story R. Nissin Mindel Z'l How was Terach viewed on the balance as a rasha or a tzadik? Did Terach know that Nimrod would violently murder the slave child Terach exchanged for Avrohom his son (subterfuge) or was Nimrod's wicked response a surprise to Terach - perhaps in those days that type of thing was accepted/common in that era? (Horrific but possible?!?) And was there any other option that Terach could have had in that scenario?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It states in Rashi Bereshit 11:32 about Terach:

Therefore, Scripture calls him dead, for the wicked, even in their lifetime, are called dead

However it also states in Rashi Bereshit 15:15

His father was an idolater, and He announces to him that he will come to him? This teaches you that Terah repented. [from Tan. Shemoth 18]

So he was seen as wicked - in fact Avraham breaks from his philosophy etc...; however, he does repent and become righteous at some point after Avraham leaving and before his own death.

title: Tannaic sources for the need to compile the Mishna
content:
# Tannaic sources for the need to compile the Mishna ## Frage

Following "Why-didnt-rebbi-compile-all-existing-pieces-of-the-oral-tradition-into-the-mishna", a common explanation for the compilation of the Mishna is that "Israel was losing track of the Oral Torah due to oppression; students weren't able to get the training they needed and they started to have a lot of disagreement".

In my understanding, such posterior claims are apologetic rather than explanational, they try to justify an existing phenomenon, rather than provide a factual cause.

I'm not aware of any sign of authorship in the Mishnah, or a need from the earlier Tannayim to unify the sources, e.g. there are fierce arguments between the House of Hillel and the House of Shammay but nobody proposes writing down a unifying version for future generations.

Is there any textual support for that claim from the generation of Rabbi Yehuda or earlier?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)
  • Introduction:

Beis Hillel and Beis Shammai are before Rebbi, and they are "unified" in Mishna (ie: both opinions recorded) - similarly their opinions are already Halachically decided who is correct.

Many times Rebbi is declaring in Mishna (and Gemara follows suit) the Halachic opinion and those who argue for a number of reasons (one is to specify the exact argument, and often that it was decided, and no other opinion was held on that topic).

  • Answer:

Authorship of the Mishna is an "on going" process before Rebbi, you can see that in the following:

Chagiga 2a Where it says "Here is the first Mishna and here is the later Mishna" It is explaining why the word "הכל" is used; possibly, because it came to include something according to Beit Hillel and subsequently Beis Hillel changed their opinion and agreed with Beit Shamai (see there); however, once the Mishna was memorized with the word "הכל" it was not changed subsequently. Either to make note of the change of opinion or because it was already memorized, or perhaps הכל had another reason for being there (as the Gemara also states). However, you can see there is a specific authorship and system for authorship. Even before Rebbi it was memorized.

There are other examples of systemized authorship before Rebbi that Rebbi included in his unified version. Though I cannot recall them all off the top of my head.

A simple proof is Chagiga 14a where it states:

בעלי משנה כגון ר׳׳י בן תימא וחביריו. פליגו בה רב פפא ורבנן חד אמר שש מאות סדרי משנה וחד אמר שבע מאות סדרי משנה

"Masters of Mishna" Like R' Yehuda ben Tema and his colleagues. Rav Pappa and The Rabbis argue: One says [they mastered] 600 orders of Mishna and One says 700 orders of Mishna

It seems clear that there were different "versions" and although there might have been "many" they were distinct sets. Presumably with a lot of overlap - but nevertheless distinct style/system of teaching the same Oral Law.

If they had different actual laws, Rebbi would need to include them either way. They would exist as Baraisos or Toseftas but we don't see any hint of that.

Also since they aren't individual Mishnas and rather called sets, meaning they were arranged and systemized; otherwise there would be an infinite and wouldn't be called a "set", rather it would be listed as number of Mishnayot on a topic - hopefully the above made sense.

Hopefully this helps you in a way understanding that the Mishnayot were systematically authored for memorization, that they existed before Rebbi, and that Rebbi simply chose or crafted one system for everybody, lest you mix two different styles/systems for example. And so that Rebbi could include the agreed upon Halachic decisions until that time.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

One can start investigating the origin of the Midrash Eleh Ezkerah, which separately records the event of tragic execution of the 10 Jewish Sages, the major tannaim, by the Roman Imperial government. The same event is also recorded in Eicha Rabba and Midrash Tehilim. While these are amoraic and post-Amoraic sources, already the tanna Elazar haKalir wrote a kinna ארזי הלבנון/Arzei haLevanon, executions of these tannaim are mentioned in the gemara and also ashkenazi Yom Kippur liturgy (אמיץ כח/Amitz Koach). The object of the Midrash is not only the description executions, but the fact that the Roman government expressed interest in Judaism and the Torah and the end result was erasing the names of the core Jewish Sages. For example, Gemara Gittin 56a records conversion of emperor Nero to Judaism, which is unconfirmed historically. What is similar to? The development of Christianity.

If one compares the story of Kamtza and Bar Kamtza in Gittin 55b, one can find a strong correlation to the story of the so called Apostolic Council of Jerusalem described in the New Testament Acts 15-17. This was a moment where the the reformers of Jewish law (Saducees, Boethusians, and others) split into two groups: one side sought rebellion against Rome headed by James (brother of Jesus) and the other side - Paul, who advocated peace with Romans. In the aftermath the followers of James wanted to kill Paul, who actually went to contact the Roman emperor Nero via Epaphroditus. The Roman documents also mention an official with such a name. I will not speculate, whether or not Christianity was a project of the Roman government, while they certainly created new religious cults in every country that they occupied combining Roman and local deities. However, the reading verses of the Scripture in a way that is devoid of tradition (i.e. by cutting the chain of tradition via erasing the names of the core tannaim), by abolishing mitzvos and subplanting the machshavah with hellenist neoplatonic philosophy certainly required that the text like the Mishna be developed.

Therefore, the real question is why the Mishna has not been put to writing prior to those events. Jewish people, like many other nations during the same time shifted from prophetic solutions to more legalistic solutions of the disputs. As discussed here in connection with development of the Mishna, Netziv in the introduction to the Ha’amek Sh’alah to Sheiltos of Rav Hai Gaon (translated as "The Path of Torah") explained that holiness of the Temple somehow allowed the Sanhedrin to arrive at the correct psak without systematically developing generic legal system. Thus, destruction of the Temple and development of Christianity are the real reasons for the need of development of the Mishna.

title: Torah service on shabbat with no kohanim and not enough yisraelim
content:
# Torah service on shabbat with no kohanim and not enough yisraelim ## Frage

If there are no kohanim in shul on shabbat, Ashkenazi practice is to give the first aliyah to a levi or yisrael, and the subsequent six aliyot to yisraelim. (See Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim 135:6,9,10.)

What happens if there are no kohanim and five or fewer yisraelim, with the rest of the minyan made up of leviim? Presumably in these cases, one would give aliyot to more than one levi.

How should the seven aliyot be distributed between the leviim and yisraelim?

Ideally, answers should address the six cases ranging from zero yisraelim to five yisraelim, and specify which aliyot go to which type of person in each case.

(I’m asking mainly about these specific scenarios in order to keep the question more manageable. Feel free to expand your answer to include other scenarios with one or more kohanim, some leviim and insufficient yisraelim.)

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The regular rules for Aliyah positions are based on three rules: 1) kohen and levi read first if available to avoid fighting about who reads first (Gittin 59a), 2) a kohen should not read directly after a different kohen, nor levi after another levi, so as not to make people wonder if the first one was found to be invalid (Gittin 59b), 3) some say Rule 2 applies even if the two are not directly adjacent since the latter 5 aliyot are generally for Yisraelim some might come to question the validity of the latter kohen/levi (cf. Shulchan Aruch OC 135:10), and some say not to worry about this third rule if calling another Kohen-Levi-Yisrael triad (cf. Mishna Berura, ibid :37).

The Shulchan Aruch (OC 135:12) rules that if you're stuck then we allow breaking all those rules. Since Rule 3 is highly disputed, that'd be the first to go. Accordingly, it comes out that you basically do as close to a repeating Kohen-Levi-Yisrael as possible as many times as needed to fill out 7 people.

There are two caveats to keep in mind. First, if the case is one with at least one Yisrael and no Levi, then the first triplet would be Kohen-Kohen-Yisrael like an ordinary situation of no Levi, but not subsequent triplets since those are arguably not actually necessary as triplets. Second, if there are only Kohanim and exactly one other, or only Leviyim and exactly one Yisrael, the Shulchan Aruch (:12) rules we flip the script and put the singleton first to avoid fighting and continue with repeating statuses from there.

Example case of 2 Leviyim and 1 Yisrael: Kohen, Levi, Yisrael, Kohen, Levi, Kohen, Kohen.

Example case of 0 Leviyim and 3 Yisraelim: Kohen, same Kohen, Yisrael, Kohen, Yisrael, Kohen, Yisrael.

Example case of 0 Leviyim and 1 Yisrael: Yisrael, Kohen, Kohen, Kohen, Kohen, Kohen, Kohen.

title: Could there be spiritual repercussions for someone who depends financially on a sinner?
content:
# Could there be spiritual repercussions for someone who depends financially on a sinner? ## Frage

If a person depends financially almost entirely on donations from another person, and that person is a sinner, would the receiver of the money face spiritual repercussions?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Since there are multiple questions here, and not all of them are Torah-related, I’ll address one that is not specific to Torah:

If you define “financial stability” as “financial independence,” i.e. no longer having to rely on tzedakah, then she would have more trouble reaching financial stability if she is relying on anyone’s tzedakah, not just that of a sinner.

You should CYLOR, but:

Kitzur Shulchan Aruch 34:15-16:

לְעוֹלָם יַרְחִיק אָדָם אֶת עַצְמוֹ מִן הַצְּדָקָה, וִיגַלְגֵל עַצְמוֹ בְצַעַר, שֶׁלֹּא יִצְטָרֵךְ לַבְּרִיּוֹת. וְכֵן צִוּוּ חֲכָמֵינוּ זִכְרוֹנָם לִבְרָכָה, עֲשֵׂה שַׁבַּתְּךָ חֹל וְאַל תִּצְטָרֵךְ לַבְּרִיּוֹת. וַאֲפִלּוּ הָיָה חָכָם מְכֻבָּד וְהֶעֱנִי, יַעֲסֹק בְּאֻמָּנוּת וַאֲפִלּוּ בְּאֻמָּנוּת מְנֻוֶּלֶת, וְאַל יִצְטָרֵךְ לַבְּרִיּוֹת.

A person should always avoid taking charity. He should suffer hardship rather than depend on people. And so did our Sages of blessed memory command, "Make your Sabbath like a weekday rather than be dependent upon others." Even if an honored scholar becomes impoverished, he should find some occupation even a lowly job, rather than depend on people.

כָּל מִי שֶׁאֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לִטּוֹל מֵהַצְּדָקָה, וּמְרַמֶּה אֵת הַבְּרִיּוֹת וְנוֹטֵל, אֵינוֹ מֵת עַד שֶׁיִּצְטָרֵךְ לַבְּרִיּוֹת. וְכָל מִי שֶׁצָּרִיךְ לִטּוֹל, וְאֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לִחְיוֹת אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן יִטּוֹל, כְּגוֹן זָקֵן אוֹ חוֹלֶה אוֹ בַּעַל יִסּוּרִין, וּמֵגִיס דַּעְתּוֹ וְאֵינוֹ נוֹטֵל, הֲרֵי זֶה שׁוֹפֵךְ דָּמִים וּמִתְחַיֵּב בְּנַפְשׁוֹ, וְאֵין לוֹ בְּצַעֲרוֹ אֶלָּא עֲווֹנוֹת וַחֲטָאִים. וְכָל מִי שֶׁצָּרִיךְ לִטּוֹל וּמְצַעֵר עַצְמוֹ, וְדוֹחֵק אֶת הַשָּׁעָה וְחַי חַיֵּי צַעַר, כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יַטְרִיחַ עַל הַצִּבּוּר, אֵינוֹ מֵת עַד שֶׁיְפַרְנֵס אֲחֵרִים, וְעָלָיו הַכָּתוּב אוֹמֵר, בָּרוּךְ הַגֶּבֶר אֲשֶׁר יִבְטַח בַּה' וְגוֹ' (רנ"ה).

Whoever has no need to take charity, and deceives people and takes, will not die before actually needing charity. Anyone who needs to take [charity], and cannot survive unless he takes [charity], for example, one who is old, sick or suffering, but whose pride doesn't allow him to take [charity], sheds [his own] blood and is liable for his own life, and all he has for his suffering are sins. Anyone who needs [charity] and inflicts himself with suffering and "bides his time," and lives a life of suffering in order not to burden the community, will not die before acquiring the means to support others. And about him it is said: "Blessed is the man who trusts in Hashem.

title: Davening and learning when emotionally distressed
content:
# Davening and learning when emotionally distressed ## Frage

In similar but slightly different light to this question: If one is mentally drained, should a person still daven? Even if that person cannot concentrate?

What is the halacha for one who is very angry, or very upset, or very emotionally shaken? Should they daven? There are sources that state otherwise, but I have heard in the past that they may not apply now, due to our lowly generation who doesn't guarantee concentration in any circumstances anyway.

Should one learn? Perhaps the study will help calm him down?

To avoid simple answers like "stop being angry", lets say that it's a situation where the distress is beyond a person's current "level" of self control, and they can't quickly calm down at the moment. They can try harder in future to improve their self control, but now is not the time for that.

title: Four Non-Kosher Animals With One Sign?
content:
# Four Non-Kosher Animals With One Sign? ## Frage

The popular subject in kiruv classes is discussion about non-kosher animals that have one non-kosher sign discussed in Vayikra 11:4-7:

The following, however, of those that either chew the cud or have true hoofs, you shall not eat: the camel—although it chews the cud, it has no true hoofs: it is impure for you. The hyrax — although it chews the cud, it has no true hoofs: it is impure for you. The hare — although it chews the cud, it has no true hoofs: it is impure for you. And the swine — although it has true hoofs, with the hoofs cleft through, it does not chew the cud: it is impure for you.

The lecturers in kiruv classes note that these are the only animals with one non-kosher sign. However the article by tuxeliana ~ Random thoughts about Judaism as of March 11, 2014 suggests that the assumption about the uniqueness of the four animals may be questioned.

How can one address the problem?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Natan Slifkin wrote a book "The Camel, the Hare, and the Hyrax" where he studied the statements in the Torah, the Talmud and other Jewish sources. He gives the following summary on his site:

  1. The Torah lists four animals that possess only one kosher sign.

  2. The Talmud, following its own principles of drawing additional meaning from words in the Torah, infers that the Torah’s list is exhaustive.

  3. Elsewhere, the Talmud states that this topic argues for the Divine origins of the Torah, but the meaning of this is disputed:

Approach A: The simple reading of Rashi is that the argument refers to Moshe being familiar with the physiology of the four animals in the list.

Approach B: Alternately, one can argue that it refers to Moshe knowing all the local animals that possess one kosher sign.

Approach C: Tosafos explains that it refers to Moshe knowing about an animal called the shesuah, but this is a difficult explanation, as the simple reading of the verse does not indicate that the shesuah is a type of animal.

Approach D: Beginning in the eighteenth century, it was claimed that the Talmud’s argument refers to the Torah saying that there are no other such animals in the entire world. This argument rests upon (a) the boldness of the claim and (b) the veracity of it (as per point 2 above).

  1. Making an argument from the boldness of the claim is fundamentally flawed, as there is no claim in the Torah that there are only four animals in the world possessing one kosher sign. Simply speaking, they are presented merely as examples from the region of the Land of Israel that were a particular dietary risk for the Jewish People. The idea that the list is specified as being exhaustive would only be accepted by someone with an a priori belief in the divine origins of the Talmud.

  2. The lamoids and peccaries from South America also possess only one kosher sign. To posit that they are of the same min as camels and pigs (respectively) can only be done with a novel definition of min that grants a high degree of unspecified flexibility in categorizing new species under the Torah’s preexisting range of types. Accordingly, making an argument out of the exclusivity of the list is greatly weakened.

  3. There is overwhelming evidence (discussed in chapters six and seven) that the shafan and arneves are the hyrax and the hare, and there are no alternative viable candidates. Positing the existence of extinct and unknown species is not viable in this case.

  4. According to all evidence, the hare does not bring up the cud. To resolve this problem, we must say that the term ma’aleh gerah is an idiom that refers to such phenomena as ruminant-style chewing or cecotrophy, and/or to invoke the concept that "the Torah speaks as in the language of men." These approaches are viable, albeit somewhat difficult.

  5. There are conflicting reports as to whether the hyrax regurgitates its food. Based on my own extensive observations of hyraxes, it appears that they do sometimes regurgitate small amounts. It is likely that the hyrax practices merycism, which can be defined as ma’aleh gerah without difficulty. If it does not practice merycism, then it can only be defined as ma’aleh gerah on the basis of its manner of chewing, probably requiring us to invoke the concept that “the Torah speaks as in the language of men.” As with the hare, these approaches are viable, albeit somewhat difficult.

  6. Since we are forced to define characteristics such as merycism, ruminant-style chewing or cecotrophy as ma’aleh gerah, then there are still further types of animals that possess only one kosher sign, even with our novel flexible definition of min/type.

  7. These further examples of animals with one kosher sign raise a problem with the Talmud, which apparently claims that the Torah’s list is exhaustive. However, there are two approaches which explain the Talmud in a way that avoids this problem:

• The Talmud is only making a statement about the exclusivity of the camel (due to it being the only ma’aleh gerah animal that is domesticated, or that lacks upper teeth, or that is a true ruminant); but the hare and hyrax may indeed share their characteristics with other animals. This only leaves the problem of the lamoids, which can perhaps be rated as a type of camel, albeit with some difficulty.

• The Talmud is only giving a rule for the general region surrounding the Land of Israel, but there may indeed be other such animals in remote regions of the world. This fits well with how various other seemingly universal rules in the Talmud are explained by other authorities - including Chazal themselves! - as only referring to local animals.

The book discusses other animals that fall under such wider classification.

The animals practicing cecotrophy: some types of rats, pikas, lemurs, coypu / nutrias, coalas (during one stage of their development), ringtail possums, capybaras, some of which obviously can be rejected as examples of sheretz.

The animals practicing merycism: cangaroos, koalas.

Among the additional animals with split hooves, which don't chew cud, the book also rejects the case of hippopotamuses, and discusses tapirs, and babirusas and concludes that despite developed stomachs these animals do not chew cud.

While Slifkin's answer reflects the present day state of science and observation of animal world, studies in genetics show that the creation of animal kinds is rather fluid (Jeanson, "Replacing Darwin"). Therefore, the rabbis in the Talmud could have been quoting the tradition from the Noach's Ark. For estimates, regarding the number of species in the Ark, one can read the articles by Jean Lightner and her collegues (Determining Ark Kinds, Mammalian Ark kinds).

title: Jewish woman that engages in relations adulterous?
content:
# Jewish woman that engages in relations adulterous? ## Frage

In Chumash Devarim Parshat Ki Tetzei 22:13 it states that if a man takes a wife and is intimate with her and then despises her and then makes libelous charges against her that she was not a virgin when he took her, why is she considered an adulterous woman?

She wasn't married when she lost her virginity so wouldn't she be considered a harlot? Or a promiscuous woman? Why an adulterous woman?

13 If a man takes a wife, is intimate with her and despises her, יגכִּֽי־יִקַּ֥ח אִ֖ישׁ אִשָּׁ֑ה וּבָ֥א אֵלֶ֖יהָ וּשְׂנֵאָֽהּ: [If a man takes a wife,] is intimate with her, and despises her: in the end he will…

וּבָא אֵלֶיהָ וּשְׂנֵאָֽהּ: סוֹפוֹ, 14 and he makes libelous charges against her and gives her a bad name, saying, "I took this woman, and when I came to her, I did not find any evidence of virginity for her." ידוְשָׂ֥ם לָהּ֙ עֲלִילֹ֣ת דְּבָרִ֔ים וְהוֹצִ֥א עָלֶ֖יהָ שֵׁ֣ם רָ֑ע וְאָמַ֗ר אֶת־הָֽאִשָּׁ֤ה הַזֹּאת֙ לָקַ֔חְתִּי וָֽאֶקְרַ֣ב אֵלֶ֔יהָ וְלֹֽא־מָצָ֥אתִי לָ֖הּ בְּתוּלִֽים: make libelous charges against her: One sin leads to another sin. He transgressed [the negative commandment of] “You shall not hate [your brother in your heart]” (Lev. 19:17); so eventually he will come to [commit the sin of] slander (לָשׁוֹן הָרַע). - [Sifrei 22:87]

וְשָׂם לָהּ עֲלִילֹת דְּבָרִים: – עֲבֵרָה גּוֹרֶרֶת עֲבֵרָה, עָבַר עַל לֹא תִשְׂנָא, סוֹפוֹ לָבֹא לִידֵי לָשׁוֹן הָרָע (עי' ספרי): this woman: We learn from here that he says nothing except in the presence of his opponent. — [Sifrei 22:89]

אֶת־הָֽאִשָּׁה הַזֹּאת: מִכָּאן שֶׁאֵין אוֹמֵר דָּבָר אֶלָּא בִּפְנֵי בַעַל דִּין (שם): 15 Then the girl's father and her mother shall obtain evidence of the girl's virginity, and take it out to the elders of the city, to the gate. טווְלָקַ֛ח אֲבִ֥י הַנַּֽעֲרָ֖ה (כתיב הנער) וְאִמָּ֑הּ וְהוֹצִ֜יאוּ אֶת־בְּתוּלֵ֧י הַנַּֽעֲרָ֛ה (כתיב הנער) אֶל־זִקְנֵ֥י הָעִ֖יר הַשָּֽׁעְרָה: The girl’s father and her mother [shall obtain evidence…]: Let those who raised this evil offspring be disgraced because of her. — [Sifrei 22:90]

אֲבִי הנערה וְאִמָּהּ: מִי שֶׁגִּדְּלוּ גִּדּוּלִים הָרָעִים יִתְבַּזּוּ עָלֶיהָ (עי' שם): 16 And the girl's father shall say to the elders, "I gave my daughter to this man as a wife, and he despised her; טזוְאָמַ֛ר אֲבִ֥י הַנַּֽעֲרָ֖ה (כתיב הנער) אֶל־הַזְּקֵנִ֑ים אֶת־בִּתִּ֗י נָתַ֜תִּי לָאִ֥ישׁ הַזֶּ֛ה לְאִשָּׁ֖ה וַיִּשְׂנָאֶֽהָ: And the girl’s father shall say [to the elders]: [The father, but not the mother.] This teaches us that a woman is not permitted to speak in the presence of her husband [when others are present]. — [Sifrei 22:91]

וְאָמַר אֲבִי הנערה: מְלַמֵּד שֶׁאֵין רְשׁוּת לָאִשָּׁה לְדַבֵּר בִּפְנֵי הָאִישׁ (שם): 17 And behold, he made libelous charges, saying, 'I did not find evidence of your daughter's virginity.' But this is the evidence of my daughter's virginity!' And they shall spread the garment before the elders of the city. יזוְהִנֵּה־ה֡וּא שָׂם֩ עֲלִילֹ֨ת דְּבָרִ֜ים לֵאמֹ֗ר לֹֽא־מָצָ֤אתִי לְבִתְּךָ֙ בְּתוּלִ֔ים וְאֵ֖לֶּה בְּתוּלֵ֣י בִתִּ֑י וּפָֽרְשׂוּ֙ הַשִּׂמְלָ֔ה לִפְנֵ֖י זִקְנֵ֥י הָעִֽיר: and they shall spread the garment: This is a figurative expression, meaning: they shall clarify the matter as [“clear”] as a [new] garment. — [Sifrei 22:92, Keth. 46a]

וּפָֽרְשׂוּ הַשִּׂמְלָה: הֲרֵי זֶה מָשָׁל, מְחֻוָּרִין הַדְּבָרִים כַּשִּׂמְלָה (שם; כתובות שם): 18 Then, the elders of that city shall take the man and chasten him. יחוְלָֽקְח֛וּ זִקְנֵ֥י הָֽעִיר־הַהִ֖וא אֶת־הָאִ֑ישׁ וְיִסְּר֖וּ אֹתֽוֹ: and chasten him: [with] lashes. — [Sifrei 22:93, Keth. 46a]

וְיִסְּרוּ אֹתֽוֹ: מַלְקוּת (שם): 19 And they shall fine him one hundred [shekels of] silver because he defamed a virgin of Israel, and he should give it to the girl's father. And she shall be his wife; he shall not send her away all the days of his life. יטוְעָֽנְשׁ֨וּ אֹת֜וֹ מֵ֣אָה כֶ֗סֶף וְנָֽתְנוּ֙ לַֽאֲבִ֣י הַנַּֽעֲרָ֔ה כִּ֤י הוֹצִיא֙ שֵׁ֣ם רָ֔ע עַ֖ל בְּתוּלַ֣ת יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל וְלוֹ־תִֽהְיֶ֣ה לְאִשָּׁ֔ה לֹֽא־יוּכַ֥ל לְשַׁלְּחָ֖הּ כָּל־יָמָֽיו: 20 But if this matter was true: [indeed,] no evidence of the girl's virginity was found. כוְאִם־אֱמֶ֣ת הָיָ֔ה הַדָּבָ֖ר הַזֶּ֑ה לֹֽא־נִמְצְא֥וּ בְתוּלִ֖ים לַנַּֽעֲרָֽה (כתיב לנער) : But if this matter was true: [as corroborated] by witnesses, and there was warning, [proving] that she had committed adultery after her betrothal. — [Keth. 44b]

וְאִם־אֱמֶת הָיָה הַדָּבָר: בְּעֵדִים וְהַתְרָאָה, שֶׁזִּנְּתָה לְאַחַר אֵרוּסִין (כתובות מ"ד): 21 they shall take the girl out to the entrance of her father's house, and the men of her city shall pelt her with stones, and she shall die, for she did a disgraceful thing in Israel, to commit adultery [in] her father's house. So shall you clear away the evil from among you. כאוְהוֹצִ֨יאוּ אֶת־הַנַּֽעֲרָ֜ה (כתיב הנער) אֶל־פֶּ֣תַח בֵּֽית־אָבִ֗יהָ וּסְקָל֩וּהָ֩ אַנְשֵׁ֨י עִירָ֤הּ בָּֽאֲבָנִים֙ וָמֵ֔תָה כִּי־עָֽשְׂתָ֤ה נְבָלָה֙ בְּיִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל לִזְנ֖וֹת בֵּ֣ית אָבִ֑יהָ וּבִֽעַרְתָּ֥ הָרָ֖ע מִקִּרְבֶּֽךָ:

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Rashi to perek 22:

ואם אמת היה הדבר. בְּעֵדִים וְהַתְרָאָה, שֶׁזִּנְּתָה לְאַחַר אֵרוּסִין (כתובות מ"ד): ואם אמת היה הדבר

BUT IF THE THING BE TRUE — proven by evidence of witnesses and after legal warning that she had committed adultery after her betrothal (Ketubot 44b).

title: Perek Kira: Hardest Sugya in Shas
content:
# Perek Kira: Hardest Sugya in Shas ## Frage

Why did the Chazon Ish say that Perek Kira is the hardest sugya in Shas?

Is it because it deals with coal ovens, which were ubiquitous for Chazal but almost entirely out of use today?

Is it because the means for making certain procedures mutar no longer directly apply, because we aren’t cooking with coals?

Is it because it’s based on gezeiros from psychology, such as our apparently unconscious desire to “stoke the coals” or the equivalent on shabbos?

Some other reason?

Edit: thanks to N.T.—I agree that it is because this sugya is highly complex. But why is it so complex compared to others?

Edit beis: thanks to Noach miFrankfurt, here are mekoros:

  1. Shabbat 36b
  2. OC 253
  3. Mishnah Shabbat 3:1
## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 11)

When it comes to sugyas there are different types of hard such as difficult/subtle concepts, terse/difficult wording, סתירות to resolve, etc.

I have no knowledge of the exact words of the Chazon Ish and what reason he might have offered. If I had to venture a guess, I would say that the difficulty in פרק כירה is the following.

Here the "hard" emerges from the sheer number of halachic variables to contend with when heating food or preserving the food's heat on Shabbos. The following is not a completely exhaustive list but it includes:

  • Type of heat source: eg. כירה, תנור, כופח, מוליאר, אנטיכי
  • State of heat source: whether גרופה וקטומה or not
  • Type of fuel used for the fire: eg. קש\גבבא, גפת\עצים
  • Activity: eg. שהייה, החזרה, הטמנה
  • Mindset during activity: eg. whether דעתו להחזיר or not
  • Type of food: eg. תבשיל, חמין
  • State of food: eg. raw, כמאכל בן דרוסאי, מבושל כל צורכו
  • Reaction of food to overcooking: מצטמק ויפה\רע לו
  • Position of food in relation to oven: eg. inside, top, near
  • Reason איסור דרבנן generated: שמא יחתה, מחזי כמבשל

This leads to a high number of potential cases and outcomes to remember and master. And this is even before we delve into a myriad of halachic opinions about these cases emerging from differences among the Tannaim and how the Amoraim view each opinion of Tannaim and how the Rishonim view all of the above. Then for extra credit, what are the סברות for each of these opinions re: rabbinic prohibitions which are often less defined and more difficult to categorize when compared with Biblical prohibitions.

This often leads to people writing down large tables and charts just to keep track eg. this which I saw (p. 6 of the PDF) at daf-yomi.com.

A New Israeli Commentary on Pirkei Avot 5:18:7 משה, כזכור, פותח את מסכת אבות והוא שב ונזכר פעמיים בפרק החותם אותה , וכך מקנה הופעתו מסגרת למסכת כולה, ורק דברי שבח נאמרים בה אודותיו. והנה, לפי האמור כאן זיכה משה את הרבים ועל כן גם לא חטא ....על פי אחד מן החיבורים המאוחרים שבספרות זו, "מדרש פטירת משה רבנו עליו השלום", מוחה משה בפני האלוהים על שנגזר עליו למות, ובמיוחד עוד קודם לכניסתו לארץ ישראל; לדבריו אין בידו שום עוון שבגינו הוא חייב למות...אך לא פחות מהם, לפי חיבור זה, נגזר על משה למות בשל הריגת המצרי : "אמר לו הקב"ה: כלום אמרתי לך שתהרוג את המצרי? אמר לו [משה]: ואתה הרגת כל בכורי מצרים, ואני אמות בשביל מצרי אחד?...אמר לו הקב"ה: ואתה דומה אלי, ממית ומחיה? כלום אתה יכול להחיות כמוני?!". מסתבר שלדעת חיבור זה לא צריך היה משה להרוג את המצרי, ויכול היה למנוע אותו מהכאת העברי בדרכים אחרות. title: Maase Miriam on the way of leaving Egypt?
content:
# Maase Miriam on the way of leaving Egypt? ## Frage

The Torah in this week's Parsha tells us on Deut.24:9 to remember what Hashem did to Miriam on the way of getting out of Egypt.

I looked at the most commentaries from the Rishonim and could not find an answer to the following question: why does the Torah stresses out "on the way of getting out of Egypt"? Seemingly this verse is referring to what happened to Miriam, end of Parshat Behaalotcha, nearly one year after camping at the foot of Mount Sinai. Is that still considered Egypt?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The answer is given in Midrash Sifrei Devarim 275:2-3:

בדרך, בשעת טירופכם

on the way: when you were tossed about.

בצאתכם ממצרים, בשעת גאולתכם אלא שתלה הכתוב במרים ללמדך שכל זמן שהיו הדגלים נוסעים לא היו הולכים עד שמרים מקדמת לפניהם וכן הוא אומר (מיכה ו ד) ואשלח לפניך את משה אהרן ומרים סליק פיסקא

when you left Egypt: the time of your redemption, and all was stopped because of her, whereby we are apprised that all of that time when the standards of the tribes traveled, they did so only when Miriam preceded them, viz. (Michah 6:4) "In fact, I brought you up from the land of Egypt, I redeemed you from the house of bondage, And I sent before you Moses, Aaron, and Miriam."

In other words, the time of geula, based on the verse in Micha, is called "getting out of Mitzraim" (physically and spiritually), and it was marked by Moshe, Aharon, and Miriam leading Jewish people. However, because of Miriam's punishment, the whole travel was halted and everyone had to wait for her.

title: Word switching from plural to singular when it is many?
content:
# Word switching from plural to singular when it is many? ## Frage

In Shir HaShirim (5:11), Rashi writes: "רְבָבוֹת הַרְבֵּה קְרוּיִין רְבָבָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר "רְבָבָה כְּצֶמַח הַשָׂדֶה נְתַתִּיךְ": Many myriads are called ‘רְבָבָה’, as it is stated, “Myriads רְבָבָה like the vegetation of the field have I made you.”

So the plural word רְבָבוֹת becomes singular (רְבָבָה) when there are many of it. Are there any other examples in Lashon HaKodesh of a word switching from plural to singular when there are many of it?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

It seems that the plural is dropped when the number of objects is large enough that the individuals are indistinguishable within the mass, in which case they are simply referred to as a single mass of x species. In the same way that Rashi (Bereishis 1:11) explains דשא as “vegetation” as a concept as opposed to individual “plants”, a hoard of men will be described as “man” (e.g. Shoftim 7:23 ויצעק איש ישראל - “the Israelite man rallied”.) In this case, “man” is merely identifying the species of which the mass is comprised.

Some more examples: ומלאו את הארץ חלל - “they filled the earth with ‘corpse’” (Yechezkel 30:11)

ולא ימיש מעשות פֶרי - “it does not cease to give fruit” (Yirmiyah 17:8)

וסוס ורכב רב מאד - “and horse and chariot, a great many” (Yehoshua 11:4)

The more difficult it is to distinguish the individual, the more natural this becomes. We would not expect the word חול - “sand” to have a plural form, because we are referring to the abstract mass, not just to a large group of sand grains.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

This happens pretty frequently with nouns in Hebrew, when either a large unspecified number is meant, or a number larger than ten.

See eg Bereishit 32:6 or Shemot 26:19.

title: Should one pay more than one fifth (20%) for goods or services from a fellow Jew?
content:
# Should one pay more than one fifth (20%) for goods or services from a fellow Jew? ## Frage

On a recent shiur, a Rov mentioned that one is supposed to spend up to a fifth (20%) more on goods or services provided by a fellow Jew. So for example, if you're in a Jewish bookstore and they're selling a book that's a couple dollars cheaper on Amazon, it would be preferable to purchase it from the Jewish bookstore, even for more than it's listed on Amazon, as long as it's not over 20% more expensive.

Is there a source for this minhag? Is it a halacha?

This was specifically referring to a non-mitzva related item. Just general business transactions.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Rav Moshe Zvi Neria wrote that one must buy produce from Jews, even if it costs up to a third more. His teacher Rav Kook concurred but rejected the one-third limit, saying there is no limit. [Likutei HaRe’iyah, Kfar Haroeh, 1991, pp. 279-280.] The Rema said one must support Jewish businesses even if their price is higher.[Teshuvot HaRema 10] However, the Chafetz Chayyim ruled that there is no obligation, but it is preferable to deal with Jewish businesses, even if the cost is slightly higher. [Ahavat Chesed 5:6-7] I think the halacha of the matter is not completely settled.

title: Optional personal requests in prayers according to Rambam
content:
# Optional personal requests in prayers according to Rambam ## Frage

Following "Praying-for-too-many-people".

In my understanding, Rambam had a peculiar and somewhat unorthodox view of God's immutability and inability to be influenced by our Earthly prayers. This aligns with the Gemmora that states, that the only choice humans have is to be pious or wicked, nothing from physical reality.

Therefore, he saw the prayers as meditations, aimed at bettering ourselves, our knowledge of God, our beliefs in final salvation, seeking guidance and wisdom, cultivating humility and modesty, promoting moral growth and self-reflection, maintaining a connection with God, unifying the community, and more. (I might have a wrong understanding of Rambam though).

The Gemmorah in Brochos concludes that one can add personal requests in the middle Brochos. And our personal requests, do focus mostly on physical wellbeing and prosperity.

From Rambam's view, what's the purpose of optional personal requests, and, since God can't be influenced, what intentions should a person have while reciting those requests in prayer?

title: Why do many great Tzaddikim die so young?
content:
# Why do many great Tzaddikim die so young? ## Frage

Examples:

  • Chanoch (365)
  • King Shlomo (55)
  • King Yoshiyahu (38)
  • R' Hasdai Crescas (41)
  • Rabbeinu Tam (49)
  • Ritva (54)
  • Ramak (48)
  • The Arizal Hakodesh (38)
  • Rema (42)
  • Shach (41)
  • Ohr Hachaim Hakodesh (46)
  • Ramchal (39)
  • Rebbe Nachman (38)
  • Rabbi Aryeh Kaplan (48)

Why, sometimes, do the greatest of the greats, die so young? Is there any reason given in our sources?

To make the question more focussed: I have put in bold 5 names in the list of people who were extremely important teachers of Torah, in the specific sense that they came along and revolutionised the Torah landscape in a significant way, providing rich, timeless and unique material that became important foundations.

For example, King Shlomo wrote some of the most significant works in Ketuvim, because he was the wisest man to ever live. the Ramak's Pardes and other works were extremely and uniquely significant in ironing out long standing machlokeses in Kabbalah; the Arizal's Torah produced unmatched clarification of Kabbalah, and many schools; the Ramchal wrote key works that are essential to our understanding of hashkafa across the board; Rebbe Nachman produced a whole movement - a very significant one - and nobody came after him to replace him. The Ohr Hachaim was described by the Ba'al Shem Tov as the Moshiach of his generation and has remained one of the most respected and awesome Rabbis, since his untimely passing.

In all of these cases, had these people been alive for another 20, 30 or 40 years, the impact that would have had on Torah and Judaism would have been unimaginably significant! It produces, I feel, a really understandable kasha in one's heart, moreso than the vast majority of other Rabbis, who lived long or died young.

This is why I am asking, and the kind of answer I would accept would be one that directly addresses why one of these 5 specifically, or why we have several examples of particularly significant and impactful Rabbis dying young. For example, a source that says

The Arizal had to die young, because had he lived any longer, he would have completely revealed the entire Torah and the Moshiach would have been forced to come

or

The Arizal's job was to come and reveal his wisdom to R' Vital, and then return so that R' Vital could continue the teachings in his own form to his students

(this is purely speculative; made-up examples to help illustrate the kind of answer I am looking for. I have a feeling I have seen answers to these in significant sources, hence I feel it appropriate to ask this kind of question)

(The list is curated on minimal criteria, and therefore it may be true that not all names will apply to the answer you want to give - that's fine, please give it, all sourced answers welcome. This is an emotional and serious topic, so please, no cynical answers or comments. Just don't.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

In general this isn’t true. Gedoley Torah have a MUCH longer life span than the average person. Even though people are rarely regarded as Gedoley Torah when they are younger than sixty they still outlive what is on the actuarial chart for most sixty years old. By many years. As far as why some die younger it could be it was just their mazal at birth to die young. Of more substance when the Chofetz Chaim’s son in law R’ Hirsh Levinson died young, his wife asked him how is it possible such a Tzadik could die so young. The CC answered that Midas HaDin would have caused the destruction of half the world. Instead Midas HaDin took R’ Hirsh Levinson as a misas tzadikim mechaper.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

The final appendix to Service of the Heart is a letter from Rav Moshe Wolfson ztz”l to a woman who lost a pregnancy. He refers to the kabbalistic concept of the “well of souls,” a repository min hashamayim that contains all the souls that are destined to take bodies on earth. He explains that when a neshama has fulfilled its tachlis on earth, Hashem calls the soul back up, and sometimes this happens quite quickly. Even in such tragic cases, he adds, such short lives bring us closer to Mashiach.

Moed Katan 28a:

Rabbi Ami said: Why was the Torah portion that describes the death of Miriam juxtaposed to the portion dealing with the red heifer? To tell you: Just as the red heifer atones for sin, so too, the death of the righteous atones for sin. Rabbi Elazar said: Why was the Torah portion that describes the death of Aaron juxtaposed to the portion discussing the priestly garments? This teaches that just as the priestly garments atone for sin, so too, the death of the righteous atones for sin.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 2)

The Midrash says:

Rabbi Chiya Bar Abba said: The sons of Aaron died the first day of Nisan. Why then does the Torah mention their death in conjunction with the Day of Atonement? It is to teach that just as the Day of Atonement atones, so also the death of the righteous atones [Leviticus Rabbah 20:12].

This will not satisfy everybody.

title: Does Deut. 34:10 mean that Joshua wasn’t the prophet like Moses?
content:
# Does Deut. 34:10 mean that Joshua wasn’t the prophet like Moses? ## Frage

I used to think Deuteronomy 18:18

I will raise them up a prophet from among their brethren, like you, and will put My words in his mouth

was about Jesus but I see the Jews believe it’s about Joshua which makes a lot of sense after reading Joshua 1.

However, my confusion comes in when Deuteronomy 34:10

And there arose not a prophet since in Yisra᾽el like Moshe, whom the Lord knew face to face

is read because it seems to indicate that the prophet like Moses has to speak directly to יהוה like Moses did.

Does Deut. 34:10 mean that Joshua wasn’t the prophet like Moses? If not Joshua, who is the prophet described in Deut. 18:18?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The prophet who immediately succeeded Moses as leader was Joshua, and this bestowal of leadership begins in Numbers 27:15-23. As you mentioned, we indeed see the Almighty speak prophetically to Joshua in Joshua 1:1-9, and He was with Joshua as He was with Moses (3:7).

Nonetheless, the context of Deuteronomy 18 indicates that it is not only about Joshua, but about a series of true prophets who would continue to guide the Children of Israel throughout many future generations. As such, the singular word "נביא" (prophet) is referring to a template for a class of true prophets. Likewise, 18:19-22 speaks in a parallel manner of a template of false prophets who must be rejected, and the singular "נביא" is used even though such false prophets arose in multiple later generations (see, e.g., I Kings 22 and Jeremiah 28:10-17).

As you mentioned, Moses had a sui generis type of prophecy ("face to face") that would never be achieved by anyone else (Deut. 34:10-12). Various commentators have addressed the meaning of "like you" in Deut. 18:15,18, and some of them point out explicitly that the similarity of this prophet to Moses does not extend to the advanced level of prophecy that Moses achieved.1

Targum Yerushalmi (Deut. 18:15, "דְּדָמֵי לִי בְּרוּחַ קוּדְשָׁא") explains the similarity to be that the future prophets will be infused with a prophetic spirit of holiness.

Rashi (ad loc., "כמו שאני מקרבך מאחיך יקים לך תחתי וכן מנביא לנביא") explains the point of similarity to be that future prophets will be like Moses insofar as they will emerge from the brethren within the Children of Israel. Thus, Rashi reads the verse as, "A prophet who will be from your midst, from your brethren, [and as such will be] like me."

Rashbam (ad loc.) explains that the prophet will be like Moses in exhorting the Children of Israel to follow the Torah, unlike a false prophet or dreamer who tells Israel to worship idolatry. The Rashbam adds that Deut. 34:10 should be interpreted to read, "And no other prophet arose in Israel like Moses, [insofar as] he knew the Lord face to face," while prophets would arise who would be similar to Moses in other respects.

Ibn Ezra (ad loc., "כמוני שהוא נביא השם לא מנחש") provides a similar explanation that future true prophets would be prophets of the Almighty, and not sorcerous diviners.

The Ramban (ad loc., "וכן על דעתי 'כמוני' שיהיה נאמן לנביא לה' ותאמין בו כאשר אתה מאמין בי") provides a similar explanation, that the true prophets would be similar to Moses insofar as being a faithful prophet of the Almighty, and that the Children of Israel should trust in such a prophet just as they trusted in Moses.

Rabbeinu Bechaye (ad loc.) explains that the prophet described in Deut. 18:15,18 is Joshua, but can also include the series of later prophets who would guide Israel. Rabbeinu Bechaye provides an explanation of "like me" which is similar to Rashi's explanation, and Rabbeinu Bechaye explains that the repeated language is necessary to drive home the point that future prophets for Israel would not merely emerge from distant "brethren" (namely the descendants of Esau or Ishmael), but only from the Children of Israel themselves.

Rabbeinu Bechaye also provides another explanation similar to the Rashbam, that future true prophets would never seek to permanently or completely uproot any of the commandments of the Torah, and at most they would have the authority to temporarily suspend observance of a commandment in some cases for certain exigencies (see Y'vamos 90b).

Finally, Rabbeinu Bechaye points out that the Children of Israel believed Moses not because of the miracles Moses performed, but rather because the entire congregation of Israel heard the Almighty's voice together with Moses and therefore knew that later pronouncements they would hear from Moses were from a true and reliable prophet. In a similar vein, the Children of Israel would establish future prophets not on the basis of miracles, but on the basis of verifying their prophecy and thereby establishing them as authentic prophets going forward (see Deut. 18:21-22).

1 The New Testament passage to which you alluded (Acts 3:19-23) is a christological eisegesis that injects Christian interpretation into verses in the Hebrew Bible by ignoring the context of Deut. 18.

title: Sanhedrin power do redefine Hebrew language concepts (left and right)
content:
# Sanhedrin power do redefine Hebrew language concepts (left and right) ## Frage

The Torah forbids us from straying from Sanhedrin's rulings left or right (Deut 17.11). Left and right are abstract linguistic concepts that reflect certain social conventions. Needless to say, the Torah is full of situations that point to the use of right or left (like in "But Israel stretched out his right hand and laid it on Ephraim’s head, and his left hand on Manasseh’s head..." Gen 48.14).

Two Halachic approaches emerge:

  1. Rabbis can NOT change basic concepts like left and right (Jer Horayot.1.1.7):

"יָכוֹל אִם יֹאמְרוּ לָךְ עַל יְמִין שֶׁהִיא שְׂמֹאל וְעַל שְׂמֹאל שֶׁהִיא יְמִין תִּשְׁמַע לָהֶם? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר לָלֶכֶת יָמִין וּשְׂמֹאל. שֶׁיֹּאמְרוּ לָךְ עַל יָמִין שֶׁהוּא יָמִין וְעַל שְׂמֹאל שֶׁהִיא שְׂמֹאל."
"One could think that if they say about right that it is left, and about left that it is right, he should listen to them? [Nonsense,] The verse says, “to go to the right or to the left;” [meaning only in the case] that they should tell you about the right that it is right, and about the left that it is left."

  1. Rabbis can change basic concepts like left and right (Sifrei Devarim.154.5 and supported by Rashi):

"ימין ושמאל, אפילו מראים בעיניך על ימין שהוא שמאל ועל שמאל שהוא ימין שמע להם".
"right or left": Even if they show you that left is right and right is left, listen to them.

According to the latter, commonly accepted, approach, does it mean the Sanhedrin had the power to change the meaning of basic linguistic concepts? When "they show you that left is right and right is left", do they redefine those concepts and switch their meaning, like calling a cow a dog?

In general, can we say that the Rabbinic power (aka "Not in Heaven") extends even to redefining the Hebrew Language?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

This is from a friend's Facebook feed. It is too long for a comment but only addresses some of the question:

Neil Fleischmann

R Isser Zalman Meltzer notes that opposites can be conveyed as up & down, or as black & white, etc. Why choose right & left as the way we're meant to adhere to The Rabbis? Because my right is your left and vice versa. We face the Chachamim and see it backwards because their right is our left!

Soon the phrase is repeated and the same drasha is not made - the king keeps a Torah and should not deviate from it right or left. Similarly, Rav Isser Zalman's approach applies (as explained by Rav Daniel Feldman): he shouldn’t think he has G-d’s perspective, he's still a human and his perspective is reverse!

Micha Berger

As a lefty, I like the idea of strong-side vs weak-side. Halachic works even often specify that a lefty should do something with "his right hand", which is everyone else's left. E.g., (one of 133 in Sefaria's Halakhah section) Shulchan Arukh OC 27:6 opens, "ואיטר יד ימינו אם עושה כל מלאכתו בשמאלו מניח בשמאלו שהוא ימין של כל אדם - A lefty who does all his work with his left hand puts his Tefillin on his 'left hand' which is the right hand of all people." An important reminder these days especially: Good is stronger than evil!

# Why does Sfas Emes start his commentary on Parshat Noach by saying he doesn't know it? Is the translation faulty? ## Frage

Sfas Emes begins his commentary on Parshat Noach, according to Sefaria, by saying "I do not properly remember." All the other Parshas begin with some variation of "B'H". Why does he say this here? Is it possible the translation of Sefaria is incorrect?

The Sfat Emet isn't originally a written composition, but rather a record of discourses that were delivered orally. So in the year 5631 he just didn't remember perfectly what he had said (understandably, since that was the first year he started recording his discourses in writing).

title: Why doesn’t the commandment to obliterate Amalek run afoul of children not dying for their father's sins?
content:
# Why doesn’t the commandment to obliterate Amalek run afoul of children not dying for their father's sins? ## Frage

How does the Torah's command to obliterate Amalek, due to their attack on the Israelites during the Exodus (Shemos 17:8-16, Devarim 25:17-19), align with the principle that "children shall not die for their fathers' sins" (Devarim 24:16)?

Is the distinction between the command to obliterate Amalek and the prohibition against punishing children for their fathers' sins rooted in the difference between national identity (Amalek as a collective entity) and individual accountability?

(By extension the question can be broadened to include the prohibition against an amoni or moavi marrying into Israel which is explained as due to ancestral malice)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Some said the commandment was never to kill Amalekites. Rabbi Samson Raphael Hirsch pointed out that the commandment was to destroy “the remembrance of Amalek”, not to kill Amalekites. [Hirsch on Deut. 25] Likewise, the Sfat Emet said that the commandment was to hate Amalek, not perform any action against them. [Shemot Zakhor 346] The Chafetz Chaim added that God will eliminate Amalek. Jews are only commanded to remember what Amalek did to them. Rabbi Simcha Bunim pointed out that the Torah says to “blot out the memory of Amalek” (כִּֽי־מָחֹ֤ה אֶמְחֶה֙ אֶת־זֵ֣כֶר עֲמָלֵ֔ק מִתַּ֖חַת הַשָּׁמָֽיִם׃) in the singular, not the plural. Not the Amalekites, but Amalek alone.

Finally, the Rambam said that it is forbidden to declare war on anybody without first attempting to settle things peacefully. The main condition is acceptance of the Seven Noahide laws. [Mishneh Torah, Kings and Wars 6:1] This rule includes Amalek. Rabbi Yosef Karo, author of the Shulḥan Arukh, confirms: “If they do this, they are no longer Amalekites, but Noahides.”

Others ruled that only a king or an organized community can perform the commandment, not an individual. [Rambam in Sefer Hamitzvot, Ramban on Exodus 17:16, Sefer HaYereim 435, Hagahot Maimoniyot (Hilchot Melachim 5:5)]

title: What exactly was so wrong with Amalek's actions?
content:
# What exactly was so wrong with Amalek's actions? ## Frage

Given their southern proximity to Canaan, wasn’t Amalek justified in perceiving itself as a potential target of Israelite conquest? In the context of (what they may have perceived as a defensive) war, isn’t it considered strategic to press an advantage?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

First, the Amalekites were cowards. They attacked without provocation weak refugees untrained for war who were just passing through. They attacked them from the rear, including their women and children.

Second, Amalek was first in a long line of antisemites and represents them all. He was the archetypal enemy of the Jews. The injunction to uproot him really applies to all antisemites.

Third, the Midrash tells us that Amalek weakened the nations’ fear of God:

When Israel came out of Egypt, and God split the sea before them and drowned the Egyptians within it, the fear of Israel fell upon all the nations. But when Amalek came and challenged them, although he received his due from them, he cooled the fear of them for the nations of the world. [Midrash Tanhuma, Ki Tetze 9]

Finally, the Torah says: "The Lord will be at war with Amalek throughout the ages." [Ex. 17:16] That’s because God knew Amalek's heart. It's not so much what Amalek did at that time, bad as it was. It was really a war between the forces of good and the forces of evil, which takes place in every generation, and is therefore eternally relevant.
