title: In this page of Ein Yaakov on Sotah, near the bottom of the page, appears the word "Piska" in bold lettering. What does it signify?
content:
# In this page of Ein Yaakov on Sotah, near the bottom of the page, appears the word "Piska" in bold lettering. What does it signify? ## Frage

In this page of Ein Yaakov on Sotah, near the bottom of the page appears the word "Piska" in bold lettering. I don't think it's part of the actual Gemara, so what does this signify? Thanks.

https://hebrewbooks.org/pdfpager.aspx?req=67688&st=&pgnum=55

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

“Piska” is a term literally meaning “break” and is used to signify a new section. In Talmud Yerushalmi it is often used when the gemara quotes a part of the mishnah before discussing it.

In this case, the quote is indeed from the mishnah above, but as the mishnah is not entirely aggadah, only the first part was included in Ein Yaakov. Thus, to signify that this second quote is from the mishnah as well, the quote is titled “piska”.

title: Understanding the Shoah
content:
# Understanding the Shoah ## Frage

I am Italian (Catholic) and passionate about religions at a “non-professional amateur” level.
May I ask two questions (hoping they are not stupid):

(a) Can hatred of Jews also stem from the fact that they are God's chosen people? The envy of other religions as a push against Jews?

(b) Can the Shoah (extermination of Jews) have been God's demand to get to the Promised Land (present-day Israel)? Shoah as a necessary (political, human, social, geopolitical) price to get to Israel?

I repeat I am not a theologian or refined scholar but I have the hobby of studying religions.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Thank you for your question.

As Al Berko mentioned in his response, the subject of Holocaust has been a difficult topic for many Jewish people. I am myself a grandson of survivors and the subject of the World War 2 as well as reserch related to Holocaust interests me greatly. In response to your questions, as I understand, there could be several ways to explain what happened. It was a combination of many bad odds against the Jewish people, that perhaps each one is worthy to learn from and seek alleviating that it will not happen.

(a) Hatred of the Jewish people. Rabbi Eliezer Berkovitz discussed the subject in his book "Faith after the Holocaust". He analyzes religious hatred instigated historically in Christian Europe as well more recent era ethnic hatred in secularized societies were the legal system is not G-d given which allowed such a grave crime to take place. In my opinion, his best idea is demonstration that a perpetrator of crime has stronger hatred towards the victim than the victim has towards the perpetrator of crime because the victim always stays a loud witness in the human court and the Heavenly court. One can view chosenness of Jews due to our survival as a sequence of generations recording history, as a perpetual witness. Thus, R. Berkovits' suggests that Holocaust was such an attempt to erase the witness of the past without thinking that one will nevertheless stand for trial in the Heavenly Court of Justice.

(b) The internal Jewish answer as to why we got Holocaust. It has been also discussed in many ways, including the already mentioned book by R. Berkovits. Another book "Shoah" by Rabbi Yoel Schwartz and Rabbi Yitzchak Goldstein has a large section "Why the Holocaust?" - Searching for a Meaning presents several additional possible angles:

  • Birth Pangs of Redemption (big disasters preceed great religious events)
  • Search for Sins (lack of proper religious observance in years preceeding the war)
  • Assimilation and decline
  • Secular Zionism

These are not reasons but angles under which the causes of Holocaust could be discussed. We do not understand the Divine Justice. Especially Justice of such magnitude. We can only develop practical lessons for the life that we are given ahead of us. There are a number of other books and articles on the subject.

At the same time, it is important to note that Hitler's regime in Germany had a strong affinity to that of the Stalin's regime in the USSR. They celebrated the same holidays (like May 1st), had red color flags, and were leaders of "workers movements". The marxist ideology, by declaring ends justify means, has destroyed lives of hundreds of millions of people. Stalin also planned massive repressions against Jewish people in 1953, but his death on the Jewish holiday Purim put an end to his evil plans.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The only cause of antisemitism is stated at the very beginning of the Torah, in the story of the patriarch Isaac, the first person born Jewish:

Then Isaac sowed in that land, and reaped in the same year a hundredfold; and the Lord blessed him. And the man became rich, and gained more and more, until he became very wealthy. He had possessions of flocks, and possessions of herds, and large numbers of servants. And the Philistines envied him. And the Philistines stopped up all the wells which his father's servants had dug, in the days of Abraham his father, and filled them with earth. And Abimelech [king of the Philistines] said to Isaac, “Go away from us, because you are much mightier than we are.” And Isaac departed from there, and encamped in the valley of Gerar, and dwelt there. [Genesis 26:12-17]

So, to summarize, Isaac lives peacefully among his neighbors, then, through hard and honest work, becomes fabulously wealthy and powerful. So his neighbors hate him, harm him by depriving him of water, and finally expel him.

The only reason for antisemitism is jealousy. The envy of those who are perceived as more successful, more prosperous, more intelligent, God's chosen. Antisemites never acknowledge this reason because it makes them look bad, and Jews don't publicize it for fear of exacerbating antisemitism. That’s why you don’t hear much about it.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

I arrived to this question trying to write mine.

I would agree with your first question that since the Jewish people was chosen, it is a magnet for different quests and questions that sometimes end up in hatred.

I, however, have a big problem with the second question, because I have heard already a few times, that Jews are kind of the scapegoat of the world. We, Jews, through our death, we atone for the sins of the non-Jewisch world. This is kind of too the vision which christians have of Jesus, who died for their sins. We have a similar principle that says that the death of the righteous atones for the people, but I think its obvious meaning relates only to the repentances inspired when the righteous die. People tend to feel lonely, try their best etc. People repent. However, here you are saying that the Jews had to atone in some horrible way in order to be able to inherit the land of Israel in the eyes of non-Jews who allowed it. This is also not true because many Jews were already in Palestine before the Shoah and maybe if it weren't for it, many others would have also moved and helped the Zionist initiative.

Nevertheless, I want to say that the Shoah is so massive and incomprehensible that it screams "such a thing can only happen to the Chosen people". Its dimensions are of biblical proportion. This is also what happens in the Torah everytime G-d reveals himself through a miracle. Most of the miracles bring destruction whether in Egypt or in Sodom and Gomorrah, they are destructive. I do not know however if'd go so far away to say that the Shoah was kind of a negative miracle too. Yet, I would not call it an atonement / "price" for the Jewish people nor for the non-Jewish world necessary to enter the Land of Israel.

title: Did the Jews do anything to merit the end of the Persian exile?
content:
# Did the Jews do anything to merit the end of the Persian exile? ## Frage

Whereas during the slavery in Egyptian the Torah indicates that the Jews cried out and their cries reached Hashem, I am not aware of any similar verse which indicates the Jews did any action which led to the end of their exile under Darius. I realize that the exile had to come to an end at some point because it was prophesized to last for 70 years, however I would like to know if the sages propose any action on the part of the people which triggered the end of their exile at that time.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

R. Michoel Miller, a scholar of Maharal, wrote a small book "Darkness and Destiny: The Four Empires in Midrash and Beyond" which collects all midrashic and outside sources on the four kingdoms. Unfortunately, it does not have a commentary, but it did pointed out for me the Midrash Bereshis Rabba 99:2 which gives cryptic reasons for the fall of each of the four empires.

Here's the part relevant to the question asked:

Benjamin opposite the kingdom of Media – this one was likened to a wolf, and that one was likened to a wolf. This one was likened to a wolf: “Benjamin is a wolf that mauls” (Genesis 49:27); and that one was likened to a wolf: “Behold another, a second beast, resembling a bear [ledov]” (Daniel 7:5) – Rabbi Ḥanina said: Ledov is written, but it was called dev. (Commentary: *The word dov, bear, is sometimes written with a vav. In this instance it is written without a vav, such that it can be read dev, which is Aramaic for ze’ev, wolf. Thus, the midrash is saying that Media is compared to a wolf.) This is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, as Rabbi Yoḥanan said: ... “a wolf of the deserts will plunder them” (Jeremiah 5:6) – this is Media. Into the hands of whom did the kingdom of Media fall? Into the hands of Mordekhai, who descended from Benjamin.

The midrash is amaizingly cryptic, so what does it mean? First of all, according to wikipedia, wolves live in packs which are led by strong leaders. Therefore, the midrash notes that in Persia there was a problem of the community leadership and internal community strife.

We know, that Persian empire offered people unbelievable freedom, so that any girl could become a queen. Yalkut Meam Loez 1:5 in the name of Yearos D'vash points that the seven day banquet in Shushan began during the 10 days of repentance on the 3rd of Tishrei and ended on Yom Kippur (with kosher food). That was why Mordekhai protested that people should not come to the banquet, but they did not listen.

Rabbeinu Bachya ibn Pekudah in his commentary on Shemos 38:25 points another problem among the Jews: they no longer viewed each other as equal members one community. Why did Haman offer 10,000 kikar of silver to Achashveirosh to eliminate all the jews, which weighted against the 100 kikar of shekalim brought by 600,000 Jews? Haman used the bigest valuation of Arachin, 50 shekels (Vayikra 27:3) per male. Compared to half-shekel, 50 shekalim gives a factor of 100 and 10,000 = 100*100. In other words, Haman's accusation against the Jews was that even when raising money we did it according to the laws of Arachin (individually) and not according to the laws of Shekalim (same value for everyone).

Certainly, the point of Rabbeinu Bachya also goes against the rule that in a pack of wolves everyone but the leader is equal. Today we fix these problems with the mitzvah of shekalim before Purim and sending the same mishloach manos, and of course with recognising the true value of Torah leaders like Mordekhai. Additional important point is made in gemara Shabbos 88a:

Rava said: Even so, they again accepted it willingly in the time of Ahasuerus, as it is written: “The Jews ordained, and took upon them, and upon their seed, and upon all such as joined themselves unto them” (Esther 9:27), and he taught: The Jews ordained what they had already taken upon themselves through coercion at Sinai.

Finally, the above midrash Bereshis Rabba 99:2 fits well with historical calculations in the book by R. Alexander Hool "The Challenge of Jewish History", which shows that Achashverosh was Cambyses and the son of Esther Darius the 1st had lost the war to Alexander the Great (contrary to the academic historical dogma from Herodotus that it was Darius the 3rd). See also, Carl Olof Jonsson "The Gentile Times Reconsidered".

title: How can Sanhedrin abolish "whole body of Halachah" from the Torah?
content:
# How can Sanhedrin abolish "whole body of Halachah" from the Torah? ## Frage

The Mishna in Horayos (1.3) describes a possibility of the Sanhedrin annulling a "whole body of Halachah" from the Torah, such idolatry or Shabbos, and concludes that "they are exempt":

הוֹרוּ בֵית דִּין לַעֲקֹר אֶת כָּל הַגּוּף, אָמְרוּ, אֵין נִדָּה בַתּוֹרָה, אֵין שַׁבָּת בַּתּוֹרָה, אֵין עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה בַתּוֹרָה, הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ פְטוּרִין.‏

There are many interpretations of what "exempt" means, but everybody accepts such a possibility.

Given the procedure for appointing rabbis to the Kosher Sanhedrin (and not a coup), in what universe can a Sanhedrin rule fundamental Halachic pillars, such as idolatry or Shabbos, void?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Ramban (Bamidbar 15:22) says that this would apply in the case that the leaders of the Jewish people decided that the Torah has been abolished, as indeed happened in the past, such as when the elders of Israel came to Ezekiel with the suggestion that their contract with God was broken and that they should start worshiping idols. Or it could apply in the case that the Torah is forgotten, as happened in the wicked kings of Israel and in the time of Ezra, when the people needed to be reminded of the most basic commandments.

והנה זה כפי משמעו הוא קרבן המשומד לכל התורה בשוגג, כגון ההולך ונדבק לאחת מן האומות לעשות כהם ולא ירצה להיות בכלל ישראל כלל. ויהיה כל זה בשוגג, כגון שיהיה ביחיד בתינוק שנשבה לבין הגוים ובקהל, כגון שיחשבו שכבר עבר זמן התורה ולא היתה לדורות עולם. או שיאמרו, כמוזכר בסיפרי (ספרי במדבר ט״ו:מ״א): מפני מה אמר המקום, לא שנעשה ונטול שכר? לא עושין ולא נוטלין. כענין שהיו ישראל אומרים ושואלין את יחזקאל שנאמר: ויבואו אלי אנשים מזקני ישראל וישבו לפני (יחזקאל י״ד:א׳). אמרו לו רבינו יחזקאל הרי עבד שמכרו רבו לא יצא מרשותו וכו׳. או שישכחו את התורה, וכבר אירע לנו כן בעונותינו כי בימי מלכי ישראל הרשעים כגון ירבעם שכחו רוב העם התורה והמצות לגמרי, וכאשר בא בספר עזרא באנשי בית שני.‏

The truth is that your question is about the slightly different case of ruling that one of the commandments (rather than the entire Torah) isn't in force; however, both answers might still apply: the Sanhedrin could reach the conclusion that one part of the Torah is abolished through a process of reasoning, or one part of the Torah could be forgotten.

title: What place does the Abarbanel call טראסיי"א?
content:
# What place does the Abarbanel call טראסיי"א? ## Frage

On the verse (Beresheet 10:2):

"The descendants of Japheth: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras."

Abarbanel writes:

"והבן הז' הוא תירס ממנו יצאו אנשי טראסיי"א אנשים אכזריים והיא בארץ שיטיי"א ומהם היו מלכיות רוסיי"א ואינגלא"טירא."
"And the seventh son is Tiras, out of which came the people of טראסיי"א, cruel men, and it is located in the Land of Scythia, and from them came the kingdoms of Russia and England."

I'm familiar with most of the terms, and so can identify most of the places mentioned by Abarbanel in his commentary on Tiras (hence my translation of those terms). But what place does he mean by "טראסיי"א"? And what people is he referring to?1, 2

Edit: I will note that Rabbi Avraham Zacuto wrote in Sefer Yochasin on Tiras:

"תירס הם חזקים מלכות תרסייא ונראה שהם האונגרים."
"Tiras are strong, the Kingdom of תרסייא, and it seems that they are the Hungarians."

From his phrasing it sounds like he found the name תרסייא somewhere and isn't sure of its exact meaning, but suggested that it refers to the Hungarians.

1 Abarbanel mentions a few times in throughout the commentary on the verse Yosef ben Gurion, i.e., Yosifon/Yosippon, but not in his gloss on Tiras. I checked, and Yosifon identifies Tiras directly with Russia.

2 To clarify, I'm not asking about the historically correct identification of Tanachic Tiras, but with whom or with what did Abarbanel himself (and perhaps also R"A Zacuto) identify him/them/it.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Apparently "Tyrsenians" is an alternative term for "Tyrrhenian" which is believed to come from the region of Etruria an ancient country in the Italian Peninsula.

In Attic Greek, the Etruscans were known as Tyrrhenians (Τυρρηνοί, Tyrrhēnoi, earlier Τυρσηνοί Tyrsēnoi),[31] from which the Romans derived the names Tyrrhēnī, Tyrrhēnia (Etruria),[32] and Mare Tyrrhēnum (Tyrrhenian Sea).

This seems to compliments the BDB definition:

† תִּירָ֑ס n.pr.terr. et gent. ‘son’ of Japhet Gn 10:2; 1 Ch 1:5; Θειρας; identified by MeyGesch. d. Alt. i. 260 Di Holz Gunk al. with Gk. Τυρσηνοί, Egypt. Turuša, on coast of Ægean.

Both the Aegean Sea and Tyrrehenian Sea are part of the Mediterranean sea in a similar region.

This also seems to tally with the Radzhiner Rebbe in his famous treatise on techeiles - Psil Techeiles in the hakdama there when talking about the dye writes:

ומלאכת הצביעה היה ידוע אז במדינת טוראס, ומעת נהרסה המדינה הזאת וכל סביבותיה בחופי ים התיכון על ידי הישמעאלים נשכח מלאכת הצביעה,

And the craft of dyeing was known then in the country of Turas, and when this country and all its surroundings on the shores of the Mediterranean Sea were destroyed by the Ishmaelites, the craft of dyeing was forgotten

Alternatively, note in the Antiquities of the Jews where he writes:

תירס בן יפת קרא את העמים אשר משל בם בשם תירסים (טהירער) על שמו, והיונים הסבו את שם תירסים לשם טְראַסים (טהראציער).

Thiras also called those whom he ruled over Thirasians; but the Greeks changed the name into Thracians.

According to Wikipedia:

According to the English theologian John Gill (1697-1771) the biblical Tiras, son of Japhet, was described as the founder of Thrace identical to Thrax,[23] stating that:

...for the descendants of Thiras, as Josephus observes, the Greeks call Thracians; and in Thrace was a river called Athyras, which has in it a trace of this man's name; and Odrysus, whom the Thracians worshipped, is the same with Tiras, which god sometimes goes by the name of Thrax; and is one of the names of Mars, the god of the Thracians."

However, note that it goes on to say like the first suggestion we made...

Various biblical commentators have identified the descendants of Tiras with the Tyrsenoi, "who raided throughout the Aegean sea"; and to the Tursha. Scholars have associated this geographical locale with the Tershi (Tyrrhenians), one of the groups which made up the Sea Peoples, a naval confederacy which terrorized Egypt and other Mediterranean nations around 1200 BCE.[25][26] These Sea People are referred to as "Tursha" in an inscription of Ramesses III, and as "Teresh of the Sea" on the Merneptah Stele.[27][28] Some biblical commentators also propose a possible connection with the city of Troy, known in the Hittite language as Taruisa.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Probably Thrace (Spanish/Portuguese: Tracia/Trácia). According to Wikipedia, Scythia was sometimes considered part of it.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

Abarbanel is talking about Crimean peninsula, in Greek Ταυρική also Tauris. Its inhabitants the Greeks called Tauri or Scythotauri, Tauri Scythae, Tauroscythae (Pliny, H. N. 4.85). They were known in Greek texts for exceptional cruelty as Tauri engaged in piracy in the Black sea and were a big threat to the Greak power in the region. The geography of the peninsula is such that up until the end of 1940s most of the population could live on the southern coast of the peninsula separated by the mountains, hence the separation with Scythians in the north. Much of the northern part of the peninsula used to be a salty desert. Only after diverting water from the Dnieper river in Ukraine they were able to build successful agriculture all over the peninsula.

The problem is that we do not know how the Tauri called themselves. Only recently historians found that Scythians called themselves something like Σκόλοτοι < *skula-ta < *skuδa-ta < *skuda-ta, which is suspected to be connected to the later name of the Slavs via similarity with other designations of Slavs, as Sklaboi (Σκλάβοι), Sklabēnoi (Σκλαβηνοί), Sklauenoi (Σκλαυηνοί), Sthlabenoi (Σθλαβηνοί), or Sklabinoi (Σκλαβῖνοι).

Also Megilla 13b:

Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Bigthan and Teresh were two Tarsians (טַרְסִיִּים), and they would talk with one another in the Tarsian language.

Interestingly, the forms of names Bigdan - Bigdan/Bogdan and Teresh - Taras are very common names in Ukraine even today. What is also interesting, is that the Persian king Darius I ventured into Scythia, i.e. it is possible that these two guys were the Tauri and not Thracians (תירס).

title: Will there be Sanhedrin in Messianic Times?
content:
# Will there be Sanhedrin in Messianic Times? ## Frage

Following my back-and-forth with @RabbiKaii I suddenly realized that the reinstitution of a functioning Sanherdin is not mentioned in Rambam's vision of the Messianic times (Hil. Melachim 11.1 and on).

"הַמֶּלֶךְ הַמָּשִׁיחַ עָתִיד לַעֲמֹד וּלְהַחְזִיר מַלכוּת דָּוִד לְיָשְׁנָהּ לַמֶּמְשָׁלָה הָרִאשׁוֹנָה. וּבוֹנֶה הַמִּקְדָּשׁ וּמְקַבֵּץ נִדְחֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל. וְחוֹזְרִין כָּל הַמִּשְׁפָּטִים בְּיָמָיו כְּשֶׁהָיוּ מִקֹּדֶם. מַקְרִיבִין קָרְבָּנוֹת."

I assume many would argue that it is included in "וְחוֹזְרִין כָּל הַמִּשְׁפָּטִים", but one might object that the Sanhedrin would be obsolete, as there would be no Bad Inclination, no sin, and the Messiah as a prophet will singlehandedly establish the new "Jewish world order".

No human rabbi could possibly object to him after he successfully fulfills all prophecies and builds a functioning Temple, so the Sanhedrin would be completely unnecessary.

So which one is that: "business as usual", or "no Sanhedrin necessary" 1) according to Rambam elsewhere and 2) according to additional views?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Rambam actually writes it pretty explicitly in his commentary to Sanhedrin 1:3 that it is a prerequisite for Messianic times. (Thus he doesn't list it as a requirement for the Messiah per se to perform.) He doesn't spell this out in his code (the Yad), but the Yad does say in Sanhedrin that he reasons there must be a way to reboot real Semicha; as his reasoning for it appears in the commentary to the Mishnah, it's pretty reasonable to assume that he didn't retract from that reasoning.

ויראה לי כי כשתהי' הסכמה מכל החכמים והתלמידים להקדים עליהם איש מן הישיבה וישימו אותו לראש ובלבד שיהא זה בא"י כמו שזכרנו הנה האיש ההוא תתקיים לו הישיבה ויהיה סמוך ויסמוך הוא אחר כן מי שירצה שאם לא תאמר כן אי אפשר שתמצא ב"ד הגדול לעולם לפי שנצטרך שיהיה כל אחד מהם סמוך על כל פנים והקב"ה יעד שישובו כמו שנאמר ואשיבה שופטיך כבראשונה ויועציך כבתחלה אחרי כן יקרא לך עיר הצדק וזה יהיה בלא ספק כשיכון הבורא יתברך לבות בני אדם ותרבה זכותם ותשוקתם לשם יתברך ולתורה ותגדל חכמתם לפני בא המשיח כמו שיתבאר זה בפסוקים הרבה במקרא.

It appears to me that if an agreement from all scholars and students is reached to promote one man as head, if done in the Land of Israel, ... that fellow shall be samuch, and can grant semicha to others. As if we do not say this, it will forever be impossible to find a Great Court, as it requires all of their individuals to be samuch; yet HKB"H testified that they shall return, as Isaiah writes -- I shall return your judges as before, and your advisors as originally, and then you shall be called the City of Righteousness; and this will undoubtedly happen when G-d will establish the hearts of people, and they will have many merits and desire for G-d and the Torah and have great wisdom, before the coming of the Messiah, as is explained in numerous verses in Scripture.

title: Was Eve created for rescue rather than assistance?
content:
# Was Eve created for rescue rather than assistance? ## Frage

Gen.2.18 says Eve was created to be "Ezer K'Negdo": "וַיֹּאמֶר י"א לֹא־טוֹב הֱיוֹת הָאָדָם לְבַדּוֹ אֶעֱשֶׂהּ־לּוֹ עֵזֶר כְּנֶגְדּוֹ׃".

I looked up the usage of עזר in the Tanakh and all I could find was some kind of "rescue" or "deliverance", not mere "assistance in daily chores". Compare:

"וְשֵׁ֥ם הָאֶחָ֖ד אֱלִיעֶ֑זֶר כִּֽי־אֱלֹהֵ֤י אָבִי֙ בְּעֶזְרִ֔י וַיַּצִּלֵ֖נִי מֵחֶ֥רֶב פַּרְעֹֽה׃"
"ק֭וּמָֽה עֶזְרָ֣תָה לָּ֑נוּ וּ֝פְדֵ֗נוּ לְמַ֣עַן חַסְדֶּֽךָ׃"
"אֱלֹהִ֣ים לָ֭נוּ מַחֲסֶ֣ה וָעֹ֑ז עֶזְרָ֥ה בְ֝צָרֹ֗ות נִמְצָ֥א מְאֹֽד׃"
"שִׁ֗יר לַֽמַּ֫עֲלֹ֥ות אֶשָּׂ֣א עֵ֭ינַי אֶל־הֶהָרִ֑ים מֵ֝אַ֗יִן יָבֹ֥א עֶזְרִֽי׃"
"אֱלֹהִ֥ים לְהַצִּילֵ֑נִי יְ֝הוָ֗ה לְעֶזְרָ֥תִי חֽוּשָֽׁה׃"
"הַאִ֬ם אֵ֣ין עֶזְרָתִ֣י בִ֑י וְ֝תֻשִׁיָּ֗ה נִדְּחָ֥ה מִמֶּֽנִּי׃"
"אֹ֣ורוּ מֵרֹ֗וז אָמַר֙ מַלְאַ֣ךְ יְהוָ֔ה אֹ֥רוּ אָרֹ֖ור יֹשְׁבֶ֑יהָ כִּ֤י לֹֽא־בָ֨אוּ֙ לְעֶזְרַ֣ת יְהוָ֔ה לְעֶזְרַ֥ת יְהוָ֖ה בַּגִּבֹּורִֽים׃"

Unkelos also translates closer to "resque" than "assistance": "אַעֲבֵד לֵהּ סְמַךְ לְקִבְלֵהּ:".

Jastrow online (עֵזֶר), however, provides only the later interpretation based on the verse in Genesis. And so do most traditional interpreters - "Eve was created as an assistance to Adam".

Based on the use of the word in the rest of Taanakh, can the original intention of God in the creation of Eve be different? Maybe to save him from the sin of bestiality (see Yevamot.63a?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It’s possible, as the Or HaChaim suggests, that she did save him from the sin of bestiality:

ויאמר ה' וגו' לא טוב וגו'. קשה הלא כבר ביום ברא אלהים אדם זכר ונקבה ברא אותם, עוד קשה אומרו סמוך לו אעשה לו עזר כנגדו וגומר ויצר וגומר כל חית השדה, שנראה שרצה לזווג לו חית השדה וזה פלא לזווג אדם ובהמה, ועוד שיסיר נקבת בהמה או חיה מבן זוגה ולזווגה עם האדם, עליונים למטה ותחתונים למעלה, עוד קשה אומרו ויפל ה' תרדמה וגו', וכי לא היה ה' יכול לברוא לו בת זוגו עפר מן האדמה. מלבד מה שהקשינו שמצינו לו שברא לו בת זוגו ביום הבראו וכמו שהעיד הכתוב אחר כן זכר ונקבה בראם וגו' ביום הבראם ורז"ל אמרו דרשות רבות וצריכין פותר אבל פשט הכתוב לא מצאנוהו: ויאמר השם אלוקים לא טוב.

The Lord G'd said: "It is not good for man to be alone, etc." This is difficult since G'd had mentioned already on the day He created man that the species had been created male and female (1,27). Another problem in the text is the expression אעשה, "I shall make for him a helpmate." The Torah then immediately proceeds to describe that the mammals and the birds were formed, i.e. ויצר השם אלוקים (2,19). This gives the impression that G'd intended one of these animals to be man's helpmate. Such a thought is not only extremely strange, but if true it would also result in one of those animals being deprived of its own mate! Besides, why did G'd have to put Adam to sleep and to remove part of his body? Could He not have formed woman as dust from the earth as He had formed man himself, especially since He formed Eve on the very same day He formed Adam (5,2) זכר ונקבה בראם? Our sages have given many homiletical explanations in answer to these questions, but they have not provided us with פשט, straightforward answers that justify the text as it stands.

Or HaChaim:

ונראה לפי מה שקדם מדברי רז"ל (עירובין יח) כי אדם וחוה דו פרצופין נבראו למאן דאמר פרצוף, ולמאן דאמר זנב, כדאיתא במס' שבת, וכפי זה זאת האשה וזה בניינה כי מתחלה בראה דבוקה עמו ממש למ"ד כסברתו ולמ"ד כסברתו. ובסדר זה ישנם גם כן בהכנת המוליד דהלא תמצא שאמר ה' להם (א' כח) פרו ורבו וגו' קודם הנסירה הא למדת שהכינם ה' להוליד גם בהיותם בסדר זה וזאת האשה אשר נסר ה' ולקחה ממקום דביקתה אשר בראה ביום הבראם.

We may have to fall back on the opinions expressed in Berachot 61 that originally man was created with two faces in one body. The Talmud there offers two opinions as to what was removed from Adam, a tail or a face, respectively. This is a reasonable explanation because it justifies G'd's blessing or command to Adam to be fruitful and to multiply (1,28) at a time when woman had not yet been reported as a separate entity.

Brachot 61a:

אִי נָמֵי כִּדְרַבִּי יִרְמְיָה בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר: דּוּ פַּרְצוּפִין בָּרָא הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא בָּאָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אָחוֹר וָקֶדֶם צַרְתָּנִי״.

Alternatively, this duplication in the language of creation can be explained in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar, as Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar said: The Holy One, Blessed be He, created two faces [du partzufin] on Adam the first man; he was created both male and female in a single body, as it is stated: “You have formed me [tzartani] behind and before” (Psalms 139:5); tzartani is derived from the word tzura [face]. God formed two faces on a single creation, back and front.

We can translate כנגדו as “facing,” according to this reading.

Holding a person accountable is a necessary part of any relationship. If we accept the interpretation of Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar, the hermaphroditic two-faced Adam would not be able to do so insofar as it requires “facing” a person.

Animals have many parallels to human faces, but they don’t have the level of intelligence that we have, and looking an animal in the eye yields a different experience. Animals can’t hold us to account for our actions.

Rabbi Shraga Silverstein translates it as follows, based on Rashi:

“[I shall make him a help [(If he merits it, she is a help)], against him [(If he does not merit it, she is against him, contending with him)].”

She helps him not “just by assistance in daily chores” but by withholding her help from him if he does not merit it. This means that G-d gives her the power to discern his merit.

title: Does Raba Hold That Mishnayot do not Need to Present Information in an Ascending Order of Novelty?
content:
# Does Raba Hold That Mishnayot do not Need to Present Information in an Ascending Order of Novelty? ## Frage

Tosfot's Premise: Mishnayot present cases in order of novelty - לא זו אף זו (See Tosfot Meilah 2a, ששחטן בדרום, " דסדר משנתינו כך הוא ששונה אותו שיש בו חידוש יותר "בסיפא )

My Premise: Rabbinic Meilah is a greater novelty than Biblical Meilah. This is due to the fact that on a biblical level this particular sacrifice is useless due to an egregious defect, but nonetheless the rabbis instituted Meilah.

Raba (Meilah 2b) seems to disagree with one of the premises.

The Mishna in Meila 2a lists several sets of cases of defective animals which still retain the possibility of Meilah. Prima facie, they all retain biblical Meilah potentiality. The Talmud 2a expressly explains that the set of cases involving a holy of holies animal wrongfully slaughtered/blood received in the south of the courtyard goes first in the Mishna because it is the least novel (the defect, relatively speaking, is not that bad, and so it retains biblical Meilah). The set of cases involving wrongfully slaughtering/sprinkling blood of an animal at night, however, goes next because it represents an even greater defect (thus a greater novelty - that these latter cases, notwithstanding their more egregious defect, still retain biblical Meilah).

The Talmud then introduces a game changer on 2b:

תְּנַן: קׇדְשֵׁי קָדָשִׁים שֶׁשְּׁחָטָן בַּדָּרוֹם – מוֹעֲלִין בָּהֶן. בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַב יוֹסֵף נִיחָא, אֶלָּא לְרַבָּה קַשְׁיָא! מַאי מוֹעֲלִין בָּהֶן – מִדְּרַבָּנַן. We learned in the mishna: With regard to offerings of the most sacred order that were disqualified before their blood was sprinkled on the altar, if one slaughtered them in the south of the Temple courtyard, he is liable for misusing them if he derives benefit from them. Granted, according to the opinion of Rav Yosef, this halakha works out well. But according to the opinion of Rabba, it is difficult: The Gemara explains: What is the meaning of the clause: One is liable for misusing them? This means that one is liable for misusing them by rabbinic law, but they are not subject to the halakhot of misuse by Torah law.

To recap - the first set of cases in the Mishna per Raba (in R. Shimon) - the set of slaughtering/receiving blood in the south - is rabbinical Meilah only. The rest of the cases in the opening Mishna (night etc.), however, are biblical. BUT this means, per Raba, that a set of cases involving rabbinic Meilah precedes cases in the Mishna that involve Biblical Meilah?!! Are we still ascending in order of novelty? Does Raba even care?

title: Why did God form adam only male if He already created them both male and female?
content:
# Why did God form adam only male if He already created them both male and female? ## Frage

In Gen 1.27 we read:

"וַיִּבְרָא אֱלֹהִים אֶת־הָאָדָם בְּצַלְמוֹ בְּצֶלֶם אֱלֹהִים בָּרָא אֹתוֹ זָכָר וּנְקֵבָה בָּרָא אֹתָם׃"
Lit: "And God created the adam in His image, in the image of Elohim [He] created him, male and female created them."

Note that the use of the definite article ה points to the fact that "adam" is a noun, not a name, so I keep using it that way. We also distinguish between the stage of creation (ברא) and formation (יצר).

We would assume, that the later formation of the adam should also be male and female. Indeed, nothing in the latter verse (Gen 2.7) indicates that the adam was formed male, as male gender is used in Hebrew also as neutral (like "a child"). We only realize that later in the narrative:

"וַיִּיצֶר י"א אֶת־הָאָדָם עָפָר מִן־הָאֲדָמָה וַיִּפַּח בְּאַפָּיו נִשְׁמַת חַיִּים וַיְהִי הָאָדָם לְנֶפֶשׁ חַיָּה׃"
Lit: "And Y"E formed the adam (noun) humus from the soil, and blew into his nostrils the breath of life: and the adam became a living soul".

"וַיֹּאמֶר יְהוָה אֱלֹהִים לֹא־טוֹב הֱיוֹת הָאָדָם לְבַדּוֹ אֶעֱשֶׂהּ־לּוֹ עֵזֶר כְּנֶגְדּוֹ׃"
"And Y"E said, “It is not good for the adam to be alone; I will make a fitting counterpart for him.”

Since God already created them male and female, why did He form the adam only [imperfectly] male?

Also, knowing that he was imperfect, why did He wonder “It is not good for the Human to be alone; I will make a fitting counterpart for him.” and tried several experiments to find a cure?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It's a part of the general trend of Genesis Ch. 1 and Genesis Ch. 2 having different focuses. First Chapter 1 gives us the bigger view -- "God made humans as part of every thing else in creation." Then Chapter 2 rewinds, zooms in, and tells us the "how."

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

I think the answer is given by Marina Goodman in "Why Should I Stand Behind the Mechitzah if I Could Be a Prayer Leader?", pp. 49-50:

Originally G-d created Adam who was both male and female. However, the female was completely subsumed in male. (YDJ: we see that that G-d refers to Adam - he in the singular). The female in the male-female had no identity, and as a result the male was alone. ... this was an important intermediary state. However, G-d stated that "It is not good, Adam being alone" (Bereshis 2:18). G-d then proceeded to separate out the female and give her her own identity and her own perspective. The male was no longer alone but in a relationship. The female was still in a relationship, but now had a distinct voice.

In other words - as a male, Adam remained, where he was. He was already fit for the job. G-d separated the part that needed development which could not have it otherwise. Sefer Zikaron on Brachos 61a says on Rashi's Bereshis 2:21 comment:

As Rashi has stated, the woman was not created through a removal of internal organ from man. (i.e. no diminishmement of man occured). She was created by separating the female form from the male form of the original dual body... There only remained a wound that needed to be healed.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

The Or HaChaim—حاييم بن موشي بن عطار, חיים בן משה בן עטר, lived in Morocco around 400 years ago.

He notes that in Bereishit 1:27, the Torah says that G-d created Man male and female. However, in 2:18, G-d says, “it is not good for him to be alone.”

How is this possible? The Or HaChaim adds that in 1:28, G-d gives Man the command to be fruitful and multiply, at a time when the Torah has not yet mentioned the existence of Woman as a separate entity. We may have to rely on the explanation of Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar in the Babylonian Talmud, Berachot 61a, he concludes.

According to Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar, G-d initially created Adam with two faces, each facing a different direction, with the capacity to reproduce independently.

In 2:21, G-d makes the two-faced Adam fall unconscious and takes “מצלעתיו”, closing over the flesh. Rabbi Shraga Silverstein translates מצלעתיו as “sides,” which is consistent with the Talmud, indicating that this primordial surgery removed the male half of Adam from the female half.

Aside from addressing the two-faced Adam’s loneliness, what was the purpose of this surgery?

In 2:18, G-d says, “I shall make a helpmate for him.” However, “for him” is the word כנגדו, which also means “against” or “facing” him. It can also mean opposite, against, before, in view, in sight of, conspicuous to, in the presence of, parallel to, from before, open to, known to, etc.

Holding a person accountable is a necessary part of any relationship. If we accept the interpretation of Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar, the two-faced Adam would not be able to do so insofar as it requires “facing” a person. The two-faced Adam didn’t have a contemporary to hold him accountable.

Rabbi Silverstein brings this translation:

“I shall make him a help [(If he merits it, she is a help)], against him [(If he does not merit it, she is against him, contending with him)].”

The Or HaChaim also shows that immediately after this verse, the Torah describes the animals, as if to suggest that they did not merit to be Adam’s partner.

Mekoros:

Or HaChaim:

ויאמר ה' וגו' לא טוב וגו'. קשה הלא כבר ביום ברא אלהים אדם זכר ונקבה ברא אותם, עוד קשה אומרו סמוך לו אעשה לו עזר כנגדו וגומר ויצר וגומר כל חית השדה, שנראה שרצה לזווג לו חית השדה וזה פלא לזווג אדם ובהמה, ועוד שיסיר נקבת בהמה או חיה מבן זוגה ולזווגה עם האדם, עליונים למטה ותחתונים למעלה, עוד קשה אומרו ויפל ה' תרדמה וגו', וכי לא היה ה' יכול לברוא לו בת זוגו עפר מן האדמה. מלבד מה שהקשינו שמצינו לו שברא לו בת זוגו ביום הבראו וכמו שהעיד הכתוב אחר כן זכר ונקבה בראם וגו' ביום הבראם ורז"ל אמרו דרשות רבות וצריכין פותר אבל פשט הכתוב לא מצאנוהו: ויאמר השם אלוקים לא טוב.

The Lord G'd said: "It is not good for man to be alone, etc." This is difficult since G'd had mentioned already on the day He created man that the species had been created male and female (1,27). Another problem in the text is the expression אעשה, "I shall make for him a helpmate." The Torah then immediately proceeds to describe that the mammals and the birds were formed, i.e. ויצר השם אלוקים (2,19). This gives the impression that G'd intended one of these animals to be man's helpmate. Such a thought is not only extremely strange, but if true it would also result in one of those animals being deprived of its own mate! Besides, why did G'd have to put Adam to sleep and to remove part of his body? Could He not have formed woman as dust from the earth as He had formed man himself, especially since He formed Eve on the very same day He formed Adam (5,2) זכר ונקבה בראם? Our sages have given many homiletical explanations in answer to these questions, but they have not provided us with פשט, straightforward answers that justify the text as it stands.

Or HaChaim:

ונראה לפי מה שקדם מדברי רז"ל (עירובין יח) כי אדם וחוה דו פרצופין נבראו למאן דאמר פרצוף, ולמאן דאמר זנב, כדאיתא במס' שבת, וכפי זה זאת האשה וזה בניינה כי מתחלה בראה דבוקה עמו ממש למ"ד כסברתו ולמ"ד כסברתו. ובסדר זה ישנם גם כן בהכנת המוליד דהלא תמצא שאמר ה' להם (א' כח) פרו ורבו וגו' קודם הנסירה הא למדת שהכינם ה' להוליד גם בהיותם בסדר זה וזאת האשה אשר נסר ה' ולקחה ממקום דביקתה אשר בראה ביום הבראם.

We may have to fall back on the opinions expressed in Berachot 61 that originally man was created with two faces in one body. The Talmud there offers two opinions as to what was removed from Adam, a tail or a face, respectively. This is a reasonable explanation because it justifies G'd's blessing or command to Adam to be fruitful and to multiply (1,28) at a time when woman had not yet been reported as a separate entity.

Brachot 61a:

אִי נָמֵי כִּדְרַבִּי יִרְמְיָה בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר: דּוּ פַּרְצוּפִין בָּרָא הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא בָּאָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אָחוֹר וָקֶדֶם צַרְתָּנִי״.

Alternatively, this duplication in the language of creation can be explained in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar, as Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar said: The Holy One, Blessed be He, created two faces [du partzufin] on Adam the first man; he was created both male and female in a single body, as it is stated: “You have formed me [tzartani] behind and before” (Psalms 139:5); tzartani is derived from the word tzura [face]. God formed two faces on a single creation, back and front.

title: How was Adam given the 7 Noahide laws without animals or women in existence?
content:
# How was Adam given the 7 Noahide laws without animals or women in existence? ## Frage

The Gemmorah in Sanhedrin 56b learns that Adam was given the 7 Noahide laws from the verse "וַיְצַוי"א עַל־הָאָדָם לֵאמֹר מִכֹּל עֵץ־הַגָּן אָכֹל תֹּאכֵל׃", that comes before the formation of animals and Eve:

"From where are the Noahide mitzvot, derived? Rabbi Yoḥanan says: It is from that which the verse states (Genesis 2:16–17): “And the Lord God commanded the man, saying: Of every tree of the garden you may freely eat; but from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, you shall not eat from it, for on the day that you eat from it, you shall die” ."

Apparently, Adam was created intelligent enough to understand the laws which include adultery and bestiality (some say also castration) which necessitate the existence of both animals and women.

However, not only was he alone, but he didn't wonder where are all those creatures he was commanded about. God also doesn't show any sign of puzzlement or confusion. He forms those only after realizing that leaving the human by himself is "not good".

How can this story be harmonized?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

In the previous chapter, animals are clearly made before man. If the order in the second chapter confuses you, you can say that those animals are additional, exemplar animals for the naming. Or you could say that bestiality also applies to fish and birds.

Regarding adultery, perhaps the unseparated Adam was a married unit and bestiality would also be adultery?

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

In Bereshit 2:19, it says "And Hashem Elokim formed (ויצר) all the beasts of the field from the earth..." Rashi on the spot comments that this "creating" (yetzirah) is the same "making" (asiyah) which is referenced earlier in 1:25, when it says "And Elokim made the beasts of the field according to their types, and the domesticated animals according to their types, and those that creep in the earth according to their type, and Elokim saw that it was good." Here in 2:19, says Rashi, the text is returning to an earlier topic and giving us more information previously unrevealed.

Note that the word used in 1:25 is עשה, not ברא.

So the prohibition against bestiality is not a question, as the animals already existed, and Adam saw them about him. (Shortly thereafter, a representative sample was brought to him to be named.)

As for the prohibition against adultery, which necessarily assumes the existence of women, it seems to me that there are at least three explanations available to us.

One, when Hashem made this statement to Adam, he did not immediately grasp its full significance; full understanding only came later, as the last elements of the universe were created.

Two, Adam was granted such wisdom that he was able to foresee the existence of women, and could therefore understand this command.

Three, this verse serves us, through the Torah She'ba'al Peh, as a source for the Noachide Commandments, but Hashem said them more clearly to Adam somewhat later, in a discussion which the Torah does not record.

title: Insertions in the amida from Rosh Hashanah to Yom kipur
content:
# Insertions in the amida from Rosh Hashanah to Yom kipur ## Frage

In the gemera brachos 34a it says one is not to make any additions to prayer in the first three and last three brachos of the amida. This is also brought down in rambam in chapter 1 of tefila and birchas kohanim that one should never change or add anything to the first and last three blessings yet we common practice is to make additions in these places and even in ch. 2 of tefila and birchas kohanim the rambam goes on to say many people are accustomed to making these additions.

Why are these allowed and how did they come to be part of the amida?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Gemoro you quote says:

One must never request his own needs in the first three or in the last three blessings; rather, he should do so in the middle blessings.

The implication is that the needs of everyone can be mentioned in the first and last three. This is explicit in Shulchan Oruch O Ch 112 (1) who says:

אל ישאל אדם צרכיו בג' ראשונות ולא בג' אחרונות ודוקא צרכי יחיד אבל צרכי צבור שרי:

“A person should not ask for his needs in the first three [blessings] nor in the last three [blessings of the Amidah prayer] but asking for the needs of the community is permissible.”

title: Why in Genesis 1 all is good and Gen 2 all is "not good"?
content:
# Why in Genesis 1 all is good and Gen 2 all is "not good"? ## Frage

In Genesis 1, God testifies consistently that everything He created ranged from good to very good.

In Genesis 2, on the other hand, everything goes haywire: Adam is created not perfect, and his loneliness is deemed "not good", causing God to create animals, that were again "not good" for him. Finally, God creates Eve and we all know how badly the story ended (Gen 3).

It appears that in Gen 1 God knows what He's doing and enjoys the fruits of His creation, while in Gen 2, He consistently changes His mind and tries to fix it.

Why such a stark contrast?

  • Can it be connected with using YHWH Elohim instead of Elohim alone as God's name?
  • Can it reflect the difference between the ideal world of בריאה (creation) and our less-than-ideal material world of יצירה (formation)?

NB: I found a related question about the differences in the narrative.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

When discussing the other elements of the physical universe aside from mankind, the Torah seems satisfied to inform us that Hashem made them, and they are as He intended them to be, which is indeed very good. It is not necessary for the Torah to teach us deeply about the nature of fishes or mountains or birds, as none of these things impact on the purpose of the Torah, which is to teach us how to be human beings. To the extent that it is useful to us to learn about these physical elements of our world, we should get up and investigate the world, observe it and learn.

But when it comes to humanity, the Torah indeed needs to teach us about the nature of humanity, which is our nature, because this impacts profoundly on the purpose of the Torah. And so here we are informed that "it is not good for man to be alone," that men are fundamentally and unbridgably apart from the animal world, about the risks of social interaction, and more.

All of these things are part of the task for which the Torah was created; namely, to teach us how to be the human beings that Hashem had in mind, both as a species and as individuals. And so here, it is not enough to say that in the big picture it is "very good." Rather, here the Torah must go into details and teach us about different ways in which we might fail, so that we can learn from the text and avoid the experience.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Actually, there is one aspect in Genesis 1 that is not good. The second day of creation is not called good by God. There is no mention of good in Genesis 1:6-8 concerning the second day. However, the third day makes up for this with two labels of good.

Seems as though Genesis 1 is a creation account from the "heavenly" perspective, (Genesis 1:1) since Genesis 2's creation account is from an "earthly" perspective. Earth is first before Heaven in the latter part of Genesis 2:4. Adam is also created first according to Genesis 2 (unlike in Genesis 1), so from man's point of view, it does seem as though things are not good and that they need to be fixed. Man has a very limited perspective.

The heavenly perspective in Genesis 1 transcends time and is probably already looking at the Messianic era of the year 6000 AM. Hence why everything is good and in order according to chapter 1.

This is just my guess though. Feel free to disagree.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

According to the documentary hypothesis, Gen. 1 and Gen. 2 are from two different authors. While most Orthodox Jews reject the this hypothesis, several Orthodox rabbis have begun to do so. Many Conservative and Reform rabbis accept it.

The hypothesis indeed focuses on the fact that "YHWH Elohim" is the name of God in Gen. 2 while simply Elohim alone as is God's name in Gen 1. Scholars who uphold this view hold that Gen. 1 was composed somewhat later than Gen. 2 and expresses the idea of God's absolute sovereignty over all creation. Gen. 2 expresses a time (possibly during the reign of King Hezekiah) when both female deities and snake gods still represented a threat. Thus the woman and the serpent are presented as opposed to God's will in Gen. 2, while in Gen. 1 - as the OP points out - "all is good."

title: Peshat meaning of "help against him" in Biblical Hebrew
content:
# Peshat meaning of "help against him" in Biblical Hebrew ## Frage

Note, this question is NOT about interpretations and commentaries, only about the plain meaning of the verse (Peshat).

The verse says,"אֶעֱשֶׂהּ־לּוֹ עֵזֶר כְּנֶגְדּוֹ". In Biblical Hebrew, עזר means help, rescue, and כנגדו though a singleton, should mean something close to נגד - against, opposing, or facing, like in "וַיִּחַן־שָׁם יִשְׂרָאֵל נֶגֶד הָהָר".

So "rescue against him" - doesn't make sense, it should rather read "עזר לו", or "עזר בשבילו".

How can this phrase be meaningful in its plain reading (Peshat) in Biblical Hebrew?

Slightly related "עזר - rescue or assistance?".

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Compare to Tehillim 16:8

שִׁוִּ֬יתִי ה' לְנֶגְדִּ֣י תָמִ֑יד כִּ֥י מִֽ֝ימִינִ֗י בַּל־אֶמּֽוֹט

I have put Hashem לנגדי always, because He is at my right hand I will not stumble.

Here, לנגדי obviously does not mean "opposing me," but something like "in front of me." David declares that because Hashem is always before him, in his thoughts, therefore He will offer help and protection and David can be confident that he will not come to harm.

It seems to me that the simple פשט reading of "כנגדו" is similar. The woman shall be a helper "before him," in his immediate presence rather than at a remote distance. This fits well with the Divine statement in the same verse that "It is not good for man to be alone." Because it is not good for him to be alone, he will be provided a helper that will live with him and be constantly with him, ending his state of "aloneness."

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

There are multiple valid ways to translate it into English, but the one that makes most sense to me is “a helper facing him,” because facing can mean opposite, against, before, in view, in sight of, conspicuous to, in the presence of, parallel to, from before, open to, known to, etc.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

Like is understand from Rashi's commentary to the Chumash, Peshat also includes proper grammar usage. (His commentary is a tremendous resource for the correct rules of Hebrew grammar.) Your translation of עזר as a verb is incorrect.

In the expression, it is used as a noun. As a noun, it means "assistant" or "complement", meaning a thing that completes and is "complementary to" the subject in the sentence, meaning the individual, the husband.

Similarly, כנגדו is being used as an adjective modifying the subject of the sentence (indicated by the suffix letter ו), which is "him", meaning the man, the husband. (Just to emphasize, it does not say כנגדה, meaning corresponding to her.)

The root, נגד, has several different meanings, which explains why the prefix letter "כ" is also applied. That prefix can have a meaning of "like" or "according to". This means that the type of assistance from the wife varies according to the character and need of the husband.

title: Rabbeinu Yonah's Shaarei HaAvodah online
content:
# Rabbeinu Yonah's Shaarei HaAvodah online ## Frage

The Rabbeinu Yonah, famously known for his work on Teshuvah, Shaarei Teshuvah, also wrote a sefer called שַׁעֲרֵי הָעֲבוֹדָה (Shaarei HaAvodah).

Does anyone know where to find this sefer online (free access)? Is it available online?

title: Does a mourner during shiva omit the "Titkabel" verse from Kaddish Shalem?
content:
# Does a mourner during shiva omit the "Titkabel" verse from Kaddish Shalem? ## Frage

My recollection from when I sat shiva for my father (z"l) is that if an avel is the shaliach tzibbur in a shiva house, he omits the verse "titkabel" from the final Kaddish Shalem. I remember seeing this instruction in the siddur for the house of mourning that was provided for our use by the local funeral home. I always assumed that this was related to the fact that "titkabel" is omitted on Tisha b'Av, and that it is not included in the Kaddish Yatom.

However, at a shiva house this evening none of the other people present were aware of this custom, and I could find no mention of it in either the Artscroll or the Koren siddur. Now I'm wondering if I am misremembering, or if I hallucinated the whole thing. (For what it's worth, at the time I sat shiva we were using a Conservative siddur, not an Orthodox one, so perhaps this is something specific to Conservative practice.)

Can anybody enlighten me on whether this is an actual practice, and (if so) whether it is limited only to certain communities or if it is more generally observed? Sources are appreciated.

Edited: Shortly after posting this question I found the following on the OU website:

Although some have the custom to omit the "titkabel" passage from the final kaddish recited at the end of services in a shiva house, it is reported that Rabbi Moshe Feinstein was very against this practice and insisted that the final kaddish be recited in its entirety as normal.

This seems to both confirm that the custom exists while simultaneously arguing against it. It does not, however, provide any sources for where this custom comes from, who follows it, and whether there are any other respected poskim who hold differently than Rabbi Feinstein, so I would still appreciate any information that can be provided.

title: Defining boundaries of Jewish Orthodoxy
content:
# Defining boundaries of Jewish Orthodoxy ## Frage

With a plethora of Jewish denominations, it becomes harder and harder to sort out religious views in general and Orthodox Judaism in particular. In my debates, I was frequently pointed out that "a particular view is "not Orthodox", and that caused me to ponder about a method, an algorithm for concluding whether a particular view can be seen as orthodox.

My difficulty in finding one is the fact that the adoption and letting go of ideas in traditional Rabbinic/Talmudic Judaism seems arbitrary and accidental, largely depending on the characters and circumstances involved, not the essence of the ideas themselves.

For example, monogamy was considered "Orthodox" in Christian Europe, while polygamy was "Orthodox" in the Islamic world. Or, if not the charismatic personalities of Chassidic leaders the early Hassidism could be completely ousted like Sabbatarianism (following HaGoen's ban). Or the contemporary ban by the Israeli Ultra-orthodoxy on Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz.

I considered Rambam's 13 principles as some kind of basic consensus, but it becomes somewhat useless if any principle can be interpreted metaphorically, rather than literally. E.g. the principle says "וְאֵין לוֹ שׁוּם דִּמְיוֹן כְּלָל" but our liturgy appeals to God allegorically as "אבינו מלכנו".

Did rabbis or researchers try to systematize the curent-day "orthodox approach" possibly providing hints on methodology?

Note: the question doesn't ask whether a particular idea of view can be considered Orthodox or not.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

I know of no higher authority on "What is Judaism?" than the consensus of rabbinic opinion over time. Of course, by "rabbinic opinion," I do not mean "anyone that calls himself or herself a rabbi, without regard to what they believe or say or do," but those men that, having immersed themselves for many years in study of Torah and avodas Hashem, and who are acknowledged by their contemporaries as being among the heirs of previous generations of rabbinic authority.

Which means that I cannot give you any algorithm, any semi-simple series of steps which a computer could walk through to determine "Does this idea fit into Judaism or not?" The only way to determine that is to become oneself a rabbinic figure of stature, or to ask such a one.

Incidentally, I don't believe that anyone ever claimed that monogamy is a necessary part of Judaism. That would be a hard thing to do, as two of the Patriarchs had multiple wives simultaneously, as well as various great figures after the Giving of the Torah, most notably Kings David and Solomon!

But monogamy, which even in Biblical times was preferred, has certainly become a very strongly-entrenched custom amongst Ashkenazi and Sephardi Jews, and I would be extraordinarily surprised if polygamy ever returned.

title: Remote melacha: remoting into a place where it is Shabbat or Yom Tov
content:
# Remote melacha: remoting into a place where it is Shabbat or Yom Tov ## Frage

VR control of robots in other locations is a thing. In fact, there is a concept of actually working this way. This article* describes a robot that can be manually controlled to stack shelves, and people can remote into it to do the work from home. They see through its cameras in VR, and they control its arms, and move it around, with hand-held controllers.

See: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UxWH5XAcFnM

In theory, the person can control a robot anywhere in the world.

What is the halacha of performing this work for a company that is in a timezone where it is currently Shabbat for them but not you? Is this the same question as all timezone/melacha questions, or is there something novel here, because of the control of the robot, which physically moves under said control?

For review:
If it's fine, and identical to other "remote melacha timezone" questions, then, even though it might be halachically identical on the surface, perhaps there are other considerations. For example, if this became widespread, cheap, and common, people might start remoting in to visit their family on Shabbat (note: I don't want to get into the halacha of CCTV, babycams etc). They might start doing melachot for them (with or without being asked).

So, it might be a "spirit of the law" thing, or a posek might forbid it due to potential misuses like this etc.

* The pictures in this article are fine, but I have ad blocker so I can't verify if the ad service they use is kosher. Click at your own risk!

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I used to work from the US on a computing cluster in Europe. I also regularly met on video with colleagues in Europe (they were not Jewish).

When I started, I asked my LOR if it was ok to do these things on Friday afternoon and was told it was no problem.

title: Sources for the Noncontradiction principle in Judaism
content:
# Sources for the Noncontradiction principle in Judaism ## Frage

IMU, the "Law of Noncontradiction" does not apply in religion in general - same rabbis can hold opposing views and contradicting Halochos can coexist (see אֵלּוּ וְאֵלּוּ דִּבְרֵי אֱלֹהִים חַיִּים, Eruvin 13).

My question is whether some sources for the existence of such a principle can be found in the scripture or Rabbinic literature?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

I believe that, contrary to your assertion that the Law of Noncontradiction does not exist in Judaism, it is in fact fundamental to the entire Talmud.

For example, just on Yoma 14b, which I happen to have studied recently, it appears four times.

  1. The Gemara derives from the Mishna that in the daily service in the Temple, first the incense was burnt, and afterwards the Menorah was cleansed of ashes that had accumulated. It questions how this can be, given that it contradicts a Mishna elsewhere (in Tamid) which gives the opposite order.
  2. In response to the answer of Rav Huna, who asserts that unattributed Mishnayos in Tamid follow the views of Rabbi Shimon Ish Hamitzpeh (and therefore represent a different opinion than unattributed Mishnayos in Yoma), the Gemara asks how this can be. A beraisa in Tamid has Rabbi Shimon Ish Hamitzpeh arguing against the view of an unattributed Mishna there; thus we see that he is not the author of unattributed Mishnayos there.
  3. Following (but not in response to) the answer of Rabbi Yochanan, who asserts that unattributed Mishnayos in Yoma follow the view of Rabbi Shimon Ish Hamitzpeh, the Gemara questions an apparent contradiction within Yoma itself. On the one hand, the local Mishna puts the incense prior to the cleansing of the Menorah. On the other hand, another Mishna in Yoma puts the cleansing of the Menorah first and the burning of the incense afterwards.
  4. In response to Abaye's answer, that first five arms of the Menorah were cleansed, then the incense was burnt, then the remaining two arms of the Menorah were cleansed (thus, each Mishna refers to one part of cleansing the Menorah), the Gemara asks how could this be. Abaye seems to contradict himself, for he says elsewhere that the sprinkling of the blood of the Daily Offering, not the burning of the incense, was in between the two stages of cleansing the Menorah.

Much Talmudic argumentation takes this form. Some statement X is quoted or proposed. The statement is questioned because it contradicts a more authoritative source, or because the rabbi that proposed it thereby contradicts himself--that is, at face value, statement X violates the Law of Noncontradiction. Then, either a resolution is found, or else statement X is abandoned.

The Gemara in Eruvin which you reference says the following: Rabbi Abba declared in the name of Shmuel, for three years Beis Shammai and Beis Hillel debated. Each said "the halacha is like our opinion." Finally, a Bas Kol (Heavenly Voice) emerged and said that both these and those are the words of the Living G-d, but the halacha is like Beis Hillel.

It seems clear from this that in fact the halacha cannot be self-contradictory. While both Beis Hillel and Beis Shammai found favor in Hashem's eyes, and one who studies the words of either is credited with studying Torah, the practical halacha must follow one or the other.

I do not know what source you think you have for the assertion that one rabbi can hold two contradictory opinions.

title: Going against traditional rules = "I just want to be me" - hashkafic (and halachic?) analysis
content:
# Going against traditional rules = "I just want to be me" - hashkafic (and halachic?) analysis ## Frage

The modern trend is to try to say that any "traditional" restrictions on human expression are no longer enforcible, and in fact, those who defy them are to be celebrated as "being able to truly express themself".

For example, Gonzo in Muppet Babies (a show aimed at children), when he comes out as cross-dressing (something that general society considered an idiosyncrasy until recently), explains his deception by saying:

"I don't want you to be upset with me... but I don't want to do things just because that's the way they've been done, either. I wanna be me."

Question: What do Torah sources say about this concept... specifically, the concept of "being me" being associated with "going against traditional rules"?

Examples of things I've seen that could be relevant:

  • The question "aren't all the many laws and halachot in Judaism restrictive to a person's freedom?"
  • The idea of tachlit, tikun, yi'ud - i.e. the person's mission/purpose
  • The concepts of humility and bittul - "I just want to be me" could be animal soul/yeitzer hara, especially because...
  • ...Avot 6:3: שאין לך בן חורין אלא מי שעוסק בתלמוד תורה
  • Mesirat Nefesh
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

As one can imagine, the Torah is very against such an attitude:

And it be, when he hears the words of this curse that he bless himself in his heart, saying: [These curses will not come upon me, but] "All will be well with me, for as my heart sees fit shall I do," so that the unwitting (sin) is added (for punishment) to the willful, The L-rd will not wish to forgive him, for then the wrath of the L-rd and His vengeance will burn against that man, and there shall descend upon him the entire curse that is written in this scroll, and the L-rd will erase his name from under the heavens. And the L-rd will set him aside for evil from all of the tribes of Israel, according to all the curses of the covenant that are written in this scroll of the Torah.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The closest I am aware the Torah comes to this is Mishlei 22:6, which states "חֲנֹ֣ךְ לַ֭נַּעַר עַל־פִּ֣י דַרְכּ֑וֹ גַּ֥ם כִּי־יַ֝זְקִ֗ין לֹֽא־יָס֥וּר מִמֶּֽנָּה"

Which can be translated as "Train a child according to his way and he will not veer from it in his old age"

This would appear to suggest that "the way it's always been done" may not work for every child, and that by doing things his way, you will give him an education that will last a lifetime.

As always, one should consult a posek before putting anything on this site into practice, and you'd probably want to look at some meforshim there as well. Also, this would clearly not provide a basis to allow something assur mid'orayta like cross-dressing.

title: Why is the translation of selah so obscure?
content:
# Why is the translation of selah so obscure? ## Frage

The word 'selah' appears numerous times in Tehillim and Tefillah.

אַשְׁרֵי יוֹשְׁבֵי בֵיתֶךָ עוֹד יְהַלְלוּךָ סֶּלָה

וְכל הַחַיִּים יודוּךָ סֶּלָה וִיהַלְלוּ וִיבָרְכוּ אֶת שִׁמְךָ הַגָּדול בֶּאֱמֶת לְעולָם כִּי טוב הָאֵל יְשׁוּעָתֵנוּ וְעֶזְרָתֵנוּ סֶלָה

I've observed a strange prevalent ignorance in the correct translation of the word 'selah'. This seems to be compounded by the insistence of reliable translation authorities to omit the translation of this word. See, for example, how Artscroll don't translate:

Why the curious hesitation to accurately translate?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Targum Yonasan indeed translates it as 'Forever' and R Avraham ibn Ezra as 'Truth'.

However, as @J. W. Tanner commented, Radak writes that it is a musical signifier (cf Septuagint and Vulgate).

Artcroll is presumably agreeing with the latter interpretation and therefore leaves it as it is—a hebrew musical term (as does the KJV).

(Radak, Tehillim, 3:3

Selah – The majority of commentators say of the word Selah that it is equivalent to לעולם ("for ever"); and so Jonathan renders it in the Prayer of Habakkuk (iii. 3, 9, 13) for ever (לעלמין). And in this sense the word is common in our prayers. And the learned Rabbi Abraham ben Ezra – may the memory of the just be blessed! – has interpreted (ad loc.) that it is equivalent to אמת (truth). For myself, I say it is not a significant word. And it is to be interpreted as having the meaning "lifting up" (of the musical accompaniment) from (the passage) "cast up, cast up (סלו) the way" (Is. Ixii. 10), signifying that at the point where this word is mentioned and read there was a raising of the sound of the music (מזמור). And the proof is in the fact that it is not found except in this book and in the Prayer of Habakkuk, which was a song (accompanied by music), as is written also there (iii. 19), "For the chief musician on my stringed instruments.")

Ditto if you accept Hoil Moshe's suggestion that it is a way of referring to HaShem.

(Hoil Moshe, ibid, 3:9:

Selah — Many interpretations have been offered for this word (see Otzar HaShorashim by Rabbi Wolf Heidenheim), and it seems to me that the most accurate meaning of the term, according to tradition (its translation as "forever"), is the most correct one. We only find it in Psalms and two or three times in the prayer of the prophet Habakkuk, which was composed according to the shigyonot, meaning in the style of songs known as shigyon (see what I will write, with God's help, on the meaning of the word shigyon, at the beginning of Psalm 7). Certainly, the songs of David were never forgotten by the people of Israel, not even for a single generation, and the meaning of this word has been preserved for us correctly through tradition.

If we investigate its origin, we find its pattern in the word herah ("flee" in Genesis 12:8), which is similar to "ascending" (lehar, "to the mountain"). Selah is from the root that appears in "You are still exalted (mistolel) among my people" (Exodus 9:17) and "Extol Him who rides upon the heavens" (Psalm 68:5), meaning to exalt and lift high (even though, in truth, the lamed [in salu] ought to be emphasized). Therefore, the basic application of the word Selah is as a reference to God, blessed be He. Just as we find that the word netzach is a reference to Him (and also netzach Yisrael, 1 Samuel 15:29) and is also used as a verbal form meaning "forever," the same applies to the word Selah. Examine Meir Natib, and you will find that in every instance it can be explained with one of these two meanings. None of the other interpretations offered in the Otzar HaShorashim are valid in all cases without significant difficulty.)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

It is a good question why it is not translated. It is however false to assume that we don't have an early tradition to its meaning. Provided that Targum Tehilim is authoritative, it translates as "always".

title: Multidimensional person
content:
# Multidimensional person ## Frage

Rabbeinu Ari writes :

כי כמו שמשה רבינו ע"ה הוא בבחי' הדעת העליון דז"א מצד אבא כן בלעם היה הרע שבמשה והיה כנגדו בדעת

...because, just as Moshe, our Rabbi A'H represents the aspect of the Da'at Eliyon of Zeir Anpin, from the side of Abba [Kabbalistic/Chassidic terminology/metaphors], so too was Bilam, the evil/negativity of/in Moshe, corresponding to him in Da'at.

(Shaar haHakdamot, Seven Kings of Edom 1)

The Ari says that the Bilam is the "evil in Moses" and at the same time he is a process in the shvirat haKelim which happened before there was Adam and at the same time he is the evil prophet who lived at the time of Moses.

My question is: Can someone explain how one person is at the same time a part of another and simultaniously a concept and if there are more cases of a person being "multidemensional" ?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Obviously, I can't explain what this all means, but there are subject headers:

  1. A person can be a "concept" because our souls are rooted in the higher realms, which also correspond to concepts. A soul being rooted in "da'at elyon" means that that soul's way of operating, and viewing the world, is rooted in the higher da'at that analyses good and evil and chooses the good, whereas a soul rooted in the lower da'at will merely be the world's expert at mixing good and evil (See Podoh Beshalom 5672).
  2. A person being part of another is a basic concept that we are all part of Adam. His soul is composed of 10 sefirot, and "broke" into many pieces. If you realise that the sefirot are contained within eachother fractally, you can see how the 10 can become millions - there is a soul that is Chesed within Chesed within Gevura within Tiferet within Da'at, and depending exactly on this make up/spiritual anatomy, he will see operate and see things in his unique way. Someone higher than him on the chain will be able to see things his way too, and become his teacher, and acts as his root (See Shaar Hagilgulim)

title: Who threw the plate in that made the Egel Zahav עֵגֶל זָּהָב come out?
content:
# Who threw the plate in that made the Egel Zahav עֵגֶל זָּהָב come out? ## Frage

Yehuda haKohen relays:

The Hebrew worldview associates Yosef with cattle. In Moshe’s brakhot to the different tribes at the end of Sefer D’varim, we see Yosef likened to a shor – a bull. Our Sages teach that when Moshe raised Yosef’s sarcophagus from the bottom of the Nile, he had written the words “aleh shor” – “arise bull” on a metal plate and then cast that plate into the river. Yosef’s body then rose to the surface and Moshe was able to fulfill the nation’s oath to bring it with us out of Egypt.

The Midrash Tanḥuma teaches that someone retrieved this metal plate and brought it to Sinai. When the people demanded that Aharon construct a new god to replace Moshe, Aharon collected their gold and began to melt it down. Then this man threw the metal plate with the words “aleh shor” into the fire and the Golden Calf emerged.

Who was this man who inherited the golden plate and caused the golden calf to emerge? What was his name?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

His name was Michah, per Midrash Tanchuma, cited by Rashi to Shemos 32:4:

There are some who say that Micah the idolator mentioned in Judges ch. 17, was there, who had been drawn forth from the foundations of a building in Egypt where he was nearly crushed. He had in his possession a “supernatural name” (שם) and a plate upon which Moses had written: “Come up, ox, come up, ox!” in order to raise the coffin of Joseph who is compared to an ox (cf. Deuteronomy 33:17) out of the Nile, and he cast it (the plate) into the melting pot and the calf (the young ox) came out (ויצא העגל הזה) (Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 19).
