title: Ki Savo: Idols of Wood and Stone
content:
# Ki Savo: Idols of Wood and Stone ## Frage

Devarim 28:64 says:

וֶהֱפִֽיצְךָ֤ יְהֹוָה֙ בְּכׇל־הָ֣עַמִּ֔ים מִקְצֵ֥ה הָאָ֖רֶץ וְעַד־קְצֵ֣ה הָאָ֑רֶץ וְעָבַ֨דְתָּ שָּׁ֜ם אֱלֹהִ֣ים אֲחֵרִ֗ים אֲשֶׁ֧ר לֹא־יָדַ֛עְתָּ אַתָּ֥ה וַאֲבֹתֶ֖יךָ עֵ֥ץ וָאָֽבֶן׃

יהוה will scatter you among all the peoples from one end of the earth to the other, and there you shall serve other gods, wood and stone, whom neither you nor your ancestors have experienced

Of course, the galus part came true literally, but I am wondering about the אֱלֹהִ֣ים אֲחֵרִ֗ים אֲשֶׁ֧ר לֹא־יָדַ֛עְתָּ אַתָּ֥ה וַאֲבֹתֶ֖יךָ עֵ֥ץ וָאָֽבֶן.

B’zmanenu, there are still certain groups who perform avodah zara for wooden idols, but they are not at all dominant outside of India l’choira.

Rashi writes:

ועבדתם שם אלהים אחרים. כְּתַרְגּוּמוֹ — לֹא עֲבוֹדַת אֱלֹהוּת מַמָּשׁ אֶלָּא מַעֲלִים מַס וְגֻלְגֹּלִיּוֹת לְכוּמְרֵי עֲ"זָ: ועבדתם שם אלהים אחרים

AND YE WILL SERVE THERE OTHER GODS — Understand this as the Targum does: (ye will serve the peoples that worship idols); not actually that they shall serve idols, but they will have to pay tribute and poll-taxes to the priests of the idols.

This makes sense in Rashi’s France, when his government was explicitly Christian, but how do we understand this for our generation?

Are our “idols” money and values contrary to Torah? Are the “priests” politicians and bureaucrats?

Edit: this question is distinct from another question regarding the idea of contemporary nochri idolatry in that it is with reference to this particular pasuk.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Satmar Rav (Divrei Yoel Al HaMoadim, Shekalim, Zachor, Purim, p. 54-55 ff.) explains that nowadays, we have different kind of avodah zarah than there was back in the days. He says:

כי הנה כן אנו רואים היום שמלבישים תמיד איזה צורה אחרת לעבודה זרה ועל ידי זה כבר נמשכים אחריה שאומרים שאינו כמו אותו עד עכשיו אלא שהוא באופן אחר

For indeed, we see today that idolatry is constantly being disguised in new forms, and through this disguise, people are led astray after it. They claim that it is not the same as the idolatry of the past but something different

וזאת ועוד נוסף כי אכן לאמיתו של דבר הרי המתבונן מבחין שבאמת נשאר הכל ממש כאותו העבודה זרה שהיתה מלפנים אלא שיש בכוחו של היצר הרע לטכס עצה ולמצוא תמיד איזה לבוש שונה באופן אחר שיוכל להלביש בזה את העבודה זרה שתהיה נראית שהיא אחרת

Moreover, upon closer reflection, one can discern that in reality, nothing has changed—it remains exactly the same idolatry as it was before. The only difference is that the evil inclination has the ability to devise new strategies and continuously find different ways to cloak idolatry in various forms

So, according to the opinion of the Satmar Rav, avodah zarah changes. De avodah zarah of the time of pharao is not the same as we have now, but the foundational ideas are the same.

He says:

ומעתה נאמר שכל זה רמוז באומרו לא יהיה לך אלהים אחרים דהנה אמרו ז"ל במכילתא מכילתא ס' בחודש פ"ס ומובא ברש"י שמוח כ' ג' לבאר אומרו לא יהיה וגו' על פני כל זמן שאני קיים שלא תאמר שלא נצטוו על ע"ז אלא אותו הדור ע"כ ולדרכינו הכוונה שלא תאמר שלא נצטוו אלא על אותו הלבוש והדמות שהיתה נראית העבודה זרה שבאותו הדור ולכן אמר אלהים אחרים היינו שנצטוו גם אפילו אם ישתנו דמותי וצורות הע"ז שיהיו נראין באופן אחר מכפי שהיו אז וכדבר האמור שהצורות והלבושים שלהם משתנים תמיד וזהו כוונת אומרו שאלו נפרש להם כל שם ע"ז לא היה מספיק כל העורות שבעולם דהנה גם אצל פרעה לא היו רק אותם הע"ז שהיו אז בימיו אבל לא היה יודע מה שיהיה אחריו וכל אופני שמות העבודה זרה שיש בימינו אלה לא היה לו בספרו אמנם כוונת המכילתא הוא על כל אופני העבודה זרה שיתחדשו בהמשך כל הדורות ועל כך אמרו שאכן אם ירצו לכתוב כולם מה שהיו בהמשך הזמנים ועד לימינו אלה בעיקבתא דמשיחא שתמיד משתנים בדמותם ולבושיהם השונים הרי ודאי שלא היה מספיק כל העורות שבעולם כי אין להם שיעור

As we mentioned earlier, the forms and appearances of idolatry are constantly changing. This is what the verse means when it says that if we were to specify the name of every idol, all the hides in the world would not suffice. Just as in the time of Pharaoh, only the idols of his time were known, but he had no knowledge of the idols that would come after him, nor did his book contain the names of all the forms of idolatry that exist in our time. The intention of the Mechilta is to encompass all forms of idolatry that will arise throughout the generations. And they said that if one were to attempt to write down all the forms of idolatry that have existed from then until today, in the footsteps of the Messiah, where idolatry constantly changes its form and appearance, all the hides in the world would not suffice, for there is no limit to them

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

One can use the quoted passage to include atheism. In colleges professors like to tell a story that polytheists worship many gods, monotheists worship one god, and then there are progressive atheists who do not worship anyone. As an answer, one can use the comment of R. Eliyahu Mizrachi on Rashi Bereshis 18:4, which defines atheism as avoda zara:

ורחצו רגליכם כסבור שהם ערביים כו'. במציעא פרק השוכר את הפועלים ולאו מרחיצה קא מפיק לה דאם כן לבן שלא היה מקפיד למה נתן להם מים לרחוץ וכן לוט שלא היה מקפיד שהרי הקדי' לינה לרחיצה למה נתן להם לרחוץ אלא עכ"ל דרחיצה אורחא דמילתא היא לכל הולכי דרכים והא דדרז"ל אינו אלא מדהקדים רחיצה לביאה שלא כדרך המנהג שמנהג העולם להכניסם תחלה ואחר כך לרחוץ והיינו דמסיים אבל לוט שלא הקפיד הקדים לינה לרחיצה כלומר כפי דרך המנהג לא כאברהם דאם לא כן מה טעם להזכיר כאן את לוט ונראה לי דאבק רגליהם לאו דוקא אלא לכל אבק הם משתחוים והא דנקט אבק רגליהם משום דאורחייהו דהולכי דרכים להמצא האבק ברגליהם והא דלא הקפיד בהם על שהיו עובדי כוכבים להכניסם בביתו הוא משו' דאין מקפידין על העובדי' אלא על הנעבדי' שהם עבודת כוכבים עצמם ומפני שכל הלומדים תמהי' על זה היאך אפשר להיות שישתחוה שום אדם לאבק שעל רגליו שהוא הפחות שבנמצאות נראה לי לתת טעם על זה שמפני שהקדמוני' מהפלוסופים היו מאמינים שכל הנמצאות כלם מורכבים מהעצמים הפרדיים שהם האבק ושבחבורם יתהוו כל הנמצאים ובהפרדם יפסדו ושאין מנהיג זולתם רק הם עצמם האלוהו' כמו כת אפיקורוס וסיעתו והאבק נמצא תמיד ברגלי הולכי דרכים הוכרח אברהם אבינו ע"ה לתת להם מים לרחוץ טרם הכנסם בביתו כדי שלא יכנסו בביתו עם האבק שהיו משתחוים לו לשום אלהות לא שהיו משתחוים לאבק שברגליהם ממש:

And wash your feet as you think they are Arabs, etc. The incident is noted in Bava Metziya 86b, perek haSocher es Poalim. And if he did not perform the wash, in the case of Lavan, who was not particular, why did he gave (Eliezer) water to wash (feet) (Bereshis 24:32)? And also Lot, who was not careful, because he offered spending night before washing (feet), why did he offer them to wash (Bereshis 19:2)? Rather, washing was a common custom for all wayfarers. But from the drasha of RZ"L in Bava Metziya 86b it is not so, because Abraham preceded washing (feet) to coming into (the tent) contrary to custom entering the tent and then washing (as Lot did).

It seems to me that the verse is not speaking simply (לאו דוקא) of the dust of the (travelers) feet. Rather, to all kinds of "dust" (i.e. materiality) the bow. And here it chose to speak of the dust of their feet because it is the way of travelers to have dust on their feet. Thus [Lot] was not particular about it when bringing [guests] into the house because he only focused on those who bow to stars themselves. Because anyone who learns wonders how is it possible for a human to bow to dust on one's feet, which is less than material amount? I would like to give reason to it. The ancient philosophers, such as the sect of Epicurus and his helpers, believed that all things that exist are composed of the individual particles that are the dust; and that by joining them one can bring to existence all things; and by separating them one can destroy all things; and that there is no force other than them, only these particles are god himself. Since the dust is always at the feet of wayfarers, Abraham our father was forced to give them water to bathe before entering his tent so that they would not enter his house with the dust that they would bow down as deification of materiality, not that they bowed down to the dust itself on their very feet:

The teachings of Epicurus are pretty much the foundation of the modern atheism. R. Mizrachi states that one cannot view these teachings other than avoda zara.

title: Is "thinking" out loud considered a Hefsek (interruption)?
content:
# Is "thinking" out loud considered a Hefsek (interruption)? ## Frage

Let's say someone was making a calculation in his head, and while doing so he uttered a part of his calculation verbally, is it considered a Hefsek, if he did so between Shel-Yad and Shel-Rosh, or is speaking only considered a Hefsek (interruption) either if one spoke to somebody else, or as a prayer or some other Mitzva?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

As I understand it ANY speaking is a hefsek (interruption).

To quote the Shulchan Aruch HaRav בְּלִי שׁוּם הֶפְסֵק דִּבּוּר is the key phrase

For this reason, the Sages ordained that one put on the head-tefillin directly after putting on the arm-tefillin without making any interruption by speaking in the interim. In this way, the blessing recited for the arm-tefillin applies also to the head-tefillin.

title: Should buying an Etrog from Israel take precedence over Chutz laarerz?
content:
# Should buying an Etrog from Israel take precedence over Chutz laarerz? ## Frage

Is there an Inyan or Halacha to buy an etrog from Eretz Yisrael? Is there a מעלה of purchasing etrogim from Israel over other countries? Does it make a difference if the person asking this question is located inside or outside the land of Israel?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Yes.

The Aruch HaShulchan (after establishing that the Israeli esrogim were without concern of murkav whereas the Corfu esrogim were) concludes:

ולכן כל איש מישראל אשר נגע יראת ד' בלבו – לא יקח רק אתרוגי ארץ ישראל

Therefore, any Jew whose fear of God affects his heart shall take only of Israeli esrogim.

He then adds:

ואיך לא נבוש ולא נכלם בדבר מצוה שנוכל לקיימה מפרי ארצנו הקדושה, ליטול דווקא מארץ העמים? אוי לה לאותה בושה, אוי לה לאותה כלימה! ועל זה נאמר: וימאסו בארץ חמדה.

And how can one not be ashamed and humiliated — regarding a mitzva which he is able to perform through fruit of our holy land — to intentionally take from other lands? Woe for such a shame! Woe for such a humiliation! Regarding this it states "And they despised the cherished land."

(He lived in Lithuania and was not limiting his rulings to those living in Israel.)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

It appears to be a machlokes depending on whether we have such a mesorah and the quality of that mesorah.

Halachipedia:

Many say that the etrogim from Eretz Yisrael have a good mesorah. Avnei Nezer CM 415 the Etrogim from Eretz Yisrael are the best because there were religious Jews living there the entire time of the exile, but because they’re difficult to get, we use Korfu. Taharat Haetrogim p. 298 cites this.

However, some claim that the etrogim from Eretz Yisrael have no mesora since religious Jews didn’t live there for many years before and after the Ramban (Taharat Haetrogim p. 299 quoting Sod Yesharim p. 356, Horat Heter p. 5. He also cites a testimony from R’ Yakov of Karaz that the minhag Yerushalayim was to use Korfu etrogim.).

However, others uphold the mesora of the etrogim from Israel. (Taharat Haetrogim p. 300 quoting Rav Meir Auerbach author of Imrei Binah (Nefesh Chaya OC 4). He also cites Rav Chaim Nissim Abulafia supporting those etrogim.).

title: Sacrific volume
content:
# Sacrific volume ## Frage

From Lev. 1:2, "when any one of you brings an offering to the Lord" - the sheer volume of sacrifice indicated here seems a staggering amount of work, killing, preparing, burning. How did the priests keep up? Even the act of leading a bull to the alter would be no small task. Grateful for any insight.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

In the following video Simcha Jacobovici explains that based on the size of the bones they find in archeological digs in Israel, the biblical cows were smaller 2000 years ago. There was not so much problem in doing the task as a result. Additional proof one can find in the Siege of Lachish relief found in Ninveh (capital of Assyrian Empire), which documents the battle of Assyrian and Israeli armies, and the aftermath exile of the Israelites by Sanherib. Here is the part showing the Israeli prisoner leading his cattle:

As one can easily see, the grown cattle is as tall as children and significantly shorter than adult men. Therefore, a grown Kohein could lead, tie, and slaughter tied oxen on his own. Carrying of the body parts is described in mishnayot Yoma and Tamid was not as strenuous as it may seem.

This also answers the question why animals, such as cows, sheep, goats were about a factor of 0.1 cheaper compared to prices now.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

The Mishna in Yoma (25a) indicates that a sacrifice would normally be done by a team of Kohanim, such that any individual load was bearable.

The second daily lottery: Who would slaughter, who would sprinkle the blood on the Outer Altar, who would clear away the ashes from the Inner Altar, who would clear away the ashes from the Menorah, who would carry the limbs partway up the Ramp of the Outer Altar--the head and one back leg, the two forelegs, the rump and the tail, the breast and the throat, each of the two flanks, the innards--who would perform the service of the accompanying Flour Offering, of the pancakes, and of the wine. Thirteen kohanim altogether would win this lottery. Ben Azzai quoted the view of Rabbi Yehoshua in the presence of Rabbi Akiva that the sacrifice was brought up in the order in which it walked (that is, first the front parts of the animal, and then the back parts of the animal).

Of course, it is obvious that this could only be done once a sufficient population of kohanim existed. In the early days, when it was only Aaron and his sons, they must have been very busy indeed!

title: How does Devarim 28:68 jive with the opinion that positive public prophecies are never reversed?
content:
# How does Devarim 28:68 jive with the opinion that positive public prophecies are never reversed? ## Frage

Midrash Tanchuma (cited in Rashi to Yirmiyahu 28:7) and Rambam (hakdamah to peirush hamishnah) are of the opinion that only negative public and positive private prophecies can become undone with the betterment/deterioration of behavior respectively, but positive public prophecies can never be revoked, even if bad behavior develops.

Others argue (e.g. Abarbanel to Yirmiyahu ad loc and ibn Kaspi to Devarim 18:21) and say that even public positive prophecies can be voided with the development of bad behavior.

Devarim 28:68 reads:

וֶהֱשִׁיבְךָ יְהֹוָה מִצְרַיִם בׇּאֳנִיּוֹת בַּדֶּרֶךְ אֲשֶׁר אָמַרְתִּי לְךָ לֹא תֹסִיף עוֹד לִרְאֹתָהּ וְהִתְמַכַּרְתֶּם שָׁם לְאֹיְבֶיךָ לַעֲבָדִים וְלִשְׁפָחוֹת וְאֵין קֹנֶה.

Hashem will bring you into Egypt again with ships, by the way of which I said to you, "You shall see it no more again", and there you shall sell yourselves to your enemies for bondservants and for bondmaids, and no man shall buy you.

which refers to Shemos 14:13:

וַיֹּאמֶר מֹשֶׁה אֶל הָעָם אַל תִּירָאוּ הִתְיַצְּבוּ וּרְאוּ אֶת יְשׁוּעַת יְהֹוָה אֲשֶׁר יַעֲשֶׂה לָכֶם הַיּוֹם כִּי אֲשֶׁר רְאִיתֶם אֶת מִצְרַיִם הַיּוֹם לֹא תֹסִפוּ לִרְאֹתָם עוֹד עַד עוֹלָם.

Moshe said to the people, "Do not be afraid. Station yourselves and see Hashem's salvation that He will do for you today, for as you have seen Egypt today, you shall not see them ever again.

The Torah seems to be explicitly saying that the positive public prophecy will be reversed with the advent of deleterious behavior.

How would the first opinion account for it?

(Oddly, Abarbanel himself, to the Devarim verse, proffers a difficult suggestion in defense of the other opinion, I'm looking for something more straightforward)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Perhaps the verse in Shemos is a command, not a prophecy. Not "I promise that you will never go back there again," but "I command you not to return there again." Alternatively, we could read it as referring to the people. "Today you have seen these people, but you will never see them again--for they will sink to the bottom of the sea."

title: Gold and Shofaros
content:
# Gold and Shofaros ## Frage

The Mishna in Rosh Hashana 26a states that according to the Tanna Kama, a shofar may not be made of a cow's horn.

In the Gemara, Ulla states that one reason for this is that "the accuser cannot become the defender," a concept which Rav Chisda had previously used to explain the fact that the Kohen Gadol does not wear the Golden Vestments while doing the parts of the Yom Kippur service which involve entering the Holy of Holies. Since the Golden Calf was made (as the name suggests) of gold, it would be wrong to use gold in this service. So too, says Ulla, since the Golden Calf was (as the name suggests) a statue of a calf, it would be wrong to use a cow's horn for the shofar.

The Gemara on the spot asks why the Kohen Gadol does wear Golden Vestments on other occasions, and answers that the rule of "the accuser cannot become the defender" only applies inside the Holy of Holies. If so, the Gemara asks of itself, what does the rule of "the accuser cannot become the defender" have to do with the shofar of Rosh Hashana, which is blown outside the Holy of Holies? The answer given is that the Torah describes the shofar as being for "remembrance," and this is the equivalent of being inside the Holy of Holies.

About a page later, on 26b , another Mishna teaches that the shofar used in the Beis Hamikdash was partially gold plated. (This point appears to be unanimous amongst all the Tannaim.)

My question is this--how would Ulla explain this Mishna? Why does not the rule of "the accuser does not become the defender" prevent us from decorating the shofar with gold plate, just as it prevents the Kohen Gadol from wearing the Golden Vestments inside the Holy of Holies?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The shofar's sound, which causes 'remembrance', is what makes it considered akin to being 'inside'.

The gold, which adorns the shofar, invalidates the shofar if it impacts the sound.

As the gold contributes no part to the sound emitted and by extension the 'remembrance' generated, it is therefore not considered as being 'inside'.

title: Why doesn't Josephus mention the golden calf?
content:
# Why doesn't Josephus mention the golden calf? ## Frage

When studying the text of the Jewish Antiquities written by the Roman historian Josephus, I found that events related to Moses and the travels of Hebrews in the wilderness are covered in considerable detail. At the same time, Josephus does not mention at all the event of the Golden Calf. What is the reason for the omission?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Gregory E. Sterling, "When Silence Is Golden: The Omission of the Golden Calf Story in Josephus", in: Golden Calf Traditions in Early Judaism, Christianity, and Islam, pp. 87-96 discussed the possibility you suggested in the comments regarding the libel of the statue in the Temple, but rejected it on the grounds of Josephus still mentioning Jeroboam's two golden calves later in Antiquities, as well as multiple other instances of Israelite idolatry.

He suggested a combination of two other reasons instead:

  1. Tremendous respect for Aaron. Other ancient Hellenistic Jewish authors had difficulties with Aaron's embarrassing sin, and more so Josephus, who wrote about Aaron in glowing terms elsewhere. In this omission, Josephus was not different from Philo and the later Pseudo-Philo, who also skirted over the topic. Philo did mention the calf, but did not state that Aaron created it. Pseudo-Philo restructured the narrative so it'd be more clear that Aaron did it because he knew that he would be in mortal danger if he did not comply with the nation's demands.

  2. Respect for the sacredness of the tablets and the commandments - Josephus did not want it be known that Moshe had broken the first set of tablets in anger, which were sacred in his (Josephus's) eyes. This second reason explains why Josephus didn't pursue a description similar to that of Philo or Pseudo-Philo (i.e., freeing Aaron from blame), instead preferring to omit the story entirely.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

My understanding is that Antiquities was written for a Roman audience and Josephus was trying to portray the Jews in as favorable and sophisticated a light as possible.

title: "It would have been better if they had not been born" - why?
content:
# "It would have been better if they had not been born" - why? ## Frage

I have seen the phrase "it would have been better if they had not been born" in regards to lots of sins.

Here is a sample.

I notice that this phrase can often be used in isolation, without any explanation. This guides me towards curiosity.

  • What are the origins of this phrase
  • Does it have a specific meaning or is it context based?
  • Why is it used so often without explaining itself. Ok, it would have been better to not have been born, but why? What was it like before and why is it now worse? In what way?
  • Why are we, against our will, put into a situation that could (so easily) end us up in a worse position than had we never been put into that situation? p.s. Why does it seem most of the time, it seems to be a phrase used when there are two outcomes, it is the failure state: a man should do x and he will be rewarded y, but if not it would have been better had he not been born
  • Is there any good news for the (seemingly many) unsuccessful ones, who "should never have been born"?

So, this question is regarding the phrase ונוח להם שלא נבראו and equivalent, & it seeks an answer that is able to deal with explaining it as properly and fully as possible. I suspect there probably is some source out there somewhere that tries to do so, but will accept whatever I can get that helps with the above questions regarding this specific phrase.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן שְׁתֵּי שָׁנִים וּמֶחֱצָה נֶחְלְקוּ בֵּית שַׁמַּאי וּבֵית הִלֵּל הַלָּלוּ אוֹמְרִים נוֹחַ לוֹ לְאָדָם שֶׁלֹּא נִבְרָא יוֹתֵר מִשֶּׁנִּבְרָא וְהַלָּלוּ אוֹמְרִים נוֹחַ לוֹ לְאָדָם שֶׁנִּבְרָא יוֹתֵר מִשֶּׁלֹּא נִבְרָא נִמְנוּ וְגָמְרוּ נוֹחַ לוֹ לְאָדָם שֶׁלֹּא נִבְרָא יוֹתֵר מִשֶּׁנִּבְרָא עַכְשָׁו שֶׁנִּבְרָא יְפַשְׁפֵּשׁ בְּמַעֲשָׂיו וְאָמְרִי לַהּ יְמַשְׁמֵשׁ בְּמַעֲשָׂיו ערובין יג ע"ב

The Rabbis taught: For two and a half years, Beis Shammai and Beis Hillel debated. One said that it would have been better (or maybe easier) for a man not to have been created, and the other said that it was better that he was created. They concluded that it would be better that he were not created, but now that he is created, he should examine his deeds; and some say, he should feel his deeds. Eruvin 13b

It seems to me that one of these schools of thought held that being given the opportunity to cling to Hashem is "worth it," even for someone that fell away from Him, while the other held that for someone that fell away from Him, the theoretical (but unutilized) opportunity to cling to Him has basically expired worthless. They concluded that the second approach was more correct, but noted that this only applies once a man is dead. While he is still alive, he can improve his deeds with mussar and cheshbon hanefesh, and he should do so.

As for the sources that apply the phrase "נח לו שלא נברא" to people that commit various sins, I think that they are pointing out that such people are indeed throwing away the opportunity of life, and we can apply to them the final decision that he would have been better off had he never been created

The good news for such people is that so long as they're alive, they can turn things around. And even after they're dead, it is possible that some merit will be found for them. For example, perhaps their children or grandchildren will do better, and this will redound to their benefit.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

I note that the phrase used is frequently:

רָאוּי לוֹ כְּאִלּוּ לֹא בָּא לָעוֹלָם -- It would have been better FOR HIM if he had never come into the world.

I see the key word as "for him", not necessarily for the world -- meaning: To spare him pain. (E.g., in Chagigah 2:1)

title: Alzheimer's and Dementia and counting for a minyan
content:
# Alzheimer's and Dementia and counting for a minyan ## Frage

I have tried to find any discussion or responsa on whether someone with dementia or alzheimer's would count for a minyan.

The obvious question is, are they with it enough to know what is being said, respond to amen etc.

Maybe it's taken on a case by case basis, maybe not. Either way, what are the halachic principles to apply to this question?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -1)

If the person still knows where they are and what they’re doing—even for a short time—they can usually be counted in a minyan. It mostly depends on how aware they are. If they understand they’re praying with others, that’s a good sign. But if they are very confused and don’t know what’s going on, then they might not be able to count. These things are different for each person. It’s a good idea to ask a rabbi to be sure. Everyone deserves respect, no matter what they’re going through.

title: Why restrict the teaching of forbidden sexual relations?
content:
# Why restrict the teaching of forbidden sexual relations? ## Frage

The Mishnah says:

אֵין דּוֹרְשִׁין בַּעֲרָיוֹת בִּשְׁלֹשָׁה -- One may not expound the topic of forbidden sexual relations before three [or more] people. [Chagigah 2:1]

Why this restriction? Since the topic is clearly of paramount importance in Judaism, shouldn't the rabbis instruct the people on this matter as much as possible to avoid them sinning? Why should they wait until they have two people before them? Don't people need to know?

I don't understand the answers from the commentators I read. Examples:

-I read: "The danger of expounding upon the verses about forbidden relations in the Torah is either that people will be confused and make irreparable mistakes (i.e. create mamzerim) or that they will be titillated by the attention paid to these verses and they will not be able to control their urges and they will come to sin. " Does not answer my question.

-Also: "If there are only two, the Master speaks to one, and the other listens to him. But if there are three, one listens, and the other two discuss it between them, and can err and come to a wrong conclusion to permit an unlawful thing." Will they always do that? Doesn't the Master hear them?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

To understand this Mishna you need to learn the Talmud on it.

אמר רב אשי מאי אין דורשין בעריות בשלשה אין דורשין בסתרי עריות (בשלשה) מ"ט סברא הוא בי תרי כי יתבי קמי רבייהו חד שקיל וטרי בהדי רביה ואידך מצלי אודניה לגמרא תלתא חד שקיל וטרי בהדי רביה והנך תרי שקלו וטרו בהדי הדדי ולא ידעי מאי קאמר רבייהו ואתו למישרי איסורא בעריות.‏

The conclusion of the Talmud is that this is referring to a specific type of forbidden sexual relations called בסתרי עריות

בסתרי עריות. שאינן מפורשות כגון בתו מאנוסתו ואם חמיו ואם חמותו דנפקי במס' סנהדרין (דף עה.) מדרשא:‏

As Rashi explains, these are forbidden sexual relations that are not explicitly mentioned in the Torah, but are deduced using the classic Talmudic deductive methods.

Other forms of forbidden sexual relations are taught publically, including reading them out aloud on the day everybody goes to services: Yom Kippur!

As stated, the worry is that in a class of 3 students, one student will engage the teacher and the other 2 will start chatting and will miss the finer details, resulting in a wrong ruling.

Does this happen all the time? And why only a subset of forbidden sexual relations?

אי הכי כל התורה נמי עריות שאני דאמר מר גזל ועריות נפשו מחמדתן ומתאוה להם אי הכי גזל נמי עריות בין בפניו בין שלא בפניו נפיש יצריה גזל בפניו נפיש יצריה שלא בפניו לא נפיש יצריה:‏

The Talmud explains that due to human nature, people are attracted to forbidden sexual relations more than to any other sin. For example, the urge to steal something is usually only evoked when one sees an item one fancies.

However, fantasizing about forbidden sexual relations happens even when the object is not around, and sometimes even if the object doesn't exist. Hence the greater worry about misunderstanding lessons referring to forbidden sexual relations.

I think that covers all your questions on the subject.

title: Is God glad when punishing us?
content:
# Is God glad when punishing us? ## Frage

Devarim 28:63 reads:

וְהָיָה כַּאֲשֶׁר שָׂשׂ י״י עֲלֵיכֶם לְהֵיטִיב אֶתְכֶם וּלְהַרְבּוֹת אֶתְכֶם כֵּן יָשִׂישׂ י״י עֲלֵיכֶם לְהַאֲבִיד אֶתְכֶם וּלְהַשְׁמִיד אֶתְכֶם וְנִסַּחְתֶּם מֵעַל הָאֲדָמָה אֲשֶׁר אַתָּה בָא שָׁמָּה לְרִשְׁתָּהּ.

It shall happen that as Hashem rejoiced over you to do you good, and to multiply you, so Hashem will rejoice over you to cause you to perish and to destroy you; and you shall be plucked from upon the land where you go in to possess it.

Although Chazal (b Megillah 10b) say that it means God will cause others to rejoice when destroying you (your enemies), Onkelos renders it straightforwardly, as translated above.

Despite Yashar (R. Yitzchak Shemuel Reggio ad loc) explaining that as God loves us He therefore rectifies our behavior via punishment, the plain language of the pasuk indicates that HaShem is as happy to punish us as He is to reward us.

It sounds disturbing (as were Chazal in the referenced gemara) that HaShem should actually enjoy administering the therapy that we humans experience as pain and suffering.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Had the verse meant that God Himself will rejaice. It would have used ישוש, in the kal. The form ישיש is in the hifil and means "He will cause others to rejoice. Mesiach Ilmim; Havanas HaMikra, based on Megillah 10b). See also שני לוחות הברית

ספר יין הטוב על התרגומים explains it to mean that the foreign nations will rejoice. Although that is an explanation of יב"ע and not אונקלוס.

As an aside: There's a story about a chasidishe rebbe who lived poland, forgot who, who was niftar and before he passed was asked to pray that the bad decress should stop. After his passing the situation worsened. He came to the current rav of the city in a dream and said in shamayim it's all objectively good.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

A statement like this one can be understood at a level mida keneged mida. In other words a person or community were seeking gladness at provoking Hashem. The punishment, k'viyakhol inevitably should reflect k'neged mida a similar response. The punished people should feel as if Hashem is happy. Similarly, many people are glad at performing mitzvos properly, k'neged mida Hashem is glad giving the reward. In other words, joy at doing a mitzvah makes a person feel as if Hashem is glad at rewarding a person. However, as we understand, G-d is not having the emotion, He only applies righteous justice.

title: Is reading "Journey To The West" Avodah Zarah?
content:
# Is reading "Journey To The West" Avodah Zarah? ## Frage

So I'm considering reading the famous Chinese novel Journey To The West, which is about a Buddhist monk, and entails interactions with Taoists and Confucians. From my understanding this book is considered a great novel in world history, and is read throughout China and Japan. Does someone violate Jewish laws of Avodah Zarah by reading this book?

Backdrop: interest in this book has picked up since a famous video game based on it came out and it's also the basis for Dragon Ball.

Edit: so YesChat.ai's Rabbi GPT-Orthodox Jewish Law AI says:

""Journey to the West," a classic Chinese novel, is primarily a fantasy-adventure story based on the pilgrimage of a Buddhist monk to retrieve sacred texts. It involves numerous mythological figures, including gods and demons, many of whom are drawn from Buddhist and Taoist traditions. This does raise questions about avodah zara (idol worship) because the novel includes depictions of deities and practices that are associated with foreign religions.

When considering if reading such a book is avodah zara, we can approach the issue from a halachic perspective:

Actual Worship vs. Study: Avodah zara generally refers to the actual worship or participation in forbidden practices. Simply reading about non-Jewish religious ideas or mythologies does not necessarily fall under this prohibition, especially if the intent is not to engage in those practices. Many poskim allow the study of such material for academic or literary purposes as long as it doesn't lead to admiration or respect for the foreign gods or practices described (Shulchan Aruch, Yoreh De'ah 147:2).

The Concern of Influence: However, there is a concern about exposure to ideas that could influence one’s emunah (faith) or lead to improper thoughts. The Rambam in Hilchos Avodah Zarah (2:2) emphasizes distancing oneself from foreign religious ideologies, which could affect one's spiritual purity.

Entertainment Value: If someone is reading the book purely for its entertainment value, without taking the religious elements seriously, it may be more lenient. But still, it's recommended to have a level of caution regarding materials that openly promote or depict avodah zara, even in a fictionalized format.

In conclusion, while reading Journey to the West isn't technically avodah zara if read for academic or literary purposes, it's important to be mindful of the content and how it might affect one’s beliefs. It’s advisable to consult with a local Rav for a more personalized psak, especially if one feels that the material might be spiritually compromising."

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim 307:16 (translation mine, with my own comments in italics):

It is forbidden to read stories, parables regarding secular matters, love stories like the Book of Emanuel, books of wars (possibly he means adventure stories) on Shabbat. And it is even forbidden to read them on weekdays, because of the concept of moshav leitzim (literally, a gathering place of scoffers--by spending your time on these things, you show a lack of regard for important matters like Torah study). One who reads them also transgresses the verse of "Do not turn towards the non-gods," meaning "do not turn towards that which teaches of them." Love stories are additionally prohibited because they incite lust. The authors of such works, their editors, and certainly their publishers are all guilty of causing the public to sin.

Mishna Brura, sub-paragraph 59:

Because of the concept of moshav leitzim. And how much more so is it forbidden to go to theaters or circuses for this reason, or to other entertainments. And even on Purim, the only entertainment which is permitted is that which is done to remember the miracles of Achashverosh (that is, Purim plays which recount the miraculous events that occurred in the times of Achashverosh). In our many sins, nowadays many people treat this prohibition very lightly, freely attending the theater. Scripture screams about this, saying 'Israel, do not rejoice in the entertainments of the nations!' It also incites the Evil Inclination. Chazal said that one who does such things will 'fall into Gehennom...and also he will suffer (in This World), as it says 'Do not be leitzim, lest your suffering increase.'

So I don't know if it's specifically a violation of the laws of Avodah Zarah, but it seems clear to me that it is not permitted.

title: What is the context, in Sefer Yossipon, of this? “Because in their fury they killed an Ox” (Gen. 49)
content:
# What is the context, in Sefer Yossipon, of this? “Because in their fury they killed an Ox” (Gen. 49) ## Frage

The author is making a list of places where the LXX translators changed the wording and meaning.

The sixth, “Because in their fury they killed an Ox” (Gen. 49). That phrase was replaced for, “in their will they broke the Crib”. Lest the King should deride them and ask, “what hath a man to do with an Ox?”

It is an altered version of Gen 49.6, which describes Simeon and Levi. [credit: Harel, see below]. Does anyone know where this text came from?

Is this anything to do with Joseph, as per shur in the 49.22 - which I interpret as a misreading for shor - (and Deut 33.17 which corresponds to it)?

I'm also curious, though less so, about the change that was made to "crib". The word is ambiguous in English. (It can mean bed, cradle or cowshed.) What is the story behind that?

(I am aware that shor and evus occur together once: in Isa 1.3.)

If anyone has a copy of the Hebrew that would be extremely helpful. It's not in the Sefaria library.

I'm sure there are critical editions of Josippon which must address this puzzle. But I don't have access to any.

[Question edited in light of answer below.]

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

Welcome to Mi Yodeya.

You're using a modernized version of the 17th century edition of "The Abbreviated English Josippon: The Wonderful and Deplorable History of the Jews". As the editors of that volume stated themselves, the first section of the book was taken from older works (Josephus, Maccabees, etc.), which they found to be helpful to the readers. The passage you're quoting is from that section and doesn't appear in Josippon itself. I don't know from where exactly they chose to quote, but the list of verses changed by the 72 sages who authored the LXX appears in a number of Talmudic sources, chief among them Mekhilta de-Rabbi Yishmael 14:17:

"..."כיוצא בו כתבו אליו..."כי באפם הרגו שור וברצונם עקרו אבוס..."
My translation: "....similarly, they wrote for him [Ptolemy]..."for in their anger they killed an ox and when pleased they maimed a manger (can also be translated as "crib").

This also appears in Yerushalmi Megillah 1:9, Bavli Megillah 9a, Tractate Sefer Torah 1:9, Tractate Soferim 1:8, and a specific mention in Beresheet Rabbah 98:5 (mentions of other specific changes can be found in various sources).

As Rashi explains in his commentary on Megillah 9a, this change was made so that the king wouldn't be led to conclude that the ancestors of the Jews were bloodthirsty murderers.

I don't know exactly what you mean by the verse in this text being slightly different from the MT, but I'll assume you mean that the English wording is different from what you found on Sefaria. While it's not farfetched to imagine that the original author of Josippon had a slightly different Masoretic tradition, in this case it's not evidence of a different MT, as each translator chooses a different way of translation (and all the more so given that this section was not translated from Josippon but likely from one of the early printed [=re: standardized] editions of one of the above referenced works, or from a work that quoted such an edition).

As an aside, I believe the only critical edition of Josippon is David Flusser's edition, which is based on the oldest complete manuscript, MS Jerusalem. However, to my knowledge it cannot be accessed online for free (but vol. 1 can be found on the Kotar website and vol. 2 on Otzar Hachochmah). That said, many copies of Josippon can be found on Hebrewbooks, e.g. the editio princeps (can also be found on the NLI website). Text versions are also available on Wikitext (albeit incomplete) and the Maagarim website.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Thank you to Harel13 for showing that the change to the Hebrew text compared to the Greek, is attested in the Talmud (various places) and has only been added to Josippon.

As it happens, the text of the LXX we have DOES differ from the MT, but it is not as described in the Talmud.

The text is Jacob's blessing (Gen 49). Specifically, his words to Simeon and Levi are a rebuke and a curse IMO. It appears to relate to their treacherous attack on Shechem, where they killed the men and enslaved the women. Afterwards, Jacob said: You have made me a stink to the inhabitants of the land (Gen 34.30).

Here is the text of Gen 49.6.

בְּסֹדָם אַל־תָּבֹא נַפְשִׁי בִּקְהָלָם אַל־תֵּחַד כְּבֹדִי כִּי בְאַפָּם הָרְגוּ אִישׁ וּבִרְצֹנָם עִקְּרוּ־שֽׁוֹר

In their counsel let not come my soul. In their assembly let not be joined my glory. Because in their anger they killed a man. And in their self-will they hamstrung an ox. (my trans)

εἰς βουλὴν αὐτῶν μὴ ἔλθοι ἡ ψυχή μου, καὶ ἐπὶ τῇ συστάσει αὐτῶν μὴ ἐρείσαι τὰ ἥπατά μου, ὅτι ἐν τῷ θυμῷ αὐτῶν ἀπέκτειναν ἀνθρώπους καὶ ἐν τῇ ἐπιθυμίᾳ αὐτῶν ἐνευροκόπησαν ταῦρον.

Into their counsel let not come my soul, and to their banding-together let not be fixed my LIVERS. Because in their anger they killed MEN; and in their desire they hamstrung A BULL. (LXX, my trans)

I like ἥπατά. It translates kaved liver instead of kavod glory. As the two clauses have parallel meaning, I interpret both "my soul" and "my liver" to mean "I", "my life". LXX pluralizes the men killed (which fits the story). MT has only one victim. LXX keeps singular the bull who was hamstrung. The greek word is very specific and means exactly that - to sever the sinew. Ikker is used that way in 4 other instances, but there it refers to chariot horses in war. Note that the Hebrew word more usually means "to uproot" and is connected with words meaning "descendant" and "barren".

Jerusalem Talmud Megilla 1.9.15 alleges the version presented to Ptolemy goes thus:

“For in their rage they slew a bull and in their will uprooted a trough"

כִּי בְאַפָּם הָֽרְגוּ שׁוֹר וּבִרְצוֹנָם עִקְרוּ אָבוּס

Evus "trough" connotes food and shelter - it's a shed as much as a manger. I came across it because of the greek φάτνη in Luke's infancy story, which translates it. Although there is nothing in the usage in the Hebrew bible to suggest birth - only food and shelter - I do wonder if that was a pre-existing connotation. (I am sticking my neck out, I know.)

There is no mention, in Gen 34 (the sack of Shechem) of hamstringing livestock. In fact it says Simeon and Levi took all the livestock, which makes sense. Why spoil when you can steal? I think the only reason the LXX jumps to ἐνευροκόπησαν, is because of the other 4 instances, where the military logic is compelling. In short, I think the more natural interpretation of the MT here is "uproot", or "deprive of issue".

I will be honest. I think the bull shur may refer to Joseph, who was either killed and/or deprived of issue. (cf. Gen 49.22. Deut 33.7). My intuition is that there may be an older version of the sack of Shechem, which still involves Simeon and Levi, but where the victim is not Hamor but Joseph. Joseph is deeply associated with Shechem, where he is buried. This would explain the curious Hosea 6.9, where a murder is committed on the road to Shechem, with priestly and robber-band connotations. I also link it to Proverbs 1:10–18.

I am aware I am going out on a very long limb here. But I ask you to consider it..

As for Rashi's interpretation - that killing a bull makes the Jews seem much less bloodthirsty than killing a man - I remind you that in the account we have of the sack of Shechem, they kill ALL the men. Which LXX acknowledges: ἀπέκτειναν ἀνθρώπους (pl).

Killing one man and one bull is an odd way of describing the story in Gen 34. It actually makes more sense if the man and the bull are the same. And how else to explain the curious reference to evus a manger? ...

This is a speculative interpretation, which may not convince. It provides the context of the original text. It's an explanation of the Talmudic amended text (which may once have been LXX), namely "kill a bull... ruin a crib" (my paraphrase). It is euphemistic, because it refers to the killing or castrating of a beloved culture hero. Like all euphemisms, it is intended both to disclose (to the wise) and to keep hidden (from others).

Please see Haral13's post above for the Talmud passages which attest to the altered text.

title: Not saying Amen to the brachas - Ki Tavo
content:
# Not saying Amen to the brachas - Ki Tavo ## Frage

In Parashat Ki Tavo starting 27:15, a list of curses are read by the Levites and it explicitly mentions that the whole nation answered Amen

A few verses later when mentioning the blessings there is no mention that the whole nation said Amen

The Gemara in Sota on 37b states:

וּלְהַקִּישׁ בְּרָכָה לִקְלָלָה, לוֹמַר לָךְ: מָה קְלָלָה בִּלְוִיִּם, אַף בְּרָכָה בִּלְוִיִּם. וּמָה קְלָלָה בְּקוֹל רָם, אַף בְּרָכָה בְּקוֹל רָם. וּמָה קְלָלָה בִּלְשׁוֹן הַקּוֹדֶשׁ, אַף בְּרָכָה בִּלְשׁוֹן הַקּוֹדֶשׁ. וּמָה קְלָלָה בִּכְלָל וּפְרָט, אַף בְּרָכָה בִּכְלָל וּפְרָט. וּמָה קְלָלָה — אֵלּוּ וָאֵלּוּ עוֹנִין וְאוֹמְרִים ״אָמֵן״, אַף בְּרָכָה — אֵלּוּ וָאֵלּוּ עוֹנִין וְאוֹמְרִים ״אָמֵן״.

And furthermore, the verse comes to juxtapose the blessing with the curse, to say to you that just as the curse is recited by the Levites, so too, the blessing is uttered by the Levites; and just as the curse is proclaimed loudly, so too, the blessing is proclaimed loudly; and just as the curse is proclaimed in the sacred tongue, Hebrew, so too, the blessing is proclaimed in the sacred tongue; and just as the curse is proclaimed both in general and in detail, so too, the blessing is proclaimed in general and in detail. And just as after the curse is uttered, both groups of people on each mountain respond and say amen, so too, after the blessing is uttered, both groups respond and say amen.

Anyone know why the Torah didn’t explicitly say it? I understand that the Gemara learns that we can learn one from the other but I am wondering why the Torah didn’t specifically mention it

I haven’t seen any commentators comment on this (if anyone knows of any I would love to know)

Thank you

title: Egyptian priests as closet monotheists, and Joseph’s Pharaoh as a Canaanite?
content:
# Egyptian priests as closet monotheists, and Joseph’s Pharaoh as a Canaanite? ## Frage

An exceptionally rare 1936 book by Rev Dr Izak Goller, called First Chapter, includes the following:

A powerful shepherd king of Canaan had invaded and conquered Egypt, and one of his descendants ruled from the throne of the Pharaohs, much to the annoyance of the Egyptians and their exiled dynasty […Joseph’s] death was followed by a general uprising that deposed the foreign dynasty, reinstated the old line of Pharaohs and bred a natural hatred for us due to our friendship and kinship with the hated usurpers … Moses, brought up in Pharaoh’s palace, received a princely education which included a knowledge of the One God undisclosed to the masses, among whom the Egyptian priests – for their own political purposes – cultivated the most absurd forms of idolatry.

This passage contains two narratives I’ve not seen before:

  1. Joseph’s Pharaoh was a Canaanite invader and there was a revolution between his death and the enslavement of the Israelites.
  2. The Egyptian priesthood were closet monotheists.

Did Rev Dr Goller invent these glosses or do we find them in any traditional sources? Thanks!

title: Do new items need to be kashered?
content:
# Do new items need to be kashered? ## Frage

Do brand new kitchen items (e.g. crockpots, glassware, etc.) need to be kashered? What's the source?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

No. Kashering is for removing traces of non-kosher foods previously cooked in them. If the items have never been used, then there are no traces, and kashering is not needed.

Tevilah (immersion in a natural body of water or in a mikvah) of the object, on the other hand, would be needed, if they were manufactured or retailed by a non-Jew.

See here for more information about tevilat keilim.

# Can you sing religious songs in the restroom? ## Frage

Is it allowed to sing in the restroom? I understand some customs hold that you shouldn't speak in the restroom, but what if someone enjoyed singing in the shower? Also, what if someone sang religious songs in the shower? Would you need to replace any words?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

According to the Yabia Omer:

Regarding a room that houses a bathtub or shower nowadays, one may not recite any words of holiness in it. One is permitted, however, to think words of Torah in it and may therefore listen to a Torah lecture or holy songs from the radio and the like there.

Note: Obviously, the aforementioned Halacha applies only to a room that houses a bathtub or shower alone; however, if there is a toilet in the room, one may not even think words of Torah there.

title: What are the four names of Jesse?
content:
# What are the four names of Jesse? ## Frage

Jesse was called by four names.

In Midrash Tanchuma, Ki Tisa 13 he is named as one of only 7 men who had multiple names.

But the text doesn't elaborate on Jesse. Are the four names explained anywhere else?

I know that one of the names is Nachash (if indeed that is the same person). But not the others.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

According to the parallel version brought in Shemot Rabbah 40:4, the word "ישי" (Jesse) in Tanchuma is a scribal error and should be "יש" (there is):

"יֵשׁ שֶׁנִּקְרְאוּ לוֹ אַרְבָּעָה זֶה אֵלִיָּהוּ"
"There is one who had four names, this is Elijah."

This is also evident from the next paragraph (in both texts), which begins discussing the list with Elijah, then continues to Bezalel, who was the main focus of this midrashic exposition.

This was also the version that was before Rabbi Avraham Helin (Hebrew Wiki) in his commentary Yedei Moshe and Rabbi Chanoch Zundel in his commentary Etz Yosef.1

It's possible that the scribal error in some versions arose from the fact that at the end of the list Elijah seems to be mentioned once again as having four names, however this is an erroneous reading of the text. Here Elijah is mentioned again as a dibbur hamatchil, a starting quote before the next section of exegesis, which discusses the origins of Elijah. And then the midrash moves to discussing Elijah's four names.

1 Note that the linked printed edition which features the Etz Yosef has the same scribal error; the Etz Yosef himself used a different edition, and perhaps also saw manuscripts.

title: Is there any reason to suppose that "Reish Lakish" means something like "chief of the bandits"?
content:
# Is there any reason to suppose that "Reish Lakish" means something like "chief of the bandits"? ## Frage

I feel like I've heard this many times over the years. In the last couple of days I've shopped the question around, and everyone seems to have heard the theory that because of his colorful past, Reish Lakish was so-called because it means "chief of the bandits."

It doesn't seem to make much sense. Jastrow doesn't list such a word, Lakish = bandit. It seems hard to reconcile with the frequently-used Shimon Ben Lakish, unless that Ben is taken to mean something like the Ben of Ben Torah. And it would seem rather strange to call him forever by reference to his former bad character which he so greatly improved. To me it seems much more natural to assume that Reish is a contraction of Rav Shimon, used just because there were a lot of Shimons to be distinguished.

Anyhow, is there any source or good reason to the view that Reish Lakish means something like "chief of the bandits"?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

R’ Yochanan (Bava Metzia 84a) refers to Reish Lakish as “Bar Lekisha”. The added alef seems to indicate that “Lakish” is more than just a name.

Lekisha translates as “the late one”. (See Targum Onkelos, Bereishis 30:42; Vayikra Rabbah 30:3.) This is one of the reasons the late rain is called מלקוש. Perhaps the name “Reish Lakish” alludes to his belated devotion to Torah study, dubbing him “the Latecomer” — and indeed, “the Head of the Latecomers”.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

In reference to the name Reish Lakish, R. Reuven Margalit לחקר שמות וכינויים בתלמוד on page 6 points out midrash Bereshis Rabba 73:10, which ends with words:

רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר בַּכִּירַיָּא דְלָבָן, רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר לַקִּישַׁיָא דְלָבָן.

Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Those born earlier were Laban’s. Reish Lakish said: Those born later (lakishaya) were Laban’s.

The name signifies he was born later to his parents.

Alternatively, it seems that the nickname Reish Lakish of R. Shimon ben Lakish is a play on words. Lakish was the name of R. Shimon's father, and it means "the late one" as explained Yø-c Ro. However, for R. Shimon the nickname was used as a hint ריש מלקה איש - Reish Malkeh Ish - Chief hitter of men (Thank you Harel13!), as in Mishna Makkos 3:3 " לוֹקֶה אַרְבָּעִים " - flogged with forty lashes.

We can infer the etymology as follows. In the final conflict with R. Yochanan in Bava Metzia 84a R. Shimon b. Lakish says to R. Yochanah:

אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וּמַאי אַהֲנֵית לִי? הָתָם ״רַבִּי״ קָרוּ לִי, הָכָא ״רַבִּי״ קָרוּ לִי!

Reish Lakish said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: What benefit did you provide me by bringing me close to Torah? There, (among the bandits), they called me: Rabbi (literally Leader/Great Man), and here (among Torah scholars), too, they call me: Rabbi.

The description of what R. Shimon did before he became a rabbi is given in Gittin 47a also here

The Gemara recounts a related incident: Reish Lakish sold himself to gladiators. He took a bag and a round stone inside of it with him. He said: There is a tradition that on the final day of a captive’s life, before his captors kill him, they do for him anything that he requests of them, so that he would forgive them for the spilling of his blood. On the final day before they were set to kill him they said to him: What is amenable to you? He said to them: I want to tie you up and have you sit, and I will אֶמְחְיֵהּ/strike each one of you one and a half times. He tied them up and had each one of them sit. When he struck each of them with one strike with the stone in the bag, the one whom he struck died, because Reish Lakish was of great strength. Reish Lakish gritted his teeth in anger, and said to the one whom he killed, in order to prevent the others from realizing what was happening: Are you laughing at me? You still have half of a strike remaining with me, as I struck you only once. He killed them all, and Reish Lakish escaped his captors.

The Aramaic word מחי is the same as Hebrew מכה and מלקה is used in the context of מכות.

title: Nikkud of מפעילה + אותו
content:
# Nikkud of מפעילה + אותו ## Frage

What is the proper nikkud of the feminine הפעיל in the present tense, + אותו? (E.g. מַחֲזִירָה + אוֺתוֺ.) I’ve seen it vowelized variously as ,מַחֲזִירְתּוֺ, מַחֲזִירַתּוּ and מַחֲזִירָתוֺ. (I’ve noticed the Kehati Mishnayos vowelizes pi’el in the present tense as מְשַׁמְרַתּוּ, although I had assumed this was an error.)

Does anyone know of any examples in Tanach where this form appears?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

All of them are okay. The difference between cases 2 and 3 is probably if the word is in pause, if it's in pause then the shva probably turns into a qamets. The 1st case is also okay, it is just that the long form מַחֲזִירַתְהוּ, when the suffix gets swallowed up in the תּ it becomes מַחֲזִירַתּוּ, hence the dagesh for compensation.

It works the same way like in past verbs, the form זכרה becomes the form זְכָרַתְהוּ with a suffix (she remembered him) and then to זְכָרַתּוּ when the ה gets swallowed up in the תּ. The same happens to זְכָרַתְהָ (she remembered her), this always becomes זְכָרַתָּה, and always without mappik.

I don't think I could find sources for the present tense because even the past tense is hard to find, but they should both work the way way.

ישעיהו 59:16 זְכָרַתְהוּ

רות 4:15 זְכָרַתּוּ

ישעיהו 34:17 זְכָרַתָּה

title: Are there any good Jewish books which speak on trauma and emotional pain and then tie in lessons taken from Jewish sources?
content:
# Are there any good Jewish books which speak on trauma and emotional pain and then tie in lessons taken from Jewish sources? ## Frage

Trauma and emotional pain are both common themes of both the Jewish and human experience.

I was curious if there were any good books which dive in deep on this topic and cite references from the Talmud and Torah and even just opinions/anecdotes from the sages on how a Jew should best deal with the issue of pain and trauma?

This is an open ended question but I'll cite specific examples of the topics I mean.

  • The spiritual significance of emotional pain and trauma
  • How a Jew should best handle such issues (both for themselves or for others)
  • The wisdom of respected sages and Rabbis on the topic
  • Why it seems some people seem to suffer more than others given the same circumstances
  • etc.
## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

I suggest that you take a look at some of the works of Rabbi Dr. Abraham J. Twerski, who was both a rabbi from an old and respected rabbinic family and a psychiatrist specializing in addictions, and who wrote numerous books on these topics. (According to Wikipedia, he wrote over 90 books.)

As for which book to read first, that really just depends on what appeals to you. He said himself that he didn't so much write 45 books (or whatever number he was up to at the time), as he wrote the same book 45 times. They all tend to talk about the same ideas. So whichever one appeals to you is a great place to start.

That said, "When Do The Good Things Start?" is full of wisdom and insight, and if you like Charlie Brown and his friends, that's an added bonus.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

Rabbi Dr. Twerski’s books are great. Other books on this topic include the following:

  • Yissurim: A Blessing in Disguise by Leib Gershon Seligson;
  • Pain is a Reality, Suffering is a Choice by Rabbi Asher Resnick;
  • The Holy Fire by Nehemia Polen;
  • Finding Light in the Darkness by Shaul Rosenblatt; and
  • Why God Why by Rabbi Gershon Schusterman.
### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

Garden of the Souls is a small book on suffering from a Breslov perspective. Not to be confused with the Garden series from R Shalom Arush.

title: Can a witness at Kiddushin have committed _serious_ crimes, if no one knows?
content:
# Can a witness at Kiddushin have committed _serious_ crimes, if no one knows? ## Frage

See Can a witness at Kiddushin have had committed inconsequential crimes?, and Can somone admit to being a invalid witness?. I'd like to expand the question. Say there's an observant Jew who unfortunately has not been that successful in his observance. He believes in the Torah, wants to keep it, but has failed on some serious aveiros, and has not been able to really do teshuvah on them; he knows that so far he hasn't been able to rule them out in the future. He's not a mumar, hasn't given up on them at all, doesn't want them.
However he has been careful never to do these kinds of things in public, and as far as the Beis Din and the community is concerned he is a completely upstanding member.
[I'm guessing that, depending on which aveirah, this kind of thing might be pretty common.]

Question: Is he a kosher witness? He knows what he has done, but no one else does beside the רבונו של עולם. The Beis Din will obviously accept him - they won't even listen if he would confess! If he is called as a witness to a Kiddushin does he need to decline if he cares about the couple, or is the only important thing what the Beis Din knows about him?

Maybe to illustrate the question I'll add something that I heard from a very big talmid chacham, which maybe should be a separate question. There's a she'elah on a piece of meat, and the Beis Din hears witnesses and rules it kosher. I have information that they don't that it is neveilah, and they wouldn't even believe me about it if I would have told them; say two witnesses said the opposite. In any case, I didn't say anything to anyone. Am I allowed to eat the meat?
This talmid chacham answered me briefly: "The Torah says you're not allowed to eat neveilah."

title: Do animals go extinct
content:
# Do animals go extinct ## Frage

The Chinuch, on the mitzva of shiluach hakein says the following:

מִשָּׁרְשֵׁי הַמִּצְוָה. לָתֵת אֶל לִבֵּנוּ שֶׁהַשְׁגָּחַת הָאֵל בָּרוּךְ הוּא עַל בְּרִיּוֹתָיו בְּמִין הָאָדָם בִּפְרָט, כְּמוֹ שֶׁכָּתוּב (איוב לד, כא) כִּי עֵינָיו עַל כָּל דַּרְכֵי אִישׁ וְגוֹ' וּבִשְׁאָר מִינֵי בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים בַּמִּינִים דֶּרֶךְ כְּלָל, כְּלוֹמַר שֶׁחֶפְצוֹ בָּרוּךְ הוּא בְּקִיּוּם הַמִּין, וְעַל כֵּן לֹא יִכְלֶה לְעוֹלָם מִין מִכָּל מִינֵי הַנִּבְרָאִים, כִּי בְּהַשְׁגָּחַת הַחַי וְקַיָּם לָעַד בָּרוּךְ הוּא עַל הַדָּבָר יִמָּצֵא בּוֹ הַקִּיּוּם. וּבְהַנִּיחַ הָאָדָם דַּעְתּוֹ עַל זֶה יָבִין דַּרְכֵי הַשֵּׁם, וְיִרְאֶה כִּי הַמְשָׁכַת קִיּוּם הַמִּינִין בָּעוֹלָם שֶׁלֹּא כָּלָה וְאָבַד אֶחָד מִכֻּלָּם, מִבֵּיצֵי כִּנִּים וְעַד קַרְנֵי רְאֵמִים מִיּוֹם שֶׁנִּבְרְאוּ, הַכֹּל בְּמַאֲמָרוֹ וְחֶפְצוֹ עַל זֶה.

It is from the roots of this commandment [that it is] to put into our hearts that the providence of God, may He be blessed, is upon all of His creatures — with the human species individually, as it is written (Job 34:21), “For His eyes are upon a man’s ways, etc.”; and upon the other species of animals generally, meaning to say that His desire, may He be blessed, is towards the existence of the [particular] species. And therefore, no species will ever become extinct from all of the species of creatures, as it is due to the providence of the Living and Existing forever, may He be blessed, that their existence is found.

Is this statement, that no species will ever become extinct, meant to be taken literally? Also, is this thought found in other sources?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Supposing that the Chinuch means exactly what it sounds like. If so, he's wrong. Empirically, we see that many species have become extinct. And therefore, his interpretation, moving as it is, is not correct.

This is not a problem for us. We're not committed to the idea that no Rishon could ever err. Rishonim made mistakes, and Amoraim made mistakes...even Moshe Rabbenu and the Avos and Imahos made a few mistakes.

Hashem is free of all error. Human beings, however great, err.

content:
# Where does it say that Abraham rescues all Neshamos from gehinom? ## Frage

I heard from a sephardic guy that Abraham rescues all Neshamos from gehinom. There is a caveat that he doesn't help those who sleep with a gentile woman. Does anyone know the source?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The source is in Gemara (Eruvin 19a):

״עוֹבְרֵי בְּעֵמֶק הַבָּכָא״, הָהוּא דִּמְחַיְּיבִי הָהִיא שַׁעְתָּא בְּגֵיהִנָּם, וְאָתֵי אַבְרָהָם אָבִינוּ וּמַסֵּיק לְהוּ וּמְקַבֵּל לְהוּ. בַּר מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁבָּא עַל הַגּוֹיָה, דְּמָשְׁכָה עׇרְלָתוֹ וְלָא מְבַשְׁקַר לֵיהּ.

Those who are liable at that time for punishment in Gehenna, but our father Abraham comes and raises them up and receives them. He does not leave the circumcised behind and allow them to enter Gehenna, except for a Jew who had relations with a gentile woman, in punishment for which his foreskin is drawn, and our father Abraham does not recognize him as one of his descendants. (Sefaria translation)

title: Comparison of the Persian king's headquarters with the Holy of Holies in the Temple
content:
# Comparison of the Persian king's headquarters with the Holy of Holies in the Temple ## Frage

In the story of Esther, a queen needed an invite into the king's inner room, despite the fact that it was the place for immediate family. Why was it done in the Persian palace? Can the ritual of providing an invite for a queen be compared to the permission to enter the Holy of Holies room in the Jewish Temple and what deeper meaning can one learn from it?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

In fact this is a very interesting question, making a comparison between the "inner sanctum of the King" and the "inner sanctum of the Beis Hamikdash".

The Targum Simcha brings down in his Sefer, in Parshas Tetzaveh, which of the characters in the megillah may have worn the bigdei kehuna, and when he discusses Queen Esther, he makes the suggestion you are insinuating, based on various sources, primarily the Kav Hayashar 97:3.

title: List of Second Temple Rabbis
content:
# List of Second Temple Rabbis ## Frage

Is there a list of all of the rabbis during the second temple period?

Pirkei Avot lists the men of the great assembly, followed by Shimon haTzadik. The problem is that there are at least three different people that this Shimon could be and from what I could find, traditional sources list him as synonymous with one of the other two. There is Shimon haMacabee, there's Shimon the high priest who met Alexander, and there is the Shimon of Pirkei Avot. Unfortunately, there are some sources mentioning Antigonus (his disciple) living in the second century BCE, and others saying he lived in the 4th century BCE. If it was the former, then the identification of Shimon with Shimon haMacabee seems to be correct, but then we don't know the chain of descent from the men of the great assembly to Shimon. This theory also goes against the common view that the nassi at the time of the chanukkah story was Yossi ben Yoezer. The other theory, identifying Shimon HaTzadik with the Shimon that met Alexander, also doesn't make sense because then there's not enough generations in Pirkei Avot between him and Yossi ben Yoezer, and also still doesn't fix the issue of us not knowing who his teacher was, because Pirkei Avot says that he was the last of the Great Assembly, but if so, then he would have been a contemporary of Ezra, who lived around 200 years before (temple being built in the late 500s BCE).

Are there any sources that perhaps mention the Great Assembly lasting for multiple generations or around 200 years? If not, and the sources say that the Great Assembly was a one-generation thing, how do we account for the gap in time and the inconsistency of who Shimon haTzadik is?

I am aware that there is a differing chronology between the Seder Olam Rabbah and the archeological evidence, and I think that the conventional chronology makes more sense (Seder Olam can be interpreted non-literally, so meshing the two isn't an issue for me), so how do we account for a seeming glaring gap in teachers?

Edit: I also came across an opinion by Rabbi Ishmael that there was roughly 700 years between the destructions of the temples, which seems to line up more with the conventional chronology, but Rabbi Ishmael doesn't break down how he calculated everything and who the leaders in each generation were, so we still have the same issue I asked about above.
