title: Inserting other mitzvot between loan-related commandments
content:
# Inserting other mitzvot between loan-related commandments ## Frage

In Berakhot 21b we learn that even those, who don't interpret the juxtaposition of different verses in the first four books of the Torah, they do so in the Book of Deuteronomy, because – as Ritva points out there among others – in Devarim Moses reiterated all the commandments he had heard from Hashem, so he consciously chose a logic order, which is not necessarily so in the previous books. Therefore, I found it unusual when I was reading Ki Teitzei that between two loan-related prohibitions (taking a millstone as a pledge and entering the house of a debtor) the prohibition of kidnapping and a reminder of tzaraat are interjected. I haven't seen Rashi commenting on this issue despite having done so a few verses earlier. Have you found any commentators discussing this seemingly strange insertion?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Even Ezra gives an explanation. He quotes others that say because of this question, that the first passuk refers to husband and wife and not a millstone. He then argues and explains differently:

כי נפש הוא חובל – כי בו מחית נפשות, והסומכים על הסמך הפרשיות איננה טענה, כי כל מצו' עומדת בפני עצמה והסמיכות כדרך דרש. וזאת הפרש' דבקה, כי הזכיר שלא יגזול ענבים לתת אל כליו וחרמש בקמה, ולקחת אשה והיתה לו גם לאחר ויצא מרשותו, והלוקח אשה שישמח בה לא יהיה עשוק שיצא בצבא. וחביל' הרחים עושק וגם גונב נפש, וכן נגע הצרעת שלא ישמרו משפטיה תזיק הקרובים, וכן לא תעשוק העני בעבוטו והשכיר, והבנים הקטנים שלא ימותו בעון אביהם, והטיית משפט גר יתום וחבול בגד אלמנה, ושכחה בשדה כי היא לעני, וכן לא תעולל וכן פן יוסיף ונקלה, וחסימת השור עשק כי יגע ולא יאכל, והממאן ליבם כדמות עשק, והמחזקת במבושים עושקת, אבן ואבן איפה ואיפה עשק ממש, גם עמלק עשק לישראל:‏

For he taketh a man's life to pledge – For life is sustained by these instruments. Those who rely on the juxtaposition of the sections have no argument, (That our verse speaks metaphorically of sexual intercourse.) for each commandment stands by itself. (The commandments are not necessarily tied together. Each commandment is an independent unit.) The explanation of their juxtapositions is midrashic. (It therefore cannot be used as a reason to interpret a law metaphorically when the plain meaning of the text is acceptable.) This section (The law regarding taking a mill to pledge.) is connected to the previous ones in the following way: (That is, if we want to connect this section midrashically to what comes before, we can so in the following manner.) the Torah mentions that one is not to steal grapes by putting them in his pots (Deut. 23:25), or to lift up a sickle upon his neighbor’s grain (Deut. 23:26); or to take a woman after she has been his and then left his house and married another (v. 1). It also states that one has to cheer the woman whom he marries (v. 5); he is not to be oppressed by going into the army (Ibid.). The taking of a millstone in pledge is a form of oppression. (Hence the positioning of our law.) So too is kidnapping a person. Similarly the plague of leprosy, for if he does not observe its laws then the plague will injure those in proximity to it. (By infecting them.) Scripture similarly states, do not oppress a poor person by taking a pledge from him (v. 10). It similarly states do not oppress a hired person (v. 14) and small children should not be put to death for the sins of the fathers (v. 16). It likewise warns against perverting the justice due a stranger or the fatherless (v. 17). It prohibits the taking of a widow’s garment as a pledge (v. 17). It prohibits one from retrieving a sheaf which was forgotten in the field, for it belongs to the poor (v. 19). Similarly Thou shalt not glean (v. 21). Likewise lest if he should exceed…Then thy brother should be dishonored (Deut. 25:3). (Deut. 25:3 prohibits the infliction of more that 40 stripes to one being punished by lashes. Exceeding this number of stripes is a form of oppression.) The muzzling of an ox (v. 4) is an act of oppression, for the animal toils but cannot eat of its toil. Similarly, refusing to perform levirate marriage (Deut. 25:5-10) is a form of oppression. The woman who grabs a man’s testicles (Deut. 25:11) commits an act of oppression. Employing diverse weights and diverse measures (Deut. 25:13,14) is oppression in its purest form. Furthermore, Amalek oppressed Israel (Deut. 25:17-19). (Thus the laws in Deut. 23:25-25:19 are thematically related. Hence the law prohibiting the taking of a mill was included in this section.) (Sefaria)

title: How old was Abraham when Rebecca (Isaac's wife) was born?
content:
# How old was Abraham when Rebecca (Isaac's wife) was born? ## Frage

Genesis 22 states from what I can gather that Milkah (daughter of Haran, niece of Abraham) married her uncle (Abraham's other brother) Nahor. She had children it appears after Abraham's (Isaac's sacrifice) Mount Moriah incident and the death of Sarah.

Do we have any clues or more information as to Abraham's age was when Rebecca was born?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Rivka was born at the time of the Akeidat Yitzchak, according to Rashi on Bereshit 25:20, based on ibid 22:20. Yitzchak was 37 at the time, based on the fact that Sarah died then, at 127 (ibid 23:1), and she was 90 when Yitzchak was born (ibid 17:17), and Avraham was 137 at the time (because Yitzchak was born when he was 100 - ibid 21:5). Yitzchak married her when he was 40 (ibid 25:20), so therefore Avraham would have been 137 when Rivka was born, according to Rashi, based on Seder Olam, which fills in some of the gaps, specifically the fact that 22:20 implies Avraham got news of Rivka's birth, and Sarah's death (implied by 23:1), both at the time of the Akeidat Yitzchak [I suspect there is no way to calculate the age based on direct scripture without this exegetical fact].

### Antwort 2 (Score: 6)

This subject has been discussed at length in the commentary to Midrash Seder Olam by R. Guggenheimer, here's a quote with some modifications for readability:

"In most French manuscripts and sources the reading (of excerpt from Seder Olam chapter 1):

Our forefather Yitzchak was 37 years old when he was bound to the altar (Bereshis 21:34)...At that time Rivka was born. It follows that Yitzchak married Rivka when she was 3 years old"

In a few (French manuscripts) we find reading "4 years". Some Oriental-Sephardic manuscripts have reading "14 years".

The reading "3 years" is quoted by Rashi on Bereshis 25:20 (see Rabbi Kaii's answer) and Tosafos Yebamos 61b (s.v. וכן), who write "Seder Olam teaches explicitly that she was 3 years old when Yitzhak married her and it is impossible to emend the text since we read there: 'Our forefather Yitzchak was 37 years of age when he was bound to the altar and at that time, 'Rivka was born' and it is written (Bereshis 25:20) 'Yitzchak was 40 years old when he married Rivka.'" Once one accepts the reading "37 years" ..., the unlikely conclusion that Rivka went out alone to fetch water at the age of 3 seems inescapablle.

The reading "4 years" can also be explained the same way: Abraham was informed of Rivka's birth on his return from Mount Moriah, so Rivka can be assumed to be born in the preceding year. This argument does not violate any of Rabbi Yose (b. Chalafta) principles (that Scripture does not come to hide but to explain). But if we accept the reading "37 years" (for Yitzchak), it seems better to accept also the reading "3 years" (for Rivka), not only because of the overriding authority of Rashi and Tosafos, who accept the reading, but also as we have seen before (in the commentary to the midrash), that R. Yose accepts the opinion of R. Yehoshua, that the years start in Nissan, and the patriarchs and matriarchs were born in Nissan. The tradition that the Akkeida on Mount Moriah was on the 1st day of Tishrei; there seems no dissent to this opinion. Therefore the messenger would have more than 6 months (to travel) from Charan to Beer Sheva. In addition, Rashi is a very careful reader of manuscripts, who never hesitates to point out readings he finds questionable.

But nevertheless it is difficult to accept the reading "3 years". The text "at that time Rivka was born" is found in all manuscripts, whether ashkenazic, Sephardic, or Oriental. The text is the base for computation "3 years" as explained. On the other hand, none of the Galilean midrashim has any trace of an opinion that Rivka married as a toddler. Also Talmud Bavli Yebamos 61b is clearly of the opinion that Rivka married as na'arah, a girl in her puberty, who legally is no longer a minor but has not yet acquired the status of an independent adult. This also seems to be implied by the legal language of the verse Bereshis 24:16. The Talmud (loc. cit.) has difficulties with reconciling the rule, derived from Bereshis 16:3, that a couple after 10 years of childless marriage is obliged to seek ways to have a child with the fact (Bereshis 25:20,26) that Yitzchak waited 20 years after his marriage before he was roused to activity. If Rivka actually was only 3 years of age, the first nine years of her marriage would not count since, for a minor, any pregnancy is a hazard to her health or life (Yebamos 12b). However, the Talmud, which otherwise follows Seder 'Olam very strictly, does not choose this easy way out but instead insists that Yitzchak was sterile during the first ten years of his marriage.

In addition, R. Yose (ben Chalafta) is quoted in Pirkei D'Rebbi Eliezer (Chapter 32) saying "3 years did Isaac mourn his mother. After 3 years he married Rebecca and forgot the mourning for his mother," without mentioning that he had to wait anyhow since 3 years is the minumum age after which a father can marry off his daughter. Similarly, the Gallilean Bereshit Rabba (57:2) mentions that "after these happenings" (Bereshis 22:20) of the 'Akkeidah, Abraham realized that he should find a mate for Yitzchak and was informed of Rivka's existence, without insisting that it was a notice of her birth. In fact, as explained ..., the notice that Abraham received from his family was a notification of his father's death, with the notices on his brother's children being incidental. Therefore, it seems clear that one should accept the reading "14 years" as the original reading of Seder 'Olam, as given in Oriental - Sephardic manuscripts.

The Tosafos themselves (Yebamos 61b) give the following argument: "Rebbi Sh'muel (ben Kalonymos) the Pious of Speyer proved that Rivka was 14 years old since it is stated in Sifri (Devarim # 357, cf. also Bereshis Rabba 100:10): 6 couples lived the same number of years, and among them Kehas (son of Levi) and Rivka. Kehas lived 133 years as given by Scripture (Shemos 6:18), and if Rivka was 14 at the time of her marriage then the computations come out right. When Yaacov was born she was then 34 years of age and Yaakov was 99 years old when his mother died (see Seder Olam Chapter 2), that makes 133 years. For Yaakov was 63 years old when he received his father's blessing (Seder 'Olam Chapter 2), 14 years he hid in the house of Ever (loc. cit., Megillah 17a), 20 years in Laban's house (Bereshis 31:38), 2 years he spent on the road (Seder 'Olam Chapter 2), and at that time Rivka died (Seder 'Olam Chapter 2), as we explain, based on Bereshis rabba 81:5, Koheles rabba 7:2, Tanchuma Teitze 4, Tanchuma Buber Vayishlah 26, Pesiqta d'Rav Kahana Zakhor 24a: "(Bereshis 35:8) allon bakhut, aλλov בכות another crying, two mournings,one for Rivka and the other one for her wet nurse (Devorah); for a total of 99 years. One has to assume there are different midrashic traditions."

We even know that not Rebbi Sh'muel the Pious is the author of the argument but Rebbi Eliezer ben Nathan of Mayence / Maynz, known as RAVa"N (Responsa, #118). He reports to have been asked by Rebbi Sh'muel ben Kalonymos about the source for the assertion that Rivka's life was equal in length to that of Kehas "and I answered him, it is taught in Seder 'Olam: At the time of the 'Akkeidah, Rivka was born and was married to Yitzchak at age 4, and Devorah the wet-nurse of Rivka died (Bereshis 35:8) together with Rivka, and if you compute from the 'Akkeidah to the death of Devorah you will find only 123 years and she would have lived 10 years less than Kehas. But certainly, the author of Sifri disagrees with the author of Seder 'Olam and in his opinion she was 10 years old at the time of the 'Akkeidah and was married at age 14, or also he might be of the opinion that she was born at the time of the 'Akkeidah but he does not accept that she died at the same time as her wet-nurse but lived another 10 years and the entire statement is a tradition (not supported by Scripture)." His interpretation is accepted by the later French commentator Chizkuni (Bereshis 25:20) as based on the correct reading of Seder 'Olam "14 years."

As explained in the introduction (of the commentary), it seems that Seder 'Olam is a Babylonian compilation of the school of Rav, based on Rebbi Yose's material. There are also good reasons to accept the attribution of the editing of Sifri to the same school. Therefore, it is most reasonable to accept the reading that Isaac was 26 years old at the time of the 'Akkeidah and Rivka was married at age 14 as the original Babylonian text. This is also the opinion of C.J. Milikowski."

To answer the question:

Opinion 1 (French manuscripts of Seder Olam Rabba according to Rashi). Rivka was born at the time of Akkeida which was also the time of Sarah's death. She was 3 years old when she married Yitzchak, who was 40 at the time of the marriage. Abraham was 137 years at the time of Akkeidah, since he was 100 when Yitzchak was born.

Opinion 2 (Oriental-Sephardic manuscripts of Seder Olam Rabba). Rivka was born at the time of Akkeida. Rivka was 14 when she married Yitzchak. Thus, she was born 11 years prior to Sarah's death. In other words, Yitzchak was 26 years old at the time of the Akkeidah and Abraham was 126 years old then. Sarah imeinu died 11 years later.

The opinion that Sarah died because of the Akkeidah comes from a later Rabbi Yose (Bereshis Rabba 58:5). There is a manuscript of Seder Olam stating that "Our father Yitzchak was 26 years old when he was bound to the altar." This reading was also proposed by the Vilna Gaon.

Opinion 3. Sifri Devarim as explained by Rebbi Eliezer ben Nathan of Mayence and Rebbi Sh'muel (ben Kalonymos) the Pious of Speyer. Rivka was born 11 years prior to the time of Akkeida, which also was the time of Sarah's death. Rivka was 14 when she married Yitzchak, who was 40 at the time of the marriage. Abraham was 137 years at the time of Akkeidah, since he was 100 when Yitzchak was born. Thus, he was 126 years old when Rivka was born.

I also heard that there could be a reconciliation between all these opinions based on mysticism (most likely source Or haChaim, but I did not see it there). As we know, Sarah, mother of Yitzchak died 3 years prior to Rivka's marriage. Perhaps, a part of Sarah's soul at that time was given to Rivkah. Thus, one can say that as Rivkalah, daughter of Bethuel haArami, she was 14 when she married Yitzchak. However, as a girl with potential of Rivka imeinu she was only 3 or 4 years.

title: Where does Jewish Oral Tradition address the duration of the enslavement of Israel in Egypt?
content:
# Where does Jewish Oral Tradition address the duration of the enslavement of Israel in Egypt? ## Frage

In an answer on Biblical Hermeneutics Stack Exchange addressing the duration of Israel's enslavement in Egypt, user conceptualinertia writes,

Gal[atians] 3:16-17 [a reference to a passage in the Christian New Testament] is line with the Oral Tradition (that Orthodox Jews believe provides authoritative interpretation of the Old Testament). Abraham is told that his children will sojourn in "a land that is is not their own" for 400 years (Genesis 15:13). Egypt is not specified and neither is it clear that the suffering and enslavement would last the full 400 years (in the cantorial notes there is full stop, which functions like a semi-colon) before the words "400 years"). The Jewish tradition understands the 400 years to begin with the birth of Isaac who was always a sojourner, moving from place to place and never governing land.

Which sources in the Jewish Oral Tradition discuss relation between 400 years and the duration of the Egyptian exile?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The primary source for these calculations is Midrash Seder Olam Rabba, chapter 3. Unfortunately the translation on Sefaria is wrong:

It was said to our forefather Abraham at the Covenant Between the Pieces (Gen. 15:13): "You shall certainly know that your seed will be strangers in a foreign land for 400 years." Who is the seed? That is Isaac, of whom it is said (Gen. 21:12): "Because Isaac will be called seed for you." About Isaac it says (Gen. 25:26): "Isaac was 60 years of age when they were born." Our forefather Jacob said to Pharaoh (Gen. 47:9): "The days of the years of my wandering are 130 years". This makes together 190 years, this leaves 210 years, a sign for the lifetime of Job who was born at that time as it is said (Job 42:16): "Job lived thereafter 140 years" and it is said (Job 42:10): "The Eternal added double to all that Job had". It turns out that Job was born when Israel descended to Egypt and he died when they left.

Or maybe that Israel was in Egypt the full 400 years? But Kehat was among those who entered Egypt (Gen. 46:11) and it is written (Ex. 6:18): "the years of the life of Kehat were 133 years," (Ex. 6:20) "the years of the life of Amram 137 years." Together with 80 years of Moses this makes 350 years. What does Scripture teach us in the verse (Gen. 15:13) "they will enslave them and mistreat them for 400 years" that all the time they spent in a land that was not theirs adds up to 400 years; "they will enslave them" (these are the years of slavery) "and mistreat them" (these are the years of deprivation) and all of them together add up to 400 years.

The commentary provides futher details as to how these numbers are reconciled between different texts. It can also be added to the answer.

title: How would Jews observe Shabbat on a 20-hour planet?
content:
# How would Jews observe Shabbat on a 20-hour planet? ## Frage

I'm writing a sci fi novel in which the main character finds a Jewish community living on a planet he explores. The planet has a 20 hour day and takes around 520 days to orbit the sun. How would Shabbat happen in that case? I'm guessing the Jewish calendar itself would remain unchanged in terms of the chagim. But what about Shabbat? Would Jews observe the 'full' day of Shabbat or just the 20 hours?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

When on a planet in space, you must prorate the length of the day or the year. Rabbi Azriel Rosenfeld says: "On Mars, a “day” is 24 hours and 39 minutes in earth time and a “year” is 687 days in earth time, so you must modify observance of the calendar accordingly."

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

To clarify the point of Maurice Mizrahi, think of the rotation of your planet around the Sun to be occurring at the same angle and in the same plane as the Earth. The seasons would be determined by the angles at which the seasons change on Earth. The same should go for days. However, to correct with the Earth's calendar, you will have to introduce a double Shabbat (or double Yom tov) at some points to synchronize.

title: Why is תא שמע used for both Attempted Challenges & Proofs?
content:
# Why is תא שמע used for both Attempted Challenges & Proofs? ## Frage

Why does the Gemara use תא שמע for both Attempted Challenges & Attempted Proofs?
It can get especially confusing.

Take Bava Basra 94b-95a for example, which is discussing Rav Huna of the previous Amud:

  • 1st תא שמע is Attempted Challenge
  • 2nd is Attempted Proof
  • 3rd is Attempted Proof
  • 4th is Attempted Challenge
  • 5th is Attempted Proof
  • 6th is Attempted Proof
  • 7th is Attempted Proof

While obviously one can use logic to figure out which one it is,
my question is why is there no specific term for each?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

According to "Talmudic Terminology" by R. Nosson Dovid Rabinowich the expression תא שמע can have 3 different uses:

  1. To show that a Memra, a reported teaching, opinion or decision of the Amoraim, is in conflict with a Mishna or Baraisa (i.e. a Tannaic statement).
  2. To provide a solution to a problem בעיה.
  3. To introduce an argument or difficulty.

The reason, why there are such different uses, is explained in the Practical Talmudic Dictionary by R. Yitzchak Frank: the expression תא שמע introduces a mishna, a baraitha, a pasuk, or an early amora's statement or practice that is quoted. The usage of the quote itself can serve a a proof for the opinion of an amora, or as a resolution to a problem, or as a basis for argument or difficulty.

According to both R. Frank and R. Rabinowich, as a refutation תא שמע slightly differs from מיתיבי. The word מיתיבי is only used synonymosly to introduce a refutation (תיובתא) of an amoraic statement based on higher authority of undisputed Mishna or Baraitha. Thus it does not have a flavor of a possibility that an argument may continue. I.e. מיתיבי is a more certain clause, while תא שמע leaves open the possibility that a discussion will continue.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

In plain translation, it means "come and hear". It invites the reader to compare the coming cites and see if it brings proof to the question posed one way or another. It is part of the "shakla V'tarya" way of teaching that the Gemara is famous for. Literally, it means "taking and throwing". It invites scrutiny, examination, discourse, questions and answers, splitting hairs, finding distinctions, finding supporting analogies, etc. That way of thinking has been admired by the non Talmudic world as being responsible for Jewish brains, acumen, and overall "out of the box" thinking.

title: Commentary on the Vidui
content:
# Commentary on the Vidui ## Frage

Are there any classical commentaries on the Vidui (short and long)? I see explanations in the Koren and Artscroll, but those are mostly modern.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Siddur Torat Ḥayyim by Mosad HaRav Kook is a good place to look for several Rishonic commentaries on the long viduy. The second volume contains a line-by-line commentary by Abudarham and the Rokeaḥ, along with sporadic comments from Ra'avan, Sefer HaManhig, and R. Yehudah ibn Yakar.

It seems that the Abudarham's commentary can be found on Sefaria here, but I don't know its completeness/accuracy.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Two ones I know of are:

The Chida has a breakdown on each of the words in his Sefer Vidui Gadol

In Chapter 143 of the Chayei Adam there is a famous commentary - again there is an explanation for each word/individual part.

title: Did the Arizal's daughter marry the son of R' Yosef Karo?
content:
# Did the Arizal's daughter marry the son of R' Yosef Karo? ## Frage

Is there any source [historical, academic, mystical] that the Arizal's daughter married the son of R' Yosef Karo, author of Shulchan Aruch?

I see this mentioned in this article (unsourced), and noticed a similar claim on this forum (citing a story about the shidduch to 'Shivchei Ari' - I couldn't find this in a OCR search of Shivchei Ari).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The source for this legend is toward the end of Shivhei HaAri, by R. Shlomo Shlomil Ben Chaim. There, R. Shlomil writes the following story:

ואני הצעיר שלמה מעיד שדברתי עם אלמנותו של רי"ק ז"ל וסיפרה לי שמהררי"ק היה לו בן נחמד ושידך אותו עם בתו של האריז״ל והלך מהררי״ק עם בנו לסעודת אירוסין לביתו של האריז״ל כיון שחזר לביתו אמר מהררי״ק לאשתו אשתי אשתי מה אומר לך או מה אספר מהרזים ומהטעמי התורה והמצוה מה ידיעה הרווחתי עתה בזה הסעודה מפי הקדוש של ר׳ יצחק אשכנזי היכן הוא כח ביד שום מלאך לידע מה שיודע הוא אין זה כי אם נשמה אחת מהנביאים הראשונים שאפילו תנא אחר אינו יכול לומר מה שאמר הוא אבל אני מפחד עליו בעו״ה מאור שזה הדור הגרוע לא יכול לסבול רוב קדושתו ויוקח ויאבד מהם בקוצר שנים בעונות וכן היה

And I, the young Shlomo, testify that I spoke with Rav Yosef Karo's widow and she told me that Rav Karo had a fine son and matched him with the daughter of the Arizal. And it went, that after Rav Karo went with his son to the engagement meal at the Arizal's house he returned to his home and Rav Karo said to his wife: "My wife, my wife, what can I say or tell you of the mysteries of the Torah and Mitzvot? How much knowledge have I now gained during this feast from the holy mouth of R. Yitzchak Ashkenazi [Luria]. He holds knowledge beyond what any angel knows, and there's no doubt he has the soul of one of the early prophets. Even a Tanna could not teach what he taught. But I am afraid for him. It is clear that this is the worst generation, which cannot tolerate his holiness, and he will be taken away and lost to them at an early age." And so it was.

Does this mean their children indeed married? It's hard to know. R. Shlomil came to Tzfat some 30 years after the Arizal died, and his book mixes verifiable historical information with many folkloric legends about the miracles and powers of the Arizal. So take it with a grain of salt.

That the Arizal and R. Yosef Karo knew each other is undisputed, as we have a teshuva from R. Karo, answering a question posed by the Arizal on the halakha of a business after a partner dies (cf. Avkat Rokhel #136).

title: Does Tzovei'ah apply to Dichromatism?
content:
# Does Tzovei'ah apply to Dichromatism? ## Frage

Dichromatism is when a material's hue changes with its concentration and thickness.

For example, pumpkin seed oil changes color based on how much of the liquid is present. And ground-up green leaves in alcohol (ethanol or isopropyl) display a red spot when shined at with a flashlight, while the rest of the liquid appears green (based on the mixture ratio).

Would it be Rabbinically forbidden to cause a dichromatic solution to have light cast on it on Shabbos, since it's changing the colors? Is handling pumpkin seed oil considered Tzovei'ah?

Note the flashlight shining on the solution, which causes a red spot to appear amidst the green:

Pumpkin seed oil exhibiting dichromatism:

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

R Ovadia Yosef, who required sunglasses for everyday use, ruled that Transition Lenses are fine on Shabbat. Only actual pigments are problematic. These tricks of the light aren't an issue.

https://halachayomit.co.il/en/default.aspx?HalachaID=3384

(There’s a mistake in the link’s fifth paragraph; ignore the word “whatsoever").

title: Sochatchov on renewing the soul with the Shofar
content:
# Sochatchov on renewing the soul with the Shofar ## Frage

In the sefer Eretz Tzvi, by Rabbi Aryeh Tzvi Frumer it says (Eretz Tzvi, Moadim, Newer Version, Vol. 2, p, 48):

ויש לומר הענין בזה לפי מה ששמעתי מאדמו"ר הזקן זצוקלה"ה מסוכטשוב דע"י שופר מתעורר הכוח מהא דכתיב (בראשית ב' ז'): ויפח באפיו נשמת חיים, אז יש התחדשות הבריאה עכד"ק.

"We can explain this according to what I heard from the elder Rebbe of Sochatchov, of blessed memory, that through the shofar, the power of what is written (Genesis 2:7): 'He breathed into his nostrils the breath of life,' is awakened, and then the creation is renewed — thus spoke the holy elder."

Does someone know where to find this in the works of Sochatchov? I heard it is from the Avnei Nezer, but I am not sure. Rav Daniel Glatstein shlita mentions the Avnei Nezer, and that he quotes from the Zohar, that says that when the posuk says "He breathed into his nostrils the breath of life", it is "Baal Tokea". But I don't know where to find this, and if this is the same as what the Eretz Tzvi quotes.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Shem MiShmuel (son of the Avnei Nezer) Ki Savo 11:

וי"ל שרמז יש בזה לר"ה שבזוה"ק ויהי היום רומז לר"ה, והיינו עפי"מ שהגיד כ"ק אבי אדמו"ר זצללה"ה שזה היום זכרון ליום ראשון שכתוב ויפח באפיו נשמת חיים, כן בכל ר"ה נותנים לאדם חיים חדשים מלובשים בקול השופר

He repeats this idea in several other places. A search in Sefaria with the words ויפח באפיו filtered to Shem MiShmuel should give you an extensive list of the many times he discusses it.

title: Rav Chaim Volozhin - being moser nefesh for teshuva
content:
# Rav Chaim Volozhin - being moser nefesh for teshuva ## Frage

In the Shabbos Shuva drasha printed at the end of Ruach Chaim, Rav Chaim Volozhiner, says one must be moser nefesh for teshuva. His source is from the posuk:

וְשַׁבְתָּ עַד ה’ אֱלֹקיךָ כו’ בְּכָל לְבָבְךָ וּבְכָל נַפְשֶׁךָ

And you return to your G-d...with all your heart and with your soul (Devarim 30:2)

His proof to this is from the Gemara in Avodah Zara 17a which tells us about Rebbi Elazar ben Durdaya who was a big baal aveirah to the point that he wasn’t able to do teshuva. Once he realized this, he said, “אין הדבר תלוי אלא בי” — “It all depends on me — the responsibility is totally mine!” He then put his head between his knees and cried until he died after which a bas kol (heavenly voice) emerged from shamayim and declared, “Rebbi Elazer ben Durdaya is worthy of Olam Habbah.”

The question is that we only find one has to be moser nefesh for the big three; idol worship, immorality and murder (Mishneh Torah - Yesodei HaTorah 5:2), so how can Rav Chaim Volozhiner now add in teshuva as well?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

There's another example of this, in regards to learning Torah. In Brachos 61b, we find:

The Rabbis taught: One time the Evil Empire decreed that the Jews may not learn Torah. Papus ben Yehudah found Rabbi Akiva teaching Torah to large crowds. He asked him: Akiva, aren't you frightened of the Empire? Rabbi Akiva responded: I will provide you a parable. One time there was a fox walking alongside a river, and he saw fishes swimming from one spot to another. He asked them: What are you fleeing? And they answered: We flee the fishermen and their nets! Responded the fox: Do you want to come up on the dry land and live together with me, as my ancestors and your ancestors once dwelt together? Answered the fishes: Are you the one that I call the cleverest of all beasts? You are not clever--you are a fool! In the place where we can live we are afraid, in the place where we must die how much more so! The same is true of us. We sit and learn Torah, about which the verse says 'For it is your life and the length of your days' and we are afraid--if we would stop learning Torah, how much more so! They said: Not much later, they arrested Rabbi Akiva and imprisoned him, and they arrested Papus ben Yehuda and imprisoned him together with Rabbi Akiva. He said: Papus, who brought you here? He responded: How fortunate are you, Akiva, that you wre seized for the sake of Torah--and woe to Papup, who was seized for the sake of worthless things. When they took Rabbi Akiva out to execute him, it was the time of Krias Shema, and they were scraping off his flesh with iron scrapers, and he recited Krias Shema and accepted Hashem's Kingdom. His disciples asked him: Our teacher, how can you be so focused? He responded: All my life I was worried about the verse of "And with all your soul," meaning "even if He takes your soul." Now that it has come to me, shall I not fulfill it? He extended his recitation of the word "One," and his soul left him as he pronounced it. A Heavenly Voice declared: You are fortunate, Rabbi Akiva, and you are invited to the life of the World to Come!

How was Rabbi Akiva allowed to give up his life for the sake of Torah? Notice that he does not argue that it is a time of shemad, and then one must give up his life for any mitzvah; he provides a lengthy parable to emphasize the uniqueness of Torah.

I would suggest to you that when it comes to a one-off sin, even the most terrible, the sinner can potentially rebuild his connection to Hashem afterwards. Even if he committed idolatry, arayos, or murder, he can come close again afterwards. Therefore, with regards to those issurim, I could well have thought that one should not give his life rather than transgress.

However, if we stop learning Torah, there is no possibility of having any connection to Hashem. And if we cannot do Teshuva, there is no possibility of any connection to Hashem. Therefore, when it comes to these mitzvos, it is obvious that one must pay any price in order to fulfill them, up to an including giving his life.

Brachos 61b

# Looking for the source of a drasha ## Frage

In the book “Between Cross and Crescent” the author cites a midrash which apparently says: “God revealed himself in four languages: Hebrew, Latin, Arabic and Aramaic”

apparently in reference to v'Zot haBerachah pasuk 2 but the author does not cite his source.

"דבר אחר כשנגלה הקדוש ברוך הוא ליתן תורה לישראל לא בלשון אחד אמר להם אלא בארבעה לשונות שנאמר ויאמר ה' מסיני בא זה לשון עברי וזרח משעיר למו זה לשון רומי הופיע מהר פארן זה לשון ערבי ואתה מרבבות קדש זה לשון ארמי."

title: Kiddush Cup Minhag pertaining to the woman of the house
content:
# Kiddush Cup Minhag pertaining to the woman of the house ## Frage

I'm not sure where this minhag originates from but I have frequented a Breslover maggids house frequently for shabbos and I noticed that whenever he made kiddush he would always pour from the cup into other cups to distribute and always handed the kiddush cup to the woman of the house. I do not believe he ever drinks from the bekher himself.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Minhag Breslev is to recite kiddish over a koss containing 3 revyisn of wine and drink one revyis on Friday night leaving the (covered) koss with the remaining two revyisn on the table for Shabess (one revyis for the morning kiddish and one for the havduleh). Some use smaller cups each time. Mind that the mekadesh must drink from the koss, unless he has some health issues or be a nozir, in which case he may delegate his kiddish wine to someone who heard his kiddish, provided they are above 6 years of age.

As for women you might like to check out Magen Avruhom on S"A O"Ch 271. Specifically, in 271:2 he states: "Women are obligated in Kiddush, even though it is a positive commandment that time causes, because זכור is compared to שמור. And these women, since they are included in שמירה, they are included in זכירה. And they can discharge men (from their obligation) since they are obligated מן התורה like them." This probably refers to those women who haven't prayed mayrev, which might be the case.

I'm not sure if the ownership of the koss makes any difference for the established custom. So, probably, your maggid knows that in terms of kabboleh the koss represents Malchess (while wine is Daas) and the woman is also Malchess (while the man is Zayr Anpin), so it seems like a very weird zivveg? But this is not minhag Breslev.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

I don’t think this has so much to do with a Chassidic minhag but rather Halacha.

If the one making kiddish drinks from the kiddish cup, it’s becomes pagum and so someone else can’t drink from it an be yotzei Kiddush (according to all opinions) in the best possible way without “fixing” the kos (by adding more wine). This is because strictly speaking, a person only needs to listen to kiddish to be yotzei Kiddush but there are opinions that state to be “makom kiddish” one has to eat or drink something and by drinking from the Kiddush wine one makes a better connection with the meal that is about to follow.

This is the relevant Halacha regarding pagum

שולחן ערוך הרב אורח חיים סימן קפ״ב

סעיף ד׳

"כוס של ברכה צריך שלא יהא פגום, ובא שנתן מימיה וישתה ממנה — פגום. ואפילו לא הביא אליו את פיו אלא שפך לתוך פיו. אבל אם שפך ממנו לתוך ידו או לתוך כלי ושתה — אין בכך כלום."

סעיף ה׳

"כוס פגום יכולים לתקנו על ידי שיוסיפו עליה מעט יין, … וכך מתקן."

title: Carpet pages from Leningrad Codex
content:
# Carpet pages from Leningrad Codex ## Frage

The editions of Lenigrad Codex have the following picture on its cover:

The photograph was taken by Bruce and Kenneth Zuckerman, West Semitic Research, in collaboration with the Ancient Biblical Manuscripts Center. Courtesy Russian National Library (Saltykov-Schedrin).

There is small handwritten text which creates lines and words in the picture. Does anyone know what it says? Although it looks like a picture from the back of Leningrad Codex, is it possible to find out from which manuscript was it taken?

The wikipedia page for Leningrad Codex does not have the above cover page. Instead it gives the following cover:

It also has a very intricate design. I am also curious about the contents of this cover as well.

Where can one get information about both covers? Do we know the artisan?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Interesting question. As it turns out, a PhD dissertation was written on these pages and the other illustrated pages of the Leningrad Codex, and is open-access on ProQuest: S. L. Schmidt, 'The Carpet Illuminations of Codex Leningrad National Library of Russia Ms. Evr. I B 19a', University of the Holy Land 2019.

It seems that none of these pages are cover pages per se, but are found at the end of the manuscript. These sorts of pages are defined as "carpet pages" because they resemble elaborate carpets (think especially oriental-type carpets).

The first one you ask about is folio 478r (r = recto, the front or right side of a page; v = verso, the back or left side of a page), discussed on pp. 267-278, with a table of the verses on this page appearing in pp. 270-277. Schmidt also included an artistic discussion of the page, suggesting that the page represents

"a visual construct of the idea of God occupying the heavens above. Israel occupies the earthly realm in the lower half of the folium and the arcade of the Temple, with the messianic hope for the believer who obeys and goes up for pilgrimage on the Feasts."

The second page you ask about, folio 474r, is discussed on pp. 159-173. This page features a dedicatory colophon in the center, including the name of the scribe - who is also the artist, Shmuel ben Yaakov - and masoretic notes and verses around, listed in pp. 161-173.

It should be noted that both pages, as well as other pages, are discussed in other chapters of the dissertation, besides the above-referenced pages, which are part of a section of the work that discusses each page by itself. So it would likely be worthwhile for you to read or at least skim the entire work, to gain a better understanding of these pages.

title: Chazan's repetitions for verses right after opening the Ark for the Torah
content:
# Chazan's repetitions for verses right after opening the Ark for the Torah ## Frage

After opening Ark to get sefer Torah on Shabbos and Yom Tov in Ashkenazy custom many congregations sing verses:

כִּי מִצִּיּון תֵּצֵא תורָה. וּדְבַר ה' מִירוּשָׁלָיִם: בָּרוּךְ שֶׁנָּתַן תּורָה לְעַמּו יִשרָאֵל בִּקְדֻשָּׁתו:

What is a reason for a double repetition of phrases: כִּי מִצִּיּון תֵּצֵא תורָה and בָּרוּךְ שֶׁנָּתַן תּורָה, i.e. what was the intention of the composer of the tune?

The fact that the word תּורָה is repeated as תּורָה-תּורָה when singing בָּרוּךְ שֶׁנָּתַן sounds as if it refers to both written and oral Torah in opposition to Reform not accepting the oral Torah. Why would some chazanim avoid making these repetitions?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

There are many melodies written for the paragraph beginning "Vay'hi Binsoa", but by far the most common one is by Salomon Sulzer. Interestingly, his setting is in his Yom Tov section of his book; he has a different Shabbat setting that no one uses.

He does indeed repeat the phrase כִּי מִצִּיּון תֵּצֵא תורָה twice. It's hard to infer exactly what his intent was here, but suffice to say it is a classic example of a sequence ascending by a tone, which is a typical compositional technique, and is pleasing to the ear as we recognise what we've already heard.

But Sulzer's melody stops at "Mirushalayim" and does not have anything written for בָּרוּךְ שֶׁנָּתַן תּורָה. So what you hear in North American congregations where the same melody from כִּי מִצִּיּון is applied to this verse is a later adaptation that Sulzer never wrote. I have heard some Rabbis and Chazzanim are opposed to this repetition of the word Torah for theological reasons, but know that it was never part of the original composition.

Outside of North America, it is more common to attach on a different, rising ending for בָּרוּךְ שֶׁנָּתַן תּורָה which actually comes from an earlier traditional melody. You can hear that full composition here: https://youtu.be/mGm22rCCnIA?si=8gghQvz_LrNhVZwM

title: Hadran for Tanach?
content:
# Hadran for Tanach? ## Frage

Is there a hadran recitation to be said upon the completion of learning all of Tanach?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Here's one version:

הדרן עלך עשרים וארבעה ספרי התנ"ך דעתן עלך ודעתך עלן עשרים וארבעה ספרי התנ"ך. לא נתנשא מנך ולא תתנשא מנן לא בעלמא הדן ולא בעלמא דאתי.

ויהי רצון מלפניך ה' אלוקינו ואלקי אבותינו אשר בחר בנביאים טובים ורצה בדבריהם הנאמרים באמת שבזכות ספרי התנ"ך ממקראי קודש ובזכות פסוקיהם ותיבותיהם ואותיותיהם ונקודותיהם וטעמיהם ושמות הקדושים היוצאים מהם, ובזכות נביאי האמת, שופטי ישראל, וצדיקי הדורות המוזכרים בספרי התנ"ך נזכה להיות נועם ה' אלוקינו עלינו ומעשה ידינו כוננה עלינו ומעשה ידינו כוננהו, להיות זוכים היום ביום חתונתנו וביום שמחת לבנו. לעורר אם הבנים שמחה וליחד סוד תורה שבכתב עם סוד תורה שבעל פה ביחודא שלים באהבה ואחוה וריעות. הא-ל הנאמן בכל דבריו ימשיך עלינו שפע אור החיים לנפש, רוח ונשמה, להאריך ימינו בטוב וביראת ה' כל הימים. והערב נא ה' אלוקינו את דברי תורתך בפינו ובפי עמך בית ישראל, ונהיה אנחנו וצאצאינו וצאצאי צאצאינו וצאצאי עמך בית ישראל כולנו יודעי שמך ולומדי תורתך לשמה. ונשמח ונעלוז בדברי תלמוד תורתך ובמצותיך ובחוקותיך לעולם ועד. כי הם חיינו ואורך ימינו ובהם נהגה יומם ולילה. יהי ה' אלוקינו עמנו כאשר היה עם אבותינו, אל יעזבנו ואל יטשנו להיטיב לבבנו אליו, ללכת בכל דרכיו ולשמור מצותיו וחוקותיו ומשפטיו אשר צוה את אבותינו.

ויהי רצון מלפניך ה' אלקינו ואלקי אבותינו שכשם שעזרתנו לסיים עשרים וארבעה ספרי התנ"ך ממקראי קודש כן תעזרנו להמשיך ללמוד ספרים מתורה שבכתב ומתורה שבעל פה ולסיימם, ללמוד וללמד, לשמור לעשות ולקיים את כל דברי תלמוד תורתך באהבה. ותפתח לבבנו הערל בסודות תורתך הקדושה, ותאציל עלינו אור מקור נשמותינו בכל בחינותינו, ושיתנוצצו ניצוצי אבינו רועה משה רבנו ע"ה אשר על ידו גלית עמקי סודי תורתך. וזכותו וזכות כל נביאי ישראל הקדושים וספריהם וקדושתם יעמדו לנו שלא נכשל לעולם ועד, מתט אשורינו מתורתך הקדושה ח"ו, ולהיות דבריהם נאמנים ונחמדים, חיים וקיימים לעד ולעולמי עולמים עלינו ועל בנינו ועל דורותינו ועל כל דורות זרע ישראל עבדיך, על הראשונים ועל האחרונים דבר טוב וקיים באמת ובאמונה, חוק ולא יעבור. ונזכה ונחיה ונראה ונירש טובה וברכה לחיי העולם הבא. ובזכות התורה הקדושה שבכתב ושבע"פ הושיענו ה' אלוקינו וקבצנו מן הגוים, ומלוך על כל העולם כולו בכבודך והנשא על כל הארץ ביקרך. והשפיע עלינו אור ישועה ורחמים ממעייני הישועה.

אמן כן יהי רצון. יהיו לרצון אמרי פי והגיון לבי לפניך ה' צורי וגואלי.

title: What does Bereshit Rabbah mean when it says the Scriptures spoke untruths?
content:
# What does Bereshit Rabbah mean when it says the Scriptures spoke untruths? ## Frage

As far as I can tell Bereshit Rabbah 48:18 says that G-d actually repeated everything Sarah said to Abraham including that he was old, but the Torah falsely says that G-d only told Abraham that Sarah said that she was old in order to avoid strife between Abraham and Sarah. How does this fit with the belief that the scriptures are inerrant, especially since this passage seems to make perfect sense with its plain meaning?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

You misunderstand the text. Let's take a look.

“The Lord said to Abraham: Why is it that Sarah laughed, saying: Shall I indeed bear a child, and I have grown old?” (Genesis 18:13). “The Lord said to Abraham: Why is it that Sarah laughed, saying: [Shall I indeed bear a child, and I have grown old?]” – bar Kappara said: Peace [between spouses] is a great thing, as even Scripture spoke untruths in order to establish peace between Abraham and Sarah. “Sarah laughed to herself, saying: After my languishing, shall I have youth, and my husband is old?” But He did not say this to Abraham, but rather, “Why is it that Sarah laughed, saying: Shall I indeed bear a child, and I have grown old?” The verse does not say as Sarah said: “My husband is old,” but rather, “I have grown old.”

The Medrash notes that Hashem deliberately misreported Sarah's comments to Avraham. Whereas she had commented that her husband, Avraham, was old, Hashem told Avraham that she had said that she herself was old. This was not an error on His part, nor an error on the part of the Torah as to what He said. He said this, and He said it intentionally. The purpose was to uphold marital peace between Avraham and Sarah, as Avraham might feel offended if he heard that his wife regarded him as elderly.

Again, when Sarah heard that she would yet have a child, she said "How can this be? My husband is too old."

When Hashem discussed this with Avraham, He said that Sarah had said "How can this be? I am too old."

Chazal note the discrepancy, and explain that Hashem is here teaching us that it is correct behavior to tell "white lies" in order to maintain peace between people, particularly between married couples.

title: Connection Between Shechem and Yitro? (and Amalek)

# Connection Between Shechem and Yitro? (and Amalek) ## Frage

When Saul goes to war against Amalek, he tells the Kenites to withdraw from among the Amalekites (1 Samuel 15:6).

In Josephus's Antiquities, it is David who gives this warning when he is attacking the Amalekites who sacked Ziklag, however, "Shechemites" is used in place of Kenites.

Linking the two versions, is a one sentence mention of one of the Judges.

And Abdon the son of Hillel the Pirathonite died, and was buried in Pirathon, in the land of Ephraim, in the mountain of the Amalekites.

So Jethro's people are adjacent to the Amalekites and the verse from Judges confirms that there were Amalekites in the region of Ephraim, which contains Shechem.

Are there any Rabbinic sources confirming a connection between Jethro and Shechem?

title: Source of Chofetz Chaim’s Statement on Every Nation Having Translated Bibles and Believing in the Revelation at Mount Sina
content:
# Source of Chofetz Chaim’s Statement on Every Nation Having Translated Bibles and Believing in the Revelation at Mount Sina ## Frage

In the Sefer Taharas Yisroel (chapter 1), the Chofetz Chaim claims that all nations (in his time) believed in the revelation at Mount Sinai recorded in the Bible and had copies of the Bible in their own language.

The phrase "all nations on earth from one end to the other" suggests that he was referring to every nation without exception. Furthermore, the chapter's context suggests that he refers to every nation. He aims to highlight the utter foolishness of those who reject the Torah, as all nations accept its story. His argument loses much of its force if the Bible is acknowledged solely by Christianity and Islam rather than universally.

What is the source of this?

I find it hard to believe that Hindus, Buddhists, and all the Indigenous peoples of Africa, South America, and Australia had copies of the Bible, let alone believe it.

He does cite a verse in Parshas Nitzavim which states that all nations will acknowledge Israel's suffering as a consequence of abandoning their covenant with God. However, employing this as evidence to discredit Torah skeptics is circular reasoning. It claims they are foolish for disputing something supposedly recognized by all nations, yet the sole claim to its universal acknowledgment is the Torah itself.

title: (When) is it an aveirah to NOT do a mitzvas asei?
content:
# (When) is it an aveirah to NOT do a mitzvas asei? ## Frage

I have heard conflicting opinions about not doing a mitzvas asei. Some seem to hold that one just misses out by not doing one, while others seem to class it as an aveirah to not do the mitzvah. Given that there are always mitvos asei that you could be doing, should we always be using any idle time to do so? It seems an impossible ideal for most people (and probably bad for the most people’s mental health).

As men, we put a lot of emphasis on time-bound mitzvos asei. Not wearing tzitzis, not putting on tefillin, not hearing the shofar on Rosh Hashanah would all be considered a big deal, but would that actually be an aveirah?

Does this depend on how much effort would be required to do the mitzvah? e.g. hearing the shofar on Rosh Hashanah is a lot easier for me than shiluach hakan. Am I obligated to go out and find an appropriate mother bird that I can send away to take the eggs too so that I have done that mitzvah? If so, how often must I do it?

EDIT: nb. for the purposes of this question, I'm defining aveiros as things that we receive punishment for (unless we do teshuva).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

There are different types of mitzot asei. To quote the Sefer HaChinuch in his introduction:

וּמִן הַמִּצְוֹת אֵלּוּ יֵשׁ שֶׁאָדָם חַיָּב בָּהֶם לָקוּם לַעֲשׂוֹתָן בְּהַתְמָדָה, כְּגוֹן מִצְוַת אַהֲבַת הַשֵּׁם וְיִרְאָתוֹ וְכַיּוֹצֵא בָּהּ. וְיֵשׁ שֶׁחַיָּב לָקוּם וְלַעֲשׂוֹתָן בִּזְמַן יָדוּעַ וְלֹא קֹדֶם לָכֵן, כְּגוֹן מִצְוַת סֻכָּה וְלוּלָב וְשׁוֹפָר וּשְׁבִיתַת מוֹעֲדִים וּקְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וְכָל כַּיּוֹצֵא בָּהֶם, שֶׁיֵּשׁ לָהֶם זְמַן קָבוּעַ לַעֲשׂוֹתָן בַּשָּׁנָה אוֹ בַּיּוֹם. וְיֵשׁ מֵהֶן שֶׁאֵין אָדָם חַיָּב לַעֲשׂוֹתָן לְעוֹלָם אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן תִּהְיֶה סִבָּה שֶׁתָּבֹא לְיָדוֹ עִנְיָן שֶׁיִּצְטָרֵךְ לַעֲשׂוֹת בּוֹ אוֹתָהּ מִצְוָה הָרְאוּיָה לְאוֹתוֹ עִנְיָן, כְּאִלּוּ תֹּאמַר שֶׁנְּתִינַת שְׂכַר שָׂכִיר בִּזְמַנּוֹ מִצְוָה אַחַת, וּבְוַדַּאי אֵין אָדָם חַיָּב לִשְׂכֹּר פּוֹעֲלִים כְּדֵי לְקַיֵּם מִצְוָה זוֹ. וְכֵן קְצָת כַּיּוֹצֵא בָּהּ

And among the commandments, there are those that a person is obligated to do constantly, such as the commandment of loving God, and fearing Him, and that which is similar to it. And there are some that he is obligated to do at a specific time and not before then — such as the commandment of sukkah (dwelling in a hut), lulav, resting on the holidays, recitation of Shema and all that is similar to them — that have a set time to do them in the year or in the day. And there are some of them that a person is never obligated to do unless he is caused by a matter that comes to his hand that requires that commandment that is fitting for that matter. Such that you can say that giving the wage of a wageworker in its time is a commandment, while a man is certainly not obligated to hire workers in order to fulfill this commandment. And so [too,] some that are like this

So of the mitzvot asei you mention in your question, skipping tefillin or shofar would mean that you didn't do what you were supposed to do. Whereas, one is under no obligation to don a four-cornered garment (at least in theory) in order to put tzitzit on it, nor is one obliged to seek mother birds in order to send them away. Sefer HaChinuch in his discussion of each mitzvah tells you into which category a particular mitzvah falls.

If someone fails to perform a mitzvat asei that he is obligated to do (whether we're talking about something completely obligatory like shofar, or a person who puts on a a four-cornered garment and so is now obligated to attach tzitzit) it seems clear that such a person has committed "an aveirah" and would be liable to receive heavenly punishment.

For example, see Yoma 86a:

עָבַר עַל עֲשֵׂה וְשָׁב — אֵינוֹ זָז מִשָּׁם עַד שֶׁמּוֹחֲלִין לוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שׁוּבוּ בָּנִים שׁוֹבָבִים״

If one violates a positive mitzva and repents, he is forgiven even before he moves from his place, i.e. immediately, as it is stated: “Return, you backsliding children"

which certainly sounds like he can expect some form of punishment if he does not repent (or at the very least has done something wrong which needs atonement).

Possibly even more instructive, in terms of the terminology you are using, is Rashi's comment there, in reference to mitzvat asei (my emphases):

למדת שיש עבירה שמכפרת בתשובה לבדה

Thus, there is an aveirah for which teshuvah alone atones.

Finally, in the context of your statement that "there are always mitvos asei that you could be doing", it's worth noting that the Sefer HaChinuch in his epistle lists precisely four mitzvot asei (along with two mitzvot lo taaseh) that are incumbent upon us at all times, namely:

  • to believe in God
  • to conceive of His oneness
  • to love Him
  • to fear Him
### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

Just to expand on Joel K's excellent answer...

There are essentially 5 categories of Mitzvot Asei:

  • "Issur Asei" - a sin which has been phrased in the Torah as a positive action, yet reflects a prohibition (as understood by Chaza"l). For example, Leviticus 21:13 - a Kohen Gadol must marry a virgin is understood as a prohibition to marry a non-virgin.

(Eating outside the Sukka on Sukkot may be another example. Wearing a four-cornered garment without tzitit too, but this is similarly subject to dispute. see Tosafot Yevamot 90b, s.v. Kulhu)

  • A Once-per-lifetime Asei - For example, brit milah. (There is a debate (Rambam/Ra'avad) if this Asei is transgressed retroactively at death, or if the transgressor lives in sin until he has circumcision, at which point the transgression is absolved.) Another example is P'ru U'rvu, where if one's children die, Ch"V, before them, they have not fulfilled the mitzva.
  • A Time-or-situation-bound Asei - A Mitzvah with a set and limited time frame to fulfil. For example, listening to shofar or bringing a korban pesach. Allowing this time frame or obligation to pass without fulfilling the mitzva is a sin, albeit one without action.
  • A voluntary Asei - A mitzva which carries no obligation to fulfil - sort of extra credit, if you like. (The delineation between this category and the previous category is sometimes unclear, and we have to rely on Chazal, Rishonim or other commentators to help define each mitzva.) For example, Shiluach Haken.
  • A "facilitative Asei" - An Asei which technically offers no reward, yet permits actions that would have been forbidden otherwise. For example, Shechita.
### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

The Kotzeker Rebbe z'y's used to say: "Even the greatest tzadik, who has never sinned, must pray to the Aybershter that he NOT come to believe in himself, for his self-grandeur is worse than the worst aveyreh."

You see, a good yid lives between the open arms of Tohoreh and Kedisheh, which have various manifestations, e.g. haircut, tefillin, wine, mikveh and their absence respectively. And the general rule is: מעלין בקודש ואינם מורידים (one ought to rise in holiness and never retreat), e.g. if you go nozir, you gain in kedisheh, but if you interrupt it, you're called a sinner (although you might have been a tzadik before your neziress).

So, there's a certain hierarchy of Kedisheh, e.g. from chol to shabes and up to yom kipper. But internally, it depends on the state of your soul, which your body supports. Therefore, in ideal your physical acts must reflect your spiritual image, e.g. if once's mind is dirty, one is exempt from tefillin. If instead one's mind is pure and it's time for tefillin, then not wearing it damages one's image, which is not an aveireh in itself, but only in relation to the Aybershter, in Whose holy image a Ben Maylech was created.

As you say, one just cannot be holy 24/7 and that's the reason why there's Tohoreh. You kinda kosherise yourself over and over again in mikveh, toyreh, tfilleh in order to maintain your status as His holy vessel. So kedisheh is something objective (like possession), while tohoreh is something subjective (like lost-and-found aka teshiveh), which depends on you and your environment.

Der Kotzker Rebbe z'y'a also used to say: "If you haven't got a talless, wrap yourself in the four corners of the earth and pray." The truth of the matter is that as a yid deep inside you always know when, where and even why there is or isn't an aveyreh in your performing or not performing a mitzveh. The soul is what really matters, because it belongs to the Aybershter.

title: Why is "giving nachat ruach" to Hashem not considered "giving to Him" or "Him receiving from us"
content:
# Why is "giving nachat ruach" to Hashem not considered "giving to Him" or "Him receiving from us" ## Frage

There is a theme throughout all Torah thought, that we cannot give to Hashem. He is perfect and lacking nothing; He needs nothing; He has no desire to receive; He cannot receive; we have nothing to give.

There are many angles, but they all seem to agree on one thing: God can't receive from us and it's very silly, or ignorant, or heretical to say so.

As a quick example from the Baal HaSulam's Introduction to the Zohar to get the ball rolling:

ועתה שידענו בבירור שמחשבת הבריאה שהיא בכדי להנות לנבראיו, בראה בהכרח מידת 'רצון לקבל' ממנו ית' את כל הנועם והטוב הזה שחשב בעדם. הנה הרצון לקבל הזה, ודאי שלא היה כלול בעצמותו ית' מטרם שבראו בנשמות, כי ממי יקבל? הרי שברא דבר מחודש שאינו בו ית׳.

We now also know, that the Thought of Creation was to benefit those that were created. Hashem had to creat something completely new, not found in Himself. This "something" is the desire to receive all His goodness and delight. This desire to receive is not found in G-d Himself, because from whom should He receive? It is created new, since the desire to receive is not found in G-d Himself.

On the other hand, giving Hashem nachat ruach (pleasure, satisfaction) through our service seems to be just as uncontroversial. We say it every day in Shacharit, quoting Rabbi Yehuda the Tanna. In the very same works that we are told Hashem does not receive from us, we are told that we give Him nachat ruach. Same sources as above:

ועל ידי עסק המצוות מי"ג שנים ואילך, שעוסק על מנת להשפיע נחת רוח ליוצרו

And through his involvement in mitzvot beginning at thirteen, for the purpose of giving satisfaction to His Creator

My question: what reconciliations are given to this seeming contradiction? Why is the concept(s) of "giving nachat ruach" or "Hashem getting nachat ruach" possible, if He can't receive/we can't give Him anything?

I am looking for answers from any place. I would love to hear multiple reconcilations coming from various schools of thought, even opposing schools.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Necessarily, there is some reason for creation, otherwise there would be nothing rather than something (unless you posit that it derives from the divine will—sans reason—which I have a hard time wrapping my head around).

The source you cite explains it as God's desire to bestow good onto others.

That reason, which some would term a 'need', is somehow part of the divine perfection (as in, e.g., a perfect being necessarily provides goodness to others).

As mitzvos can be seen as enabling us to fully experience that good, they in turn can be seen as providing pleasure to HaShem—not per se, but indirectly—as they allow Him to realize the purpose of creation.

title: Tzaddik or Rasha: Correlation between human abilities and merits
content:
# Tzaddik or Rasha: Correlation between human abilities and merits ## Frage

"If you have learned much Torah, do not claim credit for yourself, because for such a purpose were you created.". Avot 2.8:

"And that angel takes the drop of semen from which a person will be formed and presents it before the Holy One, Blessed be He, and says before Him: Master of the Universe, what will be of this drop? Will the person fashioned from it be mighty or weak? Will he be clever or stupid? Will he be wealthy or poor?" Niddah 16.b

Recent neuro- and behavioral science appears to back those earlier Jewish sources concerning the strong correlation between individuals' genetics, epigenetics, and environmental factors and their behaviors. In other words, these elements significantly influence a person's decisions.

They imply that human free will (if exists), is quite limited, constrained by these factors.

If so, it would be reasonable to refrain from both criticizing the wicked (e.g. atheists or criminals) and praising the pious (renowned rabbis or Tzaddikim), as we cannot know which part of their behavior was "predetermined" in Heavens and what choice they had.

Is there a discussion of such a phenomenon in Rabbinic literature?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The perspective of the Toras Haminchah (talmid of the Rashba) Parshas Matos seems to answer this:

וכשהנפש השכלית משתלחת לבוא להתקשר בחומר, שואלים לה שתבחר לה הדרך שתחפוץ ותרצה בו דכתיב וכל צבאם, ודרשו חז״ל לצביונם נבראו, פירוש לרצונם ולדעתם.

יש מהם שבחר להיות צדיק ועשיר כדי שיוכל לעמוד בצדקו… ושיעשה רצון קונו בעושר ההוא, והקב׳׳ה מוסרו למזל העושר והצדק להנהיגו באלו הדרכים ומזהירו שישמור עצמו מלחטוא, שאע״פ שנמסר למזל מ׳׳מ רשות ביד האדם להכריח המזל יותר ממה שיש רשות וכח במזל להכריחו, ועל זאת ההתראה הוא בא לעולם דכתיב ראה נתתי לפניך היום את החיים ואת הטוב ואת המות ואת הרע, אתן לפניך לא נאמר אלא נתתי כבר.

הרי זה האיש במעט התעורתת שיתעורר יהיה צדיק גמור שהמזל מצוה עליו להכין אותו ולסעדו, ונמצא שהוא צדיק וטוב לו. וקראו חכמי האומות לזה הצדיק ״צדיק מנוחה״ כלומר שאין לו טורח להדריך עצמו בדרכי הצדק וגם יש לו עושר. ואם יטה אשורו מיני דרך לא יאבד ממנו העושר ההוא כי הוא משתדל להוסיף הון והמזל עוזרו, אבל יענש לעולם הבא עונש גדול כפול שהרי כל מה ששאלו עיניו נתנו לו וברצונו חטא בלי הכרח נמצא רשע וטוב לו, ואם ילך ברע היושר זה צדיק וטוב לו.

ויש שאינו חפץ להיות עשיר אלא צדיק ועני, כי אם יהיה עשיר שמא העושר יסיתנו לכפור ביוצרו…

ויש שאינו חפץ להיות צדיק אלא רשע, כי הרוצה להיות צדיק ונמסר למזל הצדק אין לו כ״כ שבח כי זה עובד השם ית׳ מצד הטבע לא מצד ההכרח, וכבוד השם כשאדם מכתת את טבעו לעבודתו ובזה מתרבה כבודו, וע״כ הוא בוחר להיות רשע כדי שיכתת המזל לכבוד שמים… שאע״פ שבחר להיות רשע הרשות בידו להיות צדיק ועל זה הוא בוטח להיות שולט במזל…

ויש שאינו חפץ להיות עשיר אלא עני ורשע כמו שאמרנו למעלה וזהו רשע ורע לו, ואם יצדק עצמו יהיה צדיק ורע לו ושכרו כפול ומכופל על כולם. ולזה קוראים חכמי האמת ״צדיק תלאה״ כי יש לו טורח מצד טבעו ומצד עניותו.

The gist of it is that souls choose their tendencies before descending to the physical world. I would highly recommend reading it in full (the sefer is available on hebrewbooks.org).

I know this might not be a direct response to the question, but I felt this is fascinating and relevant enough to justify it.

Ksivah vachasimah tovah.

title: Why didn't Bruriah tear kriyah?
content:
# Why didn't Bruriah tear kriyah? ## Frage

In Yalkut Shimoni Mishlei Remez 964 there is a record of Bruriah informing her husband Rebbi Meir of the death of their sons

ד"א אשת חיל מי ימצא. אמרו מעשה היה בר' מאיר שהיה יושב במנחה בשבת ודורש ומתו שני בניו, מה עשתה אמן הניחה שניהם על המטה ופירשה סדין עליהם, במוצאי שבת בא רבי מאיר מבית המדרש אמר לה היכן שני בני, אמרה לו לבית המדרש הלכו, אמרו לה צפיתי בבית המדרש, ולא ראיתים, נתנה לו הכוס של הבדלה והבדיל וחזר, ואמר לה היכן שני בני אמרה לו פעמים שהלכו למקום פלוני ועכשו הם באים, הקריבה לפניו לאכול, לאחר שאכל אמרה לו רבי שאלה יש לי לשאול, א"ל אמ רי שאלתך, אמר לו רבי קודם היום בא אחד ונתן לי פקדון ועכשו בא ליטול אחזיר לו או לאו, אמר לה בתי מי שיש לו פקדון אינו צריך להזיר לרבו, אמרה לו חוץ מדעתך לא הייתי מחזרת אותו, מה עשתה תפשה אותו בידו והעלהו לחדר והקריבה אותו למטה, נטלה הסדין מעליהם וראה שניהם מתים מונחים על המטה, התחיל בוכה ואומר בני בני רבי רבי. בני בדרך ארץ ורבי שהיו מאירין עיני בתורתן, באותה שעה אמרה ליה רבי לא כך אמרת לי שאנו צריכין להחזיר פקדון לרבו, כך ה' נתן וה' לקח יהי שם ה' מבורך, א"ר חנינא בדבר זה נחמתו ונתישבה דעתו לכך נאמר אשת חיל מי ימצא

My question is after Rebbi Meir made havdalah and Shabbat was over didn't Bruriah have an obligation to tear kriyah for the death of her sons right away? My assumption is that she did not do so, because otherwise wouldn't that have indicated to Rebbi Meir that she was mourning?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Halichipedia says:

Ideally a person should tear kriyah immediately or as soon as possible after the person dies or he hears about it. The Sephardic minhag, however, is to tear kriyah after the burial or before the seudat havrah. This minhag has what to rely upon. Note: Chazon Ovadia (Aveilut v. 1 p. 226) writes that the Sephardic minhag to tear kriyah after the burial has what to rely upon. Rav Mordechai Eliyahu's comment on Kitzur S”A 195:2 confirms this minhag.

So one possibility is that Rebbi Meir's wife held like the Sephardic minhag.

Another possibility is based on the idea (don't have a source now) that the tearing is done when the grief is most intense. Rebbi Meir's wife's grief was not at its height until she told her husband.

title: Meaning of "Av Harachamim"
content:
# Meaning of "Av Harachamim" ## Frage

Time-sensitive question (today is 29 Elul..!)

Artscroll translates the phrase "Av Harachamim" as "father of mercy".

What does this mean exactly? How can G-d be the Father of a Midah (character trait)?

Is it analogous to the phrase, "he was the father of modern medicine" (father meaning "founder" or "progenitor")? What would that mean exactly anyway?

Or does it perhaps mean something like "paragon"?

Sources for any answers requested, the older the better.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

It is similar to our blessing of גומל חסדים טובים (bestows beneficient kindnesses) in a multifold form, so is אב הרחמים - a father of multifold mercies. Perhaps, it is connected to the fact that grammatically speaking, both main names of Hashem - E-lohim and A-donai - are plural of the forms (E-loah and A-doni).

The language of father comes from the midrash Bereshis Rabbati Vayishlach 12 on Bereshis 33:3 "and he (Yaakov) himself went on ahead of (his wives and children to greet Eisav)

(my translation may need correction) The verse Tehilim 103:13: Like a father has mercy for his children, (so the LORD has mercy for those who fear Him). Our rabbis said that so taught Yoav to David, as he said that he wondered if really a father is more merciful to his children than their mother. Is not she greatly merciful to them as she troubles herself with pregnancy, birth, and raising them? And he (David) said yes, but did not give a fitting answer. So Yoav went to find out to see whether the saying is true and what it means. He encircled entire land of Israel and found one elderly man among many and who had 12 sons and who could provide for their needs with difficulty with earnings of his entire day. Yoav asked him if he would sell him one of the sons and this way he would provide for his wife and other children. The man scolded him. So Yoav went to his wife and spoke to her at lenghth and at the end he bought a son from her for a 100 gold dinars. In the late evening the elderly man came home to eat and did not find one son. He asked where he was. His wife spoke so and so and in a roundabout way showed him 100 dinars. The man understood what happened, he became very angry and did not sleep entire night. In the morning he rose, took those dinars, he took his weapons in his hands and went to find the big man (gavra) who bought his son. The elderly man did not ask details (of the sale) and did not weigh the money until he found Yoav. So he said to him, "I will not be adding to complete the payment, but if you will not retun my son either I will kill you or you will kill me". Yoav heard the man, he took the money and returned his son. So Yoav said: indeed David said correctly: "Like a father has mercy on his children and not like a mother has mercy on her children. Such is a fact, the mother would sell me her son so that she would not be working as hard to provide for her children, but the father exerted himself in providing for the family and was ready to sacrifice himself to kill for his son. That is what it means "like a father has mercy on his children".

title: Borders of Paran?
content:
# Borders of Paran? ## Frage

The child Ishmael lived in the wilderness of Paran (פָּארָן):

Genesis 21:21: "God was with the boy and he grew up; he dwelt in the wilderness and became skilled with a bow. He lived in the wilderness of Paran; and his mother got a wife for him from the land of Egypt."

The sons of Ishmael dwelt from Havilah to Asshur (the whole of Arabia?).

Genesis 25:18: "their names, in the order of their birth: Nebaioth, the first-born of Ishmael, Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam, Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedmah. These were the years of the life of Ishmael: one hundred and thirty-seven years; then he breathed his last and died, and was gathered to his kin. They dwelt from Havilah, by Shur, which is close to Egypt, all the way to Asshur; they camped alongside all their kin.

Should the borders of the wilderness of Paran, where the child Ishmael lived, include all the land from Havilah to Asshur? If not, why not?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The wilderness of Paran was in the south-west of Eretz Israel (Sinai Peninsula) or South of Israel (in the west of the Arabian Peninsula). It was one of the places of travels of Jewish people during their 40 years travels in the desert. The land of Ashur is to the East of Syria or in the North-East of Eretz Israel. The simple reading of the area of dwelling of Ishmaelites should include Eretz Israel. In the ancient world the road from Egypt or Western Arabia to Mesopotamia was going through Eretz Israel or lands of Edom, Moav and Ammon. King Yoshiyahu unsuccessfully tried to prevent pharaoh Neco from going to fight with the Assyrian army on the river Euphrates (Melakhim B 23:29). Neither Eretz Israel, Ammon, Moav, Edom, Midian, or Syria were inheritance of Ishmael. We must conclude that Ishmael's descendands were nomadic people originating in the wilderness of Paran and moving with their cattle on unsettled lands along the Southern or Eastern borders of countries of Levant.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

"should" is the wrong verb. There is no language of the specific land of Paran being given to Ishmael in the sense that Eretz Yisroel and Mt. Seir were given to the Jews and the Edomites.

title: What's with all the wordplay on Rosh Hashana?
content:
# What's with all the wordplay on Rosh Hashana? ## Frage

I am dividing my question into 3 parts:

  1. We all know that you are not meant to sleep so much on Rosh Hashana, so that you don't have a "sleepy" year.
  2. At the Rosh Hashana meal at night, we have many Simanim. For example, we eat an apple dipped in honey, so that we will have a "sweet" year. We eat the head of a fish, so that this year we should be on top, like a head, and not on bottom, like a tail. And that is only a few of the Simanim we have on Rosh Hashana.
  3. Many people began to make their own Simanim for Rosh Hashana. The most famous one created is the lettuce, raisin, and celery. People eat all three of them to say - "Let us (lettuce) have a raise in (raisin) our salary (celery).

So, my question is what is up with all this wordplay? Isn't it all a bit childish for such a holy day?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I will try to address all your points which seem to play in similar ways but may come from different sources.

  1. Sleep on Rosh Hashanah. A deep analysis made by Rabbi Laufer in the book "Rendezvous with G-d" draws strong parallels between experience of the Jewish people at the moment of Giving of the Torah at Sinai and the minhagim of Rosh Hashanah. The connection is discussed here and here. Because of midrash Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer 41:7:

Rabbi Chanina said: || In the third month the day is double the night, and the Israelites slept until two hours of the day, for sleep on the day of the (feast of) 'Azereth is pleasant, the night being short. And Moses went forth and came to the camp of the Israelites, and he aroused the Israelites from their sleep, saying to them: Arise ye from your sleep, for behold, your G-d desires to give the Torah to you.

To correct the words of the midrash, we have a minhag not to sleep on Rosh Hashanah (and later the midrash became a source for another minhag not to sleep on the night of Shavuos once coffee became available).

  1. During the times of the Talmud, the Jewish communities in the Persian empire often faced persecutions from the followers of Zoroastreanism, the old official Persian religion. Many of the established Rosh Hashanah simanim and minhagim externally appear similar to those of Zoroastreans celebrating Nowruz (their New Year) and other holidays. Haft Sin (Persian: هفت‌ سین‎, originally هفت‌ چین: Haft Chin1) is an Iranian tradition of a festive table for the holiday of Nowruz. Haft Sin includes 7 elements, the names of which begin with the letter ﺱ - "Sin", the fifteenth letter of the Persian alphabet: سیر (sir) - garlic, a symbol of medicine; سیب (sib) - apples, a symbol of beauty and health; سبزه (sabzeh) - sprouts (wheat or lentils), a symbol of the revival of nature; سنجد (senjed) - lokh, a symbol of love; سرکه (serke) - vinegar, a symbol of wisdom and patience; سمنو (samanu) - bread pudding, a symbol of prosperity; سماق (somag) - sumac, a symbol of dawn.

A "book of wisdom" is also commonly included, which might be, Avesta, the Shahnameh, the Quran or the Divān of Hafez. They place on the table sweets, nuts, decorated eggs, a mirror, candles, goldfish, as well as a ribbon or any composition of traditional Iranian flowers (green-white-red), or the flag itself are often present on the table. Coins (سکه sekke), hyacinth (سنبل sonbol), and clock (ساعت suat also pronounced so-at) are sometimes included too.

It is common practice on the eve of Nowruz to bring "Haft Sin" to the graves of relatives so that the deceased can also take part in the holiday.

Externally, it appears that the Jewish customs were observed on purpose so that the surrounding Persians did not think that the Jews were practicing Judaism. However, the Jewish customs have Jewish sources:

  • The apple in honey. Apple comes from the Shir HaShirim 2:3, and honey in the ancient world was “food of kings”, for example, Yaakov avinu included honey as a gift to the Egyptian Vice Roy (who turned out to be Yosef). Regarding Apple we have Gemara Shabbos 88a written in the contexts of Matan Torah:

Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: What is the meaning of that which is written: “As an apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved among the sons. Under its shadow I delighted to sit and its fruit was sweet to my taste” (Song of Songs 2:3)? Why were the Jewish people likened to an apple tree? It is to tell you that just as this apple tree, its fruit grows before its leaves, so too, the Jewish people accorded precedence to “We will do” over “We will hear.”

  • Maharal miPrague in Chudushei Aggados (Horayos perek 4, 60:1) notes that Jewish simanim allude to the qualities of Jewish heroes that we expect as ushpizin-guests on the holiday of Succos, which comes two weeks after Rosh Hashanah:
  • For example, zucchini or pumpkin (קָרָא) - to declare nullified bad decrees and proclaim (קרי) merit, which alludes to Avraham. Avraham chose to follow the path of good commandments, which gave merit and protected him from troubles.
  • Fenugreek, beans (רוביא) - to increase merit (רובה) allude to Yitzchak. Yitzchak, through self-control, re-dug up his father's wells that other people buried, and his harvest was increased 100 times.
  • Leek (כָרָתֵי) - so that all who hate and envy be cut off (כרת), and friends remain alludes to Yaakov. Yaakov chose the path of truth, thanks to which he defeated angels and his enemies, since the truth swallows any lie.
  • One can draw several other such derushim about all traditional simanim connecting them to also Moshe, Aharon, Yosef, and David.
  1. When people make various wishes, which are not connected to Jewish sources, there is a danger that they look like the described customs of Zoroastreans. All such expressions, if one does not have a reputable source, ideally should be worked out with the personal rav to see if they are kosher.

title: Can one have a Christmas tree in their sukkah?
content:
# Can one have a Christmas tree in their sukkah? ## Frage

There's a Jewish teenage boy who isn't so into his Orthodoxy. He said to his father: "I want you to have a Christmas tree in the sukkah this year, etc, and I will come in with my friends into the sukkah." Maybe they want to be different, etc. Is there any Jewish violation in having a Christmas tree with or without lights on it in the sukkah during Sukkos?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I think you need to ask a Rabbi who knows the family and situation.

It is likely idolatry:

Yirmiyahu 10:2-4

So says the Lord: of the way of the nations you shall not learn, and from the signs of the heaven be not dismayed, for the nations are dismayed from them.

3For the statutes of the peoples are vanity, for it is but a stock that one cut from the forest, the handiwork of a carpenter with a small axe.

4With silver and gold he beautifies it, with nails and with sledge hammers they strengthen them so that it does not bend.

I have heard of those who belong to that religion and do everything on x-mas not even do it...

But like I said maybe speaking to an Orthodox Rabbi who understand all the ins and outs can better advise the situation. There might be some sort of compromise or something that can be had.

What if the Schach (ie: roof) is pine leaves and there are xmas lights on the roof? Someone competent who knows more would be likely much more helpful.

Side note: It is interesting it mentions this in association with a carpenter...

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

According to the wikipedia article, the origin of Christmas trees may not be pagan, as the custom originated among the protestants in Germany and Livonia (current Latvia and Estonia) around 1600s, even though there were some similar pagan variants of it in the past. The triangular shape of the tree is understood as symbolic of the Christian trinity. As pointed out by R. Kravitz, while certain beliefs about G-d may be permissible for non-Jews, the Christian theology concerning G-d is one example of a belief that is absolutely forbidden to Jews according to the Hebrew Bible. Usage of symbolism associated with forbidden beliefs cannot take place in a succah at all.
