title: What was the date of Avraham Avinu's bris millah?
content:
# What was the date of Avraham Avinu's bris millah? ## Frage

Based on the Rashi's comment on Bereshis 18:1,

AND THE LORD APPEARED UNTO HIM to visit the sick man. R. Hama the son of Hanina said: it was the third day after his circumcision and the Holy One, blessed be He, came and enquired after the state of his health (Bava Metzia 86b)

Rabbi Eliyahu Mizrachi makes a long comment where he makes the following two suggestions:

  • According to Rabbonan the milla occured on Erev Pesach, the 14th of Nissan, and then in the afternoon Hashem and the angels visited Avraham Avinu, so that it can also be considered 15th of Nissan.
  • According to R. Chama bar Chanina, the milla was also made on the 14th of Nissan, but the visit of the angels occurred on the 17th of Nissan.

The commentary Nachalas Yaakov by Rabbi Yaakov Lorberbaum (missing in Sefaria) but quoted in Sifsei Chakhomim reviews a number of other conflicting aggados and suggests that according to all opinions the milla took place on the 12th of Nissan. We can easily see that Nachalas Yaakov corrects the R. Mizrachi's explanation of the opinion of R. Chama bar Chanina, but not quite his understanding of the opinion of the Rabbonan.

There is also a midrash Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer 29, which states:

Rabban Gamaliel said: Abraham sent and called for Shem, the son of Noah, and he circumcised the flesh of the foreskin of our father Abraham, and the flesh of the foreskin of Ishmael his son, as it is said, "In the selfsame day was Abraham circumcised, and Ishmael his son" (Gen. 17:26). "In the selfsame day" (means) in the might of the sun at midday. Not only that, but (it indicates) the tenth day of the month, the Day of Atonement. It is written in connection with the Day of Atonement, "Ye shall do no manner of work on that selfsame day, for it is a day of atonement" (Lev. 23:28); and in the present instance the text says, "In the selfsame day was Abraham circumcised" (Gen. 17:26). Know then that on the Day of Atonement (Yom Kippurim) Abraham our father was circumcised. Every year the Holy One, blessed be He, sees the blood of our father Abraham's circumcision, and He forgives all the sins of Israel, as it is said, "For on this day shall atonement be made for you, to cleanse you" (Lev. 16:30). In that place where Abraham was circumcised and his blood remained, there the altar was built, and therefore, "And all the blood thereof shall he pour out at the base of the altar" (Lev. 4:30). (It says also), "I said unto thee, In thy blood, live; yea, I said unto thee, In thy blood, live" (Ezek. 16:6).

We thus have 3 opinions about the date of Avraham Avinu's bris milla:

  1. Rabbi Chama bar Chanina according to Nachalas Yaakov says that it was done on the 12th of Nissan
  2. Rabbonan according to R. Eliyahu Mizrachi say that it was don on erev Pesach the 14th of Nissan (if not towards the evening of the beginning of the 15th of Nissan).
  3. Pirkei d'Rabbi Eliezer says it was done on the 10th of Tishrei - Yom haKippurim.

We have 2 questions:

A. Both according to Rabbi Eliezer (Rosh Hashanah 10b) and Rabbi Yehoshua (Rosh Hashanah 11a) Yitzchak avinu was born on 15th of Nissan, the day (or the next day) when the angel made a mark on a wall (Rashi on Bereshis 21:2). Can we use the suggestion of Nachalas Yaakov to explain how according to all opinions the Avraham's milla occured on 12th of Nissan, including the Pirkei d'R. Eliezer's?

B. Alternatively, if these are 3 different opinions based on different calculations what would be the calculations of Pirkei d'R. Eliezer, assuming that he knew the aggados mentioned by R. Mizrachi and Nachalas Yaakov?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

To answer the question, let us try to follow the hint of Nachalas Yaakov, that the procedure of bris milla of Avraham avinu took place on the 12th of Nissan. Therefore, the chakhamim are not arguing about timing when the procedure took place, but rather they argue about timing when Avraham avinu's bris milla was counted to him as a mitzvah. The easiest position then is that of R' Chama bar Chanina, who states that the bris milla was counted as a mitzvah at the moment of the procedure.

To understand the position of the Rabbonan, one has to carefully read the following mashal from Chofetz Chayim on the Torah, Maaseh l'Melekh, parsha Vaeschanan), which I encountered by an accident in the commentary of Chofetz Chayim on Siddur, Mizmor shir l'Yom haShabbos to words of Tehilim 92:8:

...though all evildoers blossom, it is only that they may be destroyed ... The matter is similar to a sick person suffering from illness, who got wearied from various doctors and their therapies, untill s/he encountered a great specialist who knew how to cure the illness. However, once the person signed for the treatment with the specialist, and took the prescribed bitter medicines he started feeling that his condition worsened. The sickness intensified, so that every part of the body suffered pain, from his/her foot to his/her head, the person was hanging like a sinner between life and death.

However, the wise specialist doctor explained to the sick person the purpose of the therapy so that it became clear to him: "Oh you know my dear that the desease was latent and hidden within your body. All remedies did not provided cure for you. Because of that, I had to give you strong drugs that would bring your illness out. And from now on I can give you drugs that will completely cure the disease. Such is the case with the wicked, if we see that they began sprouting like grass and all types of evildoers blossom, and makers of wickedness succeed - that's a sign that the sickness revealed itself out and there is hope that we can rely on the words "it is only that they may be destroyed forever".

We see from the mashal, that the moment of biggest pain can be viewed as the moment when the desease revealed itself and the cure is coming. As we know from the cases of anshei S'dom, the 3rd day after bris millah is viwed in our tradition as a day when a person experiences the biggest pain. This pain is therefore the kapparah for whatever a person did while being uncircumcized. This explains the position of the Rabonnan, according to Nachalas Yaakov.

Finally, we can understand the position of Pirkei d'Rabi Eliezer in regards to bris millah. The day of Yom Kippur brings kapparah, all intentional sins become unintentional, and all unintentional sins are erased. Thus, according to this opinion the effect of the mitzvah is delayed till Yom Kippur.

title: The Chazon Ish Suggests that the Rambam Sometimes Omits Laws that Aren't Explicitly Stated in Talmud - yet, per Rambam, his M"T is one-stop-shopping?
content:
# The Chazon Ish Suggests that the Rambam Sometimes Omits Laws that Aren't Explicitly Stated in Talmud - yet, per Rambam, his M"T is one-stop-shopping? ## Frage

Per the Chazon Ish, the Rambam in the Mishna Torah doesn't necessarily include in his code those things that aren't expressly stated in the Talmud. In other words, the Rambam could hold of a certain vital carveout but not state it because it is not explicitly contained in the Talmud.

But here comes the confusion - the Mishna Torah is a cogent and highly organized one-stop-shopping code of Halacha. It's job thus is very different than that of the Gemarra.

Here is an example of a life and death carveout that the Rambam did not state, but per the Chazon Ish, holds of anyway. One of the three cardinal sins in Judaism is adultery. So how did a married Esther sleep with Achashverosh?

Tosfot on Sanhedrin 74b states:

דקים ליה דמהני טעמא דקרקע עולם לענין דלא מיחייב' למסור עצמה משום עריות

The Talmud holds that Esther was like the natural ground/passive in the act and thus did not have to give herself over to death ...

The Rambam does not codify this carve out when he discusses the big three mizvot. The Chazon Ish here is quoted as saying (brought in the back of the new edition of the Rav Chayim on Rambam):

"There is no proof that the Rambam did not hold of Tosfot's carveout - because [the Rambam does not cite things that] are not explicit in Talmud."

But this is a life and death carve out and the task of a cogent and highly organized codifier is different than that of the talmud. How are we to tell what the Rambam hold's l'Halacha (and what the halacha is) if there are material gaps in his code?!

And the problem gets worse - the Rambam in his own introduction claims that his code is one-stop-shopping:

עַד שֶׁיִּהְיוּ כָּל הַדִּינִין גְּלוּיִין לַקָּטָן וְלַגָּדוֹל בְּדִין כָּל מִצְוָה וּמִצְוָה, וּבְדִין כָּל הַדְּבָרִים שֶׁתִּקְּנוּ חֲכָמִים וּנְבִיאִים: כְּלָלוֹ שֶׁלַּדָּבָר, כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יְהֶא אָדָם צָרִיךְ לְחִבּוּר אַחֵר בָּעוֹלָם בְּדִין מִדִּינֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל; אֵלָא יִהְיֶה חִבּוּר זֶה מְקַבֵּץ לְתוֹרָה שֶׁבְּעַל פֶּה כֻּלָּהּ, עִם הַתַּקָּנוֹת וְהַמִּנְהָגוֹת וְהַגְּזֵרוֹת שֶׁנַּעֲשׂוּ מִיְּמוֹת מֹשֶׁה רַבֵּנוּ וְעַד חִבּוּר הַתַּלְמוּד, וּכְמוֹ שֶׁפֵּרְשׁוּ לָנוּ הַגְּאוֹנִים בְּכָל חִבּוּרֵיהֶן, שֶׁחִבְּרוּ אַחַר הַתַּלְמוּד. לְפִיכָּךְ קָרָאתִי שֵׁם חִבּוּר זֶה מִשְׁנֵה תּוֹרָה – לְפִי שֶׁאָדָם קוֹרֶא תּוֹרָה שֶׁבִּכְתָב תְּחִלָּה, וְאַחַר כָּךְ קוֹרֶא בְּזֶה, וְיוֹדֵעַ מִמֶּנּוּ תּוֹרָה שֶׁבְּעַל פֶּה כֻּלָּהּ, וְאֵינוּ צָרִיךְ לִקְרוֹת סֵפֶר אַחֵר בֵּינֵיהֶם. [This will make it possible] for all the laws to be revealed to both those of lesser stature and those of greater stature, regarding every single mitzvah, and also all the practices that were ordained by the Sages and the Prophets. To summarize: [The intent of this text is] that a person will not need another text at all with regard to any Jewish law. Rather, this text will be a compilation of the entire Oral Law, including also the ordinances, customs, and decrees that were enacted from the time of Moses, our teacher, until the completion of the Talmud, as were explained by the Geonim in the texts they composed after the Talmud. Therefore, I have called this text, Mishneh Torah ["the second to the Torah," with the intent that] a person should first study the Written Law, and then study this text and comprehend the entire Oral Law from it, without having to study any other text between the two.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Rambam's goal was not the inclusion of every single detail in Halacha, as that would be simply impossible. Rather it was to collect in one place every recorded halacha mentioned in any of the authoritative works of the Sages through history. This is why so much effort has been made to find the source of every Halachah: if it is in there, it must be a law stated somewhere in the Rambam's predecessors. And if it isn't stated anywhere, even if it is logically true, the Rambam would not have included it.

title: When do we learn the Chok l'Yisrael for parashat Vezot Habrachah?
content:
# When do we learn the Chok l'Yisrael for parashat Vezot Habrachah? ## Frage

חוק לישראל is a weekly learning study organised according to the weekly פרשה reading. It consists of readings from the פרשה itself and from נ"ך, משנה, גמרא, זוהר, מוסר and הלכה from Sunday to Thursday. Thursday night one reads 26 פסוקים from the פרשה. On Friday one reads the whole פרשה שנים מקרא ואחד תרגום.

This works for every פרשה of the חומש, except for פרשת וזאת הברכה. This one is not read on שבת but rather on שמחת תורה only. But it does have an entry in חוק לישראל just like every other פרשה.

I know that the שמו"ת is read on הושענה רבא. But when do we learn the pieces for Sunday - Thursday night?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I read the following here:

פרשת וזאת הברכה לומדים עד שבת חול המועד סוכות, ושבת בראשית לומדים החל משבת חול סוכות ואילך.

Don't know the source for this though. Maybe just a recommended הליכה.

title: How did Rosh Hashanah come to be known as "Yom Hazikaron"?
content:
# How did Rosh Hashanah come to be known as "Yom Hazikaron"? ## Frage

In Jewish liturgy (Yaale veYavo, Musaf, etc.) the main name of each festival is the one used in the Torah except Rosh Hashanah, which is called "Yom Hazikaron". This name is not found anywhere in the Torah, Mishnah, or Gemara, so where did it come from? I am aware of the thematic appropriateness of the name, and that "Zichron Terua" is mentioned in the Torah, but why specifically "Yom Hazikaron"?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Perhaps from the following pasuk we would have thought יום הזכרון would be more appropriate as a name for Pesach:

(שמות יב:יד) וְהָיָה הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה לָכֶם לְזִכָּרוֹן וְחַגֹּתֶם אֹתוֹ חַג לַה' לְדֹרֹתֵיכֶם חֻקַּת עוֹלָם תְּחׇגֻּהוּ

However it could very well be that יום הזכרון was chosen as a description for Rosh Hashana due to this which mentions a זכרון and is the ultimate pasuk we recite in the bracha of שופרות:

(במדבר י:י) וּבְיוֹם שִׂמְחַתְכֶם וּבְמוֹעֲדֵיכֶם וּבְרָאשֵׁי חׇדְשֵׁיכֶם וּתְקַעְתֶּם בַּחֲצֹצְרֹת עַל עֹלֹתֵיכֶם וְעַל זִבְחֵי שַׁלְמֵיכֶם וְהָיוּ לָכֶם לְזִכָּרוֹן לִפְנֵי אֱלֹהֵיכֶם אֲנִי ה' אֱלֹהֵיכֶם

Where the ספרי (במדבר עז:א) extracts:

אני ה' אלהיכם למה נאמר לפי שהוא אומר דבר אל בני ישראל לאמר בחדש השביעי אבל מלכות לא שמענו, ת"ל ה' אלהיו עמו ותרועת מלך בו, זה שופרות ומלכיות. ר"נ אומר א"צ, שהרי כבר נאמר ותקעתם בחצוצרות הרי שופרות והיו לכם לזכרון זה זכרונות אני ה' אלהיכם זה מלכויות. א"כ מה ראו חכמים לומר מלכיות תחלה ואח"כ זכרונות ושופרות. אלא המליכהו עליך תחלה ואחר כך בקש רחמים לפניו כדי שתזכר לך

This is encapsulated by Rashi on that pasuk with:

אני ה' אלהיכם. מִכָּאן לָמַדְנוּ מַלְכִיּוֹת עִם זִכְרוֹנוֹת וְשׁוֹפָרוֹת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר "וּתְקַעְתֶּם" —זוֹ שׁוֹפָרוֹת, "לְזִכָּרוֹן" — זוֹ זִכְרוֹנוֹת, "אֲנִי ה' אֱלֹהֵיכֶם" — זוֹ מַלְכִיּוֹת וְכוּ' (ספרי)

The אבודרהם also seems to point to this pasuk when discussing the nature of Rosh Hashana as יום הזכרון:

אתה בחרתנו פירשנוהו בתפלת פסח. ואומ' ותתן לנו ה' אלקינו באהבה את יום הזכרון הזה. ואין צריך להזכיר ראש חדש ולומ' את יום ראש החדש הזה דאמרי' בפ' בכל מערבין דזכרון אחד עולה לכאן ולכאן פי' כשאומר את יום הזכרון הזה גם ראש חדש בכלל שבשניהם כתוב לשון זכירה שנאמ' וביום שמחתכם ובמועדיכם ובראשי חדשיכם וגו' והיו לכם לזכרון לפני אלקיכם.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

This question is fully explored in the book "Rendzevous with God" by Rabbi Nathan Laufer, chapter 3. The problem, is that the act of Creation occured long before the time that the Jewish history start. Therefore, it cannot serve as a day of "rememberance" that occured in the Jewish history. He explains that it is not a simple day of rememberance that we observe, but specifically the rememberance of terua. (in what follows I will be quoting the book even if I will not use the quotation marks for readability). In the book of Bamidbar 10:1-10, the Torah tells us that a terua is one of two musical notes produced by the trumpet or the shofar.

The terua was blown in two sets of circumstances: as a signal to the Jewish people to move their encampment from one place to another (Bamidbar 10:5-6), and in the event of war, to "remind G-d" of their precarious plight, through the tremulous, staccato sound of their blowing (Bamidbar 10:9). An alternative shofar sound , the tekia, was blown to gather (uvehak'hil) the people (Bamidbar 10:7).

There is only one place in the Torah prior to Vayikra 23, the chapter of the holidays, where blowing of shofar on Rosh Hashanah is mentioned. The place is in the book of Shemos in the parshas Yisro during the revelation of G-d's presence at Mount Sinai. There the Torah speaks three times of the sounding of shofar:

Shemos 19:16: On the third day, as morning dawned, there was thunder (koloth), and lightning, and a dense cloud upon the mountain, and a very loud blast (kol) of the horn; and all the people who were in the camp trembled.

Shemos 19:19: The blare (kol) of the horn grew louder and louder. As Moses spoke, G-d answered him in sound (bekol).

Shemos 20:15: All the people witnessed the thunder (koloth) and lightning, the blare (kol) of the horn and the mountain smoking; and when the people saw it, they fell back and stood at a distance.

Therefore, the day of Rosh Hashanah is the day of rememberance of our experience of standing at mount Sinai as we were receiving the Torah.

There is additional biblical support for this thesis from the book of Nehemiah, ch. 8. It describes a dramatic ceremony led by Ezra the Scribe after the Jewish people returned from the Babylonian exile. The ceremony took place on the 1st day of the 7th month. During the ceremony people gathered as one and responded Amen in fear and trembling as Ezra standing on a raised platform (suggesting a mountain) revealed to the confused and struggling returnees to the Land of Israel the Torah of Moshe that they had forgotten. Apparently, Ezra also saw a linkage between the day of Rosh Hashanah and the awe-inspiring revelation of the Torah to the Jewish people who stood at the foot of Mount Sinai.

This connection goes deep through many minhagim of Rosh Hashanah, such as sounding 3 different sounds of shofar: sound of shofar (kol), sound of thunder (koloth), sound of G-d's voice. We sound shofar after reading 10 verses hinting to 10 commandments. We sound 3 sets of Shofar blows after Malkiyoth, Zikhronoth, and Shofaroth corresponding to the quoted 3 verses. There is much more that is discussed in the book on this beautiful subject.

### Antwort 3 (Score: -1)

I always thought it was to remember that Adam sinned on that day and was forgiven. Likewise, we want to be forgiven.

title: Mishnah Berurah's Torah Study Recommendation
content:
# Mishnah Berurah's Torah Study Recommendation ## Frage

Mishnah Berurah 155:3 says:

חייב אדם ללמוד בכל יום תורה שבכתב שהוא תנ"ך ומשנה וגמרא ופוסקים, a person is obligated to learn every day [the] Written Torah, which includes TaNaCH - Torah, Prophets and Writings - and Mishnah, and Gemara and work of Halacha.

I went to a Jewish Orthodox elementary and high school. They were primarily dedicated to learning Gemara. Why aren't Jewish elementary and high schools dividing up their day learning TaNaCH, Mishnah, Gemara, and works of Halacha, as the Mishnah Berurah recommends?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I do not have a written source for this one, but I believe that the reason is that the yeshivos for young students seek to provide their pupils with the tools that will enable a lifetime of "free-range" Torah study. That means taking advantage of a limited time to give them the ability to learn and understand Gemara with its commentaries, and Shulchan Aruch with is commentaries, independently. If they have the ability to do that by they time they leave yeshiva, they then have the ability to study any topic in Torah they wish. If they lack that ability, they are crippled, likely for life.

The Mishnah Brurah, in contrast, is addressing himself to grown men who already have the ability to pursue their studies independently. To them, he advises a balanced program of study, covering all the major areas of Torah learning.

title: Why do many shuls not have plag mincha/maariv on fast days?
content:
# Why do many shuls not have plag mincha/maariv on fast days? ## Frage

Many shuls have mincha/maariv minyanim at plag most weekdays in the summer. However, they typically don't at the end of a fast day. They might have a 2:00 mincha, but they don't have mincha right before plag and maariv right after.

Why not? I'd think it would be convenient for some people (especially those who have both little kids who are not fasting and young teenagers who are) to be home with that much extra time before the end of the fast. And if you're feeling sick, it might be better to daven at the earliest possible time before you feel worse.

Are there halachic reasons* not to have these minyanim? Or sociological reasons? Or maybe I'm just looking at the wrong shuls and just wrong about the lack of minyanim?

* reasons relevant specifically to fast days - I'm excluding the reasons not to say birchos krias shema before night, because these are shuls that have a plag mincha/maariv on other weekdays. I'd be ok in principle with an answer that we're more machmir because it's a day dedicated to teshuva, but I'm skeptical that that's the reason, because there are plag minyanim during the aseres yemei teshuva - just not on Tzom Gedalya.

title: Why does only the Septuagint have "Cainan" in the genealogy in Genesis 10 and 11?
content:
# Why does only the Septuagint have "Cainan" in the genealogy in Genesis 10 and 11? ## Frage

Who is Cainan, or, where was he invented?

The Septuagint records someone named Cainan between Arpachshad and Shelach in both Genesis 10:24 and 11:13. The Torah that we have today in Lashon Hakodesh does not record this name (nor anyone else between these two ancestors).

Common sense would say that it is much more likely that he was dropped than that he was added. The difference is too big to be a typo, and this would be a very bizarre thing to deliberately add. If the name got dropped, then people would be confused as to which version was right, whereas if it got added then all of the corrupted versions would have to agree with each other which would make it much harder for it to be accepted.

Judaism also believes that the Septuagint version of the Torah is inspired, or at least was when it was first written. It’s also worth noting that Cainan is included in the Gospel of Luke which is believed to have been written between 80-90 CE.

It’s also worth mentioning that the years in the Tanach tend to add up to round numbers for important events in the history of Israel, and the years in the Septuagint are completely different.

Did people find it offensive to be descended from someone whose name sounded so close to Canaan?

If the Hebrew text is correct, then where did this Cainan figure come from and how did this version become so widespread?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 12)

Andrew E. Steinmann, 'Challenging the Authenticity of Cainan, Son of Arpachshad', Journal of the Evangelical Theological Society 60 (2017), pp. 697-711, pointed out that when examining ancient sources, including various targums, Seder Olam, various Torah/Pentateuch traditions, the oldest manuscripts of Luke and the writings of the Church Fathers, it becomes clear that evidence for Cainan is only known from the 4th century CE and onwards, and even then the evidence is somewhat sporadic. He argued that "Cainan" was accidentally inserted into late 3rd or early 4th century versions of Luke as a scribal error, and from there permeated to the Septuagint and Jubilees. The Septuagint as we have it is a later work based on the efforts of the Church Fathers to create a standard Greek biblical translation,1 while the oldest manuscripts of Jubilees that are known to have Cainan are the Ethiopian Ge'ez manuscripts from the 15th century and onwards, and were likely translated from the Greek version, not the Hebrew original.2

1 For more information on the modern Septuagint, see what I've written here and here.

2 And see Steinmann's response to arguments against his paper here.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 8)

קינן/Keinan is recorded as the child of Enosh and father of Mahalalel in the Masoretic Text (Bereishis 5), with the Septuagint concurring.

As it relates to the Septuagint, R. Moshe David (Umberto) Cassuto (to 10:24) thinks that it was a later addition.

Here is his comment (to 10:24):

בתרגום השבעים: וארפכשד ילד את קינן, וקינן ילד את שלח, בהקבלה לתולדות בני שת שבפרק ה'. וכך מספר ס' היובלים על קינן בן ארפכשד. אבל כנראה אין זו אלא הוספה מאוחרת. ועי' להלן, על פס' ל"א.

In the Septuagint translation: "Arpachshad begat Cainan, and Cainan begat Shelah," paralleling the genealogy of the descendants of Seth in chapter 5. The Book of Jubilees also mentions Cainan, the son of Arpachshad. However, this is likely a later addition. See further below, on verse 31.

### Antwort 3 (Score: -1)

The LXX and Luke reading are ancient, not added after 1st century, as the LXX NETS critical edition shows. I searched the Google books with the keywords on this and found a helpful reference: Genesis A Commentary by Bruce Watke, (2001) p. 181 states,

Gen 11:12 When Arphaxad had lived 35 years, he became the father of Shelah. This should read, “When Arphaxad had lived 35 years, he became father of Cainan. And after he became the father of Cainan, Arphaxad lived 430 years and had others sons and daughters. When Cainan had lived 34 years he became the father of Shelah. And after he became the father of Shelah, Cainan lived 330 years and had other sons and daughters.” This reading is based on the Greek text and Luke 3:35-36 (see Gen. 10:24), From a text-critical point of view, it is much simpler to explain an accidental deletion of a name than an addition. This deletion is explained easily by the similarity of the two entries,12* a common scribal error. In all likelihood, the Masoretic text then was corrected as necessary to accommodate the omission. This seems more likely than a scribe adding a name to a  fixed genealogy. Some, supporting the Masoretic text, argue that Abraham is the tenth generation, but the parallel is imprecise, for they include the segmented genealogy as part of the linear, unlike the ten linear names in Genesis 5.

fn 12: LXX reads 130 years, but the additional 100 years is presumably the typical later correction of that recension (see n. 9 above).
fn. 9: The textual recensions of the SP and of the LXX add one hundred years to the ages of the patriarchs from Arphaxad to Serug at the first son's birth. Perhaps they did so to distance Abraham from Shem and to assure that only Abraham's near ancestors were still alive when he was born. As a whole, the Masoretic text shows itself as more reliable than the other two smoothed recensions, but its omission of Cainan between Arphaad and Shelah is probably secondary. See Waltke, “Samaritan Pentateuch,” 212-39; and G. Larsson, “The Chronology of the Pentateuch: A Comparison of the MT and LXX.” JBL 102 (1983): 401-9.

I found the actual answer through the reference found in The Book of Genesis Composition, Reception, and Interpretation 2012, fn, p. 398.

Samaritan Hebrew texts of Genesis. See Helen R. Jacobus, “The Curse of Cainan (Jub. 8:1-5): ‘Genealogies in Genesis 5 and Genesis 11 and a Mathematical Pattern.” JSP 18 (2009): 207-232.

Helen writes that Cainan was cursed for obtaining forbidden knowledge of the Watchers.

Cainan, the father of Shelach, son of Arpachshad, grandson of Shem and great-grandson of Noah, is listed in the genealogies of Shem in the Septuagint (LXX), LXX Gen. 10.24, Gen. 11.12-13; ( LXX A) 1 Chron. 1.18; and Lk. 3.36-37 as the thirteenth generation from Adam.
He is conspicuously absent from the Masoretic text (MT) and the Samartian Pentateuch (SP) where it is stated that Arpachshad, the ﬁrst patriarch to be born after the Flood (Gen. 10.1), is the father of Shelach (MT, SP Gen. 10.24; Gen. 11.12-13; 1 Chron. 1.18, 24) instead of Cainan

An explanation for this discrepancy between the LXX and the Masoretic and Samartian versions of the Pentateuch is contained in a surprisingly elaborate narrative in Jub. 8.1-5. According to Jubilees, Cainan, the thirteenth generation from Adam, was sent away after he discovered the secrets of astronomy and astrology. This knowledge had been imparted by the fallen angels, the Watchers, to human beings before the Flood and these terrestrial ancestors had carved the secrets into rock.

This is why his name has been blotted out by the certain textual transmission. It also seems that Canaan of Gen 9:18-29 is perhaps the same Cainan from a different source as he has been cursed for his father Ham's sin of not covering up his father Noah, in that version.

title: Why do some people say tefilat haderech on flights?
content:
# Why do some people say tefilat haderech on flights? ## Frage

Tefilat haderech is said after traveling a parsah outside of the city. (Shulchan Arukh, Orach Chayim 110:7)

Eliyahu hanavi is said to have flown on Shabbat more than tchum outside off city limits (Eruvin 43). From there, it says that flying doesn’t count as traveling (at least in matters of techum Shabbat).

Can we learn from here that flying is considered traveling for any purposes?

If so, why do some say tefilat haderech when flying?

If not so what is the distinction between traveling in terms of t’chum and travel in terms of tefilat haderech?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Note, that the rules of techum Shabbos go to a distance of 1 mil = 2000 amah (Section 3, Chapter IV/C p. 1389 vol. IV of the 39 melachos). The rules of tefilas haderekh begin applicable only after traveling 1 parsa = 8000 amah. These are different domains and one should expect different halachic rulings with respect to traveling in each one of them.

Flying out of reshus harabim above 10 tefachim puts a person into makom petur, which allows carrying and travelling. It is free from all restrictions of melacha of hotzoa including techum Shabbos (Section 3, Chapter I/D on p. 1322, vol. IV of the "39 melachos" by R. Dovid Ribiat). One is also permitted to move from any other domain of Shabbos, such as reshus hayachid or karmelis into makom petur.

On the other hand, if one goes out of the city into makom petur with respect to shabbos and extends the travel to 1 parsa, say in the middle of a forest, a desert, or sea, one still has to say tefilas haderekh.

Alternatively, restrictions on travel on Shabbos are guarding one's ability to rest. The flight under such circumstances is not a common matter. Tefilas haderekh is a personal safety request, which is always important to have on long journeys.

title: Are you liable for damages while protecting someone else from damage?
content:
# Are you liable for damages while protecting someone else from damage? ## Frage

Let's say Reuven is attempting (or has already begun) to damage Shimon (or Shimon's belongings) and Levi shows up to defend Shimon from Reuven. In successfully warding off Reuven, Levi also ends up damaging Shimon (or Shimon's stuff). Who, if anyone, is liable for Levi's damages?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The relevant halachah is in Shulchan Aruch, Choshen Mishpat 380:3 (ultimately from the Gemara, Bava Kamma 117b):

ואחד שרדף אחר הרודף להציל את הנרדף ושבר כלים בין של רודף בין של כל אדם פטור כדי שלא יבואו מלימנע מלהציל את הנרדף

If one [Levi, in your example] pursues a would-be assailant [Reuven] to save the potential victim [Shimon], and he breaks utensils - whether they belong to the assailant or to anyone else - he is exempt [from payment], so that people don't hesitate to save a would-be victim.

The Business Halacha Institute has an article with some further relevant details (see the section of that page titled "Emergency!"), in particular whether this exemption also applies to something that Levi borrows for the purpose (e.g., Levi borrows a weapon to fight off Reuven, and damages it in the process).

title: Money exchange error in favor
content:
# Money exchange error in favor ## Frage

If you agreed to the clerk at the exchange to sell 5 zuz for 10 dollars. You give 5 zuz. They count the money, give you receipt and both 5 zuz and 10 dollars through a small window on a plate

What's the status of 10 dollars if you keep them? No deceit was applied. Is that a lost article? Is transaction null and you just picked up someone's money off the plate?

Basically they agreed to buy currency for a particular price but in the end they return the currency and hand the payment for the currency.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

This is basically the same thing as getting extra change at a grocery store.

This would be considered Hashavat Aveida, as it is included in that mitzvah to stop others from incurring losses. However, Hashavat Aveida only applies between fellow jews (Sefer Hachinuch 538). I will assume that the currency exchange people are non-jewish, in which case although it is not obligatory, it is certainly commendable as it would cause a Kiddush Hashem.

If, the currency exchange people are Jewish, one is expected to go to great lengths to do Hashavat Aveida.

title: What is more important: observing the fast of Gedalia or taking care of one's children?
content:
# What is more important: observing the fast of Gedalia or taking care of one's children? ## Frage

If fasting on the fast of Gedalia makes a mother too weak to care for her kids - should she fast?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

It's not a question of "which is more important." We don't play those games.

The better question to ask is: was this person included in the enactment of the fast to begin with? This is a minor fast, and only ever intended for "the well and able-bodied."

If someone can fast but will need to lie down and find a babysitter for their kids, and can do so, that's fine. If fasting puts them in a situation where they are physically not coping ... or there's no one else around to keep the kids from setting the house on fire, and tending to them while fasting makes the parent feel ill ... then we fall back on the "never included in the mitzvah to fast" category. (In which case it's not that some other value is better than fasting, it's that there's no obligation to fast.)

This really needs to be discussed with a competent rabbi, by the way.

title: Settling Lebanon as a part of E"Y
content:
# Settling Lebanon as a part of E"Y ## Frage

The modern State of Israel has had to in its short existence invade Lebanon several times in order to procure the safety of its citizens.

Recently an organization named עורי צפון ("Awake o north [wind]" an allusion to Song of Songs 4:16) has argued that the State of Israel ought to permit and encourage Jewish settlement in Lebanon, as a historic part of Eres Yisrael (the Land of Israel).

Their website hosts the following statement from R. Y. Ginsburgh:

The war in the north is a Milhemeth Miswa (a commanded-obligatory war) predicated on the fact that it is “a war fought to assist Israel from an enemy which attacks them” (H. Melakhim 5:1). The enemy ought be struck with full force, "he who comes to kill you, arise and kill him [first]"(Sanhedrin 74a) with the aim of killing all members of terrorist organizations and especially their leaders. We ought not delay military action due to the reality that the terrorists shelter themselves within a population (the recent change for the better in attitude expressed by the heads state on this issue should be welcomed).

Lebanon is a part of the Land of Israel that belongs to the Jewish nation, a gift from Hashem as written in the Torah, "the land of the Canaanites, and Lebanon, as far as the great river, the river Euphrates" (Deut. 1:7). In our generation, the Holy One Blessed Be He has given us the ability to renewedly receive this gift, and to conquer and settle the Land. Today it is clear that the time has arrived to conquer the Lebanese territories as well, that is the only way to remove the threat and bring true peace to the whole country. After the occupation and expulsion of the hostile population Jewish settlement must be established and thus complete the victory.

May the strength of the soldiers of the Israeli armies who fight for the people of Israel be enriched. May the Holy One Blessed Be He give them a heroic spirit and protect them from every trouble and enemy. And may it be fulfilled in us soon God's promise in the Torah " And the Lord thy God will bring thee into the land which thy fathers possessed, and thou shalt possess it; and He will do thee good, and multiply thee above thy fathers... And the Lord thy God will put all these curses upon thine enemies, and on them that hate thee, that persecuted thee.” With God's help together we will prevail, and merit to a good and sweet year in the complete Land of Israel, and the coming of our righteous messiah speedily and in our day.

Are there any other rabbis (presently or in recent decades) that agree with this perspective and/or expand upon the halakhic basis for doing so? If so where have they expressed these views and what do they say?

title: Are there Rabbinical commentaries on the symbolism of the altar fire revived by Nehemiah?
content:
# Are there Rabbinical commentaries on the symbolism of the altar fire revived by Nehemiah? ## Frage

I gather that 2 Maccabees is outside the canon, but surely Rabbinical commentators were aware of it. With the goal of parsing out some of the symbolism seen in the following verses 1:23-28 (alternative version on Sefaria):

For when our ancestors were being led captive to Persia, the pious priests of that time took some of the fire of the altar and secretly hid it in the hollow of a dry cistern, where they took such precautions that the place was unknown to anyone. 20 But after many years had passed, when it pleased God, Nehemiah, having been commissioned by the king of Persia, sent the descendants of the priests who had hidden the fire to get it. And when they reported to us that they had not found fire but only a thick liquid, he ordered them to dip it out and bring it. 21 When the materials for the sacrifices were presented, Nehemiah ordered the priests to sprinkle the liquid on the wood and on the things laid upon it. 22 When this had been done and some time had passed, and when the sun, which had been clouded over, shone out, a great fire blazed up, so that all marveled.

Is it possible to gloss that the preservation and transference of the altar fire from the First Temple to the Second holds a symbolic meaning? In Iranian traditions, such a symbol might be thought of as khvarenah, often glossed as "glory" and denoting divine sponsorship (though typically of a king).

Question

Are there any Midrashic traditions or even kabbalistic exegeses on the altar fire mentioned in 2 Maccabees? ## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Rabbi Dr. Eliyahu Zini in his Hebrew book Etz Erez (עץ ארז), vol. 3, pp. 97-98, 118 thought that the following passage from the Geonic-period/8th century She'iltot de-Rav Ahai, She'ilta 27 (Mirsky ed., pp. 184-185) hinted at an awareness of either the actual passage from 2 Maccabees or a similar tradition from a separate source:

באה מלכות יון הרשעה והחשיכה את ישראל בגזירותיה...והיה שם משומד א'...תתני בן פחת שמו, והיה מלמד עצות רעות על ישראל...אמר להם כל זמן שישראל מקריבין תמיד של שחר ותמיד של בין הערבים אין אתם יכולים להם. מיד עמדו וטמאו את המזבח וביטלו את הקרבן...ושוב אמר להם מצוה אחת יש בידם, אם תבטלו אותה מיד אינו יכולין לעמוד, ואיזו זו? זו הדלקת המנורה ונרותיה, שכן כתיב להעלות נר תמיד, כשם שהן מעלים את הנר תמיד כך הם מקיימים תמיד, שכן כתיב תן חלק לז' וגם לח', כל זמן שנותנים חלק בביתי לז' נרות ושומרים ח' ימי החג אינן נעקרין מארצם לעולם. מיד עמדו וטמאו כל שמנים שבה, ולא נשתייר אלא פך א' שהיה חתום בחותמו של כהן גדול תחת המזבח, אמר להם הב"ה: רשעים, עלי אתם מתיעצים, שלמה אמר בחכמתו תן חלק לז' וגם לח', תן חלק לז' אלו ז' נרות, וגם לח', אלו ח' ימי החג, ואתם רוצים לבטל אותם מתוך עמי, הריני מעמיד ז' בני חשמוני כנגד ז' נרות שאתם רוצים לבטל מביתי, ואתן אתכם בידם, ויקבעו הלל ושמאי ח' ימי חנוכה על מפלתן של רשעים, כנגד ח' ימי החג שאתם רוצים לבטל מביתי..."

"The evil Greek Empire came and darkened Israel with its decrees...and there was an apostate there...named Tatenai ben Pachat, and he would advise against Israel...he told them (the Greeks): "As long as the Israelites sacrifice the morning and evening offerings, you will not be able to defeat them. And so they proceeded to desecrate the altar and canceled the offering...and again he told them: They have one commandment that if you cancel it, they will not be able to withstand you, and what is that? That is the lighting of the menorah and its lamps, as it is written "for kindling lamps regularly", just as they kindle the lamps regularly, so do they regularly sacrifice the daily offering, as it is written: "distribute portions to seven or even to eight", so long as they distribute portions in My House for seven lamps and keep the eight days of the festival [of Tabernacles] they will not be removed from their land forever. And so they (the Greeks) immediately rose and desecrated all of the oils there, and only a single cruse sealed with the seal of the High Priest remained beneath the altar. The Holy One, blessed is He said to them: "Evil ones! You are conspiring against Me. Solomon said in his wisdom "distribute a portion to seven or even to eight", "distribute a portion to seven" - those are the seven lamps, "or even to eight", these are the eight days of the festival [of Tabernacles], and you wish to remove these from My nation? Behold, I will raise up the seven sons of Hasmonai against the seven lamps that you wish to remove from My House, and I will have you fall by their hands, and Hillel and Shammai will establish the eight days of Hanukkah for the downfall of the evil ones, against the eight days of the festival [of Tabernacles[ they you wish to remove from My House..."

The passage describes the story of the Seleucid-Maccabean War in midrashic fashion, highlighting some of the symbolism of the background of the story. While not directly referencing the altar fire, it does mention several themes related to the passage from 2 Maccabees:

  • A connection between the Festival of Hanukkah and the Festival of Tabernacles which was attested at in Nehemiah 8:14-18. Incidentally, another connection between the latter festival, the Book of Ezra (which in Jewish tradition was the first half of the Book of Nehemiah) and 2 Maccabees was discussed here.1
  • Mention of the altar and its connection to the Story of Hanukkah.
  • Symbolism of the altar as a protector of Israel against their enemies.
  • Connection between the altar and the lighting of the menorah.
  • The untainted cruse of oil hidden beneath the altar, similar to the fire of the altar hidden in a cistern.

Another possibly relevant source is the description of the purification of the Temple after the Hasmonean defeat of the Seleucids as described by Rabbi Avraham Zacuto in his book Sefer Yuchasin:

"ואז בא יהודה...ויביאו עצים ואש הקדש לא מצאו ויקראו אל ה' ותצא אש מן האבן אשר על המזבח ויתנו עצים עליה ותהי האש ההיא עד הגולה השלישית..."

"And then Judah (the Maccabee) came...and they brought wood but they did not find the holy fire and they cried out to God and fire burst from the stone that was upon the altar and they fed it wood and that fire lasted until the third exile..."

This description indicates that there was some sort of set fire (perhaps some kind of everlasting flame) that was lost during the Seleucid sacking of the Temple, and so a new miraculous fire was conjured by God to replace the old one.

1 The name of the apostate, which both Shmuel Mirsky who prepared the edition and Rabbi Zini thought was symbolic and not literally the name of the person (if he ever existed), is also connected to Ezra-Nehemiah, as it comes from the name of Tatenai, governor of the Ever ha-Nahar province of the Persian Empire (תתני, פחת עבר הנהר), who is mentioned in the Book of Ezra as causing some administrative trouble for the Jews, and in later Jewish sources is considered an evil person (see here).

title: Does modern Judaism view rape victims as less eligible for marriage?
content:
# Does modern Judaism view rape victims as less eligible for marriage? ## Frage

I understand that the Torah doesn’t blame victims of rape and that perhaps the only halachic prohibition for such a victim would be marriage with a kohen. However, reading what the Torah and Talmud say about rape victims, I notice that compensation is entirely for the purpose of ensuring their future livelihood. This comes from the consideration that their marriage opportunities have been tainted, as they are no longer virgins.

I feel conflicted reading what the Torah and Talmud say about these victims. The notion that they have somehow been defiled, dirtied or made less valuable has evoked feelings of contempt in me against a society who could hurt victims like this. The idea that a virtuous woman, who after having her virginity taken against her will, is all of the sudden unsuitable, dirty or undesirable is deeply saddening.

I understand that this is mainly in the context of an ancient society where virginity was highly valued, but this notion is really challenging me emotionally in my study of the Torah, to the point where I now feel compelled to ask for guidance on this matter.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

No.

Back in the day, it was not the girl’s eligibility that changed, but how much she was desired relative to other women. This is still the case in many Middle-Eastern countries.

In the modern West, this is almost never a concern. Men don’t see rape victims as less desirable for marriage than anyone else. (Plus, nobody today would want to marry their rapist).

The Torah and Talmud don’t consider virgins in any way better or “purer” than non-virgins.

title: Reversible vasectomy status
content:
# Reversible vasectomy status ## Frage

This question declares that vasectomies are forbidden, based on the Rambam. However, unlike in the Rambam's days, vasectomies are reversible. That being the case, then assuming such an act is still forbidden, and assuming there is an obligation to reverse the vasectomy (see this question), does the sin become a 'lav hanitak le'ase', a correctible sin, analagous to gezel (theft)?

A practical ramification to this question would be if the transgressor is liable for lashes, for example.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Is it still prohibited? Certainly yes. Rabbi Moshe Feinstein made that point about tubal ligations for women, by the way. The fact that it could be later reversed by surgery does not change that the procedure is "permanent", i.e. if left to nature.

You're asking if there would then be a mitzvah to go reverse it? Same as with lasering off a tattoo -- if there's no "thou shalt" in the Torah, there's no "thou shalt."

There could very well be an obligation to reverse it here, however, because of the general pru urvu obligation to have children.

ואין להפלא משם 'דת' אם לא מצאנוהו רק בספרים האחרונים ובל' פרסי, שהרי כמה מלות מצריות וגם יוניות ורומיות מצינו כיוצא בהם בספר תורת משה, ואין לתמוה אם תמצא ג"כ מלה פרסית.

title: In the first century, what was the impetus for the rebellion of Jerusalem against Rome?
content:
# In the first century, what was the impetus for the rebellion of Jerusalem against Rome? ## Frage

What was the major impetus of the Great Revolt? I have heard that it was NOT unfair taxation, because I recently learned that the Fiscus Judaicus did not begin until the destruction of the 2nd Temple?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Talmud and the Midrash say that the catastrophic war against Roman occupation, the death of more than a million Jews, and the destruction of Jerusalem and the Second Temple happened because of a strange local chain of events. It's long, so look it up: [Gittin 55b-56a and Lamentations Rabbah 4:3]

You ask: Is this a true story? Well, it can be corroborated in two ways.

1-First, the Jewish historian Josephus, who fought in that war, also says that the war began because the Jews did not accept the offering of the Emperor:

Eleazar, the son of Ananias the high-priest, a very bold youth, who was at that time governor of the temple, persuaded those that officiated in the divine service to receive no gift or sacrifice from any foreigner. And this was the true beginning of our war with the Romans; for they rejected the sacrifice [offered by] Cæsar… When many people … besought them not to reject the sacrifice, which it was customary for them to offer for their [Roman] rulers, they would not be prevailed upon. [Josephus, Wars II, 17:2]

2-Second, the Talmud says:

Hence the popular saying: “Because of Kamtza and Bar Kamtza the Temple was destroyed.”

The fact that it was a "popular saying" indicates that the story was believed true and widely known.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

There are several theories offered besides the Wikipedia article. One such theory, Roman Provenance, is advocated by James S. Valliant and Warren Fahy in their book "Creating Christ". They analyzed the Roman coins as a source of Roman imperial propaganda and found that the imperial family of Flavii used early Christian symbols on their coins. The historical records also showed that in every country that Romans conquered they modified the local religions to make it more Roman and less local (they took this policy from the Greeks). One finds that development of Christianity coincided with the rebellion. Thus, on one hand we had reformers of the Jewish religion (zealots, sicarii, and some orthodox saducee circles) who pushed for messianic and apocalyptic prophesies (such as the so-called "Star" prophesy). On the other side we find a strong and powerful Roman adversary seeking to completely uproot Judaic tradition using the Herodian family and its circle. We can see support for this idea in the midrash Eleh Ezkera, where the Roman emperor seeks to uproot all the major rabbis whose opinions shaped the Rabbinic Oral Torah. Analysis of the New Testament also shows a strange mixture of certain leaders who appear as leaders of rebellion who at the same time spoke about peace with Romans with whom they fought.

Additionally, one should not neglect connection to the Parthian/Persian empire which had multiple wars with Romans lasting over 6 centuries, pretty much to the time of the Arab conquest, when neither Romans nor Persians had anyone to hold weapons. After the Roman Conquest, the Chashmonaim and rebel leaders sought the help of Persians. In part, apocalyptic teachings from the 2nd Temple are similar conceptually to those of Zoroastrianism. Persians did not want to have Romans in the Middle East and it was to their advantage to supply the Jewish rebels with weapons. For example, the Persian Adiabene kingdom was known as a helper of Jewish rebels.

title: Bereishith (Genesis) chapter 49 begins with a reference to "the end of days." Is that understood to refer to something still future?
content:
# Bereishith (Genesis) chapter 49 begins with a reference to "the end of days." Is that understood to refer to something still future? ## Frage

Bereishith (Genesis) chapter 49 begins with a reference to "the end of days." Is that understood to refer to something still future?:

א וַיִּקְרָא יַעֲקֹב, אֶל-בָּנָיו; וַיֹּאמֶר, הֵאָסְפוּ וְאַגִּידָה לָכֶם, אֵת אֲשֶׁר-יִקְרָא אֶתְכֶם, בְּאַחֲרִית הַיָּמִים.

1 And Jacob called unto his sons, and said: 'Gather yourselves together, that I may tell you that which shall befall you in the end of days.

https://mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0149.htm

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

There are several directions to interpret the verse. The basic source is Bereshis Rabba 98:2:

“Jacob called to his sons, and he said: Gather, and I will tell you what will befall you at the end of days. Assemble and hear, sons of Jacob, and listen to Israel your father” (Genesis 49:1–2).

“Jacob called to his sons.” “The lot is cast in the bosom” (Proverbs 16:33) – this is the lottery of Yom Kippur. “And all of one’s judgment is from the Lord” (Proverbs 16:33) – to determine which will be for God and which will go to an uninhabitable land.

Another matter: “The lot is cast in the bosom” – this is the lot of the tribes. “And all of one’s judgment is from the Lord” – that the Holy One blessed be He agreed with him to give each and every one as befitting him. “Jacob called to his sons” – Rabbi Yudan and Rabbi Pinḥas: Rabbi Yudan said: Jacob called the Almighty to be with his sons. Rabbi Pinḥas said: He invited Him to his sons. Rabbi Avun said: He appointed Him steward for his sons. “He said: Gather ….” – gather from the land of Egypt and assemble in Rameses. Gather from the ten tribes and assemble to the tribe of Judah and Benjamin. He commanded them to act with deference to the tribe of Judah and Benjamin. Rabbi Aḥa said: Purify yourselves, just as it says: “They gathered themselves together…” (Nehemiah 12:28), “and they purified the chambers” (Nehemiah 13:9). The Rabbis say: He commanded them regarding dissension. He said to them: ‘You shall all be one assembly.’ That is what is written: “You, Son of man, take for you one piece of wood, and write on it: [For Judah] and for the children of Israel [his companions]” (Ezekiel 37:16) – it is written “his companion” – the children of Israel became a single group. Prepare yourselves for redemption. What is written thereafter? “I will render you one nation…” (see Ezekiel 37:22).

However, the one question that OP is asking only shows Yaakov's intention and failure to reveal the end of days as almost all commentaries note afterwards:

“[I will tell you] what will befall you at the end of days” – Rabbi Simon said: He showed them the downfall of Gog, just as it says: “It will be at the end of days” (Ezekiel 38:16). Rabbi Yehuda said: He showed them the building of the Temple, just as it says: “It will be at the end of days that the mountain of the House of the Lord will be established” (Micah 4:1). The Rabbis said: He came to reveal the End, but it was concealed from him. Rabbi Yehuda in the name of Rabbi Elazar bar Avina: Two people, the End was revealed to them and was then concealed from them. They are Jacob and Daniel. Daniel – “But you, Daniel, obscure the matters and seal” (Daniel 12:4). Jacob – “what will befall you at the end of days.” “Reuben, you are my firstborn, my strength, and the first of my potency; greater honor and greater power” (Genesis 49:3). “Reuben, you are my firstborn” – this teaches that he came to reveal the End, but it was concealed from him. This is analogous to a king’s confidant who was passing from the world, and his sons were surrounding his bed. He said to them: ‘Come and I will reveal to you the secrets of the king.’ He lifted his eyes and gazed at the king. He said to them: ‘Be vigilant regarding the honor of the king.’ So, Jacob our patriarch lifted his eyes and saw the Divine Presence standing over him. He said to them: ‘Be vigilant regarding the honor of the Holy One blessed be He.’ The Rabbis said: So, the congregation of Koraḥ was sinking and descending, sinking and descending, until Hannah stood and prayed on their behalf: “The Lord puts to death and brings to life; He lowers to the netherworld and elevates” (I Samuel 2:6).

title: Why is Deuteronomy 32:51 in the plural?
content:
# Why is Deuteronomy 32:51 in the plural? ## Frage

Why is Deuteronomy 32:51 in the plural?:

מח וַיְדַבֵּר יְהוָה אֶל-מֹשֶׁה, בְּעֶצֶם הַיּוֹם הַזֶּה לֵאמֹר.

48 And the LORD spoke unto Moses that selfsame day, saying:

מט עֲלֵה אֶל-הַר הָעֲבָרִים הַזֶּה הַר-נְבוֹ, אֲשֶׁר בְּאֶרֶץ מוֹאָב, אֲשֶׁר, עַל-פְּנֵי יְרֵחוֹ; וּרְאֵה אֶת-אֶרֶץ כְּנַעַן, אֲשֶׁר אֲנִי נֹתֵן לִבְנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל לַאֲחֻזָּה.

49 'Get thee up into this mountain of Abarim, unto mount Nebo, which is in the land of Moab, that is over against Jericho; and behold the land of Canaan, which I give unto the children of Israel for a possession;

נ וּמֻת, בָּהָר אֲשֶׁר אַתָּה עֹלֶה שָׁמָּה, וְהֵאָסֵף, אֶל-עַמֶּיךָ: כַּאֲשֶׁר-מֵת אַהֲרֹן אָחִיךָ, בְּהֹר הָהָר, וַיֵּאָסֶף, אֶל-עַמָּיו.

50 and die in the mount whither thou goest up, and be gathered unto thy people; as Aaron thy brother died in mount Hor, and was gathered unto his people.

נא עַל אֲשֶׁר מְעַלְתֶּם בִּי, בְּתוֹךְ בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל, בְּמֵי-מְרִיבַת קָדֵשׁ, מִדְבַּר-צִן--עַל אֲשֶׁר לֹא-קִדַּשְׁתֶּם אוֹתִי, בְּתוֹךְ בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל.

51 Because ye trespassed against Me in the midst of the children of Israel at the waters of Meribath-kadesh, in the wilderness of Zin; because ye sanctified Me not in the midst of the children of Israel.

נב כִּי מִנֶּגֶד, תִּרְאֶה אֶת-הָאָרֶץ; וְשָׁמָּה, לֹא תָבוֹא--אֶל-הָאָרֶץ, אֲשֶׁר-אֲנִי נֹתֵן לִבְנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל. {פ}

52 For thou shalt see the land afar off; but thou shalt not go thither into the land which I give the children of Israel.' {P}

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

It is a reference to Moshe and Aharon as it was originally stated in parshas Chukas, Bamidbar 20:12 also in plural:

וַיֹּ֣אמֶר יְהֹוָה֮ אֶל־מֹשֶׁ֣ה וְאֶֽל־אַהֲרֹן֒ יַ֚עַן לֹא־הֶאֱמַנְתֶּ֣ם בִּ֔י לְהַ֨קְדִּישֵׁ֔נִי לְעֵינֵ֖י בְּנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל לָכֵ֗ן לֹ֤א תָבִ֙יאוּ֙ אֶת־הַקָּהָ֣ל הַזֶּ֔ה אֶל־הָאָ֖רֶץ אֲשֶׁר־נָתַ֥תִּי לָהֶֽם׃

But יהוה said to Moses and Aaron, “Because you did not trust (plural) Me enough to affirm My sanctity in the sight of the Israelite people, therefore you shall not lead this congregation into the land that I have given them.”

As a result of the incident, both Moshe and Aharon were denied to enter Eretz Israel. Perhaps, the name of Aharon, who passed away 7 months earlier, is hinted but not mentioned due to the maxim made of the 3 parsha names: Acharei Moth-Kedoshim-Emor (after death speak only holy things about the [good] person).

title: Why did God (tell Moshe to) tell the Jewish people that they will be bad using some terrible language? Isn't it counterproductive?
content:
# Why did God (tell Moshe to) tell the Jewish people that they will be bad using some terrible language? Isn't it counterproductive? ## Frage

At the end of Vayelach, God tells Moshe how the Jews will be bad and tells Moshe to tell the Jews so (in Haazinu) using some pretty fatalistic language. Isn't it counterproductive and demoralizing? Couldn't God have said that IF you will be bad then... And for Moshe, on his last day(s), it must have been so very demoralizing to hear such things.

I'd like to try to find an answer in one of the commentaries, if possible. Which ones are more likely to have an answer? Ramban, Sforno...? (My Hebrew is not great but I'd like to try...)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The rebuke, no matter how harsh, is always given to people who have ability to correct the problem. The harshness may be indicative of the urgency to do so.

Evidently, the words imply that Moshe Rabbeinu foresaw and knew that, unless people change their attitude, there would be future exiles of the Jewish people. There are several places in the Torah and the commentaries where this idea is repeatedly stated.

Source 1. When Moshe spoke with Hashem at the burning bush he says Shemos 4:13:

But he said, “Please, O my lord, make someone else Your agent.” I.e. make someone else Your agent Lit. “send through whomever You will send.”

Targum Yonasan ben Uziel translates this verse:

And he said, I pray for mercy before the Lord. Send now Thy sending by the hand of Phinehas, by whom it is to be sent at the end of the days.

In other words, exodus from Egypt was supposed to be only the first one. This is also implied in the Rashi's comment:

Another explanation is: by the hand of some other person whom Thou wilt be pleased to send — for in the end “I” shall not bring them into the land of Palestine nor shall “I” become their deliverer in the future — and You have many messengers! (Pirkei DeRabbi Eliezer 40)

Source 2 When Jewish people sinned with making the Golden Calf some of the commentaries explain the image of the calf from Maase Merkava in Yechezkel 1:10

Each of them had a human face [at the front]; each of the four had the face of a lion on the right; each of the four had the face of an ox on the left; and each of the four had the face of an eagle [at the back].

The human form is known to us from the image of keruvim i.e. the mishkan, where the image of human-form keruvim was present inside Kodesh haKodashim. The right side usually symbolizes geula, revelation of Shechina, as Hashem took Jewish people with his right hand out of Egypt. Instead the Jewish people chose the image of the ox from the left which symbolizes galus and distancing of Shechina.

Source 3 In the episode of the bitter waters when Moshe rabbeinu hit the rock, some of the commentaries explain that Moshe did not want to raise the new generation to the level of their parents. For just like their parents faced the test with the Golden Calf and failed it, Moshe rabbeinu thought that the new generation would not be able to successfully emerge from a similar test. In other words, Moshe rabbeinu and the Jewish people accepted the idea of future exiles as an alternative to attempting immediately correct the sin of the Golden Calf (long short road).

Source 4 The Torah section that we read on Tisha b'Av Devarim 4:25-40 speaks about future exiles not as a conditional, but factually.

When you have begotten children and children’s children and are long established in the land, should you act wickedly and make for yourselves a sculptured image in any likeness, causing your God Hashem displeasure and vexation. I call heaven and earth this day to witness against you that you shall soon perish from the land that you are crossing the Jordan to possess; you shall not long endure in it, but shall be utterly wiped out. Hashem will scatter you among the peoples, and only a scant few of you shall be left among the nations to which Hashem will drive you. There you will serve gods of wood and stone, made by human hands, that cannot see or hear or eat or smell.

Therefore, one should understand the words of Moshe rabbeinu not as a harsh rebuke, but the fact of the objective vision of the future. Given that vision, he is teaching Jewish people about how we can survive and carry the message of Hashem who took us out of Mitzraim.
