title: Lashon Hara in the workplace - colleague speaks behind my back to the manager to blame me
content:
# Lashon Hara in the workplace - colleague speaks behind my back to the manager to blame me ## Frage

Case : Lashon Hara in the workplace - how to deal with it?

Hypothetical situation:

I and my teammate forgot to write a report for the manager. The teammate spoke to the manager the next morning and put the blame solely on me. A third colleague, who was an innocent bystander during the talk between the manager and my teammate, told me what had happended.

My guess is that ideally I should first talk to my teammate and ask her why she had done so, then she should apologize to me and go with me to the manager to speak about how to remedy the situation with the report.

What would be the best resolution of the problem?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Social interactions are far too complex for halachah to cover every single permutation. It will tell you what is permitted and what is forbidden, but it can't tell you the best way to deal with the millions of scenarios that arise every day around the world.

You would have to supply far more detail for someone to advise you how to manage your situation, and even if you do manage to extract good and useful advice from the internet it would be more psychology than Judaism, I think.

Yes, maligning you as you described would indeed be Lashon Hara on your colleagues part, but there's no guarantee that pointing this out will bring you any closer to resolving your problem.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

It is a hard situation because a priori you do not know what your co-worker spoke to the manager about and whether your innocent bystander is actually telling the truth. Typically, problems like this one happen at the workplace, but we go to work to do work. The best way to address situation is to try to find out how the report can be produced in the shortest time possible and you certainly need to speak to the manager together with your co-worker about that. Alternatively, if the report is no longer needed you may discuss how to avoid forgetting the assigned tasks by using electronic calendar reminders, sticky notes, and other available tools - by being factual on the task, rather than by trying to give mussar to your teammates.

If you want to sharpen your skills about halachic problems to avoid, you may review any of the sources available such as "The Laws of Interpersonal Relationships" by R. Ehrman.

title: What is the meaning of וְתֵן חֶלְקֵנוּ בְתוֹרָתֶךָ?
content:
# What is the meaning of וְתֵן חֶלְקֵנוּ בְתוֹרָתֶךָ? ## Frage

This phrase appears in 5:20 of Ethics of the Fathers and in our siddur.

One translation is "and grant us our portion in Your Torah" (Sefaria)

But I would think we each have the whole Torah. What is meant by a "portion"?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

It states in many sources, including the Alshich's commentary on Shir Hashirim (1:1 iirc), Chesed LeAvraham, Maayan 2, Nahar 12, 18, etc. that every Jew's soul derives from one of the 600,000 letters of Torah. This is interpreted to mean that there are 600,000 perspectives on the entire Torah, each viewing it in their own way. It's also brought (ibid 13) that each Jew has his own Chiddushim to bring into the world, based on his particular perspective. In fact, nobody else can bring YOUR chiddushim, and nobody even knows about it until YOU bring it into the world, even prophets, sages and tzaddikim. The one exception is Moshe, who has all 600,000 perspectives and chiddushim. This is based on Shaar Hagilgulim 17.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

Perhaps, it is the same idea as Rabbi Kaii's, although from a different angle. One can also explain the words וְתֵן חֶלְקֵנוּ בְתוֹרָתֶךָ using the Hadran tefilah that we recite at the end of finishing a seder of mishnayos or a masekhes of gemara:

מוֹדִים אֲנַחְנוּ לְּפָנֶיךָ יְיָ אֱלֹהֵינוּ וֶאֱלֹהֵי אַבוֹתֵינוּ שֶׁשַּׂמְתָּ חֶלְקֵנוּ מִיּוֹשְׁבֵי בֵּית הַמִּדְרָשׁ, וְלֹא שַׂמְתָּ חֶלְקֵנוּ מִיּוֹשְׁבֵי קְרָנוֹת. שֶׁאָנוּ מַשְׁכִּימִים וְהֵם מַשְׁכִּימִים. אָנוּ מַשְׁכִּימִים לְדִבְרֵי תּוֹרָה וְהֵם מַשְׁכִּימִים לִדְבָרִים בְּטֵלִים. אָנוּ עֲמֵלִים וְהֵם עֲמֵלִים. אָנו עֲמֵלִים וּמְקַבְּלִים שָׂכָר וְהֵם עֲמֵלִים וְאֵינָם מְקַבְּלִים שָׂכָר. אָנוּ רָצִים וְהֵם רָצִים. אָנוּ רָצִים לְחַיֵּי הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא, וְהֵם רָצִים לִבְאֵר שַׁחַת. שֶׁנֱאמַר: וְאַתָּה אֱלֹהִים תּוֹרִדֵם לִבְאֵר שַׁחַת אַנְשֵׁי דָמִים וּמִרְמָה לֹא יֶחֱצוּ יְמֵיהֶם וַאֲנִי אֶבְטַח בָּךְ:

We give thanks before You, Lord, our G-d and G-d of our fathers, for you gave us a share among those who sit in the study hall, and not among those who sit on street corners. For we arise early, and they arise early; we arise for words of Torah, and they arise for words of emptiness. We work, and they work; we work and receive a reward, and they work and do not receive a reward. We run, and they run; we run towards eternal life, and they run to a pit of desolation. As it says: (Psalms 55:24) "And You, O Lord, bring them down into a pit of desolation, people of blood and deceit will not live out half of their days; and I, I will trust in You."

As the prayer explains, the Jewish person oftentimes does all the same activities as anybody else. However, the intent of every action is to identify and perform a rooted in it mitzvah, building a relationship with HKBH. Thus, getting a portion in the Torah, is also a request to connect and reframe one's acquired daily wisdom in the language of our wonderful heritage of the Torah of the Jewish people.

title: (How) was Abaye able to endanger Rav Acha?
content:
# (How) was Abaye able to endanger Rav Acha? ## Frage

Kiddushin 29b tells a story of Abaye hearing that Rav Acha was coming to his study hall. It happened to be that there was a 7-headed demon in the study hall who would injure those that entered so Abaye instructed everyone not to extend lodging to Rav Acha (forcing Rav Acha to lodge in the study hall). Miraculously Rav Acha was able to dispense the demon, but afterwards indicates that if a miracle hadn't happened for him, he would have been in danger.

Several questions

  1. Why would Abaye tell his students not to invite Rav Acha, isn't he telling them to violate the mitzvah of hachnasat orchim? (and if so why did they listen?)
  2. Why does Abaye feel he can put Rav Acha in danger and rely on a miracle (he is actually recorded as saying "maybe a miracle will happen) - I thought there is a principle of not relying on miracles
  3. Why all the subterfuge, if Abaye believe Rav Acha will prevail, why not let him sleep in someone's home and then tell him what the problem is and invite him into the Beit Midrash during the day?

Full text of the incident from Sefaria

שְׁמַע אַבָּיֵי דְּקָא הֲוָה אָתֵי. הֲוָה הָהוּא מַזִּיק בֵּי רַבָּנַן דְּאַבָּיֵי, דְּכִי הֲווֹ עָיְילִי בִּתְרֵין אֲפִילּוּ בִּימָמָא הֲווֹ מִיתַּזְּקִי. אֲמַר לְהוּ: לָא לִיתֵּיב לֵיהּ אִינָשׁ אוּשְׁפִּיזָא, אֶפְשָׁר דְּמִתְרְחִישׁ נִיסָּא.

Abaye heard that Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov was coming. There was a certain demon in the study hall of Abaye, which was so powerful that when two people would enter they would be harmed, even during the day. Abaye said to the people of the town: Do not give Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov lodging [ushpiza] so that he will be forced to spend the night in the study hall. Since Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov is a righteous man, perhaps a miracle will occur on his behalf and he will kill the demon.

עָל, בָּת בְּהָהוּא בֵּי רַבָּנַן. אִידְּמִי לֵיהּ כְּתַנִּינָא דְּשִׁבְעָה רֵישְׁווֹתֵיהּ. כֹּל כְּרִיעָה דִּכְרַע נְתַר חַד רֵישֵׁיהּ. אֲמַר לְהוּ לִמְחַר: אִי לָא אִיתְרְחִישׁ נִיסָּא סַכֵּינְתִּין.

Rav Aḥa found no place to spend the night, and he entered and spent the night in that study hall of the Sages. The demon appeared to him like a serpent with seven heads. Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov began to pray, and with every bow that he bowed one of the demon’s heads fell off, until it eventually died. The next day Rav Aḥa said to the townspeople: If a miracle had not occurred, you would have placed me in danger.

title: Wrong Bracha Covers Other Food?
content:
# Wrong Bracha Covers Other Food? ## Frage

A Bracha made on one food covers anything same Bracha that A) one intends to consume in that sitting, or B) exists on one’s plate or table.
Thus, for example, if I’m sitting at a table with steak and mushrooms, I can make a Bracha (שֶהַּכֹּל) on one mushroom, then take and eat as many mushrooms and steaks as I want without making additional Brachot. I can also bring some more mushrooms from the refrigerator, and eat them without a new Bracha.

Can a Bracha cover food if the intent was directed at something not covered by the Bracha?

For example, if I accidentally said העץ on a cucumber, does that cover any apples on the table that I intend to eat?

What if the apples aren’t yet on the table, but I decide to eat them immediately after making the mistake? Would I have to make a new, correct העץ for the apples?

Does it make a difference if I genuinely thought cucumbers are העץ, or if it was just a slip of the tongue?

title: Yom Kippur that falls on Shabbat - Kiddush for the kids?
content:
# Yom Kippur that falls on Shabbat - Kiddush for the kids? ## Frage

Specifically regarding a situation where one has young children who eat on Yom Kippur - is it a good idea, an obligation, forbidden, or a variable custom to make a proper Friday night for them, with Kiddush and/or Challa, and/or the usual food?

Please cite sources, and specifics.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

This would be forbidden. Healthy adults, even if they don't have to make kiddush, do have to say Shehechiyanu on the holiday and that is supposed to be done on a cup of wine (on other holidays, with kiddush). The Talmud (Eruvin 40b) rejects the suggestion to let children drink the wine for an adult since the children may get used to drinking wine on Yom Kippur and think that is allowed. Accordingly, adults are stuck and recite Shehechiyanu without a cup of wine. We see that we should not teach children to ritually eat specific things on Yom Kippur, even at the expense of doing a mitzva.

title: Sleep Paralysis in Torah?
content:
# Sleep Paralysis in Torah? ## Frage

My friend recently mentioned to me that he has sleep paralysis and I was wondering what the Torah has to say about it:

  1. Why does it happen according to the Torah?
  2. How does one stop it from happening again according to the Torah?
  3. Does it affect someone spiritually speaking?

Please provide sources that directly/indirectly speak about/or describe sleep paralysis.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

If this is a longtime physical malady that has been part of the human condition then it wouldn't be surprising if there was some actual indication of this in old sources.

Of any Torah source that might hint to this physical condition (albeit a bit of a stretch without further proof and sources) is the pasuk in Shir HaShirim:

שיר השירים ה:ב - אני ישנה ולבי ער

"I am asleep but my heart is awake..."

(Hey, we are reading this pasuk tomorrow and one of my kids was just playing a song with these words - it hit home since I first viewed this question within the last few days)

Perhaps the Targum there gives us a slightly better opportunity to connect this with sleep paralysis:

כִּגְבַר דָּמֵיךְ דְּלָא יְכִיל לְאִתְּעָרָא מִשִּׁינְתֵיהּ וְקָל רוּחָא דְּקוּדְשָׁא מַזְהֲרָא לְהוֹן עַל יַד נְבִיַּיָּא וַהֲוָת עָיְרָא יָתְהוֹן מִדְּמוּךְ לִבְּהוֹן

Which starts describing a sleeping person who is not able to awake from his sleep (still a bit of a stretch).

However, I did notice a recent sefer (בלבבי משכן אבנה - יהונתן חן - תשפ"ב - עמ' קפו - available on Otzar HaChochma) where the author believes the condition of sleep paralysis (שיתוק שינה in modern Hebrew) was already described by R. Chaim Vital in his Sefer Eitz Chaim 5:5 where he quotes the Zohar to say that:

כי בלילה תרעין דגן עדן סתימין

At night, the gates of Gan Eden are closed

is a סוד that encapsulates the following ideas (especially see the highlighted words ואינו יכול לקום מאליו עד שיקראוהו ויעורר נפשו):

ונאמר אני ישנ"ה בגימ' שס"ה כי השס"ה גידין של דם הוא מהנקבה הנקרא אני והם הישנים ומסתלק כל כח הנפש בתוך הלב לבדו. ובזה תבין למה האדם מתעורר תכף מתוך שינתו כי אין לו צורך רק שיתפשט מן הלב בתוך הגידין וזה סיבת אדם המצטער כשידו מונחת על לבו בשינתו כי הנפש אינה יכולה לדפוק ע"י הדם בשאר איברים ואז האדם צועק ואינו יכול לקום מאליו עד שיקראוהו ויעורר נפשו ואז יכול להתפשט באיבריו בכח חוזק הקריאה. וז"ס פ' פנחס דף רכ"ב כי בלילה תרעין דג"ע סתימין דאינון עיינין דלבא כגוונא דתיבת נח דכל נהורין סתימין בגווה ואינון מלאכין דמתפשטין בכל איברי דגופא כולהו סתימין בלבא כי הנפש יש בה אחיזה להקליפות בהיותן בלי רוח בסוד גם בלא דעת נפש לא טוב לכן נסגרת ונסתמת היא וכחותיה תוך הלב מפני מי המבול הם המזיקין. והענין כי בהיותה מתפשטת נאחזים בה ובהסגירה אין מי שיוכל לינק משם בסוד גן נעול אחותי כלה גל נעול מעין חתום והבן זה בסוד חותם בתוך חותם שצריך ליין כדי שלא יתנסך.

Here is a translation of the sections above that most closely describe something akin to sleep paralysis:

ובזה תבין למה האדם מתעורר תכף מתוך שינתו כי אין לו צורך

...and in this you will understand why a person wakes up immediately from his sleep unnecessarily...

ואז האדם צועק ואינו יכול לקום מאליו עד שיקראוהו ויעורר נפשו ואז יכול להתפשט באיבריו בכח חוזק הקריאה

...and then the person screams and cannot get up on his own until he is called and his soul is awakened, and then he can stretch out his limbs through the strength of that forceful call...

I will hold back from a full translation of the Eitz Chaim quote since I am not proficient at all in נסתר and therefore will not do it justice without knowledge of the underlying kabbalistic concepts. The full quote was provided mainly to offer context and flow for where R. Chaim Vital discusses something that very closely resembles sleep paralysis. If someone else feels they can do a proper job, feel free to edit the translation into this answer.

Note that Sefer Eitz Chaim does point to the aforementioned pasuk "אני ישנה" as connected with this idea and references other nearby phrases from Shir HaShirim.

I hope this gives you a start. He seems to imply a spiritual paralysis that manifests itself physically - quite possibly in what we now call sleep paralysis.

title: Are you allowed to make liquid nitrogen ice cream on Yom Tov
content:
# Are you allowed to make liquid nitrogen ice cream on Yom Tov ## Frage

Liquid nitrogen is a liquid version of nitrogen gas and hence very cold. This ice cream involves sugar, chocolate syrup, milk --liquid nitrogen is poured in as one stirs vigorously. When all have evaporated, what left is soft ice cream--ready to eat.

title: How did Amram marry Yocheved, his aunt?
content:
# How did Amram marry Yocheved, his aunt? ## Frage

The Gemara Bava Batra 17a, lists Amram as one of the four people who never sinned. However, he married his aunt, which is forbidden in Vayikra 18:12.

If you are going to say that because it was before Matan Torah it was okay, Bnei Yisrael still kept the Torah before then, except in more extenuating circumstances. Can you explain what made Amram decide that he should marry her?

Also, does that imply that anyone (including the Avot), who lived before Matan Torah and is not on the list, did one of the Sheva Mitzvot Bnei Noach?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Avos kept the Torah in the strict sense that OP defines including takanos derabonnan only when they were inside Eretz Yisrael. Outside of Eretz Israel, since they were not commanded to observe the mitzvos they could violate them in certain cases in extenuating circumstances. For example,

  • Yaakov married two sisters in Lavan's house. He had to marry Rachel, but Lavan forced upon him marriage with Leah. When the family returned home to Eretz Israel, one of his wives, Rachel, died as discussed here.
  • Abraham gave his guests dairy food as a snack prior to them having a meat meal can be seen in the same way as we should ideally have a Shavuoth dairy meal as described here.
  • One can even say, that arguments between brothers parallel the arguments Bais Shammai and Bais Hillel. Mishna Yebamos 6:6 says:

A man may not neglect the mitzva to be fruitful and multiply unless he already has children. Beit Shammai say: One fulfills this mitzva with two males, and Beit Hillel say: A male and a female, as it is stated: “Male and female He created them” (Genesis 5:2).

  • Yosef son of Yaakov had 2 sons and stopped having more children due to upcoming famine since he fulfilled the mitzvah according to Beis Shammai. Levi son of Yaakov continued having children until he had a daughter Yocheved according to Beis Hillel.

Amram and Yocheved lived in Mitzraim, outside of Eretz Israel. Remarriage of Amram to Yocheved is described in Gemara Sota 12a when she was 130 years old. The gemara points out that there was a miracle:

Rabbi Yehuda says: The signs of a young woman were born in her when her husband remarried her, and she became like a young girl again.

The same story is also discussed in Midrash Shemos Rabba 1:19. Interestingly, Midrash Sefer haYashar, Parshas Shemos 19 uses the same language to the original marriage of Amram and Yocheved:

איש היה בארץ מצרים מזרע לוי, ושמו עמרם בן קהת בן לוי בן ישראל. וילך האיש ההוא ויקח אישה את יוכבד בת לוי אחות אביו, והיא בת מאה ושש ועשרים שנים ויבוא אליה. ותהר האישה ותלד בת ותקרא שמה מרים, כי בימים ההם מיררו מצרים את חיי בני ישראל. ותהר עוד ותלד בן ותקרא שמו אהרון, כי בימי הרותה החל פרעה לשפוך דמי זכורי בני ישראל.

And there was a man in the land of Egypt, from the seed ‎of Levi, and his name was Amram, son of Kehath, son of Levi, the son of Israel. And this man ‎went and took for a wife Yokheved, the daughter of Levi, the sister of his father, and she was ‎one hundred and twenty-six years of age when he came unto her. And the woman conceived ‎and bare a daughter, and she called her name Miriam, for in those days the Egyptians ‎embittered the lives of the children of Israel; and she conceived again. And bare a son, and she ‎called his name Aaron, for in the days of her pregnancy Pharaoh began to spill the blood of the ‎male children in Israel.

The midrash proves that the original marriage of Amram and Yocheved happened under extenuating circumstances. As Amram was Gadol haDor the miracle with his 126 year old wife (R. Chaim Kanievsky corrects 124 year old) served to show that even in such circumstances people should continue having children.

Family is built on mutual trust. All Avos married within a family, for example, because it is easier to have trust to one's own kin as Avraham instructed Eliezer. Eisav was the first one who married outside the family. However, his most expensive item he kept in his parents' house. It was the coat that he took from Nimrod, which Yaakov borrowed to get a blessing from Yitzchak. Eisav did so in relatively good times because he could not trust his wives. Many Rabbis in gemara married their nieces for this reason. Difficult times put big strain on relationships that are not strong. Amram was gadol hador, and did not want to endanger shalom bayis due to extenuating circumstances of crushing Egyptian hostility.

title: Where does the Medrash quote the Torah differently from the masoretic text?
content:
# Where does the Medrash quote the Torah differently from the masoretic text? ## Frage

The Wikipedia page on Midrash says as follows:

Although this material treats the biblical texts as the authoritative word of God, it is clear that not all of the Hebrew Bible was fixed in its wording at this time, as some verses that are cited differ from the Masoretic, and accord with the Septuagint, or Samaritan Torah instead.

Can anyone provide examples of this? What is the rabbinic response to the suggestion that the Torah wasn't "fixed in its wording" as the explanation for the Medrash quoting pesukim that align with "alternative" texts instead of the Torah?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

This issue is addressed in Tosafos to Shabbos 128a :

ונתן הכסף וקם לו - אין הפסוק כן אלא ויסף חמישית כסף ערכך עליו וקם לו (ויקרא כ״ז:ט״ו) ודרך הש"ס לקצר ולומר בלשון אחר קצר כי ההיא דפרק הדר (עירובין דף סה.) רבי חנינא ביומא דרתח לא מצלי שנאמר בצר אל יורה ובפרק הרואה (ברכות דף נה:) שנאמר כל החלומות הולכים אחר הפה

It is normal for Chazal to not be precise when quoting pesukim. So showing differences in wording does not necessarily indicate that they had a different text.

(This is assuming the issue is not simply a copyist's error.)

title: Messiah in every generation
content:
# Messiah in every generation ## Frage

When I was steeped in Judaism, particularly Chabad, I remember this notion that there is a "Moshiach in every generation", waiting for the right moment if the generation warrants it.

One particular example I remember is King Hezekiah, which as it turns out is discussed in Sanhedrin 94a.

I am wondering if this concept indeed exists, and if so, if it has a name.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Here is a quote from Shut Chatam Sofer collected responsa Responsa 98:

והנה בהא דביאת בן דוד צריך אני להוציע הוצעה א' והוא כמו שהי' משרע"ה שהי' הגואל הראשון נזדקין שמנים שנה ולא ידע ולא הרגיש בעצמו שהוא יהי' גואל ישראל ואפי' כשאמר לו הקב"ה לך כי אשלחך אל פרעה מ"מ סירב ולא רצה לקבל על עצמו כן יהי' אי"ה הגואל האחרון ומיום שחרב בהמ"ק מיד נולד א' הראוי' בצדקתו להיות גואל ולכשיגיע הזמן יגלה אליו השי"ת וישלחו ואז יערה עליו רוחו של משיח הטמון וגנוז למעלה עד בוא וכאשר מצינו בשאול אחר שנמשח באה עליו רוח ממשלה ורוח הקודש אשר מלפנים לא הרגיש בעצמו כן הי' בגואל הראשון וכן יהי' בגואל האחרון והצדיק הזה בעצמו אינו יודע ובעונותינו כי רבו כבר כמה וכמה מתו ולא זכינו שיערה עליהם רוחו של משיח גם כי הם ראוי' לכך אבל הדור לא הי' ראוי' אולם כשיגיע אי"ה יגלה אליו ה' כמו למשה בסנה וישלחהו או לישראל לבד או למלך א' כמו לפרעה לומר שלח עמי:

He states that in each generation there is someone fitting to be Mashiach, but it is not revealed to the person himself until the generation is fitting to be redeemed.

He will then notify this person, instruct him regarding his mission, and empower him to fulfill it.

The precedent for this; is Moses, who was 80 years old, and until G-d appeared to him, and instructed him to redeem the Israelites, Moses had no clue that he was destined to be their redeemer.

title: If a reliable person tells you that an item, bearing an otherwise reliable hechsher, is in fact NOT kosher, are you required to investigate the claim?
content:
# If a reliable person tells you that an item, bearing an otherwise reliable hechsher, is in fact NOT kosher, are you required to investigate the claim? ## Frage

Suppose I purchase a package of fresh steak bearing a very reliable and respected Hechsher (Kashrut symbol). Before starting up the BBQ, my friend passing by notices the steak and informs me that his son, who works at the slaughterhouse, has become of aware of very questionable practices that call into question the products' kosher status.

Shocked at this claim, I phoned the kosher certifier, and asked them if I can rely on their certification. I was assured that I can absolutely rely on it, and that all Kashrut protocols are strictly followed.

I am torn about what to do. Who do I rely on? My friend is a very refined and scholarly man, as is his son, and have no reason to make this story up. On the other hand, the certifier is insisting there are no issues.

Am I obligated to do my own further investigation? Can I still choose to rely on the Hechsher even though I have plausible claims that it cannot be relied on?

What is the halacha?

title: Does the mouthpiece of the shofar have to be at the tip of the horn?
content:
# Does the mouthpiece of the shofar have to be at the tip of the horn? ## Frage

This Irish ram's horn has a hole bored in the middle of the horn. Is this acceptable as a shofar or does it count as a hole in the shofar?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RITlXgK0OZY

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Interesting question! I could not find this question addressed directly with the little bit of research that I did, but I assume that it's not good.

A different shofar "hack" is discussed in Shulchan Aruch (OC 586:12):

הפכו ותקע בו לא יצא בין הפכו כדרך שהופכין החלוק שהחזיר פנימי לחיצון בין שהניחו כמו שהיה אלא שהרחיב את הקצר וקיצר את הרחב וה"ה אם תקע במקום הרחב פסול (ר"ן פ"ב דר"ה): ‏

  1. If one inverted it, he has not fulfilled his obligation, whether he inverts it like one inverts a shirt, flipping the inside and the outside, or whether one leaves it as it was but widens the narrow side and narrows the wide side. Similarly, if one blows through the wide side, it is not kosher (Ra"n chapter 2 of Rosh Hashanah).

Mishna Berura (ad loc., 60) explains:

בין הפכו כדרך וכו' - והטעם דכתיב והעברת שופר תרועה דרך העברה בעינן דהיינו כדרך שהאיל מעבירו בראשו מחיים: ‏

Whether he inverts it etc.: The reason is because it is written "Then you shall sound (והעברת) the horn loud," which means that it must be done in the direction of passing (דרך העברה). That is, in the direction that the ram passes the horn while alive.

Additionally, the Ra"n (as cited in Kaf Hachayim) would likely not either support this unorthodox horn construction:

כ"כ הר"ן בפ' ראוהו ב"ד בשם הירושלמי. ויהיב סימנא מן המצר קראתי יה. ‏

The Ra"n provides a mnemonic device to recall this halacha (of not blowing from the wide end of the shofar) from the verse in Tehillim 118 "In distress (מצר; literally, "narrow place") I called on the LORD."

Although not directly addressed in these sources, it seems reasonable to me to assume that the reasonings of דרך העברה and מן המצר would also invalidate a shofar that is blown from a hole in the middle of the horn.

title: How did Zechariah the son of Berechiah die?
content:
# How did Zechariah the son of Berechiah die? ## Frage

Inspired by this question on Biblical Hermeneutics

The Christian New Testament in Matthew 23:35 says:

And that upon you may come all the righteous blood shed upon the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel unto the blood of Zechariah, son of Barachias, whom ye slew between the temple and the altar.

There's a debate in Christianity as to whether this refers to the same Zechariah who wrote the prophetic book of Zechariah. The Bible records a different Zechariah (the son of Jehoiada) being killed in the temple, but nothing about the death of Zechariah the son of Berechiah. My question is, according to Jewish tradition, how did Zechariah the son of Berechiah, the author of the book, die? Is this New Testament text referencing a known contemporary tradition?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 13)

Welcome to Mi Yodeya.

I actually wrote an essay for a course at uni on this topic about a year ago.

The NT is referencing a Jewish tradition that appears in several other sources in variant forms. The oldest inherently Jewish version was preserved in Vitae Prophetarum, a Greek apocryphal work describing the lives of various Tanachic prophets (including extra-biblical tidbits) that many scholars believe was translated from a now-lost Hebrew vorlage authored by Jews, perhaps circa the 1st century CE. David Satran, Biblical Prophets in Byzantine Palestine: Reassessing the Lives of the Prophets, Leiden 1995, is of the opinion that the work is of Christian Byzantine origins, but concedes that the stories of Zechariah b. Jehoiada and Isaiah are likely much older Jewish traditions.

In the chapter on the life of Zechariah b. Jehoiada it says (C. C. Torrey, The Lives of the Prophets: Greek Text and Translation, Philadelphia, PA 1946, p. 47):

"He was of Jerusalem, the son of Jehoiada the priest, the prophet whom Joash king of Judah slew beside the alter, whose blood the house of David shed within the sanctuary, in the court. The priests buried him beside his father.

From that time on there were portentous appearances in the temple, and the priests could see no vision of angels of God, nor give forth oracles from the inner sanctuary; nor were they able to inquire with the ephod, nor to give answer to the people by Urim and Thummim, as in former time."

As you can see, the story is about Zechariah b. Jehoiada, not Zechariah b. Berechiah. From your OP, I gather that you're probably aware of various explanations for why the NT references Ben Berechiah, so I won't get into that. Suffice it to say that the Jewish versions have always, to my knowledge, recounted this theme of the blood of the prophet Zechariah as referring to Ben Jehoiada.

Several more traditional Jewish sources include a variant of this tradition in the form of an aggada describing what happened when the Babylonian general Nebuzaradan came to Jerusalem. The chronologically oldest source that contains this version is the Jerusalem Talmud, tractate Ta'anit 4:6 (often 4:5 in printed editions) (my translation from MS Leiden):

"Rabbi Yohanan said: "80000 priestly youths were killed over the blood of Zechariah."
Rabbi Yudan asked Rabbi Aha: "Where did they kill Zechariah? In the Women's Court or in the Court of Israel? He replied: "Not in the Court of Israel nor in the Women's Court but in the Priestly Court, and they did not take care of his blood as one would with the blood of a ram or a stag. There it says "that person shall pour out its blood and cover it with earth." However, here the case was that "I set her blood on the bare rock". And why? "so that it may stir [My] fury and to take vengeance, that is why I set her blood on the bare rock without cover."

Seven transgressions were committed by Israel that day. They killed a priest, and a prophet, and a judge, and spilled clean blood. And defiled the Court. And it was a Sabbath and Yom Kippur.

And when Nebuzardan came here he saw the blood bubbling. He said to them: "What is the nature of this?" They replied: "It is the blood of oxen and sheep and rams that we had sacrificed on the altar." They brought oxen and rams and sheep and he slaughtered them upon it and still the blood bubbled. And since they did not admit [the truth] to him, he hung them on the gallows. They said: "This is because the Holy One, Blessed is He demands his blood from us." They said to him: "That is the blood of a priest and prophet and judge who prophesied against us all that you are doing to us and we rose upon him and killed him." And so he brought 80000 priestly youths and slaughtered them, and still the blood bubbled. In that hour, he [Nebuzardan] scolded it and said to it: "What do you wish, to fell your entire nation over you?" With this, the Holy One, Blessed is He was filled with mercy and said: "What with that he is flesh and blood and cruel but has mercy for My children. I, upon whom it is said "for your God is a compassionate God, who will not fail you nor let you perish and will not forget the covenant of your forefathers" must be all the more so." He motioned to [the blood] and it was swallowed in its place."

There are several chronologically later versions of this aggadic tradition in other sources: Peskita de'Rav Kahana 15:7 (Mandelbaum edition, pp. 257-259), Eicha Rabbah 4:13 (4:16 in some versions; and several shorter references in other places in Eicha Rabbah), Kohelet Rabbah 10:4, and more. Each version subtly edited the tradition, altering sometimes extensively the moral of the story. In the Jerusalem Talmud, the story is presented as part of a compilation of stories and traditions related to the destruction of the two Temples and the tragic end of the Bar Kokhba Revolt. The gist of the story here is that the Jews sinned and brought the punishment upon themselves, but in the end God will have mercy. In several later versions, the blame gradually shifts from the Jews to Zechariah himself (Kohelet Rabbah states explicitly that Zechariah brought his death upon himself and is also to blame for the deaths of the people killed by Nebuzardan!).

In my essay, I argued that the NT also subtly altered the tradition, and this is most evident in the Matthian version. This version, as opposed to the Lukian version, uses the Greek phrase αἷμα δίκαιον, which means "righteous blood". Some English translators translate it to mean "innocent blood", but the Greek phrase is nearly consistently used in the LXX as a translation of the Hebrew "דַּם צַדִּיקִים" (blood of the righteous).1 I believe that it was the author's intent to reference the verse in Lamentations 4:13 "It was for the sins of her prophets, the iniquities of her priests, who had shed in her midst the blood of the righteous", whose LXX translation likewise uses the phrase αἷμα δίκαιον for "blood of the righteous". The idea presented in the verse in Lamentations is that the Judahites are to be blamed for all of the bad things that befell them, because they had killed their prophets and priests. The NT draws a connection between the sins described in Lamentations and the sins of its story's present (the death of Jesus, supposedly the fault of the Jews) and uses the tradition of the blood of Zechariah as proof that the Jews (equated with the Judahites) are prophet-killers and deserve to be punished. In this, the NT identified the "blood of the righteous" of Lamentations with the blood of the prophets and priests killed by the Jews.

In my opinion, the subtle editing of the Jewish version in later midrashic compilations was a reaction - at least in part - to this Christian polemic. Jewish exegetes used their versions to argue against the Christian version: In the Eicha Rabbah version, the phrase "blood of the righteous" clearly refers to the masses slaughtered by Nebuzardan to appease Zechariah's bubbling blood. And the aggadic unit ends with the phrase "and upon that time it is said: "It was for the sins of her prophets, the iniquities of her priests, who had shed in her midst the blood of the righteous" (Lam 4:13) - upon the death of the Judahites at the hand of Nebuzardan, not upon the deaths of the priests and prophets killed earlier by the Judahites. And, of course, all versions end with God's mercy towards the Judahites, as opposed to the NT's view, which is that Jews are undeserving of mercy.

Point is, yes, the NT is referencing a contemporary, and perhaps even older Jewish tradition, but it altered it in a way that suited its own exegetical needs. I would say that the "purest" (i.e., least polemically altered) versions are those presented in the Vitae Prophetarum and the Jerusalem Talmud.2

As for the death of Zechariah b. Berechiah in Jewish sources, to my knowledge the only mention of his death is in relation to the end of the prophetic period when Alexander conquered the Land of Israel. He seems to have died more or less at the same time as the prophets Haggai and Malachi, and likely in a natural way. For example (Seder Olam Zuta):

"And in [the days of Meshulam, son of Zerubbabel] the Greek Empire rose up and ruled, during the 52nd year of the Persian and Median Empire. And Haggai, Zechariah and Malachi died. And prophecy left Israel."

1 Such is the case in the LXX's translation of Deut 19:10, 21:8, 27:25; Kgs II 21:16, 24:4; Jer 26:15; Ps 106:38. The one exception which translates the phrase "דם נקי" (clean blood) as αἷμα δίκαιον is Prov 6:17, however it is generally agreed that the LXX of Proverbs as we have it today is vastly different from the septuagints of the other books of the Bible. Moreover, as T. A. W. Van der Louw, Transformations in the Septuagint: Towards an Interaction of Septuagint Studies and Translation Studies, Leuven, Paris and Dudley, MA 2007, pp. 308-309 pointed out, it's quite possible that αἷμα δίκαιον was used in this verse to contrast the "לשון שקר" (lying tongue) in the same verse, which is translated by the phonetically similar γλῶσσα ἄδικος.

2 There is, however, a slight possibility that the version of the midrash preserved in Pesikta de'Rav Kahana 15:7 echoes a tradition similar to the one brought in the NT, through which the story of the blood of the prophet Zechariah could be related to Zechariah b. Berechiah/b. Jeberechiah. In this version of the story, the midrash is presented as an exposition on the words "[Jerusalem] was filled with righteousness, but now murderers" (Isaiah 1:21). After a note by Rabbi Yudah b. Rabbi Simon on the immoral downfall of Jerusalem, it says:

"But now murderers [fill Jerusalem]" - they commit murders. There they killed Zechariah and Uriah."

And from there the midrash continues along more or less the same lines as the version in the Jerusalem Talmud. However, the mention of Uriah is significant. The prophet Uriah who was killed by the Judahites was Uriah b. Shemaiah from Kiryath-jearim (Jeremiah 26:20-23). But mentioning Zechariah with Uriah seems to have been intended to evoke memories of Zechariah b. Jeberechiah and Uriah the Priest, Isaiah's two witnesses who testify to the downfall of Judah's enemies (Isaiah 8:1-4), and in the aggadah, the coming redemption (see e.g. Makkot 24b linked below). This version of the midrash appears to implicitly state that the Jews were so far gone in evilness, that they even murdered the two individuals who were supposed to herald the coming of the days of peace! In traditional Jewish sources, Zechariah b. Jeberechiah is identified with Zechariah b. Berechiah (see for example: Babylonian Talmud, Tractate Makkot 24b). As for Uriah the Priest, there are various suggestions, but the Pesikta's own suggestion is that he is indeed to be identified with Uriah b. Shemaiah (13:12).

Of course, there is no evidence that this is anything other than the editor of the Pesikta's own development of a popular aggadic unit, but it is possible that he based it on some now-lost oral or written tradition that was similar to the one that found its way to the NT.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Shalom,

We know from 2 Chronicles 24:22 that Zechariah ben Jehoiada was killed, obviously, and the numerous expansions on the significance of this in Jewish tradition (as cited in the answers here).

Interestingly, Josephus mentions the death of Zechariah ben Baruch (~60AD) in the Temple (Wars of the Jews, Book 6.5.4). Obviously, Yeshua of Nazareth would not be referring to him as it is too late, but the cyclical parallel is important, as Jewish history is Jewish prophecy, i.e. maaseh avot siman l'banim (the actions of the fathers serve as a portent for the children), which I believe is provides the key to unlocking the narrative of Matthew 23. This is Yeshua's attempt to avert the Churban HaBayit, and to hasten the Geulah, by bringing a rebuke, the words of which can be found in Talmudic literature, i.e. Sotah 22b, Yoma 72b. Unfortunately, when people read Matthew 23 out of context, they derive conclusions opposite of the intent of the text (i.e. antisemitic diatribes). As we know, the one who rebukes is the one who loves, i.e. "Let Bilaam who hates Israel bless them, and let Moshe who loves Israel rebuke them." (Yalqut Shimoni). This leads us to Zechariah ben Berekiah (ben Iddo).

Do we have any Jewish tradition of the death of Zechariah ben Berachiah (ben Iddo) that would align with the words in Matthew 23? The answer is yes:

חֲזֵי יְיָ וּתְהֵי מִסְתַּכֵּל מִן שְׁמַיָּא לְמַן אִיסְתַּקִיפְתָּא כִּדְנַן אִם חֲזֵי לִבְנָתָא דְיִשְׂרָאֵל לְמֵיכַל פֵּירֵי בִטְנֵיהוֹן עוּלְמַיָּא רְגִיגְתָא דַהֲווּ מְלַפְפִין בִּסְדִינִין דְמֵלָתֵיהּ עֲנַת מִדַּת דִינָא וְכֵן אֲמָרַת אִם חֲזֵי לְמִקְטַל בְּבֵית מוּקְדְּשָׁא דַייָ כַּהֲנָא וּנְבִיָּא כְּמָה דִקְטַלְתּוּן יָת זְכַרְיָה בַּר עִידּוֹ כַּהֲנָא רַבָּא וּנְבִיָּא מְהֵימָן בְּבֵית מוּקְדְשָׁא דַייָ בְּיוֹמָא דְכִפּוּרַיָּא עַל דְאוֹכַח יַתְכוֹן דְלָא תַעַבְדוּן דְבִישׁ קֳדַם יְיָ:

“See, O L-rd, and observe from heaven against whom you have turned. Thus is it right for the daughters of Israel to eat the fruit of their wombs due to starvation, the lovely boys wrapped in fine linen? The Attribute of Justice replied, and said, “Is it right to kill priest and prophet in the Temple of the L-RD, as when you killed Zechariah son of Iddo, the High Priest and faithful prophet in the Temple of the L-rd on the Day of Atonement because he admonished you not to do evil before the L-rd?” (Targum Lamentations 2:20, translated by C.M.M. Brady, Sefaria.org)

Considering that Zechariah ben Berekhiah (ben Iddo) - see Zechariah 1:2, Ezra 5:1, 6:14 - prophesied the destruction of the Temple (Zechariah 11:1, see Yoma 39b for commentary), and after his death nevuah (prophecy) departed, the same situation (right down to the victim's first name) recycles, to provide the generation the merit to truly repent, thus the three Zechariahs, along with the nevi'im and the tzaddikim, dating all the way back to Hevel form a cyclical chain that recurs over and over again until we pass the test.

title: Usage of the Sch'wa nekuda
content:
# Usage of the Sch'wa nekuda ## Frage

I noticed there are many questions on Mi Yodeya to clarify the pronunciation of the Sch'wa na vs. Sch'wa nach, both having the same nekuda אְ, with elaborate rules distinguishing the two. It seems this controversy could have been completely avoided if the Sch'wa nach would not be marked at all, i.e. א. I assume the masoretes invented this nekuda at the same time as the other vowel signs. What was the reason to use the Sch'wa nekuda in both cases as opposed to only the case of Sch'wa na, which somewhat resembles the vowel?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Geoffrey Khan has the following proposal (Vowel Length and Syllable Structure in the Tiberian Tradition of Biblical Hebrew, p. 57), which requires some understanding of the Tiberian reading tradition to appreciate.

In the Tiberian reading tradition, long vowels appeared in more closed syllables than in modern reading traditions, and was in fact the general rule. There is evidence (some presented in the above article) that in such syllables, an epenthetic vowel would be added before the closing consonant. For example, שָׁמְרוּ would be pronounced /šɔ̄-ɔm-rū/, where the super-long syllable /šɔ̄m/ would be opened up by an epenthetic /ɔ/ (the sound of kamatz). Elsewhere (here, p. 289), Khan writes that the "furtive pataḥ" (the /a/ in רוּחַ /rū-aḥ/) is this same epenthetic vowel, just with a different vowel quality due to the following gutteral.

Now we can understand when Khan writes (emphasis mine):

In the early masoretic and grammatical sources there are allusions to the fact that the šəwa was sometimes mobile. In fact there may have been a degree of variation among individual readers as to whether a šəwa in a given word was made mobile or quiescent. The alternation between mobile or quiescent šəwa did not change the word form in any significant way. In each case the preceding vowel was long and was appropriate for secondary stress: שָׁמְרוּ = šɔ̄-mə-rū ~ šɔ̄-ɔm-rū. ru. It may be said that in these structures there existed a non-distinctive phonotactic variation: consonant + epenthetic ~ epenthetic + consonant. It was doubtless on account of this non-distinctive alternation that both quiescent and mobile šəwa were represented by the same sign.

There's a chiyuv to eat on erev yom kippur. How much does one have to eat? If he eats k'zais or k'grogeres he did his chiyuv and he can fast the rest of the day? title: "I am nothing" is the epitome of humility. Why not "I am worse than nothing"?
content:
# "I am nothing" is the epitome of humility. Why not "I am worse than nothing"? ## Frage

The gemara in Chullin records a beautiful teaching of Rabbi Eliezer son of Rabbi Yossi HaGalili:

אמר רבי יוחנן משום רבי אלעזר בר' שמעון כל מקום שאתה מוצא דבריו של רבי אליעזר בנו של רבי יוסי הגלילי בהגדה עשה אזניך כאפרכסת (דברים ז, ז) לא מרבכם מכל העמים חשק ה' בכם וגו' אמר להם הקדוש ברוך הוא לישראל חושקני בכם שאפילו בשעה שאני משפיע לכם גדולה אתם ממעטין עצמכם לפני נתתי גדולה לאברהם אמר לפני (בראשית יח, כז) ואנכי עפר ואפר למשה ואהרן אמר (שמות טז, ז) ונחנו מה לדוד אמר (תהלים כב, ז) ואנכי תולעת ולא איש ... אמר רבא ואיתימא ר' יוחנן גדול שנאמר במשה ואהרן יותר ממה שנאמר באברהם דאילו באברהם כתיב ואנכי עפר ואפר ואילו במשה ואהרן כתיב ונחנו מה

Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon: Any place where you find the statements of Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, in reference to aggada, make your ears like a funnel. As Rabbi Eliezer interpreted the verse: “Not because you are more in number than any people did the Lord desire you and choose you, for you were the fewest of all peoples” (Deuteronomy 7:7), as follows: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to the Jewish people: I desire you, since even at a time that I bestow greatness upon you, you diminish, i.e., humble, yourselves before Me. I granted greatness to Abraham, yet he said before Me: “And I am but dust and ashes” (Genesis 18:27). I granted greatness to Moses and Aaron, yet Moses said of the two of them: “And what are we” (Exodus 16:7). I granted greatness to David, yet he said: “But I am a worm, and no man” (Psalms 22:7) ... The Gemara relates: Rava says, and some say Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Greater is that which is stated with regard to Moses and Aaron than that which is stated with regard to Abraham. As with regard to Abraham it is written: “And I am but dust and ashes,” while with regard to Moses and Aaron it is written: “And what are we,” i.e., we are not even dust and ashes [Steinsalz translation, and commentary, slightly edited].

This famous passage records how these giants described themselves as "small" or "nothing", all of which attributes tremendous humility to them. Rava (some say Rabbi Yochanan) even shows that the "lesser" the metaphor they use, the more humble they are (at least comparing Avraham and Moshe/Aharon).

My question is: why is "I am nothing" the humblest? There is such a concept as "I am worse than nothing" i.e. "the world is worse off because of me".

Even on Yom Kippur, during the end of Shmoneh Esrei where we describe ourselves similarly, in our forefathers' legacy, we don't go below "nothing":

עַד שֶׁלֹּא נוֹצַרְתִּי אֵינִי כְדַאי, וְעַכְשָׁו שֶׁנּוֹצַרְתִּי כְּאִלּוּ לֹא נוֹצַרְתִּי. עָפָר אֲנִי בְּחַיָּי, קַל וָחֹמֶר בְּמִיתָתִי.

Before I was formed, I wasn't worthy. Now that I have been formed, it's as if I haven't been formed. I am dust in life, all the moreso in death.

Even this morning prayer doesn't go into the "worse than nothing" range, although it introduces quite a lot of versions of describing ourselves as small or nothing, in humility.

I bet there's a clever and interesting answer. I suspect some of it might be explained by the idea that Jewish humility is defined as being truthful to oneself, and grateful towards the sources of our talents, however, why can't we be honest with ourself and say that we are worse than nothing? Some strong sources seem to hold this way, and surely it is true at least some times and could be considered something we can use in our prayers. A good answer will hopefully deal with this and give a satisfying answer.

I don't really think finding a counter example (or near misses) will be a good way to answer this question. Even if there are counter examples, none of the above sources use them, and all could so that needs to be explained one way or another.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Rashi on the passage you quoted explains that "making yourselves small before Me" is about humility.

Not from your muchness. Because you do not make much of yourselves, but rather you make yourselves little. Therefore He loves you, for you are little--you make yourselves little in humility.

Sefer Orchot Tzaddikim, Chapter Two (Humility) explains humility as follows:

The root of humility is that one should think, even while he is healthy and in a state of tranquility, healthy and wealthy, that the Blessed Creator bestowed this goodness upon him. He should realize that he does not deserve it. He should consider the greatness of G-d and His exalted splendor and think: what am I? Am I not a very lowly creature, existing in a lowly world which itself must come to an end? He should also think: All the good deeds which I might do are only a drop in the ocean compared to what I really should do.

As I understand it, this means that the idea of "I am nothing" is that any good that I do is only a consequence of the good that Hashem did for me. If I have something intelligent to say, Who gave me intelligence? If I have built valuable and useful institutions, Who gave me the money and the organizational skills and the contacts to do this? And therefore I cannot take the credit, but must refer the credit back to the true Benefactor.

On the other hand, to say "I am worse than nothing, I am a net drag on the world" is, in the case of any person that learns Hashem's Torah and keeps His mitzvos, a lie. It furthermore looks rather a lot like accusing the One Above of having erred in creating him in the first place.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Our Rabbi spoke about it on Yom Kippur. I will have to ask the source. The words we say during Shemoneh Esrei "Before I was formed, I wasn't worthy. Now that I have been formed, it's as if I haven't been formed. I am dust in life, all the moreso in death," are dealing with a specific mission that Hashem assigns to each and everyone of us. Before we are born we do not know if we will fulfill this mission and now that we are living, we may not know if we are any close to fulfilling this mission. Therefore, Moshe and Aharon's words can be seen quite inline with this specific statement: "What are we?" - i.e. if our actions in this world were bad, we are worse off than at the time we were born; or if we did the mitzvos - did they bring one close to the accomplishment of the mission we had to do?

In the Gemara there is an important additional meaning in the words of Avraham as explained by Netziv's Haemek Davar Bereshis 18:27. The commentary Tosefes Bracha (different from the well known Torah Temimah) by R. Barukh Epstein connects the words of Netziv to those of Moshe and Aharon:

ומושה ואהרון, בבטולם את ערך עצמם, אמרו "ונחנו מה" (שמות ט"ז ח). ואפשר לכוין שתי המליצות (אפר ועפר - ונחנו מה) כי נאמרו למשל, לפי מצב וערך אומריהן, כי לעפר ואפר יש תוצאות הפכיות. כי העפר ניכר שבחה לאחר שעבדוה ותוציא צמחה. וכנגדה - האפר, הי' ששבחו קודם שנעשה לאבק דק, אז כשהי' עץ או מין אחר שמוציאין ממנו אש. כמו שחשיב במשנה ביצה ל"ג א', אבל מי שנעשה אפר אינו כלום. ועל זה המשיל אברהם את עצמו ביחס גדולי דורות לשניהם, כי כעפר אין לו זכות מיקודם לו, דהיינו זכות אבות, וכאפר - שאין לו זכות אחריו, זכות בנים שברא מזכי אבא (סנהדרין ק"ד א'). וזה נאמר קודם שנולד יצחק - אבל מושה ואהרון היו לכם זכותי שני הצדדים לפניהם ולאחריהם, זכות אבות וזכות בנים. ולו היו יכולים להמשיל עליהם הפחיתות מן עפר ואפר, כפי הציור הנזכר, והמשילובטולם בהם עצמם, ואמרו - ונחנו (עצמנו) מה.

And Moshe and Aharon, in their tremendous humility, said, "And what are we?" (Exodus 16:8). And it is possible to align the two statements (ash and dust - and what are we?) which were said as an example, according to the situation and value of their words, that dust/soil and ash have opposite meanings. Because the dust/soil shows richness after one had worked on it and brought forth vegetation. And opposite of it - the ashes, that is when it was a tree / wood or anything else that was used for fire, as discussed in Mishnah Beitzah 4:6-7 (or 33a in the gemara), but once it is turned into ashes it is nothing. And this is why Avraham compared himself to the greats of both groups of generations, because as dust/soil he did not have merits (of great people) that had preceded him, i.e. the merits of fathers; and as ash - he did not have merits afterwards, the merit of sons, as the son confers merit upon the father (Sanhedrin 104a). These words were said before Isaac was born. However, Moshe and Aaron had merits on both sides before them and after them, the merits of fathers and the merits of children, and they could not express their humility as dust/soil and ashes, like the described comparison. That is why they just said - and "what are we (ourselves)"?

Perhaps, gemara states that the words of Moshe and Aharon are preferable from this point of view since we, the Jewish people today, always have merits of the previous generations and may we have more children BE"H.

title: Correct girsa in yekum purkan
content:
# Correct girsa in yekum purkan ## Frage

I've seen "yifsok" and "yivtol" but also "yifsuk" and "yivtul." Which is the correct girsa?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The prayer Yequm Purkan was composed by the geonim after the Talmudic Period and it is written in Aramaic, the spoken language of Bavel at the time. The most fitting dialect of Aramaic used in Yekum Purkan is the Jewish Babylonian Aramaic of Talmud and Targum Onkelos. The future tense 3rd person male singular of the binyan קַל in Aramaic has form יִכְתּׂב or יִכתּוֹב according to grammars (1) & (2). Therefore, if one intends to say that the offspring will not interrupt (by themselves) and will not cease (by themselves), then one has to use the forms יִפְסוֹק and יִבְטוֹל. This is the case of the siddur Kol Bo, Rabbi Yaakov miEmden, Siddur שפה ברורה, Siddur בית תפילה, Siddur Shabtai Soffer, Siddur haGR"A, Rinat Yitzchak, and interlinear Artscroll which have יִפְסוֹק and יִבְטוֹל. Shabtai Soffer explains:

יפסוק. יפסק נקד רי"ן היו"ד בשב"א והפ"א והסמ"ך בפתת"ח סדור מהרש"ל. ולא ידעתי למה נקד רי"ן כן והלא כי לא יחדל אביון (דברים ט"ו י"א) תרגומו ארי לא יפסוק מסקינא

RY"N (R. Yaakov Nakdan? - I am not sure, please correct) used nekudos יְפַסַק, as stated in the Siddur MaHaRShaL. I do not know why RY"N used such a vowelization. Does not Onkelos translates Devarim 15:11 כִּ֛י לֹא־יֶחְדַּ֥ל אֶבְי֖וֹן as אֲרֵי לָא יִפְסוֹק מִסְכֵּנָא?

For authoritative critical edition of Targum Onkelos one can consult The Bible in Aramaic by Alexander Sperber. Masekhes shel Tefila by Machon Simanim in its Beurei haTefila quotes Eitz Yosef, which explains the words as the kal binyan:

זרעא די לא יפסוֹק הפסקה כלל כו'. כולם אנו מתפללים שיהיו לנו כדי לקיים התורה שלא יהא לנו שום מניעה מן התורה ע"י שחסר לנו ח"ו אחת מאלו הניזכרות כאן. ודי לא יבטוֹל אפילו בטול קטן ואחר שבטל יחזור ללמודו.

Zera di lo yifsok General interruption. We all pray thay we fulfull the Torah, and that there should be nothing preventing us from learning the Torah, because of lacking of any aforementioned in the prayer things. v'di lo yivtol that there should not be even a small nullification, and if it occurs one should go back to one's learning.

In the tradition of Yemenite manuscripts according to reference (3) the form of the future tense 3rd person male singular of the binyan קַל matches that of the the earlier form of western Biblical Aramaic which is given in the modern grammar books (4) and (5). In Biblical Aramaic the future tense 3rd person male singular is יִכְתֻּב and יִכְתּוּב.

There was also well-documented trend among Ashkenazim over the centuries to "correct" editions of siddur and Targumim to Biblical Hebrew, and it is likely the same were true about "correcting" towards Biblical Aramaic (it certainly happened with kaddish) (Thanks magicker72!). As a result, we find confusion in the older Ashkenazi grammars between the later form of Eastern Aramaic and the earlier form of western Biblical Aramaic. Old European editions of Mikraos Gedolos and sidurim may have been based on such a mixed view.

The Siddur haGR"A illustrates the difference between grammars (1) & (2) vs. grammars that mixed Aramaic dialects:

יִפְסוֹק ... יִבְטוֹל (שניהם בחולם) כ"ה בס"י, בסידור רנ"ה שניהם במלאפום

(Both with holam) so it is in Old Siddurim. Siddur R. Naftali Hertz haLevi - both words with melaphum (i.e. shuruk יִפְסוּק ... יִבְטוּל).

Yemenite siddurim and editions of targumim have have shuruk rather than holam. As mentioned by OP, there are still a number of Ashkenazi siddurim, which also have shuruk, such as Siddur תפילת יוסף with piskei Mishna Berura, many Artscroll Siddurim, Koren, Birnbaum, Shilo, and many older ones.

There is also a possibility for a reading in the passive. For example, siddur Tefilas Yosef explains its girsa:

זַרְעָא דִּי לָא יִפְסוּק - זרע אשר לא יפסיק ולא יתבטל מדברי תורה

The offspring which will not cease and will not be canceled from the words of the Torah.

The comment implies the reading in passive: offspring will not be destroyed by others. However, the Jewish Babylonian Aramaic passive should be using the binyan אִתַּפְעַל as explained in grammars (1) and (2), which in the future tense 3rd person male singular has form יִתַּפְסַק and יִתַּבְטַל. Such a form will create reading offspring will not get interrupted or ceased or nullified by others. Probably, the misunderstanding of Shabtai Soffer regarding the girsa of RY"N in siddur Maharshal comes from the corruption of the יִתַּפְסַק to יְפַסַק.

Sources on Aramaic Grammar for the forms of Aramaic verb binyanim:

  • (1) Grammar for Gemara and Targum Onkelos by R. Yitzchak Frank
  • (2) Introduction to the Aramaic of Targum Onqelos by Thomas O. Lambdin and John Huehnergard
  • (3) Aramaic language in the tradition of Yemenite Jews by Sh'lomo Morag in Hebrew: ארמית במסורת תימן. לשון התלמוד הבבלי : מבוא, תורת ההגה ותצורת־הפועל
  • (4) A Grammar of Biblical Aramaic by Franz Rosenthal
  • (5) ארמית מקראית by Elisha Qimron
  • For history of the Aramaic language please see the Wikipedia page.

title: Not smelling the besamim during havdalah
content:
# Not smelling the besamim during havdalah ## Frage

If they do havdalah in shul after Shabbat and you don’t get a chance to smell the besamim since it’s a big shul, when you get home should you make a bracha again and smell the besamim you have, or should you smell it with no bracha, or is smelling it not even necessary?

Assume when you get home you don’t have to remake havdalah for anyone

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Gemera in Brachot 53b says that Rav Yehudah in the name of Rav says one does not need to seek out light motzei Shabbat in the manner that one seeks out other mitzvot. If no flame is available over which to recite a blessing, it does not prevent one from reciting havdala. The Rashba in the name of the Ra'avad (there), and Ritva Hilchot Brachot 8:17, says the same applies to besamim. We also pasken like this in Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim 297:1. This is a case in which the person himself is doing the havdala doesn't have besamim in which halachially speaking one is not obligated to say besamim when it is available to him. I think we can say that all the more so when the person just listening to havdala where there was besamim but he didn't have the chance to smell, for sure is not obligated to go back home and smell besamim.

Nevertheless, even if one is not obligated one is highly suggested to go back home and smell besamim as the Meiri Brachot 53a says that it is to honor Shabbat to make it known that we have a neshama yeteira which is leaving us and we are sad about it.

title: Why is there no mention of the sin of Bitul Torah in the confessions of Yom Kippur
content:
# Why is there no mention of the sin of Bitul Torah in the confessions of Yom Kippur ## Frage

In the confessions on Yom Kippur, there seems to be no mention of the sin of Bitul Torah. There are references to sins that come about through lack of learning but the sin of Bitul Torah itself seems not to be mentioned. Why is this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

A few points:

Firstly, Rav Dessler (Michtav Me'eliyahu) interprets the "Al Chets" as root causes of sin, rather than a list of sins per se. With that interpretation, there are several that could account for the sin of Bitul Torah.

Secondly, the confessions are often broad and open to interpretation. So, for instance, interpreting "siah sifsoseinu" as what our lips do talk about, as opposed to what they don't.

Finally, I believe some commentators (The Chid"a springs to mind) have expanded versions of the confession, and I believe Bitul Torah makes the list (unfortunately, don't have it to hand...)

title: Why did they not give the Kohen Godol longer to practice the difficult ketores service?
content:
# Why did they not give the Kohen Godol longer to practice the difficult ketores service? ## Frage

Mishnah Yoma 1 (5) says that on Erev Yom Kippur, the Elders of the priesthood took the Kohen Godol up to the House of Avtinas. After administering an oath to the Kohen Godol, the Elders instructed him in the difficult process of the ketores offering, as the Yachin says:

ילמדוהו ז‏קני כהונה, חפינת הקטורת, דעבודה קשה היתה:

Why did they not instruct him before that to give him more time to perfect this difficult avodah?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I am answering the OP with my own answer as it seems to me to be obvious from the texts of Torah and our Sages concerning the subject matter of Yom Kippur and the High Priest's Service on Yom Kippur.

Specifically, The Torah says the High Priest must pour his (2) handfulls of incense spices onto the burning coals in the Holy of Holies. Leviticus 16: 12-13

And he shall take a pan full of burning coals from upon the altar, from before the L-rd, and both hands' full of fine incense, and bring [it] within the dividing curtain. And he shall place the incense upon the fire, before the L-rd, so that the cloud of the incense shall envelope the ark cover that is over the [tablets of] Testimony, so that he shall not die.

The Talmud explains that the High Priest must pour the incense from a special spoon into his hands and from the hands onto the coals etc. The physical juggling of the spoon tilting into his two hands and then onto the coals in a way that he doesn't lose a grain of incense in the process is called "Chafinah" and is one of the most difficult of services to perform properly in the temple. (See Yoma 47b at the top of the page)("Some say he holds the bowl/spoon with his fingertips, some say with is teeth etc." See Yoma 49b, also at the top of the page.)

So this was a difficult task and needed practice. The OP asks why the High Priest apparently waited until the last day before Yom Kippur to practice it?

List of Facts When taken together that help answer the question:

  1. Although the Mishnah deals with all time periods; but it is set in the time during the second Temple era, when the office of High Priest was usually filled by people who bid the highest amount to the King or Romans. Many were not neccesarily worthy of the position (even not-so-religious or of the Saducees etc.), but simply bought there way in so they could experience the honor and greatness of being the High Priest on Yom Kippur.

  2. The Torah requires that the commandment of the High Priest pouring his "two handfuls" of incense be exactly two handfuls and be exactly two handfuls of that particular High Priest's hands doing the service. Therefore the amount of incense used is unknown until we can examine the hands of the High Priest himself. This is an integral part of the difficult "Chafinah Service" (pouring the incense on the coals in the Holy of Holies) which the OP is focusing on.

  3. Another important fact is that the Temple would therefore manufacture a special container with a handle that held exactly the amount of incense to be used by that High Priest based on his hands' capacity. Therefore a custom utensil was made for the specific High Priest each year (certainly for different High Priests).

  4. The Law is that the Yom Kippur incense was different in physical quality and density, only on the day before Yom Kippur. This is because on the day before Yom Kippur, the incense prepared the whole year was returned to the grinder and re-pounded until it was the "finest of the finest" in texture.

  5. The High Priest was only sequestered to live at the Temple 7 days before the day of Yom Kippur.

Sources:

  1. The Gemara says that that in the first Temple (stood for 410 years), only 18 high Priests served but during the second Temple over 300 High Priests served (stood for 420 years). This is because the average high Priest did not last the year because he bought his office and was not worthy. Some were wicked or Sadducees. Others were completely unlearned and did not know Hebrew since they could only understand Scripture in Aramaic like the Book of Daniel. (See Yoma 9a; Yoma 18a - 19b sporadically at length)

2-3. The commandment of "Chafinah" required the High Priests exact 2 handfulls and the custom spoon/ladle. see Yoma (47a; Mishnah 1 etc.)

  1. The incense was repounded again erev Yom Kippur. (See Kerisos 6a-b; Jerusalem Talmud Yoma 4:5)

  2. The High Priest lived at the Temple sequestered for the 7 days before Yom Kippur. (See Yoma 1:1)

Once we know this we can answer the OP.

(First the Gemara on 19a seems to quote a Baraisa that implies the High Priest would go learn the "Chafinah" service every day of the 7 days. Indeed the Gemara claims that walking too much (each day) to find his way to the incense room to tire him out, was so he would quit from laziness if he was a Sadducee. Therefore it seems like he visited the incense chamber for all 7 days to learn and practice. If not, why did one day of practice tire him out?. However as the OP points out, the Yachin's commentary seems to indicate it was only on the day before Yom Kippur and only after the oath was administered.)

So wether you hold he practiced 7 days or 1 day, you can still ask why not practice way before for 30 days or a couple of months?

As we saw, many High Priests bought their office and were not interested in mastering the finer aspects of religious service. Therefore, the Sages and regular Priests didn't get to train the candidate until 7 days before Yom Kippur (when they bought their office).

Secondly, because the incense had to be the exact amount of that High Priest's two hands volume, the spoon couldn't be manufactured until we met the winning bidder.

Furthermore, since the incense was re-pounded freshly, only on the day before Yom Kippur, its consistency would change. Therefore, I say the Yachin's explanation is vindicated because the Temple could not manufacture the spoon/ladle for that particular High Priest to practice with, until the day before Yom Kippur, so we would know how much finer and how dense the incense would be, so it could fit exactly into his custom made vessel!

Again, just my conclusion. I hope this helps.

title: Differences between formal and talmudic logic
content:
# Differences between formal and talmudic logic ## Frage

Are there any differences between the formal and talmudic logic?

Specially in terms of usage of true/false and coherences with https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-valued_logic, or, further, with more-valued logics, as in https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/logic-manyvalued/#SysManValLog

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Yes, quite a few. Thankfully, a professor of mathematical logic has given an audio class on this.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Another difference (for my money, the main difference) between Talmudic and formal logic is that Talmud reasoning is abductive, rather than deductive. That is, it generally begins with a conclusion, poses the question "How do we know that this conclusion is correct?", and then seeks proof-texts (either in the written text of the Torah or in a baraita or other Rabbinic source) to justify the conclusion. Deductive reasoning, in contrast, begins with a premise that is taken to be true and tries to reason towards a conclusion.

Imagine a hypothetical person who, instead of reasoning abductively, tries to analyze Jewish law deductively. Such a person might start with one or more proof-texts and reason his way forward towards a conclusion. It's quite likely that such deductive reasoning might lead to a conclusion that we "know" is wrong. It's not necessarily that the premises of the argument are wrong, or that the logical structure contains errors in reasoning; rather, we know post hoc that the argument must be wrong because we already know what the correct conclusion is.

(As a not-so-hypothetical example of this, consider a person who begins with the Biblical text "Whoever kidnaps a man and sells him, or if he is found in his possession, must be put to death" (Shemot 21:16) and argues his way towards the conclusion that, since Joseph's brothers were never put to death for the sin of selling him into slavery, the Rabbis of the current generation are liable to be put to death. This is, of course, precisely what is narrated in the "Eileh Ezkerah" section of the Yom Kippur Musaf.)

title: Why no "Al cheit" in the Neila service?
content:
# Why no "Al cheit" in the Neila service? ## Frage

The Neilah service includes a full Selichot and an almost-complete Vidui, but does not include "Al Cheit..." Is there a reason for this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The rest of Yom Kippur is for thorough and exhaustive prayers. Neilah is the icing on top of the cake whose proper time is only about a half hour around sunset. Accordingly, all the variable components of the prayer (piyyutim, slichot, vidui, etc.) were written concisely and/or later truncated, often dramatically, relative to the other prayers of the day.

title: Does a korban need to be glatt kosher?
content:
# Does a korban need to be glatt kosher? ## Frage

We know that a korban needs to be free of external blemishes. But an internal blemish would obviously not be discovered until after shechitah. If it is not being eaten - eg., an Olah - would it matter if it was discovered to be treif?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

It definitely needs to be kosher. Rambam, Hil. Issurei Mizbe'ach 2:10-11:

בְּהֵמָה שֶׁנּוֹלַד בָּהּ אַחַת מִן הַטְּרֵפִיּוֹת הָאוֹסְרוֹת אוֹתָהּ בַּאֲכִילָה אֲסוּרָה לְגַבֵּי הַמִּזְבֵּחַ הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר (מלאכי א-ח) "הַקְרִיבֵהוּ נָא לְפֶחָתֶךָ הֲיִרְצְךָ אוֹ הֲיִשָּׂא פָנֶיךָ"... נִשְׁחֲטָה וְנִמְצֵאת טְרֵפָה הֲרֵי זוֹ תֵּצֵא לְבֵית הַשְּׂרֵפָה

When an animal contracts one of the conditions that render it treifah and cause it to be forbidden to be eaten, it is forbidden [to be sacrificed on] the altar. For behold it is written [Malachi 1:8]: "Present it please to your governor. Would he be pleased with you or show you favor?"... If it was slaughtered and discovered to be tereifah, it should be taken out to the place of burning.

If the condition is such that there would be an argument among the poskim whether it's kosher (which is, to oversimplify, the difference between glatt and non-glatt), then presumably one or another of the batei din in the Beis Hamikdash complex would have to rule on it.

title: Why did HaShem allow Christians to proselytize to many nations knowing that they will lead many to idolatry and commit many atrocities?
content:
# Why did HaShem allow Christians to proselytize to many nations knowing that they will lead many to idolatry and commit many atrocities? ## Frage

Why would G-d allow the Christians to bring so much misinformation and so much tragedies to many people throughout the world? This is not to say that Christianity hasn't made a number of positive contributions to the world of course but wouldn't it be more ideal if G-d were to have propagated another group that was not as antisemitic and hostile and more monotheistic than the Christians?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

I'm almost certain this has been asked and answered here before, but we'll do it once again. Maimonides, Laws of Kings and Their Wars, 11:7--8. You can read Maimonides' language there.

But in short, Christianity and Islam have both spread the vocabulary of monotheism throughout the world; even if in ways that Judaism would consider problematic.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

This is a profound question that touches on the larger issue of why G-d allows things that may seem contrary to the ideal world we envision. One perspective, as mentioned by Rambam, is that Christianity and Islam have both contributed to spreading the concept of monotheism across the world, even if the way they do so is not entirely in line with Jewish thought. These religions, while problematic in certain aspects, have played a role in bringing many people closer to understanding some form of G-d, albeit in ways that are different from Judaism.

It's also important to consider the role of free will. G-d allows people, and even entire groups, the freedom to choose their paths, even if that includes spreading beliefs or committing actions that lead to suffering. This idea can be linked to the broader question of why G-d permits any form of evil or hardship in the world—humans are granted free will, and unfortunately, that often leads to misuse of that freedom.

Moreover, we can look at the long arc of history. While Christianity may have led to suffering for the Jewish people at various points in history, it has also introduced moral and ethical teachings that, in many ways, align with Torah values. The existence of such a complex relationship between these religions and the Jewish people may point to a larger divine plan, where even actions or movements that seem harmful can eventually lead to greater awareness of G-d and His will in the world.

Ultimately, while we may struggle with understanding why certain things happen or why G-d allows them, we trust that there is a purpose, even in events that seem painful or confusing from our perspective.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

This question is basically the same as the more common "Why does G allow bad things to happen?"

This is more complex then saying that one religion proselytizes and the other does not.

Fundamentally G created us with Free will, we are all able to choose to follow G or not. This goes both ways, G will not interfere with our ability to make choices, if a person rejects G then that is their choice.

I understand that the topic of free will is not as easily reconciled within the Jewish faith. And I've seen arguments for determinism as well as for free will. I believe it is called "Bechirah chofshit" which I think was supposed to be based on the 2nd book of Moses.

I (G) have set before you life and death, blessing and curse: therefore choose life (2nd Book of Moses "Deuteronomy" 30:19)

This is true on higher levels as well, a group of people will be "permitted" to do as they please. To choose life or death.

As for the suffering they cause, it is permitted because it is a byproduct of sin. G does not want us to break his commandments and all preventable suffering is because we have turned away from HaShem.

On a side note: I think any Christian denomination that is anti-semitic is not Christian at all by their own definitions, Christians should respect jews naturally due to the shared connection to G.

Edit: I'm an Eastern Orthodox Christian, as far as I know Christians are supposed to respect the root, we are to love even those who persecute us, and so on. I'm sorry for those ... others who make you feel otherwise. I cannot judge them, but I trust that G would.

title: Why does it say the whole generation died, if Yocheved was still alive?
content:
# Why does it say the whole generation died, if Yocheved was still alive? ## Frage

Shmot 1:6 says

וַיָּ֤מׇת יוֹסֵף֙ וְכׇל־אֶחָ֔יו וְכֹ֖ל הַדּ֥וֹר הַהֽוּא

And Yosef and all his brothers and the whole generation died.

Yocheved was part of the 70 people who went down to Egypt, and those 70 people are that generation (מיתת כל הדור פי' כל הע' נפש).

My question is: If Yocheved was still alive, why does it say the whole generation died?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Midrash Lekach Tov explains that the phrase "all that generation" is a generalization that shouldn't be taken literally:

בני שמעון למשפחותם. רבי (ישמעאל) אומר (בראשית מו) שאול בן הכנענית הוא זמרי בן סלוא שהכליא עונות משפחתו. ומה שמו שלומיאל בן צורישדי. שהיה במפקד במדבר סיני. ואל תתמה שהרי שאול בן הכנענית היה מיורדי מצרים והיה עד סוף ארבעים שנה של מדבר. והא כתיב (שמות א׳:ו׳-ז׳) וימת יוסף וכל אחיו וכל הדור ההוא. תשובתך שהרי סרח בת אשר היתה מיורדי מצרים וחיית והיא נחשבת בערבות יריחו. ואין למדין מן הכללות ואפילו במקום שנאמר בו חוץ:

The descendants of Simeon according to their families: Rabbi (Yishmael) says (Bereshit 46) that Shaul, the son of the Canaanite woman, is Zimri, son of Salu, who tarnished the reputation of his family through their sins. His other name is Shlumiel, son of Tzurishaddai, who was listed in the census in the wilderness of Sinai. And do not be surprised, for Shaul, the son of the Canaanite woman, was one of those who went down to Egypt and lived until the end of the forty years in the wilderness. But doesn’t it say (Shemot 1:6-7) "And Joseph died, and all his brothers, and all that generation"?

Your answer is that Serach, the daughter of Asher, was one of those who went down to Egypt, and she lived and was still present in the plains of Jericho. And we don't derive from generalizations, even in places where exceptions are stated.
