title: Belief in Teshuvah being a prerequisite
content:
# Belief in Teshuvah being a prerequisite ## Frage

Somebody told me that the Rambam says that belief in the idea of Teshuvah is a prerequisite to Teshuvah itself. Can anyone source this?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

אֵין יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים וְלֹא הַחַטָּאת וְלֹא הָאָשָׁם מְכַפְּרִין אֶלָּא עַל הַשָּׁבִים הַמַּאֲמִינִים בְּכַפָּרָתָן. אֲבָל הַמְבַעֵט בָּהֶן אֵינָן מְכַפְּרִין בּוֹ. כֵּיצַד. הָיָה מְבַעֵט וְהֵבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ אוֹ אֲשָׁמוֹ וְהוּא אוֹמֵר אוֹ מְחַשֵּׁב בְּלִבּוֹ שֶׁאֵין אֵלּוּ מְכַפְּרִין. אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁקָּרְבוּ כְּמִצְוָתָן לֹא נִתְכַּפֵּר לוֹ וּכְשֶׁיַּחֲזֹר בִּתְשׁוּבָה מִבְּעִיטָתוֹ צָרִיךְ לְהָבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ וַאֲשָׁמוֹ. וְכֵן הַמְבַעֵט בְּיוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים אֵין יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים מְכַפֵּר עָלָיו. לְפִיכָךְ אִם נִתְחַיֵּב בְּאָשָׁם תָּלוּי וְעָבַר עָלָיו יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים וְהוּא מְבַעֵט בּוֹ הֲרֵי זֶה לֹא נִתְכַּפֵּר לוֹ וּכְשֶׁיַּחֲזֹר בִּתְשׁוּבָה אַחַר יוֹם הַכִּפּוּרִים חַיָּב לְהָבִיא כָּל אָשָׁם תָּלוּי שֶׁהָיָה חַיָּב בּוֹ:

Yom Kippur, sin-offerings and guilt-offerings do not generate atonement unless one repents and believes in the atonement they grant. If, however, one rebels against them, they do not generate atonement for him.What is implied? A person was in a state of rebellion, but brought a sin-offering or a guilt-offering, saying or thinking in his heart that these will not generate atonement. Accordingly, even though they were offered as commanded, they do not generate atonement for him. When he repents from his rebellion, he must bring another sin-offering and/or guilt-offering. Similarly, when one is in a state of rebellion on Yom Kippur, Yom Kippur does not atone for him. Therefore if he was obligated to bring a tentative guilt-offering and Yom Kippur passed while he was in a state of rebellion, Yom Kippur does not generate atonement for him. When he repents after Yom Kippur, he is obligated to bring all the tentative guilt-offerings for which he is liable (Mishneh Torah, Hilchot Shegagot 3:10).

title: Started Yaale ve'yavo on rosh chodesh Iyar/Cheshvan and then lost concentration
content:
# Started Yaale ve'yavo on rosh chodesh Iyar/Cheshvan and then lost concentration ## Frage

The halacha is, that until one has accustomed themselves to repeating a phrase in prayer (e.g. mashiv haruach) for 30 consecutive days, OR they have repeated it 90 times, if they cannot remember whether they mentioned said phrase, we have to assume they did not say it (and would therefore have to repeat the amida).

Imagine a scenario where someone knows that they began Ya'ale veyavo on Rosh chodesh Iyar or Rosh Chodesh Cheshvan, but they cannot remember if they said "beyom Rosh Hachodesh hazeh" or "beyom Chag Hasukot/Chag Hamatzot Hazeh".

Is the 30-day/90-reps rule absolute, or only lechumra? In other words, are we concerned that having said "Beyom Chag Ha____" for 8 days straight in the recent past, the habit may have become ingrained and will therefore require a new amida, or is anything less than 30 days of a different version of prayer insignificant?

(I ask about those 2 Rosh Chodesh's (Roshei Chadashim?) because any other Rosh Chodesh is more than 30 days after a different version of ya'aleh veyavo was said.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

This is a surprisingly interesting question because of what it is balancing:

  1. We don't say Yaaleh V'Yavo (YV"Y) often enough for it to become habitual that we can build the habit of saying it right, so maybe we should repeat it if we don't know if we said it correctly
  2. It also isn't said in a place where we have a previous habit in place, so there's no reason to presume that we said the wrong one either, so maybe we shouldn't repeat.

Therefore, we need a third principle and that is going to be: did we intend to say YV"Y with the correct holiday in mind or not? In most cases, we can assume that if one remembered to say it, they remembered to say it for the correct occasion.

So, the conclusion is that, if one has finished and moved on already, one does not repeat it* but if one realises right after (still in Retzei**), he can repeat, as concludes the Mishnah Berura 114:38:

(לח) בחזקת שהזכיר וכו' - ואם ברור לו שהיה בדעתו לזכור מעין המאורע [לענין הזכרה ושאלה ויעלה ויבא וכה"ג] בתוך התפלה ולאחר זמן מופלג נפל ספק בלבו אם זכר בתפלה או לא אין צריך לחזור ואם נתעורר הספק מיד אחר התפלה יש לחזור [מור וקציעה ומגן גבורים]:

It is presumed that he mentioned, etc. – If it is clear to him that he had the intention to recall the relevant occasion [regarding insertions such as mention of rain, requests, Yaaleh Veyavo, and similar] during the prayer, and after some time, he begins to doubt whether he actually mentioned it during the prayer or not, he does not need to repeat the prayer. However, if the doubt arises immediately after the prayer, he can repeat it [Mor U'Ketzia and Magen Gibborim].

*Obviously, in the rare case where one had a brain freeze and thought it was Pesach or Rosh Chodesh instead of Sukkot (or was completely unaware that it was a special occasion and said YV"Y by mistake), then one should probably repeat - but please CYLOR for practical applications of the above principles.

** See Kaf Hachaim s'k 48, explaining the Mor U'Ketzia

title: Why don't we make the bracha on the Etrog, instead of the Lulav?
content:
# Why don't we make the bracha on the Etrog, instead of the Lulav? ## Frage

According to the midrash, the Etrog is the species that is the best, because it has a good taste and a good fragrance (which represents Jews who have Mitzvot and Torah, rather than just one or neither).

title: Why do we use the leaf of the Lulav, and not the Date?
content:
# Why do we use the leaf of the Lulav, and not the Date? ## Frage

According to the midrash, the lulav is the species that has no fragrance, but it has a good taste. That's referring to its dates, yet the Torah says we should take the leaf, and use it for the avodah, rather than the date.

Why not the date?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

I got an answer from a sicha from the Lubavitcher Rebbe, as well as a few other sources. I wrote it as a dvar Torah, along with other sources and my own structure and delivered it on Sukkot 1 morning. This is the dvar Torah:

Sukkot 5785

There is a famous midrash, midrash Rabba in Vayikra, that discusses the inner meaning of the arba minim. The etrog has a good fragrance and taste, and represents Jews who have Torah and Mitzvot. The lulav has a good taste, but no smell, and represents Jews who have Torah, but not Mitzvot. The Haddasim have a good fragrance, but no good taste, representing Jews who have Mitzvot but not Torah, and finally, for the rest of us, there is the Aravot, which have neither a good taste or a good fragrance, and represent us Jews deficient in Torah and Mitzvot. Nonetheless, Hashem sees us all as one, and we are all equally precious before Him. This was concealed in Rosh Hashana and Yom Kippur – we all had one mitzva that is for all of us – listening to the Shofar. Now on Succot, we have a Mitzva that reveals the differences between us, but nonetheless we are instructed to bind the species together and thus show that we can be all one despite our differences.

There are two questions I wish to ask. Firstly, it seems clear that the Etrog is the most superior of the minim, as it has Torah and Mitzvot, yet the bracha is “Al Netilat Lulav”, not Etrog!

Secondly, the point about the lulav is that it has a good taste. That’s referring to its fruit – the dates, rather than the leaf, which is what the Torah tells us to take. Why doesn’t the Torah tell us to take the dates?

Regarding the first question, the gemara tells us that we take the lulav because it is taller than the rest. What’s that got to do with anything? We have to understand that even though it says this is a person who has Torah and not Mitzvot, it doesn’t mean that it is discussing a person who has literally no Mitzvot. Someone who studies but does not perform is described as wicked! It means that this person dedicates themselves to Torah, in order to perform Mitzvot – they put Torah study as paramount.

As such, they are able to connect to Hashem more closely. This is because the Torah is described as totally united with Hashem. As it says in Gemara Shabbat, when Hashem gave the Torah, He opened with the word “Anochi”. This interesting choice of word, instead of Ani, was chosen because it is an acronym: “Ana Nafshit Ketovit Yehovit” – I put My soul in writing and gave it to you. The Torah is Hashem revealing Himself to us, and by learning it, we connect to His Wisdom.

This is why the Ben Yehoyada describes the Lulav as representative of the Tzaddik. He learns Torah as paramount, but all in order to perform its Mitzvot. We are all bound to the Tzaddik, and through the Tzaddik, our Mitzvot and connection to Hashem are established and draw down Hashem’s blessings and love.

The connection we have to Hashem through Mitzvot is very powerful, but it is not as powerful as through Torah. The Mitzvot are described in the Zohar as the limbs of the King. Just as the limbs of the body are not one with the soul—they are, however, nullified to the soul and fulfill its will automatically as soon as the soul desires—they are nevertheless not the soul itself. So too, the performance of mitzvot reflects a person's submission and nullification to G-d, as he fulfills the Divine will. However, the individual performing the mitzvot still retains their own independent existence and is not, so to speak, unified with the Creator.

Now we have a basis to understand the concept of waving the Lulav. The Ben Ish Chai explains how the waving corresponds to Hashem’s name, YKVK, indicating that just as this Name represents that Hashem is everywhere, so too we wave the Lulav in all directions to show that we, through our learning, recognise that Hashem‘s dominion is absolute. Not only that, but he says in Ben Yehoyada that by waving the lulav, we are expressing our yearning for Hashem, and this is met with His yearning for us, and thus we create a unity between Him and us, which is possible because of the unity we have amongst ourselves, as indicated by the binding of the four species.

On top of this, it corresponds to the swaying that we engage in when we learn. The Zohar explains that the reason we sway while we learn is because the soul of man is the candle of Hashem. Just as a candle flickers because it is drawn upwards, so too the soul tries to unite with Hashem through Torah and Mitzvot.

The soul in heaven is described as standing still, as until we come down into a physical body, we cannot progress or grow. But when we come down, not only can we grow, we have unlimited potential for growth. The essential growth is through Torah, because, as we said, it connects us to Hashem in a perfect unity, even more so than the performance of Mitzvot, and that’s why it is the lulav that has the mitzva of swaying, specifically.

This brings us back to the question – why do we shake the lulav, which is the leaf of the date palm, and not the date?

The reason why there is a concept of swaying in Torah learning is because, in order to progress in our studies, we must go through a process of shak[la] vetariya. That is, we ask a question, we give an answer, we ask a question on that answer, and we have to go through this process – of constantly refining, making mistakes, improving, and making more mistakes.

Let me illustrate this with a story. A father once came to the Alter Rebbe and said, my son is very brilliant, and I thank you for letting him in your yeshiva – he is doing very well. The only issue I have with him is that it is all going to his head, he’s become arrogant. So the Alter Rebbe said, bring him to me. So the father brought him, and the Rebbe asked him a question on a gemara. The Rebbe then said, is it a good question? The bochur said yes. The Rebbe said no it isn’t! And gave a seemingly obvious answer. Then he asked him, is that a good answer? The boy said again yes, and the Rebbe said “no it isn’t!” and proceeded to ask a seemingly obvious kashe on the answer. So, is it a good kashe? The boy said yes, and he said no it isn’t! This went on another half dozen times, until the Rebbe turned to the boy, and said nu, I thought you said he was clever? The boy was taken down a notch, to say the least.

When it comes to learning, we are meant to approach it with humility and bittul. This is because, even though indeed the Torah does contain all the secrets of life, those secrets are lofty, truly infinite in their beauty and sweetness. All our learning is constantly going towards this beauty, but it is a lifetimes work.

This is why we don’t shake the date. The real pleasure in learning comes at the end, when we have the answer ("the ultimate pleasure is the resolution of doubts"). This is a lifetime’s work, and a reward for the future. For now, Torah study isn’t necessarily as pleasurable as it should be. Indeed Shak’vetariya, and pilpul can be quite frustrating. Nonetheless, this gives us an opportunity to engage in some real bittul. This bittul is what enables all Jews to come together. Even though we are very different, we don’t need to worry, we can still be united, if we can get our egos out of the way, and learn some humility, so indeed the ikar species is the lulav – Torah study, the closeness we get with Hashem, and the humility that enables us to get close to eachother.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The question can be further generalized, why the lulav bundle has only branches instead of the fruit of the plants?

When looking at the question this way, one can recall the verse Devarim 20:19

כִּֽי־תָצ֣וּר אֶל־עִיר֩ יָמִ֨ים רַבִּ֜ים לְֽהִלָּחֵ֧ם עָלֶ֣יהָ לְתׇפְשָׂ֗הּ לֹֽא־תַשְׁחִ֤ית אֶת־עֵצָהּ֙ לִנְדֹּ֤חַ עָלָיו֙ גַּרְזֶ֔ן כִּ֚י מִמֶּ֣נּוּ תֹאכֵ֔ל וְאֹת֖וֹ לֹ֣א תִכְרֹ֑ת כִּ֤י הָֽאָדָם֙ עֵ֣ץ הַשָּׂדֶ֔ה לָבֹ֥א מִפָּנֶ֖יךָ בַּמָּצֽוֹר׃

The bold letters are translated because a man is a tree of the field. If a man is like a tree, and its fruit are mitzvos, then the branches are man's efforts to fulfill mitzvos. (1)

Thus, the plants in the lulav bundle can symbolize our efforts in achieving the perfect mitzva (fruit). Perhaps, that is a reason for the mitzvah of shaking in all directions - to seek all possible efforts, as these directions also symbolize 7 physical sefiros (right - chesed, left - gevura, front - tiferes, up - netzach, down - hod, back - yesod, center - malchus, see The Four Species by R' DovBer Pinson). Also, one can connect this idea to the well-known midrash Vayikra Rabba 30:12

Another matter: “The fruit of a pleasant [hadar] tree” – this is Israel; just as the citron has taste and has fragrance, so Israel has people among them who have Torah and have good deeds. “Branches of date palms” – this is Israel; just as the date palm has taste but has no fragrance, so Israel has people among them who have Torah but do not have good deeds. “A bough of a leafy tree” – this is Israel; just as the myrtle has fragrance but has no taste, so Israel has people among them who have good deeds but do not have Torah. “Willows of the brook” – this is Israel; just as the willow has no taste and has no fragrance, so Israel has people among them who do not have Torah and do not have good deeds. What does the Holy One blessed be He do to them? To eradicate them is not possible. Rather, the Holy One blessed be He said: Let them all be bound together in a single bundle and they will atone for one another. If you do so, at that moment, I will be ascendant [mitaleh]. That is what is written: “Who built His upper chamber [maalotav] in the heavens” (Amos 9:6). When is He ascendant? When they are made into a single group, as it is stated: “And established His group upon earth” (Amos 9:6). Therefore, Moses exhorts Israel and says to them: “You shall take for you on the first day.”

One can interpret the categories of people, who either have knowledge of Torah, or have good deeds, or neither as applied to own efforts in learning Torah, doing good deeds or just plain physical acts - all tied to perform each and one single mitzva symbolized by a separately placed esrog.

Incidentally, it also answers the question, why esrog is one. When a person performs a mitzvah, s/he is exempt from other mitzvos. Esrog is like a heart, hinting that one's heart must be full with performing the mitzvah.

Also it ties well with the question why we make the blessing on lulav as lulav symbolizes the Torah knowledge, our guidance in performing the mitzvah (hence it is the tallest).

(1) Perhaps, these analogies are also at play in the story of Adam and Chava in Gan Eden and their self-imposed stringency not to touch the tree of knowledge of good and evil (Bereshis Rabba 19:3). Since the Gan was a spiritual place, its trees and their branches symbolized efforts to do mitzvos, and the mitzvos themselves were the fruit of the garden trees.

title: Can excessive checking of an Esrog be considered nezek?
content:
# Can excessive checking of an Esrog be considered nezek? ## Frage

Here's the situation: Someone in a Shul is selling arba minim sets for the whole Shul. The Rav agreed to check them all. So I would assume there's a chezkas kashrus when I buy the set and I have no need to check it. Let's say I did check it, for some reason. And at first glance it looks fine, and it's only after extensive checking that I find a very subtle spot that turns out being a p'sul. Now, I would assume that if I had opened the box and found an obviously-passul esrog in there I would be able to get my money back from the distributor, no questions asked, because the chazaka vanishes right away. However, given that this p'sul wasn't so obvious and I found it only after checking very very carefully (surely not something I needed to do given the kashrus stamp the Rav gave), does the distributor have the right to demand money for damage I caused him? Surely I can't use this esrog and therefore should have the right to demand my money back from the distributor, and would give the passul esrog back to the distributor. But had I done the "right" thing by just accepting the esrog and not checking it excessively, I would have been able to use that esrog relying on the chezkas kashrus, and the only reason this esrog is passul is because of my excessive checking. Essentially, I caused the distributor's esrog to become passul. So does the disributor have the right to demand payment from me for damaging his esrog?

title: Why pick up the arba minim prior to making the bracha?
content:
# Why pick up the arba minim prior to making the bracha? ## Frage

Brachos need to be made as close to the fulfillment of the mitzvah as possible

As one fulfills arba minim as soon as they are lifted then the natural place for the bracha should be immediately prior to picking them up

The prevailing minhag of holding them with intention not to fulfill the mitzvah or holding the esrog upside down etc seems unnecessary

(It is akin to say binding the retzuos with intention not to fulfill the mitzvah yet or initially binding the tefillin out of place)

Is it because we'd like to have the mitzvah object in hand when making the bracha?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Tosafot Sukkah 39a s.v. over la-assiyatan write:

מטעם זה צריך לברך אלולב קודם שיטלנו דאי לאחר שנטלו מדאגבהיה נפק ביה כדאמרי' בסוף פירקין (סוכה דף מב.) ומיהו לא מסתבר כלל דהיאך יברך עליו והוא מונח בכלי הא אמר בהקומץ רבה (מנחות לה: ושם) תפילין מאימתי מברך עליהן משעת הנחה עד שעת קשירה וכל שעה שאין המצוה מזומנת בידו לעשות לא מיסתבר כלל לברך עליו

To summarise their point: while it is true that at first glance one would expect that the correct procedure would be to make the blessing before picking up the lulav, it actually doesn’t make sense to make the blessing before the mitzvah item is in one’s hand and ready for the performance of the mitzvah.

Tosafot go on to offer three suggestions (two of which you list in your question) as to how one can make the blessing while the lulav is in his hand but before fulfilling the mitzvah.

Rambam Hilchot Lulav 7:6, on the other hand, does arguably write to do exactly as you suggest - first make the blessing and then pick up the lulav (although even this is not totally clear cut - compare with what he writes in Hilchot Berachot 11:15, where he allows and possibly prefers that the blessing be recited after picking up the lulav).

For the sake of completeness, I’ll note the opinion of Ran (Sukkah 20b midapei harif s.v. umiderparchinan) who writes that one simply makes the blessing after picking up the lulav even though he has already fulfilled the mitzvah, because he still has yet to wave it and complete the mitzvah totally.

Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim 651:5 rules like the first two suggestions of Tosafot (blessing between picking up the lulav and the etrog, or blessing while holding the etrog upside-down) and Beiur HaGra (quoted in Mishnah Berurah :25) prefers the third suggestion of Tosafot (holding the lulav with intent not to fulfill the mitzvah until after the blessing is made). So, that’s why common practice is as you see, rather than making the blessing before picking up the lulav.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Brachos are made at varying points in relation to the mitzvah being done. For example it's said after washing, it's said while putting on a tallis, it's said at the start of putting on tefilin, and it's said in regards to learning torah prior to learning anything. There are all unique reasons for why we say the bracha on each of the mitzvos. For lulav the fulfilling of the mitzvah is started by bringing the lulav and earog together and in the correct order. Seemingly if all species are not held together in the right order while shaking them you aren't fulfilling the mitzvah yet. Some want to already be holding all of the species when saying the bracha hence holding it upside down but will then change it at the last moment when bringing them together while others such as myself will only pick the esrog up after finishing the bracha. Either way the idea being to be able to bring the species together and wave them as close to saying the bracha as possible

title: Isru Chag Ba'avotim - what's it about?
content:
# Isru Chag Ba'avotim - what's it about? ## Frage

Background:
Near the end of Hallel
אֵ֤ל ׀ ה' וַיָּ֢אֶ֫ר לָ֥נוּ אִסְרוּ־חַ֥ג בַּעֲבֹתִ֑ים עַד־קַ֝רְנ֗וֹת הַמִּזְבֵּֽחַ׃
Hashem is G-d; he has given us light; bind the festal offering to the horns of the altar with cords.

The verse seems very obscure. When do we ever tie a korbon to the altar? And why the corners?
Rashi in Chullin says
מחמשה ועד עשרה טמא שבו קושרין את הפסחים זכר לפסח מצרים דכתי' אסרו חג בעבותים וגו' וכתיב והיה לכם למשמרת
[these lengths of rope were used] when they would tie their Korbon Pesachs [to the bed], in remembrance of the Pesach in Egypt, as is written, אסרו חג בעבותים וגו', tie the korbon with ropes..., והיה לכם למשמרת, and you will guard it...
Rashi says that the verse doesn't mean it was tied to the altar, but tied to keep it safe, in preparation for bringing it to the altar. Maybe he understands the word "עד" to mean, "until": [keep it safe] until we get it all the way there, the blood on the corners.

The gemara in Sukkah 45a-b gives three drashos on the verse:

אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: מַאי קְרָאָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אִסְרוּ חַג בַּעֲבוֹתִים עַד קַרְנוֹת הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״.
אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: כׇּל הַנּוֹטֵל לוּלָב בְּאִגּוּדוֹ וַהֲדַס בַּעֲבוֹתוֹ, מַעֲלֶה עָלָיו הַכָּתוּב כְּאִילּוּ בָּנָה מִזְבֵּחַ וְהִקְרִיב עָלָיו קׇרְבָּן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר:
Rabbi Abbahu said: What is the verse that alludes to the fact that the branches must lean one cubit over the top of the altar? It is as it is stated: “Encircle [isru] with branches on the Festival until the horns of the altar” (Psalms 118:27), indicating that willow branches should surround the horns of the altar. That is facilitated by standing the branches on the base.
Rabbi Abbahu said that Rabbi Elazar said: With regard to anyone who takes a lulav in its binding and a myrtle branch in its dense-leaved form, the verse ascribes him credit as though he built an altar and sacrificed an offering upon it, as it is stated: אִסְרוּ חַג בַּעֲבוֹתִים עַד קַרְנוֹת הַמִּזְבֵּחַ. “Bind [isru] with dense-leaved branches [ba’avotim] on the Festival until the horns of the altar” (Psalms 118:27), which alludes to both the binding of the lulav and to the myrtle branch, referred to in the Torah as the branch of a dense-leaved tree [anaf etz avot].
אָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַי, וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הַמָּחוֹזִי מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן הַמָּכוֹתִי: כׇּל הָעוֹשֶׂה אִיסּוּר לֶחָג בַּאֲכִילָה וּשְׁתִיָּה, מַעֲלֶה עָלָיו הַכָּתוּב כְּאִילּוּ בָּנָה מִזְבֵּחַ וְהִקְרִיב עָלָיו קׇרְבָּן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אִסְרוּ חַג בַּעֲבוֹתִים עַד קַרְנוֹת הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״.
Rabbi Yirmeya said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai, and Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon HaMeḥozi, who said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan HaMakkoti: With regard to anyone who establishes an addition [issur] to the Festival on the day after the Festival by eating and drinking, the verse ascribes him credit as though he built an altar and sacrificed an offering upon it, as it is stated: “Add [isru] to the Festival with fattened animals [ba’avotim] until the horns of the altar.”

So that's four different meanings to the verse, on seemingly different topics.

Rashi in Pesachim 119a has maybe a combination:
אסרו חג בעבותים - הביאו זבחים ושלמים הרבה לשמוח:
Bring many zevachim and shelamim for simcha.

Not sure how he's reading it exactly.

Question: Does someone suggest an understanding of what the verse is saying (in context of the Psalm, hopefully), that explains what all these meanings are and how they fit?

Chag Sameach!

title: Did the death of the High Priest atone for sin and cleanse the land?
content:
# Did the death of the High Priest atone for sin and cleanse the land? ## Frage

I have been studying up on Numbers 35, where it describes the issue of manslaughter and murder. If someone commits murder then they had to be put to death, but if it is found to be an accident (or perhaps there is just insufficient testimony) then the man-slaughterer could live out his days in one of the designated Cities of Refuge. There was no sacrifice or other payment that could redeem the life of the man-slaughterer.

Despite it being an accident, the act of shedding another man's blood is still worthy of death - it still defiles the land; even the land of Israel where God was said to dwell among the people. Under the Noahide Covenant (Genesis 9), any time that a man killed another man (unlawfully), regardless of intentions or the presence of any animosity, it was required of society that they put that man to death:

Genesis 9:6

Whoever sheds human blood, By man his blood shall be shed, For in the image of God He made mankind.

Numbers 35:30-34

If anyone kills a person, the murderer shall be put to death on the testimony of witnesses, but no person shall be put to death on the testimony of only one witness. 31 Moreover, you shall not accept a ransom for the life of a murderer who is condemned to death, but he must be put to death. 32 And you shall not accept a ransom for one who has fled to his city of refuge, so that he may return to live in the land before the death of the priest. 33 So you shall not defile the land in which you live; for blood defiles the land, and no atonement can be made for the land for the blood that is shed on it, except by the blood of the one who shed it. 34 So you shall not defile the land in which you live, in the midst of which I dwell; for I the Lord am dwelling in the midst of the sons of Israel.

The idea of the shedding of human blood defiling the land hearkens back to when Cain slew Abel:

Genesis 4:9-12

Then the Lord said to Cain, “Where is Abel your brother?” And he said, “I do not know. Am I my brother’s keeper?” 10 Then He said, “What have you done? The voice of your brother’s blood is crying out to Me from the ground. 11 Now you are cursed from the ground, which has opened its mouth to receive your brother’s blood from your hand. 12 When you cultivate the ground, it will no longer yield its strength to you; you will be a wanderer and a drifter on the earth.”

Under the Law, the avenger of blood referred to the one who took on the role of killing a man-slaughterer (though the scriptures don't go into detail as far as selecting who this was as far as I can tell). Despite that this was a role that God requires of society, God also established the Cities of Refuge to show mercy to those who didn't kill intentionally or out of malice. And, what is more, upon the death of the High Priest all of the man-slaughterers were seemingly forgiven; they could return home without fear of being put to death by the avenger of blood, and with no more need to cleanse the land through their blood.

Numbers 35:25-28

And the congregation shall save the one who committed manslaughter from the hand of the blood avenger, and the congregation shall return him to his city of refuge to which he fled; and he shall live in it until the death of the high priest who was anointed with the holy oil. 26 But if at any time he goes beyond the border of his city of refuge to which he flees, 27 and the blood avenger finds him outside the border of his city of refuge, and the blood avenger kills him, he will not be guilty of bloodshed, 28 because he should have remained in his city of refuge until the death of the high priest. But after the death of the high priest the one who committed manslaughter may return to the land of his property.

To get to my question then, I wanted to know how this phenomenon is understood within Judaism: did the life of the High Priest serve to atone for / cleanse the man-slaughterers? Did the High Priest's death serve to cleans the land? Or is something else going on here altogether? If not atonement, is there another term that would be used to describe this?

title: What is the (biblical) origin of the root עלם
content:
# What is the (biblical) origin of the root עלם ## Frage

I’m learning Hebrew, and with the Hitpa'el verbs, like להתחתן (to marry) or להתפלל (to pray), I can often learn new nouns by testing the root, such as חתונה (wedding) or תפילה (prayer). Recently, I encountered the verb להתעלם (to ignore), which comes from the same root (עלם) that also refers to youth or a young person (עלם/עלמה). Does anyone know if there’s a reason for the connection between being young and being ignorant or unaware?

(One could also say that children/the youth often question things, are curious and eager to learn, and are also more emotionally driven, which is why they are more likely to lean towards activism)

Toda raba!

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The two roots are unrelated in Biblical Hebrew, even though they become homophonous in later Hebrew. There are two phonemes that correspond to the written letter ע: one is ʿayin (a voiced pharyngeal fricative, IPA: ʕ) and the other is ġayin (or ghayin; a voiced velar fricative — close to modern Israeli ר but not trilled, IPA: ɣ). Both sounds were present in Biblical Hebrew (for example, note the transliteration of Gomorrah for the city עֲמֹרָה, indicating an original ġayin), but due to the relatively limited writing system adopted by Hebrew speakers, some letters did double duty (the other famous one is ח for /x/ and /ħ/).

The original root of the verb עלם meaning conceal (whence להתעלם) is with an ʿayin, and the original root of the nouns עֶלֶם and עַלְמָה is with a ġayin. For a source, you can look at The Hebrew and Aramaic Lexicon of the Old Testament (HALOT). For עלם I, it lists cognates ʿalama in Arabic and Ethiopic, ʿlm in Ugaritic. For עלם III, it lists cognates ġlm in Ugaritic and ġalima in Arabic. (עלם II also comes from a ġayin, and means "be darkened, black", and appears in Job 42:3 as מעלים, perhaps as a variant of צלם.)

So to sum up, the two roots ʿlm and ġlm are not related, even though they sound the same in later Hebrew.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

The root עלם means to hide, conceal. The word עֶלֶם means youth, strong or mature sexually as explained in the Etymological dictionary of Hebrew by Ernest Klein, and as explained in the comment by magicker72 it comes from a different source which became homophonous in later Biblical Hebrew with the root עלם. There may be a weak conceptual connection between the two roots is that a youth is having a hidden potential, which has yet to be revealed over the course of his or her life. The word עוֹלַם meaning world is referring to its hidden uknown time of existence is a derivative of the root עלם.

Perhaps, the similarity of writing of the roots עֶלֶם - עוֹלַם yielded one of the most powerful statements in the Mishna Sanhedrin 4:5

Therefore, Adam the first man was created alone, to teach you that with regard to anyone who destroys one soul from the Jewish people, i.e., kills one Jew, the verse ascribes him blame as if he destroyed an entire world, as Adam was one person, from whom the population of an entire world came forth. And conversely, anyone who sustains one soul from the Jewish people, the verse ascribes him credit as if he sustained an entire world.

title: If the High Priest were to be unintentionally killed, what becomes of the man-slaughterer?
content:
# If the High Priest were to be unintentionally killed, what becomes of the man-slaughterer? ## Frage

I've been studying up on Numbers 35, which concerns manslaughter and murder. If someone is convicted of murder then they must be put to death. However, if it is determined that the death was accidental (or if there is just insufficient testimony) then the man-slaughterer would be exiled to one of the Cities of Refuge. So long as the man-slaughterer remained within the walls of the city, the avenger of blood could not touch him. However, if he was caught outside of the city walls then the avenger of blood could kill him without sin - fulfilling the requirements of the Noahide Covenant (Genesis 9:6).

There is no animal sacrifice or other way given for someone to redeem the man-slaughterer so that he can return home. However, upon the death of the High Priest all of these man-slaughterers are forgiven. They may return home without fear of the avenger of blood. There is no longer a need to cleanse the land with their blood.

Now, what I was curious about was what happens if someone unintentionally kills the High Priest? If put on trial, would that individual be put to death for killing an anointed of the LORD? Would they be exiled to a City of Refuge until the death of the next High Priest? Or would they immediately be atoned for through the death of the High Priest along with all the other man-slaughterers?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

See Mishnah Makkot 2:7 - one who unintentionally kills the High Priest is exiled to a city of refuge and never leaves.

(There are situations involving multiple people holding the status of high priest simultaneously where it may be possible for the killer to leave - see Maimonides Laws of Murder 7:10 and commentaries there.)

title: Is it permissible to despise hateful and wicked people?
content:
# Is it permissible to despise hateful and wicked people? ## Frage

By hateful and wicked people, I am referring to the likes of antisemites, extremist/terrorists, and hardcore, militant atheists. Please provide sources.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

In Sefer Chofetz Chaim, Hilchos Lashon Hara Klal 8 Seif 5, we learn:

The prohibition of lashon hara applies only to a person whom the Torah still considers part of your nation. That means, one who is "with you" in Torah and mitzvos. However, as regards those people whom you recognize to be apikorsim, it is a mitzvah to deride them and shame them whether in their presence or in their absence, with anything you see them doing or hear about them. For the verse says (Vayikra 25:17) 'A man should not oppress his fellow" and (Vayikta 19:16) "Do not go about as a talebearer amongst your nation." And these people are not in this category (i.e. "your fellow" and "your nation"), for they do not act in the ways of your nation. And it says (Tehillim 139:21) "Do I not hate those that stir up hatred against You, Hashem, and fight against those that quarrel with You?" An apikoris is one that denies Torah and prophecy in Israel, whether he denies the Written Torah or the Oral Torah. Even if he says that the entire Torah is from Hashem except for one verse or one kal v'chomer or one gezeirah shavah or one derivation, he is in this category.

In Shaarei Teshuva 3:148 we learn:

The verse says (Mishlei 27:21) "There is a purifier for silver and a boiling pot for gold, and a man according to his enthusiastic praise." This means that a man's qualities may be judged by what he praises. If he praises righteous deeds and men of wisdom and righteousness, you can know that he is himself a good man, and the root of righteousness is within him. For he only wishes to praise goodness and good men and to deride sins and humiliate the sinners. Therefore you know his quality even before you see him refuse to sin and choose good. And even if he has some hidden sins, he still loves righteousness, and he is among the congregation of those that honor Hashem. But someone that praises despicable acts or praises the wicked--he is an absolutely evil person, and one that defiles the worship of Hashem, may He be praised.

In Sefer Orchot Tzaddikim, Shaar HaSinah, we learn:

There is hatred which is a mitzvah. Namely, hatred against a wicked person that refuses to accept rebuke, as it says (Mishlei 8:13) "Hatred of the evil is the fear of Hashem." And another verse says (Tehillim 139:21-22) "Do I not hate those that stir up hatred against You, Hashem? And I quarrel with those that fight against You. I hate them with the utmost hatred, they are my enemies." And he should hate falsehood and deceit. The bottom line is that he should hate everything that distances him from the love of the Creator, as it says (Tehillim 119:128) "I hated every false path." This is a major rule--a man must hate every false thing. And the more he hates falsehood, the more he increases his love for Torah, as it says (Tehillim 119:163) "I hated falsehood and despised it, I loved Your Torah." And he should love truth and peace, as it says (Zechariah 8:19) "And they loved truth and peace."

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Hatred of people is one of the things that removes a person from the world (Avot 2:11), although as far as I know no precise guidelines are given for when hatred of people in general is permitted or forbidden. But for a Jew to hate a fellow Jew is explicitly a violation of a Torah prohibition (Vayyikra 19:17). It would be permitted (or possibly a mitzva) to hate only in the circumstance that the hater personally witnesses the hated person committing a sin, or if the fact that the person committed the sin is established by the testimony of two witnesses (Pesachim 113b).

According to Sefer Charedim (mitzvot ase midivrei kabbala umidivrei sofrim 1:24, quoted in Tanya chapter 32), another precondition of hating is rebuking the sinner in a pleasant way and the sinner refusing to accept the rebuke (apparently this alone could eliminate most cases where it would be permitted to hate, since there might be no ability to rebuke at all in a generation; see Arachin 16b).

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

The Talmud says says that the Second Temple was destroyed because "senseless hatred" prevailed in Israel [שנאת חנם sin'at chinam]. Rashi says that it is hatred of people who have not committed any action justifying the hatred. [Rashi on Shabbat 32b]

It says not just "hatred", but "senseless hatred". This implied that some hatred makes sense. When does hatred make sense? The Talmud answers: You may bear ill will towards someone if you witnessed him engaging in an act forbidden by the Torah. [Pesaḥim 113b] However, you must assist him quickly, before assisting those you love [so that the ill will does not turn to hatred.] [Bava Metzia 32b] Now, how do you know that you have reached the point of hatred? The Talmud answers: A hater [שונא soné] is someone who does not speak to his fellow for three days because of enmity between them. [Sanhedrin 27b]

title: Can a person be adopted into a tribe?
content:
# Can a person be adopted into a tribe? ## Frage

Related: Does 2 Samuel 6:23 and Samuel 21:8 affirm that you could be adopted into tribal affiliation?

The question linked above asks whether certain Biblical passages support a theory that one can be adopted into tribal affiliation, and it seems dubious that those passages actually do that. Regardless of what the passages quoted in the above question support, is it possible via any means for a person to be adopted into membership into one of the twelve tribes?

For a hypothetical, suppose Reuven is a convert to Judaism and thus lacks tribal membership (or, perhaps, he was born Jewish to a convert father who lacked any tribal membership to pass down). He feels a strong connection to the tribe of Dan and would like to become a member of that tribe. He (somehow) finds a few members of the tribe who are interested in supporting or sponsoring him for tribal adoption. Is this possible? Would being adopted (as in traditional parent/child adoption) by a male member of the tribe be enough to grant tribal membership to the adoptee? Is admission of outsiders to tribal membership a centralized process administered by tribal leaders pursuant to halacha and tribal bylaws? Can a beit din composed of members of the tribe admit a Jew of no tribe into tribal membership in a similar way that a beit din of Jews can admit a Gentile into Jewishness?

To be clear, why a person would want to gain tribal membership in this day and age or why a tribe would want to admit outsiders into tribal membership are not in scope - this is a hypothetical and I'm curious if there is even a way to make this happen.

title: Four Minim blessing with a lack of one Hadas myrtle
content:
# Four Minim blessing with a lack of one Hadas myrtle ## Frage

The one who blessed the 4 Minim and found out (retrospectively after the blessing) that one myrtle cloth fell on him on the way and blessed the set with only two myrtle instead of 3. Before the shaking of the blessing he discovered this and added the myrtle. Is it necessary to repeat the blessing or did it come out with a blessing?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

This basically happened once to Rabbenu Meshullam. One year he accidentally forgot to put the Aravot in his Lulav-bundle and he only noticed after already shaking the deficient bundle and doing something else. He went and put the Aravot back in and blessed "Al Netilat Arava" (and Shehechiyanu since it was the first day) and shook the whole bundle again. His reasoning was the four species can in principle be taken sequentially instead of all together (Menachot 27a) so he only needs to bless on the remaining species, but it is better to take them all together so he picked them up together. (The story is quoted in Orchot Chaim (Lulav 22), in the Beit Yosef (651), and many later authorities.)

Accordingly in your case, if you hadn't interrupted yet after blessing you can just pick up and add the missing myrtle branch, but if you did interrupt then the initial blessing can't cover the myrtle and you'd pick up the three myrtle branches (and ideally all the other species too) and bless "Al Netilat Hadas" (and Shehechiyanu on the first day).

However, this assumes you actually need all 3 myrtle branches. That's a dispute in the Mishna (Sukkah 3:4) and while most authorities rule like the position that you need 3, Ramban rules you can suffice with 1 myrtle branch (cf. OC 651:1). Accordingly, if only one of the three myrtle branches was missing, you may have already fulfilled your obligation and should probably omit any further blessings out of doubt (especially since some later authorities question Rabbeinu Meshullam's position entirely).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Even if all the minim were held at the same time, right side up, he has still not fulfilled the mitzva as it should be done, as is brought in Mishna berura 651:4

וג' הדסים - אפילו שלשתן קטומים שנקטמו ראשן ופחות משלשה לא מהני אפילו לא היו קטומים

And three myrtles - even if all three are cut, that their tops were cut; but less than three is not helpful (meaning, the mtizva isn't considered fulfilled), even if they were not cut.

Therefore, it seems like one would need to retake the 4 minim to fulfill the mitzva. However, there is still the question regarding the bracha (assuming the previous bracha wouldn't work for this time, because of a hefsek - a break - between the bracha and the current taking of the minim). As was pointed out to me in the comments, the shulchan aruch goes on to say that if one doesn't have three hadassim, he should shake with one, which seems to say that bediavad one hadas is enough.

The Kaf Hachayim there (seif katan 4) talks about this explicitly:

נטלו כל הקהל ולא היה בלולב אלא ב' הדסים, צריך לחזור וליטול לולב בג' הדסים ואין כאן משום מוקצה אך לא יברכו

If the entire congregation took [the 4 minim] and there were only two myrtles, they must retake the minim with three myrtles, and there is no problem of Muktze, but they should not make a bracha

(He quotes this in the name of the Beis david, birkei yosef, knesses hagdola, and shaarei teshuva)

Interestingly, the Kaf Hachayim goes on to talk about if someone was missing one of his Aravos, in which case he brings an opinion which says he should make another bracha, because having two Aravos is learned from the Torah. He still seems to lean towards not making a bracha, though.

title: Territorial Disputes in Halacha
content:
# Territorial Disputes in Halacha ## Frage

If 2 countries are fighting over possession/ownership of land, and a person legally owns land in the disputed area according to one of the 2 countries, what would be the Halachic status of such land, in terms of Reshus HaRabim vs Reshus HaYachid?

For example, if someone owned land in Ukraine, wherein the Ukrainian government recognized that person's land as Reshus HaYachid, but the Russian government considered it Reshus HaRabim, what would be the true status of that land? Does it depend on military might or strategic foothold? Does might make right?

Or, in Heaven's perspective, are there true lines that demarcate the country's borders, irrespective of that country's own drawn borders? Like how the plagues that hit Mitzrayim revealed the true boundaries of the country, showing each side how much of the land wasn't actually considered Mitzrayim?

title: Parallel between Cain and Hevel's rivalry with that of Yaakov and Esav's: Could it be that Yaakov and Esav were reincarnations of Hevel and Cain?
content:
# Parallel between Cain and Hevel's rivalry with that of Yaakov and Esav's: Could it be that Yaakov and Esav were reincarnations of Hevel and Cain? ## Frage

It could be said that the rivalry between Cain and Hevel is essentially predicated on the fact that there is a right/proper way to serve G-d. Likewise, part of what led to the rivalry between Yaakov and Esav is the fact that Esav did not really care to serve G-d correctly, if at all, while Yaakov did. And when G-d chose both Hevel and Yaakov over their brothers, their brothers went after them to kill them. Could it be that due to this parallel, Yaakov and Esav were reincarnations of Hevel and Cain?

title: What special merit did Aharon Hakohen have to bring the Ananei Hakovod?
content:
# What special merit did Aharon Hakohen have to bring the Ananei Hakovod? ## Frage

The Gemara Taanis (9a) writes

מֵיתִיבִי, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: שְׁלֹשָׁה פַּרְנָסִים טוֹבִים עָמְדוּ לְיִשְׂרָאֵל, אֵלּוּ הֵן: מֹשֶׁה וְאַהֲרֹן וּמִרְיָם. וְשָׁלֹשׁ מַתָּנוֹת טוֹבוֹת נִיתְּנוּ עַל יָדָם, וְאֵלּוּ הֵן: בְּאֵר, וְעָנָן, וּמָן. בְּאֵר — בִּזְכוּת מִרְיָם, עַמּוּד עָנָן — בִּזְכוּת אַהֲרֹן, מָן — בִּזְכוּת מֹשֶׁה. מֵתָה מִרְיָם — נִסְתַּלֵּק הַבְּאֵר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַתָּמׇת שָׁם מִרְיָם״, וּכְתִיב בָּתְרֵיהּ: ״וְלֹא הָיָה מַיִם לָעֵדָה״, וְחָזְרָה בִּזְכוּת שְׁנֵיהֶן - The Gemara raises an objection from a baraisa: Rebbi Yosei, son of Rebbi Yehuda, says: Three good sustainers rose up for the Jewish people during the exodus from Egypt, and they are: Moshe, Aharon and Miriam. And three good gifts were given from Heaven through their agency, and these are they: The well of water, the pillar of cloud, and the manna. The well was given to the Jewish people in the merit of Miriam; the pillar of cloud was in the merit of Aharon; and the manna in the merit of Moshe. When Miriam died the well disappeared, as it is stated: “And Miriam died there” (Numbers 20:1), and it says thereafter in the next verse: “And there was no water for the congregation” (Numbers 20:2). But the well returned in the merit of both Moshe and Aharon.

What unique merit did Aharon have to deserve the Ananei Hakovod initially?

title: Was Shlomo Molcho HY”D the author of Shalom Aleichem?
content:
# Was Shlomo Molcho HY”D the author of Shalom Aleichem? ## Frage

I recently watched a video claiming that Shlomo Molcho hy”d was the author of the piyut Shalom Aleichem. Does anyone have any sources for this, or does anyone know of anyone else to whom it is attributed?

(The source of Shalom Aleichem has already been discussed here, but I haven’t seen this particular legend addressed.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The Book: "Sefer: Minhag Tov" which seems to have been written in the year (about) 1273-1275;(maybe as late as 1300?), has a list of Jewish customs. One of them (#36), states:

"And it is a good custom on Friday nights, when we come (home) from the Synagogue, to go right away next to the candles lit for the honor of the Sabbath, which we made the blessing upon, and stand next to both of them and say: "Oh angels of mercy and peace, May your coming be for peace, May your coming be for peace, Upon you should be peace, For all of you there should be peace..." And so too have I found written that Rabbi Aharon of Regensburg acustomed himself to do so."

"Sefaria.org" writes the following information about this Book, showing the author is assumed to be an Italian Rabbi of the middle ages:

"Sefer Minhag Tov, an anonymous treatise composed circa 1275, whose author may have studied with northern French Tosafists but who certainly did study with R. Moses ben Meir of Ferrera and perhaps settled in Bari or Taranto..." From Kabbalah: Journal for the Study of Jewish Mystical Texts, Volume 6 pg. 144 (Courtesy of R. Joel Zeff)."

It therefore seems that the original words of at least a proto-Shalom Aleychem liturgy was already in use as early as the mid thirteenth or even twelfth century and probably has roots beforehand as well.

Therefore it would seem to be an error to attribute the creation of the liturgy to Solomon Molcho, or any Jewish figure who lived and was active in the early 1500's.

Here is the link to Sefer Minhag Tov:

https://hebrewbooks.org/pdfpager.aspx?req=8903&st=&pgnum=12&hilite=

title: L'chatchila Ariber: what does it mean and where does it come from?
content:
# L'chatchila Ariber: what does it mean and where does it come from? ## Frage

There seems to be a famous saying from the Rebbe Maharash, Rabbi Shmuel Schneersohn (1834 - 1882):

די וועלט זאגט, אז מ'קען ניט ארונטער דארף מען אריבער, און איך האלט אז מ'דארף לכתחילה אריבער

The world says that if you can’t go underneath, you must go over. But I say that you should go over to begin with.

The Lubavitcher Rebbe often quotes this, for example in Igros Kodesh (here).

What does "L'chatchila Ariber" means, where does it come from, and what is the lesson we are meant to take from it according to the (Chabad) Rebbeim?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

As a starting point see here:

This idea of leaping over obstacles from the very beginning became a symbol of what the Rebbe called a Baal Shem’ske behavior, akin to the conduct of the Baal Shem Tov. It means rising above challenges, never letting obstacles deter you from your path.

There’s a famous story about the Besht, who instructed his students to collect icicles from the roof and then lit them like candles. This was a play on words in Yiddish, in which icicles are called אייז ליכטעלעך = Ice candles. He did this to illustrate the concept of leaping over. The world may say that icicles cannot burn like candles, but the Besht showed that with faith, even seemingly impossible things can be achieved.

In life, people often say we must work within the confines of the world, to be realistic and avoid risks. But the Rebbe teaches us to rise above, to take risks, because we are not limited by the constraints of the world. This attitude leads to success beyond limitations.

The Rebbe loved this idea and encouraged his followers to embrace it.

title: Is ישמעאל Yishm'a-EL Shimon שמעון?
content:
# Is ישמעאל Yishm'a-EL Shimon שמעון? ## Frage

Famously in this week's parshah וְזֹ֣את הַבְּרָכָ֗ה V'zot haBrakah Moses our master gives his last will and testament, his ברכה berakah, benediction to each of the 12 Tribes of Israel

But as many readers have pointed out, and commentators have addressed: not all 12 of the tribes appear to be listed.

The Tribe of Simeon, שמעון Shimon, appears to be missing.

Elsewhere commentators have wrestled with this issue, variously. Rashi says that:

לְשִׁמְעוֹן מִתּוֹךְ בִּרְכוֹתָיו שֶׁל יְהוּדָה

"Shimon's blessing is within Yehudah's"

שְׁמַ֤ע יְהֹוָה֙ ק֣וֹל יְהוּדָ֔ה וְאֶל־עַמּ֖וֹ תְּבִיאֶ֑נּוּ יָדָיו֙ רָ֣ב ל֔וֹ וְעֵ֥זֶר מִצָּרָ֖יו תִּהְיֶֽה׃

Shema'Ya (שמע יהוה), the voice of Judah: restore him to his people, through his own hands strive for him. Help him against his foes.

Remarkably Rashi says that Shema'Ya (שמע יהוה) is Shimon's name! Tying back to the story of his birth to our foremother Leah:

וַתַּ֣הַר עוֹד֮ וַתֵּ֣לֶד בֵּן֒ וַתֹּ֗אמֶר כִּֽי־שָׁמַ֤ע יְהֹוָה֙ כִּֽי־שְׂנוּאָ֣ה אָנֹ֔כִי וַיִּתֶּן־לִ֖י גַּם־אֶת־זֶ֑ה וַתִּקְרָ֥א שְׁמ֖וֹ שִׁמְעֽוֹן׃

And she conceived again and bore a son, and declared, “This is because יהוה heard that I was unloved so he has given me this one also”; so she named him Shimon: G!d heard.

Besides the obvious connection between the names Yishma'EL-Shema'Ya-Shimon (God will hear, G!d hears, G!d has heard) and the interesteing coincidence that Yishma'El also has 12 tribes .... the biographers have tried to establish this connection between Shimon & Yishma'El

Indeed as the Jewish Encylopedia records: "Many attempts have been made to connect Simeon with Ishmael and Massa, and with the founders of Mecca" 1 but it cites no source.

So: is there more to this story and is Yishma'El Shimon and is Shimon Yishma'El?

title: What would be the punishment for a pedophilic act/statutory rape according to halacha?
content:
# What would be the punishment for a pedophilic act/statutory rape according to halacha? ## Frage

Would it necessitate capital punishment, public humiliation like flogging, or something less severe? Sources please.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

There is no standalone commandment against non penetrative pedophilia but it could be a damage.

Bava Kamma lists the categories of damage that could occur.

Nézek: Damage or tort Tsa'ár: Pain or suffering Shavát: Stoppage of work Ripui: Cost of cure Bṓšeṯ: Shame or disgrace

If there was no physical or mental injury and all parties lived in a paedo society where to be molested wasn't considered disgraceful, there would be no damages.

However, the Rabbis (or the King) have a secular authority to flog, execute people, and impose fines even when there aren't kosher witnesses or the act isn't a formal sin.

But is any particular action necessitated? There is a commandment not to stand idly when your neighbor's blood is being spilled so it would make sense that executing, imprisoning, banishing etc. the pedophile would be an obligation and I'm sure some rabbis will rule that way, but I don't think it's explicitly codified in the Mishna Brura or Shulchan Aruch.

see below regarding this authority: https://jcpa.org/article/horaat-shaah-the-emergency-principle-in-jewish-law-and-a-contemporary-application/

title: Connection Between V'zos Habracha & Bereishes
content:
# Connection Between V'zos Habracha & Bereishes ## Frage

On Simchas Torah we read the end of V'zos Habracha and the begining of Bereishes - is there any special connection between them? Maybe something similiar about the Pesukim or the story line?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Rashi on the word בראשית says:

בשביל התורה שנקראת ראשית… ובשביל ישראל שנקראו ראשית.

Simply put, the world was created for the two things called Reishis: the Torah and Bnei Yisrael.

The blessings of Bnei Yisrael are thus very much intertwined with both the creation of the world and the beginning of the Torah.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

A year ago, I wrote this pertinent article, where just past the halfway point is a section beginning with the caption Comparing Bereishis to V'zos - המגיד מראשית אחרית and then has the subsequent section beginning Let's Explore How וזאת הברכה is Very Connected to בראשית!. There you will find some interesting connections between the very end of the Torah and the very beginning.

Among those connections is a great one that I can briefly highlight here. It's based on Rav Chaim Kanievsky's take on the Rokeach's take on the following well known Rashi:

בראשית ברא - אֵין הַמִּקְרָא הַזֶּה אוֹמֵר אֶלָּא דָּרְשֵׁנִי, כְּמוֹ שֶׁדְּרָשׁוּהוּ רַבּוֹתֵינוּ

בִּשְׁבִיל הַתּוֹרָה שֶׁנִקְרֵאת "רֵאשִׁית דַּרְכּוֹ" (משלי ח:כב)

וּבִשְׁבִיל יִשְׂרָאֵל שֶׁנִקְרְאוּ "רֵאשִׁית תְּבוּאָתֹה" (ירמיה ב:ג)

The peirush of the רוקח on the end of וזאת הברכה appears below:
(יצא לאור ע"י יואל קלוגמאן תשל"ט - תשמ"א, הערות מאת הרה"ג ר' חיים קניבסקי)

While the dashes indicate that parts of the original manuscript of the רוקח were unclear, Rav Chaim Kanievsky's notes indicate the following educated guess to the lines:

החומש מתחיל בראשית ומסיים ישראל ואין ראשית אלא ישראל (ירמיהו ב) "קודש ישראל ראשית", בראשית בגימטריא ישראל בחר בעמים. לכך סיים התורה ישראל, התורה כלולה בישראל

that the Chumash begins with the word בראשית and ends with the word ישראל since ישראל itself is considered a type of ראשית and therefore the Torah is filled with ישראל from beginning to end.

title: Why did Hashem create the Livyasan?
content:
# Why did Hashem create the Livyasan? ## Frage

In Parshas Bereishis it says that Hashem created the large fish. Rashi explains that it is referring to the two Livyasans (Leviathans) that Hashem created - a male & a female. He then says that Hashem had to kill the female, because if they would be able to reproduce, there would be no more room in the world for anything else since they are so big.

It is a known thing that Hashem took the Livyasan out of this world and is saving it for a big feast for the Tzadikim in Olam Haba when Moshiach comes - so why did Hashem create the Livyasan if He knew that He wasn't going to need it until Moshiach comes, years later?

title: Why did Hashem create the Ohr HaGanuz?
content:
# Why did Hashem create the Ohr HaGanuz? ## Frage

Rashi says on a Pasuk in Parshas Bereishes that Hashem created the Ohr HaGanuz / a very special light. Hashem then took away this light and reserved it for when Moshiach comes - so if Hashem knew that he wasn't going to need this light until later on, then why did he create it?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

If He created on six days, rested on the seventh, and thousands of years later worked an eighth day we wouldn't have our convenient weekly cycle.

Seven is also an important numerology number and if God was known to make extra creations now and then, it would break the significance of the 7 days of creation and the other 7s we have.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

I have 3 answers to this question:

  1. There is a Pasuk in Koheles that reads:

מַה־שֶּֽׁהָיָה֙ ה֣וּא שֶׁיִּֽהְיֶ֔ה וּמַ֨ה־שֶּׁנַּֽעֲשָׂ֔ה ה֖וּא שֶׁיֵּֽעָשֶׂ֑ה וְאֵ֥ין כָּל־חָדָ֖שׁ תַּ֥חַת הַשָּֽׁמֶשׁ

"What has been is what will be, and what has been done is what will be done, and there is nothing new under the sun"*

This shows that there is nothing new ever created and that everything was create originally by the creation of the world.

  1. So that people can find the Ohr HaGanuz through learning Torah.
  2. The Zohar says that once a week on Shabbos this light is shown on us, and therefore Hashem created it by Brias HaOlam.

title: Grammar of Pausal Forms in Selichos, Hoshanos, etc
content:
# Grammar of Pausal Forms in Selichos, Hoshanos, etc ## Frage

In the S'lichos of Nusach Lita we read towards the end a tefila, which is stated using the ךָ-ֶ (-ekha) pausal form:

עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן אֲמִתֶּךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן בְּרִיתֶךָ. עֲשֵׁה לְמַֽעַן גָּדְלֶךָ וְתִפְאַרְתֶּךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן דָּתֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן הוֹדֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן וִעוּדֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן זִכְרֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן חַסְדֶּךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַעַן טוּבֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן יִחוּדֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן כְּבוֹדֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן לִמּוּדֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן מַלְכוּתֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן נִצְחֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן סוֹדֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן עֻזֶּךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן פְּאֵרֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן צִדְקָתֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן קְדֻשָּׁתֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן רַחֲמֶֽיךָ הָרַבִּים. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן שְׁכִינָתֶךָ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן תְּהִלָּתֶךָ.

In the Yom Kippur Nussach Ashkenaz, the same tefilah is stated in the ךְ-ָ (-akh) pausal form:

עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן אֲמִתָּךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן בְּרִיתָךְ. עֲשֵׁה לְמַֽעַן גָּדְלָךְ וְתִפְאַרְתָּךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן דָּתָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן הוֹדָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן וִעוּדָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן זִכְרָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן חַסְדָּךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַעַן טוּבָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן יִחוּדָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן כְּבוֹדָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן לִמּוּדָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן מַלְכוּתָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן נִצְחָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן סוֹדָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן עֻזָּךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן פְּאֵרָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן צִדְקָתָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן קְדֻשָּׁתָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן רַחֲמֶֽיךָ הָרַבִּים. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן שְׁכִינָתָךְ. עֲשֵׂה לְמַֽעַן תְּהִלָּתָךְ.

By comparison, on Succos we say all the Hoshanos in the later form. What is the origin of these differences and what is the correct way to say?

I also saw a similar difference between some siddurim in pointing the piyut Y'did Nefesh (Seuda Shlishi of Shabbos). What is interesting, is that everybody sings the melody as if it was written for the -akh form but incorrectly pronounces the nekudos of the printed -ekha form, especially the first line. The same problem is with the last stanza of Dror Yikra (thanks Double AA).

title: Why Would a Kohen Create Pigul? Weaponization?
content:
# Why Would a Kohen Create Pigul? Weaponization? ## Frage

One who eats Pigul is Chayav Karet (see Zevachim, Mishna 2:2). There are several ways to create Pigul, but a simple case is such: Priest A is receiving the blood of a sacrificial animal, and he thinks about eating the meat of the same animal beyond its allotted time. One must discontinue the sacrificial service. But if the service is continued and certain conditions come true and the blood is sprinkled ... anyone who eats the meat of that sacrifice, even within the permitted time, receives Karet. Kohanim, however, are presumably scrupulous in their activities. Why would a Kohen do this?

In fact, the Mishna in Gitin 5:4 states:

הַכֹּהֲנִים שֶׁפִּגְּלוּ בַמִּקְדָּשׁ מְזִידִין, חַיָּבִין.Kohanim who intentionally create Pigul in the Temple are liable (for monetary damages to the owner of the sacrifice).

The Yachin/Tiferet Yisrael states:

מזידין שידע שמזיקו בזה:

Intentionally (means) that he knew he would harm/ruin (the property of another via) this (act)

The Yachin goes on to say:

ונ״ל דלהכי לא נקיט ה״נ שוגגין פטורים, מדאינו מצוי שלא ידע הכהן שמפסיד הקרבן כשיפגלו ויהיה שוגג, דהרי למד דיני קרבן ה׳ שנים קודם שנכנס לעבודה. It appears to me that the reason that (the Mishna) did not similarly state (if Kohanim created Pigul)"by accident they are not liable", is because it is not common for a Kohen not to know that he ruins the sacrifice/property when he does Pigul (the case of accident does not normatively exist) for a Kohen studies the laws of sacrifices five years before initiating his service.

Thus, it is clear that accidental Pigul is a misnomer and not part of the discussion; Kohanim knew about the ramifications and consequences of their sacrificial actions. What is the motive? A Kohen weaponizing a sacrifice - intentionally, on occasion, to thwart the penitence of another?

The weaponization theory is not that far-fetched:

בן ידיד הלכות גניבה פרק ב הלכה א כהנים שפגלו במקדש לחבירו הוא שהזיק כדי שיביא אחר או שלא יעשה רצונו שלא הביא דורון. Ben Ydid Laws of Theft, 2:1 - Kohanim who create Pigul in the Temple, he has harmed his friend in order to (force him) to bring another (sacrifice) or so that (God) not do his (friend's) will because he did not bring a gift.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

It is difficult, if not impossible, to infer any motive from the actual Kohanim from that time. And I couldn't think of a description somewhere where Pigul has actually occurred, and than explained why it had occurred. We are left to infer.

The Mishnah presents a scenario where a priest, who is ideally highly scrupulous, introduces an improper intent that could invalidate an entire sacrifice. Because Pigul requires intent we can rule out that the laws of Pigul is used to cover for any mistakes, or 'young trainee'-situations. Zevachim doesn’t elaborate much on why a Kohen might intentionally think improper thoughts during the sacrificial service, leaving us to wonder whether it was:

  • A rare but real occurrence that needed a legal framework,
  • More of a theoretical construct to safeguard the sanctity of the Temple rituals, or
  • Addressing concerns about potential spiritual negligence or internal conflicts among even our most dedicated people.

As mentioned in the comments by @Double_AA, even a momentary lapse in judgement for whatever personal reasons could create a situation of pigul; and the Mishna seems to (pre-emptively?) provide a legal framework for handling this for whenever it would occur.

Without any known anecdotes we are left to imagine scenarios where even a Kohen Gadol would suffer a momentary lapse in judgement or succumb to a spiritual struggle, or chas weshalom act out of malicious intent.

title: Is it permissible to speak while shaking the lulav and etrog in the sukkah?
content:
# Is it permissible to speak while shaking the lulav and etrog in the sukkah? ## Frage

After saying the bracha, is it permissible to speak while shaking the lulav and etrog in the sukkah?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

There would be an issue of talking between the bracha for making a mitzva and performing the mitzva. For example, when you make a beracha to put on the tallis, you shouldn't speak u til you actually wore the tallis .

In the case of the lulav, you shouldn't speak between the beracha and the נטילה. But keep in mind that the moment you hold all 4 species in the right direction (estrogen with the pittum side up) you were technically already yotze the mitzva. So talking thereafter, even while you are performing the minhag of shaking the lulav in all directions, isn't a problem, because it is not a hefsek between the berach and the mitzvah performance.

See SA SA OC 651:5, that one needs to make the beracha before holding the etrog the correct way, so that the beracha is made prior to being יוצא the mitzva. This proves that just holding the species the correct way is enough to be יוצא.

title: Who are the lulav and the hadasim?
content:
# Who are the lulav and the hadasim? ## Frage

There is a popular midrash that the four species on Sukkos represent four kinds of people. I usually see it in the form where the smell corresponds to mitzvos and the taste corresponds to Torah learning (example):

  • Esrog: Torah and mitzvos
  • Lulav: Torah but not mitzvos
  • Hadasim: Mitzvos but not Torah
  • Aravos: No Torah and no mitzvos

This is the version of the midrash in Vayikra Rabbah and Pesikta Derav Kahana.

R' Elazar Hakalir's siluk for the first day of Sukkos says the opposite: taste is mitzvos and smell is Torah, with the result that the lulav and hadasim are switched with respect to the common version.

Dr. Goldschmidt in the footnotes cites both midrashim, but (uncharacteristically) doesn't point out the switch. Are there any other old or recent sources that have the switched version? Does anyone mention the difference or discuss the implications of taste and smell corresponding to one or the other?

I would have thought that back in Europe when people were still saying piyutim, they'd have been more familiar with the Kalir's version, so it's interesting that the other one became more popular.

title: Can an Orthodox Jew attend a Christmas party?
content:
# Can an Orthodox Jew attend a Christmas party? ## Frage

Can an Orthodox Jew attend a Christmas party? Many Jewish people have Christian friends, and those that have undergone a conversion to Judaism typically also have Christian friends (as well relationships with the family that they grew up with). Is there anything that would make this forbidden?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The main issue may possibly be the Gemara (Avodah Zarah 8a) that states that "Jews in the Diaspora worship idolatry in purity". What does this mean? When a Gentile makes a personal celebration (like a wedding for their child), he invites Jews to the party and they attend. Even though they eat their own kosher food, the Torah considers it as if they are eating idolatrous sacrifices from the host. It says, “Lest you make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land, and they prostitute themselves to their gods and sacrifice to their gods, and one of them invites you and you eat of his sacrifice” (Ex. 34:15). The end of the verse implies that you may not accept an invitation from an idolater and, if you do, it is as if you are eating from his idolatrous sacrifice.

This being said- it is quite possible that these aren’t really "religious" celebrations. Most large companies nowadays try to accommodate people of all religions and do not have explicitly religious celebrations. These “holiday” parties and are entirely secular. If something even remotely religious happens, like singing Christmas carols or someone entering dressed as Santa Claus, I would possibly leave (Although I’m not convinced that either of the two examples I mentioned are actually religious). But really we are just talking about a neutral holiday party.

Gentiles today do not worship idolatry and, even if they do, they do not thank their god that a Jew who works in their legal department attended a mandatory business party.

People may get very offended if Jews as a group, or even religious Jews as a group, refuse to go to the company’s holiday party. The company spends a lot of money on what they consider to be a morale booster and if you refuse to participate, especially after they make certain that there is nothing religiously offensive and glatt kosher food is available, you are undermining company morale and offending executives.

sources for more details:

Shulchan Arukh (Yoreh De’ah 152:1)- see discussions of shach and Taz of biblical or rabbinic.

Rav Menasheh Klein (Mishneh Halakhos 7:118) rules like Taz (not allowed)

Levush explicitly rules that eivah (offending) overrides the prohibition against attending a Gentile party (to which the Taz objects)

Rav Moshe Feinstein (Iggeros Moshe, Yoreh De’ah 2:117) seems to rule like Shach, allowing it in cases of eivah.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

R. Ari Wasserman has a section in his book Making it work dedicated to the question of attending non-Jewish social gatherings and holiday parties.

He identifies several issues:

  • A Torah prohibition of eating at a non-Jewish wedding (see YD 152:1)
  • Concerns of idolatry
  • Concerns that it would lead to intermarriage
  • Having to balance the above concerns with the need to maintain cordial relations with non-Jews (eivah)

Regarding office parties specifically, he brings multiple opinions, from those strictly forbidding them (e.g., when no legitimate need, parties before non-Jewish holidays with food and alcohol served, or mixed dancing) to certain opinions permitting them (e.g., where non-attendance might bring significant repercussions and parties are professional rather than for enjoyment).

R. Doniel Neustadt (here) brings the following:

It depends on the type of party the company is having. Many times, a company’s holiday party has nothing to do with the celebration of the holiday; rather it is an employee appreciation party that happens to take place during the holiday season. There is no halachic objection to attending such a party. But if the intention of the party is to celebrate the actual non-Jewish holiday, it would be forbidden for a Jew to attend.

However, even if the party is not intended to celebrate a non-Jewish holiday, non-Jewish office parties are hardly the place for an observant Jew to be. The mode of dress, the type of language and the loose behavior at such affairs is completely alien and contrary to everything that Yiddishkeit stands for. It is clear, therefore, that if for business reasons one must attend such a party, he or she must do so only when there is no other choice, and even then, he or she must come and go as quickly as possible. Lingering in such an environment can lead to serious transgression of many Torah laws.

For further sources see here and there.

title: When G-d spoke to a particular individual, does anybody else hear what He is saying?
content:
# When G-d spoke to a particular individual, does anybody else hear what He is saying? ## Frage

At one point, the whole world heard G-d during the revelation in Mt. Sinai, but when G-d specifically spoke to someone, could anyone have eavesdropped and heard what He said or could it be only heard by the person He was talking to? For example, if G-d was revealing a prophecy to a prophet and somehow, someone was in the vicinity where G-d and the prophet are communicating, could the bystander hear/be privy to what was being said/communicated?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

In 1 Shmuel 3:1-10, G-d speaks to Samuel and Eli doesn't hear it:

1And the lad Samuel was serving the Lord before Eli. Now the word of the Lord was withheld in those days; vision had not broken through. 2And it was on that day, that Eli was lying in his place, and his eyes had begun to grow dim; he could not see. 3And the lamp of God had not yet gone out, and Samuel was lying down. In the Temple of the Lord, where the Ark of God was. 4The Lord called to Samuel, and he said, "Here I am." 5And he ran to Eli, and said, "Here I am, for you have called me." And he said, "I did not call. Go back and lie down." And he went and lay down. 6And the Lord continued to call again to Samuel, and Samuel arose, and went to Eli, and said, "Here I am, for you have called me.'' And he said, "I have not called, my son. Go back and lie down." 7Now, Samuel had not yet known the Lord, and the word of the Lord had not yet been revealed to him. 8And the Lord continued to call Samuel for the third time; and he arose and went to Eli, and said, "Here I am, for you called me." And Eli understood that that the Lord was calling the youth. 9And Eli said to Samuel, "Go, lie down. And it shall be, if He will call you, that you shall say, 'Speak, O Lord, for Your bondsman is listening.' " And Samuel went and lay down in his place. 10And the Lord came and stood, and He called as at the other times, "Samuel! Samuel!" And Samuel said, "Speak, for Your bondsman is listening."

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The Alshich describes (Shir Hashirim 1:2) prophesy as Hashem speaking to someone through their soul. Even though "the ears hear", they are hearing internally.

The Sinai event was an exception, where Hashem tore open the heavens.

It seems the default case is that nobody else can hear, unless Hashem makes an exception.

title: Can you destroy property to save your life?
content:
