title: Esav's religious and Jewish status
content:
# Esav's religious and Jewish status ## Frage

Is Esav still considered a Jew considering his parents being Yitzchak and Rivka, and having brit milah? Also, what was his religious status? Was he really an idol worshipper or just non-observant, perhaps even an atheist? Please cite sources, thanks.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The commentary Tosafos Daas Zekeinim on Bereshis 25:25 quotes a midrash without a reference, from which we can answer negatively about Eisav's circumcision:

ויצא הראשון אדמוני, “the first baby emerged, reddish looking;” according to a Midrash, when his father saw that, he concluded that the blood of the infant had not yet matured to the stage when he could be circumcised without that operation endangering his life, and that is why he delayed the date for the circumcision. Something similar is related in the Talmud, tractate Shabbat, folio 134, where Rabbi Nathan relates that he once met a lady who had lost two of her children as a result of circumcision. She asked him if she had to circumcise her third son also and risk losing him too. When Rabbi Nathan looked at the infant, he noted that his skin looked extremely red. He therefore told his mother to wait with circumcising him until this red skin would become normal looking. She did so, and circumcised him in due course and he survived without further problem. When Yitzchok waited a year or two for the skin colour of Esau to change and it did not happen, he assumed that this son was going to remain in that condition, but he still did not circumcise him. When he turned 13, he still restrained himself from circumcising him. He had waited all this time thinking that seeing he had not been circumcised at the age of eight days he would circumcise him at the age Yishmael had been circumcised. This is what was meant in the Book of Ezekiel chapter 35,6: אם לא דם שנאת ודם ירדפך, “surely though you have hated blood, blood shall pursue you.”

At the same time, the midrash Bereshis Rabba 76:9 states in affirmative that Eisav was circumcised:

“He arose during that night and he took his two wives, and his two maidservants, and his eleven children, and crossed the ford of the Yabok” (Genesis 32:23). “He arose during that night and he took his two wives, and his two maidservants…” – but where was Dina? He placed her in a chest and locked it with her in it. He said: ‘This wicked one has a covetous eye; [I do this] so he will not direct his eyes, see her, and take her from me.’ Rav Huna said in the name of Rabbi Abba HaKohen Bardela: The Holy One blessed be He said to him: ‘“For the sake of one who deprives his neighbor of kindness” (Job 6:14) – you withheld kindness from your neighbor, you withheld kindness from your brother. Had she married the man, she would not have engaged in licentiousness. You did not seek to marry her to a circumcised man, so she married an uncircumcised man. You did not seek to marry her in a permitted fashion, so she married in a prohibited fashion.’ That is what is written: “Dina daughter of Leah…went out” (Genesis 34:1).

This is resolved with the help of the commentary Yefeh Toar on Bereshis Rabba 76.9.3. The full published version by Machon Aharon states (unlike Sefaria):

We have a difficulty, above in p. 63:18 Eisav hates the blood of milla, i.e. consequently he was ערל (uncircumcized), and we cannot apply there principle that ערלי/uncircumcized of Israel are called מהולים/circumcized (as in mishna Nedarim 3:11), thus what we explained there - is fitting.

By Sefaria numbering, the reference is midrash Bereshis Rabba 63:13 (Sefaria uses different enumeration as compared to the edition of the midrash). The relevant words there:

Did Esau hate blood? Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥman said: This is the blood of birthright and offerings. Rabbi Levi said: זה דם מילה - This is the blood of circumcision. The Rabbis said: You hated a person’s blood in his body. That is what is written: “He loved curses, and they will now come upon him. [He had no desire for blessing, and it will now be far from him]” (Psalms 109:17).

Explans Yefeh Toar (in the Machon Aharon edition):

זה דם מילה: he pulled his orla, and all his children were uncircumcized.

As far as person's religious status, in Judaism either a person believes in G-d, or is a follower of Avodah Zara (foreign worship - anything but G-d). There is no distinction for atheism.

title: How could Amram have seen Jacob given Biblical chronology?
content:
# How could Amram have seen Jacob given Biblical chronology? ## Frage

The Talmud says that Amram saw Jacob (Bava Batra 121b). But Exodus 12:40 says that the sons of Israel were in Egypt for 430 years. Aaron was 83 during the Exodus, and Amram lived to be 137, and Jacob lived to be 147. So this means that Jacob was born at most 367 years before the Exodus. So even if Ex 12:40 is talking about the time in Egypt and Canaan, how can this be possible because Israel himself didn't exist 430 years before the Exodus, so his sons couldn't have done anything. In fact not even Isaac existed 430 years before the Exodus.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 9)

According to traditional Jewish sources, the sojourn in Egypt was 210 years. The number 430 refers to the length of time from the Covenant of the Pieces (ברית בין הבתרים) to the Exodus, which was defined as a kind of sojourn spread across Canaan, Goshen and Egypt. See e.g., Tanchuma Miketz 8:1; Rashi on Genesis 15:13; Rashi on Exodus 12:40 (based on Mechilta de-Rabbi Yishmael 14:15); Beresheet Rabbah 63:3; Seder Olam Rabbah ch. 3.

title: Ha'azinu as a spiritual remedy for heretical thoughts
content:
# Ha'azinu as a spiritual remedy for heretical thoughts ## Frage

The B'nei Yissoschor in the sefer Agra D'Pirka, as quoted by the sefer Kavod Shabbos (Parshas Ha'azinu, p. 548) says:

לומר בכל יום שירת האזינו: נראה לי בסגולה ללמוד בכל יום שירת האזינו, והוא סגולה להנצל מאפיקורסות ומדעות הכוזביות

To recite the Song of Ha'azinu every day: It seems to me to be a worthwhile practice to study the Song of Haazinu every day, as it is a spiritual remedy (segulah) to be saved from heresy and false beliefs.

See also the Steipler Gaon in Kiryana D'Igarta (Vol. 1, letter 45):

I have also seen it brought in holy books that reciting the Song of Ha'azinu every day greatly dispels thoughts of heresy [though, of course, not immediately but over time]. Many years ago, someone came to me, lamenting about thoughts of heresy, heaven forbid. I told him what is mentioned in the holy books about reciting the Song of Ha'azinu, and he did so for several consecutive years. He later informed me that he was completely saved from these thoughts. May G-d help us for the sake of His Name.

What exactly is it about the Shir Ha'azinu that dispells heretical thoughts from a person? Are there any meforshim or sources that discuss this? Why especially Ha'azinu?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

There is a fascinating article here which relates an amazing story about the Ramban and a student of his that became a heretic. Whilst the student starting by mocking his Rebbe, eventually they got talking about what made him reject yiddishkeit in its entirety. The student responded, “I heard from you that all the events from the creation of the world to the coming of the Moshiach, including the private things that will happen to every man of Israel, are all implied in the song of Haazinu. This seemed impossible to me and made me doubt everything I had learned from you.”

With this as an introduction, the article goes on to note that the Rebbe Rayetz also brings down the segula (refer to his Sefer Zichronos, cheilek alef, p. 125 4th par) and the article notes a tentative reason behind why Shiras Haazinu carries so much weight...

הרבי מליובאוויטש מבאר, כי שירת האזינו מהווה מכלול שלם של דרך חיים. החל מחסדי ה’ איתנו, דרך הפניית עורף מצידנו, התוצאה שנגרמת ממעשינו – ועד לגאולה העתידית. חלק התוכחה הם גם כן חלק מהשירה הכללית, ולא ניתן להתעלם, כאשר בוחנים את מסלול החיים המלא, מהקטעים הפחות נעימים. גם בהם, בגאולה העתידה, יתגלה כי הכל היה לטובה.

בסופו של דבר, השירה כולה מלמדת אותנו כי ‘הצור תמים פעלו’. גם כאשר ישנם מאורעות שאיננו מבינים, מדובר בתהליך שעלינו לעבור עד לגאולה העתידית, אז נגלה כי הכל היה לטובה. “א-ל אמונה ואין עול, צדיק וישר הוא”.

The Lubavitcher Rebbe explains that the Song of Haazinu constitutes a complete whole way of life. Starting from G-d's grace with us, through our turning away, the result of our actions – and up to the future redemption. The parts of the rebuke are also part of the general poem, and we cannot ignore, when examining the full course of life, the less pleasant parts. Even in them, in the future redemption, it will be revealed that everything was for the best.

Ultimately, the entire poem teaches us that ‘The Rock — whose deeds are perfect.’ Even when there are events that we do not understand, it is a process that we must go through until the future redemption, when we will discover that everything was for the best. “A faithful G-d, never false, true and upright indeed.”

So possibly one can suggest that since the whole song is rooted in the essence of life and alludes to G-d's all-powerful Omnipresence, that runs counter to any heretical thought.

Upon researching further, the Sefer Chikrei Minhagim (cheilek beis) brings down all the sources for the regular recitation of Haazinu, and notes a further idea that would perhaps answer this question (see over the page from the subtitle - "הפלאתה של פרשת האזינו" - "The wonder of Parshas Haazinu")

It notes that it is quoted in the name of the Ramban1 that:

כלולים כל המצוות וכל הדברים שבעולם

All the commandments and all the things in the world are included (in Parshas Haazinu).

In other words, Haazinu is significant. With a song that has such a deep rooted message, one that encompasses all the Mitzvos etc. arguably this is the strongest segula for heretical thoughts.

1 Note that this quote relates to the Ramban's interaction with his apostate student mentioned above. It is cited in several places including Seder HaDoros, cheilek alef, p.214 (left hand column, 7 lines up from the bottom) and also Kav HaYashar 23:5.

title: Why is Judaism not universally relevant?
content:
# Why is Judaism not universally relevant? ## Frage

Why are Noahide laws deemed sufficient for non-Jews while Jews are obligated to a distinct, more comprehensive system?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Sanhedrin 58b and 59a explain that gentiles who study the seven Mitzvot are considered like a kohen gadol, who undertakes the most holy service in the beit hamikdash. We have various traditions that a non-Jew can merit the World to Come for practicing these mitzvot and doing good deeds. While we are obligated to accept converts and treat them with kindness and the utmost respect, we do not attempt to convert anyone, with rare historical exceptions, such as in Yemen.

Makkot 23b shows Rabbi Simlai explaining that Jews have 613 mitzvot which we are obligated to learn and follow. This is why the seven mitzvot bnei Noach are not adequate for Jews.

title: Why do we intentionally not bless the festival after the haftarah on Shabbat Chol HaMoed Pesach?
content:
# Why do we intentionally not bless the festival after the haftarah on Shabbat Chol HaMoed Pesach? ## Frage

On Shabbat Chol haMoed Pesach, all of my Ashkenaz siddurim will tell you to make the regular Shabbat blessing as the final one after the reading of the Haftarah. This is different than the instruction on Shabbat Chol haMoed Sukkot, where one makes a blessing that also includes the festival.

One might initially think this is the same principle or pattern applied as Why is Hallel different in Sukkot and Pesach (chol ha-moed)? i.e. the ongoing use of lulav and unique sacrifices make Sukkot a special day each day. The Torah service would be consistent in that sense with the Hallel that came before except . . .

Relatively soon afterwards on that same morning, you are going to make that same blessing: מְקַדֵּשׁ הַשַּׁבָּת וְיִשרָאֵל וְהַזְמַנִּים as you do throughout the festival during Musaf. It is perfectly appropriate thing to say there, but highlights the question: why would that be inappropriate during the Torah service? It makes the explicit choice to only mention Shabbat after the Haftarah look more like an intentional exception.

What is the reason that our tradition is to explicitly not mention the festival at this point?

It also strikes me that this is in some sense different stakes than the question about Hallel. Making a berakah or which one to make is a different, possibly weightier, thing than saying more or fewer Psalms. Is this a misconception?

״אִסְרוּ חַג בַּעֲבוֹתִים עַד קַרְנוֹת הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״. אָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַי, וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הַמָּחוֹזִי מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן הַמָּכוֹתִי: כׇּל הָעוֹשֶׂה אִיסּוּר לֶחָג בַּאֲכִילָה וּשְׁתִיָּה, מַעֲלֶה עָלָיו הַכָּתוּב כְּאִילּוּ בָּנָה מִזְבֵּחַ וְהִקְרִיב עָלָיו קׇרְבָּן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אִסְרוּ חַג בַּעֲבוֹתִים עַד קַרְנוֹת הַמִּזְבֵּחַ״.

Bind [isru] with dense-leaved branches [ba’avotim] on the Festival until the horns of the altar” (Psalms 118:27), which alludes to both the binding of the lulav and to the myrtle branch, referred to in the Torah as the branch of a dense-leaved tree [anaf etz avot]. title: During the Mabul, did birds die first or last?
content:
# During the Mabul, did birds die first or last? ## Frage

Bereishis 7:21 implies the birds died first in the Mabul:

וַיִּגְוַע כָּל־בָּשָׂר הָרֹמֵשׂ עַל־הָאָרֶץ בָּעוֹף וּבַבְּהֵמָה וּבַחַיָּה וּבְכָל־הַשֶּׁרֶץ הַשֹּׁרֵץ עַל־הָאָרֶץ וְכֹל הָאָדָם׃ - And all flesh that stirred on earth perished — birds, cattle, beasts, and all the things that swarmed upon the earth, and all humankind.

However, two pesukim later (7:23) implies the birds died last:

וַיִּמַח אֶת־כָּל־הַיְקוּם אֲשֶׁר עַל־פְּנֵי הָאֲדָמָה מֵאָדָם עַד־בְּהֵמָה עַד־רֶמֶשׂ וְעַד־עוֹף הַשָּׁמַיִם וַיִּמָּחוּ מִן־הָאָרֶץ וַיִשָּׁאֶר אַךְ־נֹחַ וַאֲשֶׁר אִתּוֹ בַּתֵּבָה׃ - All existence on earth was blotted out—humans, cattle, creeping things, and birds of the sky; they were blotted out from the earth. Only Noah was left, and those with him in the ark.

Although maybe the birds were struck first by the heavy rainfall, they also could have flown to the highest available points then hovered for longer - when did they die in the flood?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Ostriches died first because they stupidly buried their heads in the flooded dirt.

Job 39:17 For God caused her to forget wisdom, and He did not give her a share of understanding.

The rest of the birds died last because they could fly to the tops of mountains.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Thank you for the humor Clint Eastwood. The obvious answer is that all creatures died at about the same time. The two orders of verses are a testament to this fact. In a number of other cases the Torah reverses the order to show that there is not special preference to either term mentioned. The most famous is Shemos 20:12 and Devarim 5:16 mitzvah of honoring parents with father preceding the mother:

Honor your father and your mother, that you may long endure on the land that your God Hashem is assigning to you.

Honor your father and your mother, as your G-d Hashem has commanded you, that you may long endure, and that you may fare well, in the land that your G-d Hashem is assigning to you.

When describing the mitzvah of reverence the order is reversed Vayikra 19:3:

You shall each revere your mother and your father, and keep My sabbaths: I Hashem am your God.

The obvious halakhic consequence: "The laws of honor and reverence are equally relevant with regard to one's father and mother" (Rabbi Moshe Lieber "The Fifth Commandment" Chapter 1, section A halacha 2).

title: Can We Use Our Reward In The Next World Like Money In This World?
content:
# Can We Use Our Reward In The Next World Like Money In This World? ## Frage

A story about the Vilna Ga’on appears in Halachic Man (on p.30 in the 1984 English edition). I feel like I’ve heard essentially the same story many times, told about various historical figures, although I cannot now remember. In Halachic Man, the author refers to the story as a folk legend.

In the story, the Vilna Ga’on is unable to obtain Hadassim that he needs to perform one of the commandments of Sukkot. He sends people out to search, and Hadassim are found, growing in a particular woman’s yard. She agrees to sell them to the Vilna Ga’on, but the price that she demands is the reward that the Vilna Ga’on should receive for performing the Mitzvah. He agrees to the price and is, surprisingly, very happy when performing the Mitzvah on these terms. He explains that he is now able to perform the Mitzvah not for the sake of receiving a reward.

I have several problems with this story.

  1. In the internal logic, it seems strange that Hadassim are growing in this woman’s yard but no place else. The climate and soil permit cultivation, and need for Hadassim on Sukkot should have taken nobody by surprise.
  2. Also in the internal logic, there seems to be no reason for the Vilna Ga’on to have been happy on this particular occasion, if he could have made the same arrangement on every occasion. Similarly, if any of you would like to assign to me all of the reward for your performance of Mitzvos, you need only say the word.
  3. Stepping outside of the internal logic now, how could our reward in the next world be like money that we can spend in this world? Could we set up an economy on this basis, paying for groceries and babysitting with a share of our reward in the next life? Could a rich man go around to all of the poor people, buying their reward on the cheap, depending only on their misfortune in needing money? This way of thinking about reward is repellant in that it undermines the justice of reward and punishment, which is seemingly the whole point of reward and punishment.
  4. The Vilna Ga’on died in 1797. The original Hebrew text of Halachic man was published in 1944. The English edition that I saw provides no source for the story.
  5. I cannot think of any old telling of any comparable story. For example, in the story (Avodah Zarah 18) about the execution of Chanania Ben Tradyon, someone sacrifices his own life to help, after assurance that he will receive a share in the world to come, and the story then assures us that he did receive that reward. And in the relationship between Zevulun and Issachar that Rashi mentions (Gen 49:13, Deut 33:18), Zevulun works to support Issachar in learning; and everyone I ask seems to understand some sort of implication for the reward each party receives. But in these stories, everyone is genuinely doing something meritorious, and the reward could simply by commensurate with the desert. That seems clearly not the intention in the story of the Vilna Ga’on. In the Vilna Ga’on story, the idea seems to be that the woman is receiving more reward than her actions really recommend, simply because she drove a hard bargain; and her reward is at the expense of the party actually deserving of the reward, so that nobody seems to be getting reward according to his merit.

So, I ask you.

Can you point me to authoritative sources for this idea that while we live, we can use our future reward as money for the payment of our bills, so that in the end these arrangements will actually transfer reward from the otherwise deserving party to the otherwise undeserving party? Is there any way to improve the provenance of this Vilna Ga’on story, or comparable “Gedolim” stories? Are there relevant ancient, medieval or Renaissance versions?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

The premise behind your question is logically compelling. How can 'future reward' be transferred from one to another like a form of currency? And, indeed, there are numerous sources - most notably, R' Hai Gaon [quoted by Maharam Alashkar (Siman 101) and cited by R' Akiva Eger (Hil. Talmud Torah)], who decry the concept of buying or selling reward.

Your question asks for authoritative sources for such a concept. If you accept the Vilna Gaon as authoritative, you probably will be happy with a source from his disciple R' Chaim Volozhin. In Ruach Chaim (commentary to Avos, 1:1) R' Chaim Volozhin tells the story of the author of Turei Zahav (known as the 'Taz'), who 'donated' the reward of one study session to a sick child, who recovered in that merit.

A century before the Taz (1586-1667), Shiltei Giborim (d. 1557) in his glosses to Rif (Baba Kama 32b) indicates this idea - that one can effectively sell his divine reward for money - although he provides a caveat that the sale takes place prior to performing the mitzvah. [See, however, Shu"t Meishiv Davar 14 for a different understanding].

ולפ"ז יעלה יפה מה שכתבתי דאדם יכול למכור המצות שלו ויעלו לאיש הקונה דהא יש להם ערך י' זהובים לאחר מיהו נראה דוקא מועיל הקנין במצוה שעתיד לעשות אבל לא במצוה שעשה כבר

Imrei Binah (Responsa, Siman 13) attempts to reconcile the opinions by differentiating between two types of 'divine reward'. See also this answer

title: The famous Morid HaGeshem vs. Goshem debate as it relates to Morid HaTal
content:
# The famous Morid HaGeshem vs. Goshem debate as it relates to Morid HaTal ## Frage

Just to establish some basic grammar rules quickly - if a word starts with two segols and is the end of a sentence, the first segol is often changed to a kamatz (one example of many in the Torah: Yefes turns into Yufes when the note is an esnachta or it's a sof passuk). Similarly, a patach will be changed to a kamatz if it's the end of a sentence (maaluh --> muluh).

There's a famous debate among poskim quoted in several answers to this question about whether the line of Mashiv HaRuach ends in Morid HaGeshem or Morid HaGushem, a segol under the gimmel or a kamatz. However it seems to be more or less universal among those who say Morid HaTal to say it with a kamatz under the tess (Morid HaT-uh-l instead of Morid HaT-ah-l). Rav Shlomo Zalman Aurbach is quoted in a Dirshu Mishna Brurah note in Siman 114 as saying it should be a patach but every siddur I've seen has it as a kamatz. Assuming there's basis for pronouncing Tul with a kamatz, which indicates that whatever line you're saying before Mechalkel is separate and has a stoppage before Mechalkel, why would you say Morid HaGeshem with a segol, which implies the line continues into Mechalkel? As it happens, R' SZ Aurbach is quoted in that same Dirshu note as saying it should be Geshem with a segol, so the question would not be on him, but most siddurim have the pronunciation of Geshem with a segol and Tul with a Kamatz.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

This answer is from Emes L'Yaakov Al HaTorah, p. מ״ו-מ״ז.

First of all, it seems the custom of the Stoliner Chasidim is indeed to say "tal" with a patach, as you would have expected.

But the reason to differentiate between "geshem" and "tul" is that "tul" goes with the previous phrase and ends it, because "tul" is involved in the mechanism of techiyas hameisim (cf. Isaiah 26:19), whereas "geshem" is at the beginning of a list of other gevuros of Hashem.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

In Mishnaic Hebrew, segolates completely lack a pausal form. Their vowels remain the same regardless of their position in a sentence. When the phrase משיב הרוח ומוריד הגשם was first instituted, the final word was pronounced הַגֶּשֶׁם, without a Kamatz.

There’s a wider debate regarding whether blessings and parts of the liturgy that were authored using Mishnaic Hebrew, should be pronounced as if they were written using Biblical Hebrew. That debate is the same reason that, in the blessing over wine, most Ashkenazim say הַגָּפֶן with a Kamatz, while Sephardim pronounce it with two Segols.

The reason most Ashkenazim pronounce הגשׁם with a Kamatz, is because it probably does come at the end of a sentence; thus, if it were Biblical Hebrew, we would all pronounce it with a Kamatz. However, as mentioned, the word’s position didn’t matter in Mishnaic Hebrew.

This debate does not apply to the word הַטָּל. In the summer months, the entire phrase of משיב הרוח is replaced by מוריד הטל. If the word “הגשׁם” is at the end of a sentence, so is הטל. A stressed Patach vowel, unlike segolates, does have a pausal form in Mishnaic Hebrew, in which the Patach lengthened to a Kamatz.

Thus, according to the majority opinion that this phrase occurs at the end of a sentence, the word הטל would have a Kamatz. According to the minority opinion that it instead begins the next sentence, it would have a Patach.

title: Does one need to repeat Birchas Hamazon if he forgot Ya’aleh Veyavo after washing again for the Afikoman?
content:
# Does one need to repeat Birchas Hamazon if he forgot Ya’aleh Veyavo after washing again for the Afikoman? ## Frage

If one forgot to eat the Afikoman, and he remembered after he bentched, so he washed again and ate the Afikoman, and then bentched again, and he forgot Ya’aleh Veyavo in the second bentching, must he repeat Birchas Hamazon?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

M”B 188:26

מפני שאינו חייב וכו' - דדוקא בשבת וביו"ט שמחויב לאכול דוקא פת וא"כ חיוב ברהמ"ז קבוע הוא בימים האלה לכן תקינו רבנן לעיכובא ג"כ להזכיר שם מעין המאורע וכמו בתפלה … וכתב המ"א דה"ה ביו"ט יותר מסעודה אחת ביום וסעודה אחת בלילה שמחויב לאכול אם אכל ושכח להזכיר מעין המאורע בבהמ"ז אינו צריך לחזור כמו בר"ח אם לא כשלא אכל הסעודה בלילה שמחויב לאכול ביום שתים כדלקמן בסימן תקצ"ט דאז אפילו בסעודה שניה חוזר [פמ"ג]

One who forgot Yaaleh V’yavo must repeat Birkas Hamazon only after a seudah in which he was obligated to eat bread. In this case, although one who forgot Afikoman must wash again, the obligation is not certain, as per Shulchan Aruch O”C 477:2:

אם שכח ולא אכל אפיקומן ולא נזכר… עד אחר שבירך בורא פרי הגפן לא יאכל האפיקומן ויסמוך על מצה שאכל בתוך הסעוד' שכולן שמורות הן משעת לישה. אבל במקום שנהגו לעשו' שימור למצת מצוה משע' קצירה אפילו לא זכר עד אחר ההלל יטול ידיו ויברך המוציא ויאכל האפיקומן:

If one already made a brachah on the wine before remembering the Afikoman, one need not wash again and instead relies on the Matzah he already ate.

Clearly, the obligation to re-wash is a safek, in which case we do not repeat Birkas Hamazon. (Since the biblical obligation of Birkas Hamazon was already fulfilled. However, in general if one is unsure whether he said Yaaleh V’yavo it is not considered a safek, as it is assumed that he did not.)

The question would, however, remain in the latter case of the S”A quoted, which rules that one has until now only eaten Matzah that is shemurah mishaas ketzirah must wash again.

Here, one is certainly obligated to eat bread. The question, then, would be: is this special status given to any seudah one is personally obligated to eat, or is it limited to the amount of seudos the day requires one to eat?

[The M”B quoted above seems to suggest the latter understanding (“…since the chiyuv of Birkas Hamazon is fixed in these days…”), while the Magen Avraham he quotes points to a more individual chiyuv. See Shaarei Teshuvah 291:1 and the Machzik Brachah that he references, who opines that a seudah must be both required and usual in order to warrant re-bentching.]

title: Evening Too is a Time to Perform Mitzvot; How, Without Tzizit, do we Effectively Remember/Trigger Their Performance?
content:
# Evening Too is a Time to Perform Mitzvot; How, Without Tzizit, do we Effectively Remember/Trigger Their Performance? ## Frage

Premise #1: Mitzvot are performed by day and night. This idea really needs no proof, but I cite a Kesef Mishna (Laws of Shema 1:2) nonetheless: "לפי שמעשה המצות שנזכר בוהיה אם שמוע נוהג בין ביום בין בלילה" - "the performance of Mitzvot that is mentioned in the second paragraph of Shema occurs by day and night..."

Premise #2: Tzizit's purpose is to remind us to perform the mitzvot; the Tzizit-reminder only occurs by day. The same Kesef Mishna: וזכירת המצות שעל ידי ציצית שנזכר בויאמר אינו נוהג אלא ביום" - the Mitzvot reminder via Tzizit that is mentioned in the third paragraph of Shema only operates during the day"

Premise #3: the reason that the reminder mechanism of Tzizit can only be utilized by day is because one can only see Tzizit via daylight (and not in the dark). Duh!

Premise #4: ONLY the seeing of Tzizit (wearing a rubber band on your wrist or uttering verses of the Torah or utilizing sticky notes are NOT fully effective Mitzvot reminders) triggers an effective Mitzvot-reminder that, in turn, leads to the performance of Mitzvot: (Menachot 43b and Lechem Mishna cited below).

ותניא אידך וראיתם אותו וזכרתם ועשיתם ראיה מביאה לידי זכירה זכירה מביאה לידי עשיה And it is taught in another baraita: The verse states: “That you may look upon IT and remember all the commandments of the Lord and do them.” This teaches that looking at the ritual fringes leads to remembering the mitzvot, and remembering them leads to doing them.

The Lechem Mishna sums up this Premise #4 well: כיון שאין הזכירה באה אלא ע״י ציצית כמש״ה וראיתם אותו וזכרתם “Since the remembering ONLY comes via tzizit as it states ‘you shall see them and remember …’”

Question - evening too is a time to perform Mitzvot; how, without Tzizit, do we remember and thus trigger an evening performance? Put it another way - why did God create a daytime-only reminder for Mitzvot that occur day and night?

A possible answer - a dose of a daytime, visual Tzizit Mitzvot-reminder is sufficient to last through the evening too. Thoughts?

Unfortunately, several of the comments below fail to account for the Gemarra and Lechem Mishna cited here which support Premise #4 - Lechem Mishna (Gimmel):

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Since you're asking for thoughts and not sources:

During the day you can see your Tzizit, but you also see everything else, hence you are constantly being distracted. Tzizit are there to help you refocus.

During the night you cannot see anything, and thus can concentrate on the task at hand. No need for Tzizit to refocus. Keeping in mind that when you can't see anything, you can't do much; you either sleep or use candlelight for specific tasks.

A final thought: Chazal teach us (Eruvin 65a) that the night was created for learning Torah, and while learning there is no need for constant reminders to do Mitzvot.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

One can use the same idea as expressed in Gemara Menachos 43b in a slightly different context.

The Sages taught in a baraita: The Jewish people are beloved, as the Holy One, Blessed be He, surrounded them with mitzvot: They have tefilin on their heads, and tefilin on their arms, and tzitzis on their garments, and a mezuza for their doorways. Concerning them David said: “Seven times a day I praise You, because of Your righteous ordinances” (Psalms 119:164). This alludes to the two tefilin, the four tzitziot, and the mezuza, which total seven.

And when David entered the bathhouse and saw himself standing naked, he said: Woe to me that that I stand naked without any mitzva. But once he remembered the mitzva of circumcision that was in his flesh his mind was put at ease, as he realized he was still accompanied by this mitzva. After he left the bathhouse, he recited a song about the mitzva of circumcision, as it is stated in the verse: “For the leader, on the Sheminith: A Psalm of David” (Psalms 12:1). This is interpreted as a psalm about circumcision, which was given to be performed on the eighth [bashemini] day of the baby’s life.

The point here that we actually have 8 markers to remind us about all the mitzvos. Tefilin and mezuzah contain parshios, such as 2 paragraphs of Shema', that have requirement of performance of mitzvos by day and by night just like the tzitzis by day. We still have mezuzos on doorposts of our houses at night. Also bris-millah is a reminder by virtue of gematria ברי"ת = 612, i.e. it is itself a mitzvah and reminds us about other 612.

title: Is Maimonides' view of free will normative?
content:
# Is Maimonides' view of free will normative? ## Frage

Maimonides discusses free will in his Eight Chapters:

"if we should say that God had destined that this sum should pass into the hands of the one and out of the possession of the other, God would be preordaining an act of iniquity" (8:6)

"In making this assertion that obedience or disobedience to the Law of God does not depend upon the power or will of God, but solely upon that of man himself, the sages followed the dictum of Jeremiah, who said, "Out of the mouth of God there cometh neither the bad nor the good". By the words "the bad" he meant vice, and by "the good", virtue; and, accordingly, he maintains that God does not preordain that any man should be vicious or virtuous" (8:7).

"It now remains for us to explain another phase of this problem, which arises from the fact that there are several Scriptural passages in which some think they find proof that God preordains and forces man to disobedience" (8:11).

I don't see how this is possible. God cannot create creatures that He can't control. I understand that a lot of people don't want to say that God willed the world in its current state, but that's His prerogative. I don't think I am misinterpreting him because I don't see why else he would feel the need to provide convoluted explanations of God hardening Pharaoh's heart and other passages. So is this the normative view in Judaism or is Maimonides just wrong here?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to the Rambam (More Nevuchim 3:17, fifth view), the view that humans have free will is undisputed in Judaism:

וזאת פינה לא נשמע כלל באומתנו ובאנשי תורתנו חולק עליה

This can be confirmed, for instance, by the agreement of diverse commentators on Avot 3:15.

The Rambam himself acknowledges that this is a very difficult concept to grasp, but nevertheless maintains that it's demonstrably true (Teshuva 5:5). The Raavad, despite criticizing his presentation of the question and (partial) answer, still agrees on the issue of free will.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

An important point to note about Pharaoh and others whom God is said to have hardened their heart - leading to their destruction: none of the sins they committed that merited their destruction were caused by God. It doesn’t say God hardened Pharaoh’s heart that he might kill the sons of Israel, for instance.

title: Does God cause people to sin?
content:
# Does God cause people to sin? ## Frage

Is the following statement within the pale of orthodox Judaism?: "As the First Cause God wills everything that happens in the universe and thus predestines all humans to their degree of righteousness or wickedness."

Edit: I am just asking about God's role. Whether or not this is compatible with free will is a different question. This is also not the question about foreknowledge because a prophet could know what someone will do in the future as well, so the real issue is not knowing the future but being the First Cause.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

There is a general working answer that is "followed" by "many" today, to whatever end one can be said to "follow" a hashkafa, and I don't have estimates on numbers and percentages, but I do know that many in the Chareidi world, including Chabad, consider this the Jewish take on this question. This is the crux of the Tanya, for example, and the schools of thought that stem from the Zohar, and beyond.

The way it works is, every person is given a specific mission in life, and one major component of that mission, for most people, is one's work with one's own yeitzer hara. There are 2 things you need to know about this:

  1. Each has their own unique yeitzer hara
  2. There are 2 categories (broken in to further sub-categories, up to 5 depending on how you count) for achievement in this arena

Regarding 1, a person's unique yeitzer hara corresponds to a specific, unique set of illicit behaviours, and the reason a person is tempted by those behaviours, is because it gives them pleasure. Their job is to avoid performing those activities, and tame the passion for them.

Regarding 2, some achievements can be total, permanent victories, and some are lifetime's work:

  • Regarding the lifetime's work category, there are some who are all-but-destined to succumb and perform the illicit activities, and their job is to never give up, and work hard to still try to tame their yeitzer hara, by doing teshuva and doing their best to limit the activity, and even conquer it one day. The conquest, however, will be a ceasefire, rather than a victory, as they will always be tempted. The other group in this category never sin, but are also, always tempted.
  • Regarding the total victory category, some are able to actually tame their passions for only good. Some of us can do this on an individual level, for specific temptations, and very few people achieve the ability to do it for all their temptations, with Hashem's help.

This brings us to the last 2 cases. Someone born a Tzaddik, and someone born a total Rasha. Some people are indeed born without any temptation, and some are born destined to be wicked tyrants, like Hitler, y'sh. This is ok, because exceptions to rules is an acceptable Torah principle, and if one delves into the reasons offered by the commentaries for both of these categories, one will nonetheless encounter some resolutions like:

  • A Tzaddik does have free will still, and free will takes on a different form without a yeitzer hara (we will have free will in the days of Moshiach). This might also be true of certain Rashaim, like Haman.
  • There is a principle that Hashem takes away free will from leaders, in order to be the Master of History.
  • It's not always a total statement. Most of us are in a state of victory on some behaviours, ceasefire on others, and still struggling to stop doing yet others.

It turns out that the question of free will leads to a very rich tapestry of a picture, which is a global human mission that Hashem has tasked us, which has a zoomed in version of our own life story and free will, and relationship with Hashem, as well as the macroscopic picture of the entire Human Spirit - each of us with our little corner of the "human life force" that we are all individually working on, battling our yeitzer hara, for the benefit of all of humanity. The rewards of this will be revealed at a later time, when we are able to see what we achieved, and note that the Jewish people have been given the Torah, which means we have taken on full responsibility for this task, and will guarantee it is fully achieved, with Hashem's help, in time for Moshiach.

tl;dr: Most people have definitely got free will, but one does have to understand that Hashem tests man, and this leads to interesting things like "destined/very very likely to sin" etc. Some people seem like either exceptions, or special edges cases. It's a vast topic, get learning!

title: Calling Up Multiple Hosafot
content:

I have only ever seen one Hosafa made, and it is always called up as יעמוד פלוני בן פלוני אחרון.

How would this work if there were multiple Hosafot? I would assume that the last Hosafa would still be called up as אחרון, but how would the other Hosafot be called up? Would it be הוספה ראשונה, הוספה שניה etc.? Perhaps it would be called שמיני, תשיעי? Would you just call up the Olim by name without specifying a name for the Aliyah?

In my shul on such occasions the gabbai calls

יעמוד פלוני בן פלוני הוספה א

title: Does the Tanakh ever say that the covenant of Moses is eternal or everlasting?
content:
# Does the Tanakh ever say that the covenant of Moses is eternal or everlasting? ## Frage

Forgive me for my ignorance, I am a fairly new convert to the Jewish faith and I have only recently started investigating the Jewish faith, Jews obviously believe that the covenant of Moses is eternal and never ends, but does the Tanakh ever explicitly say that the covenant of Moses is eternal?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

It is the plain meaning of many verses in the Bible, which speak of commandments to teach our children and our children's children, and that many commandments apply "for your generations". By a quick search on Sefaria I found 27.

It is specifically laid out by Moses in Deuteronomy Ch. 4:

Now therefore hearken, O Yisra᾽el, to the statutes and to the judgments, which I teach you, to do them, that you may live, and go in and possess the land which the Lord God of your fathers gives you. You shall not add to the word which I command you, neither shall you diminish from it, that you may keep the commandments of the Lord your God which I command you... Behold, I have taught you statutes and judgments, even as the Lord my God commanded me, that you should act accordingly in the land whither you go to possess it. Keep them therefore and do them; for this is your wisdom and your understanding in the sight of the nations, who shall hear all these statutes, and say, Surely this great nation is a wise and understanding people. For what nation is there so great, that has God so near to them, as the Lord our God is in all things that we call upon him for? And what nation is there so great, that has statutes and judgments so righteous as all this Tora, which I set before you this day? Only take heed to thyself, and keep thy soul diligently, lest thou forget the things which thy eyes have seen, and lest they depart from thy heart all the days of thy life: but teach them thy sons, and thy sons’ sons— the day that thou stoodest before the Lord thy God in Ḥorev, when the Lord said to me, Gather me the people together, and I will make them hear my words, that they may learn to fear me all the days that they shall live upon the earth, and that they may teach their children. And you came near and stood under the mountain; and the mountain burned with fire to the heart of heaven, with darkness, clouds, and thick darkness. And the Lord spoke to you out of the midst of the fire: you heard the voice of the words, but saw no form; only a voice. And he declared to you his covenant, which he commanded you to perform...
But the Lord has taken you, and brought you out of the iron furnace, out of Miżrayim, to be to him a people of inheritance, as you are this day. But the Lord was angry with me for your sakes, and swore that I should not go over the Yarden, and that I should not go in to that good land, which the Lord thy God gives thee for an inheritance: but I must die in this land, I must not go over the Yarden: but you shall go over, and possess that good land. **Take heed to yourselves, lest you forget the covenant of the Lord your God, which he made with you, and make you a carved idol, or the likeness of anything, which the Lord thy God has forbidden thee. For the Lord thy God is a consuming fire, a jealous God. When thou shalt beget children, and children’s children, and you shall have remained long in the land, and shall deal corruptly, and make a carved idol, the likeness of anything, and shall do evil in the sight of the Lord thy God, to provoke him to anger:
I call heaven and earth to witness against you this day, that you shall soon utterly perish from off the land into which you go over the Yarden to possess it; you shall not prolong your days upon it, but shall utterly be destroyed. And the Lord shall scatter you among the nations, and you shall be left few in number among the nations, where the Lord shall lead you. And there you shall serve gods, the work of men’s hands, wood and stone, which neither see, nor hear, nor eat, nor smell. But if from there thou shalt seek the Lord thy God, thou shalt find him, if thou seek him with all thy heart and with all thy soul. When thou art in distress, and all these things are come upon thee, in the latter days, if thou turn to the Lord thy God, and art obedient to his voice; (for the Lord thy God is a merciful God;) he will not forsake thee, nor will he destroy thee, nor forget the covenant of thy fathers which he swore to them. For ask now of the days that are past, which were before thee, since the day that God created man upon the earth, and from the one side of heaven to the other, whether there has been any such thing as this great thing is, or whether aught has been heard like it? Did ever people hear the voice of God speaking out of the midst of the fire, as thou hast heard, and live? Or has God ventured to go and take him a nation from the midst of another nation, by trials, by signs, and by wonders, and by war, and by a mighty hand, and by a stretched out arm, and by great terrors, according to all that the Lord your God did for you in Miżrayim before your eyes? To thee it was shown, that thou mightest know that the Lord he is God; there is none else beside him. Out of heaven he made thee hear his voice, that he might instruct thee: and upon earth he showed thee his great fire; and thou didst hear his words out of the midst of the fire. And because he loved thy fathers, therefore, he chose their seed after them, and brought thee out, he himself being present, with his mighty power out of Miżrayim; to drive out nations from before thee greater and mightier than thou art, to bring thee in, to give thee their land for an inheritance, as it is this day. Know therefore this day, and consider it in thy heart, that the Lord he is God in heaven above, and upon the earth beneath: there is no other. Thou shalt keep therefore his statutes, and his commandments, which I command thee this day, that it may go well with thee, and with thy children after thee, and that thou mayst prolong thy days upon the earth, which the Lord thy God gives thee, for ever.

This is also the closing message of the last of the prophets, Malachi (ch. 3):

Then they who feared the Lord spoke to one another: and the Lord hearkened, and heard it, and a book of remembrance was written before him for those who feared the Lord, and took heed of his name. And they shall be mine, says the Lord of hosts, on that day which I appoint as my particular day; and I will spare them, as a man spares his own son who serves him. Then you shall return, and see the difference between the righteous and the wicked, between him that serves God and him that does not serve him. For, behold, that day is coming; it burns like a furnace; and all the arrogant, and all who do wickedly, shall be stubble: and the day that is coming shall burn them up, says the Lord of hosts, so that it will leave them neither root nor branch. But to you who fear my name the sun of righteousness shall arise with healing in its wings; and you shall go out, and leap like calves from the stall. And you shall tread down the wicked; for they shall be ashes under the soles of your feet on the day that I do this, says the Lord of hosts. Remember the Tora of Moshe my servant, which I commanded him in Ḥorev for all Yisra᾽el, both statutes and judgments. Behold, I will send you Eliyya, the prophet, before the coming of the great and dreadful day of the Lord: and he shall turn the heart of the fathers to the children, and the heart of the children to their fathers, lest I come and smite the land with a curse.

Malachi describes the final day of judgement in history, and says to remember the Torah of Moshe until that day, for those that do will be rewarded, and those that don't will be punished. This means that the Torah is binding until the end of time, with the return of Elijah the prophet. This message is specifically chosen as the end of the words of the prophets. In a way, it is G-d's final direct message to us.

title: Joshua stopping the sun
content:
# Joshua stopping the sun ## Frage

Note: I'm not an expert in science.

I have been wondering for a while what does it mean that Joshua made the Sun stand still? Since the Earth revolves around the Sun, it makes more sense to say that the Earth stood still. How to understand this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

The Tanach always speaks about "science" from our perspective. So do we:

  • The sun rises
  • The moon sets

Similarly, you would have said that the sun stopped setting on that amazing day. You wouldn't say that the earth stopped spinning, since you cannot tell that the earth is spinning around itself and around the sun.

Ever seen a photo of the people watching the earth slipping away into darkness as it rotates away from the sun? Um, yes, sunset.

Chazal call this דיברה תורה כלשון בני אדם - the Torah speaks the way we do. It even has its own Wikipedia entry in Hebrew.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

There is a principle from the Baal Shem Tov that the world is recreated from nothing every instant. The question is, why is this attributed to the Baal Shem Tov? Isn't this based on tefilla, clear chazal and even pesukim? What is the Chiddush of the Baal Shem Tov?

The Chiddush is that each time the world is created, it is created from nothing. Meaning, cause and effect is just an illusion maintained by God, because His Will is the cause of everything. Indeed, this illusion that causes lead to predictable effects is because that's how Hashem basically desires the world to run. Therefore, He personally sees to it that each instant logically follows from the last, at least to the limits of our perceptibility in most scenarios.

The reason I mention this is because when we say "you can't say the sun stopped, because the earth goes round the sun, not the other way around!" we are speaking as though Hashem isn't actually making the earth go round the sun, each instant, purely based on His desire alone, but rather He spun up the earth and threw it into an orbit, letting go of it and letting it continue on its own, and only "stops" it when He desires. This is just patently not true, according to the Baal Shem Tov.

Therefore, who are we to question His statement that the sun stopped? All we have is an illusion with which to challenge it!

title: Order of events in Shacharit vs Maariv: crossing the sea and drowning
content:
# Order of events in Shacharit vs Maariv: crossing the sea and drowning ## Frage

In the morning prayer, in עֶזְרַת אֲבוֹתֵינוּ before the Amida we say:

מִמִּצְרַיִם גְּאַלְתָּנוּ, מִבֵּית עֲבָדִים פְּדִיתָנוּ, כָּל בְּכוֹרֵיהֶם הָרַגְתָּ, וּבְכוֹרְךָ גָּאַלְתָּ, וְיָם סוֹף בָּקַעְתָּ, וְזֵדִים טִבַּעְתָּ, וִידִידִים הֶעֱבַרְתָּ. וַיְכַסּוּ מַיִם צָרֵיהֶם אֶחָד מֵהֶם לֹא נוֹתַר. ‏

(Nussach Sefard is slightly different, but uses the same order)

Roughly translates to:

From Egypt You delivered us, from slavery You freed us, all the firstborns You killed, our firstborns You redeemed, the Yam Suf You split, the wicked ones You drowned, the beloved ones You passed through, their enemies drowned, not one was saved.

The bolded words are seemingly out of order: first we crossed the sea and then the Egyptians drowned.

In Arvit we say it in the correct order:

הַמַּכֶּה בְעֶבְרָתו כָּל בְּכוֹרֵי מִצְרָיִם, וַיּוֹצֵא אֶת עַמּוֹ יִשְׂרָאֵל מִתּוֹכָם לְחֵרוּת עוֹלָם, הַמַּעֲבִיר בָּנָיו בֵּין גִּזְרֵי יַם סוּף, אֶת רוֹדְפֵיהֶם וְאֶת שׂונְאֵיהֶם בִּתְהוֹמוֹת טִבַּע.‏

He smit in His anger the firstborn Egyptians, and delivered His nation Israel from them for everlasting freedom, He led His Sons between the split Yam Suf, their pursuers and enemies were drowned in its depths.

Why are the sequence of events in Shacharis in the wrong order?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

This question was asked by Chasam Sofer on Torah, Seventh Day of Pesach:

זדים טבעת וידידים העברת ויכסו מים צריהם וכו' על זאת שבחו אהובים וכו' וכו' על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו והנה וזדים טבעת ואח"כ יאמר וידידי' העברת ובאמת אחר שהעביר ידידי' אח"כ ויכסו מים צריהם ולא קודם לכן גם לדקדק על זאת שבחו אהובי' וכו' ואח"כ אמר על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו וכו' מאי כולם דקאמר ונ"ל האי זדים לאו אנשים זדים היינו המצריים אלא זדים זדונות כמו מזדים חשוך עבדך ג"כ זדים זדונות עונות של ישראל הטבעת על דרך תשליך במצולות ים כל חטאתם וזה נגד מדה"ד שאמר מה נשתנו אלו מאלו הללו עע"ז והללו עע"ז והקב"ה השליך במצולות ים והטביע כל זדונות בזכות האמונה ואז ידידים העברת ויכסו מים צריהם ואז כשכיסו מים צריהם אז על זאת שבחו האהובי' והידידי' שבישראל ואמרו ההלל כדאי' פע"פ, אך שאר העם לא שבחו כי אמרו כשם שאנו עולים מצד זה כך מצרים עולים מצד אחר והמרו על ים בים סוף (כדאיתא פע"פ שם) עד שרמז הקב"ה ופלטם הים לחוץ כדכתי' וירא ישראל את מצרים מת על שפת הים וזו על שפת הים יחד כולם הודו שירת הים אפי' אותם שאינם אהובי ידידי' אלא כולם אמרו שירה:

As I understand, when comparing against the tefilas ma'ariv, it is important to note that Shacharis is the tefila of complete Geula, whereas Ma'ariv - only geula arichta (as discussed in Gemara Brachos). Therefore, in Ma'ariv we recall events briefly the way they occured, while in Shacharis we recite the full story.

Chasam Sofer states that the words וזדים טבעת - the wicked ones You drowned do not refer to the wicked men of Mitzraim, rather זדונות - wicked acts (willful sins) as it is stated in the passuk Tehilim 19:14

גַּ֤ם מִזֵּדִ֨ים ׀ חֲשֹׂ֬ךְ עַבְדֶּ֗ךָ אַֽל־יִמְשְׁלוּ־בִ֣י אָ֣ז אֵיתָ֑ם וְ֝נִקֵּ֗יתִי מִפֶּ֥שַֽׁע רָֽב׃

and from willful sins keep Your servant; let them not dominate me; then shall I be blameless and clear of grave offense.

Also זדים - sinful acts (עונות) of Bnei Israel from the passuk Micha 7:19

יָשׁ֣וּב יְרַֽחֲמֵ֔נוּ יִכְבֹּ֖שׁ עֲוֺֽנֹתֵ֑ינוּ וְתַשְׁלִ֛יךְ בִּמְצֻל֥וֹת יָ֖ם כָּל־חַטֹּאותָֽם׃

[God] will take us back in love, Quashing our iniquities. You will hurl all our sins Into the depths of the sea.

According to midrash, these acts were performed against Midas haDin which spoke at the Yam Suf: Why are these different from those, these are idol worshipers and those are idol worshippers, and HKBH sent into the depths of the sea all the sinful acts (of Bnei Israel) in the merit of (their) Emunah and then the beloved ones You passed through; their enemies drowned, not one was saved. (There are different versions of the midrash, for example Yalkut Shimoni (Shemos), 234:6, Mekhilta R' Shimon b. Yochai 14:27).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

I saw another answer - from the דעת זקֵנִים - a Sefer ascribed to the Ba'alei Tosafoth.

They reference Rashi in the Shirat Hayam on the verse (Shemot 15:4) that says:

מַרְכְּבֹת פַּרְעֹה וְחֵילוֹ יָרָה בַיָּם וּמִבְחַר שָֽׁלִשָׁיו טֻבְּעוּ בְיַם סֽוּף:‏

Rashi explains טֻבְּעוּ as follows:

טֻבְּעוּ. אֵין טְבִיעָה אֶלָּא בִּמְקוֹם טִיט, כְּמוֹ "טָבַעְתִּי בִּיוֵן מְצוּלָה" (תהילים ס"ט), "וַיִּטְבַּע יִרְמְיָהוּ בַּטִּיט" (ירמיהו ל"ח), מְלַמֵּד, שֶׁנַּעֲשָׂה הַיָּם טִיט, לִגְמֹל לָהֶם כְּמִדָּתָם שֶׁשִׁעְבְּדוּ אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל בְּחֹמֶר וּבִלְבֵנִים (מכילתא): ‏

Basically, טֻבְּעוּ means to get stuck in the mud.

So the passage in question

וְיָם סוֹף בָּקַעְתָּ, וְזֵדִים טִבַּעְתָּ, וִידִידִים הֶעֱבַרְתָּ. וַיְכַסּוּ מַיִם צָרֵיהֶם אֶחָד מֵהֶם לֹא נוֹתַר. ‏

translates to:

And You split the Yam Suf, and the wicked got stuck in the mud (chasing behind you), and the beloved ones You crossed over, and the waters covered their foes, not one survived.

title: Is there a conflict with Isaiah if the correct meaning / translation of 'alam' (ōlām) עוֹלָֽם׃ is forever/everlasting?
content:
# Is there a conflict with Isaiah if the correct meaning / translation of 'alam' (ōlām) עוֹלָֽם׃ is forever/everlasting? ## Frage

Is forever / everlasting until the end or for a period or different depending on the context, for example when talking about God? I’m trying to work out if the English translation is correct or misleading.

If it does mean forever or everlasting would there not be a conflcit with Isaiah 32:14 & 15?

Isaiah 32 (would forever cause a conflict in this passage) 14 For the palace will be forsaken, the busy city abandoned. The hill and the watchtower will become caves forever (‘aḏ ‘ō-lām) -the delight of wild donkeys and a pasture for flocks—

15 until the Spirit is poured out upon us from on high. Then the desert will be an orchard, and the orchard will seem like a forest.

Genesis 17:13 Whether they are born in your household or purchased, they must be circumcised. My covenant in your flesh will be an everlasting covenant (‘ō-lām).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The root עלם means to hide, conceal as discussed here. Strictly speaking, עוֹלַם means hidden uknown time of existence, which got revealed due to some bad or good actions. For example, Pinchas received בְּרִ֖ית כְּהֻנַּ֣ת עוֹלָ֑ם (Bamidbar 25:13). I.e. because of his good act he created an existence in time of kehuna for himself and his offspring. In the passuk Isaiah 32:14 the words עַד־עוֹלָ֔ם mean that due to bad acts of women, the populated areas would be abandoned, i.e. that abandonment would be created in time for that part of the world. No time in the Torah is "forever", since we can say only about G-d היה, and הוה and יהיה. Translations of the word עוֹלָ֔ם as "world", "forever" certainly diminish the full Hebrew meaning.

title: What do Jews call the deuterocannonical books?
content:
# What do Jews call the deuterocannonical books? ## Frage

In theory, the Christian “Old Testament” is the same as the Jewish Bible, or at least the same texts in a different order, but in fact there are a few different versions of the Old Testament. The Catholic and Orthodox churches both accept some books which Jews (and also Protestants) don’t.

The branches of Christianity which accept those books call them “deuterocanonical” (second canon). The branches which don’t call them “apocrypha” (hidden things, I think). Does the Jewish tradition have any word for them at all, or does it simply ignore them?

title: Birkat haGomel: 'tov' vs. 'tuv'
content:
# Birkat haGomel: 'tov' vs. 'tuv' ## Frage

I have always wondered why birkat hagomel and the traditional response use the word ‘tov’ three times when the word ‘tuv’ seems more correct/appropriate. Occasionally (quite rarely), I hear people recite it with ‘tuv.’ While I am aware of the Talmudic origin of this blessing (Berakhot 54b), I am not aware of the origin of the specific language. What is the origin of the language 'tov?'

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

There is a debate both here and regarding the Grace After Meals, whether the word טוֹב itself is both a noun and an adjective or only an adjective. Seligman Baer comments on the matter in his siddur Avodat Yisrael (p. 559):

ויש לדעת, כי נקוד התבה בשורק בסדורי הספרדים, וכן נקד גם אבודרהם ובעל אור חדש דף ל"ג וכן בסדור ר"ע. אבל בעל ש"ת נקד וכל טוב ומכל טוב שניהם בחולם, וכן גם רוו"ה בסדורו, והוא הנכון, כי הלשון הוא יגמלנו לעד חן וחסד וכו', וכל טוב הוא כלשון גמלתהו טוב (משלי ל"א, י"ב), והלשון ומכל טוב אל יחסרנו הוא כלשון לא יחסרו כל טוב (תהלים ל"ד, י"א), ובשניהם טוב בחולם.‏

It should be known that the vocalisation of the syllable is shuruq in the prayer books of the Sephardi Jews, and so vocalised it Abudarham and the author of Or Chadash p. 33, and it is so in the prayer book of R' Emden. But the author of Shaarei Tefillah vocalised both וכל טוב and מכל טוב with cholam, and so did R' Heidenheim in his prayer book, and that is the correct, because the wording is יגמלנו לעד חן וחסד etc., and all טוב is like the phrase גְּמָלַתְהוּ טוֹב (Proverbs 31:12), and the wording ומכל טוב אל יחסרנו is like the phrase לֹא יַחְסְרוּ כָל טוֹב (Psalms 34:11), and in both of them טוב is with cholam.

So in short, his reasoning is that due to similar verses in Scripture it should be rather with cholam [o] instead of shuruq [u], but most contemporary editions avoid such alterations to bring the orthography of Mishnaic Hebrew closer to Biblical Hebrew.

title: For whom was the Tower of Babel built?
content:
# For whom was the Tower of Babel built? ## Frage

The descendants of Noah, who are the only survivors of the Flood, said:

Come, let us build ourselves a city, and a tower with its top in the sky. [Gen. 11:4]

Or HaChaim [on Gen. 11:1], from 18th-century Morocco, comments:

Why did they say "We will build a city for ourselves"? Who else was there to build a city for?

A very pertinent question. He does not answer it. Nothing in the Torah is superfluous. So what is the answer?

(God told Abram "Lech lecha -- Go for yourself", which the Sages interpreted as "Go for your own benefit". But there the benefit to Abram was not at all obvious to him, so 'lecha' needed to be said. But here?)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

What a great question/insight you have noticed. Yes, it does seem superfluous/unnecessary for the humans to say they will build a city for themselves, because afterall, who else would they build it for?

For me that statement is rather a reflection that mankind is no longer interested in following God's orders. God created the earth, all the plants and animals, created a beautiful garden, created humans and asked humans to protect the gardens and to be a ruler/caretaker of all the animals.

We blow it in the garden. We are no longer obligated to guard the garden. Now we will be farmers, but we are still obligated to be fruitful and multiply, to bring positive human dominion over the whole Earth like God commanded. We were not bringing this positive human dominion over the Earth, so God flooded the Earth and restored Noah to being a ruler over animals, saving most of the animals, and allowing noah and his descendants to eat animals in ritually acceptable way after the flood. If Noah's descendants had continued to be farmers (grapes/wine anyone?) and leaders of the animals then all would have been good.

Instead, the tower of Babel is humanity deciding not to expand and rule over the whole Earth like God asked. Rather, they asked themselves what they wanted, and the answer was a city with a tower that reached toward heaven. Humanity had chosen to replace God's desires, with humans desires, which was always the risk of the tree of knowledge of good and evil. They wanted safety and security, they wanted houses, and a tower that might reach toward God. And so their statement of let us build a city for ourselves, reads to me as "let us not fill the earth and subdue it [like God commanded], let us not rule over the animals [in the wild as God commanded]. Rather, let us build a [safe] city, not for God, but for ourselves, and build a tower that reaches to the heavens."

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Midrash makes Nimrod the king who built the tower. He made the people believe that he was merely the "first citizen" or the like and that after the people built the tower and killed God, the people, free of His tyrany, could live in a egalitarian society. The slogan was "for ourselves" to distract from Nimrod's probably planning on taking power himself.

title: Was idolatry the sin of the builders of the Tower of Babel?
content:
# Was idolatry the sin of the builders of the Tower of Babel? ## Frage

Many commentators bemoan the fact that the sin of the builders of the Tower of Babel is not mentioned explicitly in the Torah. A plurality (but by no means all) seems to believe they engaged in idolatry. For example, the Talmud says:

Rabbi Natan says: All of them intended to build the tower for the sake of idol worship. They said: “And let us make a name for ourselves”, and God said [in Exodus 23:13]: “And make no mention of the name of other gods”. In both cases, the word “name” is used to talk about idol worship. [Sanhedrin 109a]

The Midrash says:

They said: “How arrogant of [God] to select the upper reaches for Himself and to give us the lower reaches. Instead, let us come and make a tower and craft an idol at its top, place a sword in its hand, and it will appear as though it is waging war against Him.” [Genesis Rabbah 38:6-9]

My question is this. Idolatry is the big bugaboo in Tanakh and Talmud, and it is mentioned by name in spades when it occurs. Why wouldn't it be mentioned by name here?

title: Din versus Mitzvah
content:
# Din versus Mitzvah ## Frage

How would you describe the difference between mitzvos and dinim?

How would you describe the difference between halachah and dinim?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

A mitzvah is a raw commandment or rabbinic enactment.

Din is a halachic category that something or someone falls in, such as "a Samaritan woman has the din of a Niddah". Or "Shlomo has the din of a mazik and has to pay damages."

Halacha is the accepted way of doing things. It is based on Mitzvah, oral law/interpretations, and customs. It's the polished mitzvah and can differ vastly from the raw mitzvah. For example, we have a mitzvah to cut off the hand of a woman who grabs a ballsack of two men who are fighting. The halacha is that she only pays a monetary fine.

Sometimes halacha refers to a detail of another halacha.

title: Finishing a Berachah when in doubt
content:
# Finishing a Berachah when in doubt ## Frage

If one said “Baruch Atah Ado-nai Elo-heinu Melech Ha’olam”, and then he realized that he shouldn’t have, because of a doubt as to whether he needed to make a Berachah, should he finish the Berachah, or is it better that he should not say a full Berachah possibly in vain?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I'm not a posek, ask your LOR.

I think that since the person got up to the words מלך העולם he should not continue the bracha he was going to make for the following reason:

The Rishonim and Achronim only discuss cases in which if you mess up that you can finish the bracha you were going to make with pesukim from Tanach, but they did not discuss a case in which one reached the words מלך העולם since there is no pasuk that has the continuation of the words מלך העולם that one can use to fix before making a bracha levatala.

Three examples given of points where if one accidently made a bracha levatala he can still fix them:

  1. Shulchan Aruch Orach Chaim Siman 206:6 says that after one says ברוך אתה ה one should then say למדני חקיך since it comes from the pasuk in Tehillim 119:12 "בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה ה' לַמְּדֵנִי חֻקֶּיךָ."
  2. If one says ברוך אתה ה אלהי he can finish off with ישראל אבינו מעולם ועד עולם which is part of the pasuk in Divrei Hayamim 1:29:10, בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְהֹוָה אֱלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אָבִינוּ מֵעוֹלָם וְעַד־עוֹלָם. (however even with this one needs to still say ברוך שם כבוד מלכותו לעולם ועד- see the Tzlach Brachot 39a, Kitzur Shulchan Aruch 6:4, Kaf Hachaim Siman 206:44).
  3. If one says ברוך אתה ה אלהינו, one can finish off with ה' אֱלֹהֵינוּ כָּרַת עִמָּנוּ בְּרִית בְּחֹרֵב as its a pasuk in Devarim 5:2.

However after the word אלהינו there is no other pasuk in Tanach that continues with מלך העולם (according to my Tanach search), therefore the best thing to do is say בָּרוּךְ שֵׁם כְּבוֹד מַלְכוּתוֹ לְעוֹלָם וָעֶד as Shulchan Aruch Siman 206:6 says to mention, and it fixes the bracha levatala completely. See the Mabit in Kiryat Sefer Hilchot Shevuot 12:11, Panim Meirot 3:9 Chazon Ish Orach Chaim Siman 137:6, Chidah in Nachal Kedumim Parashat Kedoshim, Imrei Emet Parashat Vaeira, and others who also explain that ברוך שם fixes and why it works, therefore there is nothing to worry about if someone accidently got to the words מלך העולם in a bracha.

title: Akhenaten, Monotheism, King Paro, and Midrashim
content:
# Akhenaten, Monotheism, King Paro, and Midrashim ## Frage

Background and Reason I am Asking

I would like to know if there is any reason to believe, or disbelieve, that Akhenaten might have been the Pharaoh that faced the plagues. According to the Midrash, he did teshuva, and began trying to spread monotheism.

According to historians, Akhenaten also was the first Pharaoh that started spreading (at least a form of) monotheism, and many of the descriptions of the deity he insisted Egypt worship sound eerily similar to many of the Torah's descriptions of Hashem (see Great Hymn to the Aten vs Psalm 104). It's also crazy that someone was able to pull off such a massive and fast change in the religion of the great and very ancient empire of Egypt, for the first time in thousands of years, so fast and so successfully!

There's also the interesting matter that his reign is very coincident with the Exodus, approx 3350 years ago!

[I understand that the academic, cynic's and atheist's reflex would be (and has been ad nauseum) to reverse things, and say Judaism evolved/absorbed material from Akhenaten's religion in some way, but of course that is not what Traditional Judaism holds.]

Question:

Within the rubrick of traditional Judaism, is there any reason to believe that Akhenaten was [or was directly connected to] the King Pharaoh of the Exodus, and that his move to create this new, monotheistic-ish religion was because of what our sages said - he did teshuva after the plagues?

I don't trust myself to research this, I would much rather hear from an orthodox scholar who has already researched it, or knows how to research it properly. It would also be interesting and relevant to look into discussions on whether worshiping Aten has been analyzed as counting as Avoda Zara/Shittuf etc. or not, perhaps?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Summary:

  • Akhenaten knew Psalm 104 and was a contemporary of Yehoshua's conquest
  • The Exodus occured in the 7th year of Thutmose III of the 18th dynasty, which ruled over the Middle Kingdom.
  • The Exodus events took place in the Nile Delta, ruled by dynasties 4-6.

According to the book "Pharaoh" by R. Alexander Hool, p. 59-60, the Hymn of the Sun-Disc carved into the neckropolis of Akhenaten bears a striking resemblance to the Psalm 104 written by king David, who lived many years after Exodus. Based on Bava Basra 14b, we have to conclude that Psalm 104 was written by Moshe and modified to its final version later by king David.

The synchronization of the Egyptian history proposed by R. Hool places Exodus in the 7th year of Thutmose III of the 18th dynasty. Officially, Thutmose III ruled for 54 years, afterwards there was Amenhotep II (25 years), Thutmose IV (8 years), Amenhotep III (38 years), followed by Amenhotep IV Akhenaten who ruled for 17 years. Official dating of 18th dynasty would place Exodus 119 years prior to Akhenaten. However, in the Amarna letters there is a request from Abdu-Heba king of Jerusalem that pharaoh Akhenaten IV help against invading Hapiru/Apiru. If this is a reference to invading army of Yehoshua, we must conclude that Amenhotep IV Akhenaten was a contemporary to the later years of Moshe when his version of Psalm 104 was available, so that Akhenaten could know it. This synchronization allows resolving many historical enigmas well-known in the academic world.

Why Thutmose III was contemporary of Exodus? According to historian Manetho, Exodus occured under pharaoh Tutimaos. First 6 years of his reign Thutmose III co-reigned with his stepmother Queen Hatshepsut, who in an inscription speaks of "wandering people" that caused ruination of Egypt and left Egypt in her time. The mummy of Thutmose II showed that he died suddenly in his 30s evidently from a plaque of boils engulfed on his entire body. The mummy of Thutmose III also bears the same scars, and so does Queen Hatshepsut's and another contemporary.

The problem is that 18th dynasty in the 7th year of Thutmose III only ruled over the Middle Egypt, but events of the Exodus occured in the Nile Delta. It took Thutmose III several years to conquer all of Egypt and then expand his war campaign into Canaan. The 15th dynasty of Hyksos (likely the Amalekites) ruled the Delta for some time after Exodus.

It turns out that in the southwest corner of the festive hall of Thutmose III there is a well known Karnak King list which is at variance with the conventional as it mentions kings Teti, Pepi I, and Merenre from the 6th dynasty among those of 11th and 12th dynasty kings. Based on considerations given in the book, it turns out that indeed the Nile Delta was ruled by the 6th dynasty, and the Pharaoh of Exodus was the last king Neferkare the Younger (ruled 1 year), when the dynasty was suddenly interrupted. R. Hool believes that kings of 4-6th dynasties were rulling in the Delta for the duration of the Egyptian Exile of the Jewish people and he explains that they were Edomite kings, i.e. related to the rulers of Edom, which also fits well with the assumption of that they were Hyksos. It may also shed light on why both Edomite and Egyptian converts needed 4 generations to marry into Israel.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Ramses I ruled after Akhenaten. One of the towns the Jews built was called Ramses so it is unlikely that Akhenaten was the Pharaoh of the Exodus.

Further, Akhenaten was deliberately obscured and only rediscovered in the 19th century. He is unlikely to feature in any classical Rabbinic literature.

title: Why was Adam considered unique as a talking creature when the snake could speak as well?
content:
# Why was Adam considered unique as a talking creature when the snake could speak as well? ## Frage

Onkelos renders Bereishis 2:7

וַיִּ֩יצֶר֩ י״י֨ אֱלֹהִ֜ים אֶת⁠־הָֽאָדָ֗ם עָפָר֙ מִן⁠־הָ֣אֲדָמָ֔ה וַיִּפַּ֥ח בְּאַפָּ֖יו נִשְׁמַ֣ת חַיִּ֑ים וַֽיְהִ֥י הָֽאָדָ֖ם לְנֶ֥פֶשׁ חַיָּֽה

Hashem, God, formed the man from the dust of the ground and blew in his nostrils a breath of life and the man became a living being.

as

וּבְרָא יְיָ אֱלֹהִים יָת אָדָם עַפְרָא מִן אַרְעָא וּנְפַח בְּאַפּוֹהִי נִשְׁמְתָא דְּחַיֵי וַהֲוָת בְּאָדָם לְרוּחַ מְמַלְּלָא.

Hashem Elohim then formed Adam, dust from the ground, and He blew into his nostrils the breath of life. And so Adam became a speaking spirit.

In light of the snake speaking as well (if understood literally*) what was unique about man that only he was classed as a 'speaking spirit'?

*Some commentators understand it literally (e.g., R. Avraham ibn Ezra).

Onkelos translates Bereishis 3:1 as

וְחִוְיָא הֲוָה חֲכִים מִכֹּל חַיַּת בָּרָא דַּעֲבַד יְיָ אֱלֹהִים וַאֲמַר לְאִתְּתָא בְּקוּשְׁטָא אֲמַר יְיָ לָא תֵּיכְלוּן מִכֹּל אִילָן גִּנְּתָא.

The serpent was more cunning than any beast of the field which Hashem Elohim made; it said to the woman, “Did Hashem truly say that you should not eat from all the trees of the Garden?”

which would seem to indicate that he agrees with that reading

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

The Ohr Chaim here says that it wasn't speech such as we have it, but rather a standard hiss of a snake that Chava could understand.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 5)

Perhaps you can answer according to the chizkuni that says the snake got wisdom because it ate from the aitz hadaas (since wasn't commanded in not eating from it). So naturally it didn't have the ability to speak like man did.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 3)

Based on Chesed LeAvraham 4:5, and my general understanding:

There are two levels to intellect - the first is Chochma, and the second is Binah. Chochma is much higher, and more subtle, than Binah.

The Human being is the only creature that was created from Chochma. Animals were created with Binah.

Understanding the difference between Chochma and Binah should help understand the difference between the speech of humans and the speech of animals.

The problem is, this is quite hard to explain (we are trying to talk about the things that we use to talk, so that's understandable). I will give two different angles and then summarise and hope that it's a good explanation.

I came to answer this question and I didn't know what the answer was. I looked here and there and thought a bit and at some point, I figured out the answer. That happened in a split second - I had the full answer. The only problem is, it's taking me time to type it all out and put it into words, but nonetheless, everything I am writing here was all there in the initial "aha" moment, even if I didn't know exactly what words and explanations I would use to answer the question at that time.

In this example, the "aha" event was a Chochma event. The idea in its pure, "conceptual" form entered my intellect. Then, the idea was passed into my Binah, which took over in putting it into words. In this example, Chochma is almost magical - its the part of our brain whose currency is actual grasping of ideas, and is very lofty. Binah is more like a computer that processes ideas. It's still lofty, but is more akin to something we can mimick with computers, which brings us to the next example:

AI language models spend a lot of time reminding us that no, they are not actually a person, and don't actually know anything and it's all an illusion. They are not speaking to us in the way we speak, with actual awareness of what they are saying as they say it. They don't have ideas, or conceive of concepts. They are just very very good at manipulating letters and words using logical processes and computation, so that we find it useful.

ChatGPT could change its "I am not what you think I am" reminders to be "I don't have any Chochma, it's an illusion. I have something akin to binah, I process data, but I don't know what I am actually doing". The magical ingredient of knowing the meaning of the words and phrases I am using is a Chochma skill, and that's unique to humans. Animals have only a very very small, insignificant degree of Chochma, if at all.

Conclusion: So, to the commentaries that bring the point that the Nachash's speech was fundamentally different to humans, I think the difference lies here. The Nachash was more like an AI LLM in its speech than a human, if not exactly the same. It could express its desire, and even do so in a clever (or crafty) way, but it was still doing so out of instinct, rather than its own essence. Humans, on the other hand, are literally made out of the stuff of true, knowing speech - Chochma.
