title: Is making a deal with Hashem to stop doing an aveira, after a bad dream, an example of a nullifiable neder?
content:
# Is making a deal with Hashem to stop doing an aveira, after a bad dream, an example of a nullifiable neder? ## Frage

If someone experiences a frightening thought or dream and s/he says to oneself and to HaShem that this shouldn’t come to pass and s/he will not do such and such aveira from that moment on to prevent it from happening. There is no one around to hear the saying and it is literally just a statement from the person to HaShem, such as for example, “if You not let this happen, I will not do this from now on” etc? Would such a statement be considered a neder and would it be nullifiable? Would this mean you cannot make a neder to abstain from something that was already assur? Can you make a neder to “do less” of it? Are those binding?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

You ask a few things in your question.

  1. Is a personal kabala between oneself and G-d, verbalised, considered an oath? (Nitpick: the term for a vow to perform or abstain from an action is shevua, not neder)

  2. If yes, is a shevua to perform or abstain from something I am already commanded to do valid?

  3. If yes, what is the effect of this neder?

In order:

  1. Yes. A shevua does not need witnesses to take effect.
  2. The gemara in masechet nedarim 8 states that it is possible to make a shevua to fulfil the commandments in the torah, despite being already obligated. The gemara justifies this "כדי לזרוזי נפשיה" - to motivate oneself. However, there may be a distinction between whether the shevua was to perform an action, or to abstain from an action. see 3.
  3. There is a machloket Rishonim if the shevua has any effect, i.e. to create a prohibition above and beyond the already existing mitzva (which would lead to additional lashes, for example), or if the shevua merely avoids being classified as a shevuat shav (invalid oath).

According to the first opinion, the shevua would only add a prohibition if it was to perform a mitzva, not to abstain from an avera (because of the principle of Ein Issur Chal Al Issur).

One final nugget, the sefer Kehilat ya'akov (harav Kanievsky ZT"L) nedarim 10 writes, tongue-in-cheek, to explain how a shevua to fulfil something you already are obligated to fulfil works. He says that generally, when it comes to sin, people find excuses to justify why their actions are not transgressions - cognitive dissonance. It is in this space, he writes, that the shevua finds a place to take effect - in the mind of the potential sinner.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

According to the Ben Ish Chai, the neder is in force, and would require nullification, if you verbalized it. You can always say “bli neder” and with a sincere intention such a statement is far superior to a neder in most cases.

We should avoid nedarim whenever possible. See here: https://halachipedia.com/index.php?title=Hilchot_Nedarim#Precautions_and_Circumstances_for_Taking_Nedarim

title: Why do some people from Nusach Sefard say Shalom Rav only by Mincha - not by Maariv
content:
# Why do some people from Nusach Sefard say Shalom Rav only by Mincha - not by Maariv ## Frage

Every day, towards the end of שמונה עשרה for שחרית, after ברכת כהנים we say the ברכה of שלום. To be specific, we say שים שלום, regardless of what נוסח you Daven. At מנחה and מעריב - people who Daven נוסח אשכנז say a different version of the ברכה of שלום, שלום רב. Their reasoning is that שים שלום echoes the language of ברכת כהנים and is reserved for תפילות where ברכת כהנים is said (שחרית - מוסף - מנחה לתענית ציבור etc.). Therefore, it would seem inappropriate to recite it at a תפילה where we don't say ברכת כהנים.

Some examples of how שים שלום echoes the language of ברכת כהנים are:

  • "שים שלום" - echoes the words "וישם לך שלום"
  • "באור פניך" - echoes the words "יאר ה' פניו"
  • "ברכנו אבינו" - echoes the words "כה תברכו" and "ואני אברכם"

But, there are some נוסח ספרד קהילות who do say שלום רב at מעריב. So, here's my question: if they say שלום רב at מעריב because we only say שים שלום at תפילות where there is ברכת כהנים - then why do these people say שים שלום at מנחה?!? Do they either have an answer to how מנחה is connected to ברכת כהנים, or a different reason why they say שלום רב at מעריב?

title: Is leaving a fake positive review considered lying?
content:
# Is leaving a fake positive review considered lying? ## Frage

If I leave a positive review on a site for a friend whose company I never actually worked with, but it’s vague enough that’s it’s technically true (such as “this is a great and effective team”), is that lying?

title: Question regarding how the Beis Yosef understands the Rosh with regards to the required size of the Esrog
content:
# Question regarding how the Beis Yosef understands the Rosh with regards to the required size of the Esrog ## Frage

The Beis Yosef on the Tur (Orach Chaim 656) writes that when the Rosh (Bava Kama 1:7) uses the term ״כאגוז״ (the size of a wallnut) when describing the required size of the Esrog, that the Rosh is referring to Rabbi Meir’s opinion, but according to Rabbi Yehuda, the required size is that of an egg, and therefore when the Gemara (Bava Kama 9a) says that a Mitzvah-article should be bigger than the required size if possible, according to Rabbi Yehuda it should be bigger than an egg.

My question is: the Rosh (Sukkah 3:15) seems to accept that the size of an egg is not essentially the required size of the Esrog, and the only reason it needs to be that size is because an Esrog that is less than that size is considered unripe, but essentially the required size is that it should be big enough that it should be noticeable when held in one’s hand.

Based on that, why does the Beis Yosef explain the Rosh, that when the Gemara says that the Mitzvah-article should be bigger than the required size if possible, that according to Rabbi Yehuda it should be bigger than an egg - but doesn’t the Rosh say that the actual required size of the Esrog is as long as it is visible?

title: What is the Jewish perspective of natural sciences?
content:
# What is the Jewish perspective of natural sciences? ## Frage

Throughout the centuries Jews have undoubtedly contributed to natural sciences, but I don't really know what the Jewish perspective on natural sciences is, do Jews believe that G-d works through natural science or do they believe that there is a conflict between the Jewish faith and natural sciences?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

You are asking about Natural Science, and I am presuming you mean the laws of nature (i.e. that which natural science sets out to study). Regarding this, the Jewish perspective is that Hashem runs the world through Hashgacha. This means providence.

Rambam says:

We believe that this Universe remains perpetually with the same properties with which the Creator has endowed it, and that none of these will ever be changed except by way of miracle in some individual instances, although the Creator has the power to change the whole Universe, to annihilate it, or to remove any of its properties.

There are rather subtle differences among our scholars about what miracles are (e.g.), but generally everyone holds that Hashem is the Master of Nature, having created it and given it all of its power and design, according to His Will. Nevertheless, He likes nature (Derashot HaRan 8:63a) and sticks to the rules of it, out of His own desire, and we can effectively count on that, and therefore His involvement with us is, in a sense, "through nature". Therefore to answer your question specifically:

  1. God indeed involves Himself with the laws of nature, and to a large degree works through them, but we must acknowledge that He is their Master, not the other way around.
  2. There is no conflict between Torah and natural science in principle. Sometimes there is in practice, but that's going to have to come down to superficial differences, such as when science gets something wrong, or we misunderstand Torah, not fundamental ones, such as "Torah doesn't believe in gravity, but science does, so they are at odds".
### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Ramban differentiates between the Mosaic miracles—which worked outside of nature (which he terms 'explicit miracles')—vs providential reward & punishment—which operate within the bounds of nature (which he refers to as 'hidden miracles').

See Ramban, e.g., to Bereishis 17:1

The reason for mentioning this Divine Name now is that with it are done the hidden miracles for the righteous, to deliver their soul from death, and to keep them alive in famine,⁠ as well as to redeem them in war from the power of the sword,⁠ just as all the miracles done to Abraham and to the other patriarchs, and as all the blessings and curses mentioned in the Torah in the section Im Bechukothai and in the section Vehaya Ki Thavo.⁠ These blessings and curses are all miracles for it is not in nature that the rains should come in their due season when we worship G-d, nor are the skies to be like iron if we plant our fields in the seventh year, and similarly all promises in the Torah. Rather, they are all miracles by which the disposition of natural law is overpowered, except that no change from the natural order of the world is noticeable, as was the case with the miracles done through Mosheh Rabbeinu with the ten plagues, the dividing of the Sea, the Manna, the well, and their like, for these are miracles which openly changed nature, and they were done with the Tetragrammaton which He told to him. It is for this reason that He now told Abraham our father that He is the Almighty, the Victor Who will prevail over his constellation of birth so that he will have a son, and thus there will be a covenant between Him and his seed forever, meaning that the portion of the Eternal is His people,⁠ and that He will lead them at His own will, as they will not be under the rule of a star or constellation.

(See What does Ramban refer to with the term "hidden miracles"? for more from Ramban in this regard)

title: Why does the 2nd Ata in Ata Gibor have different Emphasis?
content:
# Why does the 2nd Ata in Ata Gibor have different Emphasis? ## Frage

Why does the 2nd "Ata" in Ata Gibor have the emphasis on the first syllable (AH-ta),
unlike the 1st "Ata" which is pronounced as normal (ah-TA)?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

There's an answer to this that can be found in Emes L'Yaakov Al HaTorah, p. מ״ו-מ״ז (h/t to user J. W. Tanner for making we aware of this in the answer to this question.)

It's a matter of the structure of the passuk, and how the words are broken up. He actually says, though this is not a common practice, that when you say Morid HaTal the second "Ata" would be Ah-TAH, on the second half of the word, even though when you say Mashiv HaRuach or nothing at all there (the Ashkenazi minhag in Chutz La'aretz during the summer) it is pronounced AH-tah, as most siddurim indicate.

Here's why, according to him. A good indicator of how exactly to break up the passuk is what the trop is/would be. Though admittedly, I don't know how he knew this (perhaps beyond the scope of the question too) the trop over those words in Shmoneh Esrei without any insertion there would be and with Mashiv HaRuach it would be similar

whereas with Morid HaTal it would be .

According to the Minchas Shai, if the word "ata" is a sof passuk, esnachta, or a zakeif katon (like this one), the emphasis moves from the end of the word to the beginning of the word. Any other note, it remains at the end of the word.

title: Was the world really created by the Hebrew letters?
content:
# Was the world really created by the Hebrew letters? ## Frage

There’s a somewhat-famous Kabbalistic concept, recorded first in the Sefer Yetzirah, that Hashem created the world by using the letters of the Hebrew alphabet.

Assuming Hebrew indeed evolved from an older language, how should this be understood?

Obviously, this is an extremely esoteric idea within Kabbalah, and I’m not asking for a complete explanation. Nevertheless, I hope it’s possible to explain this one facet—namely, what the Hebrew letters have to do with anything—if Hebrew as we know it didn’t evolve until much later (as per the above assumption).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The concept that Hashem used letters to create the world does not originate in kabbalistic works, but it is mentioned in Gemara B'rakhos 55a:

Rav Yehuda said that Rav said: Bezalel knew how to join the letters with which heaven and earth were created. From where do we derive this? It is written here in praise of Bezalel: “And I have filled him with the spirit of God, in wisdom, and in understanding, and in knowledge, and in all manner of workmanship” (Exodus 31:3); and it is written there with regard to creation of heaven and earth: “The Lord, by wisdom, founded the earth; by understanding He established the heavens” (Proverbs 3:19), and it is written: “By His knowledge the depths were broken up and the skies drop down the dew” (Proverbs 3:20). We see that wisdom, understanding, and knowledge, the qualities with which the heavens and earth were created, are all found in Bezalel.

Therefore, we have to conclude that the ancient languages could have used the same sounds, and the divergence between them occured historically due to merging or slight modification of sounds. This could have occured due to the fact that climate, nutrition and lifestyle in different parts of the world causes people develop differently. The shape of Hebrew letters is not really relevant - it could have been received prophetically or developed independently from Proto-Sinaitic hyeroglyphs or cuneiform.

The fact, that letters were used to create life is a very deep concept which can also be found from the science of DNA, where functionalities of 22 key amino-acids can be broken along the lines of the letters of Hebrew alphabet. For example, Erez Grinboim wrote a book exploring the connection The Genetic Code of the Hebrew AlphaBet.

title: How to push back against people who use the Tanakh to justify and promote antisemitism?
content:
# How to push back against people who use the Tanakh to justify and promote antisemitism? ## Frage

It has been argued by atheists and other thinkers, namely self-hating Jew Christopher Hitchens, that the Bible/Tanakh is the biggest contributing factor to antisemitism, and it is not exactly without sense: the Tanakh does, after all, depict Jews in a negative light at many points in time and in numerous instances, is very critical towards Jews. Furthermore, since an atheist doesn't believe in G-d, they view the commandments as being created by the Jews themselves and as they perceive some of the commandments as being primitive or inhumane, they will thus associate these characteristics with those whom they think created these laws. Additionally, Christians, Muslims, Nazis, etc. alike do refer to the Tanakh in order to vilify the Jewish people.

So, what would be the best course of action to combat antisemites who use the Tanakh to justify and promote antisemitism? I would appreciate it if we could cite rabbinic wisdom in the answers.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

If the OP's question is about negative words of the prophets - these words were said with big pain and trepidation to seek teshuvah and good deeds of the Jewish people, not to serve as an accusation, as we clearly learn in mishna Pirkei Avot 4:5:

Rabbi Zadok said: do not make them (words of Torah) a crown for self-exaltation, nor a spade with which to dig (against others).

On the opposite, the claims of anti-semites are not genuine and are always made as means to exalt oneself, acquire leadership, mobilize their people against a convenient enemy, and also rob Jewish people of their possessions. When such people are using Tanakh, the same mishna Pirkei Avot 4:5 continues:

So too Hillel used to say, “And he that puts the crown (of Torah) to his own use shall perish.” Thus you have learned, anyone who derives worldly benefit from the words of the Torah, removes his life from the world.

The Jewish tradition views such people negatively. It is certainly important to point their true intentions. Because of how these people are using the words of Tanakh, they cannot be representing the Jewish people! Hitchens (1949-2011) was a socialist of the Marx and Trotsky brand of socialism. It is a religion with its dialectic materialist mysticism, very hostile to Jewish people, just as both Marx and Trotsky were.

title: How would you respond to this claim on Isaiah 53?
content:
# How would you respond to this claim on Isaiah 53? ## Frage

I was debating a Christian friend of mine, who has become somewhat persistent since I converted to the Jewish faith, but one of the critisms that he brought up, was that Isaiah 53 can't be about Israel, since in Isaiah 53:8, the servant is "cut off for the transgressions of my people" thus indicating that the servant cannot be Israel itself, since they are cut off because of Israel, how would you respond to this claim? I obviously reject it entirely, but I wanted to know how I could answer it.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I too, coming from a christian background that since then I have renounced, used to claim such statements.

"How could Israel possibly bring back Israel if... well... Israel itself is in exile and sinning?" Primarily used to ask this on Isaiah 49:5-6

But truthfully it is not difficult at all. The answer is indeed that Israel brings back Israel to itself, and here is the thought process:

    Jeremiah 31:35-37, Isaiah 44:21, 1 Kings 6:11-13

  2. The wicked of Israel (and some righteous), are exiled due to collective sin

    Ezekiel 39:23, 2 Kings 17:7-8, Deuteronomy 28:49-68

  3. The remainder of Israel are brought back and return to righteousness & realize their survival depends on Torah observance alone

    Ezekiel 36:24-38, Deuteronomy 30:1-10, 1 Kings 8:46-51

It can be seen that this return to Torah is what leads to the ultimate salvation and restoration of Israel. Now who else would advocate Torah observance? Clearly those who have seen the other side and lived, those who have the knowledge of God and His Torah.

So yes, the wise and righteous of Israel exhort the remainder to return to Torah. After all, the prophets are righteous Jews who exclaimed to KEEP TORAH... or else.

Combine this with the popular dictum: All Israel is responsible for each other (Shevuot 39a)

I hate to add this, but in truth, christians believe jesus himself was a Jewish man. So even if a christian wants to refute this method of thinking, according to their book, a Jew brings salvation to Jews FIRST (Matthew 15:24, Romans 1:16), meaning a Jew from Israel restores... Israel. You see?

title: What is the stance of Judaism on discussing philosophies, beliefs, ideas, and practices of other religions or belief systems?
content:
# What is the stance of Judaism on discussing philosophies, beliefs, ideas, and practices of other religions or belief systems? ## Frage

What are the rules or guidelines on how a Jew should engage with others who would like to discuss philosophies, beliefs, ideas, and practices of other religions or belief systems?

  • Are Jews allowed to discuss / engage in the ideas to some degree? Or is it shunned.
  • How does Judaism incorporate ideas outside the main canon / system? (Generally speaking)
  • Are certain topics to be never discussed?

This would help me ask better questions to the Judaism community in general, but also would serve as a gauge as to how to interact. Basically, what is acceptable conversation topics in the end.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Rambam writes as follows (H Avodat kochavim 2:2-3)

סְפָרִים רַבִּים חִבְּרוּ עוֹבְדֵי כּוֹכָבִים בַּעֲבוֹדָתָהּ הֵיאַךְ עִקַּר עֲבוֹדָתָהּ וּמַה מַּעֲשֶׂיהָ וּמִשְׁפָּטֶיהָ. צִוָּנוּ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא שֶׁלֹּא לִקְרוֹת בְּאוֹתָן הַסְּפָרִים כְּלָל וְלֹא נְהַרְהֵר בָּהּ וְלֹא בְּדָבָר מִדְּבָרֶיהָ. וַאֲפִלּוּ לְהִסְתַּכֵּל בִּדְמוּת הַצּוּרָה אָסוּר שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר אַל תִּפְנוּ אֶל הָאֱלִילִים. וּבָעִנְיָן הַזֶּה נֶאֱמַר (דברים י"ב:ל') וּפֶן תִּדְרֹשׁ לֵאלֹהֵיהֶם לֵאמֹר אֵיכָה יַעַבְדוּ, שֶׁלֹּא תִּשְׁאַל עַל דֶּרֶךְ עֲבוֹדָתָהּ הֵיאַךְ הִיא אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין אַתָּה עוֹבְדָהּ, שֶׁדָּבָר זֶה גּוֹרֵם לְהִפָּנוֹת אַחֲרֶיהָ וְלַעֲשׂוֹת כְּמָה שֶׁהֵן עוֹשִׂין שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר וְאֶעֱשֶׂה כֵּן גַּם אָנִי: וְכׇל הַלָּאוִין הָאֵלּוּ בְּעִנְיָן אֶחָד הֵן וְהוּא שֶׁלֹּא יִפְנֶה אַחַר עֲבוֹדַת כּוֹכָבִים וְכׇל הַנִּפְנֶה אַחֲרֶיהָ בְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁהוּא עוֹשֶׂה בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה הֲרֵי זֶה לוֹקֶה. וְלֹא עֲבוֹדַת כּוֹכָבִים בִּלְבַד הוּא שֶׁאָסוּר לְהִפָּנוֹת אַחֲרֶיהָ בְּמַחֲשָׁבָה אֶלָּא כׇּל מַחֲשָׁבָה שֶׁהוּא גּוֹרֵם לוֹ לָאָדָם לַעֲקֹר עִקָּר מֵעִקְּרֵי הַתּוֹרָה מֻזְהָרִין אָנוּ שֶׁלֹּא לְהַעֲלוֹתָהּ עַל לִבֵּנוּ וְלֹא נַסִּיחַ דַּעְתֵּנוּ לְכָךְ וְנַחְשֹׁב וְנִמָּשֵׁךְ אַחַר הִרְהוּרֵי הַלֵּב. מִפְּנֵי שֶׁדַּעְתּוֹ שֶׁל אָדָם קְצָרָה וְלֹא כׇּל הַדֵּעוֹת יְכוֹלִין לְהַשִּׂיג הָאֱמֶת עַל בֻּרְיוֹ. וְאִם יִמָּשֵׁךְ כׇּל אָדָם אַחַר מַחְשְׁבוֹת לִבּוֹ נִמְצָא מַחֲרִיב אֶת הָעוֹלָם לְפִי קֹצֶר דַּעְתּוֹ. כֵּיצַד. פְּעָמִים יָתוּר אַחַר עֲבוֹדַת כּוֹכָבִים וּפְעָמִים יַחְשֹׁב בְּיִחוּד הַבּוֹרֵא שֶׁמָּא הוּא שֶׁמָּא אֵינוֹ. מַה לְּמַעְלָה וּמַה לְּמַטָּה מַה לְּפָנִים וּמַה לְּאָחוֹר. וּפְעָמִים בַּנְּבוּאָה שֶׁמָּא הִיא אֱמֶת שֶׁמָּא הִיא אֵינָהּ. וּפְעָמִים בַּתּוֹרָה שֶׁמָּא הִיא מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם שֶׁמָּא אֵינָהּ. וְאֵינוֹ יוֹדֵעַ הַמִּדּוֹת שֶׁיָּדִין בָּהֶן עַד שֶׁיֵּדַע הָאֱמֶת עַל בֻּרְיוֹ וְנִמְצָא יוֹצֵא לִידֵי מִינוּת. וְעַל עִנְיָן זֶה הִזְהִירָה תּוֹרָה וְנֶאֱמַר בָּהּ (במדבר ט״ו:ל״ט) וְלֹא תָתֻרוּ אַחֲרֵי לְבַבְכֶם וְאַחֲרֵי עֵינֵיכֶם אֲשֶׁר אַתֶּם זֹנִים. כְּלוֹמַר לֹא יִמָּשֵׁךְ כׇּל אֶחָד מִכֶּם אַחַר דַּעְתּוֹ הַקְּצָרָה וִידַמֶּה שֶׁמַּחֲשַׁבְתּוֹ מַשֶּׂגֶת הָאֱמֶת. כָּךְ אָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים (בבלי ברכות י״ב:) אַחֲרֵי לְבַבְכֶם זוֹ מִינוּת וְאַחֲרֵי עֵינֵיכֶם זוֹ זְנוּת. וְלָאו זֶה אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהוּא גּוֹרֵם לָאָדָם לְטָרְדוֹ מִן הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא אֵין בּוֹ מַלְקוֹת:

The worshipers of false gods have composed many texts concerning their service, [describing] what is the essence of their service, what practices are involved, and what are its statutes.⁠ The Holy One, blessed be He, has commanded us not to read those books at all,⁠ nor to think about them or any matters involved with them.⁠ It is even forbidden to look at the image of an idol,⁠ as [Leviticus 19:4] states: "Do not turn to the idols." In this regard, [Deuteronomy 12:30] states:⁠ "[Be careful]... lest you seek to find out about their gods, saying, 'How did they serve them.' This prohibits inquiring about the nature of their service even if you, yourself, do not serve them.⁠ This matter will ultimately cause you to turn to [the false god] and worship it as they do, as [the above verse continues]: "so that I will do the same." All these prohibitions have one common thrust: that one should not pay attention to idol worship.⁠ Whoever performs a deed that reflects his concern with [idol worship] receives lashes [as punishment].⁠ The worship of false gods is not the only subject to which we are forbidden to pay attention;⁠ rather, we are warned not to consider any thought which will cause us to uproot one of the fundamentals of the Torah. We should not turn our minds to these matters, think about them, or be drawn after the thoughts of our hearts.⁠ In general, people have limited powers of understanding, and not all minds are capable of appreciating the truth in its fullness.⁠ [Accordingly,] were a person to follow the thoughts of his heart, it is possible that he would destroy the world because of his limited understanding.⁠ What is implied? There are times when a person will stray after star worship,⁠ and times when he will wonder about God's oneness: Perhaps He is one, perhaps He is not?⁠ [He might also wonder:] What exists above, [in the heavenly realms]? What exists below [them]? What was before time? What will be after time?⁠ Similarly, [one might wonder about] prophecy: Perhaps it is true, perhaps it is not?⁠ And [one may also wonder]⁠ about the Torah: Perhaps it emanates from God, perhaps it does not?⁠ Since he may not know the guidelines with which to evaluate [ideas that will lead him] to the truth in its fullness, he may come to heresy.⁠ The Torah has warned about this matter, saying [Numbers 15:39]: "Do not stray after your hearts and eyes, which have led you to immorality" - i.e., each one of you should not follow his limited powers of understanding and think that he has comprehended the truth. Our Sages [interpreted this warning]: "After your hearts," this refers to heresy; "after your eyes," this refers to immorality. This prohibition - though [severe,] causing a person to be prevented [from attaining a portion] in the world to come - is not punishable by lashes.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Generally the study of other religions is discouraged and not something Jews should engage in. For example studying non Jewish philosophy was part of how Acher went off the correct path in Judaism. I'm not remembering the specific location but there is a gemera that says when he stood up in the study hall many books of apikorses he was studying would fall from his lap. On the other hand the mishnah in perke avos say know how to answer a non believer. This doesn't mean needs to know the other religion but how to answer questions based on knowing Torah itself.

title: Why is it thought that Moses was only a Priest for 7 days?
content:
# Why is it thought that Moses was only a Priest for 7 days? ## Frage

Moses is unique in the Hebrew Bible as the only Priest-King of Israel. There is also, of course, Melchizedek and probably some pagan Priest-Kings of other nations in the bible as well. Something that I've learned since I've started participating on this forum is that one traditional belief is that Moses only temporarily held the position of (High) Priest for 7 days or so whilst he ordained Aaron - at which point he supposedly ceased to be a priest.

Some here have claimed this transfer of the priesthood to be "obvious," but as one who has read through the scriptures many times and been unaware of this tradition - I do not find it obvious in the least. Moses continued to intercede for the people and for Aaron after Aaron was made the High Priest, he instructed Aaron on how to perform his duties and rebuked him, and it was Moses who went into the Tent of Meeting before God throughout the wilderness - thereby causing his face to glow and thus requiring him to use a veil to cover himself so as to not scare the people. Moses was also declared to be Elohim whilst Aaron was made his prophet. Thus, based upon the scriptures, it seems rather clear that Moses both served as a Priest for much longer than a week - and that he was higher than Aaron even when he became High Priest.

But I am open to correction and would like to know the reasoning behind the assertion that Moses was only temporarily a priest despite his continued role of interceding for the people - including Aaron? How would you argue this position? And are there competing views on this within Judaism, or is this the de-facto standard belief?

Thanks :)

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

See Zevahim 102a where a number of opinions are quoted:

  • Moses was originally meant to be a priest, but the priesthood was taken away from him and given to Aaron;
  • Moses was only ever meant to act as a priest during the seven days of inaugurating the Tabernacle;
  • Moses remained a priest his whole life, but his children were not priests.

title: What is a significantly disabled person supposed to do if no Orthodox Jew will marry them?
content:
# What is a significantly disabled person supposed to do if no Orthodox Jew will marry them? ## Frage

I'll divide this question into 4 parts:

1.

If someone has a severe disability but cannot find an orthodox marriage partner, what in halacha are they expected to do regarding forbidden sexual activities? [This is not a question about whether they are obligated to have children.] For example, if someone has significant autism (level 2 ASD) and depression but is fully verbal and understand abstract concepts, what are they required to do regarding sexual and intimate needs? For example, are they allowed to be motzei zera levatala?

Some people assume that such people could not be happily married but such assumptions may be due to issues of stigma that prevent any possibility of Jewish marriage. Yet in reality such a person could be happily married. For example, an Orthodox Jewish social reject might marry a non-Jew because such a person might be willing to consider them as a marriage prospect in a way that religious Jews are not. And such a marriage might be successful in showing that they are capable of intimacy, and in fact, are a pleasant person to live with.

2.

Suppose a Jew has autism and a progressive disease like some forms of painful multiple sclerosis which which makes their predicament worse each year. Suppose their deteriorating physical disability, makes them bed bound and unable to attend a Shul. Their pain makes their life very hard on an hour by hour basis. Are there any halachic leniencies regarding non intimate yichud? Does their level of loneliness factor into this? Does this situation allow any sexual activities not permitted in the previous scenario?

3.

Obviously intermarriage is completely forbidden in halacha.

Orthodox dating assumes that people are "currently OK". However some nonJews may be willing to date someone who is not doing emotionally great at the tine. The process of intimacy can be healing and in time, their emotional state may improve. (Obviously that doesn't mean that a relationship is an emotional cure all and there are many factors in play.)

We say that the Torah doesn't ask too much of people. People with autism are rejected by much of society, Jewish and non-Jewish. Yet they are expected not to intermarry, despite it being one of the few ways they have positive social interaction in their life. Furthermore, if the only people willing to socialize with them are a small subset of nonJews are they supposed to remain lonely?

It seems like such Jews are pushed hard in the direction of intermarriage. It seems that the Torah is asking too much. Unless you say that a lifetime of suffering, severe depression, and loneliness is not asking too much.

4.

Mental health can be hugely impacted by disability and disease. And physical pain too can cause depression. But social rejection is another big cause of negative mental health. If someone is in a situation of psychiatric pikuach nefesh because of all these things, are there sny halachic leniencies regarding sexual and intimate needs? For example a person may be long term suicidal but able to come out of it when they finally experience love from a non-Jew as well as a set of non Jewish friends who accept them for who they are with all the unusual traits of significant autism.

They may have to choose between their life and their status as an Orthodox Jew. This is not purely fictional as a countable number of formerly Orthodox Jews have been essentially excluded due to severe disability (typically multiple disabilities). Halacha sees suicide as essentially self murder and it is conceivable that it is better to do various typically forbidden practices rather than end one's own life due to foreseeable mental health problems that could be ameliorated.

NB: I'm asking assuming the scenarios I gave. In theory if we all were mekayem ואהבת לרעך כמוך properly, many of these issues would be tremendously mitigated. But in the real world, some Jews with autism / developmental disabilities are bullied and excluded. Many are made to feel like they don't belong in klal Yisroel. So they have to take the world as it is, not as it should be. Maybe fixing this may help bring Moshiach.

Edit: this is not about the obligation to procreate which is asked elsewhere. It's about what heterim are available if someone cannot get married because they are unwanted. Even if one is not ready physically or psychologically to have children, one can and should get married according to another answer given. But what if one can't get married? How does a person deal with sexual needs and emotional intimacy meeds etc? And how does one negotiate the social rejection because of severe disability?

title: Recognition of Reform conversions by Open Orthodoxy
content:
# Recognition of Reform conversions by Open Orthodoxy ## Frage

Does Open Orthodoxy recognize Reform conversions as valid? If yes, what are the minimal criteria that Reform conversions must to attend to be recognized as valid by Open Orthodoxy?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Short answer, no; not if it's performed as a usual Reform conversion. But keep reading.

You need a halachically kosher mikvah, and a panel of three men who keep Shabbos and believe in Torah as the word of God. There's no wiggle room on those. My understanding is that very few, if any, Reform conversions involve those.

(There's an Open Orthodox responsum on what exactly the panel has to witness with their own eyes ... but it's agreed that there must be a panel ascertaining the commitment, immersion, and circumcision-if-male.)

What's more of a gray area is the requirement to accept the yoke of mitzvos. Some have defined that part as "as best the candidate understands it..."

Rabbi Moshe Feinstein was asked about an Orthodox mikvah that receives funding from the broader community, including other denominations. If a non-Orthodox rabbi shows up to perform a conversion there, it's not feasible for the Orthodox rabbis to exclude them. His suggestion is ask for three Orthodox rabbis to witness the conversion, and explain that "hey all sorts of procedures need different specialists." Essentially this would be a conversion where all the mechanics of the ritual itself would be to Orthodox standards, even if the convert's education and planned level of observance would not. (Which he felt was still better than a conversion in which the ritual itself was flawed.)

title: YKVK has both a nominal and adjectival meaning?
content:
# YKVK has both a nominal and adjectival meaning? ## Frage

Rabbi Ibn Ezra mentions something intriguing on his commentary of Shemot 6:3. He claims that Ha-Shem's name is sometimes a Noun and sometimes an adjective.

As we know the pronunciation of Ha-Shem's name (Noun) was lost after the destruction of the second temple. However, Ibn Ezra noticed it had an adjectival meaning.

Any thoughts on what it could possibly be?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The distinction Ibn Ezra is making (which he explains at length on Shemot 3:15) isn't between nouns and adjectives, but rather between proper names (שם עצם) like "Abraham" and generic names (תואר) like "man." All of the other names of God describe him in some way (e.g. the name אלהים is shared with the angels), but the four-letter name of God is his proper name, referring to God himself.

But he adds that the four-letter name is also sometimes used generically. One of the characteristics of a proper name is that it's never placed in semichut (we can say "the man of X" but not "the Abraham of X"), therefore the semichut construction in ה' צבאות leads him to say that the four-letter name in that phrase is a generic homonym of the proper name (signifying his eternity, independence and dependence of everything else on him).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The explanation for R. Abraham ibn Ezra's comment can come from the two intents (kavanos) that we make for the name YHVH:

  • היה הוה ויהיה - He was, He is, and He will be, i.e. ever-living - adjective
  • אדון את הכל - Master of all - noun.

title: How come studying the Hebrew letters and Sefirot is not considered idolatry (what is the boundary)?
content:
# How come studying the Hebrew letters and Sefirot is not considered idolatry (what is the boundary)? ## Frage

First, I am not 100% sure what the definition of idolatry is in Judaism. I don't think it applies just to worshipping physical objects (your typical vision of "idols" like human-like statues, etc..), but that idols can also be mental or other types of things too? I am also not certain what the definition of worship is.

But this gets me to think about the Hebrew letters and the 10 Sefirot diagram (after absorbing a good portion of the Sefir Yetzirah book by Aryeh Kaplan).

In his commentary about the Sefir Yetzirah, he paints vivid pictures of the meaning of the structure of the letters, and how they correlate to this and that. And how engraving and carving the letters into your mind, focusing on them intensely, you can gain deep knowledge about the universe (G-d's creation). The letters are not "worshipped", in that I am not treating them I would a person and giving respect to them, and bowing down to them. But I am focusing intensely on the letters and shapes and symbolisms within them (and numerical values, associations, etc..). Focusing on this stuff can absorb your entire consciousness on your way to integrating with the divine, so to speak.

So is idolatry more of like, bowing down and respecting a symbol as if it were like a person? And it's not like what we are doing with the letters in the Sefir Yetzirah commentary here? Or is this a form of idolatry too? Where is the line drawn exactly?

Same with the 10 Sefirot diagram. This is how G-d interacts with creation, and you study it, you try and navigate it in your mind, body, and experience, etc.. You do a lot of "thinking" about it, but I guess I wouldn't call it "worship".

It seems to become "worship of idols", you would have to turn the Hebrew alphabet into something like Tarot cards (which I know mostly nothing about so far). I imagine one who deals with Tarot cards would think think they are possessed of magical powers, and not that they are just emanations of G-d's power. Going down that road, you would forget about G-d and start being passionate and absorbed about the Hebrew alphabet possessing magical powers.

Is that sort of the line for where "curiosity" and "research" (thinking and meditating), becomes "worship"? I guess I don't understand the meaning of worship clearly.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Idolatry is believing or behaving as if anything other than Hashem—an object, concept, idea, symbol, literally anything—is a god, or has power independent of Hashem.

Focusing on letters has nothing to do with idolatry.

title: Animals in the Ark of Noach: a metaphor for the nations of the world
content:
# Animals in the Ark of Noach: a metaphor for the nations of the world ## Frage

In Parshas Noach (Bereishis 6:19-20), we read the instruction G-d gave Noach to build an ark, and together with his family, to put in animals:

וּמִכׇּל־הָ֠חַ֠י מִֽכׇּל־בָּשָׂ֞ר שְׁנַ֧יִם מִכֹּ֛ל תָּבִ֥יא אֶל־הַתֵּבָ֖ה לְהַחֲיֹ֣ת אִתָּ֑ךְ זָכָ֥ר וּנְקֵבָ֖ה יִֽהְיֽוּ׃ מֵהָע֣וֹף לְמִינֵ֗הוּ וּמִן־הַבְּהֵמָה֙ לְמִינָ֔הּ מִכֹּ֛ל רֶ֥מֶשׂ הָֽאֲדָמָ֖ה לְמִינֵ֑הוּ שְׁנַ֧יִם מִכֹּ֛ל יָבֹ֥אוּ אֵלֶ֖יךָ לְהַֽחֲיֽוֹת And of every living thing of all flesh, two of every sort shalt thou bring into the ark, to keep them alive with thee; they shall be male and female. Of birds after their kind, and of cattle after their kind, of every creeping thing of the earth after its kind, two of every sort shall come to thee, to keep them alive.

There are different meforshim who explain that the term "creeping things" or "wild animals" refer to the אומות העולם הרשעים (wicked amongst the gentile nations) (see for example the Ibn Ezra on Yeshayahu 56:9):

All ye beasts of the field, etc. The idea connecting the following with the preceding verses is, that the righteous Israelites and the proselytes will return, but those that persevere in the worship of idols will not return. אתיו Come. It is imperative (comp. 21:12) of אתה to come; comp. ואתה, and He came (Deut. 33:2). God summons the idolatrous wicked nations, to come and devour the wicked of Israel, like wild beasts that devour each other.

On the peshat-level, we can explain that the reason why G-d instructed Noach to bring in these animals, was in order to preserve them, so that they, after the flood, could "start anew". However, I was looking for an explanation based on the Ibn Ezra on Yeshayahu 56:9, where he seems to explains that "wild animals" refer to the wicked amongst the nations. Maybe G-d wanted that Noach would bring them in, so that, during the stay on the ark, they would be educated to be "a mensch"? (as per the Meshech Chochma's explanation mentioned here)

title: Do non-Jews follow the solar calendar or the lunar calendar for Halachic purposes?
content:
# Do non-Jews follow the solar calendar or the lunar calendar for Halachic purposes? ## Frage

The Gemara (Sukkah 29a) says that the nations of the world base their calendar on the sun, as opposed to the Jewish people, who base it on the moon, and the Mechilta De’Rabbi Yishmael says on the verse that teaches about the commandment of sanctifying the moon - ״החודש הזה לכם״ (Shemot 12:2), that we learn it out from the word ״לכם״ - meaning “for us”.

My question is: does that mean that non-Jews have their birthday based on the solar calendar, with regards to ages of maturity, i.e. ages 9 and 13 for a male; 3 and 12 for a female, or do they follow the lunar calendar in this regard?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -2)

Not thinking scripturally, but looking at the non-Jewish world as it is today, the majority of nations have adopted-- at least civilly-- the christian calendar which is based on both in ways. The Christian year is a solar year, eg, how long it takes for the earth to complete one full revolution around the sun, and return to the same place in its orbit, however, it is by lunar divisions of time (one "lunation"-- full length of time required for the moon to go through all phases and return back to the same, such as new moon to the next new moon)-- which vary at or around 28 days, that gives the idea of christian months. Lunations are not all the same because the moon's orbit around the earth varies significantly in the length and "oval-ness" of its path, in a fixed cycle-- but on average are about 28 days each. Of course, the christian months are further confused through the adoption of the Roman months of July and August, placed into the middle of the year, which are the reason the fall months are incorrect for their English (or, better yet, Latin), prefixes-- (eg, September, Sept- means 7, but it is 9, October, Oct- means 8, etc., all the way down to December with Dec- means 10 but it is 12.). Coupling the addition of the new Roman months with a fixed number of days in each month that are unequal, has, in a way, rendered the months in the Christian calendar completely irrelevant to the moon. Worth noting is, 28 days*13=364, so you could have 13 months and one day, to make up the 365 days of the solar year. Now, none of that would have to do with jewish law, but to the point that "the nations of the world," including completely foreign lands with traditionally other cutlures, such as far east Asia, for example-- all have adopted, at least civilly, the christian calendar...This would be the calendar that, reading the question you asked, concerning today, would be considered. It is based on the sun, but in a way is based on the moon...at least in theory.

So, measuring everything, including birthdays, and therefore birthdays concerning maturity or culpability, would be based thereon.

Presenting what is truly a non-answer, it falls to anyone to judge whether the system presently worldwide-adopted is fully solar or fully lunar, it is neither completely and it is both.

title: Parshas Noach. Why was Noah called righteous in his generation?
content:
# Parshas Noach. Why was Noah called righteous in his generation? ## Frage

In the pasuk of Parshas Noach, what prompted the pasuk to write Noach was righteous in his generation? We don't find the Torah writing about any Avos or Imahos vis-a-vis they're righteous in their generation.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Satmar Rav (Divrei Yoel Al HaTorah, Parshas Noach, p. 117) quotes Rav Chaim Vital, and explains that being a tzadik, is not only because of one's deeds, but also the generation in which a person lives has an influence on the righteousness.

The Abarbanel teaches us that the word (תָּמִ֥ים) tamim - upright - means that Noach had no inclination to do evil. This is, because:

Noach walked with G-d, which means that he lived amongst evil people but did not follow their ways. He just followed G-d

The Gemara (Sanhedrin 108a) famously teaches us that Noach was a tzadik in his generation, but if he lived in the generation of Avraham, he would not be a tzadik per se.

With regard to the verse: “These are the generations of Noah; Noah was a righteous man, and wholehearted in his generations” (Genesis 6:9), Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Relative to the other people of his generation he was righteous and wholehearted, but not relative to those of other generations. And Reish Lakish says: In his generation he was righteous and wholehearted despite being surrounded by bad influences; all the more so would he have been considered righteous and wholehearted in other generations.

The Tevas Gome (Noach 4) says:

Noah was a righteous man, perfect in his generations; Noah walked with G-d” (Bereishis 6:9). Since he did not rebuke the people of his generation, nor did he pay attention to their actions at all, he did not mix with them. His entire manner of living was in solitude with G-d

According to some, this, e.g. Noach did not try to rebuke people, this is one of his sins (Chasam Sofer Al HaTorah, Parshas Noach).

Based on the Abarbanel, the reason why the Torah saw the need to mention that Noach was a tzadik in his generations, was to teach us that, in the generations of Noach, the people were corrupt, and most evil. Noach was upright and walked with G-d. However, as Rav Moshe Feinstein (Darash Moshe Al HaTorah, Parshas Noach) teaches: he did walk with G-d, not before G-d, as Avraham Avinu. Noach entered the ark because G-d told him to. With Avraham, all the trials and all what happened, did Avraham out of love for Hashem.

title: Demai - Baker / Shopkeeper / Wholesaler - which has profit and young customers?
content:
# Demai - Baker / Shopkeeper / Wholesaler - which has profit and young customers? ## Frage

[Mishna Demai 2 4] brings 3 cases:

  • A) Bakers הנחתומים separate תרומת מעשר (and חלה).
  • B) Shopkeepers החנונים separate תרומת מעשר and מעשר שני (and חלה).
  • C) Wholesalers המשפיעין don't separate anything.

רע"ב explains that B) Shopkeepers separate more, because 1) they profit more, 2) they have children customers.

החנונים. שמוכרים מעט מעט בחנות, אינן רשאין למכור את הדמאי, הואיל והן משתכרים הרבה עליהם מוטל לתקן. אי נמי מפני שרגילין למכור לתינוקות שלא יאכלו התנוקות דבר שאינו מתוקן:

[Mishna Demai 5 1] brings 1 case, of a baker הנחתום who apparently doesn't separate anything.

רע"ב explains that this baker is a wholesaler, like case C) above, in contrast to the baker in case A) above who is not a wholesaler. He further explains that A) bakers who are not wholesalers separate more, because 1) they profit more, 2) they have children customers.

הלוקח מן הנחתום. כשהנחתום מוכר במדה גסה הלוקח ממנו חייב לתקן מה שהוא לוקח והנחתום פטור. והא דתנן לעיל בפרק ב׳ שהנחתומים חייבים להפריש כדי שיעור תרומת מעשר וחלה, התם מיירי במוכר במדה דקה שמפני שהוא משתכר הרבה הטילו עליו לעשר, אי נמי מפני התינוקות שלוקחים ממי שמוכר בדקה כדי שלא יאכלו טבלים הטילו עליו לתקן. מדה גסה ודקה מפורשים לעיל ספ״ב:

What confuses me, is that the רע"ב uses the same 2 reasons to explain the most strict case B) Shopkeepers, and A) bakers who are not wholesalers.

Is this just a question of degrees, but it applies to both cases to some extent?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

I think תוי"ט addresses the question in 2:4-

תוי"ט כדי תרומת מעשר וחלה. מפורש בריש פ"ה. ומ"ש הרע"ב מתוך ששוטרי המלך וכו'. גמ' פ"ק דיומא (ט.). ולקמן בריש פ"ה מפרש הרע"ב דהכא בנחתומים המוכרים במדה דקה עסקינן, ומהני תרי טעמי דמפרש הכא בחנונים, לכך חייבוהו בתרומת מעשר וחלה כמו שכתב שם, ופטרוהו ממעשר שני מתוך ששוטרי וכו' כמו שכתב הכא. ולא קפדינן אתינוקות בטבול למעשר שני בדמאי:

It sounds like there are two separate reasons to be מיקל- All bakers are subject to price controls, so they are פטור from מעשר שני (including A and C).

And storekeepers have profit and children customers, so they are חייב in תרומת מעשר and חלה (including just A and B).

If correct that means that this comment:

רע"ב החנונים. שמוכרים מעט מעט בחנות, אינן רשאין למכור את הדמאי, #1 הואיל והן משתכרים הרבה עליהם מוטל לתקן. #2 אי נמי מפני שרגילין למכור לתינוקות שלא יאכלו התנוקות דבר שאינו מתוקן:

Even though it seems to be explaining why case B, החנונים, is more חמור than case A, הנחתומים - is actually explaining why A and B is more חמור than case C. So confusing דיבור המתחיל in the רע"ב on 2:4.

title: Why is the complete life span mentioned between Adam and Noach, but not between Noach and Avraham?
content:
# Why is the complete life span mentioned between Adam and Noach, but not between Noach and Avraham? ## Frage

When listing the generations between Adam and Noach, the Torah first says when each person had his 'important' son, then how long he lived after that, and then how long he lived altogether. For example (Bereishis 5:3-5):

ויחי אדם שלשים ומאת שנה ויולד בדמותו כצלמו ויקרא את שמו שת: ויהיו ימי אדם אחרי הולידו את שת שמונה מאות שנה ויולד בנים ובנות: ויהיו כל ימי אדם אשר חי תשע מאות שנה ושלושים שנה וימת:

When Adam had lived 130 years, he begot a son in his likeness after his image, and he named him Seth: After the birth of Seth, Adam lived 800 years and begot sons and daughters: All the days that Adam lived came to 930 years; then he died:

This holds true up to and including Noach. However, after Noach, the complete count of years is no longer mentioned when lifting the generations until Avraham. For example (Bereishis 11:10-11):

אלה תולדות שם שם בן מאת שנה ויולד את ארפכשד שנתים אחר המבול: ויחי שם אחרי הולידו את ארפכשד חמש מאות שנה ויולד בנים ובנות:

This is the line of Shem. Shem was 100 years old when he begot Arpachshad, 2 years after the flood: After the birth of Arpachshad, Shem lived 500 years and begot sons and daughters:

Why the discrepancy? In other words, why was doing the math for us important between Adam and Noach, but not between Noach and Avraham?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

It looks like it is following the warning given to Adam haRishon, that Hashem stated in Bereshis 2:17:

וּמֵעֵ֗ץ הַדַּ֙עַת֙ ט֣וֹב וָרָ֔ע לֹ֥א תֹאכַ֖ל מִמֶּ֑נּוּ כִּ֗י בְּי֛וֹם אֲכׇלְךָ֥ מִמֶּ֖נּוּ מ֥וֹת תָּמֽוּת׃

but as for the tree of knowledge of good and bad, you must not eat of it; for on the day that you eat of it, you shall die.”

Midrash Pesikta Rabbathi 40:1 teaches

[וכן] לאדם כשבא לבראותו ונסתכל שהוא חוטא בעץ ואמר אם אני בורא אותו במידת הדין אין לו תקומה ואם לבראותו ברחמים רע הוא (מתענג) [התענוג] מה עשה שיתף שני המדות מדת הדין ומדת רחמים וברא אותו שנאמר ויצר ה' אלקים את האדם (שם שם ז') וכך עשה לו בזמן שחטא דנו בשתי המדות במדת הדין ובמדת רחמים במדת הדין שאמר לו ביום אכלך ממנו מות תמות (שם שם י"ז) וכיון שאכל גזר עליו מיתה ובמידת רחמים כיצד שיתף עם מדת הדין שלא פירש לו אם יום משלו ואם יום של הקדוש ברוך הוא שהוא אלף שנים כי אלף שנים בעיניך כיום אתמול וגו' (תהלים צ' ד') והוא חיה תשע מאות ושלשים והניח לבניו שבעים שנה שנא' ימי שנותינו בהם שבעים שנה וגו' (שם שם י') ולא עוד אלא כיון שאכל היו המלאכים משמיעים קולם לפני הקב"ה שנאמר וישמעו קול ה' אלקים (בראשית ג' ח') ומה היו אומרים רבונו של עולם מת והלך לו אותו שבגן שנאמר מתהלך בגן (שם) לא כך גזרת עליו כי ביום אכלך ממנו מות תמות אמר להם הקדוש ברוך הוא שמא פירשתי לו אם יום משלי אם יום משלו יום משלי אני נותן לו לרוח היום (שם) אני נותן לו תשע מאות ושלשים ומניח לבניו שבעים שנה לפיכך אמר דוד רבון העולמים אילולי שדנת את אדם הראשון ברחמים בשעה שאכל מן האילן לא חיה אפילו שעה אחת וכשם שדנת אותו ברחמים כך התקנת עמו שאתה היום דן את בניו ברחמים לעולם ה' דברך נצב מהו נצב קיים דברך שהתקנת עם האדם הראשון שכשם שדנת אותו ברחמים כך אתה דן את כל הדורות אחריו לעולם לכך נאמר לעולם ה' (מהו) לדור ודור אמונתך (מהו) למשפטיך עמדו היום

[Also when Hashem] came to creation of man and foresaw that he will sin with (eating from) the tree and said, "If I create him according to the measure of judgment - he will have no redeeming qualities, and if I create him according to the measure of mercy it will be bad, he (will enjoy) [the pleasure]. What did He do - He mixed/partnered the two measures, the measure of judgment and the measure of mercy, and created him (man/Adam) as it is said, "And the Lord G-d created man" Bereshis 2:7) And so He did to him at the time he (Adam) sinned according to both the measure of judgement and the measure of mercy. The measure of judgement told him that "on the day you eat from it you will die (Bereshis 2:17)" and since Adam ate he was sentenced to death.

And the measure of mercy? And if the day of the Holy One, blessed be He, is a thousand years, for in Your sight a thousand years are like yesterday (Tehilim 90:4) and he lived nine hundred and thirty years, and he left to his sons seventy years, the days of our years are seventy years and ... (Tehilim 90:10) And not only that but, as he was eating the angels were uttering their voice before the Almighty, as it was said, *and they heard the voice of the Hashem G-d. *(Bereshis 3:8) and what were they saying? The Master of the World died and went to the one in the garden, as it is said, moving about in the garden etc. (Bereshis 3:8) Is this not what You decreed for him, that on the day you eat from it you will die?

The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them, "Would I have interpreted to him whether my day is mine, whether his day is mine, I give him to the spirit of this day (there) I give him nine hundred and thirty years and leave his sons seventy years.

Thus said David, the Lord of the worlds, had it not been for the fact that you judged the first Adam with mercy when he ate from the tree, he did not live for even one hour, and just as you judged him with mercy, so you decreed with him that today you judge his sons with mercy for the world, O God, your word is justified. This is how you judge all the generations after him for ever and ever. For this it is said to the world of God (what is it) for generation and generation your faith (what is it) for your judgments stand today.

We can conclude from the midrash, that for all generations prior to the flood the full count of their years signifies that their life span followed that of Adam haRishon who died on the day he was created in G-d's days. Eash one (except for Methushelach) died on the same G-d's day (close to 1000 years) as each one was born, and Methushelach saw the beginning of the next due to his righteousness. Finally, the judgement of 120 years (Bereshis 6:3) was defered for the time after the flood and then of 70 years by the times of Moshe and David.

Rabbeinu Bachya makes a related note. We do not find mentioning of death in descendats of Shem, like we find among the earlier generations from Adam till Noach. This is because the kingship of David came from Shem, and there is no death for Mashiyach ben David.

title: Whose idea was it to leave Ur Kasdim and head to Canaan?
content:
# Whose idea was it to leave Ur Kasdim and head to Canaan? ## Frage

Bereshis 11:31 seemingly reports that it was Avraham's father Terach's idea to leave Ur Kasdim and head to Canaan (although he apparently stalled out at Charan):

וַיִּקַּ֨ח תֶּ֜רַח אֶת⁠־אַבְרָ֣ם בְּנ֗וֹ וְאֶת⁠־ל֤וֹט בֶּן⁠־הָרָן֙ בֶּן⁠־בְּנ֔וֹ וְאֵת֙ שָׂרַ֣י כַּלָּת֔וֹ אֵ֖שֶׁת אַבְרָ֣ם בְּנ֑וֹ וַיֵּצְא֨וּ אִתָּ֜ם מֵא֣וּר כַּשְׂדִּ֗ים לָלֶ֙כֶת֙ אַ֣רְצָה כְּנַ֔עַן וַיָּבֹ֥אוּ עַד⁠־חָרָ֖ן וַיֵּ֥שְׁבוּ שָֽׁם׃

Terach took his son, Avram, and his grandson, Lot, the son of Haran, and his daughter-in-law, Sarai, the wife of Avram. And they set out with them from Ur Kasdim to go to the land of Canaan, and they came to Charan and dwelled there.

Whereas from two pesukim later (12:1) it seems that is was HaShem that commanded Avraham to leave his land, family and father's house—presumably Ur Kasdim—and head to a land that God will show him, which turns out to be Canaan:

וַיֹּ֤אמֶר י״י֙ אֶל⁠־אַבְרָ֔ם לֶךְ⁠־לְךָ֛ מֵאַרְצְךָ֥ וּמִמּֽוֹלַדְתְּךָ֖ וּמִבֵּ֣ית אָבִ֑יךָ אֶל⁠־הָאָ֖רֶץ אֲשֶׁ֥ר אַרְאֶֽךָּ

Hashem said to Avram, "Go forth from your land, and from your family,⁠ and from your father's house,⁠ to the land that I will show you.

How to reconcile?

title: Why is the wording different by Arpachshad and Shelach?
content:
# Why is the wording different by Arpachshad and Shelach? ## Frage

In Bereishis 11:12, when recounting the lifespan of the descendants of Noach, it is written:

וְאַרְפַּכְשַׁ֣ד חַ֔י חָמֵ֥שׁ וּשְׁלֹשִׁ֖ים שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֖וֹלֶד אֶת־שָֽׁלַח… וְשֶׁ֥לַח חַ֖י שְׁלֹשִׁ֣ים שָׁנָ֑ה וַיּ֖וֹלֶד אֶת־עֵֽבֶר׃

Why specifically about these two does the Torah say חי as opposed to the others about whom it is written ויחי פלג etc.?

(I wondered if it may have something to do with the fact that the Torah already recounted (10:24) the births of Shelach and Eiver, but the birth of Peleg is also written there.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

You are correct with your guess. According to Essay 22 "When did the Famine End" (Parashas Vayigash) in the book Understanding Rashi by R. Yisrael Isser Zvi Herczeg, there is a rule in the Tanach syntax.

  • When the narrative tells us of the transpiration of events in chronological order, it takes verbs in the form of the future tense, such as יֵדַע, and has them denote actions in the past by adding the conversive waw prefix to the verb and placing it ahead of the subject.
  • When the subject appears first and is followed by the verb in the past tense, as is done in Bereshis 4:1: והאדם יָדַע, it indicates that the narrative goes back in time to refer to an event which took place before those that had earlier been discussed.

The story immediately prior to descendants of Shem was the story of the Tower of Bavel. Before that Torah was telling us about descendants of Shem, Bereshis 10:21-31, where it mentioned both Arpachshad and Shelach. At this point, in Bereshis 11:10 the Torah returns to the parashas of descendants of Shem.

Alternatively, there is a midrash Bereshis Rabba 24:3:

בַּר קַפָּרָא פָּתַח (תהלים סט, כט): יִמָּחוּ מִסֵּפֶר חַיִּים וְעִם צַדִּיקִים אַל יִכָּתֵבוּ. יִמָּחוּ מִסֵּפֶר חַיִּים, מִסֵּפֶר תּוֹלְדוֹת שֶׁל מַטָּה. וְעִם צַדִּיקִים אַל יִכָּתֵבוּ, מִסֵּפֶר תּוֹלְדוֹת שֶׁל מַעְלָה. תָּנֵי בַּר קַפָּרָא בְּכָל מָקוֹם שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר חַי, צַדִּיק, (בראשית יא, יב): אַרְפַּכְשַׁד חַי, (בראשית יא, יד): שֶׁלַח חַי. דָּבָר אַחֵר, יִמָּחוּ מִסֵּפֶר חַיִּים, מִסֵּפֶר תּוֹלְדוֹת שֶׁל אָדָם.

Bar Kappara began: [David said of the wicked:] “May they be expunged from the book of life; and not be inscribed with the righteous” (Psalms 69:29). “May they be expunged from the book of life” – from the book of descendants on earth; “and not be inscribed with the righteous” – from the book of descendants on High. Bar Kappara taught: Everywhere that “lived” is stated, it is in reference to a righteous man: “Arpakhshad lived [ḥai]” (Genesis 11:12); “Shelaḥ lived [ḥai]” (Genesis 11:14). Another interpretation, “may they be expunged from the book of life” – from “the book of the descendants of Adam.”

title: Why did Abraham not know who Isaac should marry if G-d told him?
content:
# Why did Abraham not know who Isaac should marry if G-d told him? ## Frage

At the end of Parshat Vayera (22:20), Abraham is informed that his brother Nahor has fathered a number of descendants, including a granddaughter named Rebecca.

Rashi ad loc (20) explains that these verses were to reassure Abraham that Isaac's spouse had been born, and on the verse "and Bethuel begot Rebecca" (23) Rashi makes it clear that the entire genealogical transcription was on account of this verse.

(Also note that Rebecca is the only female mentioned in the entire passage.)

With that in mind, why wasn't it obvious to Abraham who Isaac's soulmate was destined to be? why didn't he send Eliezer with explicit instructions?

Someone suggested to me that the message was conveyed to Abraham via non-divine methods, so it wasn't a prophesied announcement.

But that sort of begs the question, what was the point of informing Abraham then?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Even though one may think that G-d had preordained that Rivka was Yitzchak's soulmate, the choice to marry was in her and Yitzchak's hands. For example, Avraham states so to Eliezer in Bereshis 24:8

And if the woman does not consent to follow you, you shall then be clear of this oath to me; but do not take my son back there.”

which Rashi explains:

THEN SHALT THOU BE CLEAR FROM THIS MY OATH etc. — and take a wife for him from the daughters of Aner or Eshcol or Mamre.

The point is also repeated in Bereshis 24:49:

And now, if you mean to treat my master with true kindness, tell me; and if not, tell me also, that I may turn right or left.”

which Rashi explains:

TO THE RIGHT HAND — to take a wife of the daughters of Ishmael. TO THE LEFT — to take a wife of the daughters of Lot who dwelt at the left of Abraham (Genesis Rabbah 60:9).

Perhaps, due to passing the Akkeida test by Yitzchak, Avraham was told about Rivka as the best available offer for his son Yitzchak. It is implied by the comment of Sforno to Bereshis 22:23 (Thanks Rabbi Kaii!)

ובתואל ילד את רבקה, the person relating all this to Avraham added that Bethuel, a son of Nachor’s proper wife, sired Rivkah. The meaning of the message was that there had been born in his own family a girl who would be a suitable wife for Avraham’s son so that he would not have to look for such a wife among the K'naanites surrounding him.

That's why Avraham tells Eliezer that Rivka was coming fully from his family, while all other candidates were not. Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre were K'naanim; Yishmael had a mother and a wife from Mitzraim; children of Lot, Ammon and Moav, also took wives from the women of K'naan. Finally, Eliezer's daughter was not from Avraham's family as Eliezer was Eved K'naani, originally from K'naan (some other opinions are known too).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

In addition to Y DJ's answer, there are a couple more possibilities.

  1. Avraham may have known, but he didn't want to interfere with Hashem's hashgacha, as is implied by this Malbim:

שכ"ז נעשה בהשגחתו, הוא ישלח מלאכו שליח ההשגחה שהיא תבא אל יצחק

Since all of this was done under His providence, He will send His angel, the agent of divine oversight, to find a wife for Isaac.

Speculation: It could be that Avraham was trying to show how important it is to rely on Hashem completely and totally, and giving Eliezer too much information would prevent that. It could also be that this is support for the concept that a soul mate is not necessarily fixed and can change based on deeds etc.

  1. He did hint that it should be Rivka to Eliezer, according to Radak:

ואל מולדתי, העיר שנולדתי והיא אור כשדים; ר"ל כי שם ימצא משפחתו, ועל רבקה רמז לו כי הוגד לו שנולדה. ובב"ר א"ר יצחק. כי אל ארצי היינו דאמרי אינשי חטין דקרתך זונין מנהון זרע:

ואל מולדתי, the town in which I was born, i.e. Ur Kasdim. Avraham meant to say that there Eliezer would find his family; he hinted at Rivkah, seeing that he had been informed of her birth. According to Rabbi Yitzchok in Bereshit Rabbah 59,8 the words “to my land” reflect a well known proverb according to which people prefer to plant seed originating in their own backyard even though the strain is known to be inferior to those available elsewhere [R Eli Munk translation]

Speculation: It could be that Avraham wanted to show how loyal and trustworthy Eliezer was, so he only gave him a hint.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

In most midrashim it says hashem told him that his zivug was born but Hashem didnt tell him who it was. It could rashi also means this, hes just saying to us who it was, but not that hashem told Avraham the name.

title: Who is the wonderful councillor, the mighty G-d, the everlasting father in Isaiah 9:5?
content:
# Who is the wonderful councillor, the mighty G-d, the everlasting father in Isaiah 9:5? ## Frage

In Isaiah 9:5 is speaks about a child being born unto his and then it goes on to provide certain titles for this child, including the wonderful councillor, the mighty G-d, the everlasting Father, so why is the child that is given this title? (I think its probably Hezekiah)

The English editions of Christian Bibles have the following footnote: "In Hebrew texts 9:1 is numbered 8:23, and 9:2-21 is numbered 9:1-20." Therefore, the Hebrew verse Isaiah 9:5 is translated as Isaiah 9:6.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Proper translation of the verse in question would be:

For a child has been born to us, a son given to us, and the authority is upon his shoulder, and the wondrous adviser, the mighty G-d, the everlasting Father, called his name, "the prince of peace."

Per Rashi, leading commentator of the Tanakh

For a child has been born to us. Although Ahaz is wicked, his son who was born to him many years ago [nine years prior to his assuming the throne] to be our king in his stead, shall be a righteous man, and the authority of the Holy One, blessed be He, and His yoke shall be on his shoulder, for he shall engage in the Torah and observe the commandments, and he shall bend his shoulder to bear the burden of the Holy One, blessed be He.

and… called his name. The Holy One, blessed be He, Who gives wondrous counsel, is a mighty G-d and an everlasting Father, called Hezekiah’s name, “the prince of peace,” since peace and truth will be in his days.

Rashi continues his refutation of the view that the person in question is Jesus in his elucidation of the following verse:

To him who increases the authority, and for peace without end, on David's throne and on his kingdom, to establish it and to support it with justice and with righteousness; from now and to eternity, the zeal of the L-rd of Hosts shall accomplish this.

Per Rashi

To him who increased the authority. To whom will He call this name? To the king who increases the authority of the Holy One, blessed be He, upon himself, to fear Him.

authority. an expression of government. [This is to refute those who disagree with us [the Christians]. But it is possible to say that “Prince of Peace,” too, is one of the names of the Holy One, blessed be He, and this calling of a name is not actually a name but an expression of (var. for the purpose of) greatness and authority. Comp. (Ruth 4:11) “And be famous (וּקְרָא שֵׁם) in Bethlehem. Also (II Sam. 7:9, I Chron. 17:8): ” And I shall make for you a name.“ Here too, Scripture means, ” And He gave him a name and authority."

and for peace. which is given to him, there will be no end, for he had peace on all his sides, and this “end” is not an expression of an end to eternity, but there will be no boundaries. On the throne of the kingdom of David shall this peace be justice and righteousness that Hezekiah performed.

and for peace. Heb. וּלְשָׁלוֹם. This ‘vav’ is to rectify the word, thus: He [Hezekiah] increased the authority upon his shoulder, and what reward will He [G-d] pay him? Behold, his peace shall have no end or any limit.

from now and to eternity. The eternity of Hezekiah, viz. all his days. And so we find that Hannah said concerning Samuel (I Sam. 1:22): “and abide there forever.” And, in order to refute those who disagree [i.e., the Christians, who claim that this (Prince of Peace) is their deity], we can refute them [by asking], What is the meaning of: “from now” ? Is it not so that the “deity” did not come until after five hundred years and more?

the zeal of the L-rd of Hosts. Who was zealous for Zion concerning what Aram and Pekah planned about it.

shall accomplish this. but Ahaz does not deserve it, moreover, the merit of the Patriarchs has terminated. [Addendum: And our Rabbis said: The Holy One, blessed be He, wished to make Hezekiah the Messiah and Sennacherib, Gog and Magog. Said the ministering angels before the Holy One, blessed be He, Should the one who stripped the doors of the Temple and sent them to the king of Assyria, be made Messiah? Immediately, Scripture closed it up.]

title: What does a 'chok' type mitzvah mean?
content:
# What does a 'chok' type mitzvah mean? ## Frage
  1. Not rationally comprehensible at all, even to the Divine intellect (an exclusive function of the Divine Will)
  2. Rationally comprehensible by the Divine intellect, but not by humans (supra-rational)
  3. Rationally comprehensible by human intellect but may take hundreds or perhaps thousands of years to arrive at a correct understanding (akin to scientific progress)
  4. Rationally comprehensible in its historical setting but the reason now eludes us
## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to the Rambam, all of the commandments, including the chukkim, have reasons, although we may be ignorant of the reasons. The Rambam says this is the opinion of all Jews (More Nevuchim 3:26; this is also presupposed by every author who wrote a work of the taamei hamitzvot genre). So, although it may be the case that the reason for a chok is unknown, it isn't the defining characteristic of a chok, which should be comprehensible to humans (as the Rambam notes there and 3:31, the value of the chukkim is said to be apparent even to the non-Jews, and Shlomo was supposed to have understood the reasons for all the commandments except for the red cow).

The difference between chukkim and mishpatim is that mishpatim are commandments that we would know to follow even without the Torah, while chukkim are commandments we know to follow only because of the Torah's commandment (Shmona Prakim 6). Or, the chukkim are commandments for which the reason isn't apparent to common people, although it may be known to others (More Nevuchim 3:26).

Another definition is that mishpatim are commandments towards equals, i.e. other humans, and chukkim are commandments towards subordinates, such as animals, plants and self (Rabbi Samson Raphael Hirsch, Nineteen Letters 10).

What should I do if I am unsure of the status of a hostage that I took responsibility to daven for? I don’t know if they are still hostage, freed, or Chas v’shalom not alive anymore.
