title: What do we learn from the phrases "and it was so" and "and there was light" in the story of creation?
content:
# What do we learn from the phrases "and it was so" and "and there was light" in the story of creation? ## Frage

The chachamim learn halachos even from individual letters so there is nothing extra in the Torah. That being so what do we learn from וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן being recited throughout creation? Also rather than וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן on the first day it repeats וַֽיְהִי־אֽוֹר. What's different about אֽוֹר from the rest of creation?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

According to Ramban on 1:3, it didn't say וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן for the light, because the light didn't stay in this state, like all the other creations (He hid it for the Tzaddikim). He clarifies in 1:7 that וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן is meant to teach us that this thing that He created is forever.

The reason why it says וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן for everything else, rather than enumerating it proper, is because the Torah wants to teach us to be brief and concise (Pesachim 3 - see Chizkuni loc. cit.)

Why it says וַֽיְהִי־כֵֽן at all is to teach us that Hashem creates things out of nothing simply from speaking, unlike humans, who can only make light from existing light sources (see HaEmek Hadavar loc. cit)

title: Why do we say leshem shamayim
content:
# Why do we say leshem shamayim ## Frage

Why do we refer to Hakadosh baruch Hu as 'heaven' in the phrase לשם שמים?

See for example avot 2:2

I'm not sure what else we should say, but is there a reason as to why we say שמים.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Maybe the simple answer is based on the Maharal in Derech Chaim on Pirkei Avot 1:3 who explains that Hashem is referred to as Shamayim because it is distant and above us. Although we are filled with love for Hashem and feel close to him, we need to temper the love with fear and perceive a distance as well.  Therefore the word Shamayim is used to connote a kind of distance and awe. Therefore maybe the same applies for לשם שמים, as however you interpret what it means, the simple meaning is your doing it for "shamyim's" sake which is Hashem, but we don't say "Leshem Hashem" because of the fear and distance that we also have with Hashem.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

From the sources I bring below, my initial assumption was that this is shorthand for The One Who dwells in shamayim in the manner of השוכן בשמים. Where for shamayim itself, there's the notion of the heavens of the physical universe and also the notion of the metaphysical shamayim. But there are also possibilities that even as early as Tanach, sometimes שמים can be a direct reference to הקב"ה.

Your example of לשם שמים in אבות ב:ב is one of many examples of חז"ל using the term shamayim to refer to G_d directly or to G_d in Heaven. Here is a list of cases I could find in the Mishna alone:

  • שם שמים - סנהדרין ו:ד, אבות א:יא, ב:ב,יב, ד:ד,יא, ה:יז
  • מלכות שמים - ברכות ב:ב,ה
  • אביו\אביכם\אביהם\אבינו\אביך שבשמים - כלאים ט:ח, יומא ח:ט, ר"ה ג:ח, סוטה ט:טו, אבות ה:כ
  • (קידשוהו שמים? - ר"ה ב:ז)
  • בידי שמים - יבמות ד:יג, סנהדרין ט:ו, יא:ה, חולין ג:ב, נגעים יא:ג
  • של שמים - נדרים ב:ד
  • נפש\גוף לשמים - נדרים ד:ג
  • מקדש לשמים - נדרים ה:ו
  • מן השמים - נדרים י:ו, סנהדרין ב:א, י:א
  • דיני שמים - ב"ק ו:ד
  • אלוקינו שבשמים - סנהדרין ז:י
  • מורה שמים - אבות א:ג, ד:יב
  • דעתו לשמים - מנחות יג:יא

We also of course have the well-known phrase בסיעתא דשמיא (with Heaven's help) which is a request for G_d's assistance.

When one examines the many usages of the word שמים in Tanach, one can see that the terminology of חז"ל didn't emerge from a vacuum and quite possibly is used in a similar way at a much earlier time to a lesser degree. Here are some of the most relevant examples from the Chumash:

  • (שמות כ:יח) וַיֹּאמֶר ה' אֶל מֹשֶׁה כֹּה תֹאמַר אֶל בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל אַתֶּם רְאִיתֶם כִּי מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם דִּבַּרְתִּי עִמָּכֶם

  • (דברים כו:טו) הַשְׁקִיפָה מִמְּעוֹן קׇדְשְׁךָ מִן הַשָּׁמַיִם וּבָרֵךְ אֶת עַמְּךָ אֶת יִשְׂרָאֵל וְאֵת הָאֲדָמָה אֲשֶׁר נָתַתָּה לָנוּ כַּאֲשֶׁר נִשְׁבַּעְתָּ לַאֲבֹתֵינוּ אֶרֶץ זָבַת חָלָב וּדְבָשׁ

  • (דברים לב:מ) כִּי אֶשָּׂא אֶל שָׁמַיִם יָדִי וְאָמַרְתִּי חַי אָנֹכִי לְעֹלָם

Where the first two indicate שמים being the place of G_d's abode (true that He is everywhere and owns all but the earth might be considered a domain that's shared with humans - see later "הַשָּׁמַיִם שָׁמַיִם לַה' והארץ נתן לבני אדם") and in the final one we might have a more direct reference to G_d.

According to Rashi on Devarim 32:40 (mentioned above) near the end of shiras Haazinu, just as a human swears in the name of G_d, G_d Himself can swear by His own name:

אשא ידי אל עצמי בשבועה

Another very important section that contributes to this idea is the tefila that Shlomo Hamelech offers at the time of the inauguration of the בית המקדש in מלכים א, פרק ח:

וַיַּעֲמֹד שְׁלֹמֹה.....וַיִּפְרֹשׂ כַּפָּיו הַשָּׁמָיִם .....הִנֵּה הַשָּׁמַיִם וּשְׁמֵי הַשָּׁמַיִם לֹא יְכַלְכְּלוּךָ אַף כִּי הַבַּיִת הַזֶּה אֲשֶׁר בָּנִיתִי ..... וְאַתָּה תִּשְׁמַע אֶל מְקוֹם שִׁבְתְּךָ אֶל הַשָּׁמַיִם וְשָׁמַעְתָּ וְסָלָחְתָּ וְאַתָּה תִּשְׁמַע הַשָּׁמַיִם וְעָשִׂיתָ וְשָׁפַטְתָּ אֶת עֲבָדֶיךָ..... וְאַתָּה תִּשְׁמַע הַשָּׁמַיִם וְסָלַחְתָּ לְחַטַּאת עַמְּךָ יִשְׂרָאֵל..... וְאַתָּה תִּשְׁמַע הַשָּׁמַיִם וְסָלַחְתָּ לְחַטַּאת עֲבָדֶיךָ וְעַמְּךָ יִשְׂרָאֵל..... וְאַתָּה תִּשְׁמַע הַשָּׁמַיִם מְכוֹן שִׁבְתֶּךָ וְסָלַחְתָּ וְעָשִׂיתָ..... אַתָּה תִּשְׁמַע הַשָּׁמַיִם מְכוֹן שִׁבְתֶּךָ וְעָשִׂיתָ כְּכֹל אֲשֶׁר יִקְרָא אֵלֶיךָ..... וְשָׁמַעְתָּ הַשָּׁמַיִם אֶת תְּפִלָּתָם וְאֶת תְּחִנָּתָם וְעָשִׂיתָ מִשְׁפָּטָם וְשָׁמַעְתָּ הַשָּׁמַיִם מְכוֹן שִׁבְתְּךָ אֶת תְּפִלָּתָם וְאֶת תְּחִנָּתָם וְעָשִׂיתָ מִשְׁפָּטָם וַיְהִי כְּכַלּוֹת שְׁלֹמֹה לְהִתְפַּלֵּל אֶל ה'.....קָם מִלִּפְנֵי מִזְבַּח ה' מִכְּרֹעַ עַל בִּרְכָּיו וְכַפָּיו פְּרֻשׂוֹת הַשָּׁמָיִם

In multiple times here it stresses shamayim as G_d's place and in certain cases such as תשמע השמים one might make that case that this even referring to G_d Himself.

The (ספר הבהיר (סימן ק brings this idea out from tefilas Shlomo with the following:

מנלן דשמים הקדוש ברוך הוא? דכתיב: וְאַתָּה תִּשְׁמַע הַשָּׁמַיִם, אטו שלמה התפלל אל השמים שישמעו תפלתם? אלא אותו שנקרא שמו על השמים, דכתיב: השמים ושמי השמים לא יכלכלוך, הרי שמו של הקדוש ברוך הוא.

Also see the following selected pesukim (among many others) which influence the ideas I have mentioned above:

  • (ישעיהו סג:טו) הַבֵּט מִשָּׁמַיִם וּרְאֵה מִזְּבֻל קׇדְשְׁךָ וְתִפְאַרְתֶּךָ אַיֵּה קִנְאָתְךָ וּגְבוּרֹתֶךָ הֲמוֹן מֵעֶיךָ וְרַחֲמֶיךָ אֵלַי הִתְאַפָּקוּ
  • (ישעיהו סו:א) כֹּה אָמַר ה' הַשָּׁמַיִם כִּסְאִי וְהָאָרֶץ הֲדֹם רַגְלָי אֵי זֶה בַיִת אֲשֶׁר תִּבְנוּ לִי וְאֵי זֶה מָקוֹם מְנוּחָתִי
  • (תהלים יא:ד) ה' בְּהֵיכַל קׇדְשׁוֹ ה' בַּשָּׁמַיִם כִּסְאוֹ עֵינָיו יֶחֱזוּ עַפְעַפָּיו יִבְחֲנוּ בְּנֵי אָדָם
  • (תהלים קג:יט) ה' בַּשָּׁמַיִם הֵכִין כִּסְאוֹ וּמַלְכוּתוֹ בַּכֹּל מָשָׁלָה
  • (תהלים קטו:טז) הַשָּׁמַיִם שָׁמַיִם לַה' וְהָאָרֶץ נָתַן לִבְנֵי אָדָם (from this we can see that the earth possesses the shared notion I mentioned above while shamayim is the sole domain of G_d)
  • (תהלים קכג:א) שִׁיר הַמַּעֲלוֹת אֵלֶיךָ נָשָׂאתִי אֶת עֵינַי הַיֹּשְׁבִי בַּשָּׁמָיִם
  • (איכה ג:נ) עַד יַשְׁקִיף וְיֵרֶא ה' מִשָּׁמָיִם
  • (קהלת ה:א) אַל תְּבַהֵל עַל פִּיךָ וְלִבְּךָ אַל יְמַהֵר לְהוֹצִיא דָבָר לִפְנֵי הָאֱלֹהִים כִּי הָאֱלֹהִים בַּשָּׁמַיִם וְאַתָּה עַל הָאָרֶץ עַל כֵּן יִהְיוּ דְבָרֶיךָ מְעַטִּים
  • (דברי הימים ב ל:כז) וַיָּקֻמוּ הַכֹּהֲנִים הַלְוִיִּם וַיְבָרְכוּ אֶת הָעָם וַיִּשָּׁמַע בְּקוֹלָם וַתָּבוֹא תְפִלָּתָם לִמְעוֹן קׇדְשׁוֹ לַשָּׁמָיִם

For further reading, see the discussion here.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

We do so because of the Rashi on Bereshis 1:1

And a further proof that the heavens and earth were not the first thing created is that the heavens were created from fire (אש) and water (מים), from which it follows that fire and water were in existence before the heavens.

Usually fire either evaporates water and water extinguishes fire. But the Holy NAME is what makes it exist in balance. Fire symbolized midas hadin (judgement), water symbolized midas harachamim (Mercy). It is also related to the saying from Berachos 56b with pot having fire (din) outside and water (hesed) inside

Rabbi Ḥanan said: There are three items seen in dreams that are indications of peace: A river, a bird and a pot. The Gemara elaborates: A river, as it is written: “I will extend peace to her like a river” (Isaiah 66:12); a bird, as it is written: “As birds hovering, so will the Lord of hosts protect Jerusalem” (Isaiah 31:5); and a pot, as it is written: “Lord, You will establish [tishpot] peace for us” (Isaiah 26:12). Peace is likened to a pot which is placed [shafat] on the fire. And Rabbi Ḥanina said: We learned that a pot in a dream is a sign of peace with regard to a pot that does not have meat in it, as a pot that has meat in it symbolizes calamity, as it is stated: “Yea, they chop them in pieces, as that which is in the pot, and as flesh within the cauldron” (Micah 3:3).

I.e. L'shem Shamayim - for the sake of name that keeps everything in balance. It is also a marker of the straight path, which avoids steering to the left (judgement) or to the right (mercy).

title: Why does the Torah specify that humankind was created male and female?
content:
# Why does the Torah specify that humankind was created male and female? ## Frage

For all of the other animals the Torah simply states that they were created. By humankind the Torah specifies that they were created male and female - why?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I heard it in yeshiva from some of the shiurim on family relationships. Geometrically, triangle is a stronger model than a line, which can bend. Building a family out of 3 (man, woman and Hashem) is a stronger construct for building faith, than out of 2 (Adam and Hashem). It is also stated in Koheles 4:9-10:

Two are better off than one, in that they have greater benefit from their earnings. For should they fall, one can raise the other; but woe betide him who is alone and falls with no companion to raise him!

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Adam and Eve were first created as a single being, then separated. The Talmud says:

Rabbi Yirmeya ben Elazar said: The Holy One, Blessed be He, created two faces [du partzufin] on Adam the first man. He was created both male and female in a single body, as it is stated: “You have formed me [tzartani] back and front” (Psalms 139:5). [Tzartani is derived from the word tzura (face). God formed two faces on a single creation, back and front.] [Berakhot 61a; also Eruvin 18a]

The Midrash echoes this:

Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥman said: When the Holy One blessed be He created Adam the first man, He created him with two faces, [That is, two conjoined bodies, male and female.] and [subsequently] He sawed him in two [separating the female part from the male part] and made [for] him two backs, [where they had previously been joined together], a back here and a back there... It is as it is stated: “Back [aḥor] and front [kedem] You shaped me…” [Psalms 139:5] [Genesis Rabbah 8:1]

title: Why does Rashi switch the order that Onkelos uses when describing the people of S'dom's sins?
content:
# Why does Rashi switch the order that Onkelos uses when describing the people of S'dom's sins? ## Frage

In Bereishis 13:13 it says:

ואנשי סדום רעים וחטאים לה' מאוד

Onkelos translates as follows:

ואנשין דסדום בישין בממונהון וחייבין בגביתהון קדם ה' לחדא

The people of S'dom were wicked with their property and sinful with their bodies towards Hashem, exceedingly.

Meaning, he takes רעים to mean monetary sins, and חטאים to mean bodily sins.

Rashi, on the other hand, explains the opposite way around:

רעים בגופם: וחטאים בממונם:

Wicked in their persons: and sinners with their wealth:

Why does Rashi explain the sins attributed to these words the opposite of how Onkelos does?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Thanks to shmosel for pointing me in the right direction

The gemara in Sanhedrin (109a) actually brings both versions. As the Gur Aryeh explains (on the Rashi quoted in my question):

רעים בגופם וכו' והתרגום תרגם איפכא. ובפרק חלק (סנהדרין קט.) איכא ברייתא כדברי המתרגם ורב יודא כדברי רש"י. ויראה לי דטעם הברייתא דיותר יש לקרות 'רע' מי שהוא חוטא בממון, כדכתיב "ורעה עיניך וגו'", ודבר זה מורה שיש בו רע עין, מאחר שאינו עושה טוב לאחר. ולדעת רב יודא 'רעים בגופם' לפי ש'רע' הוא יותר מן 'חטא', לפי שהוא רע לגמרי, ולפיכך יש לומר 'רעים בגופם' והוא יותר רע ממי שחוטא בממון, שזה נקרא 'חוטא'. ותפס רש"י דברי רב יודא, כי יותר לפי פשוטו שנקרא 'רע' מי שגופו רע.

Wicked in their persons etc. Yet Onkelos translated the opposite. In chapter Chelek (Sanhedrin 109a) there is a b'raisa like Onkelos' version, and Rav Yehuda like Rashi's. And it seems to me that the reasoning of the b'raisa is that it is more accurate to call 'evil' one who sins monetarily, because the passuk states "and your eye is evil (towards your poor brother, and you don't give him charity)", and this shows that this man has an evil eye, because he doesn't do good to others. And Rav Yehuda holds that it means 'evil with their bodies' because 'evil' is worse than 'sinner', because he is completely bad, therefore it makes more sense to say 'evil with their bodies' which is worse than sinning monetarily, which is therefore only called 'a sinner'. And Rashi chose to go according to Rav Yehuda, because it follows the p'shat explanation that one whose body is evil, is evil.

title: The meaning of Dammesek Eliezer
content:
# The meaning of Dammesek Eliezer ## Frage

Usually the meaning of דמשק אליעזר is translated as Dammesek Eliezer, meaning that he was from the city Damascus in Syria as in Bereshis 15:2 Targum Onkelos and Radak.

וַיֹּ֣אמֶר אַבְרָ֗ם אֲדֹנָ֤י יֱהוִה֙ מַה־תִּתֶּן־לִ֔י וְאָנֹכִ֖י הוֹלֵ֣ךְ עֲרִירִ֑י וּבֶן־מֶ֣שֶׁק בֵּיתִ֔י ה֖וּא דַּמֶּ֥שֶׂק אֱלִיעֶֽזֶר׃

But Avram said, “O Lord Hashem, what can You give me, seeing that I shall die childless, and the one in charge of my household is Dammesek Eliezer!”

Onkelos also translates it in this sense when writing דמשקאה “from Damascus.” It is also possible that the servant’s name was Damessek when he came to Avram, and that his master changed his name to Eliezer, seeing that this is a Hebrew name.

The discussion on the site about the Eliezer's family background, makes it unlikely to assume that Eliezer was from Damascus. Nevertheless, the etymology of the city name Damascus, דר משק, means a plentifully watered place. Could one suppose by analogy that Dammesek refers to Eliezer's primary responsibility to provide water for Avraham's household? Is there a source for it? Is there a connection between בֶן־מֶ֣שֶׁק / manager and Aramaic דַּמֶּ֥שֶׂק with שׂ replacing שׁ due to Eliezer's pronunciation?

If so, it could explain why Avraham was not afraid to send Eliezer with many camels carrying gifts, as Eliezer was highly skilled at finding wells in unfamiliar places, such as Aram Naharaim.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The gemara in Yoma (28b) states:

אֱלִיעֶזֶר עֶבֶד אַבְרָהָם, זָקֵן וְיוֹשֵׁב בִּישִׁיבָה הָיָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֹּאמֶר אַבְרָהָם אֶל עַבְדּוֹ זְקַן בֵּיתוֹ הַמֹּשֵׁל בְּכׇל אֲשֶׁר לוֹ״, אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: שֶׁמּוֹשֵׁל בְּתוֹרַת רַבּוֹ. ״הוּא דַּמֶּשֶׂק אֱלִיעֶזֶר״ — אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: שֶׁדּוֹלֶה וּמַשְׁקֶה מִתּוֹרָתוֹ שֶׁל רַבּוֹ לַאֲחֵרִים.

Eliezer, servant of Abraham, was an Elder and sat in yeshiva, as it is stated: “And Abraham said to his servant, the elder of his household, who ruled over all he had” (Genesis 24:2). Rabbi Elazar said: The verse means that he had mastery over the Torah of his master, having gained proficiency in all of the Torah of Abraham. That is the meaning of the verse: “He is Damascus [Dammesek] Eliezer” (Genesis 15:2). Rabbi Elazar said: The word Dammesek is a contraction of he who draws [doleh] and gives drink [mashke] to others from his master’s Torah.

Based on this, it is reasonable to suggest that Avraham is using Eliezer’s birthplace (regardless of its original etymology) as a play-on-words referencing his talent. Similarly, the rather unusual phrase Avraham uses for “the one in charge of my household” (בן משק ביתי) can be interpreted in the same vein.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

In Bereishis (14:15), while describing Avraham's fight against the four kings, it says:

ויחלק עליהם לילה הוא ועבדיו ויכם וירדפם עד חובה אשר משמאל לדמשק

At night, he and his servants deployed against them and defeated them; and he pursued them as far as Hobah, which is north of Damascus.

The Ha'emek Davar explains this passuk based on the midrash that Avraham's 'servants' is actually just referring to Eliezer, and says:

וירדפם עד חובה וכו' החיל שלא הוכו ונזדרזו לברוח. רדפו עליהם אנשי אברם גם לחו"ל עד חובה. [ולפרש"י דחובה הוא דן אינו מובן הפי' אשר לשמאל לדמשק]. ומש"ה נקרא דמשק אליעזר. משום דעד דן היה נקרא המלחמה על אברם. ומדן והלאה נקראת ע"ש אליעזר. ודמשק היא העיר הראשית.

And he chased them until Chobah The soldiers that weren't killed, and hurried and ran away, Avraham's people chased them, even outside of Israel, until Chobah. [And according to Rashi's explanation, that Chobah is Dan, "North of Damascus" didn't make sense]. And this is why his name is Eliezer Damascus, because until Dan the battle was named for Avraham. But from Dan and on, it was named for Eliezer, and Damascus is the main city (in that area)

So Eliezer is given the name "Damascus" because of his part in Avraham's win in the fight which took place in its vicinity.

The reason that up until Dan that battle was named for Avraham, and afterwards it was named for Eliezer, can be found in an earlier Ha'emek Davar (14:14):

וירדף עד דן דן הוא בקצה גבול צפוני של א"י כידוע בגבולי יהושע ולא רצה אברם לרדוף אחריהם בעצמו חוץ לא"י

And he chased them until Dan. Dan is at the edge of the Northern border of the land of Israel, as is known from the borders in Yehoshua, and Avram didn't want to chase them, himself, outside of Israel.

Meaning, Avraham didn't want to leave Israel, even in order to chase the kings, so instead he sent his servants (meaning, based on the midrash, Eliezer). So while Avraham was fighting, the battle of named for him. Beyond that, it's named for Eliezer.

title: Why does the Shulchan Aruch allow a Tefillas Nedavah on Motzaei Shabbos?
content:
# Why does the Shulchan Aruch allow a Tefillas Nedavah on Motzaei Shabbos? ## Frage

The Shulchan Aruch (Orach Chaim 108:11) brings down a case where one should pray as a Nedavah on Motzaei Shabbos, because of a doubt.

My question is: how can one pray as a Nedavah on Motzaei Shabbos, being that Korbanos cannot be offered at night, and there cannot even be leftovers of a Nedavah from the day, being that Nedavos cannot be brought on Shabbos, and we therefore don’t pray as a Nedavah on Shabbos (Orach Chaim 107:1)?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Here are two possible answers that I thought of:

  1. While it is forbidden to offer sacrifices at night, one is still allowed to consecrate an animal at night, which cannot be done on Shabbos.

  2. The Gemara (Zevachim 120a) brings an argument between Rav and Shmuel as to whether one was allowed to offer a sacrifice on a private altar at night, before the Beis Hamikdash was built, and according to Rashi, Rav is the one who permits it, and the Halacha is generally like Rav, aside for when it comes to monetary laws.

title: Torah term for putting others first?
content:
# Torah term for putting others first? ## Frage

Pretty self-explanatory. Is there any Torah term or phrase that refers to the ethical act of "Putting Others First"?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

To be mevatter means to give way, yield, concede, forgo, or waive. It is related to the root יתר, which means to leave over, and to the word יותר (more). An examplar in the Torah of this behavior is Rachel Imenu. Yaakov agreed to work for Lavan to marry his daughter Rachel, but Lavan gave him her sister Leah instead. The Torah says that the next morning Yaakov realized it was Leah. Rashi says Yaakov hadn't realized the previous night because he had given signs to Rachel but when she saw they were giving him Leah she was afraid her sister would be embarrassed, so she gave those signs to Leah. (Rachel was rewarded for this; cf. Rashi/Radak on Jeremiah 31:15.) Although I feel this is an example of being mevatter, I didn’t see that word actually used there. The word mevatter can also be used in a negative context, as in Mishna Sanhedrin 11:5 “one who disregards (the words of a prophet).”

title: Can a Ben Pakuah be brought as a Korban?
content:
# Can a Ben Pakuah be brought as a Korban? ## Frage

Since shechita is not required would that prohibit bringing a ben pakuah as a korban? Or would you just schect it anyway and continue on?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Chullin 74b takes it as a given that a ben pakuah is unfit to be a korban.

Rashi (s.v. degamar) explains that this is because it is was born via caesarean section (yotzei dofen), which renders it unfit to be a korban.

Tosafot (s.v. degamar) argue, and explain that it is unfit as a korban because it is viewed as having already been slaughtered.

title: Why don't the Beta Israel accept the Talmud?
content:
# Why don't the Beta Israel accept the Talmud? ## Frage

According to a Chacham I discussed this with: While some members of Beta Israel community subscribe to Rabbinic Judaism including Falash Mura who left Christianity, they do not practice it fully. The majority of the community subscribes and practices the pre-Talmudic Jewish Haymanot.

Accordingly, why don't the Beta Israel accept the Talmud?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

My understanding is that most of the Beta Israel that immigrated to Israel underwent גיור לחומרא - conversion of stringency (see Jews in Israel: Contemporary Social and Cultural Patterns, p. 131 regarding some of the controversy surrounding it). Any Orthodox conversion requires that a candidate of conversion accept the authority of rabbinic Judaism (Bekhoroth 30b, H. Issurei Biah 14:8), which in turn means acceptance of the Talmud.

The statement attributed to the anonymous Hakham makes it sound like the Beta-Israel actively reject the Talmud. I am unaware of any member of their community that vocally expresses such a perspective.

Just like may other 'olim from around the world, the Beta-Israel face pressure to assimilate to Israeli culture. This particular pressure may be more acutely felt by members of the Beta-Israel due to racial differences (see Ethiopian Jews in Israel: A Part of the People or Apart From the People? Steven Kaplan, Hagar Salamon). Given that Israeli-culture is generically secular leaning, this may culminate in lax observance of halakhah. This is not necessarily a conscious and active rejection of halakhah but rather simply a sliding into what is "comfortable" given the societal pressures.

Place this tendency in conjunction with the fact that this community has had its own traditions for at least a few hundred years (see The Beta Israel Falasha in Ethiopia: From Earliest Times to the Twentieth Century, ch. 3), it is natural that if/when there is a religious impulse by such individuals it would be expressed in their ancestral way (alongside any other widely practiced Jewish observances that are a part of generic Israeli culture).

To outward appearance, one might crudely claim that the Beta-Israel "don't accept the Talmud" however interpreted to mean an overt rejection of Talmud this is simply not so. As evidence of acceptance of the authority of the Talmud one can also readily point to counter-examples of Beta-Israel that are fully halakhically observant, and those that are furthermore enthusiastic members of the rabbinate itself (Rabbi Reuben Wabashat, Rabbi Sharon Shalom, etc.).

If it is the Hakham's claim that their community (or even select members) actively rejects the Talmud (as opposed to your characterization in the comments of "individuals [who] will do what they will just as large swathes of 'Rabbinical Jews' are not orthopraxic") that is something that would require substantiation. Otherwise it is no more than a broad slur against a community that already struggles.

title: Do Fruits of Israel (dates grown and packed in Israel) require or have a special blessing?
content:
# Do Fruits of Israel (dates grown and packed in Israel) require or have a special blessing? ## Frage

Do Fruits of Israel (organic King Solomon dates grown and packed in Israel in Kibbuz Ne´ot Smadar, bought in German Alnatura store in Germany) require or have a special blessing?

Thanks

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

B Berachot 43a

אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב חִסְדָּא לְרַב יִצְחָק: הַאי מִשְׁחָא דַאֲפַרְסְמוֹן מַאי מְבָרְכִין עִלָּוֵיהּ? אָמַר לֵיהּ, הָכִי אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה: "בּוֹרֵא שֶׁמֶן אַרְצֵנוּ". אָמַר לֵיהּ: בַּר מִינֵּיהּ דְּרַב יְהוּדָה דַּחֲבִיבָא לֵיהּ אֶרֶץ יִשְׂרָאֵל, לְכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא מַאי? אָמַר לֵיהּ: הָכִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: "בּוֹרֵא שֶׁמֶן עָרֵב".

Rav Ḥisda said to Rav Yitzḥak: This balsam oil, what blessing does one recite over it? Rav Yitzḥak said to him, this is what Rav Yehuda said: One recites: Who creates the oil of our land, as balsam only grew in Eretz Yisrael, in the Jordan valley. Rav Ḥisda said to him: Except for Rav Yehuda, for whom Eretz Yisrael was extremely beloved and who therefore mentioned it in his blessing, what blessing does everyone else recite over balsam oil? He said to him: This is what Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One recites: Who creates pleasant oil.

title: Does oral Torah contradict the Torah on cross-dressing?
content:
# Does oral Torah contradict the Torah on cross-dressing? ## Frage

Deuteronomy 22:5 appears to say that no one is allowed to wear the other gender’s clothes. However the Talmud and Rashi say that this only applies if it is part of some kind of scheme to engage in unchastity. This seems unnecessary given that that’s banned in general. Cross-dressing is also explicitly allowed on Purim. But how then can the second part of the verse be true (For everyone doing these things is an abomination to the LORD your God)? How could God say that something is an abomination to Him but then later explicitly tell people that they are allowed to do it?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The interpretation of Rabbis does not contradict the verse. There can be situations when no other dress is available for a man to cover himself and one has to do it out of modesty. Alternatively, during the cossack attacks some Jews used female dress to conceal themselves and save their lives. Certainly, the Torah does not forbid such actions as one has to choose life as it says in Devarim 30:19. Therefore, the Rabbis in Gemara Nazir 59a and Sifrei Devarim 226 treat the general prohibition on cross-dressing for both men and women (כְּלָל) in the first part of the verse to be limited by a specification abomination (פְּרָט) used in the second part of the verse. This is an application of Rule 4 of the 13 principles of Rabbi Yishmael.

Alternatively, as Fred points in the comment, the word כי used in the verse, should not be translated as for/because, due to obvious problems which were noted at the beginning. Rather, one should translate this word as if/when, to inform about cases when the prohibition applies, as stated in Rosh Hashanah 3a,

as Reish Lakish said: The word ki is used in the Bible in four senses: If, perhaps, but, and because.

title: When to assume someone’s a liar
content:
# When to assume someone’s a liar ## Frage

If someone tells you to make up something, for example, (showing that they have no problem lying) and then afterwards they tell you something, do you have to assume it’s a lie?

Example case: you’re reporting sales numbers for your company and your boss tells you to make up something. When you prompt him that that’s not something we should do, he simply responds back with the number of sales you should write. So, do we need to assume that that number he gave is probably false and he just wanted to get you off his back, and thus you wouldn’t be allowed to report it, or can we דן לכף זכות and assume he realized the problem with making up numbers so he indeed told you the real sales numbers?

Another example for clarity: your boss wants you to advertise some deals your company has made and tells you to make up the numbers. You say “do you have any real deals we can use to advertise” and then they respond with whatever numbers and case they write. Do we assume he’s telling the truth or that he just made it up himself to alleviate the other persons worries

Edit: The halachic angle is let’s say in the last case, if we assume the boss is lying and made up the numbers then you would have to refuse to advertise that because it would be geneivat daat and מסייע עוברי עברה, but if we assume he’s telling the truth then all is well

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I'm not paskening anything here, please ask your LOR.

Rabbeinu Yona in Pirkei Avot 1:6 says the following:

"והוי דן את כל האדם לכף זכות. זה מדבר עם אדם שאין יודעין בו אם הוא צדיק ואם הוא רשע. ואם מכירין אותו והוא איש בינוני פעמים עושה רע ופעמים עושה טוב ואם יעשה דבר שיש לדונו לכף חובה ויש לדונו לזכות בשיקול או אפי' (לידי) כפי הנראה נוטה לכף חובה יותר."

"This is speaking about a person about whom we do not know if he is righteous or if he is evil; or if we know that he is a moderate person, sometimes doing evil and sometimes doing good. And if he does something that can make us judge him unfavorably and [also] judge him favorably in our understanding - or even if, (towards) according to what appears, it leans more towards the side of guilt - if he can judge him favorably one should do so."

So according to Rabbeinu Yona in a case (like here) where the person doesn't know the person well, and he seems to lean towards being guilty (since he was about to do something wrong) one should still judge him favorably but is not obligated to.

However, it seems that this case is a bit different because there is an איסור involved here as well, and we do not want to judge someone favorably when there is a potential that we will do an aveirah based on that.

The Mishneh Lamelech Hichot Malveh 4:2, Ben Ish Chai Parashat Shemini אות ב, Shu"t Terumat Hadeshen all say that with regards to the issur of מסייעה if one is בספק, than there is no issur. For example, if guests come over for Shabbat or Yom Tov and you don't know if they will say berachot on the food and drink, one is allowed to give them food and drink.

The Shu”t Pnei Yehoshua Yoreh Deah 3, Shu”t Machaneh Chaim 1:47, Shu”t Beit Yitzchak Orach Chaim 29, Shu”t Yad Yitzchak 3:95 and Shu”t Minchat Yitzchak (3:79) all discuss this is more in length. The Sefer Sharei Torah 2:42 פרט ד also says we are lenient in a case where we are בספק in a case of מסייע.

Therefore it would seem from both Rabbeinu Yona and other poskim that we can be דן לכף זכות in a sense and also be lenient in a case where there is ספק מסייע לדבר עבירה.

title: What does the name of Amalek mean?
content:
# What does the name of Amalek mean? ## Frage

I know there are various etymological methods that scientists use to say "we don't really know where this word comes from" but I'm wondering about what Jewish methods we can apply to understand the name Amalek.

While I am a relatively uneducated Jew, to my eye, עמלק appears to be ayin-prefixed מ-ל-ק which itself seems to be related to מ-ל-ך king.

I don't know much about the individual values of letters but I get this feeling that letters which are visually similar are also often semantically similar. And in this case I see kaf becoming quf as a sort of "corruption" which is compounded by the initial ayin to make Amalek, the word, to me, seem to be essentially a corrupted, twisted version of Melech.

As a modern analogy in case I'm making no sense, considering Amalek to be the nemesis of Israel, I see a situation very similar to Luigi and Waluigi. Or if you imagine a Mr. Kushnir and his evil nemesis Mr. Qoshner.

How does this reasoning compare to other styles of reasoning? Is it okay to read into Amalek in this way? Are there any serious flaws with my thought process? Are there sages who have written on the etymology of this name in a way that concretely answers the question?

As a related question, is there any significance in ayin that I'm not aware of?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The midrashim point to it being a contraction of two words "עם לק" lit. "a people who lick (blood)".

For example, refer to the Yalkut Shimoni 983:

דבר אחר עמלק עם לק שבא ללוק דמן של ישראל ככלב

Alternatively, Amalek is (derived from an amalgam of "עם לק") a people that lick i.e. that come to lick from the blood of Israel like a dog.

Famously, from a gematriah (numerical) perspective, the Hebrew word "עמלק" equates to the Hebrew word "ספק" - "doubt" as they help to sow the seeds of confusion and discord.

Also refer to @Fred's answer here who sources from Rav Schneur Zalman of Liadi who...

breaks the name of the nation into component words "עם מלק" ("'am malak") meaning "severed nation" in that the nation's metaphysical brain and heart are severed at the neck.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The interpretation עם מלק can also refer to the death of Eisav (separation of intellect and emotion), when Hushim ben Dan hit his head and it separated from Eisav's body. It is a reference to the process of melikah when a kohen separates a head of a bird with his nail during a sacrifice (Vayikra 1:15). One can use this idea to explain why G-d make Yaakov's neck strong like marble when Eisav sought to bite his neck.

I also heard, in the name of R. Gedalia Schorr, that Amaleq can also be read עמל קוף - monkey labor, i.e. the nation that does not produce anything, imitates labor activity, and lives off stealing and preying on its neighbors. (For example, all types of socialist regimes need periodic wars because their economy is not efficient enough to sustain).

title: Kunteres Acharon on Shulchan Aruch Harav

title: How could the patriarchs have observed the ritual commandments?
content:
# How could the patriarchs have observed the ritual commandments? ## Frage

The Sources says that the patriarchs and those they taught followed halacha.¹

There are two types of commandments: Ethical and ritual. I understand that the ethical commandments could have been derived by logical thinking, and also from the Noahide laws that had already been given before the patriarchs. But how could the patriarchs possibly have derived the ritual commandments? The Midrash says that Lot even observed Pessah, long before the Exodus [Genesis Rabbah 48:12]! How could they be prescient of Purim, Hanukkah, Pessah, etc., and in particular their specific dates? Or shaatnez, Shema, tzitzit, tefillin, taharat hamishpacha, etc.? Any commentaries on this question?

Some say that the ritual commandments were revealed to Abraham supernaturally. Let me add then: What is the benefit in him observing them, thereby revealing to all those around him (through the holidays) what the future will be?

¹Sources:

עֵ֕קֶב אֲשֶׁר־שָׁמַ֥ע אַבְרָהָ֖ם בְּקֹלִ֑י וַיִּשְׁמֹר֙ מִשְׁמַרְתִּ֔י מִצְוֺתַ֖י חֻקּוֹתַ֥י וְתוֹרֹתָֽי׃
Because Abraham obeyed my voice, and kept my charge, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws. [Genesis 26:5]

Abraham our Patriarch fulfilled the entire Torah, even the mitzvah of the joining of cooked foods, as it is stated: "Torotai My Torahs". [Since the term is in the plural, it indicates that Abraham kept two Torahs:] one, the Written Torah, and one, the Oral Torah. [Yoma 28b]

Jacob observed Shabbat before it was given. [Bereshit Rabbah 79:7]

Based on their intuitions, the Patriarchs kept mitzvot and observed Shabbat [Peninei Halakhah, Shabbat 1:3:2]

...opinions offered by the Talmud and subsequent scholars that the patriarchs observed even minutiae of later rabbinical ordinances. [Rabbeinu Bahya, Bereshit 26:5:4]

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Many Rabbonim discuss this question. The common answer is that Avraham could sense the mitzvot from the very sensitivity his great and lofty soul had towards spirituality. His "kidneys" counselled him to order to figure out all of the mitzvot. There is that famous Rashi about how Avraham kept Pesach etc.

This is explained in the Zohar to mean that the Jewish soul has 613 "limbs", each corresponding to a Mitzva. Avraham could sense this through his sensitivity and emunah. This even applied to "chukim" and ritualistic commandments, even edut; mitzvot that pertain to an event that hadn't even happened yet, like Pesach.

Sources so far: Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer 26 with Radal (who also brings Nedarim 32a), cf. Sefer HaYashar 24. Also, Ben Ish Chai Rav Pealim 4, Malbim on Bereshit 22:4.

He also learned in the home of Noach and the Yeshiva of Shem (see Y JD's answer, both of whom were very holy tzaddikim, who had extensive knowledge from angels, nevua and sefarim passed down from previous generations, even going back to Adam. Finally, he also learned with Gavriel the angel.

Sources: Sefer HaYashar pp. 24-25, Yalkut Meam Loez, Maaseh Avraham (from Otzar Midrashim 1, pp.3-4, 6). Please see Dov's answer for more sources for my points, as well as another, important way that Avraham learned about the mitzvot

As for what is the benefit, I am not sure the question is particularly compelling because it has an obvious answer: for the reward. Otherwise, for more nuance, one could look into the status of Avraham as a Jew - many hold, such as Parashat Derachim, that he became a fully fledged Jew the moment he dedicated himself to serving Hashem at which point he became obligated in the mitzvot.

See this Rosh David (by the Chida), which brings lots of opinions, in his discussion on why Avraham waited until age 99 to perform the Brit Milah. It even brings an opinion that he was a "partially obligated Jew", and therefore had to avoid the aveirot, but wasn't obligated in the positive mitzvot, which he either did voluntarily (for the reward, the tikkun, etc), or waited until he was commanded (such as the Brit Milah).

As for "revealing the future", that would make it's own (great imo) question.

I recommend trying to get hold of the work "Avraham Avinu", the Elzas Edition by R Chaim Zvi Noyek, which like the "Let my nation" series, works through all the midrashim and tells the story of Avraham, and it contains extensive footnotes and appendices.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

There are several sources about this.

Like @Rabbi_Kaii mentioned about the kidneys, note the Avos DeRabbi Nosson 33:1:

ולא היה אחד מהם שיהלך בדרכי הקב״ה עד שבא אברהם אבינו והלך בדרכי הקב״ה שנא׳ (בראשית כ״ו:ה׳) עקב אשר שמע אברהם בקולי וגו' (וכי תורה אחת שמר והלא תורות הרבה שמר) אלא מלמד שזימן הקב״ה לאברהם אבינו ב׳ כליותיו כשני חכמים והיו מבינות אותו ויועצות אותו ומלמדות אותו חכמה כל הלילה שנא׳ (תהילים ט״ז:ז׳) אברך את ה׳ אשר יעצני אף לילות יסרוני כליותי

and there was not one among them who walked in the ways of the Holy Blessed One until Abraham our forefather came along, and he walked in the ways of the Holy Blessed One, as it says (Genesis 26:5), “Because Abraham heeded My call [and kept My charge, My commandments, My rules, and My Torahs.]” (But there is only one Torah! How could he have kept Torahs, plural?) This teaches that the Holy Blessed One planted two inner voices (lit. kidneys) in Abraham, like two wise men, who helped him understand, advised him, and taught him wisdom all night long, as it says (Psalms 16:7), “I will bless the Eternal who has advised me. Even at night, the voices inside of me [lit., my kidneys] have admonished me.”

As also has been mentioned, Avraham maintained a relationship with Malkitzedek/Shem where he learnt Torah. Refer to the posuk in Bereishis 14:18 where one view in Bereishis Rabbah 43:6 writes:

וְרַבָּנָן אָמְרֵי תּוֹרָה גִּלָּה לוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (משלי ט, ה): לְכוּ לַחֲמוּ בְלַחְמִי וּשְׁתוּ בְּיַיִן מָסָכְתִּי

The Rabbis say: He revealed Torah [precepts] to him, as it is stated: “Come, partake of my bread, and drink of the wine that I have mixed” (Proverbs 9:5).

At the heart of it was his relationship with Hashem. All the avos spoke exclusively with Hashem (refer to Midrash HaGadol 17:22 which notes that when G-d spoke to them he did so exclusively without the Chayos or Merkavah etc.). Indeed note the Pesikta DeRav Kahana 5 which writes that Hashem showed Avraham four things - one of which was Torah (the other three being Korbanos, Gehennom and the Four Kingdoms - Bavel, Paras, Yavan and Edom).

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

Extending the answer of Rabbi Kaii, we know that Shem was Melchizedek of Salem the priest of G-d most high (Bereshis 14:18). We also have Bereshis Rabba 46:5,

Rabbi Yishmael says: Abraham was a High Priest, as it is stated: “The Lord has taken an oath and will not renounce it: You are a priest forever…” (Psalms 110:4), and it is stated elsewhere: “You shall circumcise the flesh of your orla” (Genesis 17:11). [Abraham wondered,] from where should he become circumcised? If he would become circumcised from the ear, he would be unfit to perform sacrifices; if from the mouth, he would be unfit to perform sacrifices; if from the heart, he would be unfit to perform sacrifices. From where could he become circumcised and still be fit to sacrifice? You must say, it is the orla of the body.

Therefore, one has to conclude that Avraham either learned the ritual law from Noach, Shem, and Ever or / and it was revealed to him as a covenant of Bris Millah.

There is a dual purpose of the ritual law. It was a vehicle to "get closer" to Hashem, i.e. to develop attachment, deveikus. At the time of Abraham all religions were based on active practice of ritual laws, which had strong symbolism and certainly Judaism also had to have such a vehicle to attract a following in opposition to Egypt, Bavel, K'naan, which all had developed religions with epic texts detailing rituals. Additionally, the ritual law can be used as means of kapparah to erase the aftereffect of sins that one could have done.

title: How is it possible that man can sometimes dissuade HaShem if HaShem's will cannot be changed and He knows best?
content:
# How is it possible that man can sometimes dissuade HaShem if HaShem's will cannot be changed and He knows best? ## Frage

For example, G-d wanted to annihilate the Israelites in ch. 32 of Shemot and yet, Moshe was able to change G-d's mind. This happens again Bamidbar 14. Yet, we see in Bamidbar 23 that G-d is not a man that He changes His mind, and it is often affirmed in Judaism that G-d always knows and does what's best. If that's the case, how can He be at times dissuaded, by a human being, no less?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The idea that Hashem does not change is very misunderstood. Rocks never change, statues never change. Of course this does not apply to Hashem, chas veshalom. Pretty much the main message of the Torah is that He is not a statue!

What it actually means is that He is perfect in every form of perfection, and cannot improve. He cannot become more patient, more just, more kind, more wise, more knowledgable etc. He is already the most patient, just, kind, wise and knowledgable possible - perfect in all forms of perfection!

So, if we ask His opinion on any matter, His opinion is also perfect, and will never change*! If He did change His opinion, that means His original opinion was not perfect. There was some flaw in His wisdom, His knowledge, His kindness etc, and it was pointed out, so He rectified it, and reanalysed and came up with a new opinion as a result, chas veshalom. So no, His opinions are perfect, and can never change.

Therefore, if we see Him have a new opinion on the same matter, the only possibility is that it's not actually the same matter. The matter has changed, and hence we are now hearing His opinion on this new matter.

For example, Hashem says "salachti kidvarecha" i.e. "I forgive you, because of your words", by the sin of the spies (Bamidbar 14:20). What changed? Moshe apologised, prayed, and thus the situation itself changed. Hashem's opinion didn't change about the same situation, but now that the situation changed, Hashem revealed a new opinion. When it comes to "sins of spies", if nobody apologises, Hashem's opinion is that they should be destroyed. If someone does apologise, His opinion is to spread the anger over many generations and galuyot, ultimately not destroying all but preserving a remnant - see Rabbeinu Bachaye on ibid 17**. This is also true of the incident with Moshe and the Chet HaEgel; see Rashi and Ramban on Shemot 32:10. Ramban reads עתה הניחה לי ויחר־אפי בהם ואכלם "leave me and I will pour my anger on them and destroy them" as "if you leave me and do not pray, then I will, but through your prayer, [which will change the situation] I will 'repent' and not destroy them".

This is really not too hard to understand. When my child does something very insolent, it makes me angry and feel he deserves to be punished, because I feel like he doesn't understand how wrong it is. However, if he apologises, he surprises me - turns out he did know how wrong it was. Suddenly I don't want to punish him anymore, in fact I want to reward him. Did I change my mind? No, I still agree that punishing him would have been right, if he didn't know what was wrong with what he did. It's just that I don't believe that anymore, because turns out it was never true. I "changed my mind", but I really didn't. The situation was different.

The truth is, humans do change their mind, because we are fallible. We can gain wisdom and knowledge, and lose it, and therefore make mistakes (like I did with my kid, above). We can be patient one day, and not the next. Our kindness goes up and down, as does our justice. If we are in the wrong mood, we punish, if we are in the right mood, we forgive. The lesson here is that this is not true of Hashem. He is always true, always patient, always perfectly kind and just. He can't gain knowledge or wisdom, nor lose it. Therefore His opinions are also all perfect, and do not change on a whim or a mood. If we see Hashem change His mind, look closer - He didn't, the situation changed.

There are tons of sources on this from all angles; Chakira (see Sefer HaIkkarim 4:18), Kabbalah (see Nefesh Hachaim 2:11), Chassidus (see Derech Mitzvotecha Ha'amanut Elokut 5-6***) and Mussar (see Michtav Me'Eliyahu, Volume IV, pages 79–81). This question is very related: If Hashem doesn't change, how does prayer work?, as are many many questions on this site. Just do a quick search for Hashem change, God change etc.

* if someone wishes to argue that there might be some interesting cases where there are 2 or more "perfect" opinions about the same thing, that would make for an interesting question its own right :)
** This source actually gives us an explanation on how to "change Hashem's mind" about something, i.e. exactly how to apologise, the right way, for the right sin, which Hashem taught Moshe at Sinai via the 13 Middot Rachamim
*** I would say this source is the clearest, and most detailed source for the main point of my answer, and strongly recommend it!

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

I think the distinction is that Hashem has an ultimate plan or objective which must come to pass, and this plan we cannot alter, however we can alter the way in which it plays out.

For example we daven that he forgive us; “אבל לא על ידי יסורים וחלים רעים, not by way of inflicting us with tragedy and sickness”. Rather, he figure out some other “less painful” way to forgive us.

So it’s clear that we can affect the method he uses to carry out his plans. However, I don’t think the Torah insinuates anywhere that we have the ability to change his ULTIMATE plans (for indeed they are good and perfect. Why would we want to?).

Hashem created the world with rules that even he abides by. Sometimes those rules allow us room to squirm in to his schemes, and sometimes it’s those very rules that make his actions solidified and unchangeable.

title: Why Did Ramban Write His Own Commentary on Massekhet Nedarim Instead of Annotating the Rif’s Commentary?
content:
# Why Did Ramban Write His Own Commentary on Massekhet Nedarim Instead of Annotating the Rif’s Commentary? ## Frage

Why did Ramban write a commentary on Massekhet Nedarim that closely follows the general approach of the Rif, even though there was already a commentary on the Rif he could have annotated directly?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

The printed work attributed to the Rif on Nedarim isn't actually by the Rif. Rabbi Yaakov Chayyim Sofer gives the following proofs (Tzefunot 7 p. 77, which I found quoted here):

  • The Ramban wouldn't have authored his own Halachot if the Rif had already done so. Since he made extensive research to interpret the Rif and even checked the Rif's autograph, it couldn't be that he simply didn't have a copy of the Rif on an entire tractate if it existed.

  • None of the early rishonim mention the Rif on Nedarim.

  • What is known of the Rif doesn't align with the work on Nedarim. A citation of the Rif in the Tur doesn't appear in the printed Rif on Nedarim, and the Rashba says the Rif omitted something that does appear in the printed Rif on Nedarim.

title: I’m 13 and I’m interested in Judaism. (Reform)
content:
# I’m 13 and I’m interested in Judaism. (Reform) ## Frage

My name is Charlie, and for a long time, since sixth grade, I’ve been heavily interested in Judaism. I’m not looking to convert just yet. I wanna wait till I’m a full adult. But I have some questions and fears.

I have extremely unsupportive parents. I wanted to celebrate Yom Kippur, but I can’t go to a synagogue. I’m also not good at cooking, and I don't think my mom wants me celebrating Hanukkah either because even though she said she would buy me a menorah, she keeps talking about Christmas around me to mock me. It hurts a lot. :( I feel so hopeless, and I have no support groups or Jewish friends to help me. I feel so invalid and fake, and it hurts so much.

How can a person in my situation learn and practice more Judaism?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Most rabbis will not convert a minor, especially without parental approval or permission. Use these years to privately learn anything you can about our beautiful faith. Here’s a good website to start you off: My Jewish Learning.

There are some Reform and Conservative synagogues that livestream their services. Some of these livestreams are available to the public online; others are private and require you to contact the rabbi to gain access. Just Google “synagogue livestream”.

Opening a line of communication with your local rabbi would be a good idea. Be sure to explain your situation and desire to learn. Though you can’t convert right now, perhaps the rabbi would be able to send you some helpful resources to stimulate your growth in the meantime.

Familiarize yourself with the Seven Laws of Noah. You don’t have to be Jewish to worship and follow the Creator.

Finally, the community here on Mi Yodeya is ready to answer any questions you may have. Be sure to utilize the search function to ensure there is not already an existing question.

Good luck in your journey, and may God always guide you throughout your life!

title: How to deal with non-Jews claiming to be Jews?
content:
# How to deal with non-Jews claiming to be Jews? ## Frage

I ask this because I know this fellow who claims to be a Jew. He was notorious for so many things back in high school and some time after graduation, he came out as a bisexual and fell out with his high school friends as a result.

I reached out to him and talked with him about Judaism, particulalry his observance (or lack thereof.) Then he revealed to me that he is actually Messianic. He still considers himself a "Jew" even though he is not devout (to his faith). I confronted him that he should stop calling himself a Jew because he objectively is not one but he unfortunately persists.

The worst part about this is that I can only imagine the negative perceptions he may have conjured or even reinforced about Jews among those who are under the impression that he is a Jew and also know of his notoriety. I tried mitigating this by talking to some of his former pals back in high school, explaining to them that he is not a Jew, but a messianic. Unfortunately, they, perhaps out of antisemitism, seem to persist in regarding him as a Jew.

How does one deal with a situation like this, where a gentile falsely claims to be a Jew and gives Jews a bad name as a result of his terrible behavior?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Okay, so this is definitely a Christian who is not halakhically Jewish, but they think they are a Jew. Been there! Keep in mind that this is not a person deliberately trying to bug us. They are simply in the dark, so they deserve our patience.

I don't think there is any formula that guarantees success, but I will share what I myself would do.

I would find a time that I catch them alone, like we are out for coffee or kicking back at home. That way there is no embarrassment on their part when you correct them. Then very tactfully and in a kind voice let them know the you are concerned that they don't understand what a Jew is. Explain that it is Jewish Law that sets the rules, and the rules are that you either have a Jewish mom or you have made a formal conversion to Judaism.

Assure them that there is nothing wrong with being non-Jewish; that the reason we don't proselytize is that no one really needs to be a Jew.

Then suggest that on rare occasions someone might have such a great affinity for the People of Israel that they do want to join us, even though it means observing 613 laws. Say something like, "No pressure of course, but if you ever do feel like you are interested in something like that, let me know, and I'll be happy to help."

It is possible that even if you do this with all the tact in the world, that they may still feel offended because of x, y, or z. For example, someone in their group may have told them they are a Jew and they trust that person. Or they may simply think they know better than you.

At that point you will need to gauge things for yourself. How much do you want to push this? Or is it better to simply let it slide since you almost never see the person? Only you can be the judge at that point.

I wish you all the best luck in this! If you can, let us know how it went.'

Shalom.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Before I give any advice, I just would like to clarify.

It sounds from your post that this is someone who is not halakhically a Jew, aka his mother is not a Jew. But he thinks because he attends a Messianic "Judaism" Christian Church that this makes him a Jew. Is this the case?

A second possibility is that this is a person who is halakhically Jewish, but was not raised Jewish, and doesn't know any better, and has been hoodwinked into thinking that this Christian Church is an appropriate expression of his Yiddishkeit. I believe such a person is seen as a "captured child," not fully responsible for their actions.

And a third possibility is that it is a case of true apostasy.

I think in all cases, the person should be treated compassionately, but there would obviously be differences in what you might say.

I'll wait for your clarification before I reply further.

title: Why does the Gemara in Bava Kamma seemingly ignore the fact that the Melachah is being done with a Shinuy?
content:
# Why does the Gemara in Bava Kamma seemingly ignore the fact that the Melachah is being done with a Shinuy? ## Frage

The Gemara (Bava Kamma 26b) brings a case where someone had a stone in his lap, and he either forgot or did not realize that it was in his lap, and when he got up the stone was flung out of his lap, and the Gemara says that with regards to the laws of damages he would be liable, but with regards to Shabbos he would be exempt for any Melachah that was caused by the stone.

My question is: with regards to the laws of Shabbos, why does it matter that he forgot or did not realize that he had the stone in his lap - wouldn’t he be exempt even if he did know that it was in his lap, being that the Melachah was done with a Shinuy?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Dayan Padwa addresses this in Ohr Yisroel 3:3 (Nissan 5758), p. 41. (The context is a discussion about a case where one didn't disconnect the refrigerator light before Shabbos, whether he may ask a fellow Jew who doesn't know that to open the refrigerator.)

First he cites R. Akiva Eiger (Teshuvos, no. 8), that the Gemara wanted to make the point that where there's no meleches machsheves (intent to perform the melachah), then by definition there's no melachah at all (unlike if he had been misasek, intending to perform the action but with something where the melachah is inapplicable, where it would be considered a melachah, just an inadvertent (beshogeg) one).

But then R. Padwa goes on to note that in essence, meleches machsheves (or lack thereof) is a broad category that includes misasek, mekalkel (performing a melachah for a destructive purpose) and kil'achar yad (doing the melachah in a non-normal manner, as in your questiopn), so that the Gemara may simply be mentioning that general category.

title: Is there a Pidyon HaBen for the first child of a daughter of a Kohen who was adopted by a non-Kohen?
content:
# Is there a Pidyon HaBen for the first child of a daughter of a Kohen who was adopted by a non-Kohen? ## Frage

If a daughter of a kohen was adopted by an Israelite family when she was young, does her male firstborn child require pidyon haben?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

As a general rule, the answer is yes. Since she is the biological daughter of a Cohen, her firstborn, if it's a male, is exempt from Pidyon Haben.

Being adopted has no bearing on her priestly pedigree.

However, as discussed here, there are cases that would nullify the exemption. Specifically, if she had relations with a non-Jew prior to having her first child, then her firstborn would be required to have a Pidyon Haben.

title: Going beyond the letter of the law: the comment of the Shita Mekubetzes
content:
# Going beyond the letter of the law: the comment of the Shita Mekubetzes ## Frage

The Shita Mekubetzes on Bava Metzia 24b writes:

למי שאינו כל כך אדם חשוב דלא מחייבינן ליה לעשות לפנים משורת הדין

This applies to someone who is not such an important person, for whom we do not obligate to go beyond the letter of the law.

The Shita Mekubetzes, citing Rabbeinu Yehonsan, explains that a person of distinction, by virtue of his stature, is halachically obligated to go beyond the letter of the law (לפנים משורת הדין) (ArtScroll-translation).

However, aren't we meant to go beyond the letter of the law, even when we are benonim and not tzadikkim per se (as per the Bartenura) here.

What exactly does this Shita Mekubetzes mean? And how to reconcile it with the explanation of Avos and the Bartenura there? Isn't it the best way to act לפנים משורת הדין?

title: how to pronounce ריש גלותא
content:
# how to pronounce ריש גלותא ## Frage

I always thought was pronounced "galuta".

However I just noticed in my sidur today in יקום פורקן , the words there are "reshei galvata".

Is that just the plural of "galuta"? Or have I been pronouncing it wrong all along?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 13)

When referring to a singular galus, it is pronounced גָּלוּתָא; see e.g. Daniel 2:25: ״מִן בְּנֵי גָלוּתָא״.

When referring to exiles in the plural, it is pronounced גַּלְוָתָא. (Compare Daniel 6:8: ״לְגֹב אַרְיָוָתָא״)

title: Usage of פגרים in Parashat Lech-Lecha
content:
# Usage of פגרים in Parashat Lech-Lecha ## Frage

In the Brit bein haBetarim (the sixth 'aliyah in Lech-Lecha), the following verse (Gen. 15:11) occurs, with a mystifying uncommon word.

וַיֵּ֥רֶד הָעַ֖יִט עַל־הַפְּגָרִ֑ים וַיַּשֵּׁ֥ב אֹתָ֖ם אַבְרָֽם׃

And the bird of pray fell upon the carcasses and Avram shooed them away.

The word פגר ("carcass", "corpse") rarely occurs in Chumash, the only other time which comes to mind being in Parashat Shelach, where Hashem curses the Dor HaMidbar to die in the dessert. As such, it's a somewhat mystifying usage here, since in no other place is it used to refer to an offering to Hashem.

I checked the commentaries to which I had access* and no one among them addresses the choice of word.

Do any traditional sources address the usage of the word פגר in this context, as opposed to another word ?

*I had access to a Torat Chaim, which includes R' Saadia's Tafsir (translated into Hebrew), Rashi, Ibn 'Ezra, Rashbam, Chizkuni, and Ramba"n. I may have forgotten someone

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Bereishis Rabbah 44:16:

אָמַר רַבִּי עֲזַרְיָה לִכְשֶׁיֵּעָשׂוּ בָנֶיךָ פְּגָרִים בְּלֹא גִּידִים וַעֲצָמוֹת, זְכוּתְךָ עוֹמֶדֶת לָהֶן

Said R. Azariah: [G-d was telling Avraham,] "When your children will become carcasses, lacking sinews and bones (without any mitzvos or merits - Matnos Kehunah; without any strength or rescue - Etz Yosef), your merit will stand them in good stead."

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

There are 22 usages of the word פגר in Tanach in the meaning "dead bodies or carcasses" according to the Concordance by Abraham Even-Shoshan. A total of 5 can be found in the Torah, in addition to your examples also Bamidbar 14:29, 14:32, and 14:33 when the punishment for believing the report of the spies was announced.

According to the Etymological Dictionary of Biblical Hebrew by R. Matityhu Clark, the root פגר has meaning abandon, divorce from active life. In addition to the meaning "corpse, carcass", it is also used as "being sluggish" i.e. not so lively (Shmuel A 30:10, 30:21).

title: Why was Sara informed about having a baby just months before she would've found out on her own?
content:
# Why was Sara informed about having a baby just months before she would've found out on her own? ## Frage

In Parshas Vayeira, a Malach told Avraham that he and Sara will have a baby in a year. But Sara was anyway going to find out about the baby several months later, when she would realize the pregnancy. So why was it so important for Hashem to inform Sara several months before she would've found out on her own?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The news about Sarah's pregnancy were given to Avraham on the day he was commanded to have bris millah. The angels visited him on either the same day or one the 3rd day afterwards. The Torah Bereshis 18:11 states that Sarah could no longer have children (also see Rashi):

Now Abraham and Sarah were old, advanced in years; Sarah had stopped having her periods.

Note that this verse is out of order (see syntactic rule here) since its subject precedes the verb which is in the simple past tense (קל). Immediately prior to the verse (i.e. after the verse chronologically), once the angels came, Rashi on Bereshis 18:8 states

ויקח חמאה וגו AND HE TOOK חמאה, ETC. — but he (Avraham) did not bring bread, on account of Sarah becoming mentstruant; as the 'way of women' returned to her that day, and the dough became impure (Bava Metzia 87a).

Therefore, the angels informed Sarah immediately once they cured her so that she could conceive. Informing her prophetically prior to that could also suggest to her that she might be giving birth unnaturally, which would put her life in big danger and add unnecessary stressful feelings. Also, we see that both Sarah's ability to conceive and the news of her upcoming pregnancy and giving birth and were contingent on Avraham passing the test of bris millah.

title: What was Lot doing in the city gates of Sodom on Pesach night?
content:
# What was Lot doing in the city gates of Sodom on Pesach night? ## Frage

The Torah says the angels came to Sedom at night (Bereishis 19:1), which was the night of Pesach (see Rashi 19:3), yet Lot was sitting by the city gates at that time. What was he doing there? (Wouldn't he have been making a Seder with matzah in his home?)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

You asked:

Wouldn't he have been making a Seder with matzah in his home?

The Or HaChaim HaKadosh explains that Lot did not observe the Torah and its mitzvos as Avraham Avinu did:

The correct meaning of the verse is that while Lot prepared a meal for them the angels ate only matzot. This was because Lot did not observe the commandments of the Torah as did Abraham.

So, according to this, he wouldn't have been making a Seder.

Interestingly, the Chizkuni writes that his house was at the gates of the city, and he sat there judging:

ולוט יושב בשער סדום, while Lot was seated (as a judge) in the public square of Sodom;” this was at the time when the quarrel about his guests broke out and he returned home, which was close to the gate of the city.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

According to Chazal (Bava Metzia 86b, and cited in Rashi 18:1), the angels visited on the third day from Avraham’s bris milah.

Avraham’s bris, according to Rabbi Eliyahu Mizrachi’s interpretation of Rashi, took place on Erev Pesach, and the angels visited either on the third day of Pesach or in the afternoon of the first day. In either case, the angels did not arrive at Lot’s house on the seder night. This is why, instead of ובכן ויהי בחצי הלילה, on the second night of Seder we sing ובכן ואמרתם זבח פסח, which mentions the story of Lot in the 3rd stanza:

זוֹעֲמוּ סְדוֹמִים וְלוֹהֲטוּ בָּאֵשׁ בַּפֶּסַח, חֻלַּץ לוֹט מֵהֶם וּמַצּוֹת אָפָה בְּקֵץ פֶּסַח, טִאטֵאתָ אַדְמַת מוֹף וְנוֹף בְּעָבְרְךָ בַּפֶּסַח. וַאֲמַרְתֶּם זֶבַח פֶּסַח.

The men of Sodom raged and burned in fire on Pesaḥ. Lot was saved; he baked matzot at the end of Pesaḥ (i.e. end of 1st day of Pesaḥ). You swept bare the land of Mof and Nof [Egypt] in Your great rage on Pesaḥ. TELL [your children]: “THIS IS THE PESAH.”

title: How can missionary arguments about free will be refuted?
content:
# How can missionary arguments about free will be refuted? ## Frage

In light of the fact that the majority of Christians including Catholics and Orthodox believe in predestination, as does Islam (in fact, one of Antony Flew's ("the world's most famous atheist") biggest reasons for being an atheist was that he correctly realized that if God exists He would be controlling everyone):

I recently came across the following on chabad.org:

QUESTION: "If everything is predetermined by G‑d, then how should we live?" ANSWER: As it is said, "Everything is in the hand of G-d except the fear of G‑d." There is much that is pre-determined - but not our moral choices. You would have realized this for yourself if you had pushed your questioning one step further, that is: If everything is predetermined by G‑d, then how can He reward us or punish us? The only possible answer is that those aspects in our lives which incur reward or punishment are not under the control of destiny; they are truly free choices.

And this idea has serious support. For example, Rashi commenting on Sotah 2a says:

“Do they in fact pair them up according to wickedness and merit? But before their formation, when his wickedness and meritoriousness are not known, they announce his match. And if you'll ask that everything is revealed before God, [the answer is that] everything is in the hands of Heaven except for fear of Heaven. As is stated in Tractate Niddah: "the angel appointed over pregnancy takes a drop and brings it before the Omnipresent and says before Him, 'what will be with this drop? Strong or weak? Wise or foolish? Rich or poor?'" But he does not say to Him 'righteous or wicked', since that is not in the hands of Heaven.”

And Maimonides clearly held this view as well:

“However, this is known without any doubt: That man's actions are in his [own] hands and The Holy One, blessed be He, does not lead him [in a particular direction] or decree that he do anything” (Hilchot Teshuva 5:5).

“if we should say that God had destined that this sum should pass into the hands of the one and out of the possession of the other, God would be preordaining an act of iniquity" (Eight Chapters 8:6).

"In making this assertion that obedience or disobedience to the Law of God does not depend upon the power or will of God, but solely upon that of man himself, the sages followed the dictum of Jeremiah, who said, "Out of the mouth of God there cometh neither the bad nor the good". By the words "the bad" he meant vice, and by "the good", virtue; and, accordingly, he maintains that God does not preordain that any man should be vicious or virtuous" (Eight Chapters 8:7).

"It now remains for us to explain another phase of this problem, which arises from the fact that there are several Scriptural passages in which some think they find proof that God preordains and forces man to disobedience" (Eight Chapters 8:11).

The Ra'avad responding to Maimonides said:

“If the righteousness and wickedness of a person were dependent on the decree of God, we would say that His knowledge is His decree and we would have the very difficult question. But now that God has removed this dominion from His hand and given it to the hand of man himself, His knowledge is not a decree; rather, it is like the knowledge of the astrologers who know from another source what the ways of this person will be” (Hilchot Teshuva 5:5).

Gersonides held this view and consequently denied that God knows the future:

“[However,] human choice rules over this arrangement of their actions based on the celestial causes. And it is therefore possible that what people actually do is different from what God knew [they would do] based on the arrangement of their actions” (Commentary on Genesis 18).

This view is also strongly implied by the idea that rulers do not have free will, which seems to imply that if they had free will then God would not be in control of what they do. This view is also strongly implied by the idea that you shouldn’t pray to be matched with a specific person. This seems to be based on the notion that if you end up marrying someone because you chose to pray about it using free will then God couldn’t have predestined it. This also seems to imply that free will is outside of God’s control.

However God is the only First Cause which means that He willed everything about the universe including every decision made with free will. Any other view is illogical (and polytheist). So is it OK to say that these commentators acting out of a misguided desire to protect God’s goodness were simply wrong, but it doesn’t matter because Judaism doesn’t have dogmatic teachings about this sort of thing?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

The premise of this question is unfounded. You write "However God is the only First Cause which means that He willed everything about the universe including every decision made with free will. Any other view is illogical (and polytheist)." This claim does not withstand scrutiny.

G-d willed everything in the universe into existence, including a being that can make free choices, Man. That is what "created in in the image of G-d" means. G-d provides Man with multiple options and allows him/her to choose among them. G-d provides Man with the space to make these choices (G-d's will is necessary to effectuate those choices but the choices are Man's).

The Torah expressly states this idea in Deuteronomy 30:15-20.

רְאֵ֨ה נָתַ֤תִּי לְפָנֶ֙יךָ֙ הַיּ֔וֹם אֶת־הַֽחַיִּ֖ים וְאֶת־הַטּ֑וֹב וְאֶת־הַמָּ֖וֶת וְאֶת־הָרָֽע ... וּבָֽחַרְתָּ֙ בַּחַיִּ֔ים לְמַ֥עַן תִּֽחְיֶ֖ה אַתָּ֥ה וְזַרְעֶֽךָ

See I have placed before you live and good and death and evil ... And you should choose life in order that you and your offspring shall live.

You've asserted that this position is illogical and polytheist but have provided no argument to support that position. Moreover, everyone (or nearly so) alive experiences free will on a regular basis.

Isn't it more likely that a universally experienced phenomenon exists and you just don't understand how it works, than it doesn't exist and G-d's just creating an illusion for his automatons to go through life deluding themselves that they can make choices?

### Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

That claim is totally incompatible with Judaism.

Reward and punishment are the result of moral choices. If those choices weren’t ours to make, we wouldn’t get reward or punishment, and thus a fundamental part of Judaism—referenced explicitly a multitude of times in scripture¹—would be impossible. See רמב״ם in משנֶה תורה, הִלְכוֹת תשובה, פרק ה׳ (from ״אִלּו הַאֵל היה גוזר…״).

¹e.g:
Genesis 4:7, קַיְן can make the moral choice to repent;
Leviticus 26:2–45, blessings and curses depend on the explicitly-conditional moral choices of the nation;
Deuteronomy 11:13-28, where the Jews are given a moral decision with its consequences laid out in detailed form, and then (in Parashat Re’eh) in abstract form;
Deuteronomy 30:15–20, where the Jews are given another explicit moral choice in order to mentally prepare them before entering the land;
Joshua 24:14–15, where Joshua tells the Jews to make a moral decision regarding their loyalty to G-D.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

One line answer: the Jewish picture is that we only have free will when it comes to our relationship with God/morality.

In a world where it feels like we have absolutely no control, so many people have been struggling with the concept of free choice.

When we think about it, most of the choices that people make on daily basis are not FREE at all.

They are pragmatic decisions, based on a risk-benefit analysis, influenced by one’s personality and nature.

This is not what we are referring to when we talk about free choice from a Torah perspective.

G-d does not want to control us; He wants us to have independence.

But the only area where our choice really matters is in our relationship with Him.

What He wants is for us to choose Him.

And this is where our free choice lies. Hence, "all is in the hands of heaven, except fear of heaven", i.e. except when it comes to our relationship with Hashem.

See this lecture, "Is G-d Controlling You? The Truth About Our Freedom Of Choice", for more information. Rabbi Friedman's team recently sent this in an email, with the above blurb (which I have edited partially).

title: Yehoshua bin Nun and Yosef

In Sefer Yehoshua chapter 24 it says that Yehoshua lived to be 110 years old, Yosef also lived to be 110 years old. Also Yosef's burial follows Yehoshua's burial. Is there any significance to this?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

יהושע להיותו גלגול יוסף שלא לקח אשת אדוניו לקח עתה את רחב גלגולה ובהיותה מבחינת ירח לכן היה ביריחו (ג"נ אות מ')

title: Why did Hashem wait three days to reveal to Avraham the exact place of the Akeida?
content:
# Why did Hashem wait three days to reveal to Avraham the exact place of the Akeida? ## Frage

In Parshas Vayeira, it says that Hashem revealed to Avraham the exact place of the Akeidah on the third day of Avraham's journey. Rashi explains that Hashem waited three days in order to counter the claims of the Goyim that Avraham didn't have enough time to think about what he was about to do. With three days to ponder, he had a clear mind. My question is, what is significant about three days; would not have been one day enough to counter their claims?

Maybe these three days have some connection to the third day that Hashem visited Avraham at the beginning of the Parsha?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

According to Bereshis Rabba 56:1 there is a merit of the 3rd day, since the Torah was given on the 3rd day, while Rabbi Levi thinks it's the opposite, Avraham's Akkeida set the 3 days significance:

“On the third day, Abraham lifted his eyes, and saw the place from a distance” (Genesis 22:4). “On the third day, Abraham lifted his eyes” – it is written: “He will revive us after two days; on the third day, He will lift us, and we will live before Him” (Hosea 6:2). “On the third day” of the tribes, as it is written: “Joseph said to them on the third day, [do this and you shall live]” (Genesis 42:18). “On the third day” of the spies [sent by Joshua], as it is stated: “You shall hide there three days, […and then go on your way]” (Joshua 2:16). “On the third day” of the giving of the Torah, as it is stated: “It was on the third day” (Exodus 19:16). “On the third day” of Jonah, as it is written: “Jonah was in the innards of the fish three days and three nights” (Jonah 2:1). “On the third day” of those who ascended [to the Land of Israel] from the Diaspora [with Ezra], as it is written: “We remained there three days” (Ezra 8:32). “On the third day” of the revival of the dead, as it is written: “He will revive us after two days; on the third day, He will lift us” (Hosea 6:2). “On the third day” of Esther: “It was on the third day; Esther donned royal raiments [and stood in the courtyard of the king’s house]” (Esther 5:1). She wore the royal raiments of her ancestor’s household. By what merit [did Esther succeed in her mission on the third day]? The Rabbis and Rabbi Levi, the Rabbis say: It was by the merit of the third day on which the Torah was given, as it is stated: “It was on the third day, when it was morning” (Exodus 19:16). Rabbi Levi said: It was due to the merit of the third day of Abraham our patriarch, as it is stated: “On the third day, [Abraham lifted his eyes].”

“And saw the place from a distance” – what did he see? He saw a cloud attached to the mountain. He said: ‘It appears that this is the place where the Holy One blessed be He told me to sacrifice my son.’

In other words, there were many events in the Jewish history that happened on the 3rd day, all of them are tied to either the Sinai revelation or Akkeidah (according to R. Levi). 3 days is usually sufficient time for complete preparation for undertaking an important mission (argument, counter-argument, resolution). Hashem made sure that all of them were done with clear mind and sufficient readiness. Just like Jewish people had to prepare themselves for Matan Torah so they had to prepare in each of the events presented by the midrash.
