title: 4 Babies' Brisim on 4 different days!
content:
# 4 Babies' Brisim on 4 different days! ## Frage

Is there any situation in which 4 different babies can be born within the same 2 hours in the same hospital, without any one them being sick, yet, their Bris is on 4 different days? In other words, each one's Bris will be on a different day than the others,

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

For argument's sake, the 4 babies names are: Baby 1, Baby 2, Baby 3, Baby 4.

Now, let us say that the 4 babies were all born in between 6:00 P.M. and 8:00 P.M. on a Friday night. Let's break this down into steps:

  • Step #1 - Baby 1 is born before Shkia (6:15), so his Bris will be on the following Friday.
  • Step #2 - Baby 2 is born after Tzeis HaKochavim (7:20), so his Bris will be on the following Shabbos.

The rule that you can do a Bris on Shabbos is only when the actual date of the Bris falls out on Shabbos. If a baby is born during Bein HaShmashos (between Shkia & Tzeis HaKoChavim), it is considered as if he was born after Tzeis HaKoChavim. But this is still not his exact date for the Bris, since we aren't completely sure if he was born before or after the next day started. So, if a baby was born on Friday night Bein HashMashos, his Bris will not be on the following Shabbos, since a Bris only pushes off Shabbos if it is the correct date, and this isn't the 100% correct date.

Now, let us say that Shabbos and Sunday are Yom Tov:

  • Step #3 - Baby 3 is born during Bein HashMashos Friday night, and his mother is from Israel, so Sunday is not Yom Tov for them since they only hold of one day Yom Tov. So, his Bris will be in 2 Sundays, since this Bris won't push off Shabbos, so we do it the next Sunday.
  • Step #4 - Baby 4 is born during Bein HashMashos Friday, but his Bris can't be on Shabbos or on Sunday (because it's Yom Tov), so his Bris will be in 2 Mondays.
### Antwort 2 (Score: 7)

They are all non Jews and convert on different days.

title: Is extortion prohibited by the Torah?
content:
# Is extortion prohibited by the Torah? ## Frage

Is extortion prohibited under Torah Law? If so what is the textual source? If not is there a rabbinical prohibition? How does it change in the case of corporate bodies/actors?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Just so we are all on the same page.

Extortion is the practice of obtaining benefit (e.g., money or goods) through coercion. (Wikipedia.)

You asked:

Is extortion prohibited under Torah Law?

Depending on how you define coercion, the answer may be Yes.

If so what is the textual source?

In the 10 commandments. As the Rambam (Laws of Robbery 1:9) codifies:

כָּל הַחוֹמֵד עַבְדּוֹ אוֹ אֲמָתוֹ אוֹ בֵּיתוֹ וְכֵלָיו שֶׁל חֲבֵרוֹ אוֹ דָּבָר שֶׁאֶפְשָׁר לוֹ שֶׁיִּקְנֵהוּ מִמֶּנּוּ וְהִכְבִּיר עָלָיו בְּרֵעִים וְהִפְצִיר בּוֹ עַד שֶׁלְּקָחוֹ מִמֶּנּוּ אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁנָּתַן לוֹ דָּמִים רַבִּים הֲרֵי זֶה עוֹבֵר בְּלֹא תַּעֲשֶׂה שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (שמות כ יד) (דברים ה יח) "לֹא תַחְמֹד". וְאֵין לוֹקִין עַל לָאו זֶה מִפְּנֵי שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה. וְאֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר בְּלָאו זֶה עַד שֶׁיִּקַּח הַחֵפֶץ שֶׁחָמַד. כָּעִנְיָן שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר (דברים ז כה) "לֹא תַחְמֹד כֶּסֶף וְזָהָב עֲלֵיהֶם וְלָקַחְתָּ לָךְ". חִמּוּד שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה: ‏

Translated in Sefaria as:

Anyone who covets a servant, a maidservant, a house or utensils that belong to a colleague, or any other article that he can purchase from him and pressures him with friends and requests until he agrees to sell it to him, violates a negative commandment,even though he pays much money for it, as Exodus 20:14 states: "Do not covet."
The violation of this commandment is not punished by lashes, because it does not involve a deed. One does not violate this commandment until one actually takes the article he covets, as reflected by Deuteronomy 7:25: "Do not covet the gold and silver on these statues and take it for yourself." Implied is that the Hebrew tachmod refers to coveting accompanied by a deed.

Hat tip to Shalom for this.

If not is there a rabbinical prohibition?

Yes. Extortion in the classic sense is forbidden and is called חָמָס in the Talmud. The perp is called a חַמְסַן - chamsan.

The Talmud defines this in Bava Kama 62a:

אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אַדָּא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אַוְיָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: מָה בֵּין גַּזְלָן לְחַמְסָן? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: חַמְסָן – יָהֵיב דְּמֵי, גַּזְלָן – לָא יָהֵיב דְּמֵי. ‏

Translated in Sefaria as:

Rav Adda, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi: Concerning two terms used to describe those who take another’s property against his will, a gazlan (a thief) and a ḥamsan, what is the difference between them? Rav Ashi said to him: A ḥamsan gives money for the article that he takes from its owner, albeit against the owner’s will, whereas a gazlan (a thief) does not give money.

The Shulchan Aruch codifies it as a Rabbinic prohibition. (Choshen Mishpat 34:13):

י"ג. העובר על גזל של דבריהם פסול מדבריהם כיצד (כגון שגזל מציאת חרש שוטה וקטן או) (טור) החמסנים והם הלוקחים קרקע או מטלטלים שלא ברצון הבעלים אע"פ שנותנים הדמים וכן הרועים אחד רועי בהמה דקה ואחד רועי בהמה גסה של עצמם הרי הם פסולים שחזקתן פושטים ידיהם בגזל ומניחים בהמתן לרעות בשדות ובפרדסים של אחרים: ‏

  1. One who violates rabbinical theft is rabbinically disqualified from testifying. How so? If he stole a found-item from one was who deaf, a fool or a minor or if he is a chamsan- one who takes land or movable items without the owner’s permission and pays for it.

Up for discussion: Where is the line between the Rabbinic prohibition and the Torah prohibition? IOW why is this codified as Rabbinic when it seems to be in the 10 commandments?

How does it change in the case of corporate bodies/actors?

I did not find anything explicit either way in the case of corporate bodies/actors.

title: How do the contemporary sources advise that one starts praying shmoneh esrei of shacharit at hanetz hachama?
content:
# How do the contemporary sources advise that one starts praying shmoneh esrei of shacharit at hanetz hachama? ## Frage

I understand that as Halachipedia puts it

The ideal mitzvah is to start praying shmoneh esrei of shacharit at hanetz hachama (sunrise).

Question part 1: How precise does one have to be with the time of hanetz? Even where sunrise is observable, if one is a minute after the computed time (on e.g. Myzmanim.com), is that no longer “starting at hanetz”?

Question part 2: My Rav said that there are opinions that it is better to daven a little after the computed time to be sure that one is not davenning before hanetz hachama.

So please tell how the contemporary sources advise that one starts praying shmoneh esrei of shacharit at hanetz hachama?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The practice of Rav Chaim Kanievsky zt"l according to this book written by his grandsonwas to daven within a few minutes after netz. He held (and so did the Chazon Ish) that that is considered davening at netz.

On a practical note, it isn't really possible to time netz to the second, as it depends on the visibility of the sun, which varies depending on altitude and humidity. (Water causes light to curve, so water molecules in the air can make the sun's light more curvy, meaning it is visible for longer while supposedly being below the horizon. So you would also have to calculate humidity between your position and the horizon.) You would be better off giving it a few minutes so you don't daven too early by mistake. However, b'dieved one would still be yotzei since it is after "alos hashachar".

title: Why didn't Hashem tell Avraham what would happen to Lot?
content:
# Why didn't Hashem tell Avraham what would happen to Lot? ## Frage

We see that Avraham cares for Lot, as is shown in Bereishis perek 14, where Avraham goes after 4 kings in order to save Lot. Why then, when Hashem tells Avraham that He's going to destroy Sodom, doesn't He say that He'll save Lot? Also, why doesn't Avraham ask Hashem what Lot's fate will be?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

I think the answer is that Avraham knew that Hashem would save Lot. Either because Hashem told him and it is just not in the text (because it is not relevant for future generations) or because he saw two angels left for Sodom and if Lot was not being saved, only one angel would have been necessary. See Rashi to Genesis 19:1.

That's why when Avraham prays for Sodom et al to be spared, he does not pray specifically for Lot (who would be saved based on Avraham's merit) but for the cities as a whole.

I am editing my answer to add an additional peshat (explanation). Perhaps the reason Avraham does not daven for Lot is because he has given up on him. Lot first camped near Sodom because he was attracted by its wealth (Bereishis 13:10), despite knowing that Sodom was evil. Then Lot was taken captive because he chose to live in or near evil Sodom. (Bereishis 14:12, Rashi ad loc.) Despite Lot bringing this tragedy upon himself, Avraham risked his life (and his zechusim) to save Lot.

Then what does Lot do as soon as Avraham rescues him? He moves back to Sodom! He even becomes a member of the government. Lot should have moved as far from Sodom as he could. Instead, he ignored the cause of his suffering and went right back to the evil that enticed him the first time.

So why should Avraham daven for him? Why should Avraham ask Hashem for special favors to save Lot? Lot had his chance and chose Sodom.

Indeed, when the Torah (Bereishis 19:29) appears to say that Lot was saved from the merit of Avraham or for the benefit of Avraham, Rashi explains otherwise. Rashi explains that Lot was saved on his own merit for protecting Avraham's secret when they were in Egypt. Why does Rashi feel the need to read the verse differently than the simple reading? Because Avraham was no longer willing to use his merits to save his nephew. He was no longer going to bat for, or defending, Lot.

Indeed, from this point forward Avraham has no connection to Lot in the Torah.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

There can be several answers. According to Rabbi Saadia Gaon on Bereshis 18:32 the 10 righteous people in Sodom were

ד. כסבור היה, שיש בסדום עשרה [צדיקים]: לוט ואשתו, ארבע בנותיו וארבעת חתניו. וראיה לכך, שארבע בנות היו ללוט ממה שנאמר: וידבר אל חתניו לוקחי בנותיו הנשואות, וכשלא יצאו אלה, אמרו לו המלאכים: קח את שתי בנותיך הנמצאות, וחשב אברהם שארבעתן נשואות.

He believed that Sodom had ten [righteous]: Lot and his wife, his four daughters, and four sons-in-law. The proof that Lot had four daughters is from what is said (Gen 19:14) “and he spoke to his sons-in-law, who had married his daughters,” they were married. And when they would not come with him, the angels said to him (Gen 19:15), “take the two daughters who are with you.” But Abraham thought all four of them were married.

This answer means that Hashem told Avraham about Lot. The opinion is contested by Radak on Bereshis 18:32:

לא זכר לו לוט שיצילנו כי חשב שיכלה בכלל הרשעים כיון שנשתקע וישב אצלם ולא היה לו דרך להנצל אם לא יצא מן העיר, גם לא ידע אם היה צדיק או למד ממעשיהם.

And he (Avraham) didn’t mention Lot, to ask for him to be saved, since he thought that he would be destroyed among the wicked, since he assimilated into them and dwelt with them, and he had no way to be saved unless he left the city. [Abraham] didn’t even know whether he (Lot) was still righteous or if he learned from their ways.

We also have Rashi on Bereshis 19:29 (Thanks @Lo ani)

ויזכר אלהים את אברהם GOD REMEMBERED ABRAHAM — What bearing has God’s remembering Abraham upon the rescue of Lot? He remembered that Lot knew that Sarah was Avraham’s wife and that when he heard that Avraham said in Egypt regarding Sarah, “She is my sister”, he did not betray him because he had sympathy with him. For this reason God had mercy upon him (Lot) (Genesis Rabbah 51:6).

The point of this midrash is that treating guests well and making sacrifices for them Lot learned from Avraham. However, keeping silence to save his uncle was a chidush that Lot chose to do on his own. While according to Radak, Avraham did not mention Lot, Avraham certainly gratefully knew about Lot's merit. That could be sufficient for Lot to be saved without having Hashem directly telling Avraham about the Lot's fate.

title: Can one kill lice on Shabbat?
content:
# Can one kill lice on Shabbat? ## Frage

(Inspired by this comment by @Ari)

In [Shabbat 12a], a difference in opinions is brought regarding whether one may kill a louse on Shabbat. The discussion culminates in a debate between בית שמאי and בית הלל, the latter of which, as usual, rules leniently. Since we generally follow the ruling of בית הלל over בית שמאי, it seems the final Halachah is that one may indeed kill a louse of Shabbat.

Later on, in [107b], there is a law described against killing animals on Shabbat. Rashi claims that the reason for lice aren’t included in this prohibition, is because most animals reproduce normally, but lice spontaneously generate.

Considering modern research has proved spontaneous generation a myth, does the Gemarah’s ruling still apply?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The פחד יצחק brings that question, and concludes that we do not. His reasoning is that, had חז״ל been exposed to modern scientific knowledge, they would have recanted their ruling that lice can be killed on Shabbat, and this would in the end be forbidden.

It appears that, at least according to him, we don’t follow Halachot that were based on a now-disproven misunderstanding of חז״ל regarding nature.

title: Source that Sarah laughed because she heard that the bracha for children was only temporary i.e. "You call that a bracha?"
content:
# Source that Sarah laughed because she heard that the bracha for children was only temporary i.e. "You call that a bracha?" ## Frage

In this answer I quote a lecture by Rabbi Manis Friedman, where he explains that Sarah heard that the beracha from the angel was only going to be temporary. Her laughter was a form of protest; a mother praying for and defending her child.

She knew this because a true beracha is meant to be given to the one being blessed, personally, but instead her beracha was actually told to Avraham. The lack of permanence was because of the Akeida - she was right and sensed that her son would die young.

Thus the angel reassured her that he would personally return and ensure that the child would be ok. This very same angel was the one who appeared as Avraham was about to slaughter Yitzchak, and stopped him.

A few more details:

  • She was a greater prophetess than Avraham, which is why she figured it out but he didn't
  • Part of it was also due to the difference. He was a "seer", she was a "hearer". She heard that the beracha was off
  • A similar thing happened with the Shunamit woman, who also heard that her son would die young, from the wording of the beracha: "you will coddle a child". She didn't want to just coddle a child, she wanted him to grow up! So Elisha reassured her that he would personally see to it that he doesn't die young. When he died young, Elisha resurrected him

This is clearly from a sicha or a maamar. I could ask Rabbi Friedman but I would like the answer ASAP, and it takes time for me to get hold of him, and I try not to disturb him for scattered sources if possible. My own Baal Chassidus Rav is on holiday, but I have asked a few others (if they get back to me, I will answer my own question)

So, does anyone know where I can find the (or a) source for these ideas?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Here is the drasha I ended up writing, that answers this question and quotes various sources to back it up:

As we said in Parashat VeZot HaBeracha, each year of our life, we learn something new, deeper and more mature about the events and personalities in the Torah. This week, I would like to present a new perspective on Avraham and Sarah, one that takes us to a higher level of appreciation of the gadlut. I want to defend them, as in this week’s parasha, we find they both do something questionable, and as a result, people view them negatively as a result, chas veshalom. I like to always try to defend the Kadmonim, because we know that they were on the highest madregot, yet sometimes the Torah, the commentaries, and people in general, present a negative view of them, often one that is hard to understand given how holy and flawless they are!

So I will start with Sarah Immenu. In this week’s parasha, she is informed that she will have a child in her old age, and, famously, she laughs. The standard understanding is disbelief. We are taught from a young age that she shouldn’t have laughed, because even though she was too old to have children, she should trust in Hashem, because He can do anything. This doesn’t make sense, that Sarah, a greater prophetess than Avraham, would think Hashem couldn’t make her pregnant? That’s not giving her the credit she deserves.

As we get older, we learn that it’s not so much that she didn’t believe that Hashem could give her a child, but that she felt she didn’t deserve such a spectacular miracle. Better, yes, but at the end of the day, this now becomes a violation of Bitachon. We see time and again, when someone turns to Hashem and says “Katonti- I am not worthy”, this is counted against them.

It may sound like a praise – they were so humble that they truly believed they were not worthy, but it counts as a sin because we must factor in that we are in a relationship with Hashem. In a relationship, trust is essential. If my wife says she will do something for me, and I say “I doubt you will, because I will end up blowing it by being a bad husband”; if one party in a relationship is convinced their partner doesn't love them really, and He is constantly weighing their merits against their demerits, with His love, favours and promises all contingent on the scale being on the side of merit, then there is something that needs correcting in this relationship, to say the least.

So, this is the real answer: Sarah didn’t laugh out of disbelief. She laughed because she heard something wrong with the bracha. A bracha should be given face to face, according to Hilchot Tefilla and the blessings of the Cohanim, as well as Ohr Hachaim’s commentary on the Pasuk. But the bracha, which was exclusively for her according to Yismach Moshe, was given to her husband and she therefore sensed that it was only a temporary bracha. She was right, Yitzchak was destined to die during the Akeda, so she lobbied for him, like a true, devoted mama. She laughed, saying “you call that a bracha?” And it worked, the angel reassured her that he would personally see to it that the child would live, and indeed the same angel is the one who came to Avraham to tell him to not put his hand against Yitzchak!

Sarah was a greater prophetess than Avraham, and she was a “hearer”, "Sarah heard", whereas Avraham was a seer "he raised his eyes and he saw", which is why she sensed it, and Avraham missed it. She heard something wrong with the bracha, similar to how the Shunamit woman heard something wrong with her bracha – “you will coddle a child”. She wanted a child who would grow up, not just be coddled, and indeed Elisha promised her that he would ensure this, and when the boy died, Elisha resurrected him. See אמרי נועם עה"ת, for more support (thanks Joel K).

title: Is there a dagesh in the kuf of קמנו?
content:
# Is there a dagesh in the kuf of קמנו? ## Frage

I have seen different versions of the second-last posuk in Tehillim 20: ואנחנו קמנו ונתעודד. Some have the kuf with a dagesh (קַּמְנוּ). Others have the kuf without a dagesh (קַמְנוּ). The Minchas Shai doesn't mention this difference in girso. What is behind this difference?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Aleppo Codex page is unfortunately lost as noted by @Qwertrl in the comments. Edition of Keter Yerushalaim produced by R. Breuer, based on existing 15 old manuscripts and 16 classical reference works, has dagesh. The Nusach haMikra notes supporting Keter Yerushalaim on this particular word are absent in recording any differences. I.e. all agree that there should be a dagesh. Tanach Simanim and Tanach ArtScroll have dagesh as they are likely following this opinion. So does The New Concordance of the Hebrew Bible by Abraham ibn Shoshan.

The Leningrad Codex edition as Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia has dagesh. However the Massora on the bottom has a comment sic L, mlt Mss Edd קַ, i.e. such is the Leningrad codex manuscript, but multiple other edited manuscripts do not have dagesh. The Leningrad codex edition of Aharon Dothan has dagesh and no variants in the back.

The Mikraos Gedolos edition of Machon haMaor does not have dagesh. Neither does edition of ArtScroll Tehilim. It seems this opinion is based on the European manuscripts collected by the Bomberg publishing House and included in the study by C.D. Ginsburg. The C.D. Ginsburg edition of The Masorah v. 4, p. 522 from year 1905 does not have dagesh in this word. The list of the manuscripts that he used is described in Chapter 12 of his book "Introduction to the Massoretico-Critical Edition of the Hebrew Bible", pp. 469-778. It describes 60 manuscripts. The author does not disclose the manuscript differences, and his list of manuscripts includes the Leningrad / St.Petersburg Codex.

title: Why does it seem from Rabbeinu Shimshon that מי חטאת are Machshir?
content:
# Why does it seem from Rabbeinu Shimshon that מי חטאת are Machshir? ## Frage

The Mishnah (Parah 11:7) says that one should not use hyssop of Terumah for the purpose of spraying מי חטאת, and Rabbi Shimshon of Shantz explains that one of the reasons is in order that it should not become מוכשר לקבל טומאה.

My question is: why would מי חטאת be Machshir - isn’t there a rule (see commentaries on the Mishnah, Machshirin 6:4) that anything that has a שם לווי (additional name) is not Machshir? (see Zevachim 22b that ״מי כיור״ are considered to have a שם לווי, so ״מי חטאת״ should seemingly be the same).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The mishna speaks about hyssop of terumah which is already susceptible to tumah, i.e. it can be impure or pure. It teaches that hyssop of terumah that is impure, even if it is less that an egg size and would not make impure the מי חטאת, is still forbidden for sprinling since it is impure. The same is true for hyssop of chulin which is impure. In the case of the hyssop of terumah that is pure there are two cases:

  • If the size of hyssop less than an egg, the hyssop that was prepared with purity stringencies of teruma would still be considered impure relative the stringences required for מי חטאת.
  • Even if the size is more than an egg and the terumah was prepared with stringencies fitting for מי חטאת, one would still not use it for sprinkling, for perhaps accidentally there will be psul for sprinkling which will cause the מי חטאת cause impurity to the terumah and cause it to be disqualified.

The relevant part to the OP's question is the second part of the Rabbeinu Shimshon to Parah 11:7 comment:

ושל תרומה. שלקטו לאכילה דחייב בתרומה ודאי דפסול בתרומה טמאה כדתנן לקמן בפ"ב (מ"ו) דאזוב טמא הזאתו פסולה והוא הדין של חולין טמאין ואגב סיפא דמחלק בתרומה טהורה דלכתחלה לא יזה נקט רישא תרומה וטעמא דלא יזה בטהורה כדאמרינן בסוכה (דף לה:) גבי אתרוג פליגי בה ר' אמי ור' אסי חד אמר מפני שמכשירה וחד אמר מפני שמפסידה:

The hyssop was picked for eating is liable for terumah. Obviously, (sprinkiling) is disqualified for impure terumah, because it is taught in Mishnah 15:9 (the numbering is different), the hyssop that is impure is disqualified from sprinkling. The same is true with hyssop of impure chulin. The second part regarding hyssop of pure terumah, there is a distinction, lehatchila one should not sprinkle, as it is said in Succah 35b regarding esrog of terumah. There R' Ami and R' Asi argue about esrog of terumah taken for the mitzvah of lulav and becoming wet, whether it would make it susceptible to tumah or whether it will spoil it.

One must conclude that the esrog in Gemara Succah was only designated for terumah, but remained tevel. This is different from the case of the mishnah, where the hyssop of terumah is already susceptible to tumah. Alternatively, if our hyssop is only designated for terumah (with all stringencies of מי חטאת), but not rendered susceptible, we should not use it lehatchila because מי חטאת will makhshir it and there may occur an accident which will disqualify it by impurity.

title: Were Yom Kippur korbanos eaten on Yom Kippur
content:
# Were Yom Kippur korbanos eaten on Yom Kippur ## Frage

I know that some korbanos such as a chatos would be eaten by the kohanim , what about the korbanos chatos of Yom Kippur did they wait until after Yom Kippur to eat it or did they actually eat it on Yom Kippur or where they not eaten at all?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 13)

The meat was eaten at night after the fast. If the next day was Shabbat they'd have eat it raw since you can't cook on Shabbat or Yom Kippur. If Yom Kippur was on Shabbat, the shewbread would be distributed only at night after the fast. (Mishna Menachot 11:7)

title: Abraham Halevi (?) Messianic Prophecy for 5481?
content:
# Abraham Halevi (?) Messianic Prophecy for 5481? ## Frage

Chevre,

I have come across a passage from the Historical Register which tells of the case of a false Messiah called Felix Coen, who was elected "king" on the basis of a certain "Abraham of the tribe of Levi", and who argued for the redemption to be brought about in the Jewish year 5481, i.e. 1721, according to an unclear calculation: add 3533 years (I have corrected the source below that mistakenly reads 4333 rather than 3533) since "the birth of Abraham", i.e. 1948 + 3533 = 5481, i.e. 1721.

That the prophecy was wrong is obvious, since we live in a much worse world, especially after 7/10. However, I suppose that this "Abraham of the tribe of Levi" could well be our Abraham ben Eliezer Halevi (?) but his messianic calculations do not include anything close to these numbers. Assuming this is reasonable, how do you think they came up with the odd number 3533 and the even odder calculation of counting "from the birth of Abraham"? I have also noticed that both 3533 and 5481 were Jubilee years but I don't really know how to solve this.

[EDIT] After doing some supplementary research myself, I can confirm that this event was connected to an obscure blood accusation in Ferrara. where Felix Coen lived as a wealthy business man (he died in 1738). The source is “The Historical Register," 1721 (here). My interest here only focuses on the calculation of the 5481 as a messianic year by adding 1948 (Abraham's birth) to 3533 (Jubilee) on account of “Abraham Levi"'s prophecy. I found NO evidence elsewhere of such calculation and such use of Abraham's birthday with messianic implications. Might it be something Sabbatean? Az, todah rabbah le-kulkhem!

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

See kidushin 76b

וְעוֹד אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: אַרְבַּע מֵאוֹת יְלָדִים הָיוּ לוֹ לְדָוִד, וְכוּלָּם בְּנֵי יְפַת תּוֹאַר הָיוּ,

title: Did Lot have sons?
content:
# Did Lot have sons? ## Frage

When the angels ask Lot to warn his relatives about the catastrophe Bereshis 19:12:

Then the agents said to Lot, “Whom else have you here? Sons-in-law, your sons and daughters, or anyone else that you have in the city—bring them out of the place.

Rashi comments the word sons as

ובניך THY SONS means the sons of your married daughters. The Midrashic explanation of עוד YET is: since they have perpetrated so disgraceful an act, can you yet be so bold (more literally, “can you yet open your mouth”) to speak in defence of them? — for the whole night through he had been talking in favor of them. To obtain this explanation you must read: עוד מי לך פֶּה Have you yet a mouth! (instead of פֹּה here) (Genesis Rabbah 50:5).

From Rashi on Bereshis 19:14 we learn that Lot had 2 married daughters who lived with their husbands and two daughters at home who were betrothed at the time that the angels came to visit Lot. Furthermore, from Pirkei d'Rabbi Eliezer 25:8 and Sefer haYashar Veyera 5-6 we learn a tragic story about Lot's daughter Paltith, who was brutally murdered for trying to help a destitute man. Thus, Lot was a father of 5 daughters, but seemingly no sons.

How could the meforshim be sure that Lot did not have any sons?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Thanks to the comment of @Fred we have two comments on the quoted Rashi, which answer the question:

Sifsei Chakhamim by R' Shabbethai ben Yosef Bass (Strom) also known as Mishorer (poet) quoting R' Eliyahu Mizrachi:

בני בנותיך הנשואות. ואם תאמר מנא ליה לרש"י דילמא בניו היו ולא בני בניו ויש לומר מדכתיב חתן תחילה ואח"כ בניך ובנותיך משמע דקאי בניך ובנותיך על חתן דהיינו בנות הנשואות:

Your married daughter’s sons. You might ask: How does Rashi know this? Perhaps they were his sons and not his grandsons! The answer is: Since it is written “son-in-law” first, followed by “your sons, your daughters,” it implies that “your sons, your daughters” refers back to “son-inlaw,” i.e., the married daughter’s sons.

Alternatively, Gur Aryeh by R' Yehuda Loew ben Betzalel (Maharal):

דהא בודאי מלאכים היו, ויודעים היו שאין לו בנים, כדמוכח קרא (פסוק יד) שלא רצה לוט להציל רק חתניו, ואם כן למה אמר "ובניך".

The visitors for sure were angels and they knew that Lot did not have sons, as the verse Bereshis 19:14 states that Lot ran to save only his sons-in-law, that is why the verse says "and your sons".

In both of these cases we have to also mention the midrash Bereshis Rabbasi Vayishlach 12 (see translation here) about father's feeling towards his children. I.e. if Lot had sons he would not avoid saving them.

There is also midrash Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer 25:11:

עירית אשתו של לוט נכמרו רחמה על בנותיה הנשואות והביטה לאחריה לראות אם הולכות אחריה אם לא (וראת אחרי) [וראתה אחריה] השכינה ונעשית נציב מלח, שנאמר ותבט אשתו מאחריו ותהי נציב מלח:

The pity of 'Edith (Irith) the wife of Lot was stirred for her daughters, who were married in Sodom, and she looked back behind her to see if they were coming after her or not. And she saw behind the Shekhinah, and she became a pillar of salt, as it is said, "And his wife looked back from behind him, and she became a pillar of salt" (Gen. 19:26)

We could accept it as a proof that the midrash does not mention her sons. But is it possible that she did not like her sons and did not want to have mercy on them? In view of the gemara Nidda 31a we can reject this point as well:

וא"ר יצחק אשה מזרעת תחל' יולדת זכר איש מזריע תחלה יולדת נקבה

Rabbi Yitzḥak says that Rabbi Ami says: (The sex of a fetus is determined at the moment of conception). If the woman emits seed first, she gives birth to a male, and if the man emits seed first, she gives birth to a female, as it is stated: “If a woman bears seed and gives birth to a male” (Leviticus 12:2).

I.e. naturally a woman has a stronger connection to her son, while a man to his daughter. Because in the midrash the Lot's wife got stirred for her daughters and not sons, she did not have any sons.

title: Is anyone in the Tanakh referred to by their mother's name?
content:
# Is anyone in the Tanakh referred to by their mother's name? ## Frage

Many people in the Tanakh are referred to by their father's name. For instance שלמה בן דויד in 2 Chronicles 1:1. Are there any instances where someone is referred to by their mother's name? Like "John son of Martha"? I'm specifically looking for examples that use this grammatical form, not just places where we are told who someone's mother is.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 20)

  • Two of Esav's sons: Elifaz ben Ada and Re'uel ben Basemat (Bereishit 36:10)

  • The brothers Yoav ben Tzeruyah and Avishai (also known as Avshai) ben Tzeruyah. See for example Shemuel I:26:6 and Shemuel II:2:13. (For confirmation that Tzeruyah is indeed the name of their mother, see Divrei HaYamim I:2:16.)

  • Three of David’s sons: Avshalom ben Ma’acha, Adoniyah (or Adoniyahu) ben Chagit and Shefatya ben Avital (Shemuel II:3:3-4).

  • Aviyam (or Aviyah) ben Rechav'am is referred to in Divrei HaYamim II:11:22 using his mother's name: Aviyah ben Ma'acha.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 15)

דינה בת לאה - Dinah Bat Leah

Genesis 34:1

### Antwort 3 (Score: 5)

Saul, son of the Canaanite woman וְשָׁא֖וּל בֶּן־הַֽכְּנַעֲנִֽית in Bereshit 46:10

title: How many sons did Chizkiyahu have?
content:
# How many sons did Chizkiyahu have? ## Frage

As Berachot 10a-10b tells us, Chizkiyahu initially did not have children because he knew they would be wicked. It is only when the idea strikes for him to marry Yeshayahu's daughter does he comply, hoping the merit of them both will protect his children.

There is a section in Berachot 10a that the Ein Yaakov includes which is no longer a part of the Talmud. Quoting Chabad.org's translation, "Isaiah gave his daughter to Hezekiah. They gave birth to two sons: Menashe and Ravshakeh. One day, Hezekiah was carrying the boys on his shoulders… whereupon one of them said, “father’s head would be suitable for roasting a small fish, while the other boy said father’s head would be suitable for offering an idolatrous offering. When Hezekiah heard this, he cast them down to the ground. Menashe survived, while Ravshakeh died." See also Targum to Kohelet 10:9 on a different fate for Ravshakeh.

It's stated that Chizkiyahu only had two sons, but the prophet Zephaniah from Trei Asar descends from Chizkiyahu, as it says in Zephaniah 1:1, "The word of the Lord came to Zephaniah the son of Kushi, the son of Gedalya, the son of Amarya, the son of Chizkiyahu..." This Chizkiyahu is the same as King Chizkiyahu according to Ibn Ezra, Malbim, and Radak commenting on the verse. However, there are two main problems:

  1. Why is this third son of Chizkiyahu only mentioned here and nowhere else? There is no source external from Zephaniah 1:1 that Chizkiyahu had three sons, and all other sources strongly point to him having a maximum of two children. One answer to that is that perhaps Amarya is another name for one of his two sons, but besides for there being no tradition of this, problem 2 shows it is unlikely.
  2. From Zephaniah 1:1 we learn the rule that whenever we learn of a Tzaddik being introduced in the name of his father(s), and we never met his father(s) before, we can assume all introduced are Tzaddikim (Megillah 15a). This means that Kushi, Gedalya, and Amarya were Tzaddikim. However, there is no indicator that Chizkiyahu had any non-evil children. Quite the opposite. The dialogue between Isaiah and Chizkiyahu in Berachot 10a, "That which you are commanded, you are obligated to do; let the Holy One, then do as He sees fit," and "The decree has already been issued," seem to say this is God's will, and Chizkiyahu can't change it. While he does later recover from his illness, we see through Menashe that his wish for good children didn't come true. And if out of all of Chizkiyahu's children, Menashe was the most fitting to rule, I would hate to imagine how Amarya turned out! And yet, Megillah 15a says Amarya was a tzaddik.

As a result, I am wondering, how many sons does Chizkiyahu have? Why is Amarya only mentioned in Zephaniah 1:1 as Chizkiyahu's son and nowhere else? How does Amarya fit into all this, was he a tzaddik or a rasha?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

There is a comment from Ben Yehoyada to Brachos 10a on the missing portion:

החַד אָמַר חָזִי רֵישָׁה דְאִמָא לִמטוּי בֵּיה גְלַדנָאִי. הנה לפי סדר שמותם דנקיט הש"ס נראה שזה הראשון שאמר למטוי ביה דלדנאי היה מנשה? ונראה לי בס"ד לכך אמר דברים אלו, כי מזליה חזי שסופו לעשות תשובה ולהתתקן, ובני אדם נמשלו לדגים כנזכר בקהלת, ואמר חזי זכות אבא שיגין למטוי ביה גלדנאי הם בני אדם הרשעים, שיתבשלו ויתוקנו באש התורה, אבל רַבְשָׁקֵה אמר דבר רע ומר מאד להקריב לעבודה זרה, לכך כיון שחבטו מת תיכף על ידי נפילה זו מן השמים, כי ודאי הוא לא חבטם חביטה שיש בה שעור להמית, אלא מן השמים עשו כך לטובתו, ולכן נקרא רַבְשָׁקֵה אותיות בהשקר שהיה דבק בו, והא דארכבנהו אכתפיה, ודאי לא היה מזלזל בכבוד מלכות לפני בני אדם, אלא עשה כן בהצנע, וכונתו לשם שמים, לחבב התורה בעיני הילדים האלה בראותם שהוא מלך ומרכיבם על כתיפו בשביל ללמוד תורה.

קָרֵי אֲנַפְשֵׁיה (ישעיהו לב, ז) וְכֵלַי כֵּלָיו רָעִים. נראה לי בס"ד דהאשה נקראת כלי של בעלה, וכמו שאמרו רבותינו ז"ל אין אשה כורתת ברית אלא למי שעשאה כלי, וכן שלחה אשתו של רבי אלעזר לרבי כלי שנשתמש בו קודש ישתמש בו חול, והוא בטח שיגיע לו מצדה בזכות אביה איזה סיוע ועזר לדבר זה, ועתה בראותו כי לא הועילה גם מצידה לכך אמר וכלי, הוא שהיה כלי במצוה זו של פריה ורביה שלא נשא אשה מתחלה, הנה קרה לו שגם כליו מצד אשתו גם כן נפקי רעים ונ"ל, לכך אמר הנה לשלום מר לי מר, כי מנשה רבשקה ראשי תיבות מר, ואין שלום אלא אשה והוא קיוה כימן השלום הנשואין שנשא בת ישעיה יצא לו בנים טובים, ועתה ראה כי מן השלום יצא לו מ"ר, יען לי מר ראשי תיבות מנשה רַבְשָׁקֵה.

(he also has a possibly faulty girsa about "frying on mother's head") Behold, is it true that according the order of names the first who said to fry the fish is Menashe? And I think that it is he who said so because in the future he (Menashe) would repent and mend (his ways). People are compared to fish as mentioned in Koheles 9:12, so he said that the merit of his father was to fry fish i.e. the evil men who would be cooked and get improved in the fire of the Torah. But Ravshakeh said bad and bitter words to sacrifice to avodah zara, since he was struck immediately by the fall, it was by heavely decree, for Chizkiyahu did not hit them with deadly strike. Thus, he was called Ravshakeh, same letters as in falsity (בהשקר). (Chizkiyahu) certainly did not disdain the honor of kingship before men, but did so with modesty, and his intention was for the sake of Heaven, to endear the Torah in the eyes of these children, so that they saw that he was a king and carried them on his shoulders for learning.

Based in Yishayahu 32:7, As for the knaves (vessels), their tools are knavish, as it is said in (Sanhedrin 22b) that a woman only cuts a covenant with one who ‘makes her a vessel’... Chizkiyahu married to have children and it happened that the vesels from the side of his wife came out bad, so he said, Yishayahu 38:17 Truly, it was for my own good that I had such great bitterness ..., because Menashe and Ravshakeh initials מ"ר (bitterness). And there is no peace except a woman, and he hoped that the peace of the marriage that he had with the daughter of Isaiah would produce good sons for him, and now he saw that from peace he would produce מ"ר bitterness, the initials of Manasseh, Rabshakeh.

Ben Yehoyada seems to agree with the indication of the OP that Chizkiyahu only had two sons due to abbreviation מ"ר. The first son Menashe, although called evil in gemarah Sanhedrin, actually repented 33 years before his death, as noted in Seder Olam Rabba 24:1.

The opinion that Chizkiya mentioned in the verse Tzephania 1:1 is king Chizkiyahu comes from ibn Ezra:

The scripture mentions the names of the fathers until it reaches the most honorable, which is King Hezekiah, and behold, according to the interpretation, Amariah was the brother of Manasseh. And do not be surprised because Josiah is third to Hezekiah, for there are more than a hundred years from the day Hezekiah grew up to father a son until Josiah became king.

Tzephaniah was a prophet during the time of Yoshiyahu, as explained in the second part of Radak. Radak actually disagrees with ibn Ezra and states

י"א כי חזקיה זה חזקיה מלך יהודה ואפשר (אבן עזרא) אלא שאין בזה ראיה אבל באמת גדולים היו אבותיו לפיכך נזכרו

There are those who say that Chizkiya is Chizkiyahu king of Yehudah and it is possible (ibn Ezra). Rather, there is no proof from these words (i.e. here in the verse). However, the ancestors of Tzephaniah were great people, that is why they were mentioned.

Therefore, we cannot accept the opinion of ibn Ezra based on Ben Yehoyada, since Ravshakeh completely became lost to the Jewish people. It would be difficult to identify Amarya with repented Menashe, since then one would have to identify Kushi with children of Menashe, etc. Alternatively, ibn Ezra might have identified Amarya with Ravshakeh, since he may not be fully consistent with Megilla 15a that the names of ancestors mentioned must all be righteous, as we find with bnei Korach. In this case, one can translate the meaning of the name Amarya not as the usual Hashem Said, but as I will embitter (אמרר) Hashem.

title: Are there any multi-word names in the Tanakh?
content:
# Are there any multi-word names in the Tanakh? ## Frage

The words יערי ארגים in 2 Samuel 21:19 are sometimes claimed to be a two-word name. (For example the KJV translates them that way.) Are there any other names in the Tanakh like this, which consist of two words with a space (or dash) between them?

There are lots of theophoric names like אלימלך composed of a few words fused together, but these are not what I am looking for.

There are also several names like בת שבע or בן הדד which start with "ben-" or "bat-". I am excluding these as well.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 20)

Disclaimer: This list is not comprehensive. I'll update with more names suggested in the comments or that I have come across.

  • Yeshayahu had a son named מהר שלל חש בז (Maher Shalal Chash Baz) (Isaiah 8:1-3).

  • Another of Yeshayahu's children was named שאר ישוב (Sha'ar Yeshuv) (Isaiah 7:3).

  • There's also עמנו אל (Immanu El) (Isaiah 7:14) which, though theophoric, is spelled with a space. It's not known whether he was Yeshuayahu's son or Achaz's son (perhaps another name for Chizkiyahu).

  • Menashe's mother was called חפצי־בה (Cheftzi-Bah) (Kings 2:21:1).

  • According to Metzudat David, there was a Levite named זכריהו בן (Zecharyahu Ben) (Chronicles 1:15:18).1

  • In a simple reading of Hoshea, he had a daughter named לא רוחמה (Lo Ruchama) and a son named לא עמי (Lo Ami) (Hosea 1:6-9).2

  • מלכי צדק (Malki Tzedek), king of Shalem, spelled like that both in Genesis 14:18 and Psalms 110:4.

  • אדני־צדק (Adoni-Tzedek) (Joshua 10:1-3), king of Yerushalayim.

  • אדני־בזק (Adoni-Bezek) (Judges 1:5-7), king of Bezek.

  • תובל קין (Tuval Kain) (Genesis 4:22), son of Lemech.

  • כל־חזה (Kol-Chozeh) (Nehemiah 11:5), the ancestor of a Judahite province head who lived in Yerushalayim.

  • אבי־עלבון (Avi-Elbon) (Samuel 2:23:31), one of the warriors of David.

  • מריב בעל (Meriv Baal) (Chronicles 1:8:34), the real name of Mephiboshet, son of Yonatan.

  • According to Metzudat Tzion and Radak, ישבי בנב (Yishbi Benov) (Samuel 2:21:16), a giant.

  • According to Radak, Ralbag, Metzudat David and Rabbi Steinsaltz, חצי המנחות (Chatzi Hamenuchot) (Chronicles 1:2:52).

  • According to Rashi, עזובה אשה (Azuva Isha) (Chronicles 1:2:18), a daughter of Kalev son of Chetzron (cf. Malbim on the verse).

  • As noted by @Yø-c Ro, עבד אדום (Oved Edom) (e.g. Shmuel 2:6:10).

  • Likewise, עבד מלך (Eved Melech) (e.g., Jeremiah 38:7-8), a servant of Tzidkiyahu.

  • Likewise, יושב חסד (Yushav Chessed) (Chronicles 1:3:20).

  • Likewise, טוב אדניה (Tov Adonyah) (Chronicles 2:17:8).

  • As noted by @moses, רממתי עזר (Romamti Ezer) (Chronicles 1:25:4), a Levite.

  • As noted by @Chani, מי זהב (Mei Zahav) (Genesis 36:39, Chronicles 1:1:50).

  • בעל חנן (Ba'al Chanan), a name shared by an Edomite king (Genesis 36:38-39, Chronicles 1:1:49-50) and a servant of David (Chronicles 1:27:28).

  • As noted by @Sholom, the Assyrian king תגלת פלאסר (Tiglat Pilesser) (and in one case Tilgat Pilnesser) (e.g., Kings 2:15:29).3

  • Likewise, the Babylonian king מרודך בלאדן/בראדך בלאדן (Merodach Baladan/Berodach Baladan) (e.g., Isaiah 39:1, Kings 2:20:12).3

  • Likewise, the Babylonian king אויל מרודך (Evil Merodach) (Kings 2:25:27).3

  • Likewise, עבד נגו (Aved Nego), the Babylonian name for Azariah, one of Daniel's friends (e.g., Daniel 1:7).

  • As noted by @manassehkatz-Moving 2 Codidact, the Egyptian priest פוטי פרע (Poti Pherah) (e.g., Genesis 41:45).

  • According to Metzudat David, ישבי לחם (Yashuvi Lachem) (Chronicles 1:4:22).

  • As noted by @Sholom, perhaps כדר לעמר (Kedar Laomer) (see Chullin 65a and Minchat Shai on Genesis 14:1).

  • As noted by @manassehkatz-Moving 2 Codidact, perhaps צפנת פענח (Tzophnat Pa'aneach) (Genesis 41:45).4

  • According to Rabbi Steinsaltz (and tentatively proposed by Ibn Ezra), פכרת הצביים (Pocheret Hatzevai'im) (Ezra 2:57).

  • According to Malbim, את יריעות (Et Yeriot) (Chronicles 1:2:18), a daughter of Kalev son of Chetzron.

  • According to the JPS translation, ישב בשבת (Yoshev Bashevet) (Samuel 2:23:8).

  • Perhaps פחת מואב (Pachat Moav) (e.g., Ezra 8:4, Nehemiah 10:15).5

  • Perhaps בית רפא (Beit Rapha) (Chronicles 1:4:12).6

Thanks to everyone for their suggestions!

1 But see here for a different interpretation.

2 Cf. Hoshea 2:3.

3 The cuneiform name is also composed of multiple words.

4 Assuming Tzophnat Pa'aneach is a name rather than an official title of sorts.

5 Some propose that this was a title for various individuals. As a side-note, Aharon Kaminka, "Towards a Solution for the Riddle of the Strange Versions in the Septuagint" (לפתרון חידת הנוסחאות המשונות בתרגום השבעים), in: ibid., Studies on the Bible and the Talmud and Rabbinic Literature (מחקרים במקרא, ובתלמוד, ובספרות הרבנית), Vol. 1, Tel Aviv 5698/1938, p. 191 argued that this is where Rabbi Chiya's nickname for Rav, בר פחתי (Bar Pachti), comes from.

6 It's not clear in context whether this is a toponym or a personal name.

title: Dina malchuta dina - detailed definition
content:
# Dina malchuta dina - detailed definition ## Frage

Assume an observant Jew living in an area controlled by a Colombian guerilla. The guerilla is independent from (actually opposed to) the central government of the country and make their own laws.

Dina malchuta dina applies to the central government laws, or to the laws of the guerilla?

title: Why, when Klal Yisroel were scared to go into Eretz Yisroel after the meraglim returned, did this cause a קָרְבָּן and גָּלוּת until moshiach comes?
content:
# Why, when Klal Yisroel were scared to go into Eretz Yisroel after the meraglim returned, did this cause a קָרְבָּן and גָּלוּת until moshiach comes? ## Frage

We know that Klal Yisroel were afraid to go into Eretz Yisroel, because they felt that they had committed too many sins, and lost their Divine protection, which appears to be a legitimate reason to be afraid.

Therefore the question is posed, why did this cause a korban for all future generations, and a galus until moshiach comes?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Welcome to Mi Yodeya, great question.

  • See this answer which explains why it is considered a sin to say "I am worried Hashem will retract His promises to me, because I might sin/have sinned".
  • See this Rabbenu Bachaya for why doing so regarding Eretz Yisrael was considered such a terrible violation of this principle.

To summarise: the whole point of choosing the Jewish people was for Hashem to take them to Eretz Yisrael and build a "bayit ne'eman". This was the vision of our forefathers and Hashem's purpose. Therefore, refusal to proceed is considered one of the worst sins we ever did, and is indeed practically unforgivable, as there is no alternative plan. Therefore the only solution was for Hashem to wipe us out, but Moshe prayed for the maximum amount of forgiveness possible. This was that Hashem spread out his anger over many generations, so that each generation only received a managable amount, and we went into גָּלוּת until all of the sin is atoned for.

As for the point you made that the Jews were only afraid for seemingly legitimate reasons, i.e. they were worried that they would die not because Hashem can't protect them, but because Hashem would refuse to protect them because of their sins, this is considered a sin. Even Yaacov Avinu did this and it was counted as a sin. The basic explanation is, a true marriage is not conditional. If a wife thinks that her husband only loves her conditionally, and every day is watching to see if she will sin, and is constantly ready to back out of the relationship the moment she does, then surely the husband will be upset with her for this. He promised to be with her unconditionally, and she doubts it? That's a breach of trust, bitachon, in a relationship.

In a case of Pikuach Nefesh, for example, someones plane crashes on a deserted island and the only "edible" items are a dead human being or a pig, which one should that person eat?

There would be reason to assume that cannibalism is preferred as it's at worst a positive (עשה) transgression according to some, or even outright allowed (see here) vs. eating pig, which is an issur deoraysa. To keep the question focus, let's assume no blood will be consumed by eating the human.

Is there another way to approach this question?

title: What's bad with knowing what's good and what's evil?
content:
# What's bad with knowing what's good and what's evil? ## Frage

After Adam and Eve eat of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil, we read:

וַיֹּ֣אמֶר ׀ יְהֹוָ֣ה אֱלֹהִ֗ים הֵ֤ן הָֽאָדָם֙ הָיָה֙ כְּאַחַ֣ד מִמֶּ֔נּוּ לָדַ֖עַת ט֣וֹב וָרָ֑ע

title: Prohibition from having intimacy while being a guest - source from Chumash
content:
# Prohibition from having intimacy while being a guest - source from Chumash ## Frage

I’m looking for a source from Chumash that intimacy should not be conducted in a another’s house.

I recently learned Siman 240:13 in OC Shulchan Aruch which prohibits intimacy when sleeping in another’s house. All the sources from there quote Ketubot 65a and the pasuk from Shmuel to prove it.
However, I explicitly remember learning the same idea from somewhere in Chumash, where a verse subtly indicates that a married couple (I forgot which one) remained separate. We learn from there good conduct in that they did not engage in intimacy while staying at someone else’s house.

If anyone can give me any relevant information, I would really appreciate it.
Thank you!

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 9)

Rashi (Bereishis 12:2) says:

ואעשך לגוי גדול. לְפִי שֶׁהַדֶּרֶךְ גּוֹרֶמֶת לִשְׁלֹשָׁה דְבָרִים, מְמַעֶטֶת פְּרִיָּה וּרְבִיָּה וּמְמַעֶטֶת אֶת הַמָּמוֹן וּמְמַעֶטֶת אֶת הַשֵּׁם, לְכָךְ הֻזְקַק לִשְׁלֹשָׁה בְּרָכוֹת הַלָּלוּ, שֶׁהִבְטִיחוֹ עַל הַבָּנִים וְעַל הַמָּמוֹן וְעַל הַשֵּׁם:

AND I WILL MAKE OF THEE A GREAT NATION: Since traveling is the cause of three things — it decreases family life, it reduces one’s wealth and lessens one’s renown, he therefore needed these three blessings: that God should promise him children, wealth and a great name (Genesis Rabbah 39:11).

The Maharsha in Kesubos (65a) states that the reason traveling decreases family life is because intimacy is forbidden when one is a guest.

### Antwort 2 (Score: -2)

Genesis 26:8 Isaac engaged in intimacy (or at least behavior associated with man and wife and not done between brother and sister) when he was staying in Gerar, outside the king's palace.

This shows that the Avot were not concerned about intimacy while a guest.

title: Age of Haran when he had Sarah
content:
# Age of Haran when he had Sarah ## Frage

Abraham was 100 and Sarah was 90 when they gave birth to Yitzchak. That means they’re 10 years apart. And Sarah is the daughter of Abraham’s younger brother Haran. So when Sarah was born, Abraham was 10, meaning Haran who was younger must’ve been 8 maximum (because Nachor was in between). And so when Sarah was conceived he must’ve been 7. Do any mefarshim address issues like this or give any creative answers, or do most ignore it or just say “nature was different back then”

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

According to Seder haDoros year 1916, Terach was 38 years old and had Haran and Nachor born (Sefer haYashar Noach). In the year 1948, Terach married a different woman named Amatlaah bas Carnevu who gave birth to Avram. I.e. Haran was older than Avram by 32 years. In the year 1955 Haran was 39 years old, he married a woman who gave birth to Lot, then Milka, and then Sarah. In the year 1958, Haran was 42 years when Sarah was born.

Gemara Sanhedrin 69b states that Avram was older than Nahor by 1 year, and older than Haran by 2 years. So it implies that Haran was 8 when Sarah was born. I do not know how to reconcile all these numbers. It can be that Terach's 1st wife was getting very sick and died when Avraham was just 1 year old. Terach married Avraham's mother to help him with sick wife, who later adopted both Nachor and Haran.

Regarding "nature was different argument" in year 1957 Seder haDoros states that Avram could have a child at the age of 9 years old. This is within halacha, but Haran's ability to do so at 8 is not. Thus, one may accept that the number 8 years is hinting to some additional information.

title: Biographies of the Matriarchs
content:
# Biographies of the Matriarchs ## Frage

I am looking for a biography of Sarah Immenu, Rivka Immenu, Rachel Immenu and Leah Immenu. I want to give a Drasha dedicated to Sarah next week, an obituary, if you will, and then I might do the same for the rest of the Immahot and either way I am very interested.

Where can I find the most information about their lives, with all the background from Aggada, Midrashim and our Rishonim?

FYI I already have Avraham Avinu, by Chaim Zvi Noyek, which does have a lot of information about Sarah, but I am looking for more.

Do you have any book recommendations, or even a good list of sources for me to look at?

Thanks!

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

A good starting point is a personal fave of mine - Ishei HaTanach: Encyclopedia of Biblical Personalities by Rabbi Yishai Chasida.

It is not a biography but it looks at key features of their life and provides numerous sources.

It has 5 pages worth of sources on Sarah's life and explores:

  1. Her personality
  2. Her Beauty
  3. Her Righteousness
  4. In Pharoah's Palace
  5. With Hagar
  6. Birth of Yitzchak
  7. Death

It has 2.5 pages on Rivka exploring:

  1. Her personality
  2. Her marriage
  3. Her pregnancy
  4. Yaakov's blessing
  5. Death

3 pages on Rochel, exploring:

  1. Personality
  2. Meets Yaakov
  3. Bears Children
  4. Teraphim
  5. Death

2 pages on Leah, exploring:

  1. Personality
  2. Marriage
  3. Children
  4. Death
### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

There is a longer source written in English "The Passions of the Matriarchs" by Shera Aranoff Tuchman and Sandra E. Rapoport. The story of Sarah occupies pp. 3-82 with the following sections:

  1. Introduction to Sarai, Abram's wife
  2. Sarai's Abduction by Pharaoh
  3. G-d promises Sarai a Child and Changes her Name
  4. Sarah's Rejuvenation
  5. Sarah's Abduction by Avimelech
  6. Sarah's pregnancy and birth of Isaac
  7. The children of Sarah and the Handmaiden
  8. Abraham Heeds Sarah's Plea
  9. Sarah is Separated from Isaac: The Akeda
  10. The Death of Sarah
  11. Sarah is Eulogized and Buried in Ma'arat haMakhphela
  12. Epilogue to Sarah

It has similar parts for Rivkah, Leah and Rachel. It is is written for girls and has many interesting sources. I had my struggles with some choices of words in it, so it may need to be revised to be more polished.

title: Yishmoel and the power of teshuvo - source?
content:
# Yishmoel and the power of teshuvo - source? ## Frage

In Lech-Lecho, Yishmoel's name is mentioned. In Vayeiro, his name isn't mention. In Chayei Soro, his name is mentioned again. It seems to me that the reason for this is that, since Yishmoel did teshuvo, his name is not mentioned in relation to his sinful days in Vayeiro. Therefore, his name is only mentioned before he sinned (i.e., when he was born and when he agreed to have bris milo) and after he had done teshuvo (i.e., when burying his father and his death). I have told this to various local Rabbonim and they like it. However, I have not found any Rov who has said this in the past. My question is: who has said this chiddush previously?

The Kaddish concludes as follows:

title: Why were Lot and his family told not to look back?
content:
# Why were Lot and his family told not to look back? ## Frage

While God was destroying Sodom, the angels told Lot and his family: "Flee for your life! Do not look behind you, nor stop anywhere". [Gen. 19:17] But...

וַתַּבֵּ֥ט אִשְׁתּ֖וֹ מֵאַחֲרָ֑יו וַתְּהִ֖י נְצִ֥יב מֶֽלַח׃ -- Lot’s wife looked back, and she thereupon turned into a pillar of salt. [Gen. 19:26]

Why were they not supposed to look back?

Pirkei d'Rabbi Eliezer [25:11] says that HaShem was there and you die when you see Him. (But does it turn you into salt?) Rashi says it's because it's not right that they should witness the doom of the people they knew while they themselves are escaping. Ramban says it's because the lethal agents (heat, fumes, bacteria, viruses, radiation, etc.) could affect them even from afar. (But does it make a difference if they hit you in the back?)

I think something is missing because the punishment (death) seems too harsh. The angels did not threaten punishment of any kind. A warning or an explanation would have been in order.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

As you quoted, the Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer teaches us that the intention was to prevent Lot and his family from seeing the shechinah as it descended to destroy Sedom. However, I stumbled upon another explanation from Rabbi David Tzvi Hoffmann (see AlHaTorah):

ויהי כהוציאם וגו' – מכיוון שהוצא מן העיר חרף העדר אמונתו, בחמלת ה', הרי שלפחות הצלתו מכאן ואילך צריכה להיות בזכות מעשה אמונה. משום כך נצטווה שלא לעמוד כלל, ואפילו לא להביט אחורה כדי לראות, אם אמנם יבוצע העונש כפי שנתבשר.

Since Lot was taken out of the city despite his lack of faith, solely due to G-d's compassion, it follows that his salvation from this point onward needed to be earned through an act of faith. For this reason, he was commanded not to stop at all, nor even to look back to see whether the punishment, as foretold, would indeed come to pass.

The Radak also says that by looking back, Lot was giving the impression that he was not sure whether the city was really destroyed:

to ascertain if the city behind him was really being destroyed.

So, if we extrapolate the meaning of the words of R' Hoffmann, we can explain that by looking back, Lot was giving the impression that he lacked faith that G-d would destroy the city due to the sins of it's inhabitants.

The Chida in Pnei David (Bereishis 19:17) hints to us that this posuk means that one should leave a sinning-environment and is instructed not to look back, e.g. one should leave his sins behind and not to stay at that place. By looking back, I think the Chida is learning us that Lot was not ready to "move on" from sinning.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

One can answer using the Rashi's comment to Bereshis 19:17:

אל תבט אחריך LOOK NOT BEHIND THEE — You sinned with them but you are being saved through the merit of Abraham. It is not fitting that you should witness their doom whilst you yourself are escaping (Genesis Rabbah 50:11).

The fact, that one needs to have special merit to see the punushment of the wicked people by G-d, we learn from Tehilim 91:8-9:

You will see it with your eyes, you will witness the punishment of the wicked. Because you took Hashem — my refuge, the Most High — as your haven...

The first verse, Tehilim 91:8, talks about seeing punishment, so Rashi there asks:

and...the annihilation Heb. ושלמת, complete destruction. And why?

The answer comes from the following verse Tehilim 91:9, that speaks about great faith of a person:

For you You said, “The Lord is my refuge.” This is an elliptical verse (i.e. it omits words that are obviously understood but must be supplied by the comment to make the sentence grammatically correct). the Most High you made your dwelling. You made the Holy One, blessed be He, the seat of your trust.

The commentary Be'er haTorah (a part of Hoil Moshe) by rabbi Moshe ben Avraham Mat from Przemyśl (a town in south-eastern Poland) has a long comment on this specific question and he gives several additional reasons.

  1. When analyzing the comment of Rashi, he mentions Noach who was righteous in his generation. At the time to enter the Ark, Hashem closed the door behind Noach and did not let him watch destruction of the evil people. In other words, since even for the righteous Noach there was no permission to stare at the destruction, more so for the controversial person like Lot and his family.

Additionally, R'Moshe mentions 2 practical reasons regarding real danger when looking at the fire:

  1. Ramban on Bereshis 19:17:

Looking upon the atmosphere of a plague and all contagious diseases is very harmful, and they may cleave to him. Even the thought of them is harmful. Therefore, the leper is isolated and dwells alone. (Vayikra 13:40).

  1. The fire of sulfur and salt additionally contained poisonous salt which is extremely dangerous for the eyes (Sodomite salt). The poisonous steams from the fire were were a real danger as they hit the face, but not the back of people running away, even if the wind blew in their direction.

title: What issurim are involved in putting a pin through material on Shabbos?
content:
# What issurim are involved in putting a pin through material on Shabbos? ## Frage

The question is about putting a pin through material on Shabbos for example to pin on a brooch onto a garment. I think there are 3 situations:

1] the material is non-woven; putting in the pin will remove material where the pin goes in.

2] the material is tight woven; putting in the pin will disturb the weave permanently.

3] the material is loosely woven; the pin can be inserted in the spaces in the weave.

I would assume that [1] is a rabbinic issur of כל המקללין פטורים. I imagine [3] is allowed. I don't know about [2].

What issurim are involved in putting a pin through material on Shabbos?

title: A question on rejoicing in the downfall of enemies
content:
# A question on rejoicing in the downfall of enemies ## Frage

Sanhedrin 39b says:

At that time the ministering angels desired to recite a song before God. God said to them: My handiwork [the Egyptians] are drowning in the sea, and you sing a song before Me? Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina says: God does not rejoice in their downfall, but He causes others to rejoice.

Why does God "cause" (note: not "allow") people to rejoice at the downfall of their enemies, but refrains from rejoicing Himself? If the lesson is that we can rejoice in our victory but not in the pain inflicted on the enemy, why wouldn't that apply to God as well?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

1). Rashi states there "שנאכם" That the others are the "enemies" who rejoice.

Presumably this means that you can praise Hashem over being saved, like the Jews at the splitting of the sea.

2). ויאמר שמואל (Sanhedrin 39b) similarly: The angels praise Hashem over his might and this is inappropriate because it is like praising "vengance". But the Jews are praising Hashem over the salvation.

Now it makes sense why Hashem nor the Angels would "sing" or "enjoy" since they are not "saved" via this act of strength.

3). Chid''a (Rosh David, Parsha Beshalach 54) says, that the angels cannot rejoice at the moment of punishment, but after the נגמר הדין (literally: end of judgement) the punishment is over and the miracle is revealed it is appropriate to sing Shira even for the angels and presumably this might apply to Hashem as well?

title: What is the origin and history of Nusach Roma?
content:
# What is the origin and history of Nusach Roma? ## Frage

This year I visited Italy. There I found that, at least in Rome, the Jewish community uses a unique prayer order that differs greatly from other nuschaot, like Sephardic and Ashkenazic. Does Rome’s nusach predate others still in use? What are the major differences that make it unique? Also, why did the Italians continue to keep their own nusach?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The description of nussach Roma or Italian Rite is presented in the article by Etan Fiorino based on the introduction to the Siddur Benè Roma by Rav Riccardo Di Segni. Some shortened adaptation of the article to answer the OP question is as follows:

Italian Jewish community account a continuous settlement on the Apennine (Italian) peninsula for over twenty-two centuries. Traditional Hebrew name fo Italy - אי טל-י-ה - I-tal-yah - "Island of Divine Dew". Italian Jewish community follows traditions that are different from either Sephardi or Ashkenazi rites, which sets it apart from other communities in the Diaspora.

At present, it is kept alive only by a small population spread between Italy, Israel, and the Americas. It is currently maintained in Rome, Turin, and Milan, while in Florence and Venice it has merged with Sephardic and Ashkenazic traditions which imposed a different flavor... Until the Shoah, there were Italian synagogues in Mediterranean communities such as Salonica, but the devastation of those communities by the Nazis obliterated the last vestiges of Italian congregations that dated back hundreds of years. Today, outside of Italy, the Italian rite is only practiced in the Conegliano Synagogue in Jerusalem. The presence of Italian rabbis in cities including New York, Boston and Tokyo contributes to foster interest in this heritage.

... Italian Jews have kept a unique set and order of prayers, cantillation style and original liturgical songs... They also developed their own specific legal codes, Judeo-Italian dialects and folkloric traditions that are not found elsewhere. ... This multilayered set of traditions, melodies, liturgical repertoire and cantillation style is known by different names: minhag Qahal Qadosh Roma (“of the sacred community of Rome”); minhag lo’ez or lo’azim (literally: “those who speak a foreign language”, probably in Latin); or minhag Benè Roma (“of the sons of Rome”), indicating the original centrality of Rome.

Elements of the Italian nusach, one can find in the work of Sa'adia Gaon, who was born in Eretz Israel, lived in Egypt and Babylonia. It is believed that Italian nussach is one of the vestiges of the nussach of Eretz Israel, while the Babylonian rites, represented by Seder Rav Amram Gaon, became more authoritative in the Sephardi and Ashkenazi world. The rites became nore normalized around 700 CE, "due to a strong trend towards normalization of the liturgy and establishment of accepted practices emerged, leading to the development of a more fixed structure and set of prayers."

By the Middle Ages, the prayer service had become relatively fixed. ... With the development of the printing press and further standardization of the liturgy, among the first printed Hebrew texts was the Soncino prayerbook of the Italian rite, published in 1486.

Italy occupies central geographic location and, for the most part, historically it provided relatively hospitable environment for Jewish life. Many waves of immigrants from both Ashkenazi and Sephardi world, came to Italy, where they opened own synagogues next to the local Italian ones.

Although Italian Jews have clung to their distinctive liturgy even when outnumbered by Ashkenazim or Sephardim, in this environment, cross-fertilization in liturgical practices was inevitable. Thus, in spite of the perceivable distinction of the Italian rite today, when taking a closer look at it, we discover that through centuries of migrations and encounters, the original Italian canon has absorbed a significant amount of traits from other Jewish worlds. Neverteless, the Italian nusach retains much of its distinctive character that remains cherished by Italian Jews wherever they may live.

References

  • Rav Samuel David Luzzatto (Shadal), Introduction (Mavò) to the Machazor benè Roma, Livorno 1856, 2
  • Daniel Goldschmidt, “Minhag benè Roma”, Tel Aviv 1965
  • I.Y.Kohn, “Bibliografia shel machazorim wesiddurè tefilla italiani”, in Mavò 1965

Italian Machazorim

  • Italian Machazor, Soncino e Casalmaggiore, 1485-86
  • Machazor di rito italiano secondo gli usi di tutte le Comunità, curated by Rav Menachem Emanuele Artom, Roma 1998-Jerusalem 2005
  • Italian Siddùr curated by Rav Panzieri, 1935
  • Siddur di rito italiano secondo l’uso delle Comunità di Roma e di Milano, curated by Rav Riccardo Di Segno and Rav Elia Richetti, Morashà Milano, 2002

title: What major international cities, with a significant Jewish presence, lack any eruv?
content:
# What major international cities, with a significant Jewish presence, lack any eruv? ## Frage

When I visited Rome this year I was aware that it had no kosher eruv in the Jewish area. Many observant Jewish tourists seemed unaware of the Shabbos prohibitions when there is no eruv, and used strollers, etc., in violation of Halacha. This problem is not limited to European capitals, but even large areas of New York have no eruv (and the crowded city is considered by most poskim to be incapable of having an eruv). Can anyone list tourist/business destinations where one should assume there is no eruv anywhere in the metropolis?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Wikipedia’s list of cities with eruvim is a good starting point Among major cities in Europe with no Eruv are: Paris, Rome, Florence, Zurich, Prague, Lisbon, Madrid, Edinburgh and Dublin.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

There are several eruvin in London, covering large parts of North West and North East London but not in the city centre. Not all eruvin in London satisfy the requirements of the strictly Orthodox/Charedi, however. I hope this is useful.

title: Signs that someone's kindness is real, and not just virtue signalling
content:
# Signs that someone's kindness is real, and not just virtue signalling ## Frage

I am looking at Torah lessons that enable one to assess if someone's kindness is genuine and not just a front for the sake of honour.

For example, if they are kind towards homeless people, but not kind to their family, maybe the Torah has something to say about that? (see the intro to Garden of Wisdom)

Do we have any statements of Chazal that help us assess this? For bonus points, practical advice would be also provided, e.g. how to improve one's own (or educate others') situation from being kind only for honour, to being kind lishma

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Why does it matter whether kindness is sincere or not, applies to everybody you know or not? It's action that matters, not intent. The Talmud [Kiddushin 40a] says:

Evil intention is not combined with deed, [there is no punishment for mere intention], for it is said: "If I saw iniquity in my heart, The Lord would not hear." [Ps. 66:18]. [Evil] intention which bears fruit [i.e., which is followed by action] the Holy One, blessed be He, combines with deed, [punishing both]. [Evil] intention which does not bear fruit the Holy One, blessed be He, does not combine with deed [and there is therefore no punishment].

Here there is not even evil intention, only incompletely good intention, so this applies in spades. Partial observance, or observance for the wrong reasons, is always better than no observance at all.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

I don't believe there is any way to truly assess if someone's kindness is true and not for the sake of honor. Only Moshiach will be able to judge a person's true essence, and not be fooled by the senses (Yeshayahu 11:3) and of the seven things that are hidden from man's knowledge, one is what is in the heart of another (Bereishis Rabbah 65:12). However, not only are we unable to tell the intents behind someone's kindness, the Talmud seems to have many anecdotes that would appeal to those who do kindness Lo-Lishmah, speaking on matters of Olam Haba and Gehinnom, informing the reader how they will be rewarded with certain kindnesses. This information would not appeal to someone who does good deeds for no reward and want to do mitzvot simply Lishmah. It would seem that the Talmud wants as many readers as possible to add as much kindness as possible to the world, and is not bothered by intent. As Arachin 16b says:

A person should always engage in Torah and mitzvot even Lo-Lishmah, as through Lo-Lishmah, one will come to do them Lishmah.

Comparing intentions vs actions, the Nefesh HaChaim concludes "the essential part of all Mitzvot are the details of their physical performance" (Shaar 1, Perek 22) and that "purity of thought only complements the act of the mitzvah" (Perakim, Perek 5). Furthermore, one should not not chide a lifelong learner who is clearly doing it for their own prestige, because there is an assumption they had a moment of Lishmah within a learning session, and those tiny moments within each session elevated all their learning (Perakim, Perek 4). While the Nefesh HaChaim refers only to learning Torah in that instance, perhaps we can apply this also to mitzvot (see below, second to last paragraph).

In terms of how to improve and do kindness Lishmah, the best antidote is as mentioned above, to do many kindnesses Lo-Lishmah, because it will bring you to Lishmah. For example, it is better to give money to the homeless painfully than not at all. If one keeps doing it, it goes from painful to a habit. If they keep at it, it goes from a habit to a joy, and then to a highlight of the day. Another powerful antidote is daily Torah learning. As Kiddishim 30b says:

I created the yezter hara and I created for it the Torah as an antidote, and if you busy yourself with Torah you will not be delivered into its hand

Related, Midrash Tehillim 1:15:

Rabbi Eliezer says, "The people of Israel said before the Holy One, blessed be He, Master of the Universe, we want to engage in Torah day and night, but we have no free time." The Holy One, blessed be He, said to them, "Perform the mitzvah of tefillin, and I will consider it as if you were engaged in Torah day and night."

Not to deviate too far from the subject, but one of the reasons why Tefillin has this ability is because it has the power to transform mitzvot done Lo-Lishmah to Lishmah. Here is the explanation of that idea.

The big barrier to doing kindness Lishmah is the Yetzar Hara. The Yetzar Hara is the ego and its drive towards honor (Bereishis Rabbah 9:7). As a result, the best remedy is to cultivate humility. Advice on how to cultivate humility is found in Rebbe Nachman's Likutei Etzot, Iggeret HaRamban, Rabbi Sacks has a fantastic article on humility, Mesilas Yesharim is on how to attain humility, Chovot HaLevavot has an excellent chapter on it, and there is much more. Thank you for your time, and thank you for your excellent question.

title: Ma'agel Tov of the Chida: why was the sefer called "the good circle"?
content:
# Ma'agel Tov of the Chida: why was the sefer called "the good circle"? ## Frage

The book Ma'agal Tov is essentially the personal diary of Rabbi Chida, in which he recorded the events that occurred during his travels to European countries on a mission from the Hebron community. This journey lasted for about five years, from 1753 to 1758. Later, he continued writing about his second trip to Europe, which took place from 1772 to 1778. The initial purpose of this diary was to document the miracles and kindnesses of Hashem that occurred during his mission. However, over time, he began to include other personal experiences and the journal expanded, especially when he wrote about his second journey, becoming more of a general diary. (Ma'agel Tov, Hakdamah, p. 13-14)

In my edition of the Ma'agel Tov of the Chida (Shira-Mishor, Rabbi Assaf Raviv), in the introduction, it does not give any information on why the Chida chose especially for his sefer to be called "the good circle" (English for Ma'agel Tov). Does anyone know why the Chida chose for this title and what the meaning behind it is?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

The name of the book is from Proverbs 2:9, and the literal meaning (in the Biblical Hebrew sense) is "good path" (not "good circle"). Since there is no further explanation of the name in the short introduction, I can only guess the reason is that a reference to a path is appropriate for a travelogue.

title: Is there an obligation for a Beit Din to explain their psak?
content:
# Is there an obligation for a Beit Din to explain their psak? ## Frage

When a Beit Din issues a ruling, are the judges required to provide the reasoning behind their ruling?

Is the ruling valid (meaning, must it be followed) if no explanation was provided? Can the loser claim that the ruling is wrong or invalid on the basis of a missing full ruling?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 10)

Judges are required to give the reason behind their ruling upon request. According to the Shulchan Aruch (Choshen Mishpat 14:4), this is the case even if the judge isn't asked explicitly but one of the parties suspects the ruling given isn't right.

According to the Rama (there), the losing party is still required to pay immediately, even before the ruling is written down, and the ruling can be reversed if it turns out to be incorrect. Whether the explanation has to be delivered orally before the payment isn't mentioned, so I'm not sure, but I notice that it's absent from the formula איש פלוני אתה זכאי איש פלוני אתה חייב (Choshen Mishpat 19:1). If the losing party wants to appeal to another court, the document they can request is required to list only the claims of both parties and the ruling, without the reasons (and the loser would, of course, appeal based on the ruling being incorrect, not based on the lack of an explanation).
