title: Why the wait to buy Marath HaMachpelah area
content:
# Why the wait to buy Marath HaMachpelah area ## Frage

Why did Avraham Avinu wait till Sarah Immeinu's death to buy the area of Marath HaMachpelah? It was known to be a special place to him, so it would make sense that he would have tried to acquire it the moment he had liquid cash in hand. Does anyone know of any info that shows that he tried to acquire that area before hand?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

The background is mentioned in the Zohar 1:127b

It notes there that even though Avraham desired the cave before Sarah died he only made a move to buy it when Sarah died so that they would not take advantage of his interest. When Sarah died he realised the time was right to claim it. Had Efron seen in the cave what Avraham saw he would never had sold it.

As a result, Avraham acted with wisdom, he did not ask for the cave but rather requested:

תְּנ֨וּ לִ֤י אֲחֻזַּת־קֶ֙בֶר֙ עִמָּכֶ֔ם

Grant me an estate for a burial site with you (Bereishis 23:4)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

The Malbim (footnote to his commentary to Bereishis 23:20) has a fascinating explanation about why the Torah makes such a big deal about the purchase - that Avraham wanted thereby to demonstrate the fundamental principles of the eternity of the soul and of resurrection (and that therefore the deceased can't just be buried anywhere; he further explains that the layout of the cave, "a lower floor and an upper one above it," symbolizes earthly life and the spiritual realms that surmount it).

Since at Sarah's death "everyone stoppped their work and came to pay their respects to Sarah" (Rashi on 23:10), Avraham may have waited for just such an opportunity, when he could publicize these points to the widest audience possible.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

I haven’t seen the question addressed explicitly but seeing how the Rishonim explain the words גֵּֽר־וְתוֹשָׁ֥ב אָֽנֹכִ֖י עִמָּכֶ֑ם seems to provide the answer. He did not have easy ability to buy the property an earlier date. Prior to his reaching תוֹשָׁ֥ב status which he didn’t necessarily have all along (he also calls himself גֵּֽר) they would not have sold real estate to him while viewing him as a foreign investor. Even if he would have bought it he would have had difficulty making it into a burial spot later on anyway. The Chizkuni says the reason he assembled everyone and told them what he is looking to do with the property instead of just dealing with Efron is because he needed permission from everyone to turn a plot of land into a burial spot. (they must have had zoning laws back then too). Such permission would be a lot easier to get as an actual resident currently looking to bury a relative than it would be as a stranger who isn’t sure he is going to remain there but is looking to bury someone there at a unknown future date.

Rashi says on the words גֵּֽר־וְתוֹשָׁ֥ב אָֽנֹכִ֖י עִמָּכֶ֑ם that he didn’t have to buy it all. Hashem gave him all of Eretz Yisroel. Had they refused to sell it, he would taken due to his legal ownership rights. Therefore buying it was probably never of any importance to him.

title: Why did Yitzchak avinu need to go through the Akkeida?
content:
# Why did Yitzchak avinu need to go through the Akkeida? ## Frage

Discussions of Avraham's trials explain how each test revealed to Avraham and the whole world a certain new quality of faith that he had. The Midrash Bereshis Rabba 56:8 also quoted by Rashi on Bereshis 22:12 seems to say that the Akkeida test was also supposed to be a test for Yitzchak:

אָמַר רַבִּי אַחָא הִתְחִיל אַבְרָהָם תָּמֵהַּ, אֵין הַדְּבָרִים הַלָּלוּ אֶלָּא דְבָרִים שֶׁל תֵּמַהּ, אֶתְמוֹל אָמַרְתָּ (בראשית כא, יב): כִּי בְיִצְחָק יִקָּרֵא לְךָ זָרַע, חָזַרְתָּ וְאָמַרְתָּ (בראשית כב, ב): קַח נָא אֶת בִּנְךָ, וְעַכְשָׁיו אַתְּ אָמַר לִי (בראשית כב, יב): אַל תִּשְׁלַח יָדְךָ אֶל הַנַּעַר, אֶתְמְהָא. אָמַר לוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא אַבְרָהָם (תהלים פט, לה): לֹא אֲחַלֵּל בְּרִיתִי וּמוֹצָא שְׂפָתַי לֹא אֲשַׁנֶּה. כְּשֶׁאָמַרְתִּי לְךָ קַח נָא אֶת בִּנְךָ, לֹא אָמַרְתִּי שְׁחָטֵהוּ, אֶלָּא וְהַעֲלֵהוּ, לְשֵׁם חִבָּה אָמַרְתִּי לָךְ, אֲסִקְתֵּיהּ וְקִיַּמְתָּ דְּבָרַי, וְעַתָּה אַחֲתִינֵיהּ.

[נסח אחר: משלו משל למלך שאמר לאוהבו העלה את בנך על שלחני, הביאו אותו אוהבו וסכינו בידו, אמר המלך וכי העלהו לאכלו אמרתי לך, העלהו אמרתי לך מפני חבתו. הדא הוא דכתיב (ירמיה יט, ה): ולא עלתה על לבי, זה יצחק. ]

Rabbi Aḥa said: Abraham began to express his astonishment, [saying to God]: ‘These events are nothing short of bewildering. Yesterday You said: “For it is through Isaac that will be called your descendants” (Genesis 21:12), then You said: “Take you your son […and offer him up]” (Genesis 22:2), and now You say to me: “Do not extend your hand against the lad”? This is bewildering.’ The Holy One blessed be He said to Abraham: ‘“I will not violate My covenant, nor alter the utterance of My lips” (Psalms 89:35) – when I said to you: “Take you your son,” I did not say: “Slaughter him,” but rather, “take him up.” I said this to you in affection. You have taken him up and fulfilled My words, now take him down.’

[Another version: They gave a parable of a king who said to his beloved one: "Bring your son up to my table." The beloved one brought him, with a knife in his hand. The king said to him: "Did I tell you to bring him up in order to slaughter him? I told you to bring him up because of my affection for him." This is as it is written (Jeremiah 19:5) "It never entered my mind" – this refers to Isaac.]

Additionally, gemara Sanhedrin 107a teaches

אמר רב יהודה אמר רב לעולם אל יביא אדם עצמו לידי נסיון שהרי דוד מלך ישראל הביא עצמו לידי נסיון ונכשל אמר לפניו רבש"ע מפני מה אומרים אלהי אברהם אלהי יצחק ואלהי יעקב ואין אומרים אלהי דוד אמר אינהו מינסו לי ואת לא מינסית לי אמר לפניו רבש"ע בחנני ונסני שנאמר (תהלים כו, ב) בחנני ה' ונסני וגו'

Rav Yehuda says that Rav says: A person should never bring himself to undergo an ordeal, as David, king of Israel, brought himself to undergo an ordeal and failed. David said before God: Master of the Universe, for what reason does one say in prayer: God of Abraham, God of Isaac, and God of Jacob, and one does not say: God of David? God said to David: They have undergone ordeals before Me, and you have not undergone an ordeal before Me. David said before Him: Examine me and subject me to an ordeal, as it is stated: “Examine me, Lord, and subject me to an ordeal; try my kidneys and my heart” (Psalms 26:2).

The Artscroll comment states:

The Patriarchs earned the priviledge of having My name affixed to theirs because they withstood all the tests of faith to which they were subjected. Abraham was subjected to 10 tests (Avos 5:3 and Avos deRabbi Nassan 33:2). Isaac was ready and willing to be slaughtered as an offering at My behest (Bereshis 22). Jacob endured a life of suffering, yet he persevered in his faith (Rashi to Bereshis 43:14, Sanhedrin 111a). You David, on the other hand, have never been subjected to a test of faith as severe as those to which the Patriarchs were subjected.

Why did Yitzchak have to go through the Akkeida, and what exactly it revealed to the world regarding him?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Arizal says Yitschak was misaken Adams Chait of ritzicha by the Akeida when he sacrificed his life for hashem.

(Arizal explains how each of the Avos were misaken different sins of Adam) (Toras chida , Pnei dovid begining of Vaetza)

title: Why shouldn't the Israelites have been asleep when God gave the Torah?
content:
# Why shouldn't the Israelites have been asleep when God gave the Torah? ## Frage

On Shavuot eve, we have a custom of staying up all night to study Torah, to make amends because, when the Israelites were about to receive the Torah at dawn, they were sleeping, and God had to awaken them with thunder and lightning. The Midrash [Song of Songs Rabbah 1:12] even says that God taunted them through the mouth of Isaiah, saying:

Why is it that when I came, no man was there; when I called, no one was there to answer? [Is. 50:2]

This is not in the Torah. The Torah [Ex. 19:16] only says it happened "בִּֽהְיֹ֣ת הַבֹּ֗קֶר -- When morning came into being", i.e. at dawn. Why shouldn't the Israelites be sleeping as dawn breaks?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Rabbi Yaakov Chaim Goldwicht z"l (אספת מערכות פרשת יתרו - sorry, no available link) has a lengthy and deep lecture to explain why they felt it important to sleep. Without delving into his words again, this is in short, and on a superficial level, the way I remember them. Any unclarity is my fault. The reason why they went to sleep was not due to an indifference to the forthcoming Revelation. On the contrary. They thought it was an essential preparation. Whilst awake, we can only achieve a limited amount of Torah knowledge, as our physicality acts as a wall between the spiritual world where the knowledge of תורה resides. That barrier disappears greatly whilst asleep, which is why all prophets, besides Mozes who was constantly on a high spiritual level, received their prophecies in a stage of sleep/trance. The knowledge attained whilst asleep can then be further developed upon awaking. In fact, many Torah giants throughout all generations, after they had toiled in Torah with all their might during the day, but were still left with unresolved questions, merited to a solution to their questions during the short sleep which they allowed themselves. To be sure, this only applies to people who use their awake hours to toil in Torah. Those who waste their days, will not become more knowledgeable whilst asleep. The Jewish people had travelled 49 days towards the giving of the Torah. During all that time they were preparing for that great Divine Revelation. However, they thought that they would be incapable to be grasp those high revelations whilst awake. Whilst their body was “dressed” on their soul. And indeed, when they eventually heard the first words of the ten commandments, they, in their physical state, couldn't cope with it. That is why they went to sleep. But they were wrong. The words of Torah can only be handed over with the full cooperation of the recipient and for that one has to be awake. What made them make that mistake? Here human nature comes to play. Perhaps, deep down, there was an element of laziness involved. By staying up Shavuos night we want to be repair that small element of laziness and thus merit to absorb the full measure of spirituality our soul is capable off.

title: Derivation of the number 600,000 in Zohar
content:
# Derivation of the number 600,000 in Zohar ## Frage

I believe that there is a derivation of the 600,000 root souls of the Jewish people in the Zohar. My own Rav couldn't remember where exactly but he believes it is connected to the 6 emotional Sefirot (as is explained in Shaar Hagilgulim 17:1), and some sort of shlemut, through hitkalelut, of the Sefirot (it would have to be 10 x 10 x 10 x 10 x 10, but that would need a justification).

Does anyone know of any source (doesn't have to be Zohar) that derives the 600,000 in this way (or similar)?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

A relevant source is Sefer Hamaamarim 5626, p. 112:

אך כדי שיומשך הוא״ו של שם הוי׳ צריך שיהי׳ כלול מיו״ד ה״א של הוי׳ ואופן ההתכללות הוא כשהוא״ו כלול מיו״ד ה׳ פעמים הוא מספר ס״ר...‏

In order for the Vov of the Name Havayah to be drawn forth, it must inter-incorporate the Yud and Hei of Havayah. This incorporation is done when the Vov is multiplied by Yud, Hei times (i.e., 6 x 105), equaling 600,000...

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Another source that explains it more directly is Sefer Maamarim 5566, שבת פ׳ במדבר that the 5 fold subdivision is

due to the the five chasadim that magnify. And it is necessary that through each of these inclusions something new will come into each middah, etc. And these are the particulars of the number of names that are in the middot of Zeir Anpin in particular. That is, when they divide into their detailed particulars to become in the aspect of a complete partzuf, etc. And they are all names of Havayah, for every name of Havayah is in Ze'ir Anpin, since He is entirely the aspect of chasadim, as it is written, "For He remembered His kindness"...

[see there for the full explanation]

title: Penimiut of Gevura is "Rechovot" - what's the explanation?
content:
# Penimiut of Gevura is "Rechovot" - what's the explanation? ## Frage

I've seen an idea from the Besht several times, e.g. in Keter Shem Tov 1:62:

וז"ש אם תשקור. וכל הבארות אשר חפרו בימי אברהם שהם צנור החסד ואהבה סתמום במות אברהם וישב יצחק ויחפור באר וצנור היראה כמדתו ע"כ ויריבו לאמר לנו המים פי' אנחנו רוצים לעבוד ה' ע"י מדת אהבה כי יש יראה חצוניות ג"כ. ע"כ ויחפור באר אחרת ירא' פנימית ונק' רחובות כי הרחיב ה' לנו ופנימיות היראה נק' רחובות והבן. וכאשר נודע לבעלי בינה לעשות יחוד גם בספורי דברים עם חבירו ולהסי' העצבות יפקח באיזה עסק והוא ג"כ יחוד כו' ע"ש על דרך הני תרי בדחי שהיו מייחדין ומעלין העולמות בכל עניני עה"ז:

All the wells that were dug in the days of Abraham, which are conduits of kindness and love, were stopped up after Abraham’s death. Isaac then re-dug a well, representing the conduit of awe, in accordance with his attribute. This is why it says, "And they quarreled over it, saying, 'The water is ours.'" The meaning is: "We want to serve God through the attribute of love," because there also exists an external form of awe. Therefore, Isaac dug another well, representing inner awe, which is called Rechovot ("spaciousness"). For through this, "God has made room for us." Inner awe is called Rechovot. Reflect on this. As is known to those with understanding, one can create unity even through speaking with a friend, or through diverting sadness by engaging in a certain task. This, too, constitutes unity, as mentioned there, in reference to the two jesters (anei trei bedichai), who created unity and elevated worlds through all worldly matters.

Clearly, I am not a person of understanding, but we have had 300 years since then to come up with an explanation, so perhaps it's ok for me to ask:

What is the explanation? This Toldot Yaakov piece offers a mashal, but I would still appreciate a deeper and more intuitive understanding of what is "Rechovot", and what is the point that the Besht is trying to make here?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Rabbi Manis Friedman explains it in this video, which is based on a Sicha given on Shabbat Parashat Acharei 5741, and is found in Likkutei Sichot vol. 30 p. 103FF.

The basic idea is as follows. There is Chesed, and there is Gevura. Traditionally we understand them to be opposites: Chesed is about closeness, and Gevura is about distance. When I want to bridge gaps and get close, I am engaged in Chesed, but when I want to put limits and restrictions, I am engaged in Gevura.

However, the truth is when one engages in the process of restriction, the end result is total bittul; total humility, and this, ironically, causes spaciousness within, rather than restriction, because one has risen above limitation.

One way Rabbi Friedman put it, that I really like, is that when we receive Chesed, we feel whole, complete, rich. If even more chesed were to be applied, we wouldn't be able to take it, because we are already full. Indeed, if more Chesed were thrust upon us, it would "blow our fuse", the fuse of our ego, and that would unlock our capacity, creating more space to receive more goodness than we ever thought possible.

Gevura, ultimately, is called "severity", because it is "so much good, it is severe". Unlimited, infinite Chesed.

He also explains how this is how we grow, when we start to see beyond our own limitations. People usually can't imagine themselves being in a better place, and it's that lack of imagination (this is where Binah comes in), that lack of "Rechovot", that actually prevents them from achieving that better place. I highly recommend the short talk.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Your question is a good one and is essentially asking what does the Ba'al Shem Tov mean about this particular type of well, which the Patriarch Yitzchok dug and was called Rechovot (רחבות)

So first, let's look at the specific wording of the teaching from the Ba'al Shem Tov.

וכל הבארות אשר חפרו בימי אברהם שהם צנור החסד ואהבה סתמום במות אברהם וישב יצחק ויחפור באר וצנור היראה כמדתו ע"כ ויריבו לאמר לנו המים פי' אנחנו רוצים לעבוד ה' ע"י מדת אהבה כי יש יראה חצוניות ג"כ. ע"כ ויחפור באר אחרת ירא' פנימית ונק' רחובות כי הרחיב ה' לנו ופנימיות היראה נק' רחובות והבן

And all the wells which were dug during the days of Avraham, which were an irrigation channel (of the qualities of) kindness and love חסד ואהבה, they (the Philistines, who are from the Sitra Achre) sealed with the death of Avraham.

Yitzchok returned and dug a well and irrigation channel of (the quality of) the Fear, corresponding to his constitution.

Therefore, (because the constitution of Yitzchok is the opposite of Avraham, meaning from the side of Severity גבורה) and they quarreled (meaning the Philistines quarreled) saying, the water belongs to us. (That absolute Severity has a connection to the Sitra Achre and the Philistines. They gain sustenance from it, so to speak. This is the concept of the Tzimtzum HaRishon through which Creation Ex-Nihilo occurred and the Universe of Tohu and the Sitra Achre.)

This means, we want to serve G-d through the aspect of Love, that has an external aspect of Fear too.

Therefore, (because Yitzchok, whose constitution is from the side of Gevurah, the opposite of Avraham, whose constitution is from the side of Chesed) he dug another well, Inner Fear, and called it Rechovot, because now G-d has made room for us (Bereshit 26:22). And understand that the quality of Inner Fear is called Rechovot רחבות.

To understand this on a deeper level we will turn to the teaching of Rabbi Yaacov Tzvi Yolles in Kehillat Yaacov, in connection to רחבת and רחובות.

רחבת: ראשי תיבות למפרע תוהו בהו חשך רוח. ועלייהו שרייה שדי, צבאות, אלהים-יהוה כמבואר בזוהר בראשית. וזהו סוד והארץ הנה רחבת, והארץ הוא זעיר ונוקבא כמו ויהוה הוא ובית דינו. והוא סוד יהוה-אלהים. הנה הוא ראשי תיבות ה״יסוד, נ״צח, ה״וד והוא סוד שדי צבאות והן שורים על רחבת, ר״וח ח״שך, ב״הו, ת״והו. ואנון נחש, שרף, עקרב, צמאון כמבואר בתקונים דף קכג:ב

Rachevet (רחבת): Is the reverse acronym of Tohu (Void) ת׳הו, Vohu (Formless) ב׳הו, Choshech (Darkness) ח׳שך, Ruach (Storm Wind) ר׳וח. Upon them rule the Holy names: Shaddai, Tz'va'ot, and יהוה pronounced Elohim, like is clarified in the Zohar, parshat Bereshit. And this is the secret of, "the land is large enough for them" (Bereshit 34:21). The word, "the land" used here means Ze'ir Anpin and Nukvah, like with the expression of the Sages, G-d and His Court. And this is the secret of G-d's name יהוה when it is pronounced Elohim.

The word, "Behold" הנה is the acronym: HaYesod, Netzach, Hod. This is the secret of the Holy names Shaddai and Tz'va'ot. They rule over Rachevet, which is the acronym for Storm Wind, Darkness, Formlessness, Void. These correspond to Nachash, Saraph, Scorpion and Thirst (in regard to the Sitra Achra) like is clarified in the Tikkunim, page 123b.

רחובות נקראת בינה שהוא רחב נחלה בלי מצרים והפרדס כתב בסוד התפשטותה על הבנים נקראת רחובות בסוד ברחבות פלגי מים. ויש לבין רחובות גימטריא בינה פשות ומלא בינה בי׳ת, יו׳ד, נו׳ן, ה׳י וב׳ כוללים. גם רחובות עם הכולל גימטריא בינה עלמא דאתי. שהבינה נקראת כן כנודע. ומבואר בזוהר תולדות שהוא בחינת יסוד דבינה.

Rechovot is called Binah. That it is a broad inheritance without restrictions. and the Pardes (Rimonim 13:3:3) wrote that it pertains to the secret of it spreading out (meaning widely disseminating) by the offspring, which is called Rechovot pertaining to the secret of streams of water in the streets. (Mishlei 5:16)

It is necessary to understand that Rechovot (רחובות, which is gematria 622) is the gematria of Binah in its plain form combined with its Miluy when counting the 2 whole names.

בינה, בי׳ת, יו׳ד, נו׳ן, ה׳י

Also, Rechovot (gematria 622) is the gematria of Binah is the World To Come (בינה עלמא דאתי) (It is referring to the time of the resurrection of the dead.), when including the count for the whole phrase and Binah is called this, like is known. And it is clarified in the Zohar, parshat Toldot, that it (Rechovot) is the aspect of Yesod of Binah.

רחובות הנהר נקראת גם כן בינה שהוא סוד הנהר היוצא מעדן ושם הוא רחב נחלה בלי מצרים. מה שאין כן כשבא לשש קצוות דזעיר הוא מצומצם. ויש לבין רחובות הנהר גימטריא אור מתנוצץ הוא בחינת בינה כמו שכתב בערכו: עיין שם

Rechovot HaNahar (the breadth and depth of the river) Binah is thus called, because it is the secret of the River that goes forth from Eden (Bereshit 2:10). And there (in Eden) it is a broad and deep inheritance without limitations or restrictions. This is not the case when it comes into six dimensional space (of Zei'r Anpin). It is condensed (and contracted. This is the same language used in Kabbalah to describe the beginning of Creation Ex-Nihilo and the Tzimtzum HaRishon. This is the quantum transition from Absolute Infinite reality to Finite Existence.).

And it is necessary to understand that Rechovot HaNahar, 622, when including the count for the whole phrase, (רחובות הנהר) is gematria Exploding Light (אור מתנוצץ), which is the aspect of Binah, like is written in the section about Binah, see there for details. (This is alluding to the concept referred to in contemporary Physics for the beginning of the universe (the Big Bang Theory).)

For those who would like to learn on an even greater depth including the concept of stopping up the wellsprings, see Sefer Ner Mitzvah v'Torah Ohr by the second Lubavitcher Rebbe (the Mitteler Rebbe, Rabbi Dovber, together with the commentary of Rabbi Hillel of Paritch, section Sha'ar HaYichud, chapters 25-27.

title: Free Speech - is it a Torah principle?
content:
# Free Speech - is it a Torah principle? ## Frage

Does the Torah have a principle of free speech? What is it?

Note, I am not talking about all speech, such as Lashon Hara etc. I am talking about how the term is mainly used in modern discourse; i.e. should we allow evil people to speak their evil ideas, like Neo Nazis etc.?

  • On the one hand, there's the argument for: let them speak, rather than forcing them underground, where their ideas will fester, unchallenged. Out in the open, they can be challenged, rebutted and their evil exposed.

  • On the other hand, there's the argument against: brainwashing is real, and easy; giving Hitler y'msh a microphone is what caused so much of Germany to turn Nazi. Evil people with evil ideas should not be given microphones.

So, can we draw any wisdom or rules from the Torah on how to manage this tension?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Judaism does not have a clear statement on freedom of speech. So must examine the issues one by one.

On the one hand, the Talmud itself testifies to such freedom, within broad bounds. It includes vigorous and feisty discussions, followed by minority opinions, followed by the majority opinion, which is usually the final decision. Opposing viewpoints are welcome. As we often hear, two Jews will produce three opinions. The Mishnah says:

אֵיזֶהוּ חָכָם, הַלּוֹמֵד מִכָּל אָדָם -- Who is wise? He who learns from everyone. [Avot 4:1]

However, Jewish law prohibits many types of speech for ethical and religious reasons: blaspheming God, pretending to be a prophet, speaking against the king, disrespecting a rabbi or contradicting him in private or in public [Rashi on Numbers 25:6-7], speaking ahead of someone who is wiser [Avot 5:7], cursing people, or teaching the opposite of a ruling of the Sanhedrin. The most reviled form of speech is malicious gossip, or lashon hara.

Also prohibited is being rude or insulting (Onaat devarim אוֹנָאַת דְבָרִים, literally “hurting people with words”. The Talmud says:

When the Torah states “Do not wrong one another” וְלֹ֤א תוֹנוּ֙ אִ֣ישׁ אֶת־עֲמִית֔וֹ – [Leviticus 25:17], it includes intentionally saying something that will hurt, frighten or embarrass someone. Whoever does this has no share in the World to Come. [Bava Metzia 58b-59a; Sefer HaChinuch 338; Shulḥan Arukh, Choshen Mishpat 228:1.]

Also, lies are forbidden, unless uttered to save a life, keep the peace, make people feel good, appear humble and modest, or protect oneself from loss or harm.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

I think there are two angles on this.

Unfair comparison

Free speech seems to be a democratic principle, and is a necessity in a system where "right and wrong" are not absolute (or at least, impossible to full capture, systematically), so should be something that the people can discuss and debate. Hence, the law of free speech is enshrined in constitutions etc. you can't be suppressed by force simply for saying what you believe is right or wrong.

Torah, on the other hand, is a system of right and wrong, therefore it does not allow someone to stand up and advocate for idolatry, for example. However, it does have somewhat of an equivalent - debating the Oral Law. The Oral Law has become fuzzy over time, so we have had to engage in honest debate to try to get to the bottom of the Law, but ultimately a decision should be made and adhered to, once the debate has arrived at its conclusions, and at that point we are no longer free to debate it (although we can always re-open a debate with a strong enough kashe)

Free will

The Torah explains that we are meant to have free will, and not be coerced to be good. Therefore we are given, practically, freedom of speech, and other freedoms, to a great degree. The difference is, that freedom is only for the purpose of using it for good. If it is not used for good, then, unlike democratic free speech, it can be punished. If someone wants to advocate for idolatry, they can, but they will be executed!

Sources for pretty much everything I've written here can be found in this answer: Why do Rabbis say that HaShem was mistaken and HaShem states that He was defeated and that He must obey the Rabbis?

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

Aside from the laws of Lashon haRa and cases in Mishna Chagiga 2:1, the mishna Pirkei Avos 5:17 teaches:

כָּל מַחֲלֹקֶת שֶׁהִיא לְשֵׁם שָׁמַיִם, סוֹפָהּ לְהִתְקַיֵּם. וְשֶׁאֵינָהּ לְשֵׁם שָׁמַיִם, אֵין סוֹפָהּ לְהִתְקַיֵּם. אֵיזוֹ הִיא מַחֲלֹקֶת שֶׁהִיא לְשֵׁם שָׁמַיִם, זוֹ מַחֲלֹקֶת הִלֵּל וְשַׁמַּאי. וְשֶׁאֵינָהּ לְשֵׁם שָׁמַיִם, זוֹ מַחֲלֹקֶת קֹרַח וְכָל עֲדָתוֹ:

Every dispute that is for the sake of Heaven, will in the end endure; But one that is not for the sake of Heaven, will not endure. Which is the controversy that is for the sake of Heaven? Such was the controversy of Hillel and Shammai. And which is the controversy that is not for the sake of Heaven? Such was the controversy of Korah and all his congregation.

In other words, it is not the subject of discussion, but intent of the discussion that is at the core of permissibility. For example, Korach questioned validity of Aharon's appointment to kehuna by asking about a garment with 4 corners made out of techeles. Such a question is clearly forbidden due to its intent. However, Korach could ask about the meil of Kohen Gadol, which had 4 corners and was made out of techeles, whether it was liable for tzitzis, whithout any other implications regarding anyone. That is a good question with an answer on Mi Yodeya!

title: Yisro wanting to go back to convert people: Moshe says no!
content:
# Yisro wanting to go back to convert people: Moshe says no! ## Frage

In Parshas Behaaloscha (Bamidbar 10:29), the Torah says:

And Moshe said to Ḥovav, the son of Re῾u᾽el, the Midyanite, Moshe’s father in law, We are journeying to the place of which the L-rd said, I will give it you: come thou with us, and we will do thee good: for the L-rd has spoken good concerning Yisra᾽el.

(side note: the Rabbeinu Bachya explains that Hovav refers to nobody more than Yisro).

The Zayis Raanan (Parshas Behaaloscha, p. 48b), written by the author of the Magen Avraham (Rabbi Abraham Abele Gombiner) explains that Moshe Rabbeinu was saying this as a request:

Here, the word 'na' (please) is used as a form of request. He said to him, 'If you are not coming, then please go with us, for by decree, you are not allowed to leave us.'

Why? The Yalkut Shimoni (ילקוט שמעוני על התורה תשכ״ו:ז) says:

You may think that you are increasing the honor of Hashem, but you are only diminishing it. How many converts and servants are you destined to bring under the wings of the Divine Presence?

I have trouble understanding why going back to Midian, would diminish the honor of Hashem ? The Satmar Rav in Divrei Yoel (Parshas Chayei Sarah, p. 542) explains that a righteous person always strive to bring other people close to Torah, even sinners.

How to explain all of this according to the opinion of the Zayis Raanan and the Yalkut Shimoni?

Also, the edition on Otzar is not clear and not really readable for me. Can some please provide a clear text/translation of the exact words of the Zayis Raanan? (Bonus :))

title: Studying/discussing secular philosophy on Shabbat and their relation to the Torah
content:
# Studying/discussing secular philosophy on Shabbat and their relation to the Torah ## Frage

I’m curious what the Halacha is regarding studying secular philosophy on Shabbat in order to compare and contrast it to genuine Limmud Torah, for example let’s say someone is discussing Martin Buber’s commentary on the Torah portion, and then the conversation discusses the influence of existentialists, for example Hannah Arendt and Martin Heidegger, on him and his thought.

There are general halachic concerns with secular discussion on Shabbat and I’m curious how a scenario like this should be treated.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

There are halachot of "daber davar", permitted speech on Shabbat, see OC 307:1

Ve’daber davar” (teaches us) that one’s manner of speech on Shabbos must not be the same as one’s manner of speech on a weekday. Therefore, it is prohibited to say 'I will do such and such tomorrow' or 'I will purchase this and this merchandise tomorrow'. Even idle talk should be curbed. RAMA: People who enjoy hearing stories or the latest news may speak these things on Shabbos but one who does not enjoy them may not speak them for the sake of giving pleasure to someone else.

In other words, one should aim to speak of Torah matters but, if two people enjoy secular subjects, they are allowed to discuss them.

The Mishna Brura adds (:4)

Nonetheless one must take care not to spend excessive amounts of time in such talk ... because for those not engaged in Torah study during the week, Shabbat was given primarily as a day of Torah study.

In the end it is a question of balance, between time spent on Torah matters and secular ones, and everyone should find the appropriate mix depending on his situation and what he enjoys discussing.

title: How is the World to Come preceded by suffering?
content:
# How is the World to Come preceded by suffering? ## Frage

The Talmud says:

Rabbi Shim'on ben Yoḥai says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, gave Israel three precious gifts, all of which were given only by means of suffering: Torah, the Land of Israel, and the World to Come... [Berakhot 5a]

Torah was preceded by the pain of slavery and the Land of Israel by the pain of war. But what suffering precedes the World to Come? A painful death? What if the death is not painful? Judgment? What if the judgment is favorable? The Talmud continues:

The World-to-Come, [because,] as it is written: “For the mitzvah is a lamp, the Torah is light, and the reproofs of instruction are the way of life”. [Proverbs 6:23].

I don't understand. How is the World to Come preceded by suffering?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Gra explains that gemara to mean avodas hamusar. To work on yourself and breaking your middos is the suffering the gemara is refferrimg to. (Gra qouted in fancy even shleima, propably somewhere on mishlei)

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The first answer to the OP's question comes from mishna Pirkei Avos 4:22

הוּא הָיָה אוֹמֵר, הַיִּלּוֹדִים לָמוּת, וְהַמֵּתִים לְהֵחָיוֹת, וְהַחַיִּים לִדּוֹן. לֵידַע לְהוֹדִיעַ וּלְהִוָּדַע שֶׁהוּא אֵל, הוּא הַיּוֹצֵר, הוּא הַבּוֹרֵא, הוּא הַמֵּבִין, הוּא הַדַּיָּן, הוּא עֵד, הוּא בַעַל דִּין, וְהוּא עָתִיד לָדוּן. בָּרוּךְ הוּא, שֶׁאֵין לְפָנָיו לֹא עַוְלָה, וְלֹא שִׁכְחָה, וְלֹא מַשּׂוֹא פָנִים, וְלֹא מִקַּח שֹׁחַד, שֶׁהַכֹּל שֶׁלּוֹ. וְדַע שֶׁהַכֹּל לְפִי הַחֶשְׁבּוֹן. וְאַל יַבְטִיחֲךָ יִצְרְךָ שֶׁהַשְּׁאוֹל בֵּית מָנוֹס לְךָ, שֶׁעַל כָּרְחֲךָ אַתָּה נוֹצָר, וְעַל כָּרְחֲךָ אַתָּה נוֹלָד, וְעַל כָּרְחֲךָ אַתָּה חַי, וְעַל כָּרְחֲךָ אַתָּה מֵת, וְעַל כָּרְחֲךָ אַתָּה עָתִיד לִתֵּן דִּין וְחֶשְׁבּוֹן לִפְנֵי מֶלֶךְ מַלְכֵי הַמְּלָכִים הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא:

He (R'Elazar haKapar) used to say: the ones who were born are to die, and the ones who have died are to be brought to life, and the ones brought to life are to be judged; So that one may know, make known and have the knowledge that He is God, He is the designer, He is the creator, He is the discerner, He is the judge, He the witness, He the complainant, and that He will summon to judgment. Blessed be He, before Whom there is no iniquity, nor forgetting, nor respect of persons, nor taking of bribes, for all is His. And know that all is according to the reckoning. And let not your impulse assure thee that the grave is a place of refuge for you; for against your will were you formed, against your will were you born, against your will you live, against your will you will die, and against your will you will give an account and reckoning before the King of the kings of kings, the Holy One, blessed be He.

Rashi explains the bold part:

שעל כרחך אתה נוצר. שבא לו מלאך הממונה על ההריון אצל הפרגוד שבו נשמות חקוקין ואומר לה לכי בתי עמי והכנסי במעי אשה פלונית ואומרת האיך אלך במקום הטנופת ואניח מקום טהרה כזה מיד בא מלאך ונוטלת' בעל כרחה ומכניסתה למעי אשה: ועל כרחך אתה נולד. בשעה שהגיע זמן העובר לצאת ממעי אמו ואינו רוצה לצאת משם לפי שהוא צופה מסוף העולם ועד סופו כמו שנא' בהלו נרו עלי ראשי מיד מוציאין אותו בעל כרחו משם: ועל כרחך אתה חי. לפי שיש אדם שהוא מדוכא ביסורין ובשעה שהוא ישן בלילה ואין הנשמה רוצה לחזור מפני עול הצרות שהוא סובל אומר לה הקדוש ברוך הוא חס ושלום לא אכפור באמונתי לעולם אלא אשלם לו הפקדון שהפקיד אצלי וכן הוא אומר בידך אפקיד רוחי ועל כן רגילין לומר אמת ואמונה בלילות. ועל כרחך אתה מת וכו' וכן אתה עתיד ליתן דין וחשבון בקבר עד כאן:

Against your will you are formed The angel in charge of pregnancy comes to the curtain, surrounding the place where the souls are hidden, and says to the neshamah, "Go, my daughter, and enter the inside of such and such a woman." And she says, "How can I go to such a filthy place and leave such a pure place?" Immediately an angel forcefully brings it inside the woman: Against your will you are born When the time has come for the child to emerge from its mother's womb and it does not want to leave, as it watches from one end of the world to the other end, as the saying goes, “When His lamp shined above my head, and by His light I walked through darkness” (Job 29:3) they immediately forcefully remove it from there: Against your will you are living Since there is a person who is oppressed by suffering and while he is sleeping at night and his soul does not want to return from the burden of his troubles, the Holy One, blessed be He, says to it, "I will never deny my faith, but I will repay him the deposit he deposited with me." And so the soul says, "In your hands I entrust my spirit..." (Psalms 31:6) Therefore, we are accustomed to saying "truth and faith" (before Shema) in the evening prayer. And against you will you die, etc. And so you will have to give an account in the grave up to this point:

After a child is formed he gives suffering of pregnancy to the mother. A soul living inside her is fully aware of the mother's pain and suffers with her. After a child is born it cries (suffers) from the loss of the Torah learned during pregnancy, experiences the pain of growing, from pain of getting able to digest food to pain of adjusting to society, teachers, etc. The suffering in life is common for many people. Many people die before their time because of various reasons (sins, improper lifestyle, bad eating habbits, etc.)

The second answer is midrash Bereshis Rabba 65:9

יִצְחָק תָּבַע יִסּוּרִין, אָמַר לְפָנָיו רִבּוֹן כָּל הָעוֹלָמִים אָדָם מֵת בְּלֹא יִסּוּרִים מִדַּת הַדִּין מְתוּחָה כְּנֶגְדּוֹ, מִתּוֹךְ שֶׁאַתָּה מֵבִיא עָלָיו יִסּוּרִים אֵין מִדַּת הַדִּין מְתוּחָה כְּנֶגְדּוֹ. אָמַר לוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא חַיֶּיךָ דָּבָר טוֹב תָּבַעְתָּ וּמִמְּךָ אֲנִי מַתְחִיל, מִתְּחִלַּת הַסֵּפֶר וְעַד כָּאן אֵין כְּתִיב יִסּוּרִין וְכֵיוָן שֶׁעָמַד יִצְחָק נָתַן לוֹ יִסּוּרִים, וַיְהִי כִּי זָקֵן יִצְחָק וַתִּכְהֶיןָ.

(Rabbi Yehuda bar Simon said) Isaac demanded suffering. He said before Him: ‘Master of the universe, a person dies without suffering, the attribute of justice is outstretched against him. When you bring suffering upon him, the attribute of justice is not outstretched against him.’ The Holy One blessed be He said to him: ‘As you live, you have demanded a good thing, and I will begin with you.’ From the beginning of the book until here, suffering is not written. When Isaac stood, He granted him suffering – “it was when Isaac was old, and [his eyes] dimmed.”

title: Touching dogs obstructs prayers - source?
content:
# Touching dogs obstructs prayers - source? ## Frage

One of the first things I learned in yeshiva was that there is some source that says that:

if one touches a dog, then their prayers are "held up in heaven" for 40 days.

I don't remember anything else, except I was pretty sure I heard a source quoted, or read it in a book, and either way IIRC I did test the idea, but was ultimately convinced that this is something worth committing to my memory and tagging as "legit".

However, to this day I have not found a source, and I would like to, if possible. Does anyone know where it is? I am particularly aiming to explore it from a halachic perspective, and failing that, seeking to at least understand what I am supposed to take from it, practically.

title: Why did Tunisian Jews not celebrate Purim for a long time?
content:
# Why did Tunisian Jews not celebrate Purim for a long time? ## Frage

From Jewish Virtual Library

The Jews of Tunis at that time scrupulously observed most of the festivals but did not celebrate the second day; they entirely ignored the festival of Purim, although they observed that of Hanukkah.

Moreover, I have come across similar references before.

Why did the Jews of Tunisia ignore Purim? Is there any explanation for this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 9)

Partial answer:

The JVL's source, as already mentioned by @EraserX in the comments, is the 1901 Jewish Encyclopedia. The Jewish Encyclopedia's source is Meir (Marcus) Fischer's תולדות ישרון (Toledot Yeshurun), p. 22, who writes:

"בשמונת ימי חנוכה ששו ושמחו בישועת אלהים ויפצחו רנה לרועץ אויבי בת ציון ויהללו לשם תפארתו על אשר הוביש את צוררי יהודה עד לא יכלו קום...אמנם, לא כן היה עמהם בענין ימי הפורים, כי חוץ מערי אזילא - Azila - ועבי יאקוב - Ebi-Iacub - לא ידעו ממנם אף שמץ דבר, וכאין ואפס נחשבו להם אלה, כאשר ספרו לנו כותבי קורות הימים וסופריהם.
During the eight days of Chanukah they celebrated in great cheer and joy for God's salvation and shout aloud for the destroyer of the enemies of the Daughter of Zion, and praise His magnificent Name for His felling of the enemies of Judah until they were unable to rise...However, not so was the case regarding the days of Purim, for besides the cities of Azila and Ebi-Iacub, they did not know a single thing about them, and they were thought of as meaningless in their eyes, as we are told by the chroniclers and their scribes.

Fischer listed most of his sources in a note on pp. 12-14, however they are all in foreign languages (Arabic, Latin, Spanish, French, etc), which, even with Google Translate, makes it difficult to know from where exactly he took this particular tidbit. I skimmed a couple of the books but had no luck yet.

Two possible reasons may be hinted at in Fischer's book:

  1. As he stated (p. 21), in the first several centuries CE the Jews of the Mauretania region, as he calls it (a region which includes Tunisia, Morocco, and more), only followed the Written Torah and not the Oral Torah, because they did not have the Talmud. This may explain why they were only aware of some d'Rabbanan customs.1
  2. The statement about Chanukah and Purim is included within a list of minhagim held by the Mauretania Jews in their early years, and is immediately followed by a hatred for wine and drunkenness (pp. 22-23). It's therefore possible that they had been aware of Purim but at some point their aversion to wine and wine-based merriment led them to stop keeping Purim and eventually forgetting about it.

1 See also Rambam's letter to his son which mentions that the Jews of Tunis and other Berber lands were uneducated in the Talmud and other Chazalic sources and laws. It should be noted, however, that Rabbi Meir Mazuz, when he was younger, opined that the author of the letter (Rabbi Mazuz also voiced skepticism of its association with the Rambam) referred to the Jews between Egypt and Tunis, i.e., the Jews of Libya.

title: Why is the kabalat hatorah at Purim needed?
content:
# Why is the kabalat hatorah at Purim needed? ## Frage

The Gemara (Shabbos 88a) says that at Har Sinai Bnei Yisrael might have only accepted the Torah out of coercion, which would enable them to say that their acceptance was not halachically valid. Therefore, Rava adds that they re-accepted it, with free will, at the time of the Purim story.

Why is this explanation needed when Moshe already reaffirmed their covenant with G-d in Parshat Nitzavim?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Tosafot says that even by the reaffirmation of the covenant in the plains of Moav it was considered coerced because

ע"פ הדיבור היה

it was by means of a command (from Hashem)

The Noda BiYehuda explains that a Divine command is akin to a physical coercion. Therefore, as the rest of the Tosafot explains, by the events of Purim,

קבלו מדעתם מאהבת הנס

they accepted it willingly out of love of the miracle

Note: the Noda BiYehuda argues on this and goes on a very long discussion about how we can still prove that there was coercion also in Moav, and concludes it's a machloket between Rabbi Yossi and the Rabbanan. I think the overall summary is:

  • Some hold, based on this tosafot, that this is a case of coercion because the holding up of the mountain as a barrel over their heads was a demonstration that Hashem could always do that, so it implies continual coercion.
  • He asks why holding the mountain was necessary when it is known from the time of Creation that the world would revert to nothing if the Jews didn't accept Torah
  • He answers that that condition was only on the world up until the 6th of Sivan, at which point the world was established forever by Hashem. Therefore we are just left with the problem of the implied coercion of the mountain
  • He then argues that, according to those who hold the Torh was given on the 7th of Sivan, that the holding of the mountain wasn't coercion for the future, it was only for the fear of immediate refusal after going through the intense experience of Sinai on the 7th of Sinai
  • Therefore there was no coercion at Mo'av, according to this opinion (Rabbi Yossi) and therefore no need for reacceptance in Achashverosh's time
  • Therefore the opinion that we had a reacceptance at Purim holds we got the Torah on the 6th of Sivan (Rabbanan)
  • He then diverts to a discussion about the Torah being given chatumah (as a sealed document, Rabbi Eliezer HaModai) vs megillah megillah (scroll by scroll, Rabbi Yehoshua), mentions the wider discussions of these tannaim about this issue, and whether the Megilla is Divinely inspired, and then aligns the views there with the opinions of Rabbi Yossi and Rabbanan above, respectively

title: Would a "fist bump" be considered the best option overall for respectful touching between the sexes?
content:
# Would a "fist bump" be considered the best option overall for respectful touching between the sexes? ## Frage

During Covid there developed a new habit for greeting people who were concerned about spreading germs. Instead of shaking someone's hand, you were encouraged to fist bump.

You would literally make a fist and you'd just tap knuckles as an alternative to handshaking.

That got me thinking about negiah rules in general and whether this form of touching may be the most appropriate form of touch for mixed gender situations.

I know that when it comes to touching between the sexes, opinions vary depending on rabbinical source. Some Jews refrain from handshakes at all while other authorities differentiate types of touch (as in as long as the touch isn't affection based, it isn't problematic)

Would a fist bump between sexes actually be the best option overall?

My logic is this.

Touching of hands can actually be an intimate act. The surface of the palm contains many nerve endings and these nerve endings can be stimulated through touch which may or may not be appropriate depending on the situation. Sensual hand touching is very much a practiced act.

Fist bumping circumvents the issue entirely. Our knuckles are a bony outgrowth on our hands. There are nowhere near as many nerve endings as there are on the palms of our hands. A fist bump allows two Jews of the opposite sexes to show greetings and affection without touching parts of the body which may become stimulated by skin on skin contact.

I'd argue fist bumping may actually be the best form of greeting for observant Jews (outside of no touching at all)

I'm curious as to whether this topic has been discussed and if the logic I am using follows based on contemporary interpretations of Jewish practice?

title: Inconsistent wording in Birkot Hashachar?
content:
# Inconsistent wording in Birkot Hashachar? ## Frage

Many of the blessings in Birkot Hashachar do not use the definitive article (letter ה) when ascribing an action to G-d. For example:

...בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְהֹוָה אֱלֹהֵֽינוּ מֶֽלֶךְ הָעוֹלָם

  • מַלְבִּישׁ עֲרֻמִּים - Who clothes the naked.
  • מַתִּיר אֲסוּרִים - Who releases the imprisoned.
  • זוֹקֵף כְּפוּפִים - Who straightens the bent.

But some of the blessings do:

...בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה יְהֹוָה אֱלֹהֵֽינוּ מֶֽלֶךְ הָעוֹלָם

  • הַמֵּכִין מִצְעֲדֵי גָֽבֶר - Who prepares the steps of man.

  • הַנּוֹתֵן לַיָּעֵף כֹּֽחַ - Who gives strength to the weary.

  • הַמַּעֲבִיר שֵׁנָה מֵעֵינָי וּתְנוּמָה מֵעַפְעַפָּי - Who removes sleep from my eyes and slumber from my eyelids.

Is there any reason for this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I'll give this a quick go, based on my research so far. I'll say though, I've asked around, including a few native Israeli Rabbis, and all are finding it hard to answer. I've also used a bit of cautious help from ChatGPT :)

The longer phrases have relative clauses, so the participle is introducing the relative clause. Therefore it must retain the ה

In the shorter ones it is acting as a finite verb, and therefore it can drop the ה, because it is clear the two words are connected and are determined. See this tosafot for a partial discussion on when the Torah does drop these הs, and why. Generally, it does tend to drop them often, and it sounds weird when it does not (hence this tosafot).

title: Judaism and aesthetics
content:
# Judaism and aesthetics ## Frage

Is there a religious Jewish perspective, either in terms of Halacha (ie Hiddur Mitzvah) or Hashkafa on aesthetics? If so, are there any aesthetic movements which integrate with Judaism’s criteria for proper aesthetics best? For aesthetics, I’m talking about any manifestation of art, be it writing, sculpture, music, painting etc.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

There is definitely a role for aesthetics in Judaism. In the Song at the Sea, the Jews said (Exodus 15:2) זֶ֤ה אֵלִי֙ וְאַנְוֵ֔הוּ, which the Talmud (Shabbos 133b) interprets to mean This Is My God (which by the way is the title of a recommended book by Herman Wouk) and I will beautify Him. Quoting that passage in the Talmud from Sefaria:

However, here, with regard to circumcision, where we need to fulfill the mitzva of: “This is my God and I will glorify Him,” which requires performing the circumcision in a beautiful manner, indeed, Rabbi Yishmael would agree that the mitzva must be performed as aesthetically as possible. דְּתַנְיָא: ״זֶה אֵלִי וְאַנְוֵהוּ״, הִתְנָאֵה לְפָנָיו בְּמִצְוֹת: עֲשֵׂה לְפָנָיו סוּכָּה נָאָה, וְלוּלָב נָאֶה, וְשׁוֹפָר נָאֶה, צִיצִית נָאָה, סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה נָאֶה, וְכָתוּב בּוֹ לִשְׁמוֹ בִּדְיוֹ נָאֶה, בְּקוּלְמוֹס נָאֶה, בְּלַבְלָר אוּמָּן, וְכוֹרְכוֹ בְּשִׁירָאִין נָאִין. What is the source for the requirement of: “This is my God and I will glorify Him”? As it was taught in a baraita with regard to the verse: “This is my God and I will glorify Him [anveihu], the Lord of my father and I will raise Him up.” The Sages interpreted anveihu homiletically as linguistically related to noi, beauty, and interpreted the verse: Beautify yourself before Him in mitzvot. Even if one fulfills the mitzva by performing it simply, it is nonetheless proper to perform the mitzva as beautifully as possible. Make before Him a beautiful sukka, a beautiful lulav, a beautiful shofar, beautiful ritual fringes, beautiful parchment for a Torah scroll, and write in it in His name in beautiful ink, with a beautiful quill by an expert scribe, and wrap the scroll in beautiful silk fabric.

title: How should religious Jews (and Noahides) respond to these criticisms
content:
# How should religious Jews (and Noahides) respond to these criticisms ## Frage

I’m curious how the community here would recommend responding to these criticisms of the claim that God exist: https://youtu.be/ExBsyaiRYW4?feature=shared. To summarize (although please for anybody who doesn’t have YouTube completely blocked, watch it yourself and try and formulate a response), his argument is twofold: he claims that since God’s nature involves infinity, omnipotence, omniscience etc., God can’t exist because of the metaphysical axiom of the law of identity (his philosophical tradition is Objectivism, the philosophy of Ayn Rand). Second, he formulates that God isn’t possible because he asserts God is absolutely arbitrary, there is no evidence for it and since there is no evidence there is no demonstration of possibility, if one can’t even demonstrate something is possible how can one reasonably believe in it? After all, why should one believe in invisible goblins on Venus who read Mark Twain books if there is no evidence for that? I believe in God, however I would appreciate community input.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

First, the law of identity states that each thing is identical with itself. G-d is identical with G-d. The speaker in the video twists the application of the law by stating that everything in this world is finite, and any action of G-d in this world is finite, therefore a finite collection of finite things should be representative of what G-d is. This way god is identified with nature, which actually was done by Hitler and his national socialist philosophers. The problem is that in Judaism G-d does not live inside the universe. As we state in Koheles 1:9:

Only that shall happen Which has happened, Only that occur Which has occurred; There is nothing new Beneath the sun!

Yes, there is nothing new beneath or under the sun, i.e. inside the universe (i.e. finite dimensional). But from G-d who is outside the universe, i.e. from "above the sun", we do get novelty - prophesy, prophetic visions, and any kind of novel ideas. We believe not only in the infinite and omnipotent G-d, but also that He will give us infinite reward for our mitzvos.

Second, the existence of "god who can change laws of nature at a whim, negates any need to know laws of science", which is nonsense. Such a point is also not applicable to Judaism. G-d does not change anything at a whim. The miracles defying natural laws were designed from the 6 days of creation (see Pirkei Avos 5:6 for example). In fact the verse in Tehilim 93:1 clearly states that G-d is not changing any natural laws at a whim:

The LORD is king, He is robed in grandeur; the LORD is robed, He is girded with strength. The world stands firm; it cannot be shaken.

Basically, the speaker invents a false premise and uses it as a pretext to defy the "competing ideology" by using 2 false witnesses. That's a totally marxist way of doing things.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

The speaker is making a few assumptions, and appears to admit that is because he is presupposing the truth of objectivism, and its atheistic implications, i.e. that there is lack of evidence for God, and there are metaphysical contradictions. I would say that he has a very left-brained, rational mind, and therefore views everything logically/rationally and materialistically. Therefore, ultimately, he can't conceive of God because he has no clue about how to apply his intellect outside of the limitations of logic.

He may not realise it, but he thinks that God must be some sort of object, and when he follows the logic there, he arrives at contradictions. However, not only does Torah not presume that God is an object, but also makes theological conclusions about God that this gentleman's line of thinking would consider "impossible" or contradictory.

The Law of Identity proves that God doesn't exist

False witness. The Law of Identity only disproves a God if God is meant to obey the law, but why should He? He does not have to follow any rules given that He created the rules themselves!

As I said, God is not an object or category.

All of the "logical paradoxes" from applying the law of identity to an infinite or undefined being are true regarding God. We do assert that He is indistinguishable from nothing, to us, in the sense of "yesh m'ayin"; something from nothing. In fact, we apply this principle to the entire spiritual cosmos, and then declare that God is exalted above even the spiritual cosmos, so how much more so does this argument not apply to God.

To put it in terms of greek philosophy, the argument being made in the video assumes that all is corporeal. The rule of identity applies in the corporeal sense that two different objects can be identical, and still exist independantly. In the spiritual cosmos, there is no corporeality, only form. If two forms are identical, they wouldn't be two, but would be the same. However, to be identical, they need to have a property or description, and would thus be composite. This does not apply to God, who cannot be composite. See Moreh Nevuchim 1 and 2 for the full discussion, who dealt with this by tackling the greek philosophy, and see Maharal, Gevurot Hashem, Hakdama 2 for the general philosophy of Torah on this theological point:

אבל הוא יתברך שקראו רז"ל בשם "הקדוש ברוך הוא", ולא נקרא "השכל ברוך הוא", כי אמיתת עצמו לא נודע, רק שהוא נבדל מכל גשם וגוף ומכל הנמצאים, ועל זה נאמר "קדוש ברוך הוא", שענין "קדוש" נאמר על מי שהוא נבדל, כי הוא יתברך פשוט בתכלית הפשיטות. ומזה בעצמו שהוא בתכלית הפשיטות, אין דבר נבדל ממנו, כי הדבר שיש לו גדר ומיוחד בדבר מה, בשביל אותו גדר נבדל ממנו דבר שאינו בגדרו. אבל מפני כי הוא יתברך פשוט ואין לו גדר כלל, אין דבר נבדל ממנו. ואם כן, הוא יודע הכל, והוא יכול הכל, וכל זה מפני שאין לו גדר יוגדר בדבר מיוחד, ובשביל זה הכל נמצא מאתו גם כן

Our sages, of blessed memory, refer to Hashem as "the Holy One, Blessed be He" and not "the Intelligent One", because the truth of His being is unknown, except that He is separated from all forms of substance and body that can be found. This is why they call Him "Holy One Blessed Be He". The term "holy" denotes an entity that is apart and removed, and Hashem is simple in the most ultimate sense of simplicity. But precisely because Hashem is the ultimate simplicity (abstraction), there is nothing that is excluded from Him.

When something has a definition, and is distinguished by certain characteristics, that same definition will exclude form it things that are outside of that definition. But because Hashem has no definition at all, nothing is excluded from Him. Therefore, He knows everything and can do anything. All this is because God is not defined by any specific definitions, therefore, everything comes from Him.

As to the point that saying something is undefined is defining it, we have already dealt with this in our theology (and this very much is right-brain stuff):

  • The Rebbe Rashab explains that indeed, He is so undefined, that even calling Him "undefined" is not correct, because that would be a limit, so the truth is beyond words:
  • language itself is inadequate to describe Him, so even calling Him undefined is insufficient, and our understanding of it is completely impossible
  • the only reason we can even say this is because of the one thing we can understand about it, like the Maharal said: Hashem's lack of definition means He can be and do and know anything and everything - nothing is excluded. We are given this gift to a small, finite extent: as people, we can be whatever and whoever we want to be.

His problem is that he is stuck with objectivism, which is a form of materialism - all that exists is only what we can see. He demonstrates this in his next point

God existing is arbitrary

This is also a false witness. Firstly, He is not arbitrary; as we teach in our first law of Mishnah Torah, God is defined as the original reality from which all other reality gets its existence from. This is the exact opposite of arbitrary.

Secondly, there are manifold claims of His existence. He may think that all those claims are wrong, but bear in mind nobody is claiming there are goblins on venus.

Thirdly, the idea that rational thinkers shouldn't entertain arbitrary claims, otherwise they are being irrational, is not a good argument. Until something is known, it won't be discovered until someone entertains the possibility of its existence. People who refuse to do that are mostly just doing it out of fear - they don't want to make a mistake and "be fooled" or "look stupid".

Fourth, the fact that everything is fixed, has laws, and all the assumptions that go into his objectivist worldview, are also arbitrary! Why should laws not change? Why should the world operate logically? We are thankful it does, but the very fact that we can conceive of "tohu", pure chaos, means that order is arbitrary.

There is much more to say but it is exhausting. The final answer, the "forest", the tl;dr, is that Torah doesn't assume all is composed of finite, concrete, identifiable entities (the basic premise of his worldview), and he does, so we disagree on the basics. All other arguments are "trees" and it is very tiresome wading through them, with people who can't see the forest for the trees.

If someone is genuinely agnostic, and wants to honestly explore God's existence, and wants to tackle it seriously; philosophically, and theologically, I would recommend Rambam's Moreh Nevuchim (english), Gevurot Hashem as quoted above by the Maharal (hebrew), and Derech Mitzvotecha Haamanut Elokut (english), immediately followed by Achdut Hashem (hebrew as of yet). I would also be happy to make more recommendations if someone wishes to ask in the comments.

Best is to not engage. Someone who is making an assumption and using it as a logical argument is not worth arguing with - they are either foolish, cynical or outright dishonest. They are very unlikely to hear you and this answer is purely for those who are not stuck in assumptions and wish to learn some Torah theology.

### Antwort 3 (Score: -2)

There is evidence for God. Many people have claimed to have interacted with him.

Even if something cannot be demonstrated true or false, one can still reasonably believe in it due to 1) Occam's Razor or 2) it is comforting/pleasurable to do so.

You don't appreciate community input because you had to specify that you believe in God. You actually fear community input and will probably crumble emotionally if it calls you a heretic.

title: Halacha of a railing with staircases מעקה
content:
# Halacha of a railing with staircases מעקה ## Frage

Imagine a studio with a loft bed that is accessed with a staircase. Does the mitzvah of a railing, מעקה, apply to staircase?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to Sefer haBayis by R' Yosef Yitzchok Lerner (English translation also exists), section 7 halakha 23 for other places which require the guardrail:

A Ramp or staircase that are higher than 10 tefachim from the ground require a guardrail, although one does not recite a blessing over it.

This is based on Sh"A Ch"M 427:7:

Both a roof or anything dangerous where it's probable that someone will stumble upon and fall, for example if there was a well or a hole in his yard, whether there is water in it or not, one is obligated to make an embankment ten-handbreadths high, or to cover it, lest a person fall into it and die.

The Aharonim are divided concerning a ramp and stairs. Since a person is careful ascending a ramp and stairs Hagaos Maimoniyos (hilkhos Rotzeyach 11:2), Rabbeinu Yerucham (51:5) quote Sifri that ramp is exempt, Chazon Ish (Ch"M Likutim 18:5) concurs. However, Rabbeinu Yonah (Sefer haYirah 277) - a person should not have stairs in his house without a railing (he understands Sifri as not exempting ramps from railing except the railing of the altar in Beis haMikdash). This view is shared by Rabbeinu Hillel (Sifri, Ki Teitze), Magen Avraham (Zayis Ra'anan, Ki Teitze 15), Minchas Chinukh (KOmetz Mincha 546).

Chayei Adam (15:24) requires a guardrail, S'dei Chemed (klalim, 40:195, U'bameh shekatav) explains that even a wide staircase requires a rail, and certinly if narrow, since many people climb up and down, even small children, who are incapable of watching themselves.

Responsa Machazeh Eliyahu 122:17 explains the Chayei Adam that we are concerned that a person may fall from the upper landing of the staircase, since people are usually careful when climbing stairs but once they reach the landing they forget to pay attention. Where the landing gapes over the staircase, a guardrail must be made around it (if the staircase is not 4 amos by 4 amos) and the stairs too without reciting a blessing. Same view Beis Borukh (25:39), Responsa Betzel haChokhmah (4:115), Kuntres Chikrei Halakhos V'halikhos Shekhenim 29, Responsa Machazeh ELiyahu 122:6 who quotes R' Eliyashiv, same rulling is in Mishna Halakhos (second ed., vol 2, Ch"M 466).

title: The Rebbe Rashab and the Lubavitcher Rebbe's Position on the Three Oaths
content:
# The Rebbe Rashab and the Lubavitcher Rebbe's Position on the Three Oaths ## Frage

B"H

I'm trying to properly understand the Lubavitcher Rebbe's view on Zionism and the land of Yisroel, but I'm having a hard time getting authoritative answers.

I heard that the Rebbe RaSha"B spoke out very harshly against early Zionism, specifically by signing his name on the letter "Ohr layasharim," which said that we should do everything possible to oppose it and protest against it, etc. He made his position clear in further writings and addresses. I believe that the Rebbe RaSha"B also said that it violates the Three Oaths, although I haven't been able to confirm the exact wording.

Obviously the Rebbe supported the land of Yisroel and defending the Jewish people living there at all costs, etc; he had many sichos about telling the world that it's our land, because Hashem gave it to us and references the first Rashi.

But what is the difference between the two views? Surely, the Rebbe wouldn't have contradicted what the Rebbe RaShaB said.

Also, regarding the Rebbe's more recent position about being firm with our claim to the land because of it's G-d given nature, is that itself enough of a reason to establish the state initially, or was that used only as the main claim specifically after it was established?

To the best of my knowledge, there are many anti zionist rabbis who use the Rebbe Rashab's words (amongst other things) to justify openly protesting against and opposing the modern day state of Yisroel. Why is there a difference if opinion between the Rebbe and these other rabbis in this matter?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Rabbi Yosef Yitzchok Schneersohn, the Lubavitcher Rebbe (1880-1950) wrote a fiery pamphlet, saying:

When a devout Jew arrives at one of these places, with the calming of his worldly worries and the inspiration of Israel's great leaders, he builds yet another institution: a Torah study room, a yeshiva, a house of kindness and charity. As stated, one of us is exiled to Barbary and another to Britain, etc., and we must have complete faith and recognize with clear understanding that when the righteous Messiah comes—speedily in our days—it will be preferable in his and G-d’s eyes to have a study hall or a house of charity founded in the exile in Barbary or Britain than a factory or a workplace established—Heaven forbid—in Jerusalem, the Holy City. (Tikun Olam, siman 41)

In Ohr Layesharim (p. 59) (quoted by RabbiKaii), the Rebbe Rashab is quoted in saying that:

Those who assist these aforementioned Zionists are destined to be held accountable, for they strengthen the hands of those who cause the multitudes to sin. Therefore, whoever is for G-d and His Torah should not associate with evildoers nor cling to them. On the contrary, they should oppose them in every possible way. Until the will of God redeems us, we must accept the yoke of exile to atone for our sins. We must strengthen ourselves to stand firm against every wave, being courageous and resolute in observing the Torah and mitzvot. This is what God demands of us, and we must hope to Him, for His salvation is near, and our righteous Messiah will come speedily in our days, Amen. Even if he tarries, wait for him, for the matter depends on us rectifying our deeds. May the Holy One, Blessed be He, have mercy upon us and hasten our redemption speedily in our days, Amen.

He gives three points:

As for the argument of the Zionists: "Why don't the God-fearing and devout stand at the head of the movement?"

How can the G-d-fearing stand at the head of a movement that opposes the core of our belief in the true redemption, as mentioned above?

  1. The G-d-fearing cannot collaborate with them because they (the Zionists) will not heed the words of the devout in matters of religion and education. They will act in their strange ways, according to the freedom deeply rooted in their hearts, and they will even dare to claim that the devout agree with them. Many of the Jewish masses, in their simplicity, will believe that all their actions are endorsed by the devout and G-d-fearing. Later, if the devout withdraw from them and cry out against them (even if they make their voices heard in the press), their withdrawal will not have as much impact.

  2. Their prior collaboration will overshadow their later separation. This is what we see now with some of their great leaders who have withdrawn from the workers’ movement and oppose them, yet their current opposition does not carry the weight that their earlier involvement did.

  3. In truth, they do not want the G-d-fearing to join them at all, because they know the devout will stand in their way and oppose their chosen path of rebellion (to completely cast off the yoke of Torah and mitzvos, turning Judaism solely into nationalism, as mentioned above). At the Warsaw gatherings, when the rabbis demanded that a rabbinical council also be included in the leadership, they refused entirely. Their representatives—their writers—published articles in the press mocking and insulting the rabbis, ridiculing them for daring to make such a demand, using disrespectful language. From this, it is evident that they do not want the involvement of the G-d-fearing, as it would hinder their wicked plans. May G-d thwart their counsel and raise the dignity of the Jewish people.

For further reading, check this out!

title: Lack of the name Hashem Tzevaot in the Torah
content:
# Lack of the name Hashem Tzevaot in the Torah ## Frage

There is a dispute on Shevuot 35 whereby, according to one opinion, Tzevaot is one of the Divine Names that may not be erased. Although Hashem Tzevaot appears frequently in various haftarot and prayers, I've recently discovered in a concordance that there is no such Divine Name in the Torah. How come? Because it first occurs in the Book of Samuel, I've tried to connect it to the establishment of the Jewish kingdom, but it's just a mere speculation, so I'd appreciate any well-sourced answer!

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Berachot 31b:

מיום שברא הקדוש ברוך הוא את עולמו, לא היה אדם שקראו להקדוש ברוך הוא ״צבאות״, עד שבאתה חנה וקראתו ״צבאות״

From the day that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created His world, there was no person who called the Holy One, Blessed be He, Lord of Hosts until Hannah came and called Him Lord of Hosts.

According to this gemara, Chana invoked this name in order to make a point, i.e. Hashem, you have צבאות, legions, is it so much to ask for just one child? The pshat of this implies that this is the way this Name should be used, and until this moment, nobody had needed to (or figured out how to) use it this way:

משל למה הדבר דומה — למלך בשר ודם שעשה סעודה לעבדיו. בא עני אחד ועמד על הפתח, אמר להם: תנו לי פרוסה אחת! ולא השגיחו עליו. דחק ונכנס אצל המלך. אמר לו: אדוני המלך, מכל סעודה שעשית קשה בעיניך ליתן לי פרוסה אחת?!

[The Gemara suggests] a parable: To what is this similar? [It is similar to] a flesh and blood king who made a feast for his servants. A poor person came and stood at the door. He said to them: Give me one slice of bread! And they paid him no attention. He pushed and entered before the king. He said to him: My lord, the King, from this entire feast that you have prepared, is it so difficult in your eyes to give me a single slice [of bread]? [Steinsaltz translation, and commentary in square brackets]

The Ben Yehoyada on this piece brings the Chida's "Chomat Anach", who gives a Kabbalistic reason why this name was only used for the first time by Sefer Shmuel. To cut to the chase, a bat kol informed Chana that Shmuel would rectify something spiritually, and this rectification was what facilitated Hashem's Name צבאות to be used.

Rabbi Yosef Chayim Z'tl also explains the difference between Hashem Tzvakot and Elokim Tzvakot, if you want to go and look there, but the answer is Kabbalistic, so I won't put it in this answer.

title: Isn’t ״צרות לבבי הרחיבו״ an oxymoron?
content:
# Isn’t ״צרות לבבי הרחיבו״ an oxymoron? ## Frage

In Tehillim 25:17, David says:

צָר֣וֹת לְבָבִ֣י הִרְחִ֑יבוּ מִ֝מְּצוּקוֹתַ֗י הוֹצִיאֵֽנִי׃

My deep distress increases; deliver me from my straits.

The root ״צר״ literally translates as “narrow”. Its antonym is ״רחב״ - wide; e.g. (Tehillim 118:5):

מִֽן־הַ֭מֵּצַר קָרָ֣אתִי יָּ֑הּ עָנָ֖נִי בַמֶּרְחָ֣ב יָֽהּ׃

In distress I called on the LORD;the Lord answered me and brought me relief.

Why, then, does David lament that his “narrowness” has “widened”?

(The Alshich and the Malbim both provide a similar explanation, but I would like to hear another approach.)

title: Can I use a red tablecloth for Shabbos?
content:
# Can I use a red tablecloth for Shabbos? ## Frage

I’ve always heard that a Shabbos table should preferably be covered in white. Is this just a preference, or is there a reason (halachic or kabbalistic) to avoid using a different color?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Beginning with the basics, the halacha is that one should use a table-cloth at this table due to the principle of "honoring Shabbos" (Chayei Adam, Shabbos 5:7). This is also the language of the Alter Rebbe in his Shulchan Aruch HaRav (262):

It is customary that the table be covered with a tablecloth throughout the entire Shabbos day as an expression of honoring the Shabbos.2 One should not deviate [from this custom].

The tablecloth should be left on during Shabbos, not only during dinner.

Back to the question what colour should be used. It seems to be a age-old minhag to use white as a colour of the table-cloth. This seems to be attributed to Rabbi Shimon Greenfeld in his Shailos U'Teshuvos Maharshag (Vol. 2, Siman 82, שו"ת מהרש"ג חלק ג) but I could not find that direct quote from that specific siman, though.

What color tablecloth is one to use? 1

The age old custom is to use a white tablecloth to cover the dining table.

1: Drashos Mahariy Even, student of Rashba; See Maharshag 2/82
