title: What happened to Sefer Yechezkel before Chananyah ben Chizkiyah ben Guriyon?
content:
# What happened to Sefer Yechezkel before Chananyah ben Chizkiyah ben Guriyon? ## Frage

There's a famous Gemara in Shabbos 13b:

אמר רב יהודה אמר רב: ברם זכור אותו האיש לטוב וחנניה בן חזקיה שמו, שאלמלא הוא נגנז ספר יחזקאל, שהיו דבריו סותרין דברי תורה. מה עשה? — העלו לו שלש מאות גרבי שמן, וישב בעלייה ודרשן.

Rav Yehuda said that Rav said: Truly, that man is remembered for the good, and his name is Ḥananya ben Ḥizkiya, as if not for him, the book of Ezekiel would have been suppressed because its contents, in many details, contradict matters of Torah. The Sages sought to suppress the book and exclude it from the canon. What did he, Ḥananya ben Ḥizkiya, do? They brought him three hundred jugs of oil, for light and food, up to his upper story, and he sat isolated in the upper story and did not move from there until he homiletically interpreted all of those verses in the book of Ezekiel that seemed contradictory, and resolved the contradictions.

Now, Chananyah ben Chizkiyah ben Guriyon was a Tanna during the time of Beis Shammai/Bais Hillel, which Wikipedia puts at around the last century BCE/1st century CE. Yechezkel, on the other hand, is dated around the 6th century BCE. That leaves a time span of approximately 500 years. What was the status of Sefer Yechezkel during that time? Was it a "lost" or "hidden" sefer? Was it viewed as a kefirah? And if no one understood it until Chananyah ben Chizkiyah ben Guriyon came along, then why was Yechezkel not put to death for being a navi sheker owing to those contradictions?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Yechezkel's undisputed prophetic status and important leadership role in the Judahite community are currently only known from the book itself (i.e., he's not known to be mentioned in other contemporaneous or near-contemporaneous sources), which both states that he was chosen by Hashem to lead the exiles in Babylon (24:24-27), and that on several occasions he taught and prophesied before the elders of Judah and Israel (8:1; 14:1-4 20:1-3).

As already stated by @Meir in the comments, the book is traditionally thought to have been authored by Anshei Knesset Hagedolah (Bavli Bava Batra 15b). Some time later, Yechezkel was mentioned by Ben Sira (49:8)1 as one of the great leaders of previous generations that are mentioned in ch. 44-49, a section which is sometimes referred to as "The Praise of the Previous Generations" (albeit not all famous Tanachic characters appear there, while on the other hand Shimon Hatzaddik does). In the same verse, Ben Sira also referenced Ma'aseh Merkava. Ben Sira was also a book of debatable status, but was nonetheless continuously quoted, paraphrased and referenced by many sages. A paraphrase of Ben Sira even appears in Mishna Avot 4:4 as the only known preserved teaching by Rabbi Levitas of Yavneh (see e.g. here).

From the little information we have, it seems that Yechezkel was known as an important prophet and his book was considered legitimate and at least somewhat widely disseminated.2 The debate of the sages was not on either of those. It's important to differentiate between the debatable status of Sefer Yechezkel and the debatable status of Shir Hashirim and Kohelet. In the latter case, the sages were disputed on the question whether touching scrolls of Shir Hashirim and Kohelet would make someone's hand impure (Mishna Yadayim 3:5). The question that lies at the root of this dispute is whether Shir Hashirim and Kohelet are even holy. Not so in the case of Sefer Yechezkel, where it was a given that even if it should not be included in the canon, it was holy and must be ganuz, i.e., placed in a genizah, like other holy texts that are taken out of use. The dispute of the sages stemmed from the question of whether it was right to distribute the book to the masses and teach it to them, because it contains some material that may not be understood by all. What Chananyah ben Chizkiyah ben Giron (or Gurion in some versions) did was develop a form of homiletic exegesis for the problematic sections of Yechzekel, which made it easier to teach to the masses. No longer would sages have difficulty in explaining problematic verses as p'shat; they could now rely on Chananyah's explanations and present these verses as drash.

1 Also in R' Dr. M. Z. Segal's edition of the Hebrew medieval Cairo Genizah manuscript, p. 336, v. 11 (in Hebrew)/v. 8 in secular numeration.

2 Consider also the existence of Yechezkel manuscripts in Qumran (which some believe were stored in the late 1st century BCE [but of course, like everything in Qumran, this is debatable]), as well as the mysterious Pseudo-Ezekiel, whose dating is also disputed. And some believe that the Septuagint's translation of Ezekiel should be dated to ca. 150 BCE (see e.g., here, p. 117 and sources cited in n. 7).

title: Can a Ger Toshav observe Shabbat?
content:
# Can a Ger Toshav observe Shabbat? ## Frage

I’m curious if a Ger Toshav is allowed to observe Shabbat according to Halacha, general Noahides/gentiles to my understanding are prohibited from it, however I’ve heard that the Halacha might be different, although I haven’t looked into any Sugyot regarding it so I’m curious if anybody here can confirm. If the answer is yes, they are allowed to observe it, is it optional or mandatory, and would it be the same Halacha as Shabbat for a Jew?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Credit to @schmerel for some of the sources here, taken from here:

Those who obligate a גר תושב to keep Shabbat:

  1. Rashi Yevamot 48b
  2. "Ohel Mordechai quotes the Ponovicher Rov adding that since for Bnai Yisroel the desecration of Shabbos is tantamount to serving Avoda Zarah (Chullin 5a), so it is for a Ger Toshav, and therefore he has to observe Shabbat."

Those who don't obligate a גר תושב to keep Shabbat:

  1. Tosafot Yevamot 48b ד״ה זה גר
  2. Rambam Hilchot Shabbat 20:14
  3. Ramban Yevamot 48b ד"ה הגר זה וכו
  4. Rashba שם ד״ה הגר זה
  5. Ritva שם ד"ה הגר זה
  6. Meiri שם ד"ה עבד שמל
  7. Mishna Berura (304: 1)
  8. Rav Yehudah bar Yakar פירוש התפלות והברכות, מהודרת שמואל ירושלמי, ירושלים, תשל"ט, עמ' קו (he adds that there is also no איסור for him to keep shabbat)

With regards to the specifics of what type of גר תושב we are talking about, see here and here.

Also according to those who say he is chaiv to keep Shabbat like Rashi and others I may have missed, I haven't seen anyone who makes a chiluk between the Jew's shabbat and גר תושב shabbat, since besides for a potential גר we either keep shabbat fully or not at all.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The thing about a Ger Toshav is that the rules for them are different because they live in the Eretz Yisrael. I don't really know how it works for a Noahide within the state of Israel. I'm following this thread so that when someone with more knowledge answers, I can learn a thing or two.

However, I know that outside Israel, the rules are not so strict. As long as a goy is not observing Shabbat in the same manners as a Jew, they seem to be okay. It's kind of like how someone going through the process of conversion keeps all the Shabbat rules, but deliberately breaks at least one, since they are not yet a Jew.

title: Must Teamim be followed while reciting Tehilim?
content:
# Must Teamim be followed while reciting Tehilim? ## Frage

The Tehillim in my Tanakh is of course full of cantillation marks, or ta'amim. But is it necessary to follow these Ta'amim, or could the recitation of Tehillim be made with “free spirit”, so to speak. I am a student, and beginning the process of familiarizing myself with cantillation marks, particularly Moroccan ta'amim. (I am referring to the melodic aspects of ta'amim, the cantillation, rather than as a means of punctuation.)

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Generally speaking I believe only one community actively teaches the te'amim of psalms using specific melodies and grammar, which is the Syrian community. Everyone else breaks down the psalms as a general melody and so most communities read a general melody for each pasuk.

In that vein I don't believe that Moroccans break down the Psalms by specific grammatical and musical te'amim. Instead they are like the Jerusalem Sephardic tradition, which has a way of generally reading the Psalms that is a flow but isn't that specific. In your case I don't see any issues being a little free flow

title: Did the Idolatrous Women of Ezekiel's Time Willfully Place Their Idol in the More Egregious Location in Order to Repudiate God?
content:
# Did the Idolatrous Women of Ezekiel's Time Willfully Place Their Idol in the More Egregious Location in Order to Repudiate God? ## Frage

In Ezekiel 8, the prophet is brought to the Temple in a vision and shown a series of abominations that explain why the Temple is to be destroyed.

Firstly, he is brought to the entrance of the courtyard; he peers through a hole in the wall of the Azara (that he enlarges) and sees the entrance of a chamber and enters and sees every form of creeping thing and detestable animal - idols - engraved on the wall of that chamber (see Metzudot Dovid). Seventy Men and Yazniyahu are offering incense there. He is told that he would be shocked if he knew what these men were doing in the dark in their own chambers (see Metzudos Dovid). Then he is informed that he will see "greater abominations."

He is then taken to the gate of the Heichal (see Metzudos) and shown that inside of the Chamber of the Knives (per Rashi) women are heating an idol from the inside called Tammuz, which has lead eyes, thereby causing the idol to 'weep,' - this means that it wants more sacrifices (see Metzudos and Rashi). Once again, he is told that he will see something worse.

Why is Tammuz the greater abomination?

The easy answer is that it's all about proximity ("where"). Tammuz was found deeper within the Temple complex and thus it is the more egregious crime.

But it doesn't sound here like proximity alone creates the more egregious crime. And so if Tamuz is worse for independent reasons - Tammuz was perfidious in that it duped others ... The seventy + one men were merely sinning on their own- this begs the question: how did the more shocking crime end up in the more shocking place? Did the women willfully place the more heinous act in a location which expressed more rebelliousness?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Several of the commentators on that verse (Abarbanel, Radak, Malbim) state that "the Tammuz" here is a form of the Molech worship of child sacrifice. Thus, as bad as it was for the elders to be worshipping creeping things and whatnot, this was indeed worse.

title: What is the plausible excuse (אמתלא) of “על ידי נתינה”
content:
# What is the plausible excuse (אמתלא) of “על ידי נתינה” ## Frage

In Talmudic jargon, an אמתלא is a “ plausible reason for correcting or retracting an evidence.”:

אֲמַתְלָא (Y. מַתְלָא) m. (cmp. h. משל) something tangible (= דבר שיש בו ממש); plausible reason for correcting or retracting an evidence. Keth. 22ᵃ אם נתנה א׳ וכ׳ if she offers a reasonable explanation of her contradictory statements, her second one is accepted. Gitt. IX, 9 ובלבד שלא יהא שם א׳ provided no reasonable explanation is offered to show how the report may have arisen by mistake; a. fr. V. מַתְלָא.

In Simla Chadasha 1:40, he talks about a shochet explaining that he didn’t mean it when he told someone the meat was not kosher (I’m going to translate the boldd part below):

טבח שעשה סימן בראש הכבש השחוט שיהא נראה שהוא טריפה וגם אמר שהוא טריפה ואח"כ אמר שכשר היה ושלא אמר כן אלא שלא יקחו אותו אחרים וישאר לו ליקח ממנו כשר כיון שנתן אמתלא לדבריו נאמן. ונ"ל דה"ה באומר טעיתי בדין זה בדבר הראוי לטעות בו עוד נ"ל דדוקא שבשעה שהחזיקה בטריפה היה מקום אמתלא כגון שיש דוחק בבשר ולשוחט צריך לו בשר או שהבהמה של גוי והשוחט אינו מפוייס עמו או מחמת נתינה וכדומה באופן שלא הוחזקה בהמה זו בעיני השומעים ורואה הסימן לטריפה וודאית בלי פקפוק אף על גב דמכל מקום אסורה היא כ"ז שלא חזר בו השוחט מכל מקום עדיין רשות בידו להחזיקה בכשירה באמירת אמתלא אבל אם בשעת אמירתו ומעשה שלו לא נשאר שום ספק בלב השומעים והוחזקה בעיני כל לטריפה ודאית לאו כל כמיניה דהשוחט דכל מידי דאתחזק באסורא א"א להוציאה מחזקה אלא בראיה ברורה ואפילו בלא עשיית מעשה רק באמירה שאמר טריפה היא ולא היה מקום אמתלא והוחזקה בטריפה וודאית בהוחלט חוכך אני להחמיר שלא להאמינו אחר כך להכשירו באמתלא ויש להחמיר בשל תורה:

…And it further appears to me the Amasla only works if at the time the shochet declared it trief, an excuse was a possibility. If, for example, there was a shortage of meat and shochet needed meat for himself, or if the animal belonged to a non-Jew and the shochet was not happy with the person he told the meat was treif, or because of נתינה and the like.

The part about the “animal belonged to a non-Jew and the shochet was not happy with the person he told the meat was treif” is based on a Gemara in chullin, end of 94B and on, see below, but what does “על ידי נתינה” mean? What is the plausible excuse?

ההוא טבחא דא"ל לחבריה.

§ The Gemara returns to the topic of selling non-kosher meat to a gentile. There was a certain Jewish butcher who said to another individual:

אי הוות פייסת מינאי מי לא ספיי לך משור של פטם דעבדי אתמול א"ל אכלי משופרי שופרי א"ל מנלך א"ל דזבן פלוני עובד כוכבים וספא לי א"ל תרי עבדי וההוא טרפה הוה

If you would have made peace with me yesterday, wouldn’t I have given you a cut from the fattened bull that I prepared yesterday? The other individual said to him: Nevertheless I ate from the finest of the fine of that bull that you prepared. The butcher said to him: From where did you get a piece? The other said to him: So-and-so the gentile bought it and fed it to me. The butcher said to him: I prepared two bulls yesterday. One was kosher, but that one you ate was a tereifa, which is why I sold it to a gentile.

איכא דאמרי אמר רבי מפני שוטה זה דאיכוון לצעוריה לחבריה אנו נאסור כל המקולין

The Gemara presents an alternate version of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s reaction to the incident cited above: There are those who say that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said: Because of this imbecile, who intended only to cause distress to his fellow, should we forbid all of the meat from gentile butcher shops? That butcher was presumably lying about the meat having been from a tereifa.

title: The four descriptions of the world as a reference to the four galuyos
content:
# The four descriptions of the world as a reference to the four galuyos ## Frage

The Torah recounts the state of the world just after G-d created heaven and earth (Bereishis 1:2):

And the earth was without form and void; and darkness was on the face of the deep. And a wind from G-d moved over the surface of the waters.

The Midrash teaches us that when we read "four", it refers to the four galuyos, e.g. Bavel, Paras-Media, Yavan, Edom-Yishmael. The Midrash (Bereishis Rabbah 2:4) expounds on the posuk in Bereishis as follows:

“The earth was emptiness” – this is the Babylonian kingdom, as it is stated: “I have seen the land, and behold, it was emptiness and disorder” (Jeremiah 4:23). “And disorder [vavohu]” – this is the Median kingdom, [as it is stated:] “They hastened [vayavhilu] to bring Haman” (Esther 6:14). “And darkness”– this is the Greek kingdom, which darkened Israel’s eyes with their edicts, as they used to say to them: ‘Write on the horn of a bull that you have no portion in the God of Israel.’ “Upon the face of the depths” – this is the evil kingdom [Edom], which cannot be calculated, like the depths; just as the depths cannot be calculated, so is it with [the wickedness of] the wicked.

The Midrash connects the different descriptions of that specific malchus to a word in pesukim elsewhere in the Torah. However, I have trouble understanding why especially these pesukim are chosen when talking about the four galuyos - the four malchuyos.

The only thing, understandable for me, I found was in the sefer Peninei Ohr (Parshas Bereishis, p. 129), by the Or HaChaim Hakadosh:

The term bohu also hints at the subsequent exile, the Babylonian exile, referred to as bohu because the Aramaic translation of bohu is “emptiness” or “void.” Concerning the Babylonian exile, it is written in Yirmiyahu 51:34, "Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, has devoured me… he has made me an empty vessel."

Are there any seforim, commentaries of articles that explain why these four descriptions of the state of the world after creating, before G-d created light are being connected to these pesukim?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

As we learn from Rashi on Bereshis 1:1 and Bereshis Rabba 1:4, that the world was created bereishis, in the merit of reishis, i.e. Israel among the nations. Just as the first produce is sacred so is Israel, G-d's sacred nation. Yet, while we are the very purpose for which the world was created, in the next breath the Torah foreshadows the trials and tribulations we must endure throughout our history. The Divine Plan for human destiny is thereby framed at the outset by the verses Bereshis 1:1-2, from day One to the End of Days.

The commentary Yefeh To'ar (1), which views the verse Bereshis 1:2 as a remez to the 4 kingdoms explains the idea of Creation with the following excerpt:

The final point of Creation is the time of moshiyach, when the world gets settles in peace, and be filled with knowledge, and everyone will speak in the name of Hashem. Hashem did not refrain from creating the world as He conceived the idea of 4 kingdoms, despite the fact that multitude of their sinful acts and variants of faith were rebellion to His Honor. Hashem knows the final end, and because of it everything perfomed for our forefathers from the time of their redemption from Egypt and building the Temple - is an afront to His final goal, and so in the end it was all destroyed as if He acted for naught.

And His answer was that everything was due to the nature of the matter. The completeness of the entire human race was withheld from others for a long time, because the nature of their creation did not accept it from its beginning. For this it took a long time with many tests and trials and rebukes from several prophets and many troubles in bitter and difficult revelations. After that the redeemed (Jewish) people came out clean as pure and refined silver and returned to Hashem with all their heart and with all their soul. Thus, they knew faithfully that there was no truth and rejected all the kinds of deceptions, which only served to turn away people from from Hashem. Yes, they were ashamed and deceived by their deeds and recognized that there was no other remedy but to seek refuge under His wings. Thus, at the end they will come to Hashem in a covenant of peace (as granted to Pinchas) which will never be broken.

The idea of four kingdoms can schematically be represented by the 4 letters of the dreidel (theme 58 in (2) and (3), also Bnei Yisaschar) or in the word גֹשְנָה - the place of the first exile in Mitzrayim, where נ - nefesh, ג - guf, ש - sekhel, and ה - hakol or neshamah. Every exile among the nations sought to target the Jewish nation in different ways. Galus Bavel destroyed the First Temple, rendering it impossible for the Jews to perfect their souls (nefesh) through sacrifices (see Vayikra 2:1). The Persian/Median exile threatened our physical existence (guf) because of Haman's plot. The Greeks sought to supplant our knowledge base sekhel with their own, and when they could not win by intellectual superiority, they attempted to suppress the study of Torah. Finally Edom/Rome attacked us in every way (hakol). The Gematria of the word משיח is 358 = ג+נ+ה+ש. Thus the the Messianic king will be able to overcome hakol. Alternatively, the final teshuvah and overcoming of each of the kingdoms would allow the neshamah of the person enlighten his/her guf, nefesh and sekhel.

The midrash connects each of galuyos using similar words.

The verse Yirmiyahu 4:23 describes the prophetic vision of the prophet Yirmiyahu about what was going to happen to Eretz Yisrael as a result of the conquest by Nevukhadnetzar king of Bavel. The army of Bavel would exile the people, destroy the Temple, and make the land empty and desolate (תֹ֖הוּ וָבֹ֑הוּ), same words as in Bereshis 1:2. In the language of Kabbala, the exile targeted the nefesh of the Jewish people, as being uprooted from their land and subject to an environment of a different country.

The verse Esther 6:14 speaks how providentially the Persian king's eunuchs came in the middle of the argument between Haman and Zeresh and hurriedly (וַיַּבְהִ֙לוּ֙, i.e. astonished him) rushed Haman to Esther's banquet. The word וַיַּבְהִ֙לוּ֙ has root בהל - shock, astonish, which is similar to the word ּבֹּהו - astonishingly empty as pointed by Matanos Kehuna.

To explain the connection pointed by Matnos Kehuna, one can used the verse Tehilim 30:8:

for You, O LORD, when You were pleased, made [me] firm as a mighty mountain. When You hid (הִסְתַּ֥רְתָּ) Your face, I was terrified (נִבְהָֽל).

I.e. just like the created אֶרֶץ was called בֹּהוּ in Bereshis 1:2 because it was void of רוּחַ אֱלֹהִ֔ים, so is a person who is נִבְהָֽל because s/he experiences the הסתר פנים של השם. In other words, upto the moment of the verse Esther 6:14 Haman felt empowered while the Jews were נִבְהָֽלִים - astonishingly frightened, as if Hashem was letting Haman do with his conspiracy to destroy Jewish people. At the moment when Haman was called to the banquet, right after Zeresh told him that he had no chance against Mordekhai, the roles changed: Haman realized that the possibility to make his evil plans was an illusion and he was going to face justice. Haman himself became נִבְהָֽל and the Jewish people realized that they have a shot to win the battle!

To understand the language of Kabbala, Rashi explains, that Harvonah overheard the conversation between Haman and Zeresh, where Haman expressed a wish to convince the king for the second time to hang Mordechai, ... and from here Harvonah knew why Haman ordered building the gallows. As we understand, the gallows is made to destroy the body.

The quote about the Greek Kingdom seems cryptic. For direct answer, one can use Yerushalmi Chagiga 2:2:4 stating

“Hillel and Menaḥem did not disagree. Menaḥem left and Shammai entered.” Where did he leave to? Some are saying, from behavior he left to behavior. But some are saying, he left against his face, he and eighty pairs of students of the Sages, wearing golden tirqe, whose faces became black like the rim of a clay pot, when they were told (by the Greeks), write on a bull’s horn that you have no part in the God of Israel.

In fact every Jew, who owned an ox was commanded to do so and publicize the heresy. Yefeh To'ar states that the decree of the Greeks hints to the making of the Golden Calf which distanced us from Hashem. The reason why this answer works, comes from another midrash, Bamidbar Rabba 2:10, which talks about different directions symbolized by the camps in the desert. In particular,

North, from there darkness emerges to the world, and corresponding to it, the tribe of Dan. Why? It is because it brought darkness to the world with idol worship. Yerovam crafted two golden calves, and idol worship is darkness, as it is stated: “Their actions are in the dark (בְמַחְשָׁךְ֙)” (Isaiah 29:15). Yerovam circulated throughout Israel and it was only the tribe of Dan that accepted it from him, as it is stated: “The king consulted, and he crafted two golden calves…and he placed one in Dan” (I Kings 12:28–29). That is why the Holy One blessed be He commanded that Dan would encamp in the north. That is what is written: “The banner of the camp of Dan is to the north…” (Numbers 2:25). With it, the tribe of Asher, which illuminates the darkness, as it is stated: “And of Asher he said: Blessed…and he dips his foot in oil” (Deuteronomy 33:24). Likewise it says: “And those who encamp with it, the tribe of Asher” (Numbers 2:27). With it, Naphtali, who is filled with blessing in order to provide sustenance, just as it is written: “Naphtali, his desire is satisfied, [and full with the blessing of the Lord]” (Deuteronomy 33:23). Likewise it says: “and the tribe of Naphtali” (Numbers 2:29). “All those counted for the camp of Dan…they shall travel last by their banners (Numbers 2:31), as anyone who engages in idol worship goes backward and not forward. That is why it is stated: “The Lord founded the earth with wisdom, established the heavens with understanding”(Proverbs 3:19).

The key point is, the kingdom of Yavan (Greece) was forcing upon Jewish people all different ways of heresy and avoda zara, with decrees to reject G-d of Israel, and the verse Isaiah 29:15 links avoda zara and darkness.

There are also circumstantial indications in other sources. For example, Megilas Taanis Adar

בח' בטבת נכתבה התורה יונית בימי תלמי המלך והחושך בא לעולם שלשת ימים.

On the 8th day of Teves the Torah was translated into Greek language in the days of king Ptolemy II and darkness (חושך) fell on the world for 3 days.

(On the kabbala level, the skin of the ox is used to make the batim for tefilin and parchments for Torah, tefilin, and mezuzos - items that symbolize the foundations of our faith and connection to the Torah. The fact that the Greeks forbade learning of the Torah - was a decree against our sekhel).

Interestingly, the mishna Mikvaos 9:2 also gives the answer which fits the language of the midrash. Among the things which prevent purification in the mikveh, the mishnah mentions טִיט הַיָּוֵן - miry, slimy clay and גֵץ יְוֵנִי - road clay, dirt:

What is meant by 'miry clay’? This means the clay in pits, for it is written: "He lifted me out of the miry pit, the slimy clay (מִטִּיט הַיָּוֵן)" (Psalms 40:3)... And "road-clay." These become like road-side pegs in these [kinds of clay] one may not immerse oneself nor immerse [other things] with them.

The root of the word יָּוֵן is the same as יון - the Hebrew name for Greece. Just like dirt prevents one to achieve purity, so did the Greek wisdom when applied to the wisdom of the Torah. For example, the Greeks denied that humans had ability to receive divine prophecy and that the laws of the Torah were divinely ordained. Such a view devalues the mitzvos and the Torah.

Regarding the kingdom of Edom, Yefeh To'ar gives two answers about the language מַה הַתְּהוֹם הַזֶּה אֵין לוֹ חֵקֶר - just as the depths cannot be calculated.

  1. Yefeh To'ar states that the evil kingdom of Edom was great and tenthfold mighty (i.e. its power cannot be calculated). The Romans recruited conscripts into their army people from all nations of the world (Bereshis Rabba 42:4). In the army they would forget their native language and all become Romans so that there would not be distinction between people of the empire. Even with respect to religion, the Romans modified the beliefs of the conquered nations so that their faiths became variants of the single imperial cult. In this respect, the empire was similar to the deep waters, where one cannot see anything and distinguish one thing from another. As every nation has its own good or bad inclinations, the mix creates the confusion when anything of value for neshamah could easily be targeted.

Alternatively, Yefeh To'ar with reference to ha-Arukh the words Bereshis Rabba 42:4 מַכְתֶּבֶת טִירוֹנְיָא מִכָּל אֻמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם as collecting taxes from all nations meaning such a large sum of money which cannot be calculated.

  1. The second answer of Yefeh Toar is based on Gemara Pesachim 54b:

the Sages taught: Seven matters are concealed from people, and they are: The day of death; and the day of consolation from one’s concerns; the profundity of justice, ascertaining the truth in certain disputes; and a person also does not know what is in the heart of another; and a person does not know in what way he will earn a profit; and one does not know when the monarchy of the house of David will be restored to Israel; and when the wicked Roman monarchy will cease to exist.

That is we cannot calculate the ending date of this kingdom.

  1. One can also adress the words מַה הַתְּהוֹם הַזֶּה אֵין לוֹ חֵקֶר directly with the verse Tehilim 42:8:

Where deep calls to deep (תְּהוֹם־אֶל־תְּה֣וֹם) in the roar of Your cataracts; all Your breakers and billows have swept over me.

Rashi here says:

Deep calls to deep One trouble calls the next one.

I.e. many troubles, hard to calculate. Radak here is even more explicit:

The deep. A hint at the troubles of the exile, which are likened to water, as if the troubles call out to each other: in the roar of Your cataracts. That is, my soul is humbled at the roar of your cataracts (conduits), meaning that thus the troubles continue upon us like water pouring from the roof from the conduit and making a sound, and it must be interpreted that the clouds will be called cataracts because they are conduits of rain and everything is a metaphor for the troubles:

  1. One can even include here the quoted Mishna Mikvaos 9:2 with reference to deep wells filled with muddy water preventing any purification and atonement for the sins. With absense of Beis haMikdash we do not have any prophetic insights to the end of the exile or to the end any of the difficulties that we have to live with and with any account for impurities that we may carry.

Finally, regarding Moshiyach, the midrash uses Isaiah 11:2, which speaks about time of moshiyach with completion of the man, as Malbim explains:

And it rested upon him, the perfection will be in three things, a. The perfections that depend on the fact that he has thinking nefesh, with strength, chokhmah, and binah. The chokhmah will be passed by tradition from the rabbis, and binah developing distinctions in matter by means of comparisons.

b. the perfection of him as a man, which includes the perfection in ability to give advice ('eitzah) and ability of might (g'vurah, i.e. guf). The power of advice as he will contemplate in every matter tenthfold. The power of might will come from completion of his physical development.

c. The perfections that depends on the fact that he is a holy, noble soul from on high whose elevation is higher than the thinking nefesh, and the perfection of this soul depends on whether he will have the knowledge of God, that is, to know true opinions in the truth of God, His providence and His ways. Such level was achieved by the prophets who communicated these truths in prophecy. And let him have a spirit of fear of God, for knowledge without fear is nothing, and likewise with fear without knowledge one does not know whom he is to fear. According to this, it means that these three perfections will be in the Messiah in completeness, sublime to the point of not being natural, but will relate to the Spirit of God, sublime from nature.

*Sources

(1) Commentary Yefeh To'ar on Midrash Bereshis Rabba 2:4 full edition by Zikhron Aharon

title: Is Hashem not obligated to provide for our needs, especially if we have been good?
content:
# Is Hashem not obligated to provide for our needs, especially if we have been good? ## Frage

Since Hashem created mankind, is he not obligated to provide for our needs? Parents are obligated to provide for the needs of their children, should we expect any different from Hashem, especially if we have been ritious and pious? Well, not according to Tehillim 16:2 which says;

"You should say to the Lord,'You are my Master; my good is not incumbent upon You.

Rashi explains: "The benefits that You do for me is not incumbent upon You to bestow [them] upon me, because You do not benefit me on account of my righteousness.

Can someone please help me understand why this is so?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

1: He created the concept of obligation. It’s His decision whether or not that concept should apply to Him.

2: We have a concept that one’s main reward is in the World to Come. Material benefits do not perfectly correlate to one’s merits. Anything that one receives in this world is only meant as a tool to increase the amount of goodness he can generate, and the ideal tools vary from person to person.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

There is a Tosfos in Berachos (I cannot currently find it), that says מאן דיהיב חיה יהיב מזונה meaning The One who gives life gives food. This is according to the attribute of Justice says Tosfos. Hence we say "נברך אלקנו" thanking Hashem (specifically using the name of Hashem that reflects Justice).

However on the other side the Ramban says in Torah Temimah (100) - I believe he states it in Chumash as well - that Hashem is not obligated to reward us - that is why Avraham trusting Hashem for the reward in this world is not an obvious requirement, because Hashem doesn't need to.

I think there is a simple resolution:

When it comes to your personal actions Hashem is not obligated, but because he had created you there should be enough food. Of course there are many functions of this world, and one of them might be to distribute food equitably - like charity. Therefore, yes Hashem makes the world have enough food - but we have a responsibility to help. Only in the wilderness that Hashem specifically led us, was Hashem possibly obligated to help us directly. (See Rav Nechemya Kornitzer on Yisro - that is why Rashi mentions the miracles Elokim (attribute of Justice) did for us is Mana, the well, and saving us from war).

title: Aliens and Ever Min Hachai
content:
# Aliens and Ever Min Hachai ## Frage

According to Halacha, does the prohibition of Ever Min Hachai apply to alien life, or only species of animals on earth? I believe it would likely apply to aliens, but since all Halacha of kashrut were in a context where only life on earth was known, I don’t know if the Psak is definitely the same for alien species.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Rambam states in Ma'achalot Asssuros 5:1

מפי השמועה למדו שזה שנאמר בתורה לא תאכל הנפש עם הבשר לאסור אבר שנחתך מן החי. ועל אבר מן החי הוא אומר לנח אך בשר בנפשו דמו לא תאכלו. ואיסור אבר מן החי נוהג בבהמה חיה ועוף בטהורים אבל לא בטמאים:

That Ever min hachai does not apply to non-kosher animals, so I suppose it might depend on whether the Alien is Kosher?

Also the Rambam points out it applies to Domesticated/Wild animals and birds. Perhaps this excludes Aliens or perhaps it is just meant to exclude fish. Similarly maybe Kashrus is only a requirement for animals from Earth?

Until further notice I'll assume the Rambam holds it does not apply to non-Kosher aliens.

title: Is the נִרְדָּף obligated to pay for the damage caused by his rescuer?

# Is the נִרְדָּף obligated to pay for the damage caused by his rescuer? ## Frage

The Gemara (Sanhedrin 74a) says that if someone caused damage while attempting to rescue his friend, he should really be liable to pay for the damages, but we still exempt him, so as not to discourage people from rescuing others.

title: What was the halachic / ethical basis for Yaakov to listen to his mother to lie to his father?
content:
# What was the halachic / ethical basis for Yaakov to listen to his mother to lie to his father? ## Frage

Yaakov was told by Rivkah to steal the blessings of Eisav and mislead Yitzchok. He went on to do so, and his only concern was that Yitzchok might reveal his identity.

What was the technical justification of this? He is obligated to respect both of his parents. To mislead his father is not against the respect? What is the weight of the command of his mother against speaking falsehood?

I saw that some explanations wanted to say that על פי הדיבור, Rivkah had a nevuah which has some sort of more obligation than regular כיבוד אב ואם, but this is very hard for me to hear. Does not the Rambam say that in order to listen to a navi to "temporary suspend" a mitzvah from the Torah the navi must have some חזקה?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

If I were Yaacov in that situation*, and I had to think on my feet, I would consider the Shach s'k 8 on SA YD 240:6, which state that when one is given a difficult situation of kibbud av v'em, one is allowed to do as they see as the best course of action. The best course of action ultimately preserves the parents' honour, and avoids their embarrassment as much as possible.

Indeed, what a difficult situation it was. On the one hand, Pitchei Teshuva brings up R' Akiva Eiger (Teshuvot, siman 68) that says maybe we should listen to the mother over the father (despite ibid. 240:18 "listen to father over mother" based on Kiddishin 31a, see Beur HaGolah) in this case, because maybe this involves a mitzva1. Rabbi Akiva Eiger quotes the Taz and overall this is also very relevant and much about honouring a father who does something "wrong" can be applied here, where he was about to give Yaacov's brachot to Esav.

The sensitivity towards how to handle complex situations is captured in the Aruch Hashulchan here, and the Ben Ish Chai Shana Bet Shoftim2, helping one factor embarrassment, emotional and moral sensitivity towards Yitzchak, his mother, and the situation, especially in the future when, as Shalom said in this comment, people will blame Yitzchak for giving the brachot to Esav.

Yaacov likely settled on the Marachei Leiv 2 Derush 73; Shaarei Ezra Y.D. 20; Kneses Hagedola 240:29; Maharshach 1:137 et al.3, which explain that one should listen to one's mother over one's father if she asks you to do something explicitly, but he didn't forbid it explicitly, in the very little time he had to think, and followed his mother. He could always blame the Shach for instructing that one should do as he pleased in these hard situations, in case it turned out he was wrong. From the overall response from commentaries on the Torah, it seems like he made the right decision though!

* This is all just theorising on my behalf of course. Thank goodness I am not actually Yaacov Avinu, because what a tough decision indeed it is, as stated. We don't wish upon ourselves the tests of our forefathers, not to mention the standards they were held to. Especially given the fact that, as we can see, bein adam lechavero (even the loftiest one that is included on the bein adam laMakom side of the luchot), involve halachot, like the Shach above, which basically say:

"do as you see fit and try your best (and make sure to learn and absorb as much Torah as possible for any chance at success!), because these situations are way too important, but also too hard and complex to provide a neat set of rules to cover everything"

1. Ensuring blessing for the Jewish people is in the Torah's interest, at least, which also is backed up by the spirit of SA YD 240:17 "do not honour requests to break the Torah", see this Shulchan Aruch Harav, and footnote 10: "Shut Rav Akiva Eiger 1:68 writes that in such a case he may precede whoever he wishes; Yad Eliyahu 1:40 rules that in such a case he must precede his mother; Chazon Ish Y.D. 149:6; Encyclopedia Talmudit ibid footnotes 655-656"
2. Especially 10 in particular, and this Taz.
3. Quoted in the same Shulchan Aruch Harav, footnote 18. See also this answer, and source.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

I've just found that Rav Osher Weiss had a very similar question and detailed analysis, alatt exactly in the same topic.

https://minchasasher.com/shiur/toldot-bereishit-shiurim/5776-midvar-sheker-tirchak/

Here he basically concludes that מדבר שקר תרחק is not an absolute Torah prohibition, rather, a virtue that can be and often indeed is overridden by other considerations.

(The irony of this all is that on the other end we have כיבוד אב ואם about which Shulchan Aruch YD 240:15 says that is overridden virtually by anything else, even rabbinic prohibition.)

title: What is the dating of Herod and Pompey's conquests of Jerusalem and the solemn fast
content:
# What is the dating of Herod and Pompey's conquests of Jerusalem and the solemn fast ## Frage

According to Josephus, Pompey took Jerusalem in the third month (Sivan) of 63 BCE during the solemn fast. He then later states that Herod captured Jerusalem in the third month, on the same day, also on the solemn fast, in 37 BCE.

Is there any record in Jewish literature of this solemn fast in the third month of Sivan? Or should this be a different month?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Whiston translation of Antiquities proposes that the fast Josephus referred to may have been the one on the 23rd of Sivan, which was traditionally believed to have originally been established to commemorate the day that King Jeroboam I banned the Kingdom of Israel from bringing tithes from the first fruits (Bikkurim) to the Temple in Jerusalem. This fast is first mentioned in some medieval lists of fasts (collectively known in modern scholarship as "Megillat Ta'anit Batra" = The Later Scroll of Fasting) that appear in works such as the Geonic-period book Halachot Gedolot (link) and Rabbi Yinon ben Tzemach's piyyut (link, lines 18-19) from the 12th century CE.

However, to my knowledge, we don't have traditional sources that tie this fast to Pompey's conquest or that of Herod.

Alternatively, a fast on the 27th of Sivan is also known from various medieval lists, as well as the late antiquity List of Fasts Inscription from the Tel Rehov Synagogue in Israel (discussed by Haggai Misgav here, p. 21). However, here again we have no known connection to Pompey/Herod.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The OP is asking two separate questions.

  1. The dating of Herod's and Pompei's conquest of Jerusalem according to Josephus

According to the article by Andrew Steinmann "When Did Herod the Great Reign?", p.8 the quote from Josephus is:

. . . this destruction befell the city of Jerusalem when Marcus Agrippa and Caninius Gallus were consuls in Rome on the one hundred eighty-fifth Olympiad, on the third month, on the solemnity of the fast,

The comment in the article explains the dating:

The consular year and Olympiad given by Josephus indicates that Herod took Jerusalem in 37 BCE. It was the Day of Atonement ("the fast") on 10 Tishri in the Jewish calendar, but the third month (September) in the Greek calendar.

This opinion is based on Emil Schürer's consensus in The History of Jewish People in the Age of Jesus Christ. In other words, Josephus is using Greek calendar, and Herod captured Jerusalem on Yom Kippur. If we were to believe that Herod captured Jerusalem exactly 27 years after it fell to Pompei, then we have to accept that Pompei also did it on Yom Kippur. However the dating of Josephus is unreliable, as the quoted article shows.

At the same time Sefer Yosipon edition of Flusser, chapter 43 The war with Antigonus,

All this came upon Jerusalem, the holy city, in the days of Roman officers Marcus Agrippa and Canidio Gallus (original: Canidius and Gallus) in the year 185 of the Olympiada in the fourth month on the day of fast.

The comment 269 (English edition comment 19) states:

The text of Antiquities by Josephus 14.487, has *in the third month of the 185th Olympiad. The author (of Sefer Yosippon) corrects the event to the fast day of 17th of Tammuz.

  1. What could be the actual dating of the Pompei's siege

According to the wikipedia, Pompei's siege of Jerusalem lasted 3 months:

After three months, Pompey's troops managed to overthrow one of the Baris towers and were able to enter the Temple precinct, both from the citadel and from the west. First over the wall was a senior officer in Pompey's army named Faustus Cornelius Sulla, the son of former dictator Sulla. Faustus was followed by two centurions, Furius and Fabius, who each led a cohort, and the Romans soon overcame the defending Jews, 12,000 of whom were slaughtered. Only a few Romans troops were killed.

and the historical site Livius.org states:

Hyrcanus' followers allowed Pompey to enter the lower town of Jerusalem, but Aristobulus' adherents, the Sadducees, still occupied the Temple. In the west, there was a bridge between the Temple and the city, but this had been destroyed; in the south and east, there were deep valleys. Therefore, Pompey decided to attack from the north. (They only worked on the siege dam on the sabbaths, because the Jews could defend themselves on that days, but were not allowed to attack.) When the siege dam was completed, towers were rolled towards the wall of the Temple. Catapults kept up a continuous pressure by hurling heavy stones; a battering ram broke the wall, and Pompey's soldiers entered the Temple terrace, where they started to kill the defenders. Many Jewish soldiers committed suicide, because they did want to see the profanation of the sanctuary (June/July 63).

If indeed Pompei captured Jerusalem on a fast day, most likely the fast in the OP's question is the Fast of the 17th of Tammuz or Fast of Sivan 23rd as suggested by Whiston.

title: Is it true that according to Kabbalah, everything that Yaakov Avinu did, Yosef also has to do, especially in the context of making 12 tribes?
content:
# Is it true that according to Kabbalah, everything that Yaakov Avinu did, Yosef also has to do, especially in the context of making 12 tribes? ## Frage

I heard this on a YouTube class from Rabbi Daniel Glatstein that he said that everything that Yaakov Avinu did, Yosef also has to do, especially in the context of making 12 tribes. I've wanted to find that class to get the source which he provided, but I can't seem to find it. Can anyone help? It had to do with the Universe of Leah and the Universe of Rochel in Kabbalah.

I also remember from another source that the 12 tribes of Yosef were made up of Efraim, Menashe, and the 10 sons of Binyamin who were all named after yosef, as it says in Rashi.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The source for this idea is in Midrash Tanchuma (Parshas Mikeitz 3) which states:

אַתְּ מוֹצֵא כָּל מַה שֶּׁהִגִּיעַ לְיַעֲקֹב הִגִּיעַ לְיוֹסֵף. יַעֲקֹב נוֹלַד מָהוּל, וְיוֹסֵף כֵּן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: אֵלֶּה תֹּלְדוֹת יַעֲקֹב יוֹסֵף. זֶה נִקְרָא בְּנִי בְכוֹרִי יִשְׂרָאֵל, וְזֶה הַבְּכוֹרָה לְיוֹסֵף. זֶה גָּלָה לְחָרָן, וְזֶה לְמִצְרָיִם. זֶה נִתְרוֹמֵם בַּחֲלוֹם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: וַיַּחֲלֹם וְהִנֵּה סֻלָּם (בראשית כח, כב), וְזֶה וּפַרְעֹה חֹלֵם

Everything that occurred to Jacob likewise happened to Joseph. Jacob was born circumcised, and so too was Joseph, as is said: These are the generations of Jacob, Joseph (Gen. 37:2). The former was called The son of my firstborn, Israel (Exod. 4:22), and the latter was spoken of as the firstborn was Joseph’s (I Chron. 5:2). The former was exiled to Haran, and the latter to Egypt. Jacob was exalted through a dream, as it is said: And He dreamed, and behold, a ladder set upon the earth (Gen. 38:22). Joseph interpreted Pharaoh’s dream.

The last statement you referenced is from the gemara (Sotah 36b):

תַּנְיָא: הָיָה רָאוּי יוֹסֵף לָצֵאת מִמֶּנּוּ שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר שְׁבָטִים כְּדֶרֶךְ שֶׁיָּצְאוּ מִיַּעֲקֹב אָבִיו, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אֵלֶּה תֹּלְדוֹת יַעֲקֹב יוֹסֵף״, אֶלָּא שֶׁיָּצָא שִׁכְבַת זַרְעוֹ מִבֵּין צִיפּוֹרְנֵי יָדָיו. וְאַף עַל פִּי כֵן, יָצְאוּ מִבִּנְיָמִין אָחִיו, וְכוּלָּן נִקְרְאוּ עַל שְׁמוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וּבְנֵי בִנְיָמִן בֶּלַע וָבֶכֶר וְאַשְׁבֵּל וְגוֹ׳״.

It is taught in a baraita: Joseph was deserving of having twelve tribes descend from him, the same as twelve tribes descended from his father Jacob, as it is stated: “These are the generations of Jacob, Joseph” (Genesis 37:2). This implies that everything that happened to Jacob was destined to happen to Joseph. However, he did not merit this because his semen was emitted from between his fingernails. And even so, the offspring that were meant to descend from him descended from his brother Benjamin, who had ten sons. And they were all named after Joseph, as it is stated: “And the sons of Benjamin: Bela, and Becher, and Ashbel, Gera, and Naaman, Ehi, and Rosh, Muppim, and Huppim, and Ard” (Genesis 46:21).

title: If someone killed accidentally and has no family members and he is not a ger can his friend kill him?
content:
# If someone killed accidentally and has no family members and he is not a ger can his friend kill him? ## Frage

If the person who was accidentally killed doesn't have any living family members to avenge him, can he be avenged by a friend? Does the killer need to seek refuge in an ir miklat?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The Ohr Same’ach (Hilchos Rotze’ach 6:12) writes that even in a case where there is no need to protect the murderer from the Goel Hadam, nevertheless he is still required to be exiled as an atonement.

He brings two proofs:

A. The Gemara says that even if the murderer already died, we still bring his body to the Ir Miklat (Makkos 11b).

B. If one accidentally killed an Eved Kena’ani, who halachicly has no relatives, nevertheless he is still required to be exiled (Makkos 8b).

title: What is the pronunciation of these nikkud?
content:
# What is the pronunciation of these nikkud? ## Frage

I am trying to learn Hebrew pronunciation by reading Rashi's commentary on the Torah. However, the Torah’s text in this version of the book has a lot of Nikkud which I cannot find an explanation. Namely, the only Nikkud whose pronunciations I found online are:

  • Hiriq ( ִ )
  • (Hataf) Kamatz ( ָ / ֳ )
  • (Hataf) Patakh ( ַ / ֲ )
  • (Hataf) Segol ( ֶ / ֱ )
  • Tzere ( ֵ )
  • Shva ( ְ )
  • Kubutz ( ֻ )
  • Shuruk (ּו)
  • Full / Lacking Hulam (וֹ/חֹ )
  • Dagesh ( ּ )

However, in this book, there are a lot of Nikkud which are not in the above list. For example, on the attached page, there are (starting on the last line of the 2nd column and going up)(and I am describing the Nikkud since I don't know their name):

  • < underneath
  • Magnifying glass on the top
  • | underneath
  • ` underneath
  • /\ underneath
  • ·/ underneath
  • / underneath

And also, in the same column, starting from the top line and going down:

  • / on top
  • . on top
  • : on top
  • ` on top
  • ד underneath

How do I pronounce these? Or do they have a use other than pronunciation?

Page illustrating the above-mentioned Nikkud:

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

The symbols you're describing are cantillation marks, or "trop." As Joel K noted, Wikipedia has a rundown of them (with melodies according to the Eastern Ashkenazi usage).

The long and short is that the various symbols are punctuation indicating syntactical groupings (with sof-passuk (אֽ׃) and etnachtah (א֑) being the strongest pauses) and (in most cases) indicating where the proper word stress should be. There are other resources on Mi Yodeya for trop; I can try to add them to this answer, later.

title: Giving charity after the person refuses to take it
content:
# Giving charity after the person refuses to take it ## Frage

If a person donated 50 for the shul to get a new air conditioner. A week later the Gabbai gives it back saying we raised the funds without you. Is there person still obligated to give the charity. Please explain the reason.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to this article, since it was a earmarked for a specific purpose which no longer exists, the contribution is nullified:

if the fundraiser set a specific goal that was known beforehand, every donor thought that his donation was going towards that goal. Had they had known that the goal was already met, they would not have given the donation; therefore, it can be said that the donations given above the goal are like the cases of the Teshuvos HaRosh where the donation is being given in error and, if possible, should be returned to the donors. title: Are there any issues of shavua (oath) in The Ritual of The Calling of an Engineer (Canada)
content:
# Are there any issues of shavua (oath) in The Ritual of The Calling of an Engineer (Canada) ## Frage

In Canada when graduating from engineering, one attends a "secret" ceremony, "The Ritual of The Calling of the Engineer." In this process, the new engineer makes a pledge to prioritize safety over profit and then receives the Iron Ring, which is worn on the pinky finger of the dominant hand.

Is there any issue of shavua or neder associated with reciting this at the ceremony?

The content of the pledge is as follows:

I, ____________, in the presence of these my betters and my equals in my calling, bind myself upon my honour and cold iron, that, to the best of my knowledge and power, I will not henceforward suffer or pass, or be privy to the passing of, bad workmanship or faulty material in aught that concerns my works before mankind as an engineer, or in my dealings with my own soul before my Maker.

My time I will not refuse; my thought I will not grudge; my care I will not deny towards the honour, use, stability and perfection of any works to which I may be called to set my hand.

My fair wages for that work I will openly take. My reputation in my calling I will honourably guard; but, I will in no way go about to compass or wrest judgment or gratification from any one with whom I may deal.

And further, I will early and warily strive my uttermost against professional jealousy or the belittling of my working colleagues, in any field of their labour.

For my assured failures and derelictions, I ask pardon beforehand, of my betters and my equals in my calling here assembled; praying, that in the hour of my temptations, weakness and weariness, the memory of this my obligation and of the company before whom it was entered into, may return to me to aid, comfort, and restrain.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The force of a shevua is the fact that it is verbally expressed as an intent to perform (or abstain from) an action, without any qualifiers. The Torah applies the halachic effect of a shevua under those conditions.

Paradoxically, if one were to attempt to add some sort of weight, an alternative authority, to the shevua, this would actually detract from the validity of the shevua (see YD 237:6). The question is, if the "oath" in this case is granted weight, according the the quoted formula, through the authority of "my honour and cold iron", does that, in effect, nullify what would have been a legitimate shevua?

I think it's reasonable to assume so. Although it is possible to interpret "my honour" as a euphemism for "the power of my word", I think this is farfetched.

Another alternative may be to pre-emptively declare in the presence of two kosher witnesses, that the oath one is going to declare should be null and void, nothingness, have no validity etc. etc.

It goes without saying that for a practical ruling, CYLOR.

title: Why did the angel strain or dislocate Yaakov's hip-socket?
content:
# Why did the angel strain or dislocate Yaakov's hip-socket? ## Frage

When the angel of Eisav was struggling with Yaakov, in Bereishis 32:26 the verse states:

וַיַּ֗רְא כִּ֣י לֹ֤א יָכֹל֙ ל֔וֹ וַיִּגַּ֖ע בְּכַף־יְרֵכ֑וֹ וַתֵּ֙קַע֙ כַּף־יֶ֣רֶךְ יַעֲקֹ֔ב בְּהֵאָֽבְק֖וֹ עִמּֽוֹ׃

When he saw that he had not prevailed against him, he wrenched Jacob’s hip at its socket, so that the socket of his hip was strained (or dislocated) as he wrestled with him.

As a result of the fight, Yaakov was limping (Bereishis 32:32)

Why did the angel injure Yaakov in this specific way, and why was it necessary that Yaakov have difficulty walking or running?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Radak on Bereshit 32:26 says it was a sin to be fearful and doubt Hashem's promises, for which he was punished:

היה לו זה מאת האל להיות בו זה לאות לפי שהיה פושע במחשבתו אחר כמה הבטחות אשר עשה עמו האל מדה כנגד מדה להיות פוסח בגופו; כי אע"פ שהיה בוטח באל בכל לבו אלא שחשב שמא יגרום החטא, אעפ"כ אחר כמה הבטחות לא היה לו להרהר ולחוש לעשו ולקראו כמה פעמים אחי ולשלוח לו מנחה גדולה ולהשתחות לו כמה פעמים, ובזה חטא, ושלם לו האל בזה העולם ולקה בגופו עונש מחשבת

This [the limping] was a sign from G’d, a reprisal of a kind, for the doubts he had expressed about the various promises G’d had made him. G’d now punished him by making him unable to rely on parts of his body that he was in the habit of relying on. True, Yaakov trusted G’d with all his heart, but he was in a constant state of worry that the promises he had received would not come true due to some sin he had committed. Considering that G’d’s promise had been repeated on different occasions, proving that in the interval Yaakov had not forfeited his claim to them, he should no longer have doubted that G’d would not keep His promise for whatever reason. His servile behaviour towards Esau, including the many times he called him adoni, “my lord,” implied a lack of trust in the validity of G’d’s promises to him. Neither should he have sent him such an elaborate gift, nor should he have prostrated himself before him repeatedly. By doing so he committed a sin and G’d punished him in this life by afflicting his body, retribution already for planning to do this. [borrowed Eli Munk's translation/explanation]

He should have relied on Hashem, and because he didn't, mida k'negged mida, he was punished by not being able to rely on his leg.

Why the hip socket?

Alshich

The hip socket is related to having children due to the phrase "יוצאי יריכו" is used by the Torah to refer to one's children. The angel was able to dislocate the hip because he found a flaw there - the fact that Yaacov married sisters. This point is explained (in slightly different ways) by various commentaries, such as Radak, Sforno.

Kitzur Ba'al HaTurim

He explains the angel touched the thigh to see if there was a joint there, because angels don't have joints. He also wanted to make a flaw in the Kehuna, and the phrase "בכף ירכו" has the same gematria as לפוסלו מכהונה, disqualified from the Kehuna.

Chatam Sofer

He explains that this is a hint at the destruction of the Beit Hamikdash, and the connection is the word "ירך", which, according to the Shalah, is three letters representing represents Torah, Torah learning, and the Beit Hamikdash respectively (the כ is for כסא, an allusion to the Beit Hamikdash), and also is pronounced kaf, which means "hollow", and that is reference to the hollow of the thigh.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

In addition to the earlier answer:

-The Rashbam says the angel came to prevent Jacob from escaping from Esau. God wants the brothers to meet, so sends the angel to dislocate Jacob's hip joint, thereby laming him and preventing any possibility of escape. The lesson is: You may not run away from your troubles.

-The Ramban says that the angel came to warn against antisemites: The whole matter represents an allusion to our future history, that there would come a time when the descendants of Esau would overcome Jacob almost to the point of total destruction. This happened during the days of the Sages of the Mishnah... There were other generations who did... worse things to us. But we endured all and it passed us by. [Also in Lekach Tov] The antisemites may wound us, as the entity wounded Jacob's hip, but they will not destroy us. After that incident, the Torah says: "וַיָּבֹא֩ יַעֲקֹ֨ב שָׁלֵ֜ם עִ֣יר שְׁכֶ֗ם Jacob arrived whole (shalem) in the city of Shechem". [Gen. 33:18] The battle will end “at the break of dawn”, which is the time of the final Redemption.

-Rabbenu Baḥya says the angel came to find a sin Jacob was guilty of, to use it as a weapon to overpower him. He did not succeed. The only sin he could find was that Jacob had married two sisters during their lifetime, something the Torah later forbade. The writing: “He inflicted an injury on Jacob’s hip joint” is a euphemism for his sexual organ and the seat of sexual desire. The punishment was administered near that organ so that Jacob limped for a while. The Zohar [1:170b] makes a similar point.

title: Why does the Torah ignore the Philistine nation?
content:
# Why does the Torah ignore the Philistine nation? ## Frage

The books of the Prophets and Kings highlight the ongoing conflict between the Judeans and the Philistines. However, the Torah shows no awareness of the Philistine nation (people) besides not letting the Israelites pass through their land in fear of witnessing war.

EDIT: Please note, I ask about the Philistines as a nation that resides within the borders of the Holy Land that God promises to His people, not the mention of several kings that Abraham and Isaac met.

They are not mentioned in the list of the eight nations to be obliterated, although they don't seem to be less idolatrous or evil. Their land, however, does constitute a part of the "Whole Eretz Israel" description "from the Nile to the Euphrates".

What are possible explanations for this phenomenon?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Both Avraham and Yitzchak extensively dealt with people living in Pilishtia and made peace agreements with them in Beer Sheva (Bereishis 21:32, Bereshis 26:28-29). Additional details about who were the Pilishtim are suggested by Talmud Chulin 60b and R' Guggenheimer in the answer regarding the wells, that Pelishtim comprized of 2 different people the Avvim who came from Teiman by the time of Avraham and displaced the Canaanim, while Pelishtim who were the Sea People from Kaftor (Cyprus) and Crete who came by the Time of Yehoshua. Possibly, because the Pelishtim (Avvim and Kaftorim) had their own lands in Teiman, the Sea Islands, and other Coastal areas, they never had a full claim to Eretz Yisrael. On the other hand, the Canaanim did have such a claim, as Avraham and Yaakov were buying land from them. (Many thanks to @Yø-cRo for very helpful sources).

Regardless, the midrash Bereshis Rabba 54:4 gives a possible reason, why the tensions between the Jews and Pelishtim arose only beginning with the era of Shoftim, once it became incumbent for the Jews to take over Eretz Israel and why they were able to conquer them only at the time of David:

“Abraham took flocks and cattle, and gave them to Avimelekh, and the two of them established a covenant” (Genesis 21:27). “Abraham set aside seven ewes of the flock by themselves” (Genesis 21:28). “Avimelekh said to Abraham: What are these seven ewes that you have placed by themselves?” (Genesis 21:29). “Abraham took flocks and cattle, and gave them to Avimelekh…Avimelekh said to Abraham: What are these seven ewes?” – the Holy One blessed be He said to him [Abraham]: ‘You gave seven ewes against My wishes, by your life, I will delay the rejoicing of your descendants for seven generations.’ ‘You gave him seven ewes against My wishes, by your life, they [the Philistines] will correspondingly kill seven righteous men of your descendants.’ They are: Ḥofni and Pinḥas, Samson, and Saul and his three sons. ‘You gave him seven ewes against My wishes, they [the Philistines] will correspondingly destroy seven Sanctuaries of your descendants.’ These are: The Tent of Meeting, Gilgal, Nov, Givon, Shilo, and the two eternal Temples [in Jerusalem]. ‘You gave him seven ewes against My wishes, My Ark will correspondingly circulate in the Philistine countryside for seven months.’ That is what is written: “He sent His strength into captivity, [and His splendor into the hand of the foe]” (Psalms 78:61) – this refers to the Ark of the Covenant. And it is written: “The Ark of the Lord was in the Philistine countryside seven months” (I Samuel 6:1). “And His splendor into the hand of the foe” – this refers to the priestly vestments, as it says: “You shall make holy vestments for Aaron…and for splendor” (Exodus 28:2).

Perhaps, the added words in brackets [the Philistines] implies that the Philistines cooperated with Assyria, Bavel, and other invaders against Jewish people. In particular, an earlier midrash Bereshis Rabba 54:2 explains the point about derekh Eretz Pelishtim:

Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said: It is written: “My enemies are mighty with life” (Psalms 38:20). What was granted to Abraham after seven generations was granted to Avimelekh after three. Why? “God did not guide them via the land of the Philistines” (Exodus 13:17), because his [Avimelekh’s] grandson was still alive [at that time]. (Moses was the seventh generation from Abraham, and he was not allowed to conquer the lands of the Philistines because Avimelekh’s third-generation descendant was still alive then. This shows the extraordinary longevity of Avimelekh’s line.)

title: Saying something in the name of someone who never actually said it
content:
# Saying something in the name of someone who never actually said it ## Frage

I remember years ago reading in one of Aryeh Kaplan's compendium works, a law that when someone feels confident that they're saying something correctly, that they can actually say it in the name of a big rabbi who never actually said it. Could somebody please confirm this? Thank you.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

The מגן אברהם brings based on 2 gemaras

אם שמע דין ונראה לו שהלכה כך מותר לאמרו בשם אדם גדול כי היכי דליקבלי מיניה [עירובין דף נ"א ופסחים דף קי"ב]

"If one hears a halacha that appears correct to himself, he may say it over in the name of a gadol in order that others will accept it"

As many in the comments pointed out, I should add that the מגן אברהם does go on to brings sources that seem to contradict this, and leaves the issue unresolved.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

As the other answer noted, the Magen Avraham brings this as one approach, though with others that contradict it. However, the Magen Avraham is an Acharon, it is worthwhile to trace his quoted sources to their origin and consider if that is their unambiguous meaning. Also, tracing sources allows us to draw influences about the situations / extent in which this might be acceptable.

This is particularly so given that this approach threatens to undermine the integrity of the masora. If any of my rabbis feel they can attribute their own thoughts to others, and that this lying is ethical, how do I know that they are not lying to me about anything that anyone said? Maybe the entire Mishnayot is made up, and none of those Tannaim said anything. Maybe the Magen Avraham never said this, and some printer decided this was a good idea on his own and then attributed it to the Magen Avraham!

To quote myself, in an article (Rabbi Yossi prevails):

In Eruvin 51a, third-generation Pumbeditan Amoraim, Rabba and Rav Yosef, were traveling before Shabbat, and wouldn’t arrive in the town in time. However, one can designate a Shabbat residence in a different location and thereby gain 2000 cubits of travel in each direction. One could travel 2000 cubits to that location and another 2000 cubits into the town. Rabba said “our residence will be under that palm tree which has another palm tree leaning on it. Rav Yosef said he did not know it. Rabba said: Rely on me, since there is a brayta in which Rabbi Yossi says that such a setup works, citing the brayta. The Talmudic Narrator continues with an astonishing comment, that it was not so – Rabbi Yossi didn’t actually say this. It was Rabba’s own position, but he falsely attributed it to Rabbi Yossi’s position, so that Rav Yosef would accept it from him, because רַבִּי יוֹסֵי נִימּוּקוֹ עִמּוֹ.

The "problem" with this suggestion that Rabbi Yossi didn't actually say it is that we have a Tosefta (much earlier authorship) in which Rabbi Yossi actually does say it. In Tosefta Eruvin 3:13:

האומר שביתתי בצד אילן בצד חרוב בצד גנה לא אמר כלום עד שיקנה לצפונו או לדרומו ד' אמות [קנה לצפון או לדרום] ד"א [נעקר] האילן [נעקר] החרוב [נעקר] הגנה אם מכיר את מקומו ה"ז מותר ואם לאו [ה"ז] אסור ר' יוסי אומר היו שנים א' מכיר וא' שאינו מכיר [הואיל וא' מהן מכיר שניהן מותרין].

Again, quoting myself:

For the Rabba - Rav Yosef incident, Tosefta Eruvin 3:13 has exactly this position for Rabbi Yossi about two travelers where only one knows the spot. There is scholarship that the Talmudic Narrator was unfamiliar with the Tosefta, so this could be another instance. Rabba didn’t make up a source or citation, but the Talmudic Narrator suggested that he did. (Indeed, I suspect this is a play on סְמוֹךְ עֲלַי, rely on me, both in a tree-knowing and halachic sense. The brayta with Rabbi Yossi may have been an earlier Stammaic stratum, explaining why Rabba said סְמוֹךְ עֲלַי, rather than Rabba’s own words, and the later Stamma took this as Rabba saying “depend on me because of the following brayta”.)

What about the other prooftext, Pesachim 112? Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai prevailed upon the imprisoned Rabbi Akiva to teach him Torah, and one of the teachings was:

אִם בִּקַּשְׁתָּ לֵיחָנֵק — הִיתָּלֵה בְּאִילָן גָּדוֹל

if you wish to strangle yourself, hang yourself on a tall tree.

Which Rav Natronai Gaon apparently says means to falsely attribute your own words. Rashi in Pesachim says:

ואם בקשת ליחנק היתלה באילן גדול - לומר דבר שישמע לבריות ויקבלו ממך ומשום דנקט לישנא דחניקה נקט היתלה באילן למוד בפני רב ואמור שמועותיו משמו:

If you wish to strangle yourself, hang yourself on a tall tree: [if you wish] to say something which is well received by people and they will accept it from you ... "hang yourself" -- learn before a rav and say his{1} teachings in his{2} name.

Note that Rashi explains this as saying שמועותיו, his teaching, משמו, in his name. He does not write שמועותיך, your own teachings in his name.

Again, quoting myself, even though I am not hanging myself on Rashi:

This need not mean fabrication. I’ve done the same in the following sense: if I want to say a big and controversial, e.g. that kezayit is actually much smaller than what kashrut organizations send out on charts, I might search for where Rav Herschel Schachter says such a thing, and then quote3. I’m not fabricating Rav Schachter’s comment, but bothering to search for it and cite it, since people won’t listen to Josh (bar Abba).

title: Is it possible to [sometimes] undo Lashon Hara?
content:
# Is it possible to [sometimes] undo Lashon Hara? ## Frage

If one spoke Lashon Hara to someone, and then realised and regretted it, can they go to that person and say "I know I said that, but I was wrong, it's not true, I was just in a bad mood and I spoke Lashon Hara, please don't believe it anymore" and potentially offer a second interpretation of what happened that is not Lashon Hara?

e.g. I said to my wife

This person doesn't know what they are talking about. They speak a lot but it's clear they don't really know what they are saying, they are just reguritating information.

Now, I look back, and I realise it was Lashon Hara. Should I go back to my wife and tell her

Actually, I was just in a bad mood, and it was Lashon Hara to say what I said, and for all I know, he does know what he is talking about and I was just being too harsh. Please pretend I never said it and let's both take on to show this person more respect in our hearts and our deeds.

This is assuming she hasn't told anyone else, in which case it will be a much bigger problem.

So, if yes, this is what one can/should do, it a complete rectification, or only partial? What else should one do when one has spoken Lashon Hara like this? Maybe they should go to the person and say what they said and ask for forgiveness, but I've heard that this isn't always the best thing to do, because it will add another sin on top of the previous one, by making them feel bad. But, there's also the side that says it's obligatory to get their forgiveness.

So, I hope my question is clear, let me know if I can sharpen it.
