title: If men are chesed, and women are gevura, why does it seem the other way around?
content:
# If men are chesed, and women are gevura, why does it seem the other way around? ## Frage

The Zohar* teaches that the penimiut (personal, inner quality, root) of men is Chesed (Kindness), and the penimiut of women is Gevura (Severity/Justice).

I think if you were to ask someone what they think is the penimiut of men and women, before teaching them this Zohar, they would arrive at the opposite conclusion. [Source: far more police officers are men, far more carers are women.]

So, how can we understand the truth vs. the fact here? The truth is men are founded on being givers, and thus kindness, but in fact, men seem to be the "harder" gender, and women, who are founded on justice and severity, seem to be the "softer" gentler gender.

What explains this (seeming) discrepancy?

* Zohar, parashat Tazria p.43a according to this Chabad article, which explains the same: https://www.chabad.org/kabbalah/article_cdo/aid/379912/jewish/Shadows-and-Soul-Mates.htm/utm_source/chatgpt.com. Note, I didn't check the source; I asked chatgpt to find an article that discusses this, because I've only seen it discussed in Chassidus, not seen the actual Zohar before, although this principle is well known in Chassidus. If someone finds an issue with this source, let me know, I can find many more)

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

I have 2 answers. The first I heard here, and the second was originally my own understanding, and then I found a source, which is quoted:

  1. Each gender is given the role that is not already part of their consitution, in order to arrive at shlemut, perfection. I.e. we must rectify the areas we are lacking*.

  2. According to this Chida, it's because we are not put "in charge" of roles that we take personally, because it prevents us being objective.

    These examples are based on my understanding of this concept, by me (and are based on stereotypes, apologies). Let me know if you understand differently from the Chida:

    I.e. if a woman senses injustice occuring to her penimiut (her, her children, her loved ones), she is predisposed to be outraged on such a primal level - she takes it so personally - that she might lose her objectivity and overreact, in general. Better that men do the "justising" in society, as they are more likely to be able to keep it together, and stay objective, as "justice" isn't "personal" to them.

    When it comes to men, there are many examples, but for now I will stick to rejection. I would say it's a cultural meme and therefore quite well known and accepted that men find rejection harder tham women do, and this is because when a man tries to give, it's personal and therefore his giving being rejected causes a deep inner pain. It is also pretty well known that men find it harder to say no than women (giving is all about 'yes'), at least in some contexts. Therefore, carer roles where it's important to have an objectivity in giving, and being able to establish boundaries, are best left to women.

To further back up this latter point, I found what could very well be the fuller explanation of the Chida's point. In אדם כי יקריב מכם (found in פלח הרמון on Vayikra, brought in Otzar HaChasidim)

Here the Mittler Rebbe tackles a few contradictions surrounding this and related issues. One resolution is that in the penimiyut (personal dimension) of Chochma, it is Gevura (He gives the example of a great sage who is often deep in his intellectual studies and therefore is not really a "giver", and great Tzaddikim who did not want to take on leadership), and in the chitzoniut (the outer part, i.e. the emotions within Chochma, from which the emotions of the heart are drawn), it is Chessed.

The converse is true of Binah.

Given that men are from the side of Chochma, and women are from the side of Binah (see here), we can perhaps look at it like this: on the emotional level, men are indeed Chesed, and women Gevura, while in the intellectual sphere, it is the other way around.

This matches the above quite well as generally, in Chassidus, the intellectual plane is considered objective, and the heart is considered subjective, and personal.

If anyone would like me to elaborate on some of the deeper Chassidut that goes behind the points I summarised here from the maamar, please ask in comments.

* Someone heard this from a quoted Rav, and told me this on this site. I can't remember who or where, so if anyone knows, please let me know and I will make sure to quote them, and the Rav (and link the comment). Thanks!

title: Why is נַעֲרָה spelled without a ה?
content:
# Why is נַעֲרָה spelled without a ה? ## Frage

In almost every instance in the Torah, the word נַעֲרָה is spelled without a ה at the end. Do any commentaries suggest any reasons for this, specifically how it relates to Rivkah?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The commentary Minchas Shai extensively deals with the problem. Minchas Shai on Bereshis 34:3 says:

את הנער. לב הנער. הנערה ק' וכן השני והשלישי ובמסורת כל אורייתא חסר במ"א וענשו אותו מאה דפ' כי תצא וכמ"ש שם והה"א לבדה במאריך וכן כולם במדוייקים:

Young Girl. Heart of a Young Girl. The full spelling נַעֲרָה can be found 100 times (in Tanach). But incomplete spelling ָנַעֲר, which we also see here in the second and third cases, is found 41 times (in Tanakh), and the one out of the 100 full spellings is penalized in parashas Ki Tetze where we explained that it is an exceptional case. All of these spellings are verified.

Minchas Shai on Bereshis 24:14 refers to Zohar "daf 51", according to Sefaria, Zohar perek 86, which says:

When they had returned, Rabbi Simeon spoke: The description I have given may be taken as a symbol of the holy unity of God. In the holy name YHVH, the second letter hé is the blue or black light attached to the remaining letters yod, hé, vav, which constitute the luminous white light.

But there come times when this blue light is not héi (ה) but dalet (ד), which is to say, poverty; this means, when Israel fail to cleave to it from beneath and it in turn fails therefore to burn and cleave to the white light, the blue light is dalet (ד), but when Israel make it to cleave to the white light, then it is hei (ה).

מְנָלָן דִּכְתִיב, (דברים כ״ב:כ״ג) כִּי יִהְיֶה נַעֲרָה בְּתוּלָה, נַעַר כְּתִיב בְּלָא ה'. מַאי טַעְמָא בְּגִין דְּלָא אִתְחַבְּרַת בִּדְכוּרָא. וּבְכָל אֲתַר דְּלָא אִשְׁתַּכְּחוּ דְּכַר וְנוּקְבָא, ה"א לָא אִשְׁתְּכַח וְסָלְקָא מִתַּמָּן וְאִשְׁתָּאַר ד'.

Why is it written in Devarim 22:23 "When there is a young (נַעֲרָה) virgin ..." but in other cases ָנַעַר without ה? What is the reason? On account that she would not join with the male. And in every place that we would not find both male and female, the letter ה will not be found, and therefore there remains only letter ד.

The fact that Rivka was 14 and over the age of 12 can be learned from the analysis of the Midrash Seder Olam Oriental manuscripts although European manuscripts state that she was 3. In other words, Zohar hints that Rivka did not develop fully and could not have children.

Finally, to address the point in parashas Ki Teitze, Devarim 22:19:

ונתנו לאבי הנערה. לית מלא בתורה והכי נמי אמרינן בכתובות פרק ג' ופרק ד' אמר ר"ל המוציא שם רע על הקטנה פטור שנאמר ונתנו לאבי הנערה נערה מלא דבר הכתוב וכו' ולפיכך יש לתמוה על הרמב"ם ז"ל והקרית ספר דבריש פרק ג' מהלכות נערה בתולה כתבו ואינו חייב עד שיוציא על הנערה שנאמ' והוציאו את בתולי הנערה נערה מלא דבר הכתוב וגם הסמ"ג בעשין נ"ה כתב כן וזה שלא בדקדוק וכבר העיר בזה הכסף משנה. ונתעוררו חז"ל בספר הזוהר על מה שכתוב בכל הפרשה נער חסר ה"א והטעם כי הה"א רומזת לה"א אחרונה של שם והיא חסרה מן הנערה הזאת אך ונתנו לאבי הנערה מלא כי היא בשלימותה וזהו כי הוציא שם רע על בתולת ישראל ורמז לכנסת ישראל של מעלה. תבין מכאן עונש המוציא שם רע עד היכן מגיע קלקולו. ריקנאטי ועיין עוד בזוהר דפוס קרימונה פרשת בראשית עמוד ס"ז:

It should not be complete in the Torah, and so it is said in Gemara Kesubos perek 3 and 4, for example Kesubos 40b

Reish Lakish said: One who slanders a minor girl, falsely claiming that she was not a virgin on the wedding night, is exempt from paying the fine, as it is stated: “And they shall give them to the father of the young woman [נַעֲרָה]” (Deuteronomy 22:19). The verse spoke of נַעֲרָה, not only pronounced but written in full, indicating that this payment is in effect only with regard to a young woman, not a minor girl. However, in places where the term is written נַעֲרָ, even a minor girl would be included.

Therefore, one can wonder on the words of Rambam and Kiryas Sefer, an in the beginning perek 3, hilkhos Virgin Maiden (Naarah Besula) where they wrote:

He is not liable unless he issues a slanderous report regarding a na'arah. (1)(2) [This is derived from Deuteronomy 22:15]: "[They will] present signs of the maiden's virginity." The word נערה, "maiden" is written in a full form. (3)(4)

And also SM"G B'Osin 55 wrote so, which is not according to grammar. And already Kesef Mishneh arose awareness about it. And in Sefer haZohar they aroused attention when in the entire parasha used נַעֲרָ (without ה) and the reason that the letter hei (ה) hints to the final ה of the name and it is lacking from this (particular) maiden. However, in this case ונתנו לאבי הנערה it is spelled with hei (ה) because she is a mature virgin (b'sheleimusa), and that is why a man who slanders a virgin of Israel, hints to the congregarion of Israel of the above. One should understand from here the punishment of the slanderer, and how far the damage that he inflicts goes. (Rekanati and also look in Zohar, Dfus Kadmon (Old Edition?), section Bereshis Amud 67).

By the way, if one stares into the words of Zohar for a long time, one finds why Yehudah spelled with hei has good children with Tamar spelled without hei, and one should not worry about Yosef and Osnath, for ת at the end is also feminine like hei. Also Sarai did not have hei and with her husband Avram they lacked ability to have children, which explains the name their name change to Avraham and Sarah.

(1) As mentioned previously, the term na'arah implies a specific time frame: the six months after a girl's manifestation of physical signs of maturity once she has reached the age of twelve.

(2) As mentioned in the notes on Chapter 1, Halachah 8, the word na'arah, "maiden" is sometimes used by the Torah to refer to girls between the ages of three and twelve and a half. In this instance, however, the meaning of the term is specific.

(3) Generally, the word נערה, maiden, is written in the Torah without the final heh. The inclusion of the heh is obviously purposeful and intended to teach a concept.

(4) The Rambam's statements have aroused the attention of the commentaries, for in our Torah scrolls the word נערה in the verse cited by the Rambam lacks a heh. The Kessef Mishneh (based on Ketubot 40b and Rashi, 44b) notes that the Talmud derives this concept from Deuteronomy 22:19: "And he shall give it to the father of the maiden." In that verse, the word נערה is written with a heh in our Torah scrolls.

title: Is Moshe Idel’s scholarship considered kosher by the Orthodox Jewish community
content:
# Is Moshe Idel’s scholarship considered kosher by the Orthodox Jewish community ## Frage

I’m curious whether the scholarship of Moshe Idel, a contemporary scholar of Kabbalah, is considered kosher (i.e., that his scholarship doesn't contradict the Mesorah) and reliable (i.e., that a significant number of Orthodox rabbis/theologians vouch for his work) by the broader Orthodox Jewish community. If so, to what degree is his scholarship considered authoritative?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The way the question is phrased is perhaps vague, but I can report having attended a lecture by Professor Idel at Yeshiva University's Revel graduate school. Revel itself does not 100% align with all of YU/RIETS Roshei Yeshivas' hashkafot, but there were many YU rabbis in attendance.

I should further point out that this lecture was not primarily focused on Idel's mysticism scholarship.

Professor Idel has said publicly and in personal correspondence that he is not orthodox. His writings explicitly indicate that he does not believe the preponderance of Zoharic material to be authored by Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

As already has been discussed in the comments, there is no doubt he is an academic. However, he does not present as "mekubal" and neither does any of his writings maintain any Rabbinic approbations.

Even the academic studies that discuss his approach to Kabbalah and Jewish outlook appear to note his apparent lack of orthodoxy. For example, here in the abstract it writes:

The article discusses the contribution of Moshe Idel’s vast research to the field of religious studies. The terms which best capture his overall approach are “plurality” and “complexity”. As a result, Idel rejects essentialist definitions of “Judaism”, or any other religious tradition.

title: Is the Heter for music on Shabbat universal
content:
# Is the Heter for music on Shabbat universal ## Frage

According to this answer some Rabbis (to my understanding, generally Hasidic ones) give a Heter for playing instruments on Shabbat because of the fact that nowadays most people aren’t skilled in repairing instruments. My question is, does this Heter apply universally, or does it only apply to people who don’t know how to repair instruments, and people who do know aren’t included in the Heter. Furthermore, are there any leniencies for Oneg Shabbat?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 9)

That wasn't what the Ramah said. His two explanations for why the hoi polloi clap and dance today are:

1.) Really, it's prohibited; but today's rabbis gave up on saying "no" because people will do it anyhow.

2.) Very few people do proper instrument repairs today. So "if we allow clapping and dancing, people will start playing instruments, and then do proper repairs on them" is exceedingly unlikely. So "everything" -- i.e. dancing/clapping -- is actually permitted today, unlike the above answer.

Let's assume in the times of the Mishna, the probability of going from clapping/dancing to using musical instruments was A, and from using them to fixing them (in a truly Biblical way) was B. Both A and B are numbers somewhere between 0 and 1. A x B yields a probability that's still plausible, so the Sages prohibited.

The Ramah says that today, the probability of going from using instruments to fixing-them-in-a-Biblical-craftsman way is now C, which is less than B. And A x C = something so negligible as to not be subject to a rabbinic enactment.

Just because A x C = negligible, does not mean that C alone is negligible. If you start clapping/dancing, you have A x C; but once you start using instruments, you have C alone, which is greater than A x C, and therefore prohibited.

Please. No musical instruments on Shabbos. (Not until you're working in the Beis HaMikdash.)

title: Who is the "other one" in Daniel 7?
content:
# Who is the "other one" in Daniel 7? ## Frage

Is there any interpretation that makes sense of the passage in Daniel 7 (quoted below):

According to Rashi the "other one" who will arise is Titus, but that would mean that Mashiach had to arrive right afterwards. According to Rambam it is Mohammed, but it does not really fit with 10 Kings. Is there any explanation that sits well?

The fourth beast [means]—there will be a fourth kingdom upon the earth which will be different from all the kingdoms; it will devour the whole earth, tread it down, and crush it. And the ten horns [mean]—from that kingdom, ten kings will arise, and after them another will arise. He will be different from the former ones, and will bring low three kings. He will speak words against the Most High, and will harass the holy ones of the Most High. He will think of changing times and laws, and they will be delivered into his power for a time, times, and half a time.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

This answer is partially about your quote from the Book of Daniel, a portion of Ketuvim, Writings, and partially to the status of Daniel as a prophet.

What follows is excerpted from Rabbi Steinsaltz introduction to the Book of Daniel as hosted on Sefaria. Rabbi Steinsaltz differentiates those people acknowledged as Nevi'im, true prophets, and those who are not. In his opinion, Daniel was not a Prophet, and the Book of Daniel is not prophecy.

Rabbi Steinsaltz defines a prophet is "a person who receives his words as a prophecy and delivers them as a messenger of G-d." Not everyone who has visions is speaking words originating directly from G-d. Many non-Jews attempt to find origins and predictions of their own religions by misinterpreting Jewish seforim through their own religious beliefs. They do this through ignorance of the original or through malicious manipulation. By claiming their interpretation as being "correct" their purpose is the conversion of Jews away from Judaism and toward their religion.

Specific to Daniel 7, Rabbi Steinsaltz writes:

(Daniel 7:1–28) The Four Kingdoms and the Kingdom That Follows Them In this vision, which Daniel receives in a dream, he sees large animals and other figures. An angel deciphers the dream’s main message, which relates to various kingdoms that will arise and fall from the stage of history in the future. Despite the angel’s assistance, the meaning of many of the details noticed by Daniel remain obscure.

The status of Daniel as a prophet:

The book of Daniel is unique among the books of the Bible in several respects.

  • The book of Daniel focuses on one central character. While other individuals appear in the book as well, it mainly relates the story of Daniel’s life, from his early years, and describes his deeds and visions.

  • Despite Daniel’s visions, he is not considered a full-fledged prophet. The fact that the book of Daniel is not listed among the books of Prophets in the Bible, but rather as part of the Writings, is not because of its relatively late date.

Rather, Daniel is not one of the books of the Prophets because Daniel has a different status from the prophets whose books were included in that section of the Bible. A prophet is not simply one who sees heavenly visions, predicts the future, or discloses events occurring in other parts of the world, but a person who receives his words as a prophecy and delivers them as a messenger of G-d.

Even when [Daniel] dealt with general matters and shared the revelations he had experienced through angels or by means of dreams, he was not sent to others as a prophet. Consequently, his book can be described as a biography.

title: Is there a halakhic basis for the position of Chief Rabbi of a country whose authority must be acknowledged by all Jewish citizens?
content:
# Is there a halakhic basis for the position of Chief Rabbi of a country whose authority must be acknowledged by all Jewish citizens? ## Frage

Wikipedia lists 39 countries which have one or more Chief Rabbis, counting the United Kingdom and Commonwealth as one rabbinate. Israel is the only country in which the Ashkenazi and Sephardic Chief Rabbis are government positions which regulate halakhic matters pertaining to all Jewish citizens.

Since Israel is a unique country, I am asking about other countries with Jewish populations and the quasi-governmental office of "Chief Rabbi," considered to be "the recognized religious leader of that country's Jewish community, or to a rabbinic leader appointed by the local secular authorities."

In countries with small, long-established Jewish communities it is likely that the Chief Rabbi's office will overlap closely with the traditional ethno-religious Jewish population. That rabbi will be the agreed upon halakhic authority of the community. For example, Iran has approximately 9,000 Jewish citizens. The three most recent Chief Rabbis of Iran have been the rabbis of The Yusef Abad Synagogue (Sukkot Shalom Synagogue), the main synagogue in Teheran.

With a Jewish population of approximately 300,000, Great Britain has representative populations of Orthodox, Haredi, Masorti, and Reform Jews. However, the Office of the Chief Rabbi is held by the Orthodox Chief Rabbi of the United Hebrew Congregations of Great Britain and the Commonwealth. This is a quasi-governmental position, as Great Britain has an Established Religion, whose leaders are permanent members of the House of Lords. While Chief Rabbis have been knighted and made Life Peers, they are not automatically members of the government.

Since Britain has a heterogeneous Jewish population, does the Chief Rabbi hold halakhic authority over British Jews outside of the United Hebrew Congregations (Orthodox)?

title: Sugar on Motzei Shabbos
content:
# Sugar on Motzei Shabbos ## Frage

I have heard of a Minhag of the Baal Shem Tov and have observed this amongst Chasidim, to have some sugar in a hot drink on Motzei Shabbos.

Does anyone know the source of this Minhag?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

In הליכות קדוש p. 434 R. A.Y.Y. Geldzahler writes (regarding the Rebbe of the Shomrei Emunim):

אחר סדר הלימוד היה רביה"ק זיע"א שותה כוס תה או קפה חם ואמר חמין במוצאי שבת מלוגמא היא

After his scheduled study the Rebbe would drink a cup of hot tea or coffee and say "hot water after the Sabbath is a remedy" (Shabboth 119b)

The footnotes add that he would instruct others to add more sugar than during the week and would tell over a story about R. Elimelekh of Lizhensk. King David once appeared to R. Elimelekh after Shabboth and asked him "why aren't you eating a se'udath melaweh malka" R. Elimelekh responded that it was very difficult for him, to which King David responded "at least drink a cup of tea" and when R. Elimelekh drank the tea with sugar then King David would appear to him with a crown on his head, and when he drank it without sugar he would appear to him without a crown. The footnotes also cites another variant of this story according to which R. Elimelekh was accustomed to drinking a cup of tea with sugar on Mosei Shabboth and one time he couldn't find even a bit of sugar in the house to put in his tea, King David appeared to him without a crown and R. Elimelekh asked him "where is your crown?" to which King David responded "where is the sugar that is missing from your Mosei Shabboth tea?"

title: Gen 25:8 Difference between translations
content:
# Gen 25:8 Difference between translations ## Frage

I was reading Gen 25:8 in Sefaria

וַיִּגְוַ֨ע וַיָּ֧מׇת אַבְרָהָ֛ם בְּשֵׂיבָ֥ה טוֹבָ֖ה זָקֵ֣ן וְשָׂבֵ֑עַ וַיֵּאָ֖סֶף אֶל־עַמָּֽיו׃

Abraham became faint, and he died at a ripe old age — old in years, and satisfied to see that what he had wanted was accomplished; and he was brought into eternal life, together with all the righteous of his people. (אונקלוס, ספורנו.)

Then I read the same verse in BibleHub.com, which offers many variants of the same type:

Then Abraham breathed his last and died at a good old age, an old man and full of years; and he was gathered to his people.

All of them missing the and he was brought into eternal life part, which is weird for christians to do, as the promise of eternal life is so prominent in Jesus' preaching.

I don't read hebrew, so I can't compare the hebrew text in BibleHub.com against Sefaria's.

What is the explanation for this difference?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 9)

The phrase under discussion comprises the three Hebrew words:

ויאסף אל עמיו

va-ye'asef el amav

which can be literally translated as something like "and he was gathered to his people".

This translation (or something similar) is what you are seeing in the Christian translations you consulted, as well as in the majority of the Jewish translations available on Sefaria.

The particular translation you linked to from Sefaria is Rabbi Charles Kahane's Torah Yesharah, which calls itself a "Traditional Interpretative Translation", and which incorporates a heavy amount of later commentary into the translation itself.

Thus, following Seforno (as noted in Hebrew in the parentheses following the translated verse) R. Kahane interprets the idea of being "gathered to one's people" as a reference to attaining eternal life alongside the righteous.

title: Lesser known Sefardi commentaries on the Parasha (online)
content:
# Lesser known Sefardi commentaries on the Parasha (online) ## Frage

Very simple question. I am always looking to add to my list of Sefardi (incl. Edot Mizrach, Italian etc.) commentaries that I can draw Divrei Torah from. I have been relying mainly on the Chida, because he has many works, and I resonate with him very well. Also, as a bonus, most of his works are on Sefaria, in full, which saves me money!

I have also been using Rabbi Yosef Chaim's sefarim (also on sefaria) to draw from, as well as R' Avraham Azulai's. There's also, in no particular order, of course Ramban, Ibn Ezra, Or HaChaim Hakodesh, Rabbeinu Bachaye, Sa'adia Ga'on, Maskil LeDavid, Tzror UMor, Sforno and the Alshich Hakodesh.

There are a great many other sefardi gedolim throughout the ages, but I am having trouble sourcing their sefarim online. I am also interested in hearing of lesser known ones, whether online or not, so to boil down my question:

Please recommend Sefardi Rabbonim's commentaries on the Parasha, especially those that are found online, especially rarer ones (and please use my list above to know what not to mention as I already have access to those)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Let me introduce you to the fantastic alhatorah.org and in particular their Mikraot Gedolot.

In addition to those you listed above, sefardic Torah commentaries available there include:

  • R. Yehuda ibn Bil'am
  • Radak (born in Provence to a family of Spanish origin)
  • R. Avraham ben HaRambam (born in Egypt to a family of Spanish origin)
  • Akeidat Yitzchak
  • Abravanel

Also, depending on how you classify who is a "sefardi", also:

  • R. Yosef ibn Kaspi (born in Provence but spent much time living in Spain)
  • Tur (long and short commentaries) (born in Germany but moved to Spain)
### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

In addition to the famous collection of halakhic drashot called "Ben Ish Chai," R' Yosef Chayim of Bagdad also wrote a collection of regular drashot on the parsha, called Aderet Eliyahu. There's also a collection of Ramchal's writings called "Ramchal on the Parsha." If you're interested in this, the Orot Sephardic Chumash might be a good choice.

title: Who established the tefilas Mussaf?
content:
# Who established the tefilas Mussaf? ## Frage

Many people know the aggadeta in gemara Berakhos 26b regarding the origin of daily tefilos:

The Gemara comments: It was taught in a baraita in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, and it was taught in a baraita in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi. The Gemara elaborates: It was taught in a baraita in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina: Abraham instituted the morning prayer (shacharis), as it is stated when Abraham came to look out over Sodom the day after he had prayed on its behalf: “And Abraham rose early in the morning to the place where he had stood before the Lord” (Genesis 19:27), and from the context as well as the language utilized in the verse, the verb standing means nothing other than prayer, as this language is used to describe Pinehas’ prayer after the plague, as it is stated: “And Pinehas stood up and prayed and the plague ended” (Psalms 106:30). Clearly, Abraham was accustomed to stand in prayer in the morning.

Isaac instituted the afternoon prayer (mincha), as it is stated: “And Isaac went out to converse [lasuaḥ] in the field toward evening” (Genesis 24:63), and conversation means nothing other than prayer, as it is stated: “A prayer of the afflicted when he is faint and pours out his complaint [siḥo] before the Lord” (Psalms 102:1). Obviously, Isaac was the first to pray as evening approached, at the time of the afternoon prayer.

Jacob instituted the evening prayer (maariv/arvit), as it is stated: “And he encountered [vayifga] the place and he slept there for the sun had set” (Genesis 28:11). The word encounter means nothing other than prayer, as it is stated when God spoke to Jeremiah: “And you, do not pray on behalf of this nation and do not raise on their behalf song and prayer, and do not encounter [tifga] Me for I do not hear you” (Jeremiah 7:16). Jacob prayed during the evening, after the sun had set.

While the question is essentially similar to the question "Who instituted the Musaf prayer?", I am asking for a source in חז"ל, not commentary. Is there a similar statement in chazal (including kabbala) regarding the origin of tefilas mussaf, attributing it to either forefathers, foremothers, or the shevatim?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

The זוהר חדש affiliates the אושפיזין to the קרנבות מוסף of Shabbos and all the Yomim Tovim. A little interpretation is needed for some of them but it appears to me as such:

שבת כנגד יוסף - Shabbos relates to Yosef

פסח כנגד אברהם - Pesach relates to Avraham

שבועות כנגד יעקב - Shevous relates to Yaakov

ראש השנה כנגד יצחק - Rosh Hashana relates to Yitzchak

יום כיפור כנגד משה - Yom Kippur relates to Moshe

סוכות כנגד אהרון - Sukkos relates to Aharon

ראש חודש כנגד דוד - Rosh Chodesh relates to Dovid

title: Please explain the end of Tosefta Eduyot
content:
# Please explain the end of Tosefta Eduyot ## Frage

At the end of Tosefta Eduyot 3:4 it states:

One who has students, they call him rabbi. When his students were forgotten, they called him rabban. When both of these are forgotten, they call him by his name.

What does this mean? There are many examples of Rabbis with the appellation Raban (such as Gamliel, Shimon etc.) whose students were not forgotten. The same is true of those who are called by name such Hillel and Shammai.

In short, please explain the end of Tosefta Eduyot.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 13)

The חסדי דוד wishes to make a correction to the text, and rather when forgotten נשתכחו, he corrects it to when his students receive ordination נסמכו, and goes on to explain, that first the teacher is referred to as Rabbi. When the students are ordained, they are now referred to as Rabbi and the teacher as Raban. When the new Rabbis now ordain students, the 3rd generation is referred to as Rabbi, the 2nd as Raban, and the 1st as just their names.

title: 70 nations vs 70 who went down to Egypt
content:
# 70 nations vs 70 who went down to Egypt ## Frage

What's the connection between the 70 nations and the 70 descendants of Yaacov who went to Egypt? Is there a 1:1 correllation anywhere?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

I tried to follow the advice of אילפא and look in Rabbeinu Bachya. Sefer Sitrei Rabbeinu Bachya, parashas Vayigash (Bereshis 46:15) states

וחיזקיר כל השבעים בלשון נפש וכו' נגד ע' המלאכים הסובבים כסא הכבוד הניקראים בית דינו כדלקמן. ועמ"ש רבינו ז"ל בפרשת בשלח ע"פ ויבואו אילימה

And he mentioned all 70 people using the term nefesh etc. The 70 souls [who descended with Yaakov to Egypt] correspond to the Throne of Glory, which is called G-d's Court of Justice, as we explained earlier. And look up what Rabbeinu Bachya wrote in parashas Beshalach, the comment on words And they came to Eylim (Shemos 15:27)

If we look up Rabbenu Bachya Shemos 15:27 (midrash, and kabbala), we find an extended comment of which the comment of Rabbeinu Bachya Bamidbar 11:16 is just a summary. It indeed explains the connection:

וע"ד המדרש שתים עשרה עינות מים ושבעים תמרים, רבי אליעזר המודעי אומר מיום שברא הקב"ה את עולמו ברא שם י"ב מבועין כנגד י"ב שבטי ישראל ושבעים דקלים כנגד שבעים זקנים. באור המדרש הזה כי מעת שנסעו ישראל מים סוף לא באו למקום טוב עד שהגיעו כאן באלים וכשם שנעשה להם נס על הים במתיקות מימיו ובשנים עשר גזרים לי"ב שבטים כן היה בכאן באלים היו מימיו מתוקים מים חיים נוזלים וי"ב מבועין לי"ב שבטים וכן שבעים דקלים לשבעים זקנים כדי לחלוק כבוד לכל שבט ושבט וכן לכל אחד ואחד מהזקנים.

A Midrashic approach (Mechilta Yayissa section 1) on the words “12 springs of water and seventy date-palms.” Rabbi Eliezer Hamodai said that from the day G’d had created the universe He had created 12 springs of water corresponding to the 12 tribes of Israel. He had also planted 70 date-palms corresponding to the seventy elders of the Jewish people. The meaning of this Midrash is that after the crossing of the Sea of Reeds the Israelites had not encountered such a good camping place as this one at Eylim. Just as they had experienced a miracle at the sea when G’d sweetened the salt-water of the sea so that they could drink from it while crossing, and He provided 12 lanes for the different tribes to cross in, so this type of miracle was re-enacted at Eylim. Its waters were sweet and flowing; there were 12 separate springs so that each tribe could have its own water supply. The seventy date-palms corresponded to the seventy elders each of whom was accorded honour in his own right.

וע"ד הקבלה ויבאו אילמה ושם י"ב עינות מים ושבעים תמרים בבאם עתה במקום הזה באלים נכנסו באותה השגה הנקראת אלהים וזהו לשון ויבאו אילמה ושם שתים עשרה עינות מים כי השיגו שם י"ב מלאכים שלשה לכל רוח מד' רוחות העולם וכל שלשה מהם עם צבאותיהם מחנה גדול והם הנקראים ד' מחנות שכינה, ושבעים תמרים הם ע' מלאכים הסובבים כסא הכבוד וממונים על ע' אומות שבעולם כל אחד ואחד ממונה על אומתו, וכן תמצא בספר הבהיר ומאי ושם י"ב עינות מים הקב"ה נתנם להם בתחלה עינות מים אח"כ החזירם להם אבנים, דכתיב (יהושע צ ט) ושתים עשרה אבנים, מה טעם מפני שבתחלה היתה התורה בעולם נמשלת למים ואח"כ נקבעה במקום קבוע מה שאין המים עושים כן שהיום כאן ומחר כאן. ומה שבעים תמרים מלמד ששבעים קומות יש להקב"ה ושואבים מי"ב פשוטות, מה המים הללו פשוטים אף הם פשוטים, ומנא לן דתמר הוי קומה דכתיב (שיר ז) זאת קומתך דמתה לתמר ולא עוד אלא בתמרים יש שבעים מינים דכתיב ושבעים תמרים ולא היו דומים זה לזה ופעולות זה אינו דומה לזה וטעם זה אינו דומה לזה ע"כ, ולפי שכל אחד ואחד פועל מנויו כמו שנתמנה עליו ואיננו רשאי ליכנס לגבול חברו ולכך אמר אינם דומין זה לזה ולא פעולתו של זה דומה לפעולתו של זה, ונרמז לך בזה כי מי"ב עינות אלה שהם ד' מחנות שכינה שואבים בה שבעים תמרים הם המלאכים הסובבים כסא הכבוד המשילום בתמרים על שם הקומה, והנה דוגמתם יצאו מיעקב י"ב שבטים הנחלקים לד' מחנות ומהם היו שבעים נפש, והבן זה המעט ותמצא מעלת יעקב שנקרא אל, כענין שכתוב (בראשית לג) ויקרא לו אל אלהי ישראל, ודרשו רז"ל מי קראו אל אלהי ישראל, ותדע ותשתכל כל עניני האבות ומצות התורה הכל ציורים ודוגמא למצוא ולדעת דעת קדושים.

A kabbalistic approach: the words “they came to Eylim where there were twelve springs of water and seventy date-palms“ mean that when the Israelites now arrived at this site they attained a certain spiritual level called “elohim” (play on the word אלימה with the letters re-arranged). The 12 fountains are a simile for 12 angels, three from each of the four directions. Each group of three angels was accompanied by an army of minor angels so that between them all they represented the מחנה שכינה, the camp of the Divine presence supported at four corners with its celestial entourage.

The seventy date-palms represent the seventy angels who surround the throne of G’d’s glory and who are assigned, one each, as the celestial representatives of the 70 nations of the world. You find this confirmed in the Sefer Habahir items 165-7. The author there asks: “what was the significance of the twelve fountains? First G’d gave the Israelites 12 fountains. These were exchanged later when the Jewish people crossed the Jordan into the twelve stones Joshua erected there (Joshua 4,9). The reason is that originally the Torah was likened to life-giving water seeing the Torah, i.e. its bearers were on the move, just like the waters issuing from fountains are on the move, their waters constantly flowing. Once the Israelites crossed the Jordan and began to conquer the Holy Land Torah found a permanent home, was stationary.

As far as the 70 date-palms are concerned, this is a symbol for seventy different קומות, conduits, by means of which G’d dispenses His largess. These draw their input from twelve of the “simple” letters in the alpha-bet. Just as these waters are ordinary waters (of terrestrial origin), so the seventy nations are essentially terrestrial in nature. Whence do we know that a date-palm may be equated with a קומה? We base this on Song of Songs 7,8 זאת קומתך דמתה לתמר, “such is your stature, likened to a towering palm tree.” Not only that but there are 70 different species of palm trees; this is meant by our verse speaking about seventy palm trees. The words ושבעים תמרים mean that each one was different from the other and the fruit they produced were different from one another, each tasting differently. So far Sefer Habahir. [Levush Orah by R' Mordechai Jaffe, in his super-commentary on Rashi, and Menachem Rekanati explain many of these concepts in greater depth. Ed.] It is important to remember that each date-palm had been assigned its task in nature and each had to contribute according to its specific task. It was not in order for them to be grafted one to another to produce new mutations. The entire phenomenon is reminiscent of Yaakov and his twelve sons and the seventy descendants who arrived in Egypt. They were likened to towering palm trees due to their spiritual stature. At the same time they drew their inspiration from Yaakov’s twelve sons who in turn drew theirs from their patriarch-father. The 12 tribes were divided into four camps of three tribes each, encamped in the four directions of the globe enclosing (protecting) the encampment of the Shechinah. This made them carriers of the Divine Presence, Shechinah. This is all reflected in the fact that the patriarch Yaakov himself was called א-ל אלו-הי ישראל, (Genesis 33,20) which line is explained in Megillah 18 as “who called him א-ל? None other than the אלו-הי ישראל, the G’d of Israel.” All of the foregoing only serves the purpose of giving us an inkling of the spiritual stature of our patriarchs.

Thus the source of all this is Sefer haBahir 167. Rabbeinu Bachya's translation covers well paragraphs 165-6 but the statement in 167 is like this:

ואמרת שבעים תמרים שבעים קומות, והא אמרת שבעים ושתים, אלא שבעים ואחת הם וישראל שבעים ושתים אך אינם בכלל, והא אמרת שבעים, אלא האחד שר השטן:

(Translation by R' Aryeh Kaplan) You said that seventy date palms represent the seventy Structures. But have you not said that there are 72? There are 71. Israel makes 72, but it is not included. But did you not say there were seventy? One is the Officer of Satan.

Afterwards there is a mashal about Satan, which is not related to the question.

Thus the connection is learned from the lofty status that Israel achieved by travelling to Eylim. This lofty status modeled the Throne of Glory of HKBH, where the 70 ministering angels represent the 70 nations of the world. The 70 palms, which hinted to those angels, in the camp of Israel made correspondence to the 70 elders of Jewish people, who in turn were representative of the 70 souls that descended to Egypt.

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Yes, This is a general paradigm that G-d established at the beginning of Creation.

In the creation of the Hebrew Aleph-Beit, the 22 letters, there are 3 general categories, 3 Amot (אמות which are אמ׳ש, which establish right ימין, left שמאל and center אמצע, as well as beginning ראש, end סוף and between תוך), 7 Kefulot (כפולות meaning doubling letters), and 12 Peshutot (פשוטות which are הוזחטילמנסע׳ק) which correspond to the major constellations and the dimension of time, like the 12 hours of day and 12 hours of night.

This follows the tradition which the patriarch Avraham received from Adam HaRishon (who received it from the Angel, Raziel) and his descendants and is recorded in Sefer Yetzirah.

The seven doubling letters (בג׳ד-כפר׳ת) establish the doubling relationship on what is described as the side of Holiness and its opposite.

The 70 souls of Israel are the side of Holiness and are the parallel to the 70 nations (who are actually manifestations of the 70 Ministering Angels who are their spiritual source.)

If you would like two excellent early sources that discuss this about the letters and the paradigm, see Sefer Ma'arechet HaElokut and Sefer Ginat Egoz, section 2, by Rabbi Yosef Gikatilla, who was a student of Rabbi Avraham Abulafia.

title: Watching people kiss in movies
content:
# Watching people kiss in movies ## Frage

I understand that, according to Jewish law, it is prohibited to watch scenes in movies that depict immoral relations. I want to clarify whether this restriction extends to scenes showing two individuals kissing on the mouth. Is such content also considered prohibited to watch?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I'm not a posek. Please ask your LOR

The Rema in Even Haezer 21:5 says:

י"א דאין לנהוג אפילו עם אשתו בדברים של חבה כגון ילעיין ברישיה אם יש לו כנים בפני אחרים (נ"י פרק חזקת הבתים):

"Some say that one should not do affectionate things even with his wife, such as to inspect her head for lice, in front of others."

The Be'er Heteiv Seif Katan 10 (also see Beit Shmuel Seif Katan 12) says

אפילו יושב ואין מונח בחיקה אסור כ"מ מתשובת הרשב"א סי' אלף קפ"ח וכתב ט"ז ונראה דיש חילוק בזה. דעיון לחוד אין נכון בפני אחרים באשתו משום הרואה יבא לידי הרהור דנזכר קירוב שלהם ע"י תשמיש. אבל בבתו ואחותו ונכדו שאין כאן זכרון תשמיש מותרת בפני אחרים. אבל שכיבה בחיקה פשיט' דאסור אפי' שלא בפני אחרים. ובשאר עריות אפי' בפנוי' אסור אפי' עיון בראשו לחוד עכ"ל:"

“Even if he is sitting and she is not placed in his lap, it is forbidden in all cases, as is learned from the Responsa of the Roshba, siman 1188. And the Taz wrote: It seems that there is a distinction here. Looking (or gazing) alone is not proper when other people are present with his wife, because those who see them may come to improper thoughts, since they will recall the closeness between them through marital relations. But with his daughter, his sister, and his granddaughter—since there is no recollection of marital relations—it is permitted in front of others. But lying in her lap is obviously forbidden even when others are not present. And with other forbidden relatives (arayot), even if she is unmarried, it is forbidden even to look at her head alone.”

From the Be'er Heteiv and Beit Shmuel, we can infer that one is not allowed to watch two individuals kissing because that may lead to improper thoughts.

title: How would a person become a rabbi around 1 CE?
content:
# How would a person become a rabbi around 1 CE? ## Frage

Given the general illiteracy, the lack of public libraries, the high cost of Torah copies and writing materials, how would a person become a rabbi in 1 CE?

Given the costs and reading/writing requisites it looks like it's a path only for sons of well-off families, living in a major city.

I have read Israel Finkelstein and Bart Ehrman books, which deal mostly with literacy but doesn't explore education.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

In the year one common era even if books would have been easily available it would have made little difference in relation to becoming a Rabbi and Jewish Education. At that point in time, on principle, almost nothing had been written down anyway.

This was seventy years before the Beis Hamikdash was destroyed, and about two hundred years before the Mishna was written down. It was forbidden to write a public record of the Oral Law. Being that almost everything was being learned by memory anyhow the lack of or easy availability of books would have had little bearing on studying to become a rabbi

title: Why Was Suffering Necessary?
content:
# Why Was Suffering Necessary? ## Frage

G-D wished to bestow good, and so created our perception of reality. This can be found in many sources such as here, here, here, here, Eitz Chaim Chapter 1 -- among others.

G-D could have created what we perceive in any way He wished. Therefore all that we perceive was a requirement/intention of our created reality. While what we perceive can take many forms, one form is one of suffering. We perceive that another experiences something that we cannot quite describe other than "pain" or something of the sort. Some may argue the morality of this. It can be argued, for example, that suffering is required to elevate oneself in some way to a higher being. Others may enjoy it on some level. However, if given the option, not influenced by all the suffering experienced until this point, that it would be better (for them or someone else) that suffering should not have been created and is not "good".

The original cause of this suffering is not revealed to most of us. However it is noted that others (e.g. Navi/Prophet) have been revealed the reason behind the need for suffering in some situations. Regardless of the reason behind our perception of - or our perception of someone else's - suffering, this was an intentional creation by a Creator who wishes to bestow Good.

Now, if all creations would agree suffering should have not been created, and it was created nonetheless, there is of course a purpose for this. Indeed, the closest documented person to G-D - Moshe Rabbeinu - could not perceive why this is so.

However, I am wondering if there is anyone with some insight on my question:

Why was Suffering required as a potential by-product for a limitless Creator to bestow Good?

Note: @Rabbi Kaii did a good job explaining why suffering is necessary, but from the viewpoint of what we perceive. In other words, we perceive suffering and everything else, and have deduced a purpose for the suffering we perceive. But the question is about it's need/purpose from the viewpoint of it's Creator -- which I realize could very well be unanswerable. A limitless "Good" G-D, in my small view, had no absolute need to require Man to suffer to receive His Goodness. Again, just looking for insights on this hard problem of mine.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

There are actually many attempts to answer this in tradition. I was learning something related to it last night, which is part of a larger body of thought on this question, so I am happy to attempt an answer bringing it all together, although it's clear that this is one of the deepest and most difficult questions in all of Torah thought; I don't expect to satisfy everyone, but for what it's worth:

Bread of Shame1

There is a concept of נהמא דכסופא, which is that if Hashem were to give us good without us earning it, it would not be a perfect good. This is a fundamental issue. I've heard two reasons about why it is fundamental.

The first is from Ramchal2, which is that the perfect good is Hashem Himself, and therefore in order to receive that good, we must be similar to Him (more on this in the next point), and just as His goodness belongs to Him, ours must belong to us (and for a finite being, that is achieved through effort - the root of suffering).

The second goes into the idea that unearned goodness is arbitrary, and arbitrariness is not what Hashem wants. Indeed, arbitrariness is not Godly at all, it is associated with tohu, Amalek, and a cold cruel world where nothing matters. See this answer which tries to give a fuller explanation. For Chesed (kindness) to be full-blown love, it must be personal, meaningful. Let that sink in.

Giving vs. Receiving

The Baal Hasulam3 exquisitely explains this idea of Hashem's desire to give. In order for there to be someone who can receive His goodness, they have to be fundamentally different to Him in one respect: they have to have a desire to receive. Therefore, He had to create that from nothing (yesh me'ayin). This creates a catch 22 - the desire to receive makes us so fundamentally different to Him, that it gets in the way of our receiving of His goodness (which, as we said, is Him, Himself). Therefore, He gives us an opportunity to transform this desire to receive into a desire to give (specifically, a desire to recieve in order to give), through effort, so that it is ours.

It's our fault

So far, we've discussed why there is suffering, but we haven't quite covered where evil comes from. The Rebbe Rashab4 explains what da'at really is. It has two elements that are relevant; one is that it is the source of (physical) sensation, and two it is the source of depth of intellect. He then explains love as follows: there is a hidden love (chasadim mechasim), and a revealed love (chasadim megulim).

Adam didn't want hidden love, he wanted to feel it and thus ate the fruit that gives him da'at, and that was the problem. Once love becomes a sensation that one feels, that's where it's possible to love the wrong thing, and that's the root of all evil, and therefore the big job of mankind begins in refining the human spirit to ensure that only love of Hashem can exist in our hearts. This is a very difficult process of birur, clarification, because of the other issue with da'at; its intellectual depth. Intellectual depth is what enables mixture of good and evil, because someone with that depth of intellect can mix and marry opposites, and paradoxes. Deep stuff!

The Yetzer Hara is necessary

The Zohar5 literally says that Hashem needs the Yetzer Hara. As the Tzaddikim point out for us, this is because without the Yetzer Hara, the Neshama (Nefesh Elokit) would not want to be on earth, where it is possible to sin. The Yetzer Hara is like a trap for the Neshama, because it forces the Neshama to enjoy the world, and indeed we receive the Yetzer Hara as children and who is more excited about life than them? However, this of course leads to the possibility of evil, which must be fixed. Our fixing of our Yetzer Hara is indeed the effort, and thus the earning, mentioned previously. See this answer for a bit more on this point, and sources there.

Hashem has a Ta'avah

This is the final point that ties everything together. We are taught that Hashem Himself has a desire, and that desire is to have a dwelling in the very lowest world; this world of physicality6. Hence, we are not (just) doing it for ourselves7, we are quite literally doing Him a service in all this. Therefore, this is quite literally, as fundamental as it gets: this is the fulfilment of Hashem's Essential Will8. Through much Torah study, especially Chassidus, one comes to appreciate this point, and see how it fits into the grand picture. I.e. we come to see what Hashem sees (l'havdil; in our own way) in this project, and realise it is a fantastic, perfect project, and all questions fall away. This takes a life time of study!

Therefore, please feel free to ask for clarification of any of the above points, especially after you have learned the sources provided. It's clear that even this relatively "long" answer is inadequate to fully explain these points, so should be treated merely has "subject headers" for the thoughtful to contemplate and further research.

Final Thoughts

There are many reasons why Hashem made the world the way that He did, and they are all rather fundamental (and they are all deeply connected). Nonetheless, we must ultimately take on faith that Hashem knows what He is doing. As the Radzyner Rebbe writes9, indeed Hashem is truly unlimited, and even though these ideas, in our paradigm, are fundamental, we shouldn't fool ourselves into thinking that Hashem is limited by them. He creates the paradigm from nothing. So, we have to take it on faith that Hashem's purposes are perfect, even if they create very difficult questions, like the one you have asked. Hashem knows what He is doing, and it's our job to serve Him exactly as He told us, and we know that the reward will be the best possible - eternal d'vekut with Him, Himself, for all eternity10. The best possible good!

1. Many sources, originating in Talmud Yerushalmi Orlah 1:3; see Zohar I 4a, R. Yosef Karo's Maggid Mesharim 2:8 etc.
2. Derech Hashem 1:3
3. Introduction to the Zohar
4. פדה בשלום נפשי י״ט כסלו, ספר המאמרים עזר"ת
5. I 23a, Bereshit 16
6. See Tanya, Sefer Shel Benonim
7. אור החמה על ספר הזהר
8. בשעה שהקדימו, יום ב' דחג השבועות, ה'תשי"ב
9. שער האמונה ויסוד החסידות
10. Derech Hashem 2:2

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

It's possible to argue that there is a silver lining to all suffering, even when it's not immediately obvious, and many commentators have done that. But it must be emphasized that, unlike other religions, Judaism does not welcome suffering per se, does not view it as positive, regardless of what comes after it. The Talmud records three variations of this conversation:

Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba fell ill. [Rabbi Yoḥanan went] to visit him, and said to him: “Is your suffering dear to you?” Rabbi Ḥiyya said to him: “I welcome neither this suffering nor its reward.” [Berakhot 5b]

In other words: I don’t want the suffering even if there is a reward that will come after it. The story continues:

Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him: “Give me your hand.” Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba [did so and Rabbi Yoḥanan] restored him to health.

So, before applying faith healing, Rabbi Yoḥanan had to make sure the patient wanted to recover! If not, faith healing will not work. He did not assume the desire for recovery was automatic.

title: Somekhos's opinion "money which is in dispute - is to be split" vs Beit Shammai
content:
# Somekhos's opinion "money which is in dispute - is to be split" vs Beit Shammai ## Frage

We know that Somekhos holds that (Baba Kamma 5:1 - Gmara ad loc):

ממון המוטל בספק חולקין

Property of uncertain ownership is divided by the two parties

However, in Baba Batra 9:8:

נָפַל הַבַּיִת עָלָיו וְעַל אָבִיו אוֹ עָלָיו וְעַל מוֹרִישָׁיו, וְהָיְתָה עָלָיו כְּתֻבַּת אִשָּׁה וּבַעַל חוֹב, יוֹרְשֵׁי הָאָב אוֹמְרִים, הַבֵּן מֵת רִאשׁוֹן וְאַחַר כָּךְ מֵת הָאָב, בַּעֲלֵי הַחוֹב אוֹמְרִים, הָאָב מֵת רִאשׁוֹן וְאַחַר כָּךְ מֵת הַבֵּן, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים, יַחֲלֹקוּ. וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים, נְכָסִים בְּחֶזְקָתָן:

A house collapsed on a son and upon his father, or upon a certain person and upon those from whom he stands to inherit, and it is unknown who died first. If the son bore the responsibility to pay the marriage contract of his wife and to pay a creditor, and the son had no money with which to pay them except that which he might inherit from his father, and the father’s heirs say: The son died first and afterward the father died, and therefore the son did not inherit property from his father, and the creditors say: The father died first and afterward the son died, resulting in the son’s inheriting his father’s property, enabling the creditors to collect payment from the property even after the son’s death, there is a dispute with regard to how to rule. Since it cannot be determined who died first, Beit Shammai say: They divide the property between them so that the father’s heirs receive half of his property and the son’s creditors receive the other half. And Beit Hillel say: The property retains its previous ownership status. Since the last known owner of the property was the father, the property is given to the father’s heirs.

It seems that it is the opinion of Beit Shammai.

Usually, the Gmara does not tolerate that a Tana (and I would say especially a "late" one) would hold and opinion of Beit Shammai, and will try to make him say "they did not discuss this point, but this one" "...לא נחלקו על ... על מה נחלקו".

But I did not find that for this case!

Does Somekhos, Rabbi Meir's student, really hold like Beit Shammai?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

See Tosfos Baba Basra 2a who explains that everyone agrees to the rule of ממון המוטל בספק חולקין when there is no one מוחזק. Both the standard argument between סומכוס and the חכמים, as well בית שמאי ans בית הלל, is when is someone considered מוחזק enough not to say the rule of ממון המוטל בספק חולקין. Hence, the case of בית שמאי is a different case, and סומכוס may acknowledge that the inheritors are מוחזק.

title: Punishment for false testimony favoring the accused
content:
# Punishment for false testimony favoring the accused ## Frage

One of the Ten Commandments is: "Don't give false testimony". This is generally understood as falsely testifying the accused is guilty, when he is innocent. One penalty is that the false witness, if caught, is given the same penalty the accused would have gotten had he been found guilty.

But what if the false witness says the accused is innocent, when he knows he is guilty? If the false witness is caught, what penalty is applied to him?

We read in Bava Kamma 55b:

It is taught that Rabbi Yehoshua said: [One] is exempt from liability according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven [if he] hires false witnesses to testify.

But here the witness is not hired. He spontaneously decided to help the accused. (You can think of many possible reasons.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

One of the Ten Commandments is: "Don't give false testimony".

That would be true whether someone is falsely testifying someone is guilty or innocent. The issue is false testimony.

The penalty is that the false witness, if caught, is given the same penalty the accused would have gotten had he been found guilty.

Not always. This is limited to the case of Eidim Zommim where two witnesses testify that original witnesses were not at the scene of the crime because they were with us elsewhere. Usually they are given the punishment they wanted the person who they falsely testifying to receive. In a case where that is not possible for technical reasons they would receive malkos (lashes). The situation mentioned in the OP is also one where the one giving false testimony is given lashes. The Rambam Hilchos Edus 20:9 כָּךְ קִבְּלוּ חֲכָמִים שֶׁשְּׁנַיִם שֶׁהִרְשִׁיעוּ אֶת הַצַּדִּיק וְהִצְדִּיקוּ אֶת הָרָשָׁע בְּעֵדוּתָן. וּבָאוּ עֵדִים אֲחֵרִים וֶהֱזִימוּם וְהִצְדִּיקוּ אֶת הַצַּדִּיק וְהִרְשִׁיעוּ אֶת הָרָשָׁע. הֲרֵי עֵדִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים לוֹקִים אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הִרְשִׁיעוּ הַצַּדִּיק לְהַלְקוֹתוֹ. our Sages received the following tradition: When two people cause an innocent person to be condemned or a guilty person to be vindicated through their testimony and two others come and disqualify their testimony through hazamah vindicating the innocent person and condemning the guilty, the first pair of witnesses receive lashes

It is taught that Rabbi Yehoshua said: [One] is exempt from liability according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven [if he] hires false witnesses to testify.

This is a slightly different concept. As Rashi on that Gemora explains, Geroma b'nizekin potur. (very roughly) meaning that as long as someone can claim in Beis Din that "I did not do that " even though he will be punished in the next world for his involvement, human courts (beis din) usually will not punish him for it. Reason being that you can always blame other people for causing things to happen, the people who took the money to testify falsely weren't being forced to do so, we don't want an American legal system where lawyers just go after whoever has the deeper pockets claiming they were the ones who caused it and the ones at fault etc.etc.etc. But that is just another case in the general concept of Geroma B'Nizokin. It isn't unique to witnesses.

title: Could Yitzchok not taste the difference between game and goat meat?
content:
# Could Yitzchok not taste the difference between game and goat meat? ## Frage

Do any meforshim discuss the fact that Yitzchok requested Esav to prepare him a dish of game meat, but Yaakov serves him goat meat? Why couldn't Yitzchok tell the difference between game and goat meat?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Rashi had the same question. See Bereshit 27:5, where he says "For the taste of a kid is similar to the taste of a deer."

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Another relevant point to the answer of יהושע ק, may come from mishna Bekhoros 4:7:

הֶחָשׁוּד עַל הַבְּכוֹרוֹת, אֵין לוֹקְחִין מִמֶּנּוּ בְּשַׂר צְבָאִים וְלֹא עוֹרוֹת שֶׁאֵינָן עֲבוּדִין.

In the case of one who is suspect with regard to firstborn animals of slaughtering them and selling their meat when it is prohibited to do so, one may neither purchase meat from him, including even deer meat, nor may one purchase from him hides that are not tanned.

R' Ovadia m'Bartenura comments:

בשר צבאים – for it (i.e., deer/gazelle meat, venison) is red and he switches it with the meat of a calf, and sometimes, when he sells the firstling of a pure calf and he said that it is the meat of a deer/gazelle, where we aren’t troubled by a firstling.

I.e. venison, the meat of a deer, is light red like veal, while the goat meat is dark like beef, even when prepared. Because Yitzchak was blind he could not see the difference, he had to go by the smell and taste.

Also in Kiddushin 70a, a man offended Rav Yehuda bar Yechezkel as Yehuda bar Sheviske’el, which some translate eater of deer meat. The deer meat is similar to veal in appearance. I.e. a kohein is supposed to eat first born calves, but he got easier available deer meat instead.

title: Procedure for repeating aliyot on shabbat
content:
# Procedure for repeating aliyot on shabbat ## Frage

I heard that if there are more than seven people who require an Aliyah on shabbat, one may add an additional Aliyah to the reading. What is the correct procedure for doing so? Should one repeat the same Aliyah? or split an Aliyah into multiple? If so how long must each Aliyah be?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Every reader must read at least three verses (OC 137:2)

No break may be within three verses of a written paragraph break, unless at a written paragraph break itself (138:1).

Some allow extra breaks beyond the minimum to be added on holidays other than Shabbat (282:1, 135:1). (Some refrain from adding on Yom Kippur even when it falls on Shabbat (Aruch HaShulchan 282:7).)

Some permit rereading verses that were already read (282:2).

Breaks should ideally be at positive thematic points (138:1).

No break may be made in Curses section of Leviticus (26:14-46), and customarily that prohibition is observed in the Curses section of Deuteronomy (28:15-69) as well (428:6).

The final 8 verses in the Torah (Deuteronomy 34:5-12) should not be split up (428:7).

The Haazinu song may only be split at the six traditional break points that were used in the Temple (428:5).

Some customarily do not split up the Song of the Sea or either record of the Decalogue (eg. Eliya Rabba 143:6).

Some customarily do not split up the list of 42 travel stations in Numbers 33 (Magen Avraham 428:5).

When a double parsha is read, some recommend all breaks be split evenly between the two while most recommend all extra breaks be added to the second parsha (Aruch HaShulchan 282:12).

title: What tribe was Shmuel from?
content:
# What tribe was Shmuel from? ## Frage

I’ve seen conflicting answers, one that he was from shevet Efraim and one that he was from shevet Levi.

Does anyone have a real source for which it was?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

There is a Midrash (Yalkut Shimoni 42:5) which discusses all the kings and judges that came from the various tribes.

In that piece it writes:

עלי ושמואל משבט לוי

Eli and Shmuel came from the tribe of Levi.

This standpoint is also taken by Shelah Hakadosh here:

והנה דוד מלך ארבעים שנה (ש"ב ה, ד), וכל זה מרומז בשם שמואל שהוא אותיות שאול מ', ושאול רומז על המלך, ומ' רומז על ארבעים שנה שמלך דוד. ושמואל היה משבט לוי אשר לו כתר כהונה. ושמואל שקול כמשה ואהרן (תו"כ שמיני ז), כי היה לוי נקרא על שבט לוי, אבל היה ג"כ צד כהונה כי היה הגלגול של אהרן הכהן, אשר על כן כתיב (שמות ד, יד) הלא אהרן אחיך הלוי, כי שמואל הלוי הוא אהרן הכהן, ורז זה גילה האר"י ז"ל והבאתי דבריו לעיל

David ruled for forty years. This figure is alluded to in the name Samuel which is comprised of the letters in the name Saul, שאול, with the letter 40=מ added. The first four letters allude to Royalty, the last to the 40 years David reigned. Samuel was from the tribe of Levi which wore the "crown" of Torah. Samuel himself was considered as equal to Moses and Aaron combined. Although he was known as a Levite, being a member of that tribe, he combined within himself elements of the priesthood, being traditionally considered the re-incarnation of the High Priest Aaron. When G–d told Moses in Exodus 4, 14: הלא אהרון אחיך הלוי וכו', "Is there not your brother Aaron the Levite?" He implied that there would be a Levite who at the same time was Moses' brother Aaron, i.e. Aaron's re-incarnate, the prophet Samuel. This secret has been revealed by the Arizal, and I have quoted his words on a previous occasion.

As far as the Efraim claim, this can be debunked. The Midrash in Vayikrah Rabbah 2:3 explains that Yaakov blessed Efraim that leaders would descend from him:

אָמַר רַבִּי פִּנְחָס עֲטָרָה זוֹ נִתְעַטֵּר אֶפְרַיִם מֵאָבִינוּ יַעֲקֹב בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁנִּפְטַר לְעוֹלָמוֹ אָמַר לוֹ אֶפְרַיִם רֹאשׁ הַשְּׁבָטִים רֹאשׁ הַיְשִׁיבָה יָפֶה וּמְעֻלֶּה שֶׁבְּבָנַי יְהֵא נִקְרָא עַל שְׁמֶךָ (שמואל א א, א):

Rabbi Pincḥas said: Efraim was granted this crown by Yaakov our patriarch when he passed to his eternal abode. He said to him: ‘Efraim, tribal leaders, yeshiva heads, and the finest and most outstanding of my descendants will be called by your name.’

The Yefei To'ar writes there:

ראש השבטים כו'. פי' כל מי שיהיה ראש וחשוב יקרא על שם אפרים. ומביא ראיה על ראש ישיבה משמואל דנקרא אפרתי אף כי היה משבט לוי.

Tribal leaders - This can be explained to mean that anyone who is a leader and important will be called by Efraim's name. And a proof can be brought about Rosh Yeshiva from Shmuel who was called "Efrati" even though he was from the tribe of Levi.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Shmuel was from shevet Levi. Rashi explains that this is explicit in Divrei Hayomim:

אלקנה. לוי היה, מבני אביאסף בן קרח, כן נתייחס בדברי הימים (א ה ח): Elkonoh. He was a Levite of the sons of Aviosof, the son of Korach —his ancestry is thus recorded in Divrei Hayomim.

https://www.sefaria.org/Rashi_on_I_Samuel.1.1.3

title: (How) did Rebbi Eliezer and Rebbi Yehoshua survive the destruction of Jerusalem?
content:
# (How) did Rebbi Eliezer and Rebbi Yehoshua survive the destruction of Jerusalem? ## Frage

In Gittin 56a we read the story of how Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai escaped the siege of Jerusalem. He was smuggled out in a coffin borne by his two students Rebbi Eliezer and Rebbi Yehoshua. When he reaches Vespasian he is granted a request to spare Yavneh and its sages from destruction as well as the family of Rabban Gamliel (the Nasi).

Since, from the story, it is clear that Rebbi Eliezer and Rebbi Yehoshua are not in Yavneh, and they could not escape the way Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai did. And, from the ensuing story it seems clear that everyone in Jerusalem was either killed or enslaved; I would like to know if we have any information on what became of Rebbi Eliezer and Rebbi Yehoshua.

Did they in fact survive and join Rabban Yohanan ben Zakkai in Yavneh? If so, how?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

I agree with @mbloch that it seems logical that Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua simply did not return to Yerushalayim after they assisted Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai's escape. I think the story's main focus is RYBZ and how he created the new Jewish center in Yavneh, and wasn't intended to discuss the particular details of how each of the other sages survived. There are, in fact, some alternate versions of their escape. One version mentions the other prominent students of RYBZ together with Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabbi Eliezer (Avot de-Rabbi Natan version B, 29). Another version mentions Rabbi Tarfon or Rabbi Akiva (only the first letter of the name was preserved; unclear if it's a ט or an ע) lamenting RYBZ as part of the funerary procession (Genizah fragment, shelfmark JTS: ENA 3843.15).

The exact details of how each survivor of the Churban escaped Yerushalayim remain a mystery. Of course we know much of RYBZ's story. There are hints that other sages and their families survived harrowing events. For example, in Mishna Ketubot 2:9, Rabbi Zechariah ben Haktzav recounted:

"I swear by this abode of the Divine Presence that my wife’s hand did not move from my hand from the time that the gentiles entered Jerusalem until they left, and I know for a fact that she was not defiled. The Sages said to him: A person cannot testify about himself. The legal status of one’s wife is like his own status in this regard. Therefore, your testimony is not accepted, and your wife is forbidden to you."

But in most cases, we don't know how exactly sages survived the Churban and escaped Yerushalayim.

What we do know is that not long after the Churban, several sages and even some of their family members popped up in various cities and towns mainly around Judea but also around the Galilee and elsewhere. In the case of Rabbi Yehoshua, he settled in Peki'in (פקיעין) (Sanhedrin 32b; Tosefta Sotah 7:6), and once visited his rabbi, RYBZ, in Bror Chayil (Tosefta Maaserot 2:2/Yerushalmi Demai 3:1).1 Rabbi Eliezer, on the other hand, went to live in Lod together with his wife Imma Shalom and his brother-in-law, Rabban Gamliel II (e.g., Sanhedrin 32b; Tosefta Maaser Sheni 5:16; Tosefta Pesachim 3:11). After RYBZ's term as Nasi ended, Rabban Gamliel moved to Yavneh (sources), and it seems that Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua spent at least some of their time there (e.g. Sanhedrin 17b). From the sources we have it's apparent that both students of RYBZ remained on good terms with their rabbi. As to why they did not live in Yavneh with him, one can only guess.2

1 RYBZ is said to have moved to Bror Chayil sometime after the destruction (Sanhedrin 32b). Most are of the opinion that he moved there after Yavneh. My personal view, is that Bror Chayil is another name for Yavneh and its vicinity.

2 My personal view (based on many sources which I will not get into here) is that RYBZ implemented a decentralized leadership model, which necessitated spreading the sages all over the Land of Israel. Rabban Gamliel, on the other hand, implemented a centralized leadership model, which demanded bringing most of the sages to Yavneh. I discussed this theory in a bit more detail here.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

I do not understand the question so well. Isn't it clear from the gemara that R Eliezer and R Yehoshua carried R Yohanan ben Zakkai out of Jerusalem?

Gittin 56a (elucidation from R Steinsaltz)

Have your students enter to bring you to burial, and let no one else come in so that the zealots not notice that you are still light. [...] Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai did this. Rabbi Eliezer entered from one side and Rabbi Yehoshua from the other side to take him out. When they arrived at the entrance of the city on the inside, the guards, who were of the faction of the zealots, wanted to pierce him with their swords in order to ascertain that he was actually dead, as was the common practice. [...] The guards then opened the gate and he was taken out.

Artscroll's history of the Talmud (p. 191) confirms this understanding.

title: What is the halachic definition of a mashehu?
content:
# What is the halachic definition of a mashehu? ## Frage

In Shabbos 8a, Rashi says that an upside down object thrown into reshus harabim will encounter lavud within 3 tefachim of the ground and that is the moment one is chayav hotzaah. Due to this, if one throws an object that is שבעה ומשהו one is chayav because the object descends into reshus harabim; but if one throws an object of שבעה ושני משהויין, he's patur because it never descends completely into reshus harabim but rather remains partially in the makom petur. The calculation for that is 2.9 (of equivalent mashehuin) tefachim of lavud, and 7.2 tefachim of object equals >10 tefachim, which means the object never completely descends into reshus harabim.

But without a specific definition of a mashehu, I can say that there is always a smaller amount of object that is sticking into makom petur. For example, if the object is within 2.91 literal tefachim of the ground, I can say that an object that is 7.1 literal tefachim is sticking 0.01 tefachim into the makom petur and also in contact with the ground because of lavud. I can also say that when an when an object is 7.01 tefachim, it is in contact with the ground and yet still in a makom petur when it reaches 2.991 tefachim of the ground.

So what is the concept of shnei mashehuin? Without a strict definition of a mashehu, it seems conceptually impossible that one would ever be chayav when an object is more 7 tefachim tall no matter the amount.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The rambam, in his peirush to kil'aim (6,6) says:

ועוד: כל שהוא בארו בגמרא שיעור זה הנוסף שהוא חלק מששים חלק באמה והוא עשירית הטפח

And an additional: "kol shehu". In the gemara they explained that this added amount is 1/60 of an Amma, which is 1/10 of a tefach.

I'm assuming that a "mashehu" and a "kol shehu" are the same thing. Unfortunately, I don't know which gemara the rambam is referencing.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

See the ריטב"א חדשים who explains Rashi with the words, "לחומרא דק, לכולא לא דק".

This means to say that Rashi, when differentiating between 1 משהו and 2 משהויים, is only coming to say that the gemara's measurement of שבע ומחצה is inexact. The distinction the gemara means to make between 7 and a משהו vs 7 ומחצה, is between something that is arguably still within 10 טפחים of the ground, and something that is clearly above 10 טפחים of the ground.

i.e. Rashi's reference to 2 משהויים is not 2 units of משהו, rather anything beyond the area that could still lead to doubt. This is likely to be significantly less than an absolute minimum value of 7.5 טפחים that the gemara gives.

title: (Why) are bereitot, especially those not found in the tosefta and midrash halacha considered canonical?
content:
# (Why) are bereitot, especially those not found in the tosefta and midrash halacha considered canonical? ## Frage

A bereita is a teaching from the time of the Tannaim or before which was not recorded as part of the Mishnah. There are breitot found in the Tosefta and midrash halacha as well as other collections of bereitot, which are no longer extant. Often the talmud will cite a bereita, even not from sources just mentioned, as posing a challenge or contradiction to a Mishnah.

I would like to understand why bereitot, especially those which were not collected in the Tosefta or midrash halacha, were considered canonical at all.

Just like there are works such as the book of the Maccabees which is considered outside the canon of the written Torah, I would expect certain material to be considered outside the canon of the oral torah, such that it would not matter if that material contradicted a Mishnah.

Since it seems this is not the case I would like to understand why, and on whose authority bereitot are considered part of the canon of the oral Torah.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Gemara says

אמר ליה ר' זירא לאו אמינא לכו כל מתניתא דלא תניא בי רבי חייא ובי רבי אושעיא משבשתא היא ולא תותבו מינה בי מדרשא

On this Rashi comments

רבי חייא ורבי אושעיא סדרו את הברייתות ודקדקו בדברי כל חכם לומר כמו שאמר אבל יש תנאים הרבה שמוסיפים על משנתם בדדמי כי הכא

Basically, only Rav Chiya and Rav Oishiya were considered exact enough in there codification of braiysot for it to be considered canon, everything is not is not exact enough to rely upon.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

There were several texts of Oral Law written prior to Mishnah. According to Iggeres Rav Sherira Gaon, (ch. 2) Rebbi mastered 13 approaches to the laws (see also Nedarim 41a).

When Rebbi had mastered 13 approaches to the laws, he taught r. Chiyya 7 of them. Rebbi took ill and forgot them. R. Chiyya restored the 7, but the other 6 were forgotten. There was a launderer who had heard when Rebbe used to recite them. R. Chiyya went and learned them from the launderer. [R. Chiyya] then went and repeated them before Rebbi. When Rebbi used to see the launderer, he would say to him: "You made me and r. Chiyya", According to some, he would say: "You made Chiyya, and Chiyya made me".

Sefer "Kerem Yehoshua" by R.Yehoshua Cohen, p.157-159, when discussing arguments between Rashi and Tosafos, writes the following about the sources of R. Yehudah haNassi's learning:

In the Babylonian Talmud we find that R. Yehudah haNassi had many teachers:

  1. His Father, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel (Bava Metzia 84b)
  2. R. Yehoshua ben Korcha (same place)
  3. R. Meir (Eruvin 13b in Rashi, contrary to Jerusalem Talmud, Beitza 5:2 (20b); and see Tosafos Menachos 104a, s.v. מוריינא; Rashbam to Bava Metzia 51b, s.v. רברבי; and Maharshal and Rashash there)
  4. R. Elazar ben Shamua (Eruvin 53a, and Menachos 18a)
  5. R. Shimon [b. Yohai] (Shabbos 147b, Rashi to Beitza 26a, s.v. א"ל; Tosafos to Makkos 9b, s.v. נשמט; et. al.)
  6. R. Yehudah [bar Ilai] (Shavuos 13a; and see Megilla 20a)
  7. R. Yose [b. Halafta] (see Tosafos to Shabbos 51a, s.v. אילו)

(Note 7 sources in light with Nedarim 41a!)

Thus, there were other legitimate sources of baraisos, other than Mishna and Tosefta, which differed in scope, logic, and style. The main point is that in Gemara the rabbis tried to cover all bases from all sides, which is why it was called gemara - from גמר - complete.

### Antwort 3 (Score: -1)

The Baritot aren't canonical for the purpose of halacha but they could be useful in determining the motivations behind previous rulings.

The Gemara rabbis will often bring an argument like this: Rabbi X ruled like this in a situation.

A response to that argument could be that Rabbi X held by a Barita that we don't follow today.

title: Earliest time to fulfill Krias Shema at night
content:
# Earliest time to fulfill Krias Shema at night ## Frage

What are some opinions brought down in Halacha for the minimum number of minutes after sunset that one can fulfill their obligation to say Shema at night?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Theoretically it's the same question as "how many minutes after sunset does shabbos end?" But many are stricter on the latter as it could involve violating a capital thou-shalt-not, vs. failing to perform a thou-shalt.

It would make a lot of sense for it to depend on one's latitude -- it gets darker faster when you're close to the equator. And to measure it in degrees depression, rather than minutes. But it was usually easier to just pick a simple number of minutes.

For New York City, the typical answers you will hear about ending shabbos are 42/45/50/60/72 minutes. Some shuls will attempt to delay maariv so they will get to Shema at 20 minutes after sunset, as that's at least some serious post-sunset time ... but as best I know, the minimum to not have to repeat later is 42 (for New York).
