title: Why do the tablets say "זכור את" and "כבד את" instead of "זכור" and "כבד"?
content:
# Why do the tablets say "זכור את" and "כבד את" instead of "זכור" and "כבד"? ## Frage

In the common representation of the Mosaic Tablets, why do they say "זכור את" and "כבד את" instead of "זכור" and "כבד"?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

One can answer that keeping Shabbos and honoring parents brings a person blessings, which is hinted by the word את. How so?

In the book "Wisdom of Hebrew Alphabet" by R. Munk, says in the prologue:

"In Devarim 11:26-28 we are asked to choose between blessing and curse:

רְאֵ֗ה אָנֹכִ֛י נֹתֵ֥ן לִפְנֵיכֶ֖ם הַיּ֑וֹם בְּרָכָ֖ה וּקְלָלָֽה׃ אֶֽת־הַבְּרָכָ֑ה אֲשֶׁ֣ר תִּשְׁמְע֗וּ אֶל־מִצְוֺת֙ יְהֹוָ֣ה אֱלֹֽהֵיכֶ֔ם אֲשֶׁ֧ר אָנֹכִ֛י מְצַוֶּ֥ה אֶתְכֶ֖ם הַיּֽוֹם׃ וְהַקְּלָלָ֗ה אִם־לֹ֤א תִשְׁמְעוּ֙ אֶל־מִצְוֺת֙ יְהֹוָ֣ה אֱלֹֽהֵיכֶ֔ם וְסַרְתֶּ֣ם מִן־הַדֶּ֔רֶךְ אֲשֶׁ֧ר אָנֹכִ֛י מְצַוֶּ֥ה אֶתְכֶ֖ם הַיּ֑וֹם לָלֶ֗כֶת אַחֲרֵ֛י אֱלֹהִ֥ים אֲחֵרִ֖ים אֲשֶׁ֥ר לֹֽא־יְדַעְתֶּֽם׃

See, this day I set before you blessing and curse: blessing, if you obey the commandments of your God יהוה that I enjoin upon you this day; and curse, if you do not obey the commandments of your G-d Hashem, but turn away from the path that I enjoin upon you this day and follow other gods, whom you have not experienced.

Regarding the blessing the emphatic article אֶת is used, while regarding curse אֶת is omitted, (but we have וְהַ). Midrash Vayikra Rabba 35:1 teaches that אֶת denotes the blessing:

Rabbi Abba son of Rabbi Ḥiyya said in the name of Rabbi Yonatan: I calculated blessings, I calculated curses; the blessings are from alef through tav, the curses are from vav through heh. Moreover, they are reversed. Rabbi Avin said: [God says:] ‘If you merit, I will transform the curses into blessings for you. When? When you observe My Torah.’ That is what is written: “If you follow My statutes.”

Regarding blessings for keeping Shabbos, there are many sources, such as Shemos Rabba 25:12. Regarding blessings for honoring parents, one is blessed with long life as in Shemos 20:12.

title: Are there any open-source Talmud?
content:
# Are there any open-source Talmud? ## Frage

I would like to partially mark the tzures hadaf of mesechta Makkos, print it out for others, and put it on-line. But I do not want to worry about copyright laws. Does anyone know where I can download a mesechta and print it out or put it on-line?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Talmud is no younger than the Medieval period. Anything written in the medieval period is no longer covered by copyright, in any jurisdiction (source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talmud) and can legally be copied freely.

The term open source can't really be applied to a book like the Talmud. Open source implies the existence of a source code, which you can modify. There is no source code for the Talmud and in any case you are not going to produce your own version of the Talmud. What you probably mean is a free version of the Talmud. Open source is a much stronger claim than "free" - it implies freedom to modify and adapt to your own purposes (under the condition that the modified version is also open source) which doesn't really make sense for the Talmud.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Hebrewbooks.org has old prints for download.

title: Do any Poskim still respond with full teshuvos/responsa?
content:
# Do any Poskim still respond with full teshuvos/responsa? ## Frage

It seems like until recently, it wasn't very hard to get a comprehensive teshuva to a shaila one had. Sefarim like Igros Moshe, Shevet Haleivi, Minchas Yitzchak, Tzitz Eliezer etc. are compilations of questions sent to the Posek, with comprehensive answers detailing the methodology and reasoning behind the psak.

I often have halachic questions that are more complex than a regular CYLOR shaila, which I would love to pose to a bona-fide posek and receive not just a psak, but a responsum to validate the psak.

Which contemporary Rabbanim accept shailas (by email or regular mail) and will reply, and how do I contact them?

(This question and this question are looking for Rabbis who will issue a ruling. I am looking for Rabbis - ideally of 'Posek' stature - who will write responsa.)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

Kollel Eretz Hemda in Jerusalem (a dati leumi kollel) answers questions from Rabbanim around the world and prints their answers (in Hebrew) in their book series called Shut Bemareh Habazak. Not to be confused with their English series, Living the Halachic Process, which are shorter answers to hundreds of questions sent to R Daniel Mann. Some of the tshuvot are translated in the Tzurba m'rabanan English series.

The Rabbanim answering these answers have smicha from the Israeli rabbanut and are training for a more advanced degree before becoming rashei kollelim around the world. They are supervised by the Rashei Kollel, R Moshe Ehrenreich and R Yosef Carmel (previous responsa were checked with R Zalman Nechemia Goldberg zl).

In this podcast, R Barry Gelman shares the story of how he wrote a question and received an answer, which he used to defend his synagogue in court regarding a complex reburial question.

The kollel can be contacted via info@eretzhemdah.org or their contact page.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

Rabbi David Golinkin responds to halacha questions with full, detailed responses.

Contact info and record of his responsa can be found here

https://schechter.edu/responsa-by-david-golinkin/

Not an individual posek, but the Beit Din of America often provides responsa-esque write ups of their halachic decisions (source) and can be reached here

The Mogein Avrohom in 580:5 says:

בכ"ח בכסלו - במגילת תענית כתב בשבעה בכסליו ובה"ג כתב בשמונה ובכל בו כתב בחמשה וכתב בשל"ה דאף המחמיר להתענות בכולן לא יתענה בחנוכה, עיין רא"ח ח"ב ס"ה:‏

title: Are self-described Reform and Conservative Jews assumed to be halachically Jewish according to Orthodox Judaism?
content:
# Are self-described Reform and Conservative Jews assumed to be halachically Jewish according to Orthodox Judaism? ## Frage

I’m curious about whether the Orthodox understanding of Halacha says we still have chazakah that the majority of Reform and Conservative are still real Jews (for example, if one is counting them in a minyan, having them cook in a kosher kitchen, getting married etc. if they say they’re Reform or Conservative do we trust them or have a beit din check their halachic status, or do different halachot apply for marriage vs minyan?).

Obviously the overwhelming majority of them are not observant of Halacha or even Shomer Shabbat according to Orthodox and often even Conservative standards, however, a Reform or Conservative Jew who was raised as such from birth has the din of tinok shenishba (lit. 'captive infant', i.e. held to be unaccountable for their lack of Jewish knowledge/practice).

There are several factors though why many people that identify as Reform and Conservative Jews might have the status of non-Jews according to Orthodox understanding of halacha, including intermarriage being widespread in both movements and sanctioned officially by the Reform movement, the Reform movement accepting patrilineal descent, the Reform and Conservative movements both perform conversions not recognized by Orthodox halacha (with very few exceptions) and the fact that it’s a self reinforcing cycle (for example, an invalid female convert leads to invalid children, invalid converts in general becoming Rabbis lead to more invalid conversions etc.).

So should it still be assumed that somebody who says that they're Reform or Conservative is a Jew according to Orthodox halacha, or not?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

From what I have seen, there don't appear to be any poskim who make sweeping statements regarding the halachic status of either of the two movements. Halacha l'maaseh, treatment of the issue is still on a case-by-case basis. Most rabbis who have dealt with topics related to the Reform and Conservative movements and their membership (usually treated as separate topics) usually do so with regards to what proper hashkafa Orthodox Jews should have towards these two topics (e.g., Rabbi Shmuel Ariel's responsa, Rabbi Shlomo Aviner and Rabbi Mordechai Tzion's responsa, Rabbi David Chai Hakohen's responsa, an article on the site RationalBelief, an article by Rabbi Eliezer Melamed, second article, third article).

With regards to halachic matters, the most common questions have to do with conversions - not, again, the movements as a whole - in light of their approach to the question of "Who is a Jew?". The most comprehensive and recent treatment of this is in Rabbi Eliezer Melamed's מסורת הגיור (can be found on Otzar Hachochmah), especially pp. 225-227, 231, 351-352, 364, 369-371, 455-456, 462, 536-537 756-758, 764-769, which includes summaries of the opinions of pretty much all poskim of recent centuries with regards to conversion, and in the cited pages, Reform and Conservative conversions. These conversions are of course invalid according to all poskim, but in many specific cases there are leniencies to reconvert individuals in a proper Orthodox conversion for various reasons. And see also another recent discussion by rabbis from Kollel Eretz Chemdah concerning the conversion testimony of Conservative rabbis, where it is concluded that such testimonies should be treated on a case-by-case basis.

Regarding marriage, either way when approaching an Orthodox rabbi for marriage nowadays, the couple must present proper documentation. If one or both side's parentage is called into question, it becomes a case-specific issue. There doesn't appear to be any sweeping ruling.

Regarding minyans, there are a few responsa on the matter. There is an extremely short responsa by Rabbi Yaakov Ariel regarding the inclusion of a Reform Jew in a minyan. However, here the underlying assumption is that the individual is 100% halachically Jewish. There's a responsa by Rabbi Benayahu Broner on the same topic, albeit based on a more specific question. There's another responsa of Rabbi Yaakov Ariel regarding the inclusion of a Conservative convert in a minyan. There's also a responsa from Rabbi Yehudah Amichai regarding joining a Reform minyan. His assumption is that most Reform Jews are still very much Jewish.

Other than Rabbi Amichai's above-mentioned assumption which formed the basis of his response, the only direct treatment of the OP's question that I have found is from an article by Rabbi Eliezer Melamed, where he said (emphasis mine):

"טוענים: כיוון שרפורמים מקבלים גויים בלא גיור כהלכה ומחתנים יהודים עם גויים, בפועל רובם כיום גויים, ואין מצווה לאהוב אותם כאחים יהודים.

תשובה: גם אם כך הדבר, חובה לאהוב את כל היהודים שבתנועה הרפורמית, וגם אם בעקבות רוח הזמן הוא נשוי לאינו יהודי, הוא עדיין אחינו ונקרא בנו של ה'. וגם את בני זוגם או ילדיהם שאינם יהודים מצווה לאהוב, שכן הם קשורים בקשר עמוק עם אחינו, ובמיוחד כשהם חשים הזדהות עם העם היהודי. וה' יעזור שנזכה להגדיל את אורה של התורה עד שכולם ירצו להצטרף כהלכה לחזון הגדול של תיקון העולם כהדרכת התורה על כל פרטי הלכותיה."

"It is claimed: Since Reform accept non-Jews without a proper halachic conversion and allow intermarriage between Jews and non-Jews, practically speaking most of them today are non-Jews and there is no mitvah to love them as Jews.

Answer: Even if it were the case, it is still incumbent upon us to love all of the Jews in the Reform Movement, and even if due to the zeitgeist they are married to non-Jews, they are still called our brethren and they are called children of Hashem. And there is a mitzvah to love also their non-Jewish spouses and children, for they have deep ties to our brethren, and especially when they identify with the Jewish people. And may Hashem help us so that we will merit to shine the light of the Torah so that all will wish to join us in a proper halachic fashion to bring about the great vision of fixing the world in accordance with the Torah and all of its halachic specifics."

It is evident that Rabbi Melamed, who has studied the Reform movement quite a bit, is doubtful with regards to whether the Reform movement as a whole, or even a majority, can be regarded as non-Jewish. Of course, this seems to be a hashkafic approach. The halachic approach appears to still be on a case-by-case basis.

### Antwort 2 (Score: -4)

I'm not sure there is one correct answer here, mostly because "Orthodox halakha" doesn't mean what it used to. It used to mean, in accordance with the rulings of the Gemara, or the Geonim, or the Mishneh Torah, or the Shulchan Arukh. Nowadays, most Orthodox Batei Din will not accept a conversion done according to the Mishneh Torah/Shulchan Arukh. Why? According to 21st Century Orthodoxy, these sources make conversion too easy.

Here's all that needs to happen for a conversion according to the Shulchan Arukh

Shulchan Arukh Yoreh De'ah 268

When a person comes to convert, say to him, "What did you see that motivated you to come to convert? If you know that Israel, in this time, that the Jewish people are oppressed, eroded, (The words are from "Why is your strong one overthrown?" -Jer. 46:15) insane, and suffering. If he says, I know this and I will still become a part of your people, receive him immediately and tell him the principles of the faith, that God is one and idol worship is forbidden, and tell him a lot about this, and teach him a few of the lighter mitzvot and a few of the more stringent mitzvot, and teach him about some of the punishments of the mitzvot, as it says, "Before you came to learn this, if you ate the forbidden fat, you would not be punished with excommunication, you transgressed Shabbat and you were not punished with stoning; but now, if you eat forbidden food, you will be punished with excommunication; and if you transgress Shabbat you will be punished with stoning." Don't say too much about this, and don't get too specific either. And when you teach him about the punishment of the mitzvot, also teach him about the rewards of the mitzvot and teach him that in the doing of certain mitzvot that will merit life in the world to come. There isn't a complete righteous person, rather a master of wisdom, that does the mitzvot and understands them. And say to him: "You should know that the world to come is hidden from the righteous, who are Israel. As for what you see that Israel is in distress in this world, because it is not granted them to receive the abundance of good things in this world like other peoples, lest their hearts should be indulged loftily and they should go astray and squander the reward of the world to come. But God didn't bring to them too much destruction, so that they would not observe. Rather, all of the idolators stand. And you explicate this idea so that he feels the dearness of it. If he receives this, circumcise him immediately and wait until he is fully healed, and afterwards, immerse him without a barrier. (Some say that you cut or shave his hair and you cut his fingernails and his toenails before immersion.) And three learned scholars stand at his back and teach him some of the light mitzvot and some of the more stringent mitzvot a second time, and he stands in the water. And if it is a woman, women sit her in the water up to her neck and the beit din is outside and they teach her some of the easy mitzvot and some of the more stringent mitzvot and she sits in the water and afterwards, she immerses before them and they turn their faces and leave in order that they do not see her when she is getting out of the water, and they bless the immersion after she comes out of the water. And once he has immersed, it is as if he is a Jew, but if he goes astray, he is like an apostate Jew - he is still sanctified, and his marriage is sanctified.

Source: https://www.sefaria.org/Shulchan_Arukh%2C_Yoreh_De'ah.268.2?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en

This is an article discussing what a normative Orthodox conversion looks like now, and if you compare it to the Shulchan Arukh it's not hard to tell how different it's become.

At a time when thousands of people are considering conversion to Judaism, however, Israel’s Orthodox rabbinic establishment is raising ever-higher barriers to them. While Israel’s chief rabbinate accepts many candidates who are willing to become fully committed Orthodox Jews, it will not readily accept those who are not ready for total commitment. Thus, a would-be convert must usually spend years studying Torah and halacha, or Jewish law, and adopt an entirely Orthodox lifestyle in order to be considered for conversion.

Now, Israel’s increasingly ultra-Orthodox-dominated chief rabbinate is attempting to impose its views on the Jewish Diaspora. Here in the United States, it has already forced the Rabbinical Council of America — the Diaspora’s largest Orthodox rabbinical association — into line.

In the spring of 2006, Rabbi Shlomo Amar, Israel’s chief Sephardic rabbi, proclaimed that the chief rabbinate would no longer accept conversions performed by Orthodox rabbis in the Diaspora, except for those specifically approved by the chief rabbinate. The RCA had to decide how to respond to this affront to the integrity of its members. After all, the chief rabbi was basically saying that RCA members can’t be trusted to do proper halachic conversions.

Sadly, the RCA leadership capitulated to the demands of Rabbi Amar. The RCA agreed to establish regional rabbinic courts to handle conversions in line with the dictates of the chief rabbi. This means that individual RCA rabbis may no longer perform conversions and expect them to be sanctioned by the RCA — or by the chief rabbinate. Power is being concentrated in fewer and fewer hands, and only into the hands of those who agree to adopt stringent and restrictive positions. The result is that many non-Jews who considered halachic conversion will turn to non-halachic means of conversion, or will give up on conversion altogether.

This is a tragedy — and an unnecessary one at that, since there is no halachic reason why the chief rabbinate’s view should carry the day. The Talmud and classic codes of Jewish law actually grant considerable leeway in the halachic acceptance of converts. While converts must “accept the mitzvot,” or commandments, there is wide latitude in understanding what this phrase means. The Talmud itself says that we must instruct the candidate for conversion in “some of the major and some of the minor commandments.” There is no requirement or expectation that the candidate must learn all the mitzvot in advance of conversion, nor that he or she will promise to keep all the mitzvot in every detail after conversion.

Yet many contemporary rabbinic authorities have taken a far narrower and more exclusionary view. Zvi Zohar and Avi Sagi (in their book “Giyyur ve-Zehut Yehudit”) found that the narrow view gained traction only as recently as 1876 when Rabbi Yitzchak Shmelkes ruled that conversion was to be equated with an absolute commitment to observe all mitzvot. Any candidate for conversion who was not committed to becoming fully Orthodox in observance was to be rejected. Later rabbis adopted this new position, until it became normative among right-wing (and much of the rest of) Orthodoxy.

Source: https://sephardimhope.com/slamming-the-door-on-converts/

According to the Shulchan Arukh, someone can convert in days or weeks. Acceptance of the commandments is a verbal, and not to be burdensome. It's worth noting that every conservative conversion I've seen is stricter than the Shulchan Arukh and takes months, like this Intro to Judaism course which is 4.5 months long.

According to common Orthodox practice now, acceptance of the commandments has to be proven by living an observant lifestyle for years. This article goes into this topic more in depth:

https://www.jewishideas.org/article/acceptance-commandments-conversion

I've had comments object to my answer and claim that there is still an issue because the judges in a conservative court may not be qualified Dayanim. As far as I'm aware, no conversion requires even a single Dayan. Any Hedyoto, any common Israelite, can sit on a Beit Din for conversion.

Ben Zion Uziel, the late Chief Sephardic Rabbi, in his very last book of Responsa Mishpote Uziel, Even Hoezer 13, p. 54, Jerusalem, 1964 says: “It is the Halacha, as we learn from the words of the Rambam, that the reception of proselytes does not require a Bes Din of skilled men, but even with three ordinary men (hedyotos) it is quite sufficient.”

Source: https://www.ccarnet.org/responsa-topics/conversion/page/2/

Based on all the sources I've read, the obvious potential halakhic issue I see with a conservative conversion is having a female Rabbi on the Beit Din. But you can request all 3 members of your Beit Din be male in order to avoid this halakhic issue. There are other less obvious issues to consider, such as things would invalidate even a ordinary Israelite being a witness, such as heretical beliefs or being a known and open sinner. But these issues can arise with any converting Rabbi, such as Chassidic sects believing their dead Rabbis is the Messiah/God, or the Orthodox Rabbi who filmed his converts naked while immersing. I personally question whether a Judge who sins in the moment of conversion is a proper dayan, but I'm no Rabbi and the RCA upheld his conversions.

So as per your question as to whether you can rely on conservative converts being halakhically Jewish. If you believe that the halakha is what's written in the Shulchan Arukh/Mishneh Torah then I think it's safe to consider Conservative Jews as Jewish. If you want to be extra careful about the sex of the judges of the Beit Din you can ask who sat on their Beit Din.

If you believe the halakha is determined by whatever Orthodox communities are doing now, then you should question all conservative converts and even Orthodox converts. I've even heard of some orthodox conversions being revoked.

The rest of my answer is anecdotal. I witnessed someone who received a Conservative and later a private Orthodox Beit Din conversion. I can say with absolute honesty that the Conservative conversion followed the dictates of the Shulchan Arukh and Mishneh Torah except that they allow women Rabbis to serve on the Beit Din, but you can request an all male Beit Din if you want to be in accordance with the Shulchan Arukh.

The private Orthodox Beit Din was done in accordance with the custom of Egypt where my family came from. And the custom was if a Jewish man marries a non Jewish woman, the Beit Din/Community would initially oppose the union. If they got married anyways, but stayed in the community and grew in observance then the community would grow more accepting. And if the woman became pregnant and wanted to raise the child Jewishly then they would do a conversion for her using the Shulchan Arukh but taking the lenient views on it to make her conversion easier for the sake of the child who would then be raised Jewishly. So in the conversion i saw they interviewed her for several hours regarding the mitzvot, how she planned to observe, how committed she was to raising the child Jewishly, and then they immersed her.

I feel that both conversions followed the Mishneh Torah and Shulchan Arukh without question, but neither conversion will be recognized by the RCA or Israel's chief Rabbinate.

Note: I have not witnessed a reform conversion so I cannot speak to their halakhic observance.

title: How does a war end?
content:
# How does a war end? ## Frage

To start an optional war, the full Sanhedrin must approve (Sanhedrin 2a.). A mandatory war would be defensive, against the 7 nations, or against Amalek.

How do these wars end?

For example, did the war with the Romans end when Masada was captured, the Persians drove out the Romans in 614, or the Eastern Roman Empire fell in 1453?

What kind of halachic act, if any, is needed to end the state of war?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

A milchemet mitzvah – whether a biblically mandated war (against Amalek or the seven nations) or a defensive war for the salvation of Israel – ends once the reason for the war no longer exists; this can happen through complete victory (destruction of the enemy or their complete submission to our terms chabad.org.), or through the elimination of the threat (e.g., the enemy withdraws or renounces their aggression); a sincere peace treaty that does not violate a Torah prohibition can also legitimately end an obligatory war – for the goal of protecting Jewish life is thereby achieved; if the war objective (e.g., the existence of Amalek) is currently unattainable or obsolete, the obligation to wage war is suspended until further notice (“It is a time to act for the Lord, they have voided Your Torah” ”עת לעשות לה', הפרו תורתך” – sometimes one must postpone the active fulfillment of a mitzvah to prevent worse outcomes); under no circumstances must one fight “to the last man” if it is foreseeable that no success is possible – פיקוח נפש pikuach nefesh then dictates laying down arms; a formal halachic act (such as a court declaration) is not necessary to end an obligatory war, as Halacha ties the state of war to objective circumstances, not to legal fictions; however, the end of the war is, of course, documented politically (ceasefire, treaty), and spiritually, one should give thanks for the peace achieved (as was done in the past through Hallel on Chanukah or local “Purim” days after salvation).

A milchemet reshut likewise ends upon the achievement or abandonment of its objective; here, the decision-making authority lies with the leading ruler (king, today's government): Since the war itself was voluntary, the leader can decide to end it at any time—be it after a victory (capture of the targeted territory), through a settlement/peace, or even by retreat in case of failure; no further Sanhedrin decision is needed as long as the peace agreement does not violate the Torah; if the leader considers uncertain steps (e.g., alliances with morally questionable consequences), it would certainly be advisable to consult the Chachamim—in biblical times, for example, the Urim ve-Tumim; however, halachically it applies: As soon as the legitimate leader declares the campaign over (and this does not contradict divine commandments), the war is over; the troops return home, the special laws applicable in war (distribution of spoils according to measurement—cf. Bamidbar 31:27, camp discipline according to Deut. 23:10-15, etc.) come to a conclusion, and the people transition to peace laws (such as Hakhel instead of an army at Sukkot after the war, see Deut. 31:10).

The revolt of 66–73 CE (Second Temple, Destruction): This was originally a discretionary war (milchemet reshut) from the perspective of the insurgents – there was initially no prophetic command to attack the Romans, and Rabban Yochanan ben Zakkai & Co. considered it unwise; however, when the Romans besieged Jerusalem, the fight for the defenders there certainly became a commanded war (milchemet mitzvah) in the sense of "saving Israel from the enemy" – it was about survival; after the city fell and the Temple burned (70 CE), the war was militarily lost; individual pockets of resistance (Masada until 73) continued to fight, but ultimately the war ended in complete defeat; halachically, the mitzvah of redeeming Israel and building the Temple remained, but due to the lack of any real possibility, this was postponed.

Leading Poskim of recent decades have predominantly recognized that Israel's defensive wars today are classified as milchemet mitzvah jewishaction.com; already in the 1948 War of Independence, rabbis like R. Shlomo Zevin wrote it was a "milchemet mitzvah" both because it is the rescue of Israel from enemies (Rambam) and because it concerns Eretz Israel (Ramban); Rav Herzog and the Chazon Ish – although not Zionist-oriented – agreed in principle that national defense and the protection of Jewish life are halachically obligatory (even if they set other priorities for individuals, see below); Rav Elyashiv, for example, explicitly referred to the Yom Kippur War of 1973 as a milchemet mitzvah with all relevant Halachot; Rav Ovadia Yosef wrote that even the Entebbe rescue operation in 1976 had the status of a milchemet mitzvah – because it involved the rescue of Jewish hostages (thus prototypically Asrat Israel mi-yad Tzar); this assessment has practical consequences: in a milchemet mitzvah, even grooms, Torah scholars, etc., must fundamentally participate; there are leniencies in the areas of Kashrut, Shabbat, etc., that go beyond normal Pikuach Nefesh; for example, Tzitz Eliezer (R. E. Waldenberg) argues that in wartime the rule "your own life comes first" does not apply – rather "all are collectively obligated to risk their lives for their brothers... within the framework of the laws of the community and state leadership" machonmeir.net; soldiers in the field may also, under certain circumstances, eat forbidden foods without immediate life danger if it serves combat morale or strength (Tzitz Eliezer XVIII,70, based on Magen Avraham and R. Akiva Eger).

title: How could the Sages suppress such sefarim such as Yechezkel and Kohelet?
content:
# How could the Sages suppress such sefarim such as Yechezkel and Kohelet? ## Frage

They of course seemed to have had good intentions so as to not let the books confuse people but how is it possible that some of the most wise and humble men decide that they have the right to suppress Yechezkel which has the word of Hashem and Kohelet which was written by someone who had been confirmed to have so much wisdom and possibly the most of any human ever? How can they think that they are more wise than the ones who have been confirmed as wise by Hashem? Regarding Kohelet for example they allowed to keep it because it began and ended with Torah. What if it didn't? If Shlomo thought that people should learn it then how could they as humble men think that they were smarter than him in allowing people to learn it? That is amplified regarding the word of Hashem in Yechezkel.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

R. Moshe Feinstein addresses this in one of his teshuvos (Yoreh De'ah 3:115). Some relevant parts:

וגם בלא זה הא מצינו דבשביל שלא ידעו חכמים לפרש דברי יחזקאל אף שהוא נבואה מהשי״ת וכל הכופר בנבואת יחזקאל הוא אפיקורס ורשע גמור,‏ מ״מ כיון שמחמת זה‏ אפשר לטועין ח״ו לחשוב שאיכא סתירה מיחזקאל הנביא לספר התורה שניתנה ע״י משה רבינו ויבא לכפור ח״ו או בתורה‏ או בנביאים או בשניהם,‏ רצו בשביל זה לגנוז אף שהוא דבר האסור דהא ניתנה ליכתב לדורות והוא מניעה‏ מדבר תורה דכל המקרא אף בנביאים וכתובים הוא תורה שבכתב ואיכא חיוב ללמוד כולן,‏ וגם דהא ספר יחזקאל וכל ספרי הנביאים הם דברי נבואה שנאמרה‏ לדורות ובשכל זה‏ נכתבו כמפורש במגלה דף י״ד נבואה שהוצרכה‏ לדודות נכתבה,‏ שא״כ הוא כמניעה‏ מלשמוע דברי הנביא שהוא עוד איסור,‏ אבל מ״מ ראו חכמים שטוב לגונזו אף שהוא עקירת תורה מספר זה‏ בשביל קיום עיקרי‏ האמונה שלא יכשלו אינשי בהו.‏ וכן היה‏ בספר משלי בשבת דף ל׳ רצו לגונזו אף שנכתב ברוח הקדש לכו״ע דלא מצינו פלוגתא במשלי,‏ וא״כ הוא ג״כ נבואה‏ שהוצרכה לדורות לבד שהוא תורה... וכהא שיש כח לחכמים לעקור דבר מן התורה שעקרו מצות שופר ולולב בשביל שלא יבואו לעבור על הוצאה דשבת וטובא כה״ג... עד שדרש חנניה בן חזקיה ספר יחזקאל ועיינו היטב בקהלת ומשלי וראו שלחכמים אין למיטעי,‏ ששוב לא חששו לטועין מסתם אינשי דמאחר דחכמים יאמרו להם שהם יודעין כל הספר יאמינו להם שאין להרהר כלום ח״ו אחר ספרים אלו.

The gist of his explanation is that the Sages knew full well that Yechezkel and Mishlei and Koheles are unimpeachably the word of Hashem (and that one who disbelieves them to be so is branded as a "heretic and thoroughly wicked"). But as long as the Sages themselves couldn't fully understand those books, such that there appeared to be insoluble contradictions within them (and between them and the Torah), then they considered the dangers of misinterpreting these books - which would weaken people's belief in the Torah itself - to outweigh the reasons to keep them publicly available. Once Chananyah ben Chizkiyah resolved the contradictions in Yechezkel, and similar methods were used for Mishlei and Koheles, then the fact that the average person might not know those reconciliations no longer matters, since they can rely on the Torah sages to tell them that such reconciliations exist and that there's nothing objectionable in these books.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The rabbis had to make decisions in the face of mountains of candidate books. Most were rejected for inclusion in the Tanakh because they had secular or Hellenistic tendencies, or disagreed with the Torah in some of their statements, or were deemed to be fictional, or were not written in Hebrew, or were not Jewish, or were too recent, or did not add new teachings, etc. Most had the name of God in them. Many, if not most, are lost as a result.

In question were The Song of Songs (no mention of God, too erotic), Ecclesiastes (self-contradictory), Esther (no mention of God), Proverbs (self-contradictory), Job (fictional), Ezekiel (contradicts Torah), etc. The discussions that resulted in their acceptance are in the Talmud [Yadayim 3:5, Shabbat 30b, Megillah 7a, Bava Batra 15a].

title: The sages quoting the word of Hashem outside of Tanach
content:
# The sages quoting the word of Hashem outside of Tanach ## Frage

There are so many examples of this but here is one, Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 2:6 it says towards the end:

Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated: The book Deuteronomy ascended, bowed down before the Holy One, praise to Him, and said to Him: Master of the Universe, You wrote in Your Torah that any disposition which is partially invalid is totally invalid, and now Solomon wants to uproot a י from me! The Holy One, praise to Him, said to it: Solomon and a thousand like him will disappear but nothing from you will disappear.

The question is did Hashem actually say that? Was there a Navi who received that word of Hashem? Was it Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai who heard it from Hashem or an angel or a bat kol? Or are they merely saying that Hashem would say something like that? There is clearly a heavy weight with the word of Hashem, is it applied to the above example? Is this counted as someone who is speaking in the name of Hashem? How does this relate to Deuteronomy 18:18-22? Is this applying the weight of Hashem's word without any of the responsibility of the one who speaks in the name of Hashem?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Gemara was written after the era of prophecy had come to a close. The aggadeta in the OP's question should not be taken literally. Examples of such aggadetas are analyzed by Rabbi Tzvi-Hirsch Chajes in his book "The Student's Guide through the Talmud", chapter XXVII Aggadoth expressing profound ideas in figurative style:

There are several subjects in the Gemara whose meaning cannot be taken in literal sense, because the text expounded literally would depict G-d as corporeal being, and would also at times involve an act of blasphemy. We should, and we are, indeed, in duty bound to believe the transmitters of true Kabbalah (i.e. tradition), who are known to us as righteous and saintly men and also as accomplished scholars, would not speak merely in an odd manner. We must therefore believe that their words were uttered with an allegorical or mystical sense and that they point to matters of the most elevated significance, far beyond our mental grasp.

The Rabbis deemed it proper not to expose to the masses the mystical doctrines that were hidden in their words, and so they uncovered only one handbreadth, leaving ten handbreadths covered. The literal sense of such words of theirs was only as if it were a mere outer garment beneath which lay a precious ideas observed only by the wise and understanding student.

... (These types of aggaddos) which according to ordinary reason, seem to have no sense and are at first glance contradictory to the principles of our religion and the fundamentals of our faith, contain important intimations on matters of high worth. And these profound thoughts are merely enveloped in a covering of many shells, the inner meaning left for those alone who can penetrate into the hiden things of G-d.

title: Why should one be immediately replaced if he messed up during the brocho of heretics?
content:
# Why should one be immediately replaced if he messed up during the brocho of heretics? ## Frage

B"H

The Rambam laws of Tefillah chapter 10 halacha 3 writes

ג שְׁלִיחַ צִבּוּר שֶׁטָּעָה וְנִבְהַל וְלֹא יָדַע מֵהֵיכָן יַתְחִיל וְשָׁהָה שָׁעָה יַעֲמֹד אַחֵר תַּחְתָּיו. וְאִם טָעָה בְּבִרְכַּת הָאֶפִּקוֹרְסִין אֵין מַמְתִּינִין לוֹ אֶלָּא מִיָּד יַעֲמֹד אַחֵר תַּחְתָּיו שֶׁמָּא אֶפִּיקוֹרְסוּת נִזְרְקָה בּוֹ. וְהוּא שֶׁלֹּא הִתְחִיל בָּהּ אֲבָל אִם הִתְחִיל בָּהּ מַמְתִּינִין לוֹ שָׁעָה. וְלֹא יְהֵא הַשֵּׁנִי סַרְבָן בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה:

That if a shliach tzibbur makes a mistake in the blessing asking Hashem to remove the heretics from the world and cause them to be troubled, he is immediately replaced, "because maybe (a thought of) heresy was thrown into him".

It seems like there's some additional reasoning between the lines that I'm trying to grasp.

Is the reason because as a heretic he personally wouldn't want to ask Hashem to remove the heretics from the world, and therefore his stuttering is a sign to us that he was hesitant to say it, or is the reason because as he was saying the blessing, Hashem instantly (or potentially even before it was even started) began to answer his prayers (of causing the heretics to be troubled etc.) by causing him to inadvertently mess up?

Even though the simple reading of the halacha, as well as the explanation of shteinzelts which implies that he, the shliach tzibbur, is intentionally avoiding it:

מִינוּת נִזְרְקָה בּוֹ. שמא נעשה מין, ומשום כך הוא משתמט מן הברכה לאיבוד המינים

Support the first way, the obvious problem with that is as follows.

If he's actually a min (or apikoros, according to the two versions of Rambam here), then according to hilchos Teshuva, he either doesn't believe that the Creator exists at all or he doesn't believe that the Creator supervises the actions of man, so then why would he be afraid of saying the blessing (the underlying implications being that he's afraid that if he says it, the power of prayer will cause Hashem to listen to it)?

And if one were to say that there were different kinds of minim/apikorsim that could have also believed a certain type of creator, but would a heretic consider himself a heretic?

Are there any commentators on the gemara, Rambam, Shulchan Aruch or other sources that discuss this question?

title: Why would non-kohen soldiers give conditional divorces and not immediate divorces?
content:
# Why would non-kohen soldiers give conditional divorces and not immediate divorces? ## Frage

I've been reading (for example, here) about how Jewish soldiers since the times of King David have given their wives conditional divorces, that are designed to take effect only if some number of years pass before the husband returns home (i.e. Shabbat 26a, and Ketubot 9b)

Apparently this practice is even continued until this day, as many Israeli soldiers have given their wives such conditional divorces in the event God forbid that they are captured and never found.

What am I wondering is what is the advantage of a conditional divorce as opposed to a regular divorce? Why must there be some delay, or agonizing condition? Why not divorce immediately with a promise to eachother to await a future reunion? This seems to be far simpler and gives both parties the freedom to decide what is best for them given the evolving circumstances.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

B"H

Getting married is a big deal.

Every marriage is supposed to last forever, ideally. We say in the blessings of nisuin "...an everlasting edifice". Saying the blessings of marriage, paying the kesuvah and then rewriting it, making an additional $50k+ wedding with the proper band, food and accomodations is a big deal.

Many sources in the Torah stress the importance of making a wedding extremely lavish, because it is the foundation of the entire marriage.

Some sources (like the rugichover) even discuss how the entire marriage is one continuous effect that is constantly being renewed every instant, and the cause that makes it become renewed is from the moment of betrothal.

That's one of the many reasons why the day of the wedding is extremely important, and why it's worth it to spend tens or even hundreds of thousands of dollars just for that one day.

According to Shulchan Aruch, the day of the wedding is like a personal Yom Kippur for the bride and the groom. Once one has already gone through all of that trouble it's no light task to simply do it again if there's no need to, there's nothing wrong with a conditional divorce.

A divorce is also a big deal and should be avoided if needed.

The mishnah says that one should never divorce one's wife unless he needs to (there's different opinions within that scope, ranging from being so strict that only if she actually acted immoral/immodestly should one divorce her, to even if he found one more beautiful than her etc., but still, it can't just be for no reason).

Especially when it applies to one's first wife, the Talmud teaches that if someone chose vishalom divorces his first wife, the throne of Glory itself is dripping with tears.

In addition, in the vast majority of cases, when a divorce happens, the husband is obligated to pay her the Kesuvah amount specified at the time of the begining of the marriage. This could involve oftentimes seizing real estate property from people who bought land from the husband during the marriage period, if husband doesn't have enough money to pay back, which could cause all kinds of additional complications and court cases etc.

Also, there's no limit as to how many times one could be called for war.

If it's a one time war, then possibly there might be some thought of a justification to do a full divorce, even with all of the reasons not to in place.

But what if one spends an additional $50k+ and goes through all of the effort to get remarried after the war, then another couple years pass and he's called in to fight again?

title: Is it all Leah's doing?
content:
# Is it all Leah's doing? ## Frage

As we know from the commentaries and midrashim, Leah's eyes were weak from praying to Hashem to not have to marry Esav. If she had, her job would have been to cause him to turn into a "good guy". If that had happened, all history would have been different.

Her tefilot were answered and she was zoche to marry Yaacov instead.

The end result is the events that transpired: Esav had to lose the right of firstborn, which was given to Yaacov. Esav remained a "bad guy", instead of becoming the fourth Av Yisrael, and we had to go through this millennia-long struggle, swapping power with Esav, being treated "like dust" by him for most of history.

I would like to find any sources that analyze this. Did all of the above happen because of her prayers and Hashem's love for her? Did she know this would be the result? Would this have happened some other way (we have so many reasons given for the galuyot after all). What's the significance of this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Regarding the point brought up in the comments about the chance of Leah changing Eisav, and why it was different that Yaakov being punished for hiding Dinah. Rav Yosef Sorotzkin in his Meged Yosef writes that if Eisav would have married Dinah, Yaakov would have looked after, and ensured, that Dinah would not have been influenced by Eisav, and on the contrary be a good influence on him. Leah would not have such a "guardian" and therefore the danger to her spirituality would be much greater. She was therefore never punished for her tfillos.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

Yes it's explicit in a midrash in Bereishis Rabbah 70:16:

וְהָיְתָה בּוֹכָה וְאוֹמֶרֶת יְהִי רָצוֹן שֶׁלֹא אֶפֹּל בְּגוֹרָלוֹ שֶׁל רָשָׁע. אָמַר רַב הוּנָא קָשָׁה הִיא הַתְּפִלָּה שֶׁבִּטְלָה אֶת הַגְּזֵרָה, וְלֹא עוֹד אֶלָּא שֶׁקָּדְמָה לַאֲחוֹתָה

She would weep and say: ‘May it be His will that I will not fall to the lot of that wicked man.’ Rav Huna said: Prayer is powerful, as it nullified the decree. Moreover, she preceded her sister.

title: Why isn't Tefillin stressed more spiritually than physically
content:
# Why isn't Tefillin stressed more spiritually than physically ## Frage

The Torah says in Deuteronomy 6:8 "וּקְשַׁרְתָּ֥ם לְא֖וֹת עַל־יָדֶ֑ךָ וְהָי֥וּ לְטֹטָפֹ֖ת בֵּ֥ין עֵינֶֽיךָ׃ " but why is the main emphasis in our culture nowadays about the physical Tefillin? The main purpose is what it was made to do, which was to be a physical "sign" so that our spiritual elements can get the aid they need to have the correct notions. As it clearly says in Exodus 13:9 "וְהָיָה֩ לְךָ֨ לְא֜וֹת עַל־יָדְךָ֗ וּלְזִכָּרוֹן֙ בֵּ֣ין עֵינֶ֔יךָ לְמַ֗עַן תִּהְיֶ֛ה תּוֹרַ֥ת יְהֹוָ֖ה בְּפִ֑יךָ כִּ֚י בְּיָ֣ד חֲזָקָ֔ה הוֹצִֽאֲךָ֥ יְהֹוָ֖ה מִמִּצְרָֽיִם׃ " that the reason to have the sign (for distinction) and the remembrance is so that (למען) we have Hashem's Torah in our mouth. These physical signs are there to help our spiritual side, because it's hard to remember sometimes what our heart should be doing, and a physical sign will assist many, especially the layman who is not so experienced in controlling his heart.

This idea seems to be strengthened by a couple of points, one of them being what's written in Proverbs 3:3 "חֶ֥סֶד וֶאֱמֶ֗ת אַֽל־יַעַ֫זְבֻ֥ךָ קָשְׁרֵ֥ם עַל־גַּרְגְּרוֹתֶ֑יךָ כָּ֝תְבֵ֗ם עַל־ל֥וּחַ לִבֶּֽךָ " which clearly shows that these elements should be bound and written metaphorically and not physically; this adds to my point of what is of higher emphasis, the physical or spiritual (in the heart). If one just goes through the physical motions without the heart actually engaging, then what value do they provide to the person other than their development of devotion? Whereas if they devote themselves but also understand why the sign is there, then they develop their devotion and their heart so that their heart chooses to connect to Hashem instead of choosing to connect to those thoughts of vanity while wearing his Tefillin. This will also help the person continue to do it their whole life because they understand the value of it and the detriment if they don't do it.

This point has some connection to what the Rambam said in Guide for the Perplexed Part 1 Chapter 50 "דע, אתה המעיין בחיבורי זה, שההַאֲמָנָה אינה העניין הנאמר, אלא העניין המצטייר (נתפס, מומשג) בנפש, אם משתכנעים לגביו שהוא כך כפי שהצטייר. " And Deuteronomy 30:14 "כִּֽי־קָר֥וֹב אֵלֶ֛יךָ הַדָּבָ֖ר מְאֹ֑ד בְּפִ֥יךָ וּבִֽלְבָבְךָ֖ לַעֲשֹׂתֽוֹ "

To summarize the question: Why isn't the main priority and emphasis regarding Tefillin on the spiritual side (in the heart and mouth) rather than just the motions of the Tefillin; there seems to be more benefit that way. I am not saying not to wear Tefillin.

I very much appreciate the work you guys do on this site.

title: Sources on hirhurei aveira
content:
# Sources on hirhurei aveira ## Frage

There's a famous Rosh, very short, on the subject of הרהורים, and the mechanics of punishment for bad thoughts alone. Supposedly, it has opened a rich literature, but my חברותא & I are not finding much.

Here is the brief Rosh on Rosh Hashanah 17b:

א"ר יוחנן אלמלא מקרא כתוב אי אפש לאומרו מלמד שנתעטף הקב"ה כשליח ציבור והראה למשה בסיני ואמר לו כל זמן שישראל חוטאים יעשו לפני כסדר הזה ואני מוחל להם. "ה' ה'" אני הוא קודם שיחטא האדם אני הוא אחר שיחטא האדם. וא"ת מה צריך האדם למדת רחמים קודם שיחטא. וי"ל אע"פ שגלוי וידוע לפניו שסופו לחטוא מתנהג עמו במדת רחמים באשר הוא שם. אי נמי קודם שיחטא בע"ז. ואע"פ שכבר חשב לעובדה ומחשבת ע"ז הקב"ה מצרפה למעשה (קידושין לט:). כדכתיב (יחזקאל יד) "למען תפוש את בית ישראל בלבם" אפ"ה מתנהג עמו במדת הרחמים קודם שיחטא וכשיחטא מצרף המחשבה עם המעשה.

There's also a long & fascinating Rabbeinu Bachye on Devarim 29:18 who discusses the same subject.

And there's a short ChID"A in his ספר, פסח עינים that picks up the topic.

That's all I've found thus far. Where is there more discussion to be found on this topic: how we are punished for thoughts alone versus our actions... or for thoughts on top of our actions?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)
  1. It seems that the ideas stem from Gemara Yoma 29a

הִרְהוּרֵי עֲבֵירָה קָשׁוּ מֵעֲבֵירָה, וְסִימָנָיךְ: רֵיחָא דְבִישְׂרָא. שִׁילְהֵי דְקַיְיטָא קְשֵׁי מִקַּיְיטָא, וְסִימָנָיךְ: תַּנּוּרָא שְׁגִירָא.

Thoughts of transgression are worse than transgression itself, and your mnemonic is the odor of meat. The smell of roasting meat is more appetizing than actually eating the meat. The heat of the end of summer is more oppressive than the heat of the summer itself, and your mnemonic is a heated oven. After an oven has been heated several times in the course of a day, lighting it again, even slightly, will produce powerful heat. So too, at the end of the summer, since everything is hot, the heat is more oppressive.

There are many commentaries on this one.

  1. Gemara Horayos 10b teaches Lot got into trouble with his daughters because he offered them to anshei S'dom. (It's too long to paste here). There are other cases.

It is mentioned by Ben Yehoyada on Yoma 38b and maybe some others:

או יובן הענין כהך מעשה של לוֹט שאם לא היתה אשתו נעשית נְצִיב מֶלַח לא היה חוטא עם בנותיו אף על פי שהוא חטא בלא דעת כלל אך כיון שמקודם היה לו הרהור תאוה רעה כמו שאמרו בהוריות (הוריות י:) על פסוק (בראשית יג, י) 'וַיִּשָּׂא לוֹט אֶת עֵינָיו' לכך לא סייעו מן השמים שלא תהיה אשתו נְצִיב מֶלַח כדי דממילא לא היה נופל בחטא זה של בנותיו והבא להטהר כגון יִשַׁי שכונתו לשם שמים כאשר תבע את שפחתו סייעו אותו שיהיה נזקק לאשתו ולא לשפחתו.

  1. I also heard an idea from one rav in a private conversation that the reason why the lives of pre-flood people were long because they worked on purifying their thoughts, which is a very difficult task as they succumbed to what they tried purify themselves from.

  2. Rabbeinu Bachya Vayikra 6:2 says that korban Olah atones for improper thoughts:

ויש שאינו נאכל לא לכהנים ולא לבעלים, והוא קרבן עולה שאין לבני אדם בו שום חלק אלא כולו להקב"ה, וזהו לשון כליל, וקרבן זה של עולה הוא הנכבד שבכל הקרבנות כלן, וכן מוכיח הלשון שאמר היא העולה, הוסיף לומר היא העולה למעלת הקרבן וחשיבותו, וכן (יחזקאל י׳:ט״ו) היא החיה אשר ראיתי. גם פרי מעשיה גדול שמכפרת על הרהור הלב, כמו שאמר באיוב (איוב א׳:ה׳) והעלה עולות מספר כלם כי אמר איוב אולי חטאו בני וברכו אלהים בלבבם, וזהו לשון עולה שמכפרת על העולה על הרוח. והיה קרבן עולה קרב כל הלילה עד הבקר לפי שהאדם מחשב בלילה וחוטא ביום, הוא שאמר הנביא (מיכה ב׳:א׳) חושבי און ופועלי רע על משכבותם באור הבקר יעשוה, ועל כן צותה התורה שתהיה כפרה בזמן העברה. ולפי שעקר העברה היא ברוח היה הכל כליל באש ושב אל הרוח, ולא היה רשות לדבר גופני ליהנות ממנו, זהו הענין האחד. הענין השני גודל חיוב הנברא לעבוד את בוראו, דבר ידוע כי האדם צריך שיהיה נכנע ושפל להקב"ה בעמדו בתפלה לפניו או בעשותו מצוה או אחד מיתר העבודות הקלות או החמורות, שיתהדר בהם לכבוד הש"י, ושלא יחוס על כבוד עצמו, אלא שיכיר בעצמו כי הבשר והדם דל הוא ואין ידו משגת לחובה העצומה, וראוי לו להכנע ולהשפיל עצמו, כענין שכתוב באברהם (בראשית י״ח:כ״ז) ואנכי עפר ואפר, והמלך דוד ע"ה אמר (תהילים ט״ו:ד׳) נבזה בעיניו נמאס וז"ש בכאן:

There are also some sacrifices of which no part may be eaten by either the Priest or the owner. This is first and foremost the sacrifice discussed here, the עולה, burnt-offering, concerning which the Torah stipulated that all of it is to be burnt up on the Altar. This is the meaning of the word כליל, (verse 15). This burnt-offering is the most highly regarded of all the offerings and that is why the Torah emphasises that היא העולה, “it is the upwards striving offering, etc.” Similarly, in Ezekiel 10,20 when the prophet describes היא החיה אשר ראיתי, “this is the chayah which I saw.” the extra word היא shows that of a variety of similar offerings or beings the one singled out with this extra word is considered the most elevated, the most highly regarded. The burnt-offering also possesses the quality of atoning for sinful thoughts as we know from Job, 1,5 where we are told that Job would offer such burnt-offerings after family gatherings during the various feasts in respect of each member of his family. [Had the offering been in respect of deeds committed, he would not have had to do this on behalf of everyone. Ed.] According to Ezekiel 20,32 this offering was in respect of sinful thoughts. Seeing man entertains these kinds of thoughts mostly at night the offering may remain on the altar all night long to counteract the thoughts of the person at night which are not carried out until daytime on whose behalf it had been brought. The prophet Michah 2,1 phrases it thus: “Ah, those who plan iniquity and design evil on their beds; when morning comes they do it, for they have the power.” This is why the Torah commanded that the atonement should occur at the time the iniquity is being committed. Seeing that in essence the sin was insubstantive, i.e. only in the mind, the offering is to dissolve entirely in the wind, the smoke rising into the air. The animal, so to speak, returns to the regions of the spirit it came from. No substantive part of the world, i.e. a body, is allowed to derive any benefit from this offering. This is one aspect of the burnt-offering.

The second aspect is the lesson of how important it is for the creature to serve his Creator. It is a well known fact that man has to relate to his G’d from a position of being submissive, humble. One needs to demonstrate this both while praying and while performing any of the other relatively easy commandments or even the difficult commandments. One needs to remain aware that performance of such commandments is not meant to be a “feather in our cap,” but is meant to enhance G’d’s glory. We need to remain constantly aware that our flesh is weak and that it is not capable of fulfilling the commandments in the manner they ought to be performed. We have to learn from Avraham who described himself as עפר ואפר, “dust and ashes,” though he had already offered his very life for Hashem (Genesis 18,27). King David expressed a similar sentiment when he said (Psalms 15,4) “man must be contemptible in his own eyes.” [He must feel that he has done less than a fraction of what is expected of him. Ed.]

  1. The pasuk Vayikra 6:6 based on Tikunei Zohar 73a

קָם סָבָא חַד מִבָּתַר טוּלָא (כותלא), וְאָמַר רַבִּי רַבִּי בּוֹצִינָא קַדִּישָׁא, קוּם אַדְלֵיק שְׁרַגָּא דְאִיהִי מִצְוָה, שְׁכִינְתָּא קַדִּישָׁא, דַּעֲלָהּ אִתְּמַר (ויקרא ו ו) אֵשׁ תָּמִיד תּוּקַד עַל הַמִּזְבֵּחַ לֹא תִכְבֶּה, וַעֲלָהּ אִתְּמַר (שמות כז כ) לְהַעֲלֹת נֵר תָּמִיד, נֵר יהו"ה אִתְקְרִיאַת וַדַּאי, אוֹר דְּנָהִיר בֵּיהּ נִשְׁמַת אָדָם, קוּם אַדְלֵיק בָּהּ.

One older person stood up from behind a wall, and said: Rebbe my teacher, The Holy Light, come and light candles, for that is a Mitzva (commandment), on that it is said: An everlasting fire shall be kept burning on the altar, it should not be extinguished. And, on that it is also said: To light the eternal flame. This is surely the light of the divine, the light that shines within the soul of every person. Come, light it with her.

is used as a segula against evil thoughts or clear one's mind when failing to concentrate during Amidah. R'Frand has a lecture "A Segula from Eliyahu from Evil Thoughts" where he mentions the last two and attributes the idea for the second to R'Moshe Cordovero.

title: Source for quote from Rebbe Nachman zy"a
content:
# Source for quote from Rebbe Nachman zy"a ## Frage

# When did Lubavitch begin eating only Lubavitch meat? ## Frage

Many Lubavitchers today only eat meat slaughtered from another Lubavitcher. Does anyone know when this came about? For of course one must eat meat from one that is yirei shamayim, for a shochet is not merely just one who slaughters meat, rather strongly G-d fearing, as has been explained by previous ChaBaD Rebbes.

title: Can the words ״שתרגילנו בתורתך״ ever count as Birchas Hatorah?
content:
# Can the words ״שתרגילנו בתורתך״ ever count as Birchas Hatorah? ## Frage

The law is (Orach Chaim 47:7) that if one already recited the blessing of “Ahavas Olam/Ahavah Rabbah”, and recited words of Torah immediately after Shmoneh Esreh, he no longer needs to recite Birchas Hatorah if he did not yet do so. The Mishnah Berurah there explains that the blessing of “Ahavas Olam/Ahavah Rabbah” contains a summary of Birchas Hatorah (i.e. a prayer that we be able to learn and understand the Torah).

My question is: if one recited words of Torah immediately after the blessing of “Hama’avir Sheina”, would he not need to recite Birchas Hatorah, being that he already said ״שתרגילנו בתורתך״?

title: Conservation of Biblical Timepoints?
content:
# Conservation of Biblical Timepoints? ## Frage

According to our tradition, several events seem to be occuring within one year one after another. Are there any sources, which explain if there is a midrashic connection?

  1. Time of Akkeida for Yitzchak and the birth of Rivkah, alternatively death of Sarah and birth of Rivkah (according to some manuscripts of Seder Olam)
  2. Blessing of Yaakov by Yitzchak and birth of Leah and Rachel
  3. Death of Rivkah and her nurse Devorah and death of Rachel
  4. Death of Leah and sale of Yosef
  5. Death of Yitzchak and release of Yosef from prison.

Should the question be reformatted as 5 separate questions?

One can show that these calculations follow from the principle of R' Yose ben Chalaphta, a student of R' Akiva. R' Yose's principle states in midrash Seder Olam Rabba 1:2:

לא בא (הכתוב) לסתום אלא לפרש

The Scripture did not come to hide, but to explain.

title: Why did Yaakov place stones around his head
content:
# Why did Yaakov place stones around his head ## Frage

I am looking for a summary of explanations for why Yaakov placed stones (Bereishit 28:11) around ('near' or 'at') his head that isn't Rashi's explanation of protection against animals.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Perhaps, you are looking for Bereshis Rabba 68:11,

“He took from the stones of the place” (Genesis 28:11) – Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Neḥemya, and the Rabbis argue:

  1. Rabbi Yehuda said: He took twelve stones. So, the Holy One blessed be He decreed that he would produce twelve tribes. He [Jacob] said: ‘Abraham did not produce them, Isaac did not produce them, I, if these twelve stones join with one another, I know that I will produce twelve tribes.’ When the twelve stones joined together one to another, he knew that he would produce twelve tribes.

  2. Rabbi Neḥemya said: He took three stones. He said: ‘Abraham, the Holy One blessed be He designated His name upon him; Isaac, the Holy One blessed be He designated His name upon him; I, if these three stones join with one another, I know that He will designate His name upon me.’ When the three stones joined with one another, he knew that the Holy One blessed be He would designate His name upon him.

  3. The Rabbis said: The minimum number of “stones” is two. Abraham, waste emerged from him – Ishmael and all the sons of Ketura. Isaac, Esau and all his chieftains emerged [from him]. I, if these two stones join with one another, I will know that waste will not emerge from me.

  4. Rabbi Levi and Rabbi Elazar said in the name of Rabbi Yosei bar Zimra: He made them in the shape of a roof gutter and placed it beneath his head because he feared the beasts.

Rabbi Berekhya and Rabbi Levi said in the name of Rabbi Ḥama bar Ḥanina (explain why the stones joined even according to Rabbi Levi and Rabbi Elazar): It is written: “For, behold, the Lord emerges from His place, and will descend and tread on the heights of the earth. [The mountains will melt under Him, and the valleys will burst like wax before the fire, like waters poured down a slope]” (Micah 1:3–4). (Even in a place where God only ‘passes through,’ valleys burst like wax.) All the more so for one in a place where the Holy One blessed be He has revealed Himself. (The stones melt and are joined together in a place where God's presence is not transient.)

There is also a less cheerful Bereshis Rabba 68:13

  1. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi interpreted the verse regarding the exile. “Jacob departed [vayetze] from Beersheba” (Genesis 28:10) – just as it says: “Send them from My presence, and let them go [veyetze’u]” (Jeremiah 15:1). “And went to Ḥaran” (Genesis 28:10) – just as it says: “With which the Lord has tormented me on the day of His enflamed wrath [ḥaron apo]” (Lamentations 1:12). “He encountered the place” (Genesis 28:11) – “until there is no more place” (Isaiah 5:8). “And stayed the night there because the sun had set” (Genesis 28:11) – “the one who bore seven is miserable…[her sun set while still day]” (Jeremiah 15:9). “He took from the stones from the place” (Genesis 28:11) – “The sacred stones are spilled at the head of every street” (Lamentations 4:1). “Which he placed beneath his head” (Genesis 28:11) – “[splendor] has come down from your heads” (Jeremiah 13:18). “And lay in that place” (Genesis 28:11) – “we will lie in our shame, and our humiliation will cover us” (Jeremiah 3:25).

Chizkuni states that the stones came from the altar on which his father Yitzchak was sacrificed.

title: Meaning of "Who maintains faith to those asleep in the dust"?
content:
# Meaning of "Who maintains faith to those asleep in the dust"? ## Frage

This phrase appears in the 2nd bracha of the amida: "Who maintains faith to those asleep in the dust". What does the phrase mean?

For example, does it refer only to good people? If so, what’s considered “good”? If not, what is the logic behind resurrecting evil people?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The statement comes from the words of Avraham, Bereshis 18:27:

וַיַּ֥עַן אַבְרָהָ֖ם וַיֹּאמַ֑ר הִנֵּה־נָ֤א הוֹאַ֙לְתִּי֙ לְדַבֵּ֣ר אֶל־אֲדֹנָ֔י וְאָנֹכִ֖י עָפָ֥ר וָאֵֽפֶר׃

Abraham spoke up, saying, “Here I venture to speak to my lord, I who am but dust and ashes:

The meaning of the verse is explained in the answer here. The dust/soil (עָפָ֥ר) shows richness after one had worked on it and brought forth vegetation. The simple meaning of the phrase is Hashem keeps faith of the people who toil on their product that it will come out well without any thoughts of spirituality. The more midrashic one is in the explanation link and in the comment of Double AA.

Additional meaning, we have a verse in Tehilim 113:7:

He raises the poor from the dust, lifts up the needy from the refuse heap.

That's the faith of those who sleep in the dust.

title: Staying in diaspora to avoid Gog Umagog
content:
# Staying in diaspora to avoid Gog Umagog ## Frage

The Navi describes that the war of Gog Umagog will be devastating. People will be killed, exiled, raped, and so on, all happening in Israel.

My question is, is it wrong to have the following thought- let me stay living in chutz la'aretz (diaspora) so that I avoid all the pains of the war, and then after the war is over I’ll move to Israel.

Do any commentaries address something like this, like why one would wanna be in Israel if all of this is gonna happen?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Maybe Rabbi Avraham Azulai's recorded statement from the Arizal will be useful to you:

וכשישראל בני קיבוץ גליות יראו שאחיהם נעשה בריה חדשה, ופורחים באויר ללכת ולדור בגן עדן תחתון ללמוד תורה מפי השם יתברך, אזי, יתקבלו בני קיבוץ גליות דאגה בלבם ודאבון נפש, ויתרעמו למלך המשיח ויאמרו וכי אין אנו בני ישראל כמותם, מאין זכו הם להיות רוחניים בגוף ונפש מה שאין כן אנו ולמה נגרע

When the exiled Jews [who have been brought back to Israel] witness their brethren being transformed into new spiritual beings and flying through the air to live in the Lower Gan Eden, where they will study Torah directly from Hashem, a feeling of anxiety and sorrow will arise in their hearts. They will complain to the Moshiach, saying, "Are we not also Jews like them? Why have they merited to be spiritual in both body and soul, while we remain unchanged? Why are we left behind?" [Chesed LeAvraham 3:22]

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

@RabbiKaii already did bring the famous explanation from the Chesed L'Avraham. However, if you read a little bit further (down), you will read that Rabbi Avraham Azulai explains that Moshiach will be complementing the people that risked their lives in going to Eretz Yisroel, "in order to merit a pure soul, not caring about their health [...] or to be captured by harsh lords" (Chesed L'Avraham, Even Shetiya, Maayan 3, Nahar 22):

And the Messiah says to them: "It is already known and widely proclaimed that all the attributes of the Holy One, blessed be He, measure for measure. Those who were in the diaspora and made efforts to come to the Land in order to merit a pure soul, not caring about their wealth or their bodies, whether by sea or land, not fearing to drown in the sea or be robbed on land, or to be captured by harsh lords. Because they acted primarily from their spirit and soul, not from their body or wealth, therefore, they returned in spiritual measure for measure. But you, who were capable of coming to the Land like them, were degraded to come for the sake of material wealth, and you were concerned about your wealth and your body. You made the essence secondary, from your soul and your spirit. Therefore, you remain materialistic measure for measure.

So, you ask, would it be better to wait in Golus and to wait until the war of Gog UMagog will be over? Well, according to the Chesed L'Avraham, the people that risk their life, health, wealth and more in order to go to Eretz Yisroel after Moshiach comes, in order to purify themselves, will be greatly awarded by G-d.

Maybe this is also how we can explain the famous statement that Moshiach will find only 7.000 Yidden in Eretz Yisroel. These Yidden are the ones that were willing to risk their lives in order to live in Eretz Yisroel.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

Another possible answer is, perhaps you are wrong about what will happen i.e. that it will be awful. Here's something from Otzrot Ramchal p 105 (Parashat Balak):

הן עם כלביא יקום וכארי יתנשא לא ישכב עד יאכל טרף ודם חללים ישתה (כג, כד). כבר ידוע שהרבה מלחמות צריכים ישראל לעבור קודם שינוחו ממלאכתם. והמלחמה האחרונה יהיה מלחמת גוג ומגוג. שאז ישראל יקומו כארי וכלביא לנקום נקמתם מן האומות אשר לחצו אותם בגלותם. ובאותו הזמן הרבה יהיו שישתעבדו תחת ישראל, והם יהיו גרים גרורים. ויהיו מהם גם כן שיזידו לעלות ולהלחם עם ישראל. ולהם נאמר: "ויצא ה׳ ונלחם בגוים ההם" וגו׳. וזהו: "הן עם כלביא יקום וכארי יתנשא". שכך טבעו של הארי, כשרואה אדם אחד מונח על הארץ כמת, אז מסיר עצמו ממנו.

Behold, the people shall rise like a lioness, and lift itself up like a lion; it shall not lie down until it devours the prey and drinks the blood of the slain" (Numbers 23:24). It is already known that Israel must undergo many wars before they can rest from their labor. The final war will be the War of Gog and Magog, at which time Israel will rise like a lion and a lioness to avenge themselves upon the nations that oppressed them during their exile. At that time, many will submit themselves under Israel and will become subjugated sojourners. Yet there will also be those who will dare to ascend and wage war against Israel. Concerning them it is said: "And the Lord shall go forth and fight against those nations" etc. And this is the meaning of: 'Behold, the people shall rise like a lioness and lift itself up like a lion.' For such is the nature of the lion - when it sees a man lying on the ground as if dead, it turns away from him.

If this is saying what I think it is saying, wouldn't want to miss it :)

title: Can you please define this yeshivish term?
content:
# Can you please define this yeshivish term? ## Frage

I was listening to someone explaining a halachic question and they kept returning to a term I could not figure out the meaning of from context "shas of the hock" (likely misspelled). It seemed to be used that in this situation, due to differing details, the halacha does not follow what you would usually expect. I would like to know a better definition of the idiom, perhaps correcting my misimpression, what language(s) it comes from, and also if it is coded towards stringency, leniency, or neutral.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 29)

She’at ha-dechak, or in yeshivish pronunciation shas hadchak.

The Hebrew is שעת הדחק, literally a pressing time, or, more colloquially, under pressing circumstances, or in extremis.

This is a very common phrase in halachic discourse, usually in the context of employing a leniency that one would not use in normal circumstances. A google search will probably give you a good sense of how and when it is used.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 14)

The term שעת דחק, means under pressing circumstances.

What one does under pressure, is not necessarily what one does in regular, day to day conditions.

Here is a link for a complete explanation: https://he.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D7%A9%D7%A2%D7%AA_%D7%94%D7%93%D7%97%D7%A7

### Antwort 3 (Score: -1)

A better way to translate Shas HaDechak is emergency situation.

title: Origin of the Conservation of Biblical Personalities principle
content:
# Origin of the Conservation of Biblical Personalities principle ## Frage

There is a discussion on this site which is defined by a principle of Conservation of Biblical Personalities, when the midrash or aggadeta would quote various persons under the same name. Rabbi Tzvi-Hirsch Chajes in his book "The Student's Guide through the Talmud", chapter XXI The Quoting of Various Persons Under One and the Same Name:

...The Rabbis had the definite principle in their himiletic interpretations of praising, so far as possible, the deeds of the virtuaous and of disparaging the doings of the wicked in every possible way. They further adopted as one of their methods that of calling different personages by one and the same name if they found them akin in any feature of their characters or activities or if they found similarity between any of their actions. Even if where there was only some resemblance in the names of different persons, they blended the two as one ...

Who defined this principle for midrashic literature and how is it related to the principle of R' Yose ben Chalaphta, a student of R' Akiva?

R' Yose's principle in midrash Seder Olam Rabba 1:2 is applied to timing of the events in Tanach:

לא בא (הכתוב) לסתום אלא לפרש

The Scripture did not come to hide, but to explain.

In other words, when an event is happening during a certain time interval as referred by a verse in Tanach, it must refer to either beginning or the end of the interval, same place, Seder Olam Rabba 1:2, towards the end:

Rabbi Yose said: Ever was a great prophet that he called his son Peleg ("split") "because in his days the earth was split" (Bereshis 10:25). You cannot say this happened when Peleg was born since his younger brother Yoqtan had 13 families as his descendants at the Language split. You cannot say that this happened during Peleg's middle life since the Scripture does not come to hide but to explain. Therefore, the verse must mean that the split occured during Peleg's last year of life.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: -1)

Difference between Rabbi Yose and the first case is Rabbi Yose is in rules of pshat and first case is in realm of drush.

title: "Being Jewish" - born from a Jewish woman or having a Jewish mother?
content:
# "Being Jewish" - born from a Jewish woman or having a Jewish mother? ## Frage

This sounds frivolous but it's a genuine distinction.

One practical ramification is regarding conversion for a child born via surrogacy, whether the birth mother is Jewish and the egg donor is not, or vice-versa (depending on the halachic debate regarding motherhood).

A Rabbi I spoke to said it was clear to him that there was no inherent connection between motherhood and Jewishness (i.e. that Jewishness could simply be a consequence of emerging from a Jewish womb), and that was why he felt the Gemara in Yevamot 78a was not relevant to the surrogacy debate.

Are there any indications or proofs either way? Does anyone discuss this?

(Looking at some of the Rishonim regarding the sugya of הורתו שלא בקדושה ולידתו בקדושה (יבמות צח.), explaining why such individuals are Jewish, the Rishonim's choice of expression focuses on the circumstances of the child's birth, rather than who their mother is. For example, the תוס' רי"ד says "דהא לא נתגייר אלא בקדושה נולד". But I don't consider that to be such a strong proof.)

I tried looking for this halacha in the Rambam, and in Tur/SA, to see if their choice of wording could imply one way or another - but I wasnt successful in finding this fundamental halacha in either.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

There are arguments both ways. Some say the legal mother is the birth mother, because a midrash says that Dinah was conceived in Rachel's womb, and Joseph in Leah’s womb, but that God switched the embryos so Rachel could give birth to a son, Joseph. [Targum Yonatan on Genesis 30:21] The basis is that all six times Leah has a son, the Torah says: “Leah conceived and bore a son”. But when it comes to Dinah, it just says: “Leah bore a daughter”. Yet, the Torah clearly refers to Leah as Dinah's mother [Gen. 34:1]. So we learn that she who gives birth is the mother, not she who produced the egg.

The Talmud says that when Esther’s mother became pregnant with her, her father died, and when she was born, her mother died. [Megillah 13a] This could mean that Esther’s mother did not become her mother until Esther was born. The Midrash says "If someone begins to perform a commandment and does not complete it, and someone else comes and completes it, the one who has completed it gets the credit. [Deut. R. 8:4] Here, the one who completes the task is the birth mother, so she is the mother.

So far, most rabbinical authorities rule that the one giving birth is the mother. But there are other arguments. The discussion continues.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The Rabbi you are quoting is suggesting that a child born through surrogacy could have a Jewish mother but not be Jewish, or have a non-Jewish mother but be Jewish, as emerging from the womb of an unrelated woman is what defines Jewishness.

Aside from this possibility not having a clear rationale, I believe it can be proved wrong from the very Gemara you reference (Yevamot 78a-b). The Gemara says that if עובר לאו ירך אמו (a foetus is not considered ‘a limb of its mother,’ but an independent entity), the foetus of a woman who converts to Judaism during pregnancy requires its own immersion, and this is achieved in the mikveh together with the mother, as the body of the mother is not a chatzitza (blockage).

Were the suggestion you make correct, even if the body of the mother were a a chatzitza, the baby should be Jewish just by emerging from the womb of a Jewish mother.

So in short, the answer is that "being Jewish" is a function of having a Jewish mother.

title: How was Rabban Gamliel’s successor chosen?
content:
# How was Rabban Gamliel’s successor chosen? ## Frage

Rabban Gamliel held of office of Nasi (patriarch) and was deposed. His successor was chosen to be Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya (Berachot 27b-28a). R' Elazar was a Kohen and therefore could not have been of the same family as the Nasi, nor could he have been a descendant of the line of David.

I would like to understand how/why R' Elazar was able to be chosen for this role (rather than either appointing someone else from the family of the Nasi or leaving it vacant until R' Gamliel died).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

R' Elazar ben Azaria was appointed as an exception because he was wise, wealthy, 10th generation after Ezra (good yichus), and because he grew grey hair (so that his wife would agree) as gemara states. Gemara Berakhos says that after Rabban Gamliel apologized to Rabbi Yehoshua and other rabbanim on daf 28a, he was reinstated:

The question arose what to do with Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya? They said: What shall we do? Remove him from his position. That is inappropriate as we learned a halakha through tradition: One elevates to a higher level of sanctity and does not downgrade. Therefore, one who was the Nasi of the Sanhedrin cannot be demoted. Let one Sage lecture one week and the other Sage one week, they will come to be jealous one of another, as they will be forced to appoint one as the acting head of the Sanhedrin. Rather, Rabban Gamliel will lecture three weeks and Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya will lecture as head of the yeshiva one week. That arrangement was adopted and that is the explanation of the exchange in tractate Ḥagiga: Whose week was it? It was the week of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. One final detail: That student who asked the original question that sparked this entire incident was Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai.

He was Rabban Gamliel II of Yavneh. His grandfather Rabban Gamliel the elder was installed as Nasi by R' Yochanan ben Zakkai after the destruction of the Temple. His father was Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. After Rabban Gamliel II, his son R' Shimon ben Gamliel II was appointed as a Nasi.

As far as yichus of the family of Hillel being descendands of David haMelekh as stated in Bereshis Rabba 98:8

Hillel, from whom did he descend? Rabbi Levi said: A genealogical scroll was found in Jerusalem in which it was written: Hillel is from David. Rabbi Ḥiyya Rabba is from Shefatya son of Avital.

or conflicting account in Kesubos 62b:

It is related further that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi arranged for his son to marry a daughter of the household of Rabbi Ḥiyya. When he came to write the marriage contract, the girl died. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said: Is there, Heaven forbid, some disqualification in these families, as it appears that God prevented this match from taking place? They sat and looked into the families’ ancestry and found that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi was descended from Shefatya ben Avital, the wife of David, whereas Rabbi Ḥiyya was descended from Shimi, David’s brother.

or Shabbos 56a

Rav said: Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, who descends from the house of David, seeks to teach the verse in favor of David.

That is only true on their mother's side. According to Yerushalmi Kilaim 9:3 and Yerushalmi Kesubos 12:3, the direct descendant of Rabban Gamilel II, his grandson Rabbi Yehuda haNassi, explicitly stated himself that he was from Shevet Binyamin on his father's side:

Rebbi was very meek and said, all a man might ask from me I am ready to do, except what the elders of Bathyra did for my ancestor: they divested themselves of their presidency and appointed him. If Rav Huna, the Head of the Diaspora, would come here I would let him sit higher than myself since he is from the tribe of Judah and I am from Benjamin, he is from the male line and I am from the female.

Rav Huna, the Head of the Diaspora, the exilarch, was a direct descendant of the exiled king Yechoyakin (Eliyakim) and obviously of David. Thus, the yichus of Rabban Gamliel was not as strong of a factor.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

R' Levi Ginzberg in his chiddushim on Yerushalmi argues that in fact R' Gamliel was never 'deposed' from the Patriarchy (Nasi) but merely from being the head of the academy (Rosh HaYeshiva).

This accords with the language of the Talmud where R' Elazar is asked

נִיחָא לֵיהּ לְמָר דְּלֶיהְוֵי רֵישׁ מְתִיבְתָּא
Would you like to be the head of the Academy

As well as the continuation that when R' Gamliel was 'restored' R' Elazar continued to give the Shabbos derasha (on certain weeks) as they were now co-Roshei Yeshiva

content:

Is it correct to say, as I once heard, that the Rebbe Maharash would learn Oral Torah the entire night while standing?
