title: Why is Y-K-V-K which denotes mercy, more strict than saying Elokim which denotes justice?
content:
# Why is Y-K-V-K which denotes mercy, more strict than saying Elokim which denotes justice? ## Frage

Kabbalistically speaking, the name Elokim denotes strict justice, while the name YHWH denotes mercy.

If this is the case, then why are we more strict not to say Hashem's name of mercy outside the Beis HaMikdash, but we often say Elokim outside? Shouldn't it be the other way around?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

First of all, these names are not defined only by judgement and mercy, there are other definitions, such as:

YKVK- היה הווה ויהיה (infinite/eternal),

Elokim- All powerful… etc…

-all among many other meanings to the names whether known or unknown to us.

However, even with just the meaning you brought, I think it’s clear that mercy is actually the greater trait.

One way we see this is that Hashems right hand is Mercy and his left is judgement, and in Judaism there is always an importance to the right hand over the left, like it says in Tehillim (118:15) “Yemin Hashem oseh chayil”.

We also say in davening “asei lemaan yeminecha”.

The Arizal (Ohr Tzaddikim 2:63) Says to give charity with the right hand. This is based on a medrash (Devarim rabba) that says that charity and Torah are in Hashems right hand.

This is in addition to all other mitzvos we do with the right, of which there are many.

On a more theological level though, mercy has always been the idea that was a revelation. Idol worshippers never had a concept of mercy. Their relationship to their deities was one of sacrifice and punishment. That was and still is the basic idea of a ruler, to exercise power (Elokim). This is indeed why the Torah refers to other “gods” as elokim, because in terms of power and might, they share that mentality with Hashem.

It’s YKVK that differentiates Hashem from other gods. And as Rav Nachman writes (Likutei Moharan I:64), this world was created so Hashem can show his mercy.

Mercy in this context though is not merely the mercy humans display, like when you feel bad for someone so you give them something to make them feel better. Mercy as it pertains to Hashem is so great that it overrides Hashems own Godly judgement. But more importantly, it exhibits Hashems supreme control over the universe. Only a being with infinite knowledge, who exists outside of time and space can make a proper decision to override judgement. Who else can say in the grand scheme of things that in this situation the rules of the world need not apply? Surely not an idol who’s specialized “power” is over the sun or moon or water and knows nothing outside of that… The answer of course is only the Grand Schemer himself.

So essentially, to be able to enact mercy, really means that Hashems not just powerful but he’s the grand Schemer, and by definition overrides the Elokim part of Hashem.

title: Did Chazal ever divorce?
content:
# Did Chazal ever divorce? ## Frage

I'm wondering, out of pure interest, if we know of any Tannaim, Amoraim, Savoraim, Geonim or Rishonim who divorced their wives?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

The relevant paragraph in the commentary Leiv Avos by R' Yaakov Haber can be translated as follows:

"When (Ben Azai) was with Rabbi Akiva they said, Kesubos 63a,

The Gemara relates: Rabbi Akiva’s daughter did the same thing (as R' Akiva's wife for R' Akiva) for ben Azzai, who was also a simple person, and she caused him to learn Torah in a similar way, by betrothing herself בצנעה to him and sending him off to study. This explains the folk saying that people say: The ewe follows the ewe; the daughter’s actions are the same as her mother’s.

And they also say in Sota 4b:

The Gemara answers: If you wish, say that he was married and separated from his wife.

And without a doubt he was a great diligent student of the Torah and also entered the PaRDe"S as described later, so he separated completedly from the ways of this world. And when he taught Yebamos 63b

(Regarding anyone who does not engage in the mitzva to be fruitful and multiply) Ben Azzai says: It is (considered) as though he sheds blood and also diminishes the Divine Image, as it is stated: “And you, be fruitful and multiply,” after the verse that alludes to both shedding blood and the Divine Image.

They said to ben Azzai: There is a type of scholar who expounds well and fulfills his own teachings well, and another who fulfills well and does not expound well. But you, who have never married, expound well on the importance of procreation, and yet you do not fulfill well your own teachings. Ben Azzai said to them: What shall I do, as my soul yearns for Torah, and I do not wish to deal with anything else. It is possible for the world to be maintained by others, who are engaged in the mitzva to be fruitful and multiply.

In all likelihood, once he divorced the daughter of R' Akivah his Rabbi, he then separated from her and afterwards complained about it, saying Nedarim 74b, when he overheard the argument of R' Eliezer, R' Akiva, and R' Yehishua regarding husband's or yavam' ability to nullify of vows of a woman:

The baraita adds a comment: Ben Azzai stated his response to hearing this discussion in this language: Woe [ḥaval] to you, ben Azzai, that you did not serve Rabbi Akiva properly.

# Is it Mishna Vrura? ## Frage

According to the rules of dikduk, is the correct pronunciation of משנה ברורה "Mishna V'rura", without the dagesh in the beis? If so, I'm curious as to why most people pronounce it with a dagesh.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Yes, in a strictly grammatical sense it should be pronounced mishnah v’rurah. However, the pronunciation of Hebrew phrases, especially everyday terms, is largely cultural (and practical). Hence, most people will pronounce it as Mishnah B’rurah, Divrei Torah, Tosfos etc. (as opposed to Divrei Sorah and Tosafos.)

title: Why did Eisav's emotions turn on?
content:
# Why did Eisav's emotions turn on? ## Frage

In בראשית לג:ד, the word "וַׄיִּׄשָּׁׄקֵ֑ׄהׄוּׄ" is dotted. Rashi explains that this is to tell us that Eisav kissed Yaakov with a full heart and not just for show.

  1. What caused Eisav to suddenly show his emotions?

  2. What can we learn from this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

One can learn the answer from well-known midrash Bereshis Rabba 78:9

“Esau ran to meet him, embraced him, fell upon his neck, and kissed him, and they wept” (Genesis 33:4). “Esau ran to meet him…and kissed him [vayishakehu]” – it is dotted above it. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Every place you find the script more numerous than the dots, you expound the script; the dots more numerous than the script, you expound the dots. Here, neither is the script more numerous than the dots, nor are the dots more numerous than the script. Rather, it teaches that at that moment he was overcome with mercy and he kissed him with all his heart. Rabbi Yannai said to him: If so, why is it dotted over it? Rather, it teaches that he did not come to kiss him, but rather to bite him, and Jacob’s neck was transformed into marble and the teeth of that wicked one were blunted. Why does the verse state: “And they wept”? It is, rather, that this one wept over his neck, and that one wept over his teeth. Rabbi Abbahu in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan derives it from here: “Your neck is like the ivory tower…” (Song of Songs 7:5).

The literal meaning of the midrash, according to Rabbi Yannai, is that Esav tested Yaakov by acting as a true brother and trying to sway his heart. At the same time, in the mind of Yaakov, Eisav was coming as a ruthless and cruel killer with an army of 400 armed men. Thus, we see, that Eisav tried to split Yaakov's mind and Yaakov's heart, force him to act contrary to his convictions, and get trapped in the land of Seir. Technically, the separation of head and body is called melikah and that's why Eisav's most dangerous descendant, Amalek can be read as "am melikah* - nation of melikah. It is also related to Esav's death, when his head was separated from his body, i.e. Eisav died from what he did to others. The fact, that Hashem made Yaakov's neck strong like marble according to Rabbi Yannai, means that Hashem gave Yaakov extra strength to resist Eisav's emotional outbreak.

According to Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, Eisav felt pity for Yaakov, who just gave much of what he earned to him. It looked in his eyes as a proof that the blessing, which Yaakov took ahead of Eisav from Yitzchak, did not materialize. Yaakov looked meek, while Eisav was a head of an army of men. Certainly, in such a situation Eisav would not be destroying Yaakov and his family in front of 400 armed men. But if Eisav could trap Yaakov to the land of Seir - there he could do what he pleased without any witnesses.

We also see a similar point in Rashi on Bereshis 46:6 when Yaakov takes his posessions to go to Egypt:

אשר רכשו בארץ כנען WHICH THEY HAD GOTTEN IN THE LAND OF CANAAN — But all that he had gotten in Padan-aram he gave to Esau in payment for his share in the Cave of Machpelah. He said, “The possessions I obtained outside the land are of no value to me”. It is to this that the words refer (Genesis 50:5) “[Bury me in my burying-place] which כריתי” I obtained for myself by means of a כרי. He placed before him (Esau) piles of gold and silver like a heap (כרי) of corn and said to him, “Take these in exchange for your share in the Cave of Machpelah” (Midrash Tanchuma, Vayechi 6).

title: How could Rachel Imeinu have revealed Yaakov's secret to Leah?
content:
# How could Rachel Imeinu have revealed Yaakov's secret to Leah? ## Frage

The Orchos Chaim L'Rosh (41) writes:

סוֹד אַחֵר אַל תְּגַל. גַּם אֶת הַדְּבָרִים אֲשֶּׁר יְדַבְּרוּ לְפָנֶיךָ שֶּׁלֹּא עַל דֶּרֶךְ סוֹד, טוֹמְנֵהוּ בְּקִירוֹת לִבֶּךָ - Do not reveal the secrets of others. Even non-confidential matters, keep in the confines of your heart.

The Chafetz Chaim paskens (Rechilus 8:5:7)

וְחַיָּב אָדָם לְהַסְתִּיר הַסוֹד, אֲשֶׁר יְגַלֶּה לוֹ חֲבֵרוֹ דֶּרֶךְ סֵתֶר, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין בְּגִלּוּי הַסוֹד הַהוּא עִנְיַן רְכִילוּת, כִּי יֵשׁ בְּגִלּוּי הַסוֹד נֵזֶק לִבְעָלָיו וְסִבָּה לְהָפֵר מַחֲשַׁבְתּוֹ, גַּם בָּזֶה הוּא יוֹצֵא מִדֶּרֶךְ הַצְּנִיעוּת, וְהוּא מַעֲבִיר עַל דַּעַת בַּעַל הַסּוֹד - And a man must conceal a secret which his friend tells him in private, even though there is no rechilus in the revelation of this secret. For there is in its revelation harm to its confider and cause for voidance of his plans. Also, in this ["dust" of rechilus], he departs from the way of modesty and transgresses the will of his confidant.

How could Rachel Imeinu have revealed the secret simanim Yaakov Avinu gave her to ensure Lavan did not switch her with Leah? See Rashi Bereishis (29:25)

ויהי בבקר והנה היא לאה. אֲבָל בַּלַּיְלָה לֹא הָיְתָה לֵאָה, לְפִי שֶׁמָּסַר יַעֲקֹב סִימָנִים לְרָחֵל, וּכְשֶׁרָאֲתָה רָחֵל שֶׁמַּכְנִיסִין לוֹ לֵאָה אָמְרָה: עַכְשָׁו תִּכָּלֵם אֲחוֹתִי, עָמְדָה וּמָסְרָה לָהּ אוֹתָן סִימָנִים (מגילה י"ג): ויהי בבקר והנה הוא לאה AND IT CAME TO PASS, THAT IN THE MORNING, BEHOLD, IT WAS LEAH — But at night it was not Leah (i. e. he failed to recognise that it was Leah) because Jacob had given Rachel certain secret signs by which they could at all times recognise one another, and when Rachel saw that they were about to bring Leah to him for the marriage ceremony, she thought, “My sister may now be put to shame”, and she therefore readily transmitted these signs to her (Megillah 13b).

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

In the book Bedarchei Avot Khelek 2, pg 357, Rabbi Aharon pessin shlit"a brings from the kol simkha that what Rakhel did was an aveira lishma

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

It wasn't a secret in the sense that it was information about himself that he didn't want revealed to others. It was a secret code that he gave her to use to identify herself. Once he gave it to her, it was hers to use. It now belonged to her and she in her infinite wisdom and compassion decided to share it with Leah. This resulted in 6 Shevatim being born out of the 12 that were destined. BTW - I recently saw that the secret code was either touching his right earlobe, right thumb and right big toe, or citing the mitzvahs of women of Challah, Niddah and Lighting candles. Also BTW- your question might have been better asked as to how she could be Gonev Daas to Yaacov as opposed to Loshen Hara. In either case, the answer will be that she saw/knew with Ruach Hakodesh that this was supposed to be her destiny. We are mere mortals. The Imuhos and the Avos were on a different plane of existence.

title: זֵכר or זֶכר in אשרי?
content:
# זֵכר or זֶכר in אשרי? ## Frage

All my life I've said זֵכר. But recently I noticed in the artscroll siddur and tehillim, זֶכר. I checked a bunch of other siddurim, they all had it as זֵכר. (Unlike parshat Zachor, no sidur mentions variant גירסאות, or a suggestion to repeat the verse.)

So which is it? Is there a debate? what's the debate about? Is it the same debate in parshat Zachor, and if so, why is there no common practice to repeat?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

A student of the Vilna Gaon wrote down (Ma'aseh Rav 28 and 134) that the Vilna Gaon read this word, and the parallel word in Deuteronomy 25, with six dots זֶכֶר, without commenting on all the other places in Tanakh this word appears. (At the time in Europe, some erroneous manuscripts and printings had caused a whole hubbub about how the word should be pronounced in verses in general, and in particular if Psalms 30:5 should be different from the rest. No one had ever suggested your case of Psalm 145:7 was different from the rest and its proper pronunciation should thus be the same as [at least nearly] every other instance of זכר in Tanakh, however you hold about that.)

Accordingly, if you follow the now widely accepted tradition (supported by all our oldest extant pointed manuscripts) to always read the word with five dots זֵכֶר but you feel compelled to technically not deviate from any snippet of the Vilna Gaon's incomplete recorded practice, then you might (as this rabbi and Artscroll Publishers seem to have done) make up an internally inconsistent "new tradition" (?) of having זֵכֶר everywhere except those two places. May God bless and keep such corruptions far away from us.

title: Why do the Sages often believe that the word רוב mean "majority," when it clearly means "a lot"?
content:
# Why do the Sages often believe that the word רוב mean "majority," when it clearly means "a lot"? ## Frage

It seems clear that the word רוב in biblical Hebrew means "a large amount." For example, Bereshit 48:16

וְיִדְגּוּ לָרֹב בְּקֶרֶב הָאָרֶץ may they teem into multitudes in the midst of the earth

certainly does not mean the descendants of Ephraim and Menashe should be the "majority" of the world (although in theory it could), but that they should be many. The same meaning is clearly implied in Devarim 1:10, "וְהִנְּכֶם הַיּוֹם כְּכוֹכְבֵי הַשָּׁמַיִם לָרֹב." It may be pronounced differently, but this is clearly the same word in Bamidbar 13:18 "הֶחָזָק הוּא הֲרָפֶה הַמְעַט הוּא אִם רָב" or 22:3 "וַיָּגׇר מוֹאָב מִפְּנֵי הָעָם מְאֹד כִּי רַב הוּא" and in many, many (a "multitude", one might say) other places in Tanakh.

Yet, in some of these instances, the Sages seem to read the word as if it means "a majority," as in, the larger part of a whole. The most famous example is Shemos 23:2 "לֹֽא־תִהְיֶ֥ה אַחֲרֵֽי־רַבִּ֖ים לְרָעֹ֑ת וְלֹא־תַעֲנֶ֣ה עַל־רִ֗ב לִנְטֹ֛ת אַחֲרֵ֥י רַבִּ֖ים לְהַטֹּֽת" (which is a difficult reading for other reasons, as Rashi and the commentators note there). But it also comes up elsewhere, such as in Megillah 16b:

כִּי מׇרְדֳּכַי הַיְּהוּדִי מִשְׁנֶה לַמֶּלֶךְ אֲחַשְׁוֵרוֹשׁ וְגָדוֹל לַיְּהוּדִים וְרָצוּי לְרוֹב אֶחָיו לְרוֹב אֶחָיו {אסתר י׳:ג׳} וְלֹא לְכׇל אֶחָיו מְלַמֵּד שֶׁפֵּירְשׁוּ מִמֶּנּוּ מִקְצָת סַנְהֶדְרִין.

Rambam even appears to have a novel biblical reading based upon this assumption in the beginning of Hil. Teshuvah Ch. 3:

אדם שעונותיו מרובין על זכיותיו, מיד הוא מת ברשעו, שנאמר ״על רוב עונך״ (ירמיהו ל׳:י״ד). וכן מדינה שעונותיה מרובין, מיד היא אובדת, שנאמר ״זעקת סדם ועמורה כי רבה״ (בראשית י״ח:כ׳). וכן כל העולם כולו, אם היו עונותיהם מרוביןא, מיד הן נשחתין, שנאמר ״וירא י״י כי רבה רעת האדם בארץ״ (בראשית ו׳:ה׳):

The question is, how are these readings justified if the word "Rov" clearly means multitude?

Possible answers might be (1) there is at least one instance in Tanakh where the context indicates that the word must mean "majority" and cannot be interpreted otherwise or (2) in these particular instances, there is some other hint in the text that motivated these rabbinic readings?

[And yes I know that this question has some methodological assumptions that might not be universally accepted]

title: What is the source for Bitachon in the Torah?
content:
# What is the source for Bitachon in the Torah? ## Frage

The Chovos Halevovos's fourth שער, section, is on Bitachon. Since his sefer is "Duties of the heart", he clearly considers this a required "duty". Unlike some other areas, he does not have a sub-section where he gives the source for such a mitzvah.
There are many verses in Nach that do sound like they command Bitachon; some of them are at the end of Uva L'Tzion in the Shacharis davening.

בָּרוּךְ הַגֶּֽבֶר אֲשֶׁר יִבְטַח בה' וְהָיָה ה' מִבְטַחוֹ: בִּטְ֒חוּ בה' עֲדֵי עַד כִּי בְּיָהּ ה' צוּר עוֹלָמִים: וְיִבְטְחוּ בְךָ יוֹדְ֒עֵי שְׁמֶֽךָ כִּי לֺא עָזַֽבְתָּ דֹרְ֒שֶֽׁיךָ ה':

And more in Hallel:

יִ֭שְׂרָאֵל בְּטַ֣ח בה' עֶזְרָ֖ם וּמָגִנָּ֣ם הֽוּא׃
O Israel, trust in the LORD! He is their help and shield.

And many others.
But I don't think there is such a verse in the Chumash, and (as far as I know) it isn't listed as one of the 613 mitzvos. Is there a source in Chumash?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

According to the Semak, the source is the Mitzvah of Anochi: "I am the G-d your Lord who took you out of Egypt from the house of bondage." We are commanded to believe that just as Hashem saved us then, He can save us now.

title: Distinction of concepts איש ,בעל, and אדון
content:
# Distinction of concepts איש ,בעל, and אדון ## Frage

When referring to the modern Hebrew word for husband, we usually use בעל. However, Sarah in Bereshis 18:12 uses אדון. Also (thanks Double AA) Leah calls her husband איש. What is the difference between these concepts, and when do we refer to G-d as בעל, when אדון, and when איש?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Well, calling Hashem בעל would run into the obvious issue of that also being used as a name for an idolatrous deity.

Anyway, Malbim (Yeshayah 26:13) explains:

בעל מורה על הקנין שי"ל בגוף הדבר ולכן בא גם על דברים שאין בהם רוח חיים ובעל השור נקי, לא כן שם אדון, שעקרו על האדנות והגדולה

בעל refers to the ownership one has over the object, so it can be used even of inanimate objects, as in "the בעל of the ox is exempt."* Whereas אדון primarily means lordship and greatness.

* צע"ק that he first says "inanimate objects" and then brings an example with an ox. Perhaps he meant to say "animate but non-human objects."

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

Thanks to Sholom, we can also use Malbim on Hoshea 2:18:

והיה ביום ההוא נאום ה' תקראי אישי, שם בעל מורה על הממשלה והקנין שמושל על הדבר מפני שהוא שלו וקנינו, ושם איש מורה על האהבה והקורבה והאישות, ועד עתה שלא היה לה' קורבה עמהם, והשגחתו היתה נסתרת ומעוטפת במסך טבעי היו עובדים מצד היראה וקוראים לו בעלי מצד ממשלתו עליהם, שבזה יביטו לפעמים אל משרתיו אשר הם אמצעיים אל השפע המגיע להם מאתו על ידם וייראו ויכבדו גם אותם, אבל לעתיד יתהלך בתוכם ויתן להם ברכותיו מבלי אמצעי כאשר יתיחד איש עם אשתו, כמ"ש חז"ל ע"ז שתהיה ככלה בבית חמיה ולא ככלה בית אביה, כי יהיה מעונתו בעולם השפל לשכון כבוד בתוכם, ותקבל שפע האלהית פנים אל פנים, ותעבוד מאהבה ולא תירא ותכבד זולתו:

And in that day — declares G-D — You will call [Me] Ishi, and no more will you call Me Baali. The name בעל is refers to one's rulership and ownership, i.e. one rules over a thing (or person) because it (he/she) is his and acquired. The name איש refers to love and closeness of relation. Until this point, for Hashem there was no closeness with them, and His providence was hidden and wrapped in a natural veil. They worshiped Him out of fear and called Him בעלי because of His rule over them, so that in this way they would sometimes look at His servants (i.e. angels, etc.) who are intermediaries, through which people receive His abundance (שפע), and they would fear and honor these intermediaries as well. But in the future, He will walk among them and give them His blessings without intermediaries just like a man unites with his wife. As the Sages say, (Pesachim 87a) "Rabbi Yoḥanan said: She shall be like a bride in her father-in-law’s house, where she experiences a close relationship with her husband. And she shall not be like a bride still in the betrothal period and living in her father’s house, during which time her relationship with her husband has still not developed." It will be His time in the lowly world to dwell in honor among them, and she will receive the abundance of G-d face to face, and she will worship out of love, and neither fear nor honor anyone else.

Thus we see that בעל due to physical ownership prevents one from having freedom of choice, but אדון or איש grants his servants such a freedom.

title: "His resting place will be Damascus" - what is the meaning of this Midrash?
content:
# "His resting place will be Damascus" - what is the meaning of this Midrash? ## Frage

The Midrash Rabbah (Shir HaShirim Rabbah 7:5) expounds on the posuk: "and Damascus shall his resting place be" (Zecharyah 9:1) that Damascus will be "the resting place of Moshiach":

Another matter, Ḥadrakh, this is the messianic king who is destined to guide [lehadrikh] all mankind in repentance before the Holy One blessed be He. “Damascus is His resting place” (Zechariah 9:1). Is Damascus His resting place? But is His resting place not the Temple, as it is stated: “This is My resting place forever” (Psalms 132:14)? He said to him: Jerusalem is destined to expand on all its sides until it reaches the gates of Damascus, and all the exiles will come and rest under its auspices, to realize what is stated: “Damascus is His resting place,” His resting place will reach Damascus.

Why will Damascus be the resting place of Moshiach? Why does the Midrash teach us this and what is the deeper meaning behind the idea that this specific place will be the resting place of Moshiach (keep in mind the idea that Jerusalem will extend to Damascus, but that is not the question).

Any meforshim/seforim on this?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

To expand upon my comment above:

מלך המשיח as the one who will rule in Yerushalayim and build the mikdash is inherently connected to Yerushalayim/mikdash upon which the midrash says will extend their boundaries to דמשק.

Now why specifically דמשק?

Before we get into a deeper meaning behind the midrash, it is worth noting what the דעת מקרא on זכריה ט:א posits (based on a Radak there) - that Zecharia's נבואה happened at the time when עולי בבל were approaching דמשק on their way to ארץ ישראל:

So if this is correct, the midrash happens to be commenting on a נבואה that actually happened in the proximity of דמשק and was projecting what would happen in דמשק in the future.

I have noticed kabbalistic sources which delve into the significance of דמשק here, namely the ערבי נחל על פרשת לך לך (by רב דוד שלמה אייבשיץ) who states that in direct contrast to the מקדש there is a קליפה called דמשק which has the exact same letters as מקדש. See the link above and review the sections before and after my quote to get a better sense of what he is trying to say.

I have seen those who write that the אריז"ל mentions some connected ideas - see his לקוטי_תורה for more on that within his comments on זכריה ט:א

Also of interest:

  • The earliest one I have seen who noticed that דמשק is an anagram of מקדש is from over 800 years ago in the פירוש הרוקח על שיר השירים ז:ה - I wouldn't be surprised if this parallel partly inspired the words of the midrash
  • the original source of this midrash is in the earlier ספרי at the very beginning of Devarim
### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

No source, but I suggest that it's possible that the midrash is tying this verse to a tradition brought by Reish Lakish in Bavli Eruvin 19a that states that one of the possible locations for the entrance to Gan Eden was in Domaskanin (Damascus). This would explain why the Mashiach's resting place had to stretch from Yerushalayim to Damascus - so the Mashiach could reach Gan Eden.

title: Apparent contradiction in the Aruch Hashulchan regarding the laws of the morning blessings
content:
# Apparent contradiction in the Aruch Hashulchan regarding the laws of the morning blessings ## Frage

The Aruch Hashulchan (OC 47:16) asks how is it that one can fulfill the obligation of Birchas Hatorah by reciting the Brachah of “Ahavah Rabbah”, being that the main parts of a Brachah are the beginning and the end, and he goes on to explain the connection between the beginning and end of “Ahavah Rabbah” to Birchas Hatorah.

Now later on (OC 52:8) the Aruch Hashulchan writes that he does not know of any reason why one would not fulfill the obligation of the Brachah of “Matir Asurim” by reciting those words in the Brachah of “Mechayeh Hameisim”.

The question is: didn’t he write previously that the main parts of a Brachah are the beginning and end? if so, in this case, there doesn’t seem to be an apparent connection between the words “Matir Asurim” to the end of the Brachah of “Mechayeh Hameisim”?

P.S. thanks to @DoubleAA for bringing the second Aruch Hashulchan to my attention here!

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The blessing over the Torah is different from other blessings, because there's a mitzvah (Torah-level, according to all opinions according to the Aroch Hashulchan 47:2) to say a blessing before studying Torah, while the other blessings are general expressions of praise and thanks but not independent obligations. If you haven't fulfilled your mitzvah obligation, you still have to say it. But if it's just an expression of praise, you don't repeat a (rabbinic) blessing unless you're innovating something you haven't already said, and possibly even something that isn't somehow included by implication (as in 46:12 for שלא עשני blessings).

So (it seems to me), it doesn't matter how many times you mention the Torah in a blessing, as long as you haven't said a blessing on the Torah you still need to say it. That's why he has to prove that the beginning and end of the blessing are about the Torah, to prove that this is an actual blessing on the Torah, not one that mentions the Torah incidentally. For anything else, an incidental mention is enough of a reason not to repeat it.

A second possibility: Assume that the above principle (that the blessing needs to be on the Torah and not just mention the Torah) is doubtful (as indeed he does express doubt regarding whether the similar themes of the other blessings exempt each other, 52:8). Even calling this a doubt, you would still need to repeat the blessing over the Torah in a case of doubt, because it's a Torah-level obligation (47:6). Whereas for the other blessings, which are rabbinic, the guiding principle he mentions behind not repeating them as the rule ספק ברכות להקל, which only applies to the rabbinic blessings and not to the blessing over the Torah (46:12, 52:8).

title: Do evil people also have hope? (Tikvat reshaim)
content:
# Do evil people also have hope? (Tikvat reshaim) ## Frage

There is a concept in Shaar Gilgulim, that there are certain great but evil men, who have a great potential, but they are doing mostly evil due to the origin of their soul. However, since every soul/human has a holy part, they therefore usually do something very very good during their lifetime.

Some examples could be:

  • Bilaam, the evil magican (who blessed Israel)
  • The rebellious Korah (whose descendants were very righteous)

Etc. It was explained that (the soul part of?) Bilaam finally appeared later in a good incarnation (because he was overwhelmed by his good inclination at a critical moment).

The question is: does this explanation diminish the possibility of teshuva? Since if somebody has such a great soul but his soul is mostly from the evil side, that compels him to do great but cruel, immoral, etc. things. On the other hand, if somebody has a holy soul root he will do certainly good things, because that is his inclination by birth.

Did the explainations about the motivations of souls in Shaar HaGilgulim change the traditional rabbinic view about the scope of free will and the possibility to self refinement, after the spread of the teachings of Arizal?

I think these texts should change how we are viewing individual human life stories and human history as whole, and they raise a lot of questions.

title: Was Cain a Murderer?
content:
# Was Cain a Murderer? ## Frage

Is Cain a murderer or merely a manslaughterer? I ask because it would appear that his punishment is consistent with that of a manslaughterer based upon Numbers 35. He was 1. Exiled and 2. Protected from being killed for his crime. In the Mosaic Law the Cities of Refuge serve both as a place of exile AND as a safe-haven from the avenger of blood.

On the other hand, whether we consider the Noahide or Mosaic Covenants, the punishment for murder is death.

Of course, the Mosaic Law as such had not been given at this point in the narrative - but if we assume that God’s justice is consistent then there shouldn’t be a problem with using the Mosaic Law to analyze this situation.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

One consideration (from Yefeh Toar, Bereishis Rabbah 22:12) is that Cain simply didn't know that certain kinds of blows or injuries can kill a person; Abel was, after all, the first human being to die. So that does indeed reduce Cain's culpability to manslaughter.

There is also the point (in the Midrash, ibid. 22:13) that Cain repented. To be sure, that doesn't help when it comes to a human court punishing the criminal, but one reason for that is because they can't possibly know whether his repentance is sincere. But G-d knows, and since Cain's punishment was coming directly from Him, there could be room for leniency.

title: What kind of bird is כרום?
content:
# What kind of bird is כרום? ## Frage

In Brachos 6b it says

מאי כרום? כי אתא רב דימי אמר עוף אחד יש בברכי הים וכרום שמו. וכיון שחמה זורחת מתהפך לכמה גוונין

What is kerum referred to by Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar? When Rav Dimi came to Babylonia from Eretz Yisrael he said: There is a bird in the cities by the sea called kerum and when the sun rises, the bird changes several colors. Similarly, one who becomes dependent upon others blushes in embarrassment.

Is this Krum bird extinct or is this bird still around? If so, what is the Krum?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 9)

A possibility is that it refers to a bird known as the "Cinnyris osea" (Palestine Sunbird).

On the Daf-Yomi website, Rav Steinsaltz's commentary is quoted:

In Rabbi Steinsaltz's commentary on Berakhot, two African species of starlings with a variety of physical colors are suggested: the splendid starling (Spreo superbus) and the magnificent glossy starling (Lamprocolius splendidus), which resemble the Palestine Sunbird found in our region.

"Krum" might refer to the Greek word χρώμα and means "colour", which might refer to a colourful bird.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

According to Sefer haArukh al haSh"S with additions by R'Binyamin Musafia and edited by R'Meir Meizlish according to the order of Sh"S, Krum is a singing bird-of-paradise from the family of Paradisaeidae. Specifically, Raggiana bird-of-paradise has characteristically blushing color as noted by the gemara.

title: Where do the te'amim variants in Bereishit 48:20-22 in Simanim come from?
content:
# Where do the te'amim variants in Bereishit 48:20-22 in Simanim come from? ## Frage

I'm a relatively new baal keriah in the process of preparing Vayechi for next month. I happened to notice that the te'amim in my Tikkun Kor'im Simanim have a couple of slight variations that I haven't been able to find anywhere else.

In Bereishit 48:20, Simanim has:

וַיְבָ֨רְכֵ֜ם בַּיּ֣וֹם הַהוּא֮ לֵאמוֹר֒ בְּךָ֞ ...

And in Bereishit 48:22:

וַאֲנִ֗י נָתַ֧תִּֽי לְךָ֛ ...

But every other text I've checked - Mechon Mamre, SBL, a Hertz chumash, a JPS Tanakh, Sefaria - has revia instead of gershayim in verse 20, and gershayim instead of revia in verse 22. Simanim has a sidenote on verse 22 referring to a note reading "וַאֲנִ֞י [וַאֲנִ֗י] נָתַ֧תִּֽי לְךָ֛ שְׁכֶ֥ם", so its editors seem to be aware of a textual variation in that verse, although there's no similar note on verse 20 as far as I can find. (I'm not very good at interpreting masorah language, though.)

What is the source of these particular variations?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

The excellent Wikitext/Wikisource project "Miqra according to the Masorah (MAM)" maintains a detailed spreadsheet of all pesukim in Tanach with notes on sources of variants in letters, nekudos and trop.

In rows 1567 and 1569 of the spreadsheet's Torah tab, it contains details on בראשית מח: כ,כב where it wraps the words בך and ואני in curly braces containing terse notes indicating the source of each of the two versions of trop:

ַַּּיּ֣וֹם הַהוּא֮ לֵאמוֹר֒ {{נוסח|בְּךָ֗|2==א(ס),ל,ל1,ב?,ש,ש1,ק3,ו <גרשיים? אינו כן אלא ברביע>{{ש}}דפוסים=בְּךָ֞ (גרשיים)}} יְבָרֵ֤ךְ יִשְׂרָאֵל֙ לֵאמֹ֔ר

י {{נוסח|וַאֲנִ֞י|2==א(ס),ל,ל1,ב,ש,ש1,ק3,ו <רביע? אינו כן אלא בגרשיים>{{ש}}דפוסים=וַאֲנִ֗י (ברביע)}} נָתַ֧תִּֽי לְךָ֛ שְׁכֶ֥ם אַחַ֖ד עַל־אַחֶ֑יךָ

Using their page containing an abbreviation key which decodes all the symbols, we get that a version with בך\רביעי and ואני\גרשיים is upheld by the following sources (with "ב" marked with a ? - possibly since it could be difficult to discern which trop is being used there):

  • א(ס) = נוסח הכתר לפי הערותיו של יעקב ספיר
  • (B 19a) ל = כתב־יד לנינגרד
  • B 17 ל1 = כתב־יד סנקט פטרבורג, פירקוביץ
  • Or 4445 ב = לונדון, המוזאון הבריטי כתב־יד
  • ש = כתב־יד ששון 507
  • ש1 = כתב־יד ששון 1053
  • ק3 = כתב־יד קהיר 18
  • Ms. 882 ,ו = מוזיאון המקרא, ושינגטון

A visual example of one of these is a section of the Leningrad Codex with the relevant words highlighted:

A version with בך\גרשיים and ואני\רביעי is contained in "דפוסים" which would be one to many old printed versions of the Tanach. A listing of those that the MAM project uses can be found here. This would be the version used by the Simanim Tanach.

Here's a visual sample of one of the referenced דפוסים (this example taken from the one listed as מקראות גדולות דפוס נעטטער (Vienna, 1859)):

In the MAM pages referenced above, near each listing of manuscripts and printed versions there are often links to images and scans of the original source material if you want to dig further.

title: I have a question about the Hebrew Bible being trustworthy?
content:
# I have a question about the Hebrew Bible being trustworthy? ## Frage

I ask this because I’m a non-believer who wants to be a believer of G-d and his scriptures. The problem I’m having is that the Hebrew Bible was written mostly by unknown authors and the supposed authors only wrote half of the books, for example the book of Isaiah.

The book that Isaiah supposedly wrote only written half of it and the rest was written by 3 unknown authors and the Torah was mostly written by unknown authors.

Moses and Joshua only wrote a small part of the Torah and the other thing that’s odd is that the authors that wrote most of the Torah didn’t even knew Moses. What I’m asking is how trustworthy is the Hebrew Bible since it was mostly written by unknown authors and how should we trust what they wrote in the most holy of holy books?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

We believe that Moshe wrote the entirety of the Torah (with the possible exception of the last eight verses).

As for the books of the other prophets, we believe they were written by the prophets themselves or later prophets.

See Bava Basra 14b for a detailed list of each book’s authorship.

title: What kind of benefit is there in being allowed to tie woolen strings onto a linen garment?
content:
# What kind of benefit is there in being allowed to tie woolen strings onto a linen garment? ## Frage

The Midrash Tanchuma (Shemini 8:2) says as follows:

שֶׁלֹּא יַטְעֶךָ יִצְרְךָ לוֹמַר, שֶׁכָּל דְּבָרִים טוֹבִים אָסַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לְיִשְׂרָאֵל, אָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא, כָּל מַה שֶּׁאָסַרְתִּי לְךָ, הִתַּרְתִּי לְךָ כְּנֶגְדוֹ. כֵּיצַד, אָסַרְתִּי לְךָ דַּם נִדָּה, הִתַּרְתִּי לְךָ דַּם בְּתוּלִים. אָסַרְתִּי לְךָ אֶת הַדָּם, הִתַּרְתִּי לְךָ אֶת הַכָּבֵד שֶׁכֻּלּוֹ דָּם. אָסַרְתִּי לְךָ אֶת הַחֲזִיר, הִתַּרְתִּי לְךָ אֶת הַדָּג שֶׁשְּׁמוֹ שִׁבּוּטָא, שֶׁהוּא דּוֹמֶה לַחֲזִיר. אָסַרְתִּי לְךָ אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ, הִתַּרְתִּי לְךָ גְּרוּשַׁת אִישׁ. אָסַרְתִּי לְךָ נָכְרִית, הִתַּרְתִּי לְךָ אֵשֶׁת יְפַת תֹּאַר. אָסַרְתִּי לְךָ אֵשֶׁת אָח, הִתַּרְתִּי לְךָ יְבָמָה לְאַחַר מִיתָתוֹ בְּלֹא בָּנִים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: יְבָמָהּ יָבֹא עָלֶיהָ (דברים כה, ה). אָסַרְתִּי לְךָ כִּלְאַיִם, הִתַּרְתִּי לְךָ סָדִין בְּצִיצִית.

Lest your [evil] drive lead you astray, saying that the Holy One, blessed be He, has forbidden Israel from having good things, the Holy One, blessed be He, said, “Whatever I have forbidden you from having, I have permitted you to have [something] that corresponds to it. How is this? I have forbidden you menstrual blood; I have permitted you virginal blood. I have forbidden you [animal] blood; I have permitted you the liver, which is wholly blood. I have forbidden you the flesh of swine; I have permitted you the tongue of a fish with the name shibbuta, which resembles swine. I have forbidden you [another] man's wife; I have permitted you a man’s divorcee. I have forbidden a gentile woman; I have permitted a beautiful woman [captive]. I have forbidden you a brother's wife; I have permitted her for you after his death, with no children, as stated (in Deut. 25:5), ‘her brother-in-law shall have sexual intercourse with her.’ I have forbidden you mingled seeds, but I have permitted you a sindon with a woolen fringe.

Question: what benefit is there in being allowed to tie woolen strings onto a linen garment?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Wool absorbs dye far, far better than linen. Techelet doesn't just mean any-fabric-dyed-with-the-special-aquatic-blue, it means wool dyed that way.

So from a strictly halachic perspective, the only way to get the full mitzvah of tzitzis if one has a linen garment is to tie on techelet-dyed-wool strings.

I think that's really all there is to it ... but I suppose from a strictly aesthetic perspective, I imagine such strings add a splash of color.

title: Why are we allowed to wear tzitzis nowadays?
content:
# Why are we allowed to wear tzitzis nowadays? ## Frage

The Torah explicitly tells us that when we wear a (four) cornered garment it needs tzitzis and Tcheles. ״ועשו להם ציצית על כנפי בגדיהם לדרותם ונתנו על ציצית הכנף פתיל תכלת״ (במדבר ט״ו:ל״ג)

Since today we are uncertain about what Tcheles is, how are we allowed to wear tzitzis?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

Rambam mishnah Torah sefer ahava tzitzis ch. 1

Here the Rambam explains the mitvah tzitzis and techeles can be fulfilled independently of each other. If one does not have techeles then the white strings can be worn alone to fulfill that mitzvah. Similarly if one had both in their tzitzis but the white stings were somehow torn off so that only techeles remained you would still be permitted to wear them to fulfill the mitzvah of tzitzis.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

The mishna in menachot (38a) states that not wearing techelet does not hold back the mitzvah, and one who wears tzitsit without techelet will still fulfill the mitzvah of tzitit, although he will lack the techelet aspect of the mitzvah. Therefore those who do not wear techelet still fulfill the mitzvah of tzitsit which is why they wear tzitsit.

### Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

Kli chemda says in mitzvas tzitzis is lidoros (for all generations)and ticheles isnt ldoros (for generations, since it is destined to be lost)(based of drasha) therefore the aseh is more chashuv and it pushes off aseh of (not wearing) ticheles. Rav perlow says similar, that mitzvas tzitzis is more chashuv than ticheles, so it pushes it off. But according to the Mordechai that holds if one cant put on strings he doesnt have to take off beged since he's ones(accident) the question doesn't start.

title: How Were the Seven Nations 'Straight in His (God's) Eyes'?
content:
# How Were the Seven Nations 'Straight in His (God's) Eyes'? ## Frage

The very first Rashi in Torah states in part:

הוּא בְרָאָהּ וּנְתָנָהּ לַאֲשֶׁר יָשַׁר בְּעֵינָיו, בִּרְצוֹנוֹ נְתָנָהּ לָהֶם, וּבִרְצוֹנוֹ נְטָלָהּ מֵהֶם וּנְתָנָהּ לָנוּ: “He created it (the world) and gave it to whom was straight/fit in his eyes. When He willed, He gave it to them, and when He willed, He took it from them and gave it to us …”

It’s a quote that the Jewish people will tell/tells the nations of the world and it’s an idea based on Jeremiah 27.

The particular words וּנְתָנָהּ לַאֲשֶׁר יָשַׁר בְּעֵינָיו, are 'telling.' God only gives land, and in particular the land of Israel, to those who are ‘fit in His eyes.’ What was initially fit/straight in God's eyes about the inhabitants of Israel – the Seven Nations?

Obviously, only God knows.

Per the Radak (Genesis 10:11):

"ונתתיה לאשר ישר בעיני" (ירמיה כ"ז) והכל לפי מעשיהם כי הוא אל אמונה ואין עול.
and I give it to anyone I please (Jeremiah 27) - and all is based on their deeds because He is a faithful God with no perversion ...

There are lots of nations to choose from. But what of the propriety of God giving the Seven Nations the choicest place on earth?

The R"I B'chor Shor states on: Deuteronomy 32:8 בְּהַנְחֵ֤ל עֶלְיוֹן֙ גּוֹיִ֔ם בְּהַפְרִיד֖וֹ בְּנֵ֣י אָדָ֑ם יַצֵּב֙ גְּבֻלֹ֣ת עַמִּ֔ים לְמִסְפַּ֖ר בְּנֵ֥י יִשְׂרָאֵֽל׃ When the Most High gave the nations their inheritance, when he divided all mankind, he set up boundaries for the peoples according to the number of the sons of Israel.

ולא רצה להנחילה לשאר אומות שלא יערערו עליה, אלא מסרה לעבדיה⁠{ם} לבני כנען, שאינם יכולים לערער עליה כלום, דמה שקנה עבד קנה רבו (בבלי פסחים פ״ח:), ושמרו אותה עד שבאו אדוניהם ונטלום מידם (God) He did not want to give it (Israel) to the other nations because they would challenge upon it (Israel's right to possess it). Rather He gave it to their servants - the sons of Canaan. They would not be able to challenge it because what a servant acquired is acquired by his master. They guarded it until their masters came and took it from them.

However, מה שקנה עבד קנה רבו is not the whole story for then we would not need הוּא בְרָאָהּ וּנְתָנָהּ לַאֲשֶׁר יָשַׁר בְּעֵינָיו, בִּרְצוֹנוֹ נְתָנָהּ לָהֶם, וּבִרְצוֹנוֹ נְטָלָהּ מֵהֶם וּנְתָנָהּ לָנוּ

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The phrase might not mean that the recipient of the land is "straight", i.e. right, but it could mean that it is right to give it to that recipient. Admittedly, that's not a strong argument, but that question would be much more answerable; we have an explicit pasuk:

ודור רביעי ישובו הנה כי לא־שלם עון האמרי עד־הנה

But in the fourth generation they shall come back here, for the iniquity of the Emori is not yet full. [Koren trans.]

Hashem is telling Avram that the Benei Yisrael will only return to take the land after the 7 nations’ sin is great enough that they warrant destruction.

The various commentaries, such as Rashi and Ramban there, explain this to mean that Hashem won't destroy a people or strip them from a land unless they have a certain level of iniquity, some adding that that is because Hashem gives them an opportunity to repent (a classical Torah principle, brought by Chizkuni there).

One could argue that the "lack of iniquity" is functionally equivalent to "merit", but Rabbi Henkin does find some bona fide merit for some of the 7 nations:

פרוש אחר, אשכל ענר וממרא היו בני ברית אברהם ולכן זכותם היתה יתירה על זכות שאר ז' העממין

Another interpretation: Eshkol, Aner, and Mamre were allies of Abraham, and thus their merit was greater than that of the other seven nations

This was counted as merit towards them, according to Rabbi Henkin. It seems he is basing this on the advice that these nations (especially Mamre) gave advice to Avraham about circumcision for his Brit Milah (Bereshit 18:1, see Gur Aryeh and Siftei Chachamim there). Rabbi Henkin adds that this merit delayed the conquering of the land because Hashem wasn't going to give the land in stages, as each one of the nations reached their "measure iniquity" one by one, but rather waited until all of them were "full of iniquity", incuding these meritorious ones.

As we know, Hashem pays back good, even the small good of the wicked (see Ramban, Shaar HaGemul).

title: Pronouncing "kometz yod vav" (e.g., "אָיו__")
content:
# Pronouncing "kometz yod vav" (e.g., "אָיו__") ## Frage

Words like יראָיו and שערָיו, with a kometz vowel followed by yod and vav without any vowel, are pronounced "AHV" [or "AHW"] by everyone I know of - ignoring the yod's Y or EE sound. [There is someone in my family who learned Hebrew later in life and still finds this difficult, tending to end these words AYV.]
I was wondering:

  1. Does everyone pronounce it this way, and has that always been true?
  2. Are there any other examples in Lashon Hakodesh where a letter is completely ignored? I'm not asking about קרי and כתיב, I'm asking about standard spelling of Hebrew words that is not phonetic.
  3. If this is unique, what is going on? Why would we have exactly one non-phonetic structure in Lashon Hakodesh?

Update: @JoelK brought what I think is a very good similar example that I completely missed: segol yod chaf, like שערֶיךָ: shaarehcha, not shaareicha. Again the segol is the only vowel, and the yod seems to be ignored.
This seems to be the upshot of the comments: This sort of thing is more common than I thought.

title: Difference in meaning לָתֶת vs. לִתֵּן
content:
# Difference in meaning לָתֶת vs. לִתֵּן ## Frage

Before the early Sh'ma in Brachot, we say the paragraph beginning with (from the Sefaria Ashkenazic davening)

לְפִיכָךְ אֲנַֽחְנוּ חַיָּבִים לְהוֹדוֹת לְךָ וּלְשַׁבֵּחֲךָ וּלְפָאֶרְךָ וּלְבָרֵךְ וּלְקַדֵּשׁ וְלָֽתֶת־שֶֽׁבַח וְהוֹדָיָה לִשְׁמֶֽךָ:

some of my siddurim don't have the bolded word, but instead have what Sefaria has for Sefardic davening:

לְפִיכָךְ אֲנַֽחְנוּ חַיָּבִים לְהוֹדוֹת לְךָ וּלְשַׁבֵּחֲךָ וּלְפָאֶרְךָ וּלְבָרֵךְ וּלְקַדֵּשׁ וְלִתֵּן שֶֽׁבַח וְהוֹדָיָה לִשְׁמֶֽךָ:

but my siddurim have a mix of which word is used, regardless of being Askhenazic siddurim.

What might the difference be in meaning between the two (I would have thought the word was "v'lAtein")? What are the grammatical rules or textual precedents that would call for one over the other?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

According to the Academia of Hebrew Language for the verb נתן - give, the Biblical Hebrew and modern Ivrit form is לָתֵת. One can find this form in Bereshis 15:7, Devarim 10:18, Devarim 17:15 and many other places. It is also found in Aleinu prayer: לָתֵת גְּדֻלָּה לְיוֹצֵר בְּרֵאשִׁית.

The form לִיתֵן is Mishnaic Hebrew. It is found in Pirkei Avot 3:1, Bereshis Rabba 1:10 and other rabbinic texts.

title: What is the status of the Book of the Wisdom of Solomon?
content:
# What is the status of the Book of the Wisdom of Solomon? ## Frage

The Book of the Wisdom of Solomon is found in the Apocrypha and is used by a number of Christian groups. Notably, for our purposes, the Ramban quotes it in his introduction to his commentary on B'reishis. He says:

וְרָאִיתִי הַסֵּפֶר הַמְתֻרְגָּם הַנִּקְרָא חָכְמְתָא רַבְּתָא דִּשְׁלֹמֹה, וְכָתוּב בּוֹ: "וְלֹא מִמְּתֹם הֲוָת תּוֹלָדְתָא חֲדֵיתָא לְמֶלֶךְ אוֹ לְשַׁלִּיט דַּחֲדָיו מַעֲלָנָא דְּכָל בַּר נַשׁ לְעָלְמָא, וּמַפְּקָנָא שַׁוִּיאַת חֲדָיו מִיטוּל כֵּן צַלִּית וְאִיתְיְהִיבַת לִי רוּחָא דְּחָכְמְתָא, וְקָרֵית וְאָתֵית לִי רוּחָא דְּאַיְדַעְתָּא, צְבֵית בָּהּ יַתִּיר מִן שִׁבְטָא וְכָרְסְוָתָא". יֹאמַר, כִּי לֹא מִדָּבָר תִּהְיֶה תּוֹלֶדֶת מְיֻחֶדֶת לְמֶלֶךְ אוֹ לְשַׁלִּיט, אֶחָד הוּא בִּיאַת כָּל אִישׁ בָּעוֹלָם, וִיצִיאָה שָׁוָה לְכֻלָּם יַחַד, וּבַעֲבוּר כֵּן הִתְפַּלַּלְתִּי וְנָתַן לוֹ רוּחַ חָכְמָה, וְקָרָאתִי וּבָאָה לִי רוּחַ דַּעַת, בָּחַרְתִּי בָּהּ יוֹתֵר מִן הַשֵּׁבֶט וְהַכִּסֵּא.

Now I have seen the Aramaic translation of the book called The Great Wisdom of Solomon, and in it is written: “There is nothing new in the birth of a king or ruler; there is one entrance for all people into the world, and one exit alike. Therefore I have prayed, and the spirit of wisdom was given to me, and I have called out and the spirit of knowledge came to me; I chose it above scepter and throne.” (Charles B. Chavel translation)

What is the halachic/hashkafic status of this book?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Elsewhere Ramban himself addressed the question of why Wisdom of Solomon wasn't included in the Canon. In Drashat HaRamban al Divrei Kohelet (Schwartz ed., p. 9) he wrote:

"ומצינו עוד ספר שנקרא חכמתא רבתא דשלמה והוא בלשון תרגום חמור מאוד והגוים העתיקו[הו] מן הלשון ההוא ואני חושב שלא העתיקוהו אנשי חזקיהו מלך יהודה אלא ירד עמהם לבבל על פה ושם אמרוהו בלשונם כי היו חכמות ולא נאמר ברוח הקודש."

"And we find another book called The Great Wisdom of Solomon which is written in difficult Aramaic and the Christians have translated it from that language. I believe that this book was not arranged by the Men of Hezekiah, the king of Judah, but that it went with the Jews to Babylon orally and there they fixed it in their language, for it only contains sayings of wisdom and has not been written by inspiration." (translation from A. Marx, 'An Aramaic Fragment of the Wisdom of Solomon', JBL 40 (1921), p. 60).

So according to Ramban the book isn't canonical because it wasn't entirely written with Ruach Hakodesh and it was also written down much later than the Biblical Period, in Babylon. However, it does contain some real wisdom, which is why it can be referenced.

It should be noted that the book was mentioned in other Jewish works, such as Livnat Hasapir by Rabbi David b. Rabbi Yehudah Hachassid (e.g., here; and from there quoted by later authors such as Rabbi Avraham b. Eliezer Halevi, see e.g. here). Rabbi Azaryah dei Rossi thought that Wisdom of Solomon was originally written in Aramaic by King Shlomo without Ruach Hakodesh, to be sent to some far-off eastern (non-Jewish) king.

Interestingly, the Nodah be-Yehudah (Rabbi Yechezkel Landau) wrote in his haskamah to Naftali Hertz Wessely's commentary on Avot that though the Wisdom of Solomon was probably originally authored by King Shlomo, it had gone through so many translations and changes over the centuries that we no longer have it in its original form. Eventually Wessely went on to translate the book and print it, though notably he did not receive haskamot for that book.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

The Sanhedrin refused to include it in the Tanakh. Several reasons are possible. It was probably written in Greek, not Hebrew. It came too late (first century). It personified wisdom as the Egyptian "goddess" Isis.

title: Can a husband make a bracha on lighting Chanukah candles when away from home?
content:
# Can a husband make a bracha on lighting Chanukah candles when away from home? ## Frage

I understand that there are circumstances in which a husband traveling during Chanukah may rely on his wife lighting candles at home. But suppose the husband chooses to light anyway, in circumstances where his personal fulfillment may be questionable. E.g., suppose he is staying in a hotel, but will light in a Chabad House where he eats. Should he make a bracha given that he can certainly be yotze with his wife's lighting?

It seems to me that we commonly say the brachot over the menorah lighting under other doubtful conditions, e.g., in shul, so maybe the aspect of pirsumei nisa makes this different from other mitzvot, and the brachot are justified in any case. Or maybe the existence of a doubt regarding brachot is a reason specifically not to light candles if one can be yotze through one's wife! Has this question been addressed?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Chayei Adam (154:33) addresses this:

מי שיש לו אשה בביתו ויודע בה בודאי שתדליק פטור מלהדליק ומיהו י"א דעכ"פ חייב לראות את הנרות ולברך שעשה נסים ושהחיינו או שישמע מאחר ויענה אמן וגם י"א דאם ירצה להדליק מותר לו להדליק ולברך ואף לפי דעה זו לפי מה שמבואר לעיל דעיקר זמן הדלקתה הוא רק עד שתכלה רגל וידוע שהנוסעים לירידים נוסעים כמה שעות בלילה ולכן ראוי לכל י"ש להזהיר לאשתו קודם נסיעתו שתהיה זהירה בזה להדליק תיכף בצאת הכוכבים והוא יסמוך עליה ומכל מקום כשיבא לאושפיזא ידליק בלא ברכה ויהדר לשמוע הברכות ממי שחייב להדליק ויענה אמן ואם אין אחר עמו והוא בבית נכרי או שבא לאחד שכבר הדליק שם ידליק ויסמוך על הפוסקים דפטור מלברך ככל דין ספק ברכות להקל.‏

He starts off by mentioning an opinion that the traveler whose wife is lighting for him at home still has an obligation to see Chanuka candles, if possible, and make the 2nd - שעשה ניסים - Bracha. On the first night, he also says the first Bracha - שהחיינו.

He then mentions an opinion that if he wants to, he can light his own Chanukia and make all the Brachot.

The Chayei Adam then seems to prefer this solution: His wife lights as early as possible so that the traveler will have fulfilled his obligation by the time he wants to light. Yet he also should light, after hearing the Brachot from somebody who needs to make the Brachot. If no such person is around, then he lights without a Bracha.

title: What does שרית עם אלהים mean?
content:
# What does שרית עם אלהים mean? ## Frage

Last week's sedra. Yaakov was called Israel by the angel כי שרית עם אלהים ועם אנשים ותוכל.

There are some heretics who use this verse to mean that we are called the people of Israel cos we are able to wrestle with God and beat him ch"v. Afra lepumayhu.

(I could have thought that the word elohim refers to an angel, which is very apropos, considering he had just fought with the angel and with men (Lovon and Esov). Or it could be referring to God. The Targum clearly translates elohim as God. The simple reading of the posuk would seem to refer to elohim as in "the angel who he just fought with", no? Perhaps these heretics don't believe in angels.

It would seem to me that the posuk in Hoshea that Rashi brings, is more indicative of an angel. It says וישר אל מלאך ויוכל, which is an exact parallel of our posuk but replacing the word שרית for וישר which would seem to be the same word, as well as replacing elohim with hamalach.)

Regardless, if the posuk truly does refer to God as the targum says, then I have two questions:

  1. What is vatuchol (ותוכל)? Does that not denote victory? How could one be victorious against god?
  2. What does שרית mean? Translating it as "wrestling" is totally incompatible with god. The targum translates איתרברבת from the loshon of sorus (שרות) meaning lordship, grandness. In short, where do they get soriso (שרית) meaning "wrestling"? Is it just a play on words? Ris-res. Based off the vayeovek (ויאבק) which means wrestle.

Thanks

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

A number of meforshim (e.g, Rashbam, Radatz Hoffman) on that pasuk say that שרית derives from שרה, which means struggle, see https://mg.alhatorah.org/Dictionary/8280, which can lend itself to wrestle. Others (e.g., Ralbag, Seichel Tov) see it as deriving from שרר, which denotes supremacy, see https://mg.alhatorah.org/#!Dictionary/8323.

title: Difference between the participles הוּכָן and נָכוֹן
content:
# Difference between the participles הוּכָן and נָכוֹן ## Frage

There are several participles derived from the root כ־ו־ן.

The nifʻal participle נָכוֹן is used in Shemos 19:15, Isaiah 2:2, and Micah 4:1), where it is translated as prepared, correct, etc.

The hufʻal participle הוּכָן is used in Isaiah 16:5, Isaiah 30:33, and Zechariah 5:11, where it also translated into English as prepared.

I would have assumed that הוּכָן would be translated as a causative passive, but everyone seems to translate it as a simple passive like nifʻal.

What is the difference between these participles?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

As one can see from the cases in Tanach, the particple הוּכָן places emphasis on the act of preparation, which will cause readiness. By contrast, the particple נָכוֹן signifies the final result of readiness irrespective of one's preparation.

Examples for הוּכָן:

  1. Isaiah 16:5

And a throne shall be established (וְהוּכַ֤ן) in goodness in the tent of David, and on it shall sit in faithfulness a ruler devoted to justice and zealous for equity.

The focus is on the work of establishing the dynasty of David by acts of goodness, which we are supposed to do now.

  1. Isaiah 30:33

The Topheth has long been ready for him; he too is destined (הוּכָ֖ן) for Melech — His firepit has been made both wide and deep, with plenty of fire and firewood, and with G-D’s breath burning in it like a stream of sulfur.

The verse is stating that Topheth, a site near Jerusalem at which human beings were sacrificed by fire in periods of paganizing, is being destined (prepared) for service of the idol Molech. And even so, at the end that will be the place where G-d will execute the judgement. The focus is on the preparation, i.e. on what people do now for this final judgement even if there are societal pressures for idol worship.

  1. Zecharia 5:11

And he answered, “To build a shrine for it in the land of Shinar; [a stand] shall be erected (וְהוּכַ֛ן) for it, and it shall be set down there upon the stand.”

I.e. the focus is on erecting the stand.

Examples for נָכוֹן:

  1. Shemos 19:15

And he said to the people, “Be ready (נְכֹנִ֖ים) for the third day: [the men among] you should not go near a woman.”

I.e. do what one needs to do, but at the end of the 3rd day make sure to be ready.

  1. Isaiah 2:2

In the days to come, the Mount of G-D’s House shall stand firm (נָכ֨וֹן) above the mountains and tower above the hills; and all the nations shall gaze on it with joy.

I.e. the Mountain of G-d will be set established to a degree that nobody will recall how it was getting established.

  1. Micah 4:1

In the days to come, the Mount of GOD’s House shall stand firm above the mountains; and it shall tower above the hills. The peoples shall gaze on it with joy.

Essentially the same verse as Isaiah 2:2.

title: Why did G-D allow non Jews to be born in circumstances whereby they might never have heard about the Torah
content:
# Why did G-D allow non Jews to be born in circumstances whereby they might never have heard about the Torah ## Frage

According to Rabbi Ovadiah Yosef, non Jews cannot do complete Teshuva, instead their Teshuva only prevents negative judgement against them in

Furthermore, non Jews get punished for doing what they think is right without acknowledging the G-D of Israel and the Torah of Moses

[SOURCE: - Rabbi Yaron Reuven says that according to the Rambam a person goes to Gehinnom for doing a a righteous deed if he does not acknowledge that he is doing it because G-D told him to do it - and I assume that this should include the acknowledgement that G-D is the G-D of Torah revealed to Moses on Mt Sinai as Maimonides wrote in the Law of Kings ch. 8.11.]

In light of these, why would G-D create groups like Australian aborgines in periods of history when they had no chance of learning about the Torah? By doing, so wasn't G-D condemning them to Gehinnom without a test [as the culture and time period made access to the Torah a near impossibility], given that non Jews cannot reincarnate according to a question I read here (which cites a text called Minchas Yehuda by Rabbi Yehuda Hachayat... So we cannot say that such individuals are reincarnations of those that rejected the Torah, making their Teshuva difficult or impossible as a punishment)?

This would imply that certain non Jews were/are born in societies where knowing that righteousness for them consists of doing the seven commandments of Noah while knowing that G-D commanded them through the Torah of Moses is near impossible, and therefore Gehinnom for such individuals is guaranteed as they would follow their natural inclination to do good without knowing about the Torah.

This is seemingly against the infinite justice of G-D, and as for the reasoning that the nations are punished like that for the sin of having rejected or deviated from the Torah is that not punishing the descendants of the ones that rejected or introduced deviation, essentially against Rabbi Tovia Singer's claim that the innocent are not punished for the sins of the wicked?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

OP says:

In light of these, why would G-D create groups like Australian aborgines in periods of history when they had no chance of learning about the Torah? By doing, so wasn't G-D condemning them to Gehinnom without a test [as the culture and time period made access to the Torah a near impossibility]...

I answer:

The Gemara teaches in Avodah Zara 3a:

אין הקב"ה בא בטרוניא עם בריותיו

The Holy One, Blessed be He, does not play the tyrant against His creations.

In its broader context, the Gemara there is explaining why in the future, He will give the nations "one last chance" to do a mitzvah and gain reward, even though the general rule is that one can only do mitzvos in This World, not in the World to Come.

However, it seems to me obvious that if He is not a tyrant, then He must judge each individual human being in light of what He knows the real capabilities of that human being to have been. The more difficult it was for a given person to learn His Torah, the more leniently that person must be judged. Of course, this is a judgement that only He can ultimately make.

And as for the comments of Rav Ovadaiah Yosef, zatzal, to which you made reference, to the effect that the possibility of repentance is a matter of mercy and this mercy is reserved for Jews, I think this must be a reference to non-Jews who could have learned Torah and served Him knowingly.

But those who did not have such an opportunity, simple justice dictates dictates that they be held to a standard of behavior no higher than they could actually have maintained. Since this is not mercy, but justice, it stands to reason that this applies to non-Jews as well.

I should also note that Rav Yosef's interpretation is just one possible interpretation of the words of Chazal upon which he comments. I do not personally agree with his interpretation, but even so I am trying to answer the question "as it is," focusing on how Rav Yosef might respond if he were here with us.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

What R'Ovadiah may be referring to is a concept that complete teshuva is mastery over ones evil inclination such that one will never repeat the sin again. In that case, one's mitzvah of teshuva gains the absolute value of the sins one did. What you say he says non Jews get is just regular teshuva. Note that teshuva may be a mitzvah. As such, a non Jew can't get credit for performing it

https://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/4134855/jewish/You-Will-Return-to-the-Lord-Your-G-d-The-Commandment-of-Teshuvah.htm

As for Yaaron Reuben, he is known to be a hothead and even Rambam is a bit of a maverick and not for the weak-minded. We'd need to read him very carefully if he says people go to gehinnom for mitzvot without specific intent to serve God. We say "the ways of the Torah are pleasant". If someone likes matza and eats more than the minimum for enjoyment, he goes to hell? Does Sugihara, a Buddhist, go to hell for saving Jews in the Holocaust without thinking about Hashem as he frantically wrote his visas and throwing them from the train?

As for R' Tovia Singers assertion that people aren't punished for other's sins, he wants to disprove the notion that Jesus can't accept the sins of others. We know people do die for other's sins because of the plague that came when David counted the Jewish people or the descendants of Saul that the unrim vthumin said to hand over to the Gibeonites for execution because of a transgression of Saul.

But it could be that my objections are wrong and God has the world set up in a way we perceive to be unfair.

# Hashem only made things we are inclined to do into aveiras ## Frage

I have heard reference to a principle in shiurim, and my wife recently reminded me of it when she claims she heard it in a lecture by Rebbetzin Heller, for example. The claim is that Hashem doesn't ban "bad" things that we wouldn't do anyway, nor does He command "good" things we would do anyway.

E.g. women are supposedly not commanded to have children because they would anyway, and it's only men who would need a nudge in that direction. The same goes the other way around - if you see something forbidden and can't understand who would do such a thing, be assured that there are some folk born with a proclivity to it, so it had to be banned. If you can think of a "bad" thing that Hashem didn't ban, and are sure it's not a derivative of something else, then you can be sure that nobody would ever do that.

Is there an actual source for this principle? I've heard it claimed in Chassidus that every sin will eventually be done by someone somewhere, who will do teshuva for it. Not that we can do sins in the first instance (lechatchila), although I haven't seen the source for it in depth.

So, I would like any source, including the one I have heard from Chassidus, that anyone can find on this particular principle, please!

title: Why beg for mercy in the middle of the praise litany of the first benediction before Sh'ma?
content:
# Why beg for mercy in the middle of the praise litany of the first benediction before Sh'ma? ## Frage

The first portion of the first benediction recited before the morning Sh'ma praises God for having created astronomical objects. Versions vary among the different communities, and on the sabbath from weekdays, but one version is as follows; others are similar.

All will thank and praise you, and say there no one holy like God. All will exalt you forever, creator of everything. The god who opens the eastern gates every day, cleaving the windows of the sky, bringing the sun from its place and the moon from its settlement, and illuminating the entire world and its inhabitants, whom he had created with mercy. Who illuminates the world and its inhabitants with mercy, and who, in his goodness, renews daily and constantly the work of creation. The king, who alone is exalted from always, who is praised and exalted since forever. The god of the world, in your mercy, have mercy upon us, our strength master, our refuge rock, our salvation shield, our refuge. There is none like you and none but you, nothing without you, and who compares to you? There's none like you, God, our god, in this world; none but you, king, in the next; nothing without you, our savior, in the days of the messiah; and none to compare to you at the revivification of the dead. God, master of all creation, blessed by the mouth of all souls. His strength and goodness fill the world; knowledge and understanding surround his splendor. He is exalted over the chaya angels, honorably splendid over the merkava. Righteousness and straightness are before his throne; kindness and mercy fill his presence. Good are the illuminations that our god made; he formed them with knowledge, understanding, and intelligence; he put strength in them that they may control earth; they're full of glow, and give off glow; their glow is nice all over the world; they are happy when they rise and when they set, doing their creator's will with reverence.…

What is the boldfaced sentence doing there? ("The god of the world, in your mercy, have mercy upon us, our strength master, our refuge rock, our salvation shield, our refuge.") Why are we suddenly begging for mercy in the middle of a litany of praises?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Daniel Goldschmidt identifies several sentences like this in various brachos and suggests that they were added by people davening in an era before the tefilla reached as fixed a form as it has today. They eventually became crystallized as part of the tefillah.

For several other additions like this (though not this one), he points out a machlokes whether or not to say it. Some were eventually accepted and some were not.

title: Would a siyum the night before the fast of the first born count?
content:
# Would a siyum the night before the fast of the first born count? ## Frage

There is a custom to make a siyum the day of Erev Pesach so that the first borns who participate will not have to fast.

I have always seen that siyum done on the day itself. I would like to know if a siyum made the night before (ie the night of the 14th of Nissan) would count so that a bechor who participated would not have to fast on the subsequent day of the 14th.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

R. Elhanan Naftali Printz (Abhnei Derekh, vol. 14, p. 240) explores this topic as it relates to a physician that will be on duty:

A physician who has a shift that starts on the night of bediqath hames, may he before his shift starts (on the night of the 14th) make a siyum on a tractate and thereby be exempt from Ta'anith Bekhoroth, or is he obligated to fast (since in the course of his shift it is reasonable to expect that he will not be able to make a siyum)?

In the Shu"T Hawoth Yair (70) he writes that there is a din se'udath miswah on the day after a siyum masekheth, and the basis for his opinion is the se'udah that King Solomon made after Hanukath Beth ha-Miqdash (when he made a se'udah for 7 days), see there. In the Shu"T Minhath Yishaq (8, 45) he expresses doubt over whether bekhorim can make a siyum on the night of the 14th of Nissan (and see there where he raises difficulties against the Hawoth Yair), and his opinion is that seemingly a siyum cannot be done at the night, see there.

In the pamphlet be-Yom Hathunatho (R. M. Gross, in Sha'ar Maamarim) he draws on the sefer Shomer Emeth (Hilkhoth Lulabh ch. 669) a hint favoring the notion of a se'udah during the day that is after a siyum, one of the sources for a siyum masekheth is from the fact that the 15th of Abh was rendered a day of joy and the Rashbam explains that on that day they completed a great miswah, "that he who increases" explains the Rashbam is one who adds from the night to a different day, thereby increases the days of his life, etc. Which is to say that it shows that the completion of the 'abhodah [of cutting the wood for the mizbeah] was on the 14th, and by the 15th they were no longer cutting, the simhah was on the 15th, from here is a hint favoring the position of the Hawoth Yair the also on the day after a siyum there is a concept of se'udath miswah.

In the Shu"T Maharam Brisk (1, 133) he seeks to differentiate between one who is mesayem himself from those that were merely with him at the time of the se'udah. Which is to say that the mesayem himself when he completes the miswah he can rejoice at any moment and time of that day in which he completed the miswah and so anyway he can make the siyum at night. But those that didn't learn (rather they just joined together for the se'udah), they can join in on his joy in the happiness of Torah (i.e. in the se'udah they are making to honor the completion of Torah and miswah) but they cannot thereby exempt themselves from the obligation of Ta'anith Bekhoroth the next day. And similarly is brought down in the Shu"T Shebhet ha-Qehati (4, 45) and in the sefer Yesode Yeshurun (6, p. 50).

And I saw that it was written in the Shu"T wa-Yebharekh Dawid (1, 24) that if one completes a masekheth at night, he does not say Tahanun the next day. And it proves that a siyum at night exempts the day. And similarly is brought in the sefer Abhodath Efraim (Ch. 12, Hilkhoth Tahanun) and the author of the Shebhet ha-Qehati also notes this.

The sefer Yuma Tabha le-Rabanan (6, 16) writes concerning this "if one completes a masekheth on the night of the 14th, there are those that say he is exempt from the fast during the following day and it even exempts those that partner together with him for the [se'udah of the] siyum, and there are those that disagree, at a time of pressing need the one who is mesayem himself is exempt but not those that partner with him", and similarly is written in the Nit'ei Gabhriel (Pesah, sec. 2 43, 15). And see also in the sefer MiBeth Lewi (Pisqe Halakhoth mi-Beth Midrashi shel Shebhet ha-Lewi, ch. 76 note 2).

The law that emerges: A physician that has a shift that begins during the night of bediqath hames may before his shift begins (on the night of the 14th) make a siyum masekheth and thereby be exempted from Ta'anith Bekhoroth (however he is not able to thereby exempt others).

title: Derashos Chasam Sofer on הגבלת of Har Sinai
content:
# Derashos Chasam Sofer on הגבלת of Har Sinai ## Frage

In sefer Beirach Moshe Al HaTorah (Vol. 4, Bamidbar, Parshas Naso, p. 38), the Beirach Moshe of Satmar, Rabbi Moshe Teitelbaum quotes a Chasam Sofer in his Derashos Chasam Sofer about the Hagbalah of Har Sinai (Shemos 19:12). There, the Torah says:

And thou shalt set bounds to the people round about, saying, Take heed to yourselves, that you go not up into the mountain, or touch the border of it: whoever touches the mountain shall be surely put to death:

The Chasam Sofer is quoted:

מרן החתם סופר בדרשותיו לחג השבועות עמוד רפת כי מטעם זה הוזהרו ישראל בשעת קבלת התורה על מצות הגבלה שתי פעמים כי מקודם נאמר שמות יט י"ב והגבלת את העם סביב לאמר היינו הגבלה גשמית כפשוטו לצל ילכו בגופם אל ההר ושוב אחר כך נאמר שמות יט כ"א ויאמר ה' אל משה רד העד בעם פן יהרסו אל ה' לראו"ת והוא הגבלה רוחנית לצל יציצו בעין שכלם בעיון וחקירה עכ"ד

Maran the Chasam Sofer wrote in his Derashos for Shavuos (p. 286) that for this reason, the Israelites were warned about the mitzvah of setting boundaries (hagbalah) twice during the giving of the Torah. Initially, it is written in Shemos 19:12, 'And you shall set boundaries for the people all around, saying,' which refers to a physical boundary, as understood simply, so they would not approach the mountain with their bodies. Then later, it is written in Shemos 19:21, 'And the L-rd said to Moshe: Go, warn the people, lest they break through to gaze upon the L-rd,' which refers to a spiritual boundary, so they would not gaze with the eyes of their intellect through excessive investigation and inquiry. Thus concluded his words."

I checked online, but could not find this specific explanation in the writings of the Chasam Sofer. Does anyone know what the exact location is of this piece from the Chasam Sofer?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

This is found in Drashot Chatam Sofer vol. 2 p. 288a (bottom of first column).

title: Deciphering BHS Masorah parva
content:
# Deciphering BHS Masorah parva ## Frage

I'm trying to understand the critical apparatus of Psalm 94:19. I understand the final ﬥ refers to the word occurring only once as indicated in the Veteris Testamenti Concordantiae Hebraicae Atque Chaldaicae (see below attachment). However, my question deals in deciphering the Masorah parva before the hapax legomenon designation indicated the final ﬥ. According to the Solomon Mandelkern reference, the word defined as "cogitationes" occurs both in Ps. 94,19 as well as Ps. 139,23 and so it's technically not a hapax, which, I suppose, is elaborated by the Hebrew text in the margin, the reason for this inquiry. The second Hebrew word, "inward part , midst" (as defined in Brown-Driver-Briggs) is also found in

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

There are three Masoretic notes here, on three different words. They need to be read one at a time, and in order. The one you are reading refers to the word תנחומיך. The note on the word שרעפי actually says it appears twice (ב'), with a difference in vowels (שַׂרְעַפַּי here vs. שַׂרְעַפָּי there).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

As you indicated in your question, there are three masoretic notes on the side:

1) for the word שרעפי: the note ב חד פת וחד קמ indicates two (instances of this word), one with a patach (under the פ) and one with a kamatz (under the פ) - as you pointed out, the two instances occur here and also in תהלים קלט:כג

2) for the word בְּקִרְבִּי: the note יא indicates the eleven occurrences where this word/lettering occurs with the stream of vowels: shva, chirik, shva, chirik - one in דברים, one in יהושע, one in ישעיהו, one in ירמיהו, five in תהלים, two in איכה (there's also one instance of בִּקְרֹבַי with different vowels)

3) for the word תנחומיך: as you correctly indicated, ל means that this word only occurs once

You also might be interested in this nice listing from Mikraot Gedolot HaKeter which has a helpful breakdown for decoding the meaning of many of the masoretic symbols
