title: Har Sinai and the Kodesh HaKodashim
content:
# Har Sinai and the Kodesh HaKodashim ## Frage

In the sefer "Yad Avraham" by Rabbi Yechiel Tenzer (Makhshirin, p. 47 sv. אי אפשר לבית המדרש בלי חידוש), a Ramban is cited that says that Har Sinai, and the boundaries G-d set up, refer to the Holy of Holies.

I.e. boundaries referred to in these verses (Shemos 19:12-13):

And thou shalt set bounds to the people round about, saying, Take heed to yourselves, that you go not up into the mountain, or touch the border of it: whoever touches the mountain shall be surely put to death:

no hand shall touch him, but he shall surely be stoned, or shot through; whether it be beast or man, it shall not live: when the horn sounds long, they shall come up to the mountain.

Does anyone know where to find the quoted Ramban, comparing the mountain and its boundaries to the Holy of Holies, and if there are other meforshim that make this connection?

The sefer Yayin Yashan mentions the Ramban's introduction to sefer Shemos, but there he writes:

When they came to Mount Sinai and made the Tabernacle, and the Holy One, blessed be He, caused His Divine Presence to dwell again amongst them, they returned to the status of their fathers when the ‘sod eloka’ (counsel of G-d) was upon their tents and “they were those who constituted the Chariot of the Holy One.”

But this does not say that Har Sinai refers to the Kodesh HaKodeshim.....

title: Is every Jewish woman's ambition to be the mother of the Messiah?
content:
# Is every Jewish woman's ambition to be the mother of the Messiah? ## Frage

On the (primarily Christian) Biblical Hermeneutics Stack Exchange, an answer to the question "Luke 1:28 favored vs highly favored" claimed that:

And that is, it was every Jewish women’s ambition to be the ‘mother’ of the Messiah.

Is this true?

Possible duplicate: Was there a tradition that Jewish girls desired to be the mother of the messiah? (where the answer seems to be resoundingly no, this is not the case), but that question specified "the historical time period of the 1st century AD or earlier", while I am interested in the answer in any time period, up to and including today.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Not at all. According to the Bible, the future messiah will be a descendant of King David, so the vast majority of women who are not married to one of his descendants know they have no shot.

There is a tradition that there was a prophecy that the Jews would have a great leader named Samuel, so many women named their son Samuel in hopes that he would be that Samuel. But Samuel was never a messiah (literally "annointed one"), rather he anointed Saul and then David.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

It's not that she desires it, it's that she "knows" that he has the potential to be. She believes in him.

title: As an atheist, what should I read to understand Judaism?
content:
# As an atheist, what should I read to understand Judaism? ## Frage

I am an atheist (i.e., I'm not Jewish by birth or by conversation) but I would like to understand religious Jewish beliefs, and specifically, how Jews both historically and today interpret the Tanakh.

I am also particularly interested in how Jewish interpretations of the Tanakh differ from Christian interpretations of the Old Testament.

What books should I read to understand this better?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Try the Artscroll or Metsudah editions of Tanakh for the most faithful translations in modern vernacular. A great resource for the differences between Jews and Christians specifically is the work of Rabbi Toviah Singer.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Your question has three parts:

  1. I would like to understand religious Jewish beliefs
  2. specifically, how Jews both historically and today interpret the Tanakh
  3. how Jewish interpretations of the Tanakh differ from Christian interpretations

To address part two directly, and part one indirectly, I recommend you read a Chumash with translation, commentary, and notes. (Part three is beyond the range of my knowledge.)

The Chumash is the printed book version of the first five books of the Torah. Chumashim combine the Hebrew text of the Torah with niqqud (vowel marks) and cantillation marks. The text is separated into its 54 constituent weekly Torah portions (parashiyyot), together with the haftarah for each portion and commentary on the text. (Source: Wiki)

I recommend you read at least two different versions of the Chumash, with extensive commentary and references. These are not all used in Orthodox synagogues, but they do have extensive commentary and notes.

Reading more than one Chumash will give you perspective on thousands of years of Jewish commentary, exegesis, and analysis.

Three Chumashim are briefly described below. By reading two side by side you will get the most out of different translations and commentaries.

The Metsudah Chumash / Rashi (5 volumes, 1991) Commentary by Rash”i (Rabbi Shlomo Yitzchaki c. 1040 – 1105 CE) This contains Rashi’s complete commentary on the text of the first five books of the Torah. Its format is line by line translation of the text and Rashi's commentary, with notes that identify Rashi's sources and identify the textual difficulties Rashi wished to clarify. (Source: Metsudah publisher)

Soncino Pentateuch & Haftorahs (first published 1937) compiled and annotated by the late Chief Rabbi of England, Rabbi Dr. Joseph Hertz. “From 1936 to 1981, there was one book that united Orthodox, Conservative, and Reform synagogue goers: the Hertz Pentateuch.The English translation and commentary on the Torah by British Chief Rabbi Joseph Hertz 'for use in Synagogue, School, and Home' was a rhetorical masterpiece that melded traditional biblical interpretation with then-modern scholarship.” (Source: Soncino Publications)

The Steinsaltz Humash compiled and annotated by Rabbi Adin Even-Israel Steinsaltz (1937 – 2020), an Israeli Chabad Chasidic rabbi, teacher, author, translator and publisher. Rabbi Steinsaltz is famous for his translation of the complete Talmud into Modern Hebrew. “A one-volume English translation of the first five volumes of Rabbi Steinsaltz’s Hebrew commentary on the entire Tanakh (Hebrew Bible).” (Source: Daily Forward)

### ✅ Antwort 3 (Score: 0)

The Talmud is a snapshot of how specific elite Jews recorded their thoughts on certain topics for other scholars. While you can see glimmers of the underlying society and how the Rabbis governed the people, it's not the main focus. Jewish practice and thought today is shaped by so much that came after the Talmud, the Talmud isn't so relevant for your goal.

I've seen the Koren Talmud and it is really nice with lots of elucidation, maps, charts, and pictures but the catch with easy to read material is that modern sensibilities and dogma can be projected backwards on the original source material. It has Steinsaltz's commentary.

I recommend this book: There We Sat Down by Jacob Neusner. But beware! It comes from an era when the best scholarship came from non-Orthodox Jews and may contain info that the Orthodox may not accept.

title: Does hair have any association with tumah like nails do?
content:
# Does hair have any association with tumah like nails do? ## Frage

For example, trimming one's hair and leaving the trimmings outside. Does the trimmed hair have a similar status to that of trimmed finger nails in regards to tumah?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Mishna Ohalos 3:3 says explicitly:

Every part of a corpse is unclean except the teeth, hair and nails; But when they are joined [to the corpse], they are all unclean.

Gemara Nidah 55a explains:

Everything that is in a corpse transmits impurity, except for the teeth, and the hair, and the nails. This is the halakha only when these items are separated from the body, but when they are attached to the corpse they are all impure. According to Rabbi Yoḥanan teeth should transmit impurity because they are similar to bones, while according to Reish Lakish they should be included in the term “from any.”

Rav Adda bar Ahava said: Only items that are similar to a bone transmit impurity: Just as a bone is an item that was created with him at the time of birth, so too, all items that transmit impurity are those that were created with him, whereas teeth are not present at the time of birth. The Gemara asks: But are there not the cases of hair and nails, which were created with him, and yet the mishna states that they are ritually pure?

While the Gemara continues with its shakla v'tarya, Rambam, Sefer Tahara, Hilkhos Tumas Meis 3:13 gives his psak as in the mishnah:

Every element of a corpse is impure with the exception of the teeth, the hair, and the nails, for they are replaced. While they are attached to the body, they are all impure.

What is implied? When a corpse is outside a house and his hair which is attached to his body is inside, everything in the house becomes impure. Similarly, one who touches hair, teeth, or nails while they are attached to a corpse becomes impure. When the hair of the deceased was ready to be cut or his nails were ready to be trimmed, their halachic status is in doubt because they are prepared to be cut off. Therefore, one who touches them is considered as ritually impure because of the doubt.

In other words, even if a nail is attached to a detached finger or hair attached to a part of a detached head, or a tooth to a jawbone - they transmit tumah upon touching as the limbs themselves transmit tumah. However, detached hair, nails, or teeth do not.

Finally, according to Kitzur Shulchan Arukh 3:9, one should wash one hands after cutting ones hair or one's nails because of spirit of impurity as a result of cutting (as stated in the footnote in the R' Eliyahu Touger translation).

title: Examples where different pronunciation changes the meaning of what you’re saying?
content:
# Examples where different pronunciation changes the meaning of what you’re saying? ## Frage

The Talmud emphasizes the importance of proper Hebrew pronunciation while leading the community in prayer.

“One may not allow people of Beit She’an, Beit Haifa, or Tivonim to pass before the ark, because they pronounce alef as ayin and ayin as alef.” (Megillah 24b)

Rashi brings down that these people blemish their prayers by confusing these two letters. He brings the example of יאר ה׳ פניו אליך, and how changing יאר to יער changes the meaning of the blessing to that of a curse.

“If they perform Birkat Kohanim, instead of saying יאר ה׳ פניו אליך (May the Lord shine his countenance upon you), they would say יער ה׳ פניו אליך (May the Lord arouse his face toward you), and this is the language of a curse. We see that the word פנים (face) can be conveyed as an expression of anger, as in פני ילכו (Exodus 33), and את פני (Leviticus 20), which Onkelos translates both as “my anger”. Thus, they turn alef into ayin, and blemish their prayers.”

Rashi brings this one example, but are there any others? Other examples don’t have to be alef and ayin, they could be hey and het, khaf and het, tav and tet, and so forth.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

This is the kind of question that may have many examples. Here are some that I heard of:

  • Those who do not pronounce ה and pronounce Cholam like “oy”, can replace the word אוהב in the phrase אוֹהַב עַמוֹ יִשְׂרָאֵל with the word אוֹיֵב, right before Sh'ma.
  • Those who confuse ח and ה can say חלל for הלל and vice versa.
  • Those who do not pronounce ע, instead of בּכָל עֵת וּבְכָל שָׁעָה say בּכָל אֵת וּבְכָל שֹׁאָה in Sim Shalom of Shemoneh Esrei
  • Ashkenazis pronunciation turns לְתַקֵּן עוֹלָם into לְסַכֵּן in the 2nd paragraph of Aleinu.
  • Those who do not distinguish צ and ס can mispronounce צֶדֶק and סֶדֶק
  • Due to the fact that voiced consonants next to voiceless ones become voiceless, and the voiceless consonants next to voiced ones get voiced (a phenomenon in some Slavic languages), Mishnah Berurah in the laws of Kaddish asks to be careful in saying יִתְגַּדַּל as many people say יִתְכַּדַּל (like a poor).
  • Same rule regarding לְמַעַן תִּזְכְּרוּ instead of תִּשְׂכְּרוּ (profit) in the 3rd paragraph of Sh'ma

Perhaps, someone could write a computer program for words in the Siddur and Tanach and identify all cases that people are likely mispronounce based on the rules suggested by OP and the one given here. In addition, it will be good to have a feature to identify tricky words with omitted consonants or mispronounced vowels as suggested by @Chani in the comments (there are many more).

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

One of the most common mispronunciation is in the 4th ברכה of ברכת המזון where they say Boreinu = our pit, instead of Bore'einu = our Creator.

The above example of לתקן עולם, also applies in אמת ויציב where it says ומתוקן

### Antwort 3 (Score: 1)

An addition to previous answers, a bit funny but true example is, שיר השירים which is supposed to be pronounced as Shir HaShirim which literally means song of songs, one can mispronounce it as Sir haSirim which means, pot of pots. I saw this originally in the halakha ubeagada of Rabbi Shalom Naki

also, כל השונה הלכות meaning all who says at halachot will have a place in olam haba, is to be pronounced Shone and not sone, which means hate, "All who hate halachot will have a place in olam haba", very strange.

title: Understanding the phrase halacha l'Moshe mi'Sinai
content:
# Understanding the phrase halacha l'Moshe mi'Sinai ## Frage

I am trying to understand the phraseology of the term halacha l'Moshe mi'Sinai, specifically why the word Sinai is used, rather than Hashem. There are certain sages who hold that not every part of the Oral Law was given at Sinai (some were given in the Plains of Moab) so I assume that (at least according to these opinions) the word Sinai is used colloquially to really mean any time after the Exodus and before Moses died.

Furthermore, using the phrase halacha l'Moshe m'Hashem would seem to me to be more accurate, and forcefully underlining that the Oral Law was equally transmitted by God to Moshe.

Do any commentaries explain the phrase halacha l'Moshe mi'Sinai and specifically the emphasis on Sinai as opposed to Hashem?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Here is how Hakham José Faur explained it in the Horizontal Society:

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

In the Gemara, rabbis try to find hints or references in the Torah to the specifics of a law. Sometimes there is a detail that is definitely part of the tradition but they can't find an allusion to it in the written Torah. It therefore must have been a standalone detail given to Moshe along with the things that are written in the Torah.

We specifically say "Sinai" lest anyone come and say there were multiple revelations and that another prophet could come along with new laws.

title: Mishneh Torah Editions: Mifal Mishneh Torah OR Steinsaltz Mishneh Torah
content:
# Mishneh Torah Editions: Mifal Mishneh Torah OR Steinsaltz Mishneh Torah ## Frage

How does the Mifal Mishneh Torah compare to the Steinsaltz Mishneh Torah?

  1. What are the advantages and disadvantages of each edition?
  2. Which edition is more accurate?
  3. Do any of you have experience learning with both editions? If so, which one provides a clearer explanation of the Mishneh Torah?
  4. Which edition is more conducive to a daily study program?
## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I own both editions and learned from them. They both are beautifully produced, clearly typeset, and have made significant efforts to correct many of the mistakes that crept up in older editions. I do not know if one is more accurate than the other but doubt it is meaningful.

The Steinsaltz/Koren edition has a biur which explains complicated words and a very useful piskei v'shitot section which brings references to Shulchan Aruch (more rarely other texts, e.g., Aruch Hashulchan) and their psakim, sometimes references to the gemara. It includes the Raavad in normal-sized font as well. Each book is relatively thick and heavy but beautifully produced as everything Koren does.

The Mifal Mishne Torah exists in "brochure" format which makes it easier to transport/learn during travel, has a similar section explaining unclear words, and its particularity is that it uses other locations in the Rambam to explain them (i.e., it uses the Rambam as a commentary on the Rambam).

None of these editions bring the traditional commentaries, e.g., Kesef Mishne, Magid Mishne. As such they help understand the text but don't delve into its meaning.

I personally prefer the Steinsaltz edition when learning at a desk (because of the additional halacha section) and the Mifal MT if I want to take it somewhere.

title: Why did God Punish the Men of the Concubine of Givah for the Idol of Micha? God Exonerated Micha for Reasons That They Knew of!
content:
# Why did God Punish the Men of the Concubine of Givah for the Idol of Micha? God Exonerated Micha for Reasons That They Knew of! ## Frage

Sanhedrin 103b:

בִּקְּשׁוּ מַלְאֲכֵי הַשָּׁרֵת לְדוֹחְפוֹ אָמַר לָהֶן הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא 'הַנִּיחוּ לוֹ שֶׁפִּתּוֹ מְצוּיָה לְעוֹבְרֵי דְּרָכִים' וְעַל דָּבָר זֶה 'נֶעְנְשׁוּ אַנְשֵׁי פִּלֶגֶשׁ בַּגִּבְעָה אָמַר לָהֶן הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא 'בִּכְבוֹדִי לֹא מְחִיתֶם עַל כְּבוֹדוֹ שֶׁל בָּשָׂר וָדָם מְחִיתֶם

The ministering angels sought to dismiss him (Micha) from the world. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to them: Leave him, as his bread is available for travelers. And it is for this matter, the sin of Micah’s idol, that the people involved in the incident of the concubine in Gibeah were punished. The tribes of Israel waged war with the tribe of Benjamin and forty thousand of them were killed. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to them: You did not protest for My honor and took no action to destroy Micah’s idol, but you protested for the honor of one of flesh and blood who was killed? Therefore, the other tribes were initially unsuccessful, and many of their soldiers were killed.

The Maharsha:

ועד"ז נענשו כו'. ר"ל שזה הדבר שהיה פתו מצויה לעוברי דרכים הטעה את אנשי ישראל במעשה פלגש בגבעה שלא מיחו במיכה ובאו לעונש כזה שנפלו מהם מ' אלף

Meaning that this matter that 'his bread is available for travelers' misled the Men of Israel in the matter of the concubine of Givah in that they did not protest against Micha and thus they came to the punishment of losing 40,000 men.

There is an obvious question - If God exonerated Micha due to 'his bread is available for travelers' and told the angels to let him be, why would God exact punishment from Israel who were also aware that Micha's bread was available for travelers and thus let him be?

Two solid approaches have come to my attention:

a. God can waive God's honor, but humans cannot waive God's honor (even if mitigating circumstances - 'his bread is available for travelers'- are involved). It's God's call to decide if a merit will mitigate against an act that violates His honor. This is NOT our call to make.

b. It's the inconsistency that's the problem. They took a casual approach to God's honor - emulating God's approach - but became interventionist and angry in the face of a human atrocity (that could have been handled differently). Something we can call selective tolerance/vigilantism. In other words, they failed to search for alternatives/mitigating circumstances during Pilegesh B'givah!

Are there other answers?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

R' Gershon Weiss in the book Shimshon's Struggle. The Era of Shoftim: Pesel Micha, Pilegesh b'Givah gives another reason after suggesting inconsistent behavior of the tribes (your item b.) on pp. 298 - 300. He writes:

Although the action of "removing evil from Yisrael" was good, the people carrying out the action were not good enough. The Bnei Yisrael considered themselves perfectly righteous and thought that the Benjamites were not. They demanded that (shevet) Binyamin deal with Pilegesh b'Givah when they themselves had failed to deal with the Idol of Michah. Before undertaking to purify Binyamin of its sin, the Bnei Yisrael should have purified themselves of their own sins. As it is said in Yalkut Me'am Loez (no exact location given):

Whenever a person criticizes, rebukes, or punishes another for some misbehavior, Hashem checks the first person's record to see whether he himself has behaved properly.

title: Where can I find the Shivat Tzion Tiklal
content:
# Where can I find the Shivat Tzion Tiklal ## Frage

I am trying to find a Yemenite Shivat Tzion Tiklal to buy, but there are a very limited number of results on Google. Can anyone help me find it?

I want to find a source to the oldest, least changed or updated version of prayer, in a Yemenite rite. If you think that the Yemenite Shivat Tzion Tiklal is not the siddur I should search for, can you give me tips on what to look for?

Thank you.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

This answer includes material I wrote in the comments above:

The תכלאל שיבת ציון was published in 1952 and has been out of print for more than half a century. If one wanted to procure this three volume set their best bet would probably be at a second-hand/used seforim store in Israel. It is possible to come across it intermittently through used online book-sellers but unless you happen to come across the listing at the right time/place, chances are fairly slim that you will be able to find it.

Within Yemen there were different regionally based nushaoth in circulation, the two main distinctions being between Baladi and Shami. Based on your request, you seem to be more interested in the nusah Baladi. R. Qafih's tiklal Shibhath Sion (תכלאל שיבת ציון) within the Baladi nusah was intended to be somewhat accomodationist in order to appeal to a broad base of Baladi users, and defers slightly more to the Maharitz than the Rambam. His later Siah Yerushalayim (שיח ירושלים) leans slightly more towards the Rambam in its representation of the Baladi nusah - this being in line the tradition of the Dardai community from which he came.

It can be debated which is more representative of "the oldest, least changed or updated version of prayer, in a Yemenite rite." R. Qafih (who put together both versions) would say that the Siah Yerushalayim is a more faithful representation of the earliest versions of the Yemenite (Baladi) nusah. He was of the view that the Rambam directly drew his siddur from the Yemenites, therefore in composing Siah Yerushalayim in a manner that draws back on the Rambam he sought to re-align nusah Baladi with its earliest strains.

The Siah Yerushalayim is a six volume set and is more readily available, with various online peddlers carrying it. The most direct would be through net-sah.org. You will probably have to correspond with them to arrange for shipping to Europe (if I recall correctly Vered is the person you will want to speak with, she is very helpful).

title: Are there any Torah sources for raising children with a close relationship to grandparents?
content:
# Are there any Torah sources for raising children with a close relationship to grandparents? ## Frage

I teach a class on chinuch habanim and would like to address this topic. Although I know there is tremendous value in general to children having a relationship with grandparents, I couldn't seem to find anything about it in Torah sources.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

There's a lot to say about the relationship to Torah that a grandfather has to his grandchild...

A grandfather is obligated to play a role in educating his grandson in Torah study. The Gemara in Kiddushin 30a relates how the grandfather of Zevulun ben Dan took pains to teach him halacha, gemara, mishnah, chumash and aggada. Such action is no small feat, and clearly underlines the importance attributed to a grandfather’s position in chinuch. Whilst learning in such depth with one’s grandson is perhaps harder to accomplish these days, every grandfather must endeavour to maintain an avid interest in their grandson’s talmud torah. This obligation is famously derived from the words:

"והודעתם לבניך ולבני בניך"

“You shall make them known to your sons and your grandsons” - Devarim 4:9.

Indeed, such is this commitment to teaching Torah to one’s grandson, that chazal view it upon doing so, as if he had personally received the Torah from Har Sinai.1

This idea is illustrated beautifully by the following story related in the Yerushalmi Shabbos 1:2. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi had the practise to review everything that his grandson had learnt with him every erev Shabbos. One week he forgot his usual undertaking, and instead made his way to the bathhouse in preparation for the coming Shabbos. Upon his arrival he realised his mistake, and instead of washing, quickly clothed himself and returned to learn with his grandson. His student Rav Chiya, witnessed the turn of events and questioned his Rebbi’s actions. Previously they had learnt that if a person were to go to the bathhouse and undress, and then remembers that they have not yet davened, one does not need to don his clothes again. Rather one may bathe first and can then go to daven. If this is so, why did Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi feel the need to swiftly return to his grandson without having first bathed himself? Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi duly responded that listening to the words of Torah from his grandson is like hearing it directly from Har Sinai.

Rabbi Boruch Ber Lebowitz זצ"ל sums up in a most clear-cut and succinct fashion. He notes authoritatively:

"שהחיוב הוא על כל איש ואיש מישראל לראות שבנו ובן בנו יהיו לתלמידי חכמים וגאונים בתורה שנאמר ושננתם לבניך"

“There is an obligation on each and every Jew to see that his son and his grandson become great Torah scholars as it says ‘And you shall teach it to your children’”.2

One cannot maintain a nonchalant approach to their children and grandchildren’s spiritual development. It is a task that lies with both a father and grandfather to ensure that their progeny are receiving a suitable and effective Torah education. Through the correct schooling and choice of yeshiva, a child will begin to start realising their potential. This overarching obligation must remain at the forefront of one’s priority, and must not be compromised. In fact, such is this responsibility, that some poskim mention that even the grandfather must help to fund a child’s tuition fees.3

1 Kiddushin 30a writes, "אמר רבי יהושע בן לוי כל המלמד את בן בנו תורה מעלה עליו הכתוב כאילו קבלה מהר סיני" – “R’ Yehoshu ben Levi said: Anyone who teaches his grandson Torah it is as if he had personally received [the Torah] from Mount Sinai”. The גמרא goes on to relate two stories of Amoraim who embodied this commitment to furthering the Torah knowledge of their grandsons.

2 See תשובה לרב אחד באשכנז בדין מצוות לימוד התורה – ברכת שמואל, קידושין, סימן כז

3 Shach, YD 245:1. Also note Shu"t Rabbi Akiva Eiger, Siman 42 - 'ברכת להכניסו ביתום'. R’ Akiva Eiger notes down in the name of the Kessef Mishnah the following:

"ועיין בכ"מ הל' ת"ת (פ"א, ה"ב) דמחויב אפילו לשכור מלמד ללמוד עם בן, וא"כ להכניסו שייך יותר על אבי האב"

“And over there in the Kesef Mishna Hilchos Talmud Torah (1:2) [it states] that one is obligated even to hire a teacher to learn with the son, and if so, how much more so is it fitting that the grandfather enter into this obligation”.

title: Why does each page of Talmud end with the first word of the next page?
content:
# Why does each page of Talmud end with the first word of the next page? ## Frage

Within a perek, the central text of the Gemara/Mishnah ends with the first word of the next daf. For example, yesterday's daf ends with שנאמר, the first word of today's.

Why?

I've heard someone state that it's to make sure no pages are lost, but that concern applies to any other text as well, and I don't know of other texts that do this.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 16)

These are called catchwords and as you said they are an error catching device to make sure all the pages go in the right order when being bound. They were common in many manuscripts and printed works a few hundred years ago.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 5)

Perhaps the duplication of a word gives the reader a brief time to turn the page without breaking stride.

title: A rabbi takes a boat ride home
content:
# A rabbi takes a boat ride home ## Frage

A Jew travels on boat from his location to his home.

The boat is scheduled to arrive to the destination the day before Shabbat. All passengers were required to pay an equal amount. The money was allocated to boat amenities, meals, maintenance, crew labor, and any construction materials used during the voyage.

The disembarking destination requires a very tall ladder to get from the boat to the dock. The boat had a sufficient ladder when it departed.

While in route, there was a storm, and the boat’s ladder was damaged beyond repair. The storm also delayed the boat’s arrival to Shabbat.

On Shabbat, the boat crew constructed a new ladder using only the materials paid for by the passengers.

What methods of disembarking may the Jew use?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

I fear you've missed the point entirely here. The issue is techum shabbos -- how far you can travel (even by walking with nothing in your pockets) outside of a city.

If at the start of Shabbos the ship was more than a mile from shore, then this Jewish fellow -- man, woman, ordained -- doesn't matter! -- then they're not allowed to disembark upon arrival. Even if the ladder was pre-set and all of that stuff.

If there is absolutely no way to safely remain on the ship, then he should disembark and then remain in the nearest building for the rest of shabbos. Tel Aviv Airport is actually set up for exactly this scenario. (Well, a delayed flight rather than a ship, but the concepts are all the same.)

If somehow the ship was traveling along a heavily-populated coastline and was very close to a city at the time shabbos started (or they arrived before shabbos started but somehow the crew to unload them didn't show up till after shabbos), then he or she may simply disembark using the ladder. The fact that the ladder wasn't available at the start of shabbos is a moot point. It may be muktzeh, but the prohibition of muktzeh is on moving items. And one would hope that the crew has secured this ladder quite well before any passengers climb down.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 1)

In Yalkut Yosef כרך א חלק א Page 323 it says:*

If a ship arrives at the port on Shabbat, if the ship was sailing above ten tefachim from the seabed, there is no issue of techum Shabbat. Therefore, when the ship arrives at the port, passengers are permitted to disembark on Shabbat using a ramp prepared for non-Jewish passengers. If the ship is anchored far from the port in open waters, it is permissible to transfer to shore via a small ferry, provided that most passengers on the ferry are non-Jews. However, one may not bring their personal belongings off the ship except through non-Jews, with the understanding that they will be compensated after Shabbat. If the ship sails within ten tefachim of the seabed for a distance of 960 meters, the passenger would have violated techum Shabbat, and they are prohibited from disembarking until Shabbat ends. The exception is if the ship continues sailing, in which case the passenger may disembark and remain within the port area. It is permissible to hand over one's passport to a non-Jewish official for stamping and permission to enter the port, as the non-Jew is performing the action for their own needs and as part of their regular job. Furthermore, the passenger would not be allowed to remain in the port area without having their passport stamped."

*It's important to note that in this halacha in Yalkut Yosef there is a very big footnote and over there he brings many other poskim who basically say the same.

Therefore in this case, if the boat was truly over 10 tefachim above the sea bed there is no problem of techum Shabbat, and one can have a non-Jew take his stuff for him. If it's not 10 tefachim one would need to stay on the boat unless the ship is going to another destination.

If it is a cruise:

In most cruise ships, it is hard to disembark the ship without using a magnetic card, which makes leaving the ship and returning to Shabbat difficult. In any such case, it is necessary to know the details but I would assume that one can use a non-jew to swipe the magnetic card for him and if not swipe the card בשינוי.

With regards to the ladder that was built on Shabbat:

In Yalkut Yosef it says that as long as the ramp was prepared for non-Jewish passengers one can use it. I would assume that in this case, the ladder is not just being built for this Rabbi but also for all the passengers with him, and it would be allowed. If it was only built for him (which would seem very theoretical) that's a separate question, and I also don't understand how everyone else would get off as well.

Hope this helps :)

title: Are non‐moving animals (like oysters) included in Bereshit 9:3?
content:
# Are non‐moving animals (like oysters) included in Bereshit 9:3? ## Frage

I want to determine the extent to which Bereshit 9:3 permits Noahides to eat living things in using the phrase “every moving thing that lives.” I’m particularly wondering about the “moving” part. Would a living animal that does not move, such as an (e.g., cooked) oyster, fall outside the scope of Bereshit 9:3? Or is “every moving thing that lives” equivalent to what we include today in the term “animals”?

NOTE

A number of similar questions exist:

  • Remes - רֶמֶשׂ - in Genesis 9:3
  • Genesis Chapter 9 : 3 Meaning
  • Can a Ben-Noach eat live oysters?

However, my question is not a duplicate of these questions for the following reasons:

  • The first question asks about different meanings of “moving thing,” not whether non‐moving animals are included.
  • The second question asks to explain an apparent contradiction in the verse, which is not what I’m discussing.
  • The third question asks whether a Ben Noach can eat live oysters, without addressing whether oysters in general, as non‐moving animals, are permissible in the first place.
## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Rule 5 of Rabbi Yishmael's brysa, which enumerates 13 rules for how to learn the Torah, helps explain this verse. The rule is that when there is a specific followed by a general the general comes to include the specific example and more. Here the Torah is not limiting Noah and his descendants to only eat animals that have the ability to move. This is just specific thing which is followed by all living things being permitted. Furthermore, as Rashi explains... "Will be yours to eat - for I did not permit Adam, the first man, to eat meat, but only plant vegetation. To you, however, in the same way that I gave full use of plant vegetation to Adam the first man, so have I given you everything." (Translation from chabad.org)

title: Rewriting Egyptian Government Protocol?
content:
# Rewriting Egyptian Government Protocol? ## Frage

Rashi (41:12) writes regarding Yosef HaTzaddik:

עֶבֶד. וְכָתוּב בְּנִמּוּסֵי מִצְרַיִם שֶׁאֵין עֶבֶד מוֹלֵךְ וְלֹא לוֹבֵשׁ בִּגְדֵי שָׂרִים - It is written in Egyptian protocol that a servant may not rule nor don aristocratic robes.

Since it was against Egyptian government regulations to allow a slave like Yosef to serve in a leadership role, what did Pharaoh do to get around this issue? (e.g., Did they rewrite the protocol? Does marrying a government official's daughter avoid this law?)

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

The Oznaim LaTorah (Bereishis 41:38) writes:

Pharaoh, as an absolute ruler, did not need his servants' consent to appoint Joseph. But because it was against fundamental Egyptian law to make a slave a ruler, Pharaoh appeased his servants by asking whether any free man in the country was fit to compete with Yosef for this highly responsible position. They would simply have to appoint the person sent to them by God, "in whom was God's spirit," to rescue them from famine.

It seems Rav Zalman Sorotzkin holds that they did not change the Egyptian laws, rather they allowed this exception because there was no one who could fill the role. (Perhaps similar to the US Federal government's direct hire authority, especially for public health emergencies.)

In the book "The Light and the Splendor: The Radiance and Inspiration of the Days of Triumph and Gratitude" by Rav Daniel Glatstein shlita (p. 218), he quotes from Rav Soloveitchik and says that when we read in Al HaNisim:"וְאַחַר כֵּן בָּאוּ בָנֶיךָ" (Your children came to the Holy of Holies of Your house) means that:

title: What is the significance of the Teivah landing on Mt. Ararat?
content:
# What is the significance of the Teivah landing on Mt. Ararat? ## Frage

There's many mountains in Judaism that have extreme religious significance. Har Sinai, Har HaMoriah, Har Gerizim, Har Eval, Har Carmel, etc. I would expect the same to be true of not only the first mountain mentioned in the Torah, but the mountain where the new founders of humanity would start their mission of reshaping the world. However, I haven't found an explanation for why Hashem made the Teivah land on Mt. Ararat.

In terms of Rishonim, all I have found who even mentioned the mountain is Radak, who has suggested that Mt. Ararat could have been the tallest mountain, or that the Teivah happened to be in the general area. He seems dissatisfied with both explanations, and both seem to take the approach of "it was the most convenient area to land". However, my question still stands. Even if it was the most convenient, it still does not explain the significance of Mt. Ararat. This is a named mountain, if there was nothing to glean from the exact location/name, the Torah could have written "a mountain" or "a tall mountain".

The Talmud (Sanhedrin 96a) links Sancheriv to Mt. Ararat by having him find a plank of the Teivah there and forming it into an idol. Does this Aggadah play a role in explaining the significance of Mt. Ararat? If so, what is the meaning behind it?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I don't know if this hits the mark exactly, but in some ancient sources (Jubilees, the Qumran Genesis Apocryphon and the medieval Sefer Asaf Ha'Rofeh) it's said that the particular mountain in the Land of Ararat that the tevah landed on was called Lubar (לובר). Richard C. Steiner, 'The Mountains of Ararat, Mount Lubar and הר הקדם', Journal of Jewish Studies 42 (1991), pp. 247-249 argued that the word 'Lubar' in Aramaic means 'ancient' or 'kedem'/'kadum' (קדם) in Hebrew. In other words, Mt. Lubar is Har Ha'Kedem, one of the boundary markers of the original settlement of the descendants of Shem (Beresheet 10:30).1

This suggests that the tevah landed right at the edge of what would eventually become the territory of the Shemites, and allows the Torah to gradually start focusing on the lineage of Shem, and from there the lineage of Avraham.

1 Rather than the usual interpretation of Har Ha'Kedem as "eastern mountain" (where Kedem [also] means 'east').

title: Understanding the commandment to build a Temple
content:
# Understanding the commandment to build a Temple ## Frage

Rambam lists building the Beit HaMikdash as a positive commandment (#20) based on the pasuk in Shemot 25:8 - וְעָשׂוּ לִי מִקְדָּשׁ וְשָׁכַנְתִּי בְּתוֹכָם

However, when David requests to build the Temple (2 Shmuel 7) the answer isn't an automatic "yes".

My understanding is that Chazal (eg Sanhedrin 20b, based on Devarim 12:10-11) see the Beit HaMikdash as the fulfillment of a biblical command. However, that doesn't seem to be the straightforward reading of the verses in Shmuel. Working on the assumption that building the Beit HaMikdash is a fulfillment of the biblical command leads to several questions in the text such as:

  1. If it was a biblical command why would David need to ask?
  2. Why would God answer that he cannot do it? (Answers regarding David having blood on his hands are not based on the text in Samuel and don't seem to apply to Nehemiah who also has blood on his hands and rebuilds the Temple)
  3. Why didn't anyone before David even talk about doing building a Beit HaMikdash if it was a biblical mitzvah?
  4. Aren't the verses cited by the Talmud making reference to the Tabernacle?

On the other hands, assuming that building the Beit HaMikdash is not a biblical commandment leads to other problems, such as the fact that a prophet cannot add a new commandment (see Temura 16a) in which case Solomon would not have been allowed to build the Temple either.

Do any commentators explain how to understand the commandment to build a permanent Temple as being biblical in light of the difficulties in the plain reading of 2 Samuel 7?

title: Why do most Litvishe circles in the US light Chanukah menorah by the window? It should either be outdoors, or on the table?

# Why do most Litvishe circles in the US light Chanukah menorah by the window? It should either be outdoors, or on the table? ## Frage

The Gemara (Shabbos 21b) says that you must light your Chanukah menorah near the doorway of your house on the outside. If you live on an upper floor, you should light it in your window. And in times of danger, you light the menorah on your table. There are many explanations why many don't light outdoors these days, along the lines that we still have the original enactment of "times of danger" (see Sefer Haitur, Shibolei Haleket & Aruch HaShulchan). Mishnah Berurah 671:38 writes that if one is lighting inside, it is more correct, where possible, to light by a window, to fulfill pirsumei nisa. ## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Mishnah Berurah 671:38 writes that if one is lighting inside, it is more correct, where possible, to light by a window, to fulfill pirsumei nisa.

title: How prevalent was Shabbat observance in ancient times?
content:
# How prevalent was Shabbat observance in ancient times? ## Frage

Elon Gilad, a writer at Haaretz, recently wrote a book "The Secret History of the Jews" (in Hebrew). I have not read the book, but have read various derivative works of his book.

He claims that Shabbat observance was only practiced after the Babylonian exile, and not during/after the exodus. He brings examples such as Nechemia (15:22) who observed that Jews didn't keep Shabbat. Or Yirmiyahu (17:23) where Jews would refuse to keep Shabbat. He claims that books written in the Temple periods there is no evidence of a weekly day of rest i.e., people go about their daily lives as normal, there is no preparation for Shabbat or observance of it, people aren't criticized for breaking Shabbat, and armies don't exploit the strategic weakness.

I will note that generally the Torah itself mentions the six days of work before rest, motif. Gilad claims that this was inserted at a later stage, or simply never observed in the first place...

He further claims that when prophets mention Shabbat it is regularly paired with ideas surrounding the new moon. He claims that in Babylonian "sabbatu" meant the day of the new moon. Gilad asserts that Jews practiced celebrations of the new moon (beginning of the month, rosh chodesh) and 'Shabbat' which was originally the middle of the month. Gilad then claims that only after the Babylonian exile did the monthly celebration transform into the weekly day of rest that it is today.

Leaving aside the Babylonian claims (I am not asking about comparative religion or appropriation), is there any evidence in Jewish scriptures that 'Shabbat' can be understood as a monthly observance (or that there was an observance of something in the middle of the month), or a weekly day of rest but was generally not observed by the masses up until the Babylonian exile?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

This sounds like another modern Academic theory that picks and chooses which parts of Tanach it wants to accept as true and reflective of their time and which parts are not. That type of motivated reasoning and special pleading can support any theory. It's silly.

Yirmiyahu isn't post-exilic. It is prophecies from the end of the First Temple period. And the people are being criticized for carrying and doing work on Shabbos (Jeremiah 17:19-23.)

We have archeological evidence that Numbers was written pre-exilic (the Ketef Hinnom scrolls) and Numbers discusses the prohibition of doing work on the Shabbos day and the special Shabbos sacrifices that follow in sequence from daily sacrifices to monthly (Rosh Chodesh) with Shabbos in between.

II Kings 11:4-8 takes place long before the exile and references the weekly switching of of the mishmoros of Kohanim and Leviim as the בָּאֵ֣י הַשַּׁבָּ֔ת and the יֹצְאֵ֣י הַשַּׁבָּ֑ת (the same terms used in Divrei Hayamim to describe the weekly mishmoros). This strongly indicates that Shabbos is a weekly event.

There are also other places in Neviim that mention Shabbos without the chodesh. E.g. Isaiah 56:4, 6; II Kings 16:18.

There is no reason to think Shabbos was ever anything but a weekly special day, just like it is today.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

I don't understand, because the Neviim were not criticising people for not keeping Shabbos, that means they didn't have Shabbos?
Or does he assume there were always Chilonim?

Off the top of my head I know Shabbos is mentioned in Yeshayahu (not off the top of my head, it's perek 58), we learn things from there.

But maybe that was added later? Maybe anything I can possibly say was added later?
Maybe all mentions of Israel were added later. Anything you want.

The Yirmiyahu passuk sounds in context like it's pre-destruction of the Beit Hamikdash. If not, and he's saying Shabbos was added only post-destruction, that would give a very short timeline for such a major mitzva to be added, accepted, not kept, and we be rebuked for not keeping it.

Edit: Some more points on what you quote.

"people go about their daily lives as normal, there is no preparation for Shabbat or observance of it" What exactly does he expect? Is every detail of daily life described and only this is missing?

"and armies don't exploit the strategic weakness"

A. That's coming form the point of view that there is no God watching over us.

B. There are shomer Shabbos soldiers and security personnel still today. Pikuach nefesh.

title: Hot plate on Shabbos for Chazarah. Cover or no?
content:
# Hot plate on Shabbos for Chazarah. Cover or no? ## Frage

Based on my observations, there seems to be a general understanding that when people use a hot plate or platah for Chazarah on Shabbos, they place the pot directly onto the hotplate. However, when it comes to placing cold items on the hotplate, they tend to add an additional thicker layer instead of placing them directly on it. My question is: why is this the case?

To elaborate, Chazal instructed us to perform Garuf Ukatum with fires prior to Shabbos to allow for Shehiya or Chazarah. The reasoning behind this is either related to the concern of Mechzei Kmevashel (it appears as though one is cooking) or the potential to stoke the fire. With a hotplate, while we are less concerned about stoking the fire, we still have concerns regarding Mechzei Kmevashel. (some do cook on hotplates regularly, and since the hotplate has the capability to cook, we treat it as an open flame) Therefore the hotplate would need to be covered.

If we regard a hotplate as an open flame, then even performing Chazarah should present a concern, as it might still appear that cooking is underway. Conversely, if it does not appear that one is cooking—such as when one is holding the item the entire time—then what is the rationale for requiring Garuf Ukatum for Chazarah at a regular open fire? Additionally, if the hotplate is not considered an open fire and is already katum, why can’t we place items directly on the hotplate during Shabbos?

How can these contradictions be reconciled?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

One way to resolve the contradiction is to assume that returning an item that was previously on the fire (hachzarah) is forbidden (in general) due to a concern of stoking the coals, as opposed to placing an item initially on the fire (hanachah) which is additionally forbidden due to it looking like cooking.

If we consider the plata to be like a kirah ketumah, we have eliminated the concern of stoking the coals, and therefore hachzarah is allowed. But placing cold food directly on the plata could still look like cooking, and therefore a genuine barrier is required between the plata and the cold food, so it no longer looks like cooking.

title: Rabbeinu Bachya States That Jonah Curled up and Slept Soundly on the Tossing Ship Because he was Confident that he Would be Saved - How did he Know?
content:
# Rabbeinu Bachya States That Jonah Curled up and Slept Soundly on the Tossing Ship Because he was Confident that he Would be Saved - How did he Know? ## Frage

Jonah was told to go to Ninveh and proclaim judgement upon them. Instead, he attempted to flee on a boat to Tarshish. When a severe tempest threatened the ship, all the sailors prayed to their gods and then they proceeded to lighten the load. Jonah, however, went into the hold of the vessel where he lay down and fell asleep. The captain urged Jonah to call out to his God.

Rabbeinu Bachya (Kad Hakemach Kipuurim Aleph):

ויונה לא עשה כן אבל הצדיק עליו את הדין והיה בוטח בהקב"ה שיצילהו כשם שהוא מציל את הצדיקים כמו שכתוב (תהלים לד) רבות רעות צדיק וגו': ויונה ירד אל ירכתי הספינה וישכב וירדם זה מוכיח שלא היתה כונתו רעה כי היה שוכב ונרדם כמי שלבו בטוח ולא היה לו פחד כלל. Jonah did not do this (pray) because he accepted the judgment (against him) and was confident that God would save him in the manner that He saves the righteous as it states (Psalms 34): "Many are the afflictions of the righteous, but the LORD delivers him out of them all..." "Jonah, meanwhile, had gone down into the hold of the vessel where he lay down and fell asleep." This proves that his (Jonah's) intention was not evil because he lied down and slept as one whose heart is confident, and he possessed no fear whatsoever...

Question: He accepted his fate, but why was he certain that it was a good fate - hadn't he just disobeyed God's command? His acts clearly caused the tempest! How did he know that death wasn't coming? And how did he know his fate was sealed (for good or bad)? The righteous pray and perform worthy acts until the very end precisely because they eschew the notion of 'one's fate being sealed.'

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The quoted text is from the paragraph 6 commenting on actions of Yonah. In the preceeding paragraphs Rabbeinu Bachya explains why Yonah acted this way and why he was at fault. To summarize, the intention of Yonah was not that a man can run away from Hashem, because David already said in Tehilim 139:7-8:

Where can I escape from Your spirit? Where can I flee from Your presence? If I ascend to heaven, You are there; if I descend to Sheol, You are there too.

Rather he sought to run from Eretz Israel, where the spirit of prophecy is always present to Tarshish (Spain?), where the Glory of Hashem ('כבוד ה) is not revealed, so that he would no longer experience prophecy.

Hashem made him a messenger. The fact that he refused to be the messenger, his thought was good and intention for the sake of Heaven, because of humility and wholeness of his heart. Yonah made Kal vaChomer to the words of Moshe rabbeinu. As Hashem sent Moshe to Pharaoh (Shemos 3:10), Moshe also refused, Shemos 4:13:

But he said, “Please, O my lord, make someone else Your agent.” (i.e. make someone else Your agent, Literally “send through whomever You will send.”)

So, Yonah reasoned, if Moshe refused to be a messenger to take out Israel, the righteous, out of Mitzraim; so he, who was sent as a messenger to warn the evil-doers in Assyria - even more so was permitted to do.

If one asks, if his intention was good, why was he punished that in the end he was sent into the sea? Rabbeinu Bachya answers, that Yonah refused to warn the evil people of Ninveh, which was a command of HKBH. Because the righteous and the prophets are obligated by way of the Torah to warn the evil-doers, as we find in Yechezkel 3:18-19

If I say to someone wicked, ‘You shall die,’ and you do not give warning—you do not speak to warn them of their wicked course in order to save their life—then that wicked one shall die for their own iniquity, while from you I will require a reckoning for their blood. But if you do warn someone wicked, and they do not turn back from their wickedness and their wicked course, they shall die for their iniquity, while you will have saved your own life.

Yonah refused, that's why he was punished. Even if one asks, Yechezkel was sent to warn Israel, but Yonah was sent to warn a foreign nation, whom Yonah was not obligated to warn. Even in this case, since Hashem said, "Arise, go to Ninveh,...", as a command, it means that Hashem hoped that they would repent, and as a result Yonah had to warn them. His refusal was equivalent that he was fit to demand their punishment, not for their honor, but for that of Hashem. That's a problem that Yonah had not yet understood. Thus, Rabbeinu Bachya concludes that Yonah's refusal cannot be compared to that of Moshe, for Moshe was sent not to warn the evil Pharaoh, but to free Bnei Israel.

Hence, Yonah deserved punishment, however he had not yet realized it. Rabbeinu Bachya already showed, that Yonah acted on a faulty premise and has not yet realized his mistake. He thought that he could continue on the way to escape. That's why the captain of the ship, who was a very wise man, warned him in verse Yona 1:6, as Rabbeinu Bachya explains this warning:

Why are you asleap as the one whose heart is confident and without fear? Even if you are confident in your righteousness, you are obligated to beseach for mercy and pray, 'rise and call your G-d'.

The captain of the ship informed him that if one is in the midst of the trouble anywhere in this world, or the time of trouble came, one can save others and oneself with prayer, as the verse Tehilim 34:18 says:

They (the righteous) cry out, and Hashem hears, and saves them from all their troubles.

Perhaps, it is this advice of the captain that saved Yonah in this case. Because of his false premise, Yonah had not realized that death might be coming. As we know, Yonah was swallowed by the fish and spent 3 days inside the belly, bringing various reasons why he should be saved. Rabbeinu Bachya reads דגה meaning a dead fish. Only then Yonah realized his mistake, as we see from his prayer, Yonah 2:3

He said: In my trouble I called to G-D, Who answered me; From the belly of Sheol I cried out, And You heard my voice.

title: What is the thought of the heart?
content:
# What is the thought of the heart? ## Frage

In the prayer before the prayer תפילה קודם תפילה of Rabbi Elimelech of Lizansk, it appears: "And with our hearts when we think.עם ליבנו בעת מחשבותינו" Apparently, the thought is in the brain (In Hebrew, the first letters of the word "thought" מח אותיות ראשונות של מחשבה). The phrase "the thought of the heart" (מחשבת הלב) also appears in other places. And if so, how can the heart think, since thinking is done in the brain (who place Tefillin on the head to correct the thought)?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

Rabbi Ran Abuhatzera from Afula replied: הרמ"ד ואלי זיע"א בספרו משנה תורה ביאור על ספר דברים (תניינא) כתב ביאורו על הפסוק הנ"ל בפרשת עקב, וז"ל: לפי שהיצר הרע והנפש הבהמית הם המחטיאים את האדם, והמביאים אותו לעשות מן העיקר טפל, לפיכך היה צריך שיתישבו הדברים האלה בלבם, כדי להכניע את שניהם, שיהיו משועבדים תחת רצונו של מקום והנהגתו של היצר הטוב. וזהו ענין אמרו בסמוך: ושמתם את דברי אלה על לבבכם, דהיינו יצר הרע שנקרא לבב. ועל נפשכם, שהוא הנפש הבהמית, דהא יצרא טבא איתעטר בהו ויצרא בישא איתכנע בהו. ולמען תהיה ההכנעה בין במחשבה בין במעשה, לפיכך נצטוינו על מצות התפילין, שהדברים האלו כתובים בהם. וז"ש: וקשרתם אותם לאות על ידכם, להכניע המעשה רע שעיקרו מן השמאל, ולכן תפילין של יד ניתנים על היד השמאלי. ולהכניע המחשבה רעה, הרי תפילין של ראש הניתנים על המוח, וז"ש: והיו לטוטפות בין עיניכם. עכ"ל. הרי לנו שלבבכם כאן הכוונה על היצר הרע שנקרא לבב ונפשכם הכוונה היא על הנפש הבהמית שהם צריכים להיות משועבדים ליצר הטוב, ואת זה אפשר לעשות כי זה עיקר העבודה להכניע את היצר הרע ואת הנפש הבהמית.

The Ramad Vali in his book Mishneh Torah Bior al-Sefer Devarim (Taniyina) wrote his commentary on the above verse in Parashat Akev, and these are his words: Since the evil inclination and the animalistic soul are what lead a person astray, and cause him to do what is essentially wrong, therefore it was necessary for these things to settle in their hearts, in order to subdue both of them, to be enslaved under the will of a place and the guidance of the good inclination. And this is the matter they said next: And you have placed these words on your hearts, namely the evil inclination called the heart. And on your soul, which is the animalistic soul, there is a tendency to bow down to it and a tendency to bow down to it. And in order for the submission to be either in thought or in deed, therefore we were commanded to follow the commandments of tefillin, in which these things are written. And this is witten: And you shall bind them as a sign on your hand, to subdue the evil deed that is primarily from the left, and therefore hand tefillin are worn on the left hand. And to subdue the evil thought, these are head tefillin worn on the brain, and these are the words: And they shall be as frontlets between your eyes. And so on. For us, your heart here refers to the evil inclination called the heart, and your soul refers to the animal soul that needs to be enslaved to the good inclination, and this can be done because this is the main work of subduing the evil inclination and the animal soul.

title: What makes a good motivator?
content:
# What makes a good motivator? ## Frage

Are there any Torah sources for what would make something a good motivator for children? i.e. are there some that are more sustainable or more productive than others?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

This answer applies mainly to older children/young adults who are more capable of reason, however it can apply to younger children as well. There are 2 parts.

First off, The Mishna in Avos (4:2).

בן עזאי אומר הוי רץ למצוה קלה ובורח מן העבירה שמצוה גוררת מצוה ועברה גוררת עברה ששכר מצוה מצוה ושכר עברה עברה

Ben Azai says, “Run toward a light mitzvah and flee from an aveirah, for a mitzvah leads to a mitzvah, and an aveirah leads to an aveirah; for the reward of a mitzvah is a mitzvah, and the reward of an aveirah is an aveirah.

The idea of mitzvah goreres mitzvah is not merely some magical concept you learnt as a kid, it’s a fact of human nature and one of the greatest motivators.

If someone does an act that appeals to his better self, he will immediately feel a sense of pride and accomplishment, thus causing him to want to experience that feeling again. The reason we fail to do what we truly want is due to fear, and this positive experience gives him the confidence to reach higher in spite of that fear. This is mitzvah goreres mitzvah on an adult level, and is why we “force” children to do certain things as part of chinuch; we shove a good feeling down their throat so they have the taste in their mouth.

The second, and more important thing, is parents. I’m not going to list Torah sources for this because A) there aren’t any explicit ones that I can think off the top of my head, although there are countless ones by way of inference, and B) it’s purely common sense which is the best source.

Parents are the greatest motivators. Not with what they tell their children to try to motivate them, but rather by how they act as people themselves.

A child’s nature is to want to emulate his or her parents. Part of the reason we refer to Hashem as Avinu Malkeinu, is because those are the 2 ultimate beings that are naturally revered. A subject naturally reveres a king, and a child naturally reveres a parent. One might even say a child idolizes a parent.

However, this natural state cannot be abused. If a parent lives a way of life that he or she is not proud of, the child will inevitably become aware of that fact whether consciously or not, and just like that there’s a crack in the child’s admiration of his parents. He’s no longer so confident that his daddy is “the man”. At that point the will to emulate his father starts to dissipate.

It’s a difficult pill to swallow, but most of the time when our children are failing in an area, it’s our fault. Kids that are confident in their parents (who are confident in themselves) are nearly untouchable. You can’t shake them because they come home everyday to their “idol” who’s the man, and that’s who they emulate and they want nothing more than to make their father proud and be just like him.

There’s no greater motivation for a child than giving them a true role model.

Hope this helps.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

I saw once in a book on parenting advice pruned from the lectures of HaRav Pinchas Sheinberg Z'tl, where he recommended "positive jealousy". Instead of making examples of bad behaviour, make examples of good behaviour.

E.g. when one child does something very good, try to make the others "jealous" of how well that child did by letting them see how you praise and reward him.

I'm sure this advice would raise some "red flags" by some people (generally, the ones who tend to use the phrase "red flag" a lot), but it's still better than shaming children who do badly, which is what most parents' natural instinct is to do.

title: Why did Rambam say that only nine parah adumah offerings ever took place?
content:
# Why did Rambam say that only nine parah adumah offerings ever took place? ## Frage

In Mishneh Torah Parah Adumah 3, the Rambam says that only nine red heifers have ever been offered, including the pre-Temple period, the First Temple period, and the Second Temple Period.

As I understand it, for someone to be purified and go to the Temple, a red heifer offering must be performed, and most men were obligated to go to the Temple during pilgrimage festivals (Mishna Chagiga 1:1).

Were people back then just very careful not to go near corpses?
What about Chevra Kadishas? Were they just exempt?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

Rambam is referring to Mishna Parah 3:5:

לֹא מָצְאוּ מִשֶּׁבַע, עוֹשִׂין מִשֵּׁשׁ, מֵחָמֵשׁ, מֵאַרְבַּע, מִשָּׁלשׁ, מִשְּׁתַּיִם וּמֵאֶחָת. וּמִי עֲשָׂאָם. הָרִאשׁוֹנָה עָשָׂה משֶׁה, וְהַשְּׁנִיָּה עָשָׂה עֶזְרָא, וְחָמֵשׁ, מֵעֶזְרָא וָאֵילָךְ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים, שֶׁבַע מֵעֶזְרָא וָאֵילָךְ. וּמִי עֲשָׂאָן. שִׁמְעוֹן הַצַּדִּיק וְיוֹחָנָן כֹּהֵן גָּדוֹל עָשׂוּ שְׁתַּיִם שְׁתַּיִם, אֶלְיְהוֹעֵינַי בֶּן הַקּוֹף וַחֲנַמְאֵל הַמִּצְרִי וְיִשְׁמָעֵאל בֶּן פִּיאָבִי עָשׂוּ אַחַת אֶחָת:

If they did not find the residue of the ashes of the seven [red cows] they performed the sprinkling with those of six, of five, of four, of three, of two or of one. And who prepared these? Moses prepared the first, Ezra prepared the second, and five were prepared from the time of Ezra, the words of Rabbi Meir. But the sages say: seven from the time of Ezra. And who prepared them? Shimon the Just and Yohanan the high priest prepared two each; Elihoenai the son of Ha-Kof and Hanamel the Egyptian and Ishmael the son of Piabi prepared one each.

The text of the Mishna implies that on many occasions they had leftover ashes from several cows available.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I found it. Its a yerushalmi in 4th perek of kiddushin. רַב הוּנָא אָמַר. בִּימֵי רִבִּי לָעְזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה בִּיקְשׁוּ לְקָרְבָן. רִבִּי אַבָּהוּ מַפִּיךְ לִישְׁנָא. בִּימֵי רִבִּי לָעְזָר. אָמְרוּ. מִי מְטַהֵר חֶלְקוֹ שֶׁלַּמִּזְבֵּחַ. הָדָא אָמְרָה יְהוֹשֻׁעַ רִיחֲקָן. אֲפִילוּ תֵימָא. יְהוֹשֻׁעַ רִיחֲקָן. כְּלוּם רִיחֲקָן אֶלָּא פְסוּלֵי מִשְׁפָּחָה. אִין תֵּימַר. מִשּׁוּם פְּסוּלֵי עֲבֵירוֹת. מֵעַתָּה הַבָּא עַל הַנְּתִינָה לֹא יְהֵא לָהּ קְנָס. וְהָתַנִּינָן. הַבָּא עַל הַנְּתִינָה יֵשׁ לָהּ קְנָס. אָמַר רִבִּי אֶלְעָזָר. אֵירְרָן כְּנָחָשׁ. שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר וְעַתָּה אֲרוּרִים אַתֶּם. וְכָתוּב וַיֹּאמֶר אִישׁ יִשְׂרָאֵל אֶל הַחִוִּי. וְכִי חִיוִּי הָיוּ. אֶלָּא שֶׁעָשׂוּ מַעֲשֶׂה חִיוִּי. אָמַר. יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי שֶׁאָמַר הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא כִּי בְּיוֹם אֲכָלְךְ מִמֶּנּוּ מוֹת תָּמוּת. אֶלָּא הֲרֵינִי הוֹלֵךְ וּמְרַמֶּה בָהֶן וְהֵן אוֹכְלִין וְנֶעֱנָשִׁין וַאֲנִי יוֹרֵשׁ אֶת הָאָרֶץ לְעַצְמִי. כָּךְ עָשׂוּ אֵילּוּ. אָמְרוּ. יוֹדְעִין אָנוּ שֶׁהַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא אָמַר לְיִשְׂרָאֵל כִּי הַחֲרֵם תַּחֲרִימֵם הַחִתִּי וְהָאֱמֹרִי וְהַפְּרִזִי כַּאֲשֶׁר צִוְּךָ יי אֱלֹהֶיךָ. וְכָתוּב לֹא תִּכְרֹת לָהֶם בְּרִית. הֲרֵי אָנוּ הוֹלְכִין וּמְרַמִּין בָּהֶן וְהֵם כּוֹרְתִין עִמָּנוּ בְּרִית. מַה נַפְשֵׁךְ. יְהָרְגוּ אוֹתָנוּ עָבְרוּ עַל הַשְּׁבוּעָה. יְקַיְימוּ אוֹתָנוּ עָבְרוּ עַל הַגְּזֵירָה. בֵּין כָּךְ וּבֵין כָּךְ הֵן נֶעֱנָשִׁין וְאָנוּ יוֹרְשִׁין הָאָרֶץ.

title: Who was the Rabbi Of Rabbi Yitzchak Kanpanton?
content:
# Who was the Rabbi Of Rabbi Yitzchak Kanpanton? ## Frage

Another question regarding the same topic, the rabbi of the Mahari Abuhav and other big rishonim was the great Rabbi Yitzchak Kanpanton. Who was his rabbi?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Rabbi Gedalyah Ibn Yechiya wrote in Shalshelet Hakabbalah:

"הרב הגדול רבי יצחק קנפנטון בן הרב הגדול ר' יעקב הנקרא גאון קסטילייא ספרדי, והרב רבי ישראל אשכנזי קבלו מאבותיהם ורבותיהם ודורות הקדמונים שנת כמו ה' אלפים ק"ס."

"The great rabbi Rabbi Yitzchak Kanpanton, son of the great rabbi R' Yaakov who is known as the Gaon of Castille, the Spaniard, and the rabbi Rabbi Yisrael Ashkenazi received from their fathers, and rabbis, and prior generations, circa the year 5160 (1399/1400 CE)."

This appears to indicate that at least one of Rabbi Yitzchak Kanpanton's rabbis was his father, Rabbi Yaakov of Castille.1 As already stated in the comments, Rabbi Yaakov, in turn, was a student of Rabbi Chasdai Crescas. According to Rabbi Avraham Zaccuto in Sefer Yuchasin, Rabbi Yaakov was very wise and authored many books. However, few have survived today. We have a commentary of his on one section of Rabbi Shlomo Ibn Yaish's commentary on one of Avicenna's philosophical works, a book on mathematics and science called Bar Noten Ta'am, and it has been argued that he authored a particular manuscript of responsa found in the Genizah. Another of his students was Rabbi Chasdai ben Chasdai. A third anonymous student was the scribe of MS Parma 2207, who stated in a note on p. 67r:

"This confession prayer was composed by […] R. Judah Ibn Tibbon […] which I who write here in the Kingdom of Castile saw at the end of the book [Hovot ha-Levavot] when I worked and served my teacher the great Rabbi Jacob Capanton [sic], may God rest his soul in Paradise [ריתב"ע], in the year 5166 [ו'ע'ץ' חיים (1406)], […] and written here in the first decade [added in the margin: "in the month of"] Av in the year 199 of the sixth millennium [=1439]." (translation based on that from the above-linked article by Arad and Glick, p. 413)

1 This interpretation of the passage was also held by Moshe Zeri, The Golden Age of Spain (in Hebrew), p. 263.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

The Chida in Shem HaGedolim (Maareches Seforim, Maareches Daled, 55) mentions him with regard to his authored sefer, Darkei Gemara (דרכי גמרא):

Rabbi Yitzchak Kanpanton, who was a great sage in Castile and whose works were printed several times. His students were two great figures of the generation: Mahari Abuhav and Mahari Di Leon

Rabbi Yitzchak Kanpanton was back then refered to as "the Gaon", not commonly used in that generation (Sefer HaYuchasin HaShalem, p. 2).

Of Rabbi Avraham Zacuto (אברהם זכות) it is said that when he was 6-7 years old, he met Rabbi Kanpanton. The story goes as follows:

When he was six or seven years old, he saw the elder Rabbi Yitzchak Kanpanton, the leader of all the exiles of Castile, whom his generation referred to with the title "Gaon," a designation not commonly used in those days. The sight of "the pious and humble one, imbued with the spirit of the holy G-d," made a profound impression on the young boy, leading him to write in his old age: "One who sees his face is as if receiving the Divine Presence." (Sefer HaYuchasin HaShalem, p. 2)

title: Concerning the variations of different Tanakh versions of Second Temple and Masoretic Text authenticity
content:
# Concerning the variations of different Tanakh versions of Second Temple and Masoretic Text authenticity ## Frage

When we cross-examine the three main earliest textual variants of Tanakh in the face of Qumran Texts, Septuagint and Samaritan texts, we find a plethora (of mostly minor) differences. While I am not concerned with differences of writing down a Vav or a Yud where it would normally not be written down today, or a scribe writing the lower part of Mem slightly longer, making it seem like Mem Sophit, I am concerned that there are specific variations that are slightly more concerning.

While Qumran texts on majority agree with Masoretic texts, there still seems to be among what we find a soup of slight variations that mix on how they relate to each other. Some parts of Qumran are closer to the Septuagint, some to the Masoretic and the same can be said about the cross-relations of different sets of those texts.

My question is, how does that co-exist with the idea of not a single letter being changed in Torah that we have today? What is the source of our confidence that the Masoretic text is the representation of unchanged original? Why were the textual small differences so prelevant? What does the talmudic and oral tradition say about the formation of the Tanakh canon and form that might point us to some explanations?

title: What is the Scope of Rabbeinu Bachya's ואין לו לבקש סבה / to NOT Look for “Natural” Ways (to Survive/Escape)?
content:
# What is the Scope of Rabbeinu Bachya's ואין לו לבקש סבה / to NOT Look for “Natural” Ways (to Survive/Escape)? ## Frage

Rabbeinu Bachya states in his intro to Parshat Miketz:

השמיני הוא שיבטח בהקב"ה בכל לבו ולא יתלה מחשבתו לסבה מן הסבות רק שירצה במה שהוא רצון הקב"ה, כלומר במה שהוא בריא או חולה עשיר או עני חפשי או אסור בבית האסורים. וכיון שרצון הקב"ה שיהיה לו אחד מן המאורעות והיסורין ההם והוא חפץ לדכאו בהם יש לו לחפוץ בזה ואין לו לבקש סבה, כי אם הוא משתדל ומבקש סבה שינצל מן המאורע ההוא שהוא בו, משים חלק אחד מלבו בבטחון אותה סבה ואיננו בוטח בהקב"ה בטחון שלם בכל לבו, ומי שהוא שלם במדת הבטחון יש עליו לבטוח בהקב"ה בכל לבו שהוא יתעלה בעל הסבות כולן יזמין אליו הסבות כפי מה שיצטרך.The eighth and final stage in his development is reached when he realizes that only G’d’s input determines his success or failure. He must learn to be happy with whatever G’d has decided should be his fate. He must give G’d credit for his health — or otherwise; he must give G’d all the credit for his wealth — or otherwise. He must appreciate that if G’d saw fit to subject him to trials and tribulations in his life on earth, that G’d had a benevolent purpose in all this, that He has his best interests at heart. G’d is equally active in protecting someone’s freedom or keeping him in jail. Seeing that G’d’s superior wisdom decrees if man is to undergo afflictions of one sort or another, it behooves man to accept such afflictions willingly. He is not to look for “natural” ways to escape such predicaments. If he does so, this demonstrates that his faith in God is not absolute, but that part of his being is still convinced that he can escape what is decreed for him.

R"B continues:

ויראה לי כי מפני זה אמר (משלי ג) בטח אל ה', ולא אמר בה', לבאר שהבטחון השלם בכל לבו הוא שיהיו כל מחשבותיו אל ה', כענין שכתוב (תהילים כ״ה:ט״ו) עיני תמיד אל ה', ואין ראוי לו לצדיק השלם במדת הבטחון לבקש סבה, והעד על זה ענין אליהו, וכמו שהזכרתי בפרשה של מעלה (מלכים א י״ז:ו׳) והעורבים מביאים לו לחם ובשר בבקר וגו', והקב"ה הזמין לו אותה סבה והוא לא בקש אותה, והנה זאת מדרגה עליונה מאד במדת הבטחון.
It appears to me that when we keep in mind these comments of the author of חובת הלבבות, we can better appreciate why Solomon wrote in Proverbs 3,5: בטח אל ה' בכל לבך, “trust towards G’d with all your heart,” instead of writing בטח בה' בכל לבך, “trust in G’d with all your heart.” He wanted to alert us that a person who truly puts his faith in G’d is someone whose thoughts are oriented only towards G’d. Another example of such a construction is found in Psalms 25,15 עיני תמיד אל ה', “my eyes are ever toward G’d.” We have already mentioned that Elijah was a prime example of someone who did not try and survive by looking for logical means to do so, but that he took refuge in a place where there was no possible chance to find food and that he relied on G’d to provide it for him in His own way. This is the highest level of trust in G’d.

והנה יוסף הצדיק הבוטח בהקב"ה לפי שבקש משר המשקים שיהיה לו סבה שיצא מבית האסורים, לכך לא הגיע למדרגה זו של בטחון ונענש בזה By asking the Chief of the butlers to intercede on his behalf, righteous Joseph demonstrated that he had not attained the level of trust in G’d which an Elijah demonstrated in his life. As a result Joseph was punished by having to stay in jail two years longer than had been decreed originally.

*Does he mean that ideally a person should not seek medical attention when they are sick? Physical or Emotional therapy? Is it far from ideal to send a flare up into the sky when one is lost? Would Elijah have been guilty of seeking a natural means to survive had he hid in a more populous area where there is a greater chance of finding food? If someone steals from you why inform the authorities (trust in God's decree)? * Is the famous Two Boats and a Helicopter joke completely off mark (the punchline is that the departed man meets God and asks why He did not intervene. God responds that He sent all the would-be rescuers to the man's aid on the expectation he would accept the help)?

title: Is it ok to say "when Moshiach comes, we will find out who is right" to someone of a different religion?
content:
# Is it ok to say "when Moshiach comes, we will find out who is right" to someone of a different religion? ## Frage

The reason I ask is because it might come across as you are not sure about your Emunah, and it might be construed that you are saying their religion could be right.

These might be problems. It might also be fine, especially in a proper context - fostering a goodwill conversation. As we know, it's not a good idea to back people into a wall, or tell them they are wrong. It's not conducive to a productive, open minded conversation, and risks turning things into a full blown debate (something we are known to avoid).

So, here's an example:

A Rabbi and a Minister are on a panel discussing religion to the public. In order to not come across as closed minded, or arrogant, and to inject a bit of humour and goodwill, the Rabbi says "...so, when the Messiah comes, if turns out to be your guy, I would happily admit I am wrong, and either way I'm sure we both look forward to the day when God's name is known by the whole world and we all have an opportunity to get close to Him"

Edit: The reason why I think this is not opinion based is because I can imagine that there would be some halachot that would assist in giving a fact based answer. The only issue would be if those halachot could be interpreted in multiple ways without Rishonic or Acharonic support.

Therefore, it would also be fact-based to bring examples. I could bring Ben Shapiro, for example, who said something very similar to what I wrote in the example above, when asked why he is not a Christian, at a talk at a university. He said effectively what Shalom said in his comment below, then added a throw away "look, when Moshiach does come, we will see who is right, and if it wasn't me, I'll happily admit I was wrong" (I'll try to find the exact quote)

Is that a good precedent? He is a learned Jew, but perhaps we have higher calibre examples, or even good solid examples from some of the many recorded discussions and debates with non-Jews over the millenia? As Yaacov Deane said, this is important, and worthy of a round table discussion (you never know when you might end up in a discussion with non-Jews about religion afterall, it's best to go in with knowledge!)

Given that there is a halacha tag, this already limits the question so people will not be on topic if they voice their personal opinions. I added the sources tag, and if anyone has any suggestions on tags to further limit it (should we make a maasim tag or is there one already?).

Lastly, if anyone wishes to edit the question themselves to salvage it, feel free. I edited the example as well, to make it more hypothetical, as that will probably make the question easier to answer. Shkoyach

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Speaking commonly with a variety of abrahamic religious types is a norm for me. Typically we all believe in a coming or returning of a moshiach type. And Moshiach does commonly come up in conversation. I try to stay in the ‘He who comes will come for us all’ realm. The example between the rabbi and minister is great! I sometimes say ‘no matter the specifics of the who/where/when/how - I will still raise my voice in praise.

Conceding to the unique correctness of HaShem is not an admission of incorrect belief. It is a show of faith.

Jeremiah 18 is commonly used to end disputes as disputations are incorrect.

Proverbs 18:6 A fools lips enter into contention. Proverbs 13:10 Only by pride cometh contention.

In our own pride we believe we know. And after all - in the light of ‘Who is right?’ there is only 1 who is correct.

Job 40 helps one see how to align correctly with this idea. Jeremiah 18 proves our need to be willing to be whatever HaShem desires us to be.
