title: Is the first light of Genesis 1:3 the production of the divine Moshiach as the first angel?
content:
# Is the first light of Genesis 1:3 the production of the divine Moshiach as the first angel? ## Frage

Genesis 1:3-4

And G-d said, “Let there be light,” and there was light. And G-d saw that the light was good. And G-d separated the light from the darkness."

Is the light from the Light a god from the G-d?

Is there any tradition, from recently or antiquity, of the first light being the first angel and the divine mashiach?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

There is specifically a tradition, which we have recorded from a Jewish Sage, 1750-1800 years ago (and goes back much further): Rabbi Yitzchak, which teaches that the verse

כה־אמר יהוה גאלך ויצרך מבטן אנכי יהוה עשה כל נטה שמים לבדי רקע הארץ (מי אתי) [מאתי]

Thus says the Lord, thy redeemer, and he that formed thee from the womb, I am the Lord that makes all things; that stretches the heavens, alone; that spreads abroad the earth by myself; [Isaiah 44:24]

means that Hashem literally created the world alone, so we wouldn't make the mistake that He needed help to do it. There were no angels even around at the time of the creation of the first light, according to this teaching.

If it is literal or not, it's very important to know this fundamental Torah principle that Hashem is One, and the only way to connect to Him is directly, not through an intermediary like an angel, or light, or even Moshiach.

In Torah tradition, Moshiach is a very righteous man, a king, and a teacher, nothing more. He will be a great teacher, who will teach us many great things about this One God, by teaching God's Torah very deeply, so we can all connect to God directly, and personally, without any intermediary.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 3)

Soley based on the way you phrased the title of this question, I would like to bring some sources that "And G-d saw the light, and it was good" (Bereishis 1:4) is connected to Moshiach.

In Psalm 97:11, it writes:

א֭וֹר זָרֻ֣עַ לַצַּדִּ֑יק Light is sown for the righteous

The commentary Eshkol HaKofer on Ruth 1:1 explains, using this verse, that it refers to Moshiach. Let's read what he says:

"מה להלן נולד משה רבינו ע"ה שהביא האור לישראל דכתיב ותרא אותו כי טוב הוא וכתיב וירא אלהים את האור כי טוב."

Just as there, Moshe Rabbeinu, peace be upon him, was born, who brought light to Israel, as it is written, 'She saw him, that he was good,' and it is written, 'And G-d saw the light, that it was good.'

אף במלך המשיח כתיב אור זרוע לצדיק הוא צמח צדיק הנקרא אור וכתיב קומי אורי כי בא אורך

Likewise, concerning the King Messiah, it is written, 'Light is sown for the righteous'— he is the Righteous Branch, called 'light,' as it is written, 'Arise, shine, for your light has come.'"

On the verse: "In Your light we shall see light" (Psalm 36:10), the Midrash (Yalkut Shimoni, Nach, Remez 499) explains that the light refers to the deeds of Moshiach, the Messiah:

"מה פירוש 'באורך נראה אור'? זה מתייחס לאור של המשיח, כמו שכתוב: 'וירא אלקים את האור כי טוב.' זה מלמד שצפה הקב"ה באורו של משיח ובמעשיו קודם שנברא העולם וגנזו למשיח ולדורו תחת כסא הכבוד שלו. אמר שטן לפני הקב"ה: 'רבש"ע, האור שנגנז תחת כסא הכבוד שלך, למי הוא?' א"ל: 'למי שעתיד להחזיר אותך ולהכלימך בבושת פנים.'"

"What does 'In Your light we shall see light' mean? This refers to the light of the Messiah, as it is written: 'And G-d saw the light, that it was good.' This teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, gazed at the light of the Messiah and his deeds before the world was created, and He concealed it for the Messiah and his generation under His throne of glory.

To clarify the above, the Pesikta Rabbasi (Chapter 36), brought down by the Leshem, says the light itself is not Moshiach, chas veshalom, but rather it was saved for the Moshiach as a reward for the good deeds Hashem foresaw that he would do:

What is meant by 'in Your light, we see light'? Which light is Israel waiting for? This is the light of the Messiah, as it is written, 'And G-d saw the light that it was good' (Genesis 1:4), teaching that G-d foresaw the Messiah and His deeds before the world was created, and He concealed it for the Messiah, for his generation, under His throne of glory.

These ancient sources indeed associate the original light with Moshiach, but not in the way presented in OP. The light is not Moshiach.

title: Is Shemini Atzeret supposed to have a connection to the conquest?
content:
# Is Shemini Atzeret supposed to have a connection to the conquest? ## Frage

There are parallels between entering Eretz Yisrael and shemini atzeret.

The Jewish people lives in tents, surrounded by clouds of glory. Then they circled Jericho seven times, and then sacked the city and acquired land for Israel.

Sukkot commemorates the booths/clouds, contains seven days of circling, and on shemini atzeret we read about Joshua, who conquered Jericho. Furthermore, 70 animals are offered on Succot "on behalf" of the nations and then SA is for the Jews relationship with God.

Is commemorating the conquest of Eretz Yisrael an official part of Shemini Atzeret or are these parallels not recognized?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

Like @dude in his comment I have not heard or read any comment or opinion from any respected source that makes this connection. While this is not a proof that there is no connection it points strongly in that direction.

So I will answer by saying that commemorating the conquest of Eretz Yisrael IS NOT an official part of Shemini Atzeret and that the parallels mentioned by the OP are NOT recognized

title: Oral tradition after Rav Ashi
content:
# Oral tradition after Rav Ashi ## Frage

The Rambam in the introduction to Mishne Torah counts 40 generations from Moshe Rabeinu to Rav Ashi (compiler of the talmud) in the transmission of the oral law and lists the names of these sages.

My question is, do we have any book or authentic source that writes further the after Rav Ashi, the chain of transmission of the Oral tradition from Rabbi to student, until the time of the achronim or at least the Rishonim?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 5)

The letter of Rav Sherira Gaon lists the chain up until his time. After that came his son Rav Hai Gaon, and then came the period of the Rishonim which is very thoroughly documented.

Another fantastic resource is the introduction of the Meiri to Pirkei Avos, which is available at alhatorah.org. He gives the entire chain of transmission from Moshe Rabbeinu until the 13th century CE.

title: Did David have 33 or 37 mighty warriors?
content:
# Did David have 33 or 37 mighty warriors? ## Frage

David's special forces are recorded in 2 Samuel 23:8-38 and 1 Chronicles 11:10–47.

The text divides them into "the Three", of which there are three, and "the Thirty", of which there are more than thirty.

The text explicitly states that there are 37 individuals in all, but it is unclear whether this refers to The Thirty, which may or may not contain The Three, or the combined total of both groups.

There seems to be Thirty and Three, 33.

But were there officially 33 men or 37 men?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 0)

In the shmuel section, Rashi notices the discrepancy and suggests:

Now they are not [all] listed here: I therefore say that it was unnecessary to mention Joab since he was the commander-in-chief. Regarding the others that were missing perhaps the sons of Jesse (Jashan. See above v. 32) were three or four

title: Did the Israelites defecate when eating the manna?
content:
# Did the Israelites defecate when eating the manna? ## Frage

In Exodus 16:1-36, we read that the people of Israel ate the bread from heaven which they gathered from the ground after the dew of the morning.

Because this material originated from HaShem in heaven, one could figure it must have been without impurity and therefore extremely healthy for the body.

The Israelites ate quail also, but did the consumption of manna result in any unusual effects on the body such as little to no waste production leading to defecation?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 8)

Talmud Bavli Yoma 75b assumes that the manna was entirely absorbed in the body, so that indeed the Israelites did not defecate:

״ועתה נפשנו יבשה אין כל״. אמרו: עתיד מן זה שתיפח במעיהם, כלום יש ילוד אשה שמכניס ואינו מוציא? וכשנאמרו דברים לפני רבי ישמעאל, אמר להם: אל תקרי ״אבירים״, אלא ״איברים״ — דבר שנבלע במאתים וארבעים ושמונה איברים.‏

“But now our soul is dry, there is nothing at all; we have nothing beside this manna to look to” (Numbers 11:6). They said: This manna will eventually swell in our stomachs and kill us; is there anyone born of a woman who ingests food but does not expel waste?

When these words were said before Rabbi Yishmael, he said to them: Do not read it as abirim. Rather, read it as eivarim, limbs. The manna was something that was absorbed by 248 limbs.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 6)

In Yoma 75b it says that the manna was completely absorbed. The Rashi on it says it didn't leave their intestines (they didn't defecate).

In Bamidbar Rabba 16:24 it says:

אָמַר לָהֶם הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא, בַּטּוֹבָה שֶׁהֵבֵאתִי עֲלֵיכֶם בָּהּ אַתֶּם מַכְעִיסִין, בָּאוּ לַמִּדְבָּר וְהֶאֱכַלְתִּי לָהֶם מָן אַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה, וְלֹא נִצְרַךְ אֶחָד מֵהֶם לִנְקָבָיו אוֹתָן אַרְבָּעִים שָׁנָה, אֶלָּא שֶׁאָכְלוּ אֶת הַמָּן וְהוּא נַעֲשָׂה לָהֶם בָּשָׂר

The Holy One blessed be He said to them: ‘With the benefit that I brought upon you, with that, you infuriate. They came to the wilderness and I fed them manna for forty years, and not one of them needed to relieve himself for those forty years. Rather, they ate the manna and it became flesh for them.

title: Is honey good or bad for kids?
content:
# Is honey good or bad for kids? ## Frage

The Rambam (Deut. 4:12) says הַדְּבַשׁ וְהַיַּיִן רַע לַקְּטַנִּים, honey and wine are bad for kids.

The Rashi on Yevamot 75b says לחם יפה לבחורים ושמן לזקנים ודבש לתינוקות, bread is good for the young men, oil for the elders and honey for the children.

Is honey good for kids or not?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

Although Rashi says that honey is good for kids the simple reading of the Gemara is that the Manna tasted like honey for the kids.

It is interesting to note that the Eitz Yosef on Shemos Rabba, has a slightly different Nusach than the Gemara.

אלא שהמן טעמו הטבעי טעם לחם היו לבחורים. וטעם דבש לזקנים. וטעם שמן לתינוקות

Tosefta Sota Chapter 4:1 also seems to say that for the kids it was like oil.

לשד השמן כיוצא מן הדד [שמן] מה דד זה עיקר לתינוק והכל טפל כך היה המן עיקר לישראל והכל טפל [להם] ד"א מה הדד [זה] אפי' תינוק יונק [הימנו] כל היום [אין מזיקו כך נעשה] המן שאפילו ישראל אוכלו כל היום כולו [אין מזיקו כך] נעשה למי שאין נחשב עליו אבל מי שנחשב עליו מתהפך בפיו לכל איזה טעם שירצה

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Doctors strongly recommend that children under the age of 1 not consume honey due to the risk of infant botulism which is very dangerous and life threatening. See here...

I'm not sure Rashi is saying precisely that it's healthy for children but that children like honey more than adults. Either way the time in which honey is dangerous for children is limited to when they are infants.

Wine and all alcohol will affect children significantly more than an adult and should be avoided as well. See here for the serious risks of giving a child alcohol...

title: Haftarah at Shabbat Minchah?
content:
# Haftarah at Shabbat Minchah? ## Frage

In the book A Voice Still Heard: The Sacred Songs of the Ashkenazic Jews by Professor Eric Werner, I found this passage that does not match usual practice as I have seen it or as any of my siddurim have printed:

The close organic intertwining — indeed the inseparability of musical and liturgical traditions in minhag ashkenaz — may be demonstrated with one telling instance: in the minhah service of the Sabbath there is a special passage called the kedusha de-sidra (beginning with the Words "u-va le-tziyon go'el" [a redeemer shall come to Zion] and continuing with a number of scriptural verses). According to a Gaonic principle this kedusha de-sidra was to be sung to a melody used by students when reciting the sidrah (Torah lesson). Elsewhere, in a rarely observed decree, R. Saadyah Gaon had listed all those scriptural verses in which the community is expected to join the reader of the lesson. Among the verses listed are those quoted in the kedusha de-sidra[15]. This is probably related to the fact that in the Sabbath minhah of minhag ashkenaz the cantillation of the Haftarah (Prophetic lesson) dominates the chant of the entire service. If this conjecture is valid, it should apply also to passages from the liturgy of public fast days, which surround the nucleus Exodus 34:6-7, 32:11-14, 34:1-10. On those days, following Saadyah Gaon's prescribed list, Exodus 32:13 and 34:6 are chanted by the entire congregation. When we turn to the actual chant (example 3) we discover that it is a direct derivative from the cantillation of the Prophetic lesson. There is also an additional prayer for these fast days (example 4), inserted into the thirteenth benediction of the Amidah, which is chanted in the same mode as the Sabbath minhah service. 15. Teshubot ha-Ge'onim, ed. Harkavy (Berlin, 1887), no. 308, Hebrew text, p. 310. See also Rashi, in Likkute ha-pardes (Polna, 1813), p. 9, and Geonica (op. cit.), where one reads: בטעמן שהתינוקות קורין לפני רבן

What is bothering me about the logic of this passage is "in the Sabbath minhah of minhag ashkenaz the cantillation of the Haftarah (Prophetic lesson) dominates the chant of the entire service." I have never heard a Haftarah recited on Sabbath afternoon, or on any afternoon except for fast days. I am familiar with the new week's Torah reading at minhah, the transplanting of kedusha de-sidra from the morning to the afternoon, but it has not been the practice anywhere I have been to read a Haftarah at this point. I am not at all clear which Haftarah one would choose either. No siddurim I have checked mention a Haftarah here (for example Artscroll p. 512). I don't think this professor dreamed this occurance up, but I would be equally surprised if this was a custom that used to be done and has seemingly disappeared. Can anyone explain it?

title: What happened to a Hebrew slave
content:
# What happened to a Hebrew slave ## Frage

When a Hebrew slave sold themselves into slavery did they have to sell everything they owned or anything else?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 2)

A hebrew slave is not allowed to sell himself unless he is extremely poorand owns literally nothing. As such a Jewish person who still owns assets wouldn't be able to sell oneself. We're he to sell those assets, than he would still have money and would still not be allowed to sell himself.

See rambam in slaves 1:1

וְאֵין אָדָם רַשַּׁאי לִמְכֹּר אֶת עַצְמוֹ עַד שֶׁלֹּא יִשָּׁאֵר לוֹ כְּלוּם וַאֲפִלּוּ כְּסוּת לֹא תִּשָּׁאֵר לוֹ וְאַחַר כָּךְ יִמְכֹּר אֶת עַצְמוֹ

A person is not permitted to sell himself unless he has no property remaining at all - i.e., even his clothing no longer remains. Only in such a situation may he sell himself.

title: In what way do שחוק and קלות ראש bring to ערוה?
content:
# In what way do שחוק and קלות ראש bring to ערוה? ## Frage

In Kitzur Shulchan Oruch, 29:6, we learn about the middos that a person should keep to. One of them is:

Schok and kallus rosh bring a person to erva.

This is directed by the Kitzur Shulchan Oruch to regular people, in regular situations - nothing to do with interactions with women.

  1. What classifies as "kallus rosh"?
  2. Whatever the answer might be, how the heck does that equal erva? Nothing to do with women!!

(Possible source for question 1:
Shulchan Oruch in Hilchos Nida, YD 195:1 says, one of the harchokos is that it is ossur to have schok and kallus rosh. The Shach (loc sit) explains: "Devorim hamargilim le'erva".
Now, there at least I can attempt to understand the connection to erva, being that a person has a strong relationship with his wife and during the days of tumah he is suppressing himself, some sort of lightheaded conduct might bring him to erva. But... how would that translate to a case where no women are involved..?!)

Even worse, the poskim there (YD 195:1) talk about all sorts of innocuous games like chess and ping-pong as examples of kallus rosh. I just thought that they are ignoring the explicit shach, who specifies "Devorim hamargilim le'erva". But now I see the shach is not qualifying which type of kallus rosh. The shach is just bringing the words of chazal, that ALL kallus rosh brings to erva.

So bizarrely it would appear that if you join the dots, all these poskim would say that two friends playing chess are engaged in "kallus rosh", which ultimately will bring them both to erva!!

How on earth do you explain this?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

Executive Summary:

  • שְׂחוֹק - being focused on non-productive activities,
  • וְקַלּוּת רֹאשׁ - or letting one's mind be filled with opinions without filtering the input,
  • מַרְגִּילִין לְעֶרְוָה - primes one to become more open to anti-Torah behavior.

The source of this "suggestion" of the Kitzur is in Avos 3:13:

רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אוֹמֵר, שְׂחוֹק וְקַלּוּת רֹאשׁ, מַרְגִּילִין לְעֶרְוָה.‏

Before explaining what the words mean, let's use the approach of the דרך החיים to this Mishna, by looking at the previous Mishna:

רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר, הֱוֵי קַל לְרֹאשׁ

Here רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל is teaching us that when dealing with a "senior" - a רֹאשׁ - one should be easygoing, and open-minded when hearing their opinions. So קַל לְרֹאשׁ and קַלּוּת רֹאשׁ seem to mean allowing one's opinions to be influenced without critically analyzing their worth or truth.

That's a good thing when dealing with a Torah personality. Otherwise it's highly troublesome.

This is confirmed by the מסילת ישירים in Ch. 5 who explains that the opposite of זְּהִירוּת - controlling and being aware of one's thoughts - is קלות ראש which leads to שחוק and is a slippery slope which, when left unchecked, leads to promiscuity.

As an added bonus we can use definitions of the Jastrow kindly provided by Sefaria in our Mishna. Picking and choosing:

  • שְׂחוֹק: laughter, sport, jest ... the sport here mentioned means idolatry, debauchery, and bloodshed.
  • קַלּוּת רֹאשׁ: light-mindedness, irreverence, disregard of custom.
  • מַרְגִּילִין: to accustom one’s self, get used to, to bring about; cause.
  • עֶרְוָה: nakedness, shame; unchastity, lewdness, obscenity.

So, putting all the above together the Kitzur or the Mishna seem to say:

  • שְׂחוֹק - being focused on non-productive activities,
  • וְקַלּוּת רֹאשׁ - or letting one's mind be filled with opinions without filtering the input,
  • מַרְגִּילִין לְעֶרְוָה - primes one to become more open to anti-Torah behavior.

Clearly, this is individual.

If you play chess to sharpen your analytical skills, that will help in your Talmud studies.
If you play chess as an excuse to be in a smoke-filled room with anti-Torah banter, the next step is to be invited to a backroom for some sinful behavior.

If you play ping-pong as an elegant way to stay fit and improve your focus, that's going to help you become a better Jew.
If you play ping-pong as a way to impress young ladies, then מַרְגִּילִין לְעֶרְוָה is a good description of your next move.

A similar approach can be made for using the internet:
If you use the internet for quick access to seemingly unlimited access to quality Torah, that's commendable.
But if you use the internet for quick access to free entertainment - שְׂחוֹק - or for accessing opinions of people who do not need to account for their behavior nor source their opinions - קַלּוּת רֹאשׁ - then you're inching closer to ruining your life, as it says: מַרְגִּילִין לְעֶרְוָה

And this is why the Kitzur uses רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא as a support for the previous admonition:

לֹא יְהֵא אָדָם בַּעַל שְׂחוֹק וּמַהֲתָלוֹת, וְלֹא עָצֵב וְאוֹנֵן אֶלָּא שָׂמֵחַ.‏

A person should not be a jokester nor a prankster, nor sad and mournful; just be happy.

Being a jokester or a prankster means you and your audience are being distracted from focusing on important things in life.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

Yes, we are living in times where we cannot see how devastating playing chess is, to our neshama, due to yeridat hadorot.

Imagine a brand new, white garment: spotless and pristine. Even a single tiny stain on it is glaring and devastating. Now compare that to a garment already covered in mud and grime. Adding another smudge doesn't make much of a difference—it’s already dirty.

The Lubavitcher Rebbe, in a sicha (I can't remember which, he has decades of sichot), he paints a clear picture. The dor hamidbar were on such a holy level, that the idea of them speaking lashon hara in the way we do nowadays with slander, insults, and slurs, is unthinkable.

So, when the Torah talks about the punishment for these people for speaking Lashon Hara (tzara'at, "leprosy"), the Torah says "when a man {adam} has a discoloration on his skin he will be brought to the Aharon the Cohen... [Vayikra 13:2]". The Rebbe points out that it uses the word "adam", which is indeed the highest complement Torah gives to man, describing him as a Godly being, similar (adame) to God. Such a being would never be nasty like this.

The Rebbe concludes that the "sin" of Lashon Hara at the time of the dor hamidbar was for making frivolous speech. Nothing more. Not even a joke, just talking about empty, mundane matters. That's when they were given the "reward" of tzara'at - an early warning sign that you are engaging in an activity that makes a small stain on your pristine soul. Keep up this activity and soon your whole soul will be black.

  1. First you discuss empty matters.
  2. Then you make jokes about empty matters.
  3. Then you make jokes about holy matters.
  4. Then holy matters become a joke to you.
  5. Next thing you know, you are speaking nasty Lashon Hara so regularly that the Chafetz Chaim foundation needs to start a movement to simply get you to keep the most basic halachot of not being nasty in your speech about your fellow Jew.
  6. (and onward up to 365) All sins become permissable.

The Torah cares about you too much to lie to you. Even though playing chess is only 1 or 2 on the ladder, it is a wrong ladder, every rung taking you one step closer to a nasty place, leaving more and more muck on your boot, your hands, your clothes. The Torah cares about you too much to say "it's ok to climb on steps 1 or 2 of the ladder, just don't go to steps 3 or 4 or 5".

Any steps on a filthy ladder is a sin to your pristine soul. Hashem doesn't let. The only reason contemporary halacha, and eitza from Rabbonim is permissive and allows us to play chess in moderation is because of rachmanut and acknowledgement of the reality of yeridat hadorot; we are already way above rung 5 on the ladder, and it's exhausting us. It's exhausting to be so filthy, and so disconnected from the true holiness inherent in our soul. It's a provision, a lesser-of-two-evils, a bedi'eved heter.

Let them at least play chess a bit, to help them find the strength to work on climbing down the ladder.

When we get lower, we will not find it so ridiculous - such a joke - that chess is an issue. We might actually start to agree with Hashem at that point*. May Moshiach come and teach us these amazing holy realities bimhera beyamenu. Until then play chess, in moderation, and think thoughts of Teshuva if you can.

tl;dr Any sin becomes possible, including the extreme sins of arayot, once we climb the ladder of letzanut high enough, and every frivolity is a rung on this same ladder. We are just so high on that ladder in today's generation that we can't relate to that, but we must trust the wise words of the Torah, and try to climb down the ladder one step at a time.

* In this video, the Rabbi says a phrase about cell (mobile) phones that stuck with me: "we get to the point of dependence on our phone for dopamine, that we can be literally sitting with our family, the people we love most in the world, but we have to pull out our phone because it's not enough dopamine."... When stated so starkly, it's impossible to not realise that yes, we do have an issue. Why do we need chess? Surely there are much more fulfilling things to do with our precious time on earth... It may be hard to relate to, but it's not a joke. It's quite sad actually. Have rachmanus on your soul.

title: Why are there no occurrences of חיסורי מחסרא in the non-talmudic Tractates?
content:
# Why are there no occurrences of חיסורי מחסרא in the non-talmudic Tractates? ## Frage

The Talmud occasionally utilises a Method of Last Resort called "חיסורי מחסרא", essentially "insert words here", to explain away a blatant incongruency or inherent difficulty in reading a Mishna (for example; a non sequitur, a contradiction from one sentence to the next, or a counterproof that undermines the statement that it is intended to prove).

This insertion often drastically changes the simple meaning of the mishna.

The Talmud that is extant covers 37 of 63 Mishnaic tractates, and yet somehow, from the remaining 26, the Mishnaic commentators were not required to resort to the principle of חיסורי מחסרא to explain any discrepancies.

Is this a massive coincidence? Or did רבי יהודה הנשיא somehow foresee the loss of the missing talmudic tractates, and word the mishnayot accordingly?

title: Does the Torah imply that the heart leads to sin more than the eyes?
content:
# Does the Torah imply that the heart leads to sin more than the eyes? ## Frage

The third paragraph of the Shema taken from Numbers 15:39 states,

וְהָיָ֣ה לָכֶם֮ לְצִיצִת֒ וּרְאִיתֶ֣ם אֹת֗וֹ וּזְכַרְתֶּם֙ אֶת־כׇּל־מִצְוֺ֣ת יְהֹוָ֔ה וַעֲשִׂיתֶ֖ם אֹתָ֑ם וְלֹֽא־תָת֜וּרוּ אַחֲרֵ֤י לְבַבְכֶם֙ וְאַחֲרֵ֣י עֵֽינֵיכֶ֔ם אֲשֶׁר־אַתֶּ֥ם זֹנִ֖ים אַחֲרֵיהֶֽם׃

That shall be your fringe; look at it and recall all the commandments of יהוה and observe them, so that you do not follow your heart and eyes in your lustful urge.

From the order of the words it seems that the Torah is implying that one is more likely to stray after his heart than his eyes. Is this really true? It seems to me, from Svara and personal experience, that the initiator to do an aveira is the eyes and the urge is carried through with the heart, so shouldn’t it be the other way around. I.e do not follow your eyes and heart in your lustful urge

Does anyone know of any Rishonim or Achronim that discuss this question or similar from another context?

Thank you

title: Does a Synagogue or Beit Midrash's Year-Round Illumination of an Electric Menorah Detract from פרסומי ניסא?
content:
# Does a Synagogue or Beit Midrash's Year-Round Illumination of an Electric Menorah Detract from פרסומי ניסא? ## Frage

I have seen synagogues or batei midrashot that have an electric menorah on all year-round. Sometimes it is outside of the building and sometimes it's on the inside. All eight lamps are on. The menorah is not fashioned with seven lamps (in which case it would resemble the Menorah of the Mishkan, etc.), but with 8 a la Chanukah.

I realize that these institutions are not in any way trying to fulfill a Chanukah duty (nor am I suggesting that the use of electric bulbs fulfills such an obligation). Does this constant illumination detract from פרסומי ניסא? If a Chanukiah is illuminated perennially, doesn't this diminish the once-a-year lighting's ability to call attention to a specific historical miracle?

(There is precedent BTW for stopping an activity a day before in order to allow a Mitzva to stand out - not blowing the shofar on erev Rosh Hashanah and not eating Matza on erev Pesach. All the more reason to create some space in the case of פרסומי ניסא.)

title: Scroll of Antiochus vs. Books of Maccabees
content:
# Scroll of Antiochus vs. Books of Maccabees ## Frage

According to Wikipedia, Megillas Antiochus (the Scroll of Antiochus) is unrelated to the Books of Maccabees except for the fact that it cites some quotations which are contained in 1 and 2 Maccabees, and it also describes the same events which are described in 1 and 2 Maccabees. What are the reasons for such a conclusion about the relation between Megilas Antiochus and the 1st and 2nd Books of Maccabees?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

If you follow the footnote at the end of Wikipedia's statement, you'll reach the JVL's entry on the Scroll of Antiochus, which features a pretty standard description of the text and its development. The entry describes the mainstream view on the creation of the text.1

One can gather from the JVL's entry that the Books of Maccabees and the Scroll of Antiochus are unrelated for the following reasons:

  • Language: 1-2 Maccabees as we have them are written in Greek, while the scroll in Aramaic. Many believe that 1 Maccabees was originally written in Hebrew (but 2 Maccabees was indeed originally written in Greek). Either way, the three books do not share the same base language.
  • Dating: 1-2 Maccabees, as indicated both by the books themselves and by later authors who cited them (e.g. Josephus), as well as modern studies of the works, are believed to have been authored by people who lived in the time of the Maccabees/Chashmonaim, while the scroll, as indicated both by its mention of the destruction of the Mikdash and its usage of Western Middle Aramaic, as well as various traditions regarding its origins, is believed to have been authored by a person who lived ca. the 2nd-5th centuries CE (centuries after the time of the Chashmonaim).
  • Familiarity with historical circumstances: Both books of Maccabees describe in detail various historic events that led to the Maccabean Revolt and the Jewish war against the Seleucids. The scroll, on the other hand, makes a small mention of Antiochus's megalomaniacal fantasies of conquering the whole world and quickly moves on to describing the defilement of the Mikdash and the killing of the Seleucid general Nicanor. According to the JVL, this indicates the author's ignorance of the real events that led to the revolt.
  • Nicanor: Both Maccabees and the scroll describe the killing of the Seleucid general Nicanor. But according to the JVL, the scroll's description followed the spirit of how the event was remembered by later generations, as the event that brought on the celebration of Yom Nicanor (13th of Adar; the Fast of Esther is a Geonic custom). 1-2 Maccabees, on the other hand, describe it from the POV of contemporaries or near-contemporaries, before the day became a longstanding traditional celebration.
  • The Miracle of the Oil: 1-2 Maccabees do not mention the miracle of the oil at all, while the scroll follows the known talmudic tradition that states that Chanukah was/is celebrated for 8 days because of that miracle.

In short, though all three texts describe the same events, they were authored by different individuals, who lived in different periods, had different backgrounds and held different points of view and different interests. For these reasons, they should be considered unrelated.

1 For other views, see here and other sources cited there; and here for another view.

title: 2 Rosh Hashonos on Tuesday in a row
content:
# 2 Rosh Hashonos on Tuesday in a row ## Frage

I have been making tables to better understand the Hebrew calendar. Here is a picture:

מלא = מ, כסדרן = כ, חסר = ח, שנה פשוטה = פ, שנה מעוברת = ע

The numbers represent the days of the week upon which Rosh Chodesh falls.

I initially used all possible iterations, and then deleted those that caused the following Rosh Hashono to fall on Sunday, Wednesday, and Friday.

I checked Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Days_of_week_on_Hebrew_calendar) to see if this was correct, and discovered there cannot be two Rosh Hashonos in a row that fall on Tuesdays, despite this being theoretically possible in a leap year in which both Cheshvon and Kisleiv have 30 days (מ״ע).

Therefore, my question is: Why can there not be two consecutive Rosh Hashonos that fall on Tuesday?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

During the thirteen months of a leap year, there are 54 weeks 5 days 21 hours 589 chalakim from the molad of Tishri at the start of the year to the molad of Tishri at the start of the next year.

Ignoring full weeks, the molad therefore shifts by 5 days 21 hours 589 chalakim from the beginning to the end of the leap year.

For a leap year to start on a Tuesday, the molad at the start of the year must fall between 6pm Monday and 6pm Tuesday. Any earlier means that Rosh HaShanah is Monday; any later and it’s Thursday.

But this means that the following year the molad must fall between Sunday 3pm and 529 chalakim and Monday 3pm and 529 chalakim. So the following year’s Rosh HaShanah must fall on Monday.

title: Where is the Rambam's source in Hilchot Melachim Umilhamoteyhem 5 that a defensive war is a milchemet mitzvah?
content:
# Where is the Rambam's source in Hilchot Melachim Umilhamoteyhem 5 that a defensive war is a milchemet mitzvah? ## Frage

"אֵין הַמֶּלֶךְ נִלְחָם תְּחִלָּה אֶלָּא מִלְחֶמֶת מִצְוָה. וְאֵי זוֹ הִיא מִלְחֶמֶת מִצְוָה זוֹ מִלְחֶמֶת שִׁבְעָה עֲמָמִים. וּמִלְחֶמֶת עֲמָלֵק. וְעֶזְרַת יִשְׂרָאֵל מִיַּד צָר שֶׁבָּא עֲלֵיהֶם. וְאַחַר כָּךְ נִלְחָם בְּמִלְחֶמֶת הָרְשׁוּת וְהִיא הַמִּלְחָמָה שֶׁנִּלְחָם עִם שְׁאָר הָעַמִּים כְּדֵי לְהַרְחִיב גְּבוּל יִשְׂרָאֵל וּלְהַרְבּוֹת בִּגְדֻלָּתוֹ וְשִׁמְעוֹ:
A king should not wage other wars before a milchemet mitzvah. What is considered as milchemet mitzvah? The war against the seven nations who occupied Eretz Yisrael, the war against Amalek, and a war fought to assist Israel from an enemy which attacks them. Afterwards, he may wage a milchemet hareshut, i.e. a war fought with other nations in order to expand the borders of Israel or magnify its greatness and reputation."

What is the source that a war to assist Israel from an enemy which attacks them (i.e. a defensive war) is a milchemet mitzvah? Is there one, beyond the simple reasoning/first principles thinking that it's not a milchemet hareshut (discretionary war) if it's to fight off an enemy that is attacking?

title: “Worship” in Judaism?
content:
# “Worship” in Judaism? ## Frage

I wanted to know if the term “worship” has any special significance in Judaism or not and why, for instance, in the Orthodox Jewish Bible the word for “bow down” is selectively translated as “worship” when it is applied to God / a god / an idol, but literally as “bow down” when applied towards men. For example:

Shemot 18:7

And Moshe went out to meet his khoten, bowed low (וַיִּשְׁתַּ֙חוּ֙), and kissed him; and they asked each other of their shalom (welfare); and they came into the ohel.

Compared with Shmuel Alef 15:31

So Shmuel turned back after Sha’ul; and Sha’ul worshiped (וַיִּשְׁתַּ֥חוּ) Hashem.

Is this purely a convention common in English translations of scripture, or is it understood that the act of bowing down when directed towards God is a fundamentally distinct action from bowing down towards men? And if the latter, why then does scripture use the same word for men to begin with? Is there perhaps a more reliable translation that you’d recommend than the OJB?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

This question might need an expert in etymology to answer. Either way Shalom is right that that word means "bow", not worship, and עבד / פלח would be more commonly translated as "worship" in more authentic translations.

But maybe there is no specific translation of this english word into Lashon Hakodesh, in the same way that there is no english word for the german word "zeitgeist".

So, we should just look at how it is used in english. You'll note three predominant uses of the word in this google definition:

  1. the feeling or expression of reverence and adoration for a deity.
  2. religious rites or ceremonies, constituting a formal expression of reverence for a deity.
  3. great admiration or devotion shown towards a person or principle.

Do we have any of those in Hebrew? Yes, all of the above is very true of Torah worship.

  1. We feel love and fear of Hashem
  2. We serve Hashem through Mitzvot (i.e. Avodah - service - including bowing when appropriate)
  3. We also strive to have a personal admiration and devotion to Hashem

For 3, consider this. In english, when a man "worships" a woman, what does that mean? It means that he thinks she is absolutely perfect in every way. He can't see her flaws. As a result he admires her and is utterly devoted to her.

In Torah, Hashem is described as perfect. It's not just a theological technicality of Divine shelemut, but I heard my Rav say we should also understand it on this personal level too. We just think Hashem is absolutely perfect, flawless, and we wouldn't want anyone else. We absolutely worship Him!

title: The b'rachah on sardines in tomato sauce

# The b'rachah on sardines in tomato sauce ## Frage

Which brachah should you say before eating a can of sardines in tomato sauce, and why?

The sardines taste good, but the tomato sauce tastes good too.

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

A.) The ikar here is definitely the fish. This is clear even from the name of the product. You're not eating sardine-flavored tomato sauce: you're eating sardines which are pleasantly complemented by the tomato sauce.

B.) Although there is an argument that you could make ha'adama on tomato sauce, most people make shehakol.

Conclusion: the blessing is shehakol

Considering A.) and B.) above, the bracha on sardines in tomato sauce is definitely shehakol.

title: Why for Samson are Nazarite Prohibition(s) Framed in Terms of Tumah?
content:
# Why for Samson are Nazarite Prohibition(s) Framed in Terms of Tumah? ## Frage

(Rambam, Laws of Nezirut, 3:13)

שִׁמְשׁוֹן לֹא הָיָה נָזִיר גָּמוּר. שֶׁהֲרֵי לֹא נָדַר בְּנָזִיר אֶלָּא הַמַּלְאָךְ הִפְרִישׁוֹ מִן הַטֻּמְאָה. וְכֵיצַד הָיָה דִּינוֹ. הָיָה אָסוּר בְּיַיִן וְאָסוּר בְּתִגְלַחַת וּמֻתָּר לְהִטָּמֵא לַמֵּתִים. וְדָבָר זֶה הֲלָכָה מִפִּי הַקַּבָּלָה:

"Samson was not a nazirite in a complete sense, for he never took a nazirite vow. It was merely that the angel caused him to be separated from impurity. What were the laws applying to him? He was forbidden to drink wine and cut his hair. He was, however, permitted to incur impurity due to contact with the dead. This concept is a halachah transmitted by the Oral Tradition."

Question - to make the point that the angel separated him … why not just say אֶלָּא הַמַּלְאָךְ הִפְרִישׁוֹ period. Or אֶלָּא הַמַּלְאָךְ הִפְרִישׁוֹ מן הדברים האסורים לנזיר. What's this business about טומאה?

The Rambam doesn't mean normative טומאה. Shimshon, per Chazal, was permitted tumas hameis. And the pasuk in his story that refers to 'Tumah' וְאַל־תֹּאכְלִ֖י כָּל־טָמֵֽא per Chazal was a prohibition directed at eating grapes and grape products - the things that he could not eat. It was not a reference to the prohibition of drinking wine or shaving. Drinking and shaving do not use the word Tumah - וְאַל־תִּשְׁתִּ֖י יַ֣יִן וְשֵׁכָ֑ר

Yet the Rambam makes no mention of the one activity that the pasuk uses the word Tumah for - eating - in this הַמַּלְאָךְ הִפְרִישׁוֹ מִן הַטֻּמְאָה law!

Rambam seems to see Tumah as a broad concept which encompasses everything that Shimshon could not do … seems to cover hair and eating prohibited grape products (even though he does not discuss this) and drinking wine. But how are any of these activities - Tumah?

You might say that since the pasuk labels one (eating grape products) of the objects of these prohibited Shimshon activities as tamei, the Rambam saw fit to utilize the same term to cover several activities (although for some reason he left the main one out - eating). But this logic simply begs the question. Why did the Pasuk in Shoftim choose the word - טמא - for prohibited eating when the Torah in Nasa uses no such word for eating (see below)?

The whole idea seems counterintuitive. The elephant in the room. The normative Tumah that we are used to seeing isn't a problem for Shimshon, but somehow - via the pasuk narrowly (eating) and the Rambam more broadly (drinking and hair and eating (although he makes no mention of eating))- frame all this as 'Tumah.' Misnomer? What gives?

In Parshat Nasa the Nazir prohibitions of eating and drinking and shaving are NOT framed in terms of Tumah:

מִיַּ֤יִן וְשֵׁכָר֙ יַזִּ֔יר חֹ֥מֶץ יַ֛יִן וְחֹ֥מֶץ שֵׁכָ֖ר לֹ֣א יִשְׁתֶּ֑ה וְכׇל־מִשְׁרַ֤ת עֲנָבִים֙ לֹ֣א יִשְׁתֶּ֔ה וַעֲנָבִ֛ים לַחִ֥ים וִיבֵשִׁ֖ים לֹ֥א יֹאכֵֽל׃ they shall abstain from wine and any other intoxicant; they shall not drink vinegar of wine or of any other intoxicant, neither shall they drink anything in which grapes have been steeped, nor eat grapes fresh or dried.

כׇּל־יְמֵי֙ נֶ֣דֶר נִזְר֔וֹ תַּ֖עַר לֹא־יַעֲבֹ֣ר עַל־רֹאשׁ֑וֹ עַד־מְלֹ֨את הַיָּמִ֜ם אֲשֶׁר־יַזִּ֤יר לַיהֹוָה֙ קָדֹ֣שׁ יִהְיֶ֔ה גַּדֵּ֥ל פֶּ֖רַע שְׂעַ֥ר רֹאשֽׁוֹ׃ Throughout the term of their vow as nazirite, no razor shall touch their head; it shall remain consecrated until the completion of their term as nazirite of יהוה, the hair of their head being left to grow untrimmed.

Only when we get to actual Tumas Meit do we see:

לְאָבִ֣יו וּלְאִמּ֗וֹ לְאָחִיו֙ וּלְאַ֣חֹת֔וֹ לֹא־יִטַּמָּ֥א לָהֶ֖ם בְּמֹתָ֑ם כִּ֛י נֵ֥זֶר אֱלֹהָ֖יו עַל־רֹאשֽׁוֹ׃ Even if their father or mother, or their brother or sister should die, they must not become defiled for any of them, since hair set apart for their God is upon their head:

*But,for Shimshon, as discussed, the proscription(s) are characterized as הִפְרִישׁוֹ מִן הַטֻּמְאָה ... why?

I am beginning to suspect that the Rambam's הַמַּלְאָךְ הִפְרִישׁוֹ מִן הַטֻּמְאָה might go beyond drinking wine and eating grapes and shaving ... it may even mean that God wanted Shimshon to see many things in terms of Tumah or Tahara and thus avoid Plishti women and saving himself with a jawbone for that very reason:

Sota 9b: ״וַיִּבְקַע אֱלֹהִים אֶת הַמַּכְתֵּשׁ אֲשֶׁר בַּלֶּחִי״. אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק דְּבֵי רַבִּי אַמֵּי: הוּא אִיוָּה לְדָבָר טָמֵא — לְפִיכָךְ נִתְלוּ חַיָּיו בְּדָבָר טָמֵא. After Samson smote one thousand Philistines with the jawbone of a donkey, he called the place Lehi, and God miraculously granted him to drink, as he was dying of thirst. The verse states: “But God cleaved the hollow place that is in Lehi, and out of there came water; and when he had drunk, his spirit came back, and he revived” (Judges 15:19). Rabbi Yitzḥak of the school of Rabbi Ami says: He desired something unclean, as he was driven by lust to Philistine women. Therefore, the saving of his life was dependent on something unclean, the jawbone of a donkey.

=======

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

But we do find in Nasso that if he becomes tamei, it says ki tamei nizro. His status has been contaminated. (Neizer is a personal status that is actually somewhere between a gavra and a cheftza -- or even "the gavra is the cheftza.") So here, though the prohibition on touching corpses is lifted (for obvious reasons), the angel is making clear it is not a "half-price" or "less-than" nezirus.

title: Because Samson did not Drink, Every Strange act that he did was Imputed to a Higher Purpose?
content:
# Because Samson did not Drink, Every Strange act that he did was Imputed to a Higher Purpose? ## Frage

Abarbanel in Chapter 13 of Judges:

וגם לסבה אחרת והיא לפי שהיה גלוי לפניו הדברים הזרים שהיה עתיד שמשון לעשותו, רצה יתברך שלא יחשוב אדם שיהיו מעשה שכרות, "and also for another reason (was Samson prohibited to drink) ... it was revealed before God the strange acts that Samson was going to perform, and God wanted that no one should think these acts were due to intoxication .. . ."

Who cares if Shimshon accomplished everything that he did, but people thought he was a drunkard? You mean to say that people did not think he was off and going berserk because he didn't drink? But the acts were strange and there's millions of reasons for people to say things. You mean that if I don't have an external thing - alcohol - to pin his actions on, I'm going to impute every strange and raging act of his to God?

title: How Did the the story of the Miracle of Hanukkah arise? 2 Macc. 10
content:
# How Did the the story of the Miracle of Hanukkah arise? 2 Macc. 10 ## Frage

Jews have long marked the day by lighting candles for each of the days that the holy oil for the Temple menorah miraculously lasted. Yet the scriptural account of event (accepted as an inspired text by Catholics but not by Jews or Protestants) does not mention the miracle of the oil.

1 When Maccabeus and his companions, under the Lord’s leadership, had recovered the temple and the city, 2 they destroyed the altars erected by the foreigners in the marketplace and the sacred shrines. 3 After purifying the temple, they made another altar. Then, with fire struck from flint, they offered sacrifice for the first time in two years, burned incense, and lighted lamps... 5 On the anniversary of the day on which the temple had been profaned by the foreigners, that is, the twenty-fifth of the same month Kislev, the purification of the temple took place. 6 The Jews celebrated joyfully for eight days as on the feast of Booths...7 Carrying rods entwined with leaves, beautiful branches and palms, they sang hymns of grateful praise to him who had successfully brought about the purification of his own place. 8 By public decree and vote they prescribed that the whole Jewish nation should celebrate these days every year.

Question: how did this account evolve into the tradition that God caused the holy oil (enough for one day only) to last for eight days?

title: Is one after the fact Yotze if they lit Chanukah candles right to left?
content:
# Is one after the fact Yotze if they lit Chanukah candles right to left? ## Frage

It seems that the common practice is to do from left to right, but what is the Halacha if someone Bedieved did it the opposite way?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

One surely was yotze because, as noted by Double AA in the comments, adding candles each night is only a hiddur, but the basic halacha only calls for one candle. There is no wrong direction when only lighting one candle , so when this person lit the first candle he was יוצא.

Additionally, this person actually lit the candles correctly based on the Taz and Pri megadim on SA 676:5. This is based on the concept -כל פינות שאתה פונה פנה לימין.

See also, biur Halacha in 676, piskei teshuvot, hilchot chat bechag .

title: Saying Boruch Hamavdil before Birkas Hamazon
content:
# Saying Boruch Hamavdil before Birkas Hamazon ## Frage

One who eats Seudah Shlishis on Shabbos and before saying Birkas Hamazon they said Baruch Hamavdil Bain Kodesh L'chol, do they still say Retzei in the Birkas Hamazon?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 7)

Shulchan Aruch HaRav O"C 188:17 says that although one wouldn't say Retzeh after maariv or a proper havdalah, it's questionable whether just saying Hamavdil would fall into the same category. However, since there are opinions that hold we never say it after nightfall, it's best to skip it in this scenario:

וְאִם אָמַר "הַמַּבְדִּיל בֵּין קֹדֶשׁ לְחֹל" בִּלְבַד בְּלֹא כּוֹס, כְּמוֹ שֶׁיִּתְבָּאֵר בְּסִימָן רצ"ט – יֵשׁ לְהִסְתַּפֵּק... אִם דִּינוֹ כְּהִתְפַּלֵּל עַרְבִית. וּלְפִיכָךְ, שֵׁב וְאַל תַּעֲשֶׂה עָדִיף, שֶׁהֲרֵי יֵשׁ אוֹמְרִים שֶׁלְּעוֹלָם אֵינוֹ מַזְכִּיר שֶׁל שַׁבָּת אַחַר שֶׁיָּצָא הַיּוֹם

### ✅ Antwort 2 (Score: 4)

According to the Mishnah Berurah (188:32):

וכיון שהתחלת הסעודה היה מבעוד יום כבר נתחייב להזכיר מעין המאורע. וע"כ אפילו נמשך זמן רב בלילה לא נפקע חיובו. וכתבו האחרונים דאם התפלל מעריב קודם בהמ"ז שוב אינו מזכיר של שבת בבהמ"ז דמחזי כסתרי אהדדי:

Since the beginning of the meal was during the day, he was already obligated to mention the occasion. Therefore, even if [the meal] extended way into the night, this obligation does not leave. The Acharonim write that if he davened maariv before saying birkas hamazon, he no longer says Retzeh in birkas hamazon as it looks like a contradiction.

Based on this reasoning, the same is true if he made havdalah or any other action demonstrating that it is no longer Shabbos.

title: Should converts say the thirteenth blessing differently?
content:
# Should converts say the thirteenth blessing differently? ## Frage

The thirteenth blessing of Shemoneh Esrei states:

on the righteous converts and on ourselves -- may Your compassion be aroused, Hashem, our God;

As a convert, I find saying this odd. If the converts are being distinguished from other Jews in this blessing, why am I identifying with the latter group? Could I say a modified form of the blessing (at least in individual prayer), such as 'on ourselves and the descendants of Abraham and Sarah'?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

No, you should say it the way it is written in your siddur. The chachamim were well aware that converts would be saying this at some point and there is no reason for you to feel embarrassed.

title: Why does the Rambam seem to include this as part of what is celebrated on Chanuka
content:
# Why does the Rambam seem to include this as part of what is celebrated on Chanuka ## Frage

The Rambam Hichos Chanuka 3:1 includes as a part of the of the Chanuka story וְהוֹשִׁיעָם מִיָּדָם וְהִצִּילָם וְגָבְרוּ בְּנֵי חַשְׁמוֹנַאי הַכֹּהֲנִים הַגְּדוֹלִים וַהֲרָגוּם וְהוֹשִׁיעוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל מִיָּדָם וְהֶעֱמִידוּ מֶלֶךְ מִן הַכֹּהֲנִים וְחָזְרָה מַלְכוּת לְיִשְׂרָאֵל יֶתֶר עַל מָאתַיִם שָׁנָה עַד הַחֻרְבָּן הַשֵּׁנִי: (Hashem), delivered them from their hand, and saved them. The sons of the Hasmoneans, the High Priests, overcame [them], slew them, and saved the Jews from their hand. They appointed a king from the priests, and sovereignty returned to Israel for more than 200 years, until the destruction of the Second Temple.

He goes further in saying what the Neis Chanukaa was but the question is on the last sentence above. Firstly their appointing a Kohen as a king who was problematic.(see the Ramban Breshis 49:10) Even if the Rambam disagrees with the Ramban about that, no one disputes that the descendants of the Chasmanoim who became kings later on were not righteous people. Some of the more evil future kings like Herod were not even Jewish. Furthermore Herod wasn't even the king. He needed Roman approval for his actions (see Bava Basra 4A) Apparently killing most of the Torah scholars wasn't something Herod felt he needed Roman approval. That should give a picture of what things were like during that time period. Even without further elaboration of how Chazal describe that time period.

Why does Rambam include the subsequent period as a part of the Chanuka story? Why would secular or anti religious quasi Jewish sovereignty be something to celebrate ? The non-Jewish King Agripas had a lot better relationship with Chazal than the most of Jewish sovereignty in those 200 years (see sotah 41 A & 41B)

title: Did Moses and Joshua wipe out the Canaanite tribes or were there terms of peace
content:
# Did Moses and Joshua wipe out the Canaanite tribes or were there terms of peace ## Frage

I was confronted by an atheist who wanted to argue. His silly debate was that God loves ethnic cleansing which is false of course.

So did Moses and Joshua completely wipe out the Canaanite tribes or did they offer them a chance to leave or take up the 7 laws of Noah?

## Antworten ### ✅ Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

The Book of Judges clearly says that the Israelites allowed the natives to stay in the Holy Land:

-And the children of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites that inhabited Jerusalem; but the Jebusites dwell with the children of Benjamin in Jerusalem unto this day. [Judges 1:21]

-And Manasseh did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-Shean and her towns, nor Taanach and her towns, nor the inhabitants of Dor and her towns, nor the inhabitants of Ibleam and her towns, nor the inhabitants of Megiddo and her towns; but the Canaanites continued to live in that land. [Judges 1:27]

-And Ephraim did not drive out the Canaanites who lived in Gezer; but the Canaanites lived in Gezer among them. [Judges 1:29]

-And Zebulun did not drive out the inhabitants of Kitron, nor the inhabitants of Nahalol; but the Canaanites lived among them… [Judges 1:30]

-And Asher did not drive out the inhabitants of Acco, nor the inhabitants of Sidon, nor of Ahlab, nor of Achzib, nor of Helbah, nor of Aphik, nor of Rehob; but the sons of Asher lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land; for they did not drive them out. [Judges 1:31-2]

-And Naphtali did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth-Shemesh, nor the inhabitants of Beth-Anath; but he lived among the Canaanites, the inhabitants of the land… [Judges 1:33]

and finally:

-And the children of Israel dwelt among the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites. [Judges 3:5]

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)
  1. The Extermination of the Cannanites Moshe didn't kill any Cannanites. He died before the invasion.

Joshua explicitly permitted some Cannanites, who had fooled him, to live, as well as the family of Rahab, who betrayed Jericho.

Apart from the Gibeonites, no Cannanites decided to become Noahides and enserf themselves to the Israelites.

Joshah 11:19

There was not a city that made peace with the children of Israel, save the Hivites, the inhabitants of Gibeon; they took all in battle.

There is a midrash that the Girgashites fled Eretz Yirsoel before the conquest and God rewarded them with a place called "Afriki"

In the book of Judges we see references to Cannanite polities and failure of the various tribes to conquer them.

  1. Does God like ethnic cleansing? God would seem to dislike ethnic cleansing as we see that he wants to show mercy towards Nineveh and we have a midrash that God is upset when he drowns the Egyptians.

However, He did command the ethnic cleansing of the 7 nations and Amalek and the Midianites and so we would presume He likes it in some instances.

However, sometimes when God decrees an ethnic cleansing, He allows himself to be talked down, such as when Avraham tries to save Sodom or Moshe refuses to go along with His offer to destroy the Jews.

To conclude, Noam Chomsky is more uniformly against ethnic cleansing than God.

title: Why the plural lighting lamps in the courtyards in Al Ha-Nissim of Hanukkah
content:
# Why the plural lighting lamps in the courtyards in Al Ha-Nissim of Hanukkah ## Frage

Near the end of Al Ha-Nissim of Hanukkah we read of lighting lamps in the courtyards. If the lights refer to the menorah, why the plural "courtyards"? The menorah was in just one courtyard.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

There were multiple lamps in multiple courtyards.

Solomon added 10 menorahs, but all in the Heichal, Menachot 98b:

ואם תאמר חמשה מימין הפתח וחמשה משמאל הפתח אם כן מצינו מנורה בצפון והתורה אמרה (שמות כו, לה) ואת המנורה נכח השולחן

And if you say that the terms “right” and “left” are referring to the two sides of the entrance to the Sanctuary, this is difficult. According to this interpretation, Solomon placed five candelabra to the right of the entrance, on the north side, and five candelabra to the left of the entrance, on the south side. If so, we find that in the case of the five candelabra to the right of the entrance, the candelabrum was placed in the north of the Sanctuary. But the Torah said: “And you shall set the Table outside the Curtain, and the Candelabrum opposite the Table on the side of the Tabernacle toward the south, and you shall put the Table on the north side” (Exodus 26:35).

Also, There were golden candelabra atop poles there in the (Women's) Courtyard, Mishna Sukka 5:2:

בְּמוֹצָאֵי יוֹם טוֹב הָרִאשׁוֹן שֶׁל חָג, יָרְדוּ לְעֶזְרַת נָשִׁים, וּמְתַקְּנִין שָׁם תִּקּוּן גָּדוֹל. וּמְנוֹרוֹת שֶׁל זָהָב הָיוּ שָׁם, וְאַרְבָּעָה סְפָלִים שֶׁל זָהָב בְּרָאשֵׁיהֶן, וְאַרְבָּעָה סֻלָּמוֹת לְכָל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד, וְאַרְבָּעָה יְלָדִים מִפִּרְחֵי כְהֻנָּה וּבִידֵיהֶם כַּדִּים שֶׁל שֶׁמֶן שֶׁל מֵאָה וְעֶשְׂרִים לֹג, שֶׁהֵן מַטִּילִין לְכָל סֵפֶל וָסֵפֶל:

This was the sequence of events: At the conclusion of the first Festival day the priests and the Levites descended from the Israelites’ courtyard to the Women’s Courtyard, where they would introduce a significant repair, as the Gemara will explain. There were golden candelabra atop poles there in the courtyard. And there were four basins made of gold at the top of each candelabrum. And there were four ladders for each and every pole and there were four children from the priesthood trainees, and in their hands were pitchers with a capacity of 120 log of oil that they would pour into each and every basin.

title: Why did David measure Moab with a cord?
content:
# Why did David measure Moab with a cord? ## Frage

In 2 Samuel 8:2 David defeated Moab and "measured them off with a cord" such that 2/3rds would be killed and 1/3 allowed to live.

I would like to understand the purpose of measuring them with a cord. If the goal was to kill 2/3rds of the people, that could have been done by counting.

Standard Mikraot Gedolot commentaries I have consulted speak about degrading the Moabites, however that seems to apply to making them lie and the ground, not the use of the cord. I would like to understand why David measured them with a cord specifically.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 6)

There is a heavily midrashic explanation in the book "The Juggler and the King" by R' Aharon Feldman, ch. 14 The midpoint of the World, especially the section 14.9. The book expounds the peirush on several aggados by the Vilna Gaon. (please see the book for many additional details)

The discussion starts with the aggadeta Bechoros 8b:

They (the Elders of Athens) said to him: Build us a house in the air of the world. Rabbi Yehoshua uttered a Name of God and hovered between the sky and the earth. He said to them: Bring up to me bricks and mortar and I will build you a house here. They asked him: Where is the center of the world? Rabbi Yehoshua raised his finger and said to them: Here. They said to him: And who says that you are correct? He said to them: Bring ropes and measure.

The point here is that the existence of humans is tied to gradual recognition of G-d, as at the end of the days the world will be full of wisdom "as water cover the sea" (Yeshayahu 11:9). Gemara Sanhedrin 97a-b splits the timing of the history into 3 eras:

The school of Eliyahu taught: Six thousand years is the duration of the world. Two thousand of the six thousand years are characterized by chaos; two thousand years are characterized by Torah, from the era of the Patriarchs until the end of the mishnaic period; and two thousand years are the period of the coming of the Messiah. That is the course that history was to take, but due to our many sins, the Messiah did not come after four thousand years passed, and furthermore, the years that elapsed since then, which were to have been the messianic era, have elapsed.

Even though the Jews had not merited the Moshiyach's coming, nevertheless the Era of Moshiyach arrived at its proper time. At "the midpoint of the world" G-d began turning the wheels of history to ensure the ultimate arrival of the scion of David.

The connection to the question of the OP, comes with the help of the vision of Zechariyah 13:8-9:

Throughout the land — declares G-D — Two-thirds shall perish, shall die, and one-third of it shall survive. That third I will put into the fire, And I will smelt them as one smelts silver And test them as one tests gold. They will invoke Me by name, And I will respond to them. I will declare, “You are My people,” And they will declare, “ The ETERNAL is our G-d!”

This prophecy is a link between R' Yehoshua's idea to refute the words of the Elders of Athens and the words Sh'muel B 8:2 noted by the OP as the significant part. To quote R' Feldman from the book:

The ultimate aim of G-d's judgement is not cruelty but bringing man to recognize Him and thereby gain eternal life. The recognition of G-d, then is the essence of human life and its consummation. During the first two-thirds of world history G-d waited for men to exercise free choice, to abolish evil from their live and reach the essence. When mankind as a whole failed, that essence was denied it and the Jewish people toook on the task. When they too failed, He withheld His revelation from them; He destroyed their land and sent them into exile. But in the last third - after 4000 years from the Creation - He manipulates history so as to give quintessential life even to those who do not deserve it. Even if the Jews do not choose to seek their G-d and recognize his rulership, he will nevertheless take them by the hand and lead them to this recognition. Worthy or not, they must be redeemed, or else the ultimate aim of Creation would never be realized.

The ropes of David are the measure of human history. The two-thirds of world history which did not choose to recognize G-d's dominion refused to choose life. But the last third will be directed to the eternal life by a Providence which will lead the Jews step by step to the recognition of their G-d.

What is the basis of your assertion, asked the Elders (of Athens) that "here", in the last third of human history, G-d's mercy is at work and we are in the era of Moshiyach? Rabbi Yehoshua answered, "Remember the ropes of king David and you will learn the ways by which G-d directs His world." They teach us that G-d will never abandon His world, that ultimately the good for which G-d created it will be realized.

In other words, David, as a prototypical Moshiyach, hinted in this punishment the ultimate punishment that Hashem will bring upon the world in exact form from every person, as stated in Zechariya.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 2)

It is worthwhile mentioning that although, indeed, the מצודות translates חבל as rope, the רד"ק brings the תרגום who translates חבל as “lots” (as in יעקב חבל נחלתו), which, of course, makes his action easier to understand. As to the lying on the floor, he did that as a way to disgrace them, as a punishment for having killed his father, mother and all his brothers. The מפרשים bring מדרשים that דוד wanted to punish the Moabites for a singularly vicious and vindictive crime which they had committed. When דוד was fleeing from שאול, he had asked the Moabite king to allow דוד’s parents and brothers to remain with him and be protected by him. Mindful of his own descent from מואב through his ancestress רות, he had thought that his family would be in safe hands. The Moabite king agreed to extend his protection to דוד's family but subsequently murdered them all with the exception of one of דוד's brothers who managed to escape. דוד, then, was avenging the murder of his family.

title: Is there a way to preserve the Masoretic Text of 2 Samuel 8:17?
content:
# Is there a way to preserve the Masoretic Text of 2 Samuel 8:17? ## Frage

The Masoretic Text (MT) of 2 Samuel 8:17 reads

וְצָדוֹק בֶּן־אֲחִיטוּב וַאֲחִימֶלֶךְ בֶּן־אֶבְיָתָר כֹּהֲנִים וּשְׂרָיָה סוֹפֵר׃

However this seems to contradict both 1 Samuel 22:20 and 2 Samuel 20:25 which have Evyatar as the son of Achimelech. I have seen modern translations which simply amend the text. I have not seen any traditional commentaries which even note the discrepancy. Is there any way to explain and preserve the reading of the MT?

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 4)

As I wrote in the comments, it seems clear to me that there were two Achimelechs: The first was Achimelech ben Achituv, who was the kohen who met David at Nov when the latter was fleeing from Shaul. This Achimelech was ultimately slain by Doeg the Edomite at Shaul's command, along with the rest of the kohanim of Nov. His son was Evyatar, who joined David's side, until he was ousted by Shlomo for passing his allegiance to Adoniyahu. The second Achimelech was one of Evyatar's sons, and was very likely named after his grandfather. This interpretation was presented as clear fact by Rabbi Yitzchak Notovitz, a 19th-century expert on Gittin (for some information on him, see here). Indeed, there are other cases in Tanach, as demonstrated by Rabbi Notovitz, of biblical characters who were named after their ancestors. I would argue that since this interpretation is clear p'shat, commentators did not see any reason to comment on the issue.

title: Understanding Tzibah
content:
# Understanding Tzibah ## Frage

In 2 Samuel 9 we meet a man named Tzibah who is a servant of the house of Saul. David consults him to find out if there are any living descendants from the line of Saul.

If there were no living descendants from the line of Saul how could Tzibah be a servant of the house of Saul, there would be no house of Saul. Furthermore, it would seem that Tzibah is not in fact serving Mephiboshet (the grandson of Saul, the person in question) since Mephiboshet is in the house of Machir and it is only in v9-10 that Tzibah is instructed to serve him.

Perhaps a charitable reading would posit that Tzibah was also in the house of Machir, serving Mephiboshet and David was just 'making it official'. But that would require David and his servants to know of Tzibah, his location, but not know that Mephiboshet was alive and being served in that same location. And/or, not really giving Mephiboshet anything new, other than meals by the king. Possible, but I would prefer to find an alternative explanation.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

The Book of Shmuel, like pretty much the rest of Tanach, wasn't written in real-time (e.g., Bava Batra 15a indicates that the book was written in stages). The title "servant of the House of Shaul" either refers to Tziva having been a former servant of that clan, or the title was given later, once he was commanded by David to serve Mefiboshet. Given the fact that: a. David decided to consult him regarding possible survivors of that clan, b. Tziva knew to give a detailed answer to the question, and c. David commanded him to return to his post as servant of the clan (Shmuel 2:9:9-10), the former option is the most likely.

Regarding the issue raised in your last paragraph, Malbim on Shmuel 2:9:1 asks how could it be that David, who was the son-in-law of Shaul (through his wife Michal, daughter of Shaul) and a former member of his household, plus best friend of Yonatan, did not know who in that family was still alive. His answer is that the other members of the clan went into hiding because they feared for their lives. They were afraid that David intended to do away with the entire rival household like other ancient (and frankly, modern) kings did (and do). This explains why David knew of Tziva but not of Mefiboshet's survival. Tziva was merely a servant and not important enough to be considered a serious contender for the crown. But Mefiboshet was certainly influential enough to pose a political threat to David. Interestingly Mefiboshet was actually found to be hiding in a prominent Gadite city, Lo-Davar,1 hosted by Machir ben Amiel, who went on to become one of David's allies.2

1 Other than mentions in David's story, it was also prominent enough to be mentioned as part of the Gadite territory in Yehoshua 13:26 and as one of two prominent Transjordanian cities (re)conquered by the Kingdom of Israel, perhaps around the time of Yerov'am II. See: Amos 6:13.

2 Interestingly, knowing that Tziva didn't like serving Shaul's household, it's possible that Tziva pointedly mentioned the fact that Mefiboshet was in a key Transjordanian city because he was supposedly orchestrating a rebellion against David.

title: Impurity Av Ha-Tuma
content:
# Impurity Av Ha-Tuma ## Frage

Im not talking about today, I just want to know the law:

Lets say a mourner/sister of the deceased went to cemetery and did not take a shower, couple of days later they pour olive oil into another persons food. Is the second person now considered to be impure? In another word, did the impurity transfered from the mourner to the second person? Ty for any explanation

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 3)

To start, taking a shower or not wouldn't affect the purity of the person. Purifying someone from the impurity of the dead is a 7-day process in which ashes of a Red Heifer and going to Mikva are necessary. So, it isn't really possible in our days.

In regard to the scenario of the OP of a person who is an Av Hatuma (because he came in contact with the human of a dead person). The short answer, no, because at worst the olive oil became טמא but it cannot make the person eating it טמא because impurity within food or drinks cannot make a human טמא (Pesachim 14a).

This is from a דאוריתא standpoint. Although see Mishna Zavim 5:12 that there is a rabbinic ruling that such a person be considered impure to the extent that he is not allowed to eat תרומה וקדשים.

### Antwort 2 (Score: 0)

To understand the halacha let's review the picture presented in the Artscroll Edition of Mishnayos Ohalos 1:5. The full scope of cases is described in maseches Ohalos.

  1. The dead body AAT is defined to be avi avos hatum'ah and so is any utensil AAU which touched a dead body. The utensil requires purification of 7 days with ashes of red heifer.

  2. A person who touched either the dead body or a utensil AAU, which has already touched the dead body, becomes only av hatum'ah, AT. Similarly a utensil which touched such a person AT, or the utensil AAU (which has already touched the dead body) becomes only av hatum'ah utensil AU. Both such a person AT and the utensil AU require purification of 7 days with ashes of red heifer.

Similarly, a person carying the dead or was under the same roof with the dead, or touched a separate but sufficient portion of the dead body (and there are many distinctions regarding a portion of the dead which are not in the question of OP) also become av hatum'ah, AT, and require purification of 7 days. There can be certain leniencies depending on how a room with the dead is located in a house but they may be too technical.

One becomes AT also by being directly under the grave or above the grave, if the corps is buried in the earth and not in its own tent / box which has sufficient air inside to function as a tent.

  1. Finally, a person who touched the AT person, or the AU utensil becomes only rishon le tum'ah. Such a person needs to go to a mikveh during the same day. After the sun sets s/he becomes tahor.

Therefore, coming to the OP's question there's a distinction in the outcome.

A. If a mourner, touched a dead person, or any utensil which touched the dead person, if s/he carried the dead body or a bier, if s/he leaned above any grave at the cemetery, such a mourner is av hatum'ah, AT. If he touches the bottle with olive oil - the bottle becomes rishon l'tum'ah.

However, here's a difference regarding the bottle. If it is earthenware it becomes Av hatum'ah outside and as long as oil is inside and does not touch exterior which is hard to do, it remains pure (assuming it was tightly sealed if in the house where the corpse was). Glass bottle has the same law as an earthenware vessel (Keilim 30:1) rabbinically. If the oil touched outside it became rishon. However, a metal, wooden, or leather bottle becomes av hatum'a utensil, so that the oil inside becomes rishon letumah (Taharos 2:1 and Machshirin 6:4).

If the oil is pure, the second person who consumes the oil is pure. If the oil is rishon the second person is really sheini l'tum'ah (Taharos 2:2, halakha like R' Yehoshua), i.e.s/he does not convey tumah for chulin and maaser. For oil designated for teruma and kodesh he conveys tumah to make it shelishi l'tum'ah. His purification is the same as rishon l'tumah - in a mikveh, he becomes pure at sunset.

B. A mourner, who was not in the house with dead body, did not touch any utensil which touched the dead person, if s/he did not carry the dead body or a bier, if s/he did not lean above any grave at the cemetery. If such a person did not touch anybody who was AT - s/he remains pure so the oil is pure so that the second person is pure. If s/he touched an AT person, s/he is *rishon l'tum'ah. If such a person did not go to a mikveh, the earthenware bottle and becomes rishon outside, same for glass derabannan. If the oil did not touch outside it remains pure and otherwise it's rishon (Taharos 2:1).

Metal, wooden, or leather bottle becomes rishon through and it makes oil inside rishon (all liquids if they touch sheini, etc. assume tum'ah rishon - (Taharos 2:1).

Thus, as before, if the oil is pure, the second person remains pure. If the oil is rishon, the second person becomes sheini.

title: Mikraot Gedolot Recommendation
content:
# Mikraot Gedolot Recommendation ## Frage

I currently use Mossad HaRav Kook's Torat Chaim mikraot gedolot. The content is excellent, but the print quality and size, as well as the format, are a bit rough on the eyes. I am looking for a recommendation for a new mikraot gedolot with the following features.

  1. Clear, easy to read font and format

  2. All Hebrew

  3. Accurate

  4. No censorship (e.g. excluding Rashbam's comment in Bereshit about the day beginning in the morning rather than the evening)

  5. Not too bulky to carry (comparable to Torat Chaim)

Can anyone recommend an edition that fulfills those criteria?

Thank you.

## Antworten ### Antwort 1 (Score: 1)

I can personally recommend Bar Ilan's Mikraot Gedolot. It has everything you can ask for, and unlike Artscroll, does not have a history of censorship. Here's a description of their work:

The Mikraot Gedolot HaKeter is a project of Bar-Ilan University, based on the most accurate Bible manuscript, the Aleppo codex.

Thousands of flaws of previous editions have been corrected. It includes an apparatus called "Ein Ha-Masorah"' which makes the terminology of the Masorah readil comprehensible.

The Aramaic targumim and commentaries are based on meticulous comparison of the best extant manuscripts. It includes the most comprehensive selection of medieval commentaries, which have been printed in an easily readable Hebrew font and are clearly punctuated, securing its establishment as an indispensable study and research tool.

They recently finished the complete Tanakh, and sell a more affordable small edition of it here.

I'm attaching a couple of pictures from their edition of Yechezkel, including extra material at the back of the book.
